title: Pakistani Soldiers Died Near Long-Disputed Border
description: One day after Pakistans Army rejected an American characterization of airstrikes that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers on Saturday as accidental  calling them instead an unprovoked attack of blatant aggression  the militarys public relations wing released video of the two border posts hit in the raid.

title: Spruced Up for the Season
description: MY vision was fairly good until I bought a home. Then a sort of blindness set in. The holes I drilled in my kitchen ceiling five years ago completely disappear whenever I walk into the room. I fail to see the pockmarks in the staircase. A light switch in my office has been covered by duct tape since early 2010, or so Ive been told.

title: A Wonderland of Stage Toys
description: ON summer evenings in the 1980s, in the garden of our home in London, my little brother and I would scale the stern of the H.M.S. Bounty. We would hoist ourselves up her sides and climb her invisible rigging. From high in the crows nest we could see Tahiti on the horizon. I would be Fletcher Christian; my little brother, William Bligh. Armed with a half-dozen wooden spears, he fought valiantly against the mutinous children and the natives from down the street and across the gardens, until the sun cast the sky red-violet and we were avenged, or called in for dinner, battle-weary.

title: Jewelry Inspired by Architectural Details
description: In high school, Rebecca Schiffman was embarrassed about living on the Upper East Side, which she considered uncool. But now she embraces the neighborhood, writing a blog about it called the U.E.S. Journal, and living in the same apartment on 88th Street where she grew up.

title: The Gimme Guide
description: IT may be better to give than to receive, but it sure is getting harder.

title: Branded Garbage Cans Stay Put
description: Chad Silver, an artist, and his wife, Colu Henry, a public relations manager at Bon Apptit magazine, were having trouble with their garbage cans, which kept vanishing from outside their Williamsburg, Brooklyn, apartment. So Mr. Silver, inspired by Gucci Gucci, a song by Kreayshawn, a West Coast rapper whose lyrics cant be printed in this newspaper, decided to brand his cans with gold stickers replicating the logos of the luxury labels Gucci, Fendi and Prada.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Altered Photos and Shopping Apps
description: Fashion, beauty and entertainment magazines have been retouching photographs for decades, but picture-editing software like Adobe Photoshop makes it so quick and easy that some photos bear no resemblance to the real person. Steve Lohr, a technology reporter with The New York Times, talks about a recent article he wrote about computer scientists at Dartmouth who developed software tools that can objectively measure the amount of alterations that have been applied to photos.

description: The 2011 Designer of the Year chosen by Design Miami, the annual design fair that runs concurrently with Art Basel Miami Beach, is not just a designer. This year, the selection committee picked an architect  albeit one who works frequently with artists and art collectors.

title: In California, Asking Voters to Raise Taxes
description: LOS ANGELES  For 33 years, since the passage of Proposition 13 slashed property taxes in this state, California has been on the leading edge of the tax cut movement that has spread across the nation.

title: Illinois: Prison Sought for Blagojevich
description: Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor convicted of trying to sell or trade the Senate seat once held by President Obama, should go to prison for 15 to 20 years, federal prosecutors said in legal papers filed Wednesday. Lawyers for Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat convicted of 18 corruption-related counts, have indicated they will seek probation when a judge sentences him next week. Mr. Blagojevich is the second consecutive Illinois governor to face prison; George Ryan, his predecessor and a Republican, is serving a corruption sentence. In their filing, prosecutors wrote, On the heels of one corrupt governor and after running on a campaign to end pay-to-play, Blagojevich took office and immediately began plotting with others to use the office of the governor for his personal gain through fraud, bribery and extortion.

title: Giants Lose Umenyiora; Bradshaw May Play
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Michael Strahan visited the Giants practice center Wednesday, and it would have been understandable if Coach Tom Coughlin had tried to give him a uniform. The Giants pass defense has gone from feared to fragile over the past few weeks, and the latest development  Osi Umenyioras sprained ankle will keep him out of Sundays game against the Green Bay Packers and probably another week or two after that  figures to only make things worse.

title: Colorado: Spill Near Refinery Is Investigated
description: Cleanup crews with Suncor Energy were trying to contain a small spill near a Denver-area oil refinery on Wednesday after liquid began seeping into a creek this week. Suncor was investigating the source of the leak and what precisely was oozing into the creek near its refinery in Commerce City. Workers were trying to keep the liquid from flowing into the South Platte River. Curtis Kimbel, an Environmental Protection Agency coordinator, described the material as a petroleum-type substance. Workers had contained the spill to an area of about 75 yards, he said. The National Wildlife Federation said it was concerned that the material could contain Canadian oil sands crude, which can be difficult to clean because it is so thick.

title: Jaguars Buyer Had His Eye on Ownership of a Franchise
description: Shahid R. Khan, who agreed this week to acquire the Jacksonville Jaguars, has coveted an N.F.L. team for several years. Khans love of football was nurtured at the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana, and his riches as an auto parts manufacturer made the dream possible.

title: Andrew Kazdin, Record Producer, Dies at 77
description: Andrew Kazdin, a producer known for his recordings of the New York Philharmonic, the pianists Glenn Gould, Murray Perahia and Ruth Laredo, and the organist E. Power Biggs, and who revolutionized classical recording by using techniques more common to popular music, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 77.

But largely unnoticed, it is Florida, home to nearly one million Cuban refugees and their descendants, that has come up with perhaps the most bizarre and pointless anti-immigrant policy of all.

title: Primary Sources
description: A few days ago, we posted an article by Thomas B. Edsall analyzing the arguments of Democratic strategists who suggest that the Democratic Party has lost its chance to win over a majority of the white working class and that party leaders should concentrate their efforts on other constituencies. The response was swift and fierce. Readers posted nearly five hundred comments. Edsalls column was picked up, dissected, lambasted and praised in dozens of blog posts and newspaper articles, with headlines like Different Flavor Kool-Aid For Democrats, Is Obama Abandoning the White Working Class? and NY Times: Democrats Not Interested in Voters Who Work, Target Losers Instead (thank you, Rush Limbaugh).

The alleged victim, now 29, is not one of the eight who were mentioned in a grand jury report revealed last month in the child sexual abuse case against Sandusky.

title: More Children Need a Free Breakfast, Lunch  and Dinner
description: I never thought a program like this would apply to me and my kids. Thats what parents in the Gates Chili school district outside Rochester are telling Debbi Beauvais, who administers the school meals program there. In a front-page article on Wednesday, The Times reported that around Rochester and across the country, suburban poverty means that schools are finding themselves serving more free or low-cost lunches  and breakfasts. And last year, when the proportion of students who qualified for free or subsidized lunches in the Hickman Mills C-1 district of Kansas City, Mo., hit 80 percent, the school began offering a third meal after the end of classes, paid for by the state.

title: Watergate? Whatever Was That?
description: House Republicans will surely invoke their all-purpose rationale  deficit savings  as they try on Thursday to repeal the public financing option for presidential campaigns. This is the highly effective reform enacted after the Watergate scandal. It is revealing that just as a new era of unbridled corporate and special-interest money engulfs the 2012 elections, Republicans are determined to kill off the public financing option.

title: Bad Call on Farm Drugs
description: The Food and Drug Administration last month denied two longstanding petitions asking it to limit the routine feeding of antibiotics to farm animals, a practice that poses a serious risk to human health. Eighty percent of the antibiotics sold in this country are fed to farm animals. The drugs make the animals grow faster, but their overuse increases the likelihood of antibiotic-resistant pathogens. Some antibiotics are used only in animals, but farmers are also using antibiotics vital in human medicine. This is the class of drugs that the petitions, sponsored by several consumer advocacy groups, had hoped to restrict.

The new system will also offer some of our most engaged readers the opportunity to post their comments on the Web site without moderation; they will appear shortly after they are written.

title: Belarus: 2 Get Death Sentences in Subway Bombing
description: A court in Belarus handed down a death sentence on Wednesday against two men who had been found guilty of setting off a bomb in a subway station in Minsk, the capital, in April, killing 15 people and wounding hundreds. Judge Aleksandr Fyodortsov said the defendants pose an exceptional danger to society, and an exceptional penalty should be applied to them. Belarus is the only country in Europe in which the death penalty remains legal. After the verdict was read, Lyubov Kovalyova, the mother of one of the defendants, tearfully told reporters that the case against her son had been fabricated.

The men arrested Wednesday are suspected of carrying out unsolved bombings in Pune, Delhi and Bangalore, the Indian Express reported.

title: Dec. 1, 1959 | Antarctica Is Set Aside as Scientific Preserve
description: On Dec. 1, 1959, representatives of 12 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, signed a treaty in Washington, which designated Antarctica as a scientific preserve, free from military activity.The signatories included the seven nations to have claimed control over a part of Antarctica: Argentina, Australia, Britain, Chile, France, Norway and New Zealand. The treaty did not affect these claims though it did ban all future claims. The New York Times noted that overlapping claims by Britain, Argentina and Chile had caused tension and that many hoped the treaty would ultimately permit the claims issue to die a natural death.

title: Marathon Swimmer Diana Nyad Takes On the Demons of the Sea
description: Today Diana Nyad is swimming for four hours. She does this four days a week in the 50-meter pool at the Rose Bowl Aquatic Center, in Pasadena, Calif. Her stroke is rhythmic, high in the water. Its hard to judge how old she is by looking at her. Her back is well muscled. Her legs are girlish  shapely and short. Her skin is as weathered as a crocodile handbag. Her arms are covered with jellyfish scars. When Nyad swims in a pool, she counts in her head, ticking off laps, first in English, then in German, then in Spanish, then in French. (Nyad is fluent in all but German.) The goal is to focus her mind on repetitive thought, as a yogi does with a mantra. But when Nyad swims in the ocean for a long time  8 or 10 or 12 or even 24 hours  she doesnt just count, she sings. Shell do It Aint Me, Babe 10 times, interspersed with the quatralingual counting, then sing Paperback Writer, 10 times, followed by quatralingual counting again. Nyad keeps in her head a playlist of 65 songs. Some are for daytime swimming; others for nighttime. Nyad knows each one intimately, how many seconds each takes, how many strokes. When I complete 2,000 It Aint Me, Babes, Bob Dylan version, I know Ive gone 4 hours and 45 minutes exactly, Nyad says. I never lose track.

title: An Awakening
description: A mother describes the surprising effect that the pharmaceutical sleeping drug Ambien has had on her brain-damaged son.

title: The Huntsman Alternative
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Seeking Evidence Through Photography
description: Svetlana Bachevanova recalls sitting at home in Sofia, Bulgaria, and straining her ears as she listened to BBC reports at low volume, to keep neighbors from hearing.

title: A Drug That Wakes the Near Dead
description: The moment she saw him, Judy Cox knew her son was dead. It was an October morning in 2008, and she had just stepped out the door to run an errand when she found him lying faceup in the driveway, ghost white, covered in purple splotches. He wasnt breathing, and when she couldnt revive him, she ran screaming into the house where her husband, Wayne, was still asleep. Chris is dead, she cried. Call 911!

title: When in Your Life Have You Been a Leader?
description: Every week, in a column called Corner Office, Adam Bryant interviews a business leader from a different industry about the experience, and challenges, of being a boss.

title: Amid the Loins Grit, Tastes of the Subcontinent Bloom
description: There aint nothin tenduh bout the Tenderloin, Wajahat Ali declares with a smirk as he welcomes me to San Franciscos red-light district.

title: Greek Workers Walk Out in Protest for 7th Time
description: ATHENS  Thousands of Greek workers walked off the job on Thursday in the seventh general strike this year to protest government austerity policies after a year and a half of cutbacks.

title: Thursday Matchup: Eagles at Seahawks
description: Eagles (4-7) at Seahawks (4-7), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, NFL NetworkLine: Eagles by 3

title: From the Wreckage, Flying Jimmy Elvis Emerges, Victorious
description: BITHLO, Fla.  Flying Jimmy Elvis hopes to add his name, which he admits does not appear on his drivers license, to a list of illustrious auto-show daredevils that includes Tricky Travelstead, Doug Danger, Tommy Trubble, Spanky Spangler, Tom Creepo the Clown Chapman and Insane Arno Selberg.

title: Week 13 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, Injured Quarterback Edition
description: Its that time of year when quarterbacks are dropping like flies. There are 9 or 10 teams playing either their second- or third-string passer for one reason or another, depending on who is counted as a starter. Of particular interest are Caleb Hanie and T.J. Yates, the two inexperienced backup quarterbacks playing for winning teams.

title: Inside the Mind of Mike Leach
description: The first of two excerpts The Quad will run from a new book, Sports for Dorks College Football, co-edited by Ferhat Guven and Mike Leach, the former Texas Tech coach hired this week at Washington State. The book is an anthology of ideas by various experts on innovations taking place in college football.

title: Tastings and Classes at Paris Wine Fair
description: Le Grand Tasting  a k a the Great Wines Fair  offers connoisseurs and novices the opportunity to taste 350 of the best French and European domains. Organized by Michel Bettane and Thierry Desseauve, two wine authorities, it takes place on Dec. 2 and 3 at the Carrousel du Louvre (99 rue de Rivoli; carrouseldulouvre.com). Distinguished labels like Veuve Clicquot and Louis Latour; wine-world stars like Herve Bizeul and Marcel Richaud; and newcomers including Beaucastel, Pichon Comtesse, Angelus and Chateau de Bellet are among the participants this year.

title: The Early Word: Fall and Rise
description: In Todays Times:

title: Central Bank Chief Hints at Stepping Up Euro Support
description: FRANKFURT  Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, laid the groundwork for a more aggressive response to the debt crisis Thursday, suggesting that the bank could increase its support for the European economy if political leaders took more radical steps to enforce spending discipline among members.

title: Official Says U.S. Needs Time to Assess Aid to North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States needs more time to decide on possible aid for North Korea because it is not sure humanitarian assistance would reach the people in need, the top American aid official said on Thursday.

title: Rice With Poached Eggs
description: Time: 1 to 1 1/4 hours

title: Leek-and-Cardamom Fritters
description: Time: About 1 hour

title: The Doctor as Poet
description: There used to be just two sure-fire ways to get a medical students attention: offer free food or give the answer to a question on an upcoming exam.

title: Yotam Ottolenghis International Cuisine
description: Yotam Ottolenghi has no trouble embracing complex issues or producing complex, difficult-to-define food. He was born in Jerusalem of European immigrants (his mother is German, his father Italian). His primary business partner, Sami Tamimi  who also grew up in Jerusalem  is Palestinian. Ottolenghi studied philosophy and literature (he has a masters in comparative literature), and though he attended Le Cordon Bleu for six months, he lacks the bossiness of most chefs. His cooking at his London restaurant, Nopi, and in four gorgeous shops (all called Ottolenghi), is usually thought of and described as broadly Mediterranean, but in fact its far more international than that. Not only does he offer out-and-out Asian dishes on the menu; he is also comfortable using soy sauce in what might be thought of as Provenal dishes or hitting tofu with rosemary. What most of the dishes have in common, he says when asked, are sun and intense flavors.

title: The Handwriting on the Wall Says, GiGi Young Originals
description: Advertising murals painted by hand on blank brick side walls in the 1800s and 1900s were supposed to have disappeared by now. Color slides were supposed to have disappeared by now. Books were supposed to have disappeared by now.

title: 7 Blogs and Newsletters That Can Help You Sell a Business
description: In a recent Transaction post, I suggested four questions to ask a business broker. Here is a fifth. Before you hire a business broker, ask something like this: Ill bet youve seen it all, havent you?

title: An Alliance for BMW and Toyota
description: TOKYO  BMW said Thursday that it would supply Toyota Motor Corporation with diesel engines and jointly develop car batteries as part of a comprehensive technology alliance.

title: Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 1
description: The rapper Kanye West received the most nominations for the 54th Annual Grammy Awards during a ceremony broadcast on Wednesday night on CBS, but it was the pop stars Adele and Bruno Mars who dominated the Song of the Year, Record of the Year and Album of the Year nominations, The ArtsBeat blog reported. Adele, the British soul singer, received six nominations for her album 21, which included the hit Rolling in the Deep. (Her singing voice has been temporarily silenced by vocal cord surgery, and it is not clear, The Los Angeles Times reported, whether Adele will have recovered sufficiently to perform when the awards are handed out on Feb. 12.) Mr. Mars also received six nominations, three for Grenade, his song about unrequited love, and three for the album Doowops and Hooligans. Mr. West was nominated seven times based on two albums  his complex solo set My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy and his collaboration with Jay-Z, Watch the Throne. Both were left off the Album of the Year list, but were nominated for Rap Album of the Year. (The snub of MBDTF, as Mr. Wests album is known, was certainly the hot topic on Twitter.)

title: Among Hundreds of Dead Dolphins, an Intriguing Survivor
description: Four more dolphins washed up on the shores of the Gulf of Mexico this week. For coastal residents from Louisiana to Florida, the beached animals are a familair sight: hundreds of decomposing dolphin carcasses have turned up over the last two years.

title: Daily Report: A Deluge of Data in DNA Sequencing
description: The study of genomes is caught in a data deluge, reports Andrew Pollack in Thursdays New York Times. Although DNA sequencing is becoming faster and cheaper, researchers are drowning in the amount of resulting data, which is expensive to store, transmit and analyze.

title: Love (and Law) in the Time of H.I.V.
description: JOHANNESBURG  A couple of years ago, courtesy of a joyous English summer, Cupid shot his arrow straight through my student heart. I fell in love with a charming American filmmaker. A blustery romance ensued. In the era of Skype, the ocean separating us had no chance of drowning our romantic spirits, and a few months later, I visited him in New York.

title: Citigroup Appoints New Head of Russian Banking
description: LONDON  Citigroup said on Thursday that it had appointed Slava Slavinskiy as the head of banking for Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States, which were formerly Soviet republics.

title: Only One Thing on His Mind
description: The cruel paradox of addiction is that it transforms a source of pleasure into an inescapable, insatiable need. An abundance  an overdose  of movies and books explores the logic of this condition, mostly with respect to drugs or alcohol. Shame, the relentless new feature from the British artist turned filmmaker Steve McQueen, has a lot in common with films that plumb the toxic romance of the bottle or the needle. The crucial difference is that its protagonist, a handsome, youngish Manhattanite named Brandon (Michael Fassbender), is hooked on sex.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Opinion Report: Supreme Court Recusals
description: From the editorial page

title: Romney Starting to Advertise in Iowa
description: 1:36 a.m. | Updated

title: X Factor Watch:  Its Michael Jackson Week. Oh Dear.
description: The X Factor did no one a favor, including viewers, by making this Michael Jackson Week, forcing all the contestants to sing Jackson songs Wednesday night. Which, of course, provided assorted opportunities to mention that swell Pepsi commercial Jackson made. Pepsi being the shows main sponsor.

title: Thursday Reading: D.I.Y. Tips to Spruce Up Your Home for the Holidays
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: In Iraq, Biden Says Tide of Conflict Is Receding
description: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq  As the United States prepared to turn over this optimistically named military base to Iraq, leaders of both countries held a solemn commemoration here on Thursday of the sacrifices of American and Iraqi troops during eight years of war, marking the moment in a garish marble palace built by Saddam Hussein.

title: Heres an Idea: You Create a Gridlock Alert, You Pay for It
description: It was truly improvident of Rockefeller Center to have begun a tradition of lighting its Christmas tree during the week after Thanksgiving, when it should have anticipated that a president might show up at the same time rattling a cup for his re-election campaign.

title: Gingrich Says He Was Acting as a Citizen, Not a Lobbyist
description: Newt Gingrich said on Wednesday night that his advocacy with state and federal legislators for policies that would help his paying clients was in keeping with his role as a citizen, and was not evidence that he ever acted as a lobbyist.

title: Is It the Year of the Dude Film?
description: Over in our non-bloggy column today, the Bagger explores the idea that there is a bumper crop of dude-oriented films among the Oscar hopefuls this year. The Descendants, Beginners, The Tree of Life, Margin Call, Take Shelter, J. Edgar, The Artist, Midnight in Paris, 50/50 and Drive all deal with fatherhood, or living up to notions of masculine identity, sexuality and power, or bashing someones head in. (And lets not even go near the Michael Fassbender vehicle Shame for the moment. We will get to the double entendres for that later, or the good folks at Fox, which is releasing the NC-17 movie, will do it for us.)

title: Final Countdown | Beauty Calendar
description: Thirty-one days to a new you for the new year  get going.

title: BP to Sell Canadian Natural Gas Unit for $1.67 Billion
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated

title: U.S. Retailers Meet Forecasts
description: Retailers midnight openings last week brought in customers, most big chains said they were pleased with their Black Friday sales and the November revenue increases at stores open at least a year came in just where analysts had expected, reports showed Thursday.

title: Jane Addams High School Accused of Credit-Switching
A Libel Law and a Balancing Act
description: JERUSALEM  Israel is still a journalistic heaven, but Israeli journalists have good reason to forget it these days. Yes, Israeli informality means that its still relatively easy for reporters to call high officials on their cellphones at all hours. Yes, the countrys smallness means that they can quickly reach its every corner. But last week the Knesset member Yariv Levin of the Likud Party cast a dark shadow on these advantages by getting a proposed amendment to Israels libel law through a first vote.

title: Talks Break Down Between City Opera and Unions
description: 1:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Stocks on Wall Street Drift Slightly After Gains
description: Stocks were mostly lower on Thursday as better-than-forecast manufacturing growth and a rally in French and Spanish bonds were not enough to extend a three-day gain in the Standard & Poors 500-stock index.

title: Sitting Pretty

title: Depression May Slow Exercise Recovery
description: Exercise is known to ease the symptoms of depression. But does depression change the way the body responds to exercise?

title: What Were Reading
description: The Chicago Tribune: The wild new incarnation of Next, the ambitious Chicago restaurant that changes its menu entirely every three months, gets four stars from the Tribune.  Julia Moskin

title: Americans Flock to Car Showrooms With Wallets Open
description: DETROIT  Auto sales in the United States climbed 14 percent in November as lower gas prices and a wider availability of Japanese models helped the industry achieve its highest selling rate in more than two years, automakers and analysts said Thursday.

title: The Summer Of Confidence
description: Ah, memories. Jean-Claude Trichet, June 2010:

title: Spains Star Chefs Are Branching Out
description: It may be too late to try Ferran Adris molecular gastronomy at El Bulli in Catalonia, which closed in July. But with the opening of several Michelin-starred hotel restaurants in Spain, travelers can experience cutting-edge cookery in places outside remote areas of the Basque Country or Catalonia. The chef Dani Garca runs Calima in the resort town of Marbella; and the twin chefs Sergio and Javier Torres run Dos Cielos in Barcelona. Both restaurants, part of the Melia hotel chain, are making Spains new cuisine easier to reach (if not easier on the wallet).

title: Poetry Pairing | Meeting on the Street
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches J. Allyn Rossers Meeting on the Street with a Modern Love column, Romances New Format.

title: The Republican Attack on Federal Workers
description: Congressional Republicans said yesterday they would support an extension of the payroll tax cut, but refused President Obamas proposal to make millionaires pay for it with a small surcharge on their earnings. Instead, they want middle-class federal workers to offset the cost.

title: Leading Off: Whats Gotten Into Hockey?
description: N.H.L. seasons are usually fairly predictable. Teams muddle around during the fall when most people think the season hasnt (or shouldnt have) started yet. Everyone is within three points of a playoff spot in February. Teams throw players around like throw pillows at the trading deadline. Everyone makes a riveting mad dash at the playoffs, which end ridiculously late in the year when people have sunscreen on their shopping lists.

title: Cloud Computing as a Threat to Older Tech Companies
description: The International Data Corporation, whose technology analysis and predictions influence a lot of corporate purchases, foresees the creation of a new high-technology industry in the convergence of mobile devices, social networking, and cloud-based computing and data storage. As a result, the company says in a new study, many industry giants will scramble to sustain relevance, and some upstarts will achieve leadership positions or be purchased.

title: How Hard Is It to Adapt a Hit Book? Ask the Makers of Tinker, Tailor
description: Over at Gold Derby, Adam Waldowski takes a look at the strong competition for the best adapted screenplay Oscar. When it picked up a nod from the New York Film Critics Circle on Tuesday, Moneyball, the adaptation of Michael Lewiss business-of-baseball best seller, got an early lead; it may also be helped by having recognizable writers in Aaron Sorkin and Steve Zaillian. On the other hand, Mr. Sorkin won an Oscar just last year, for The Social Network, and Mr. Zaillian picked up one in 1993, for a little film called Schindlers List. (He also adapted this years Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.) Who else is on deck?

title: A Second Arrival for Once
description: WHILE preparing for the lead role of Girl in the new Off Broadway musical Once, Cristin Milioti made a choice common among performers in screen-to-stage adaptations: She avoided watching the original film, a 2006 indie romance from Ireland that won an Academy Award for the song Falling Slowly. Her concern was that she might slip into mimicking Marketa Irglova, the spirited young Czech musician who became a fan favorite as Girl in the movie.

title: Steve Case Raises $450 Million Venture Fund
description: The AOL co-founder Steve Case and two former AOL colleagues, Ted Leonsis and Donn Davis, have raised $450 million for a new venture capital fund.

title: Look! Up in the Sky! Its an Astronomical Price for a Comic Book!
description: An auction for a copy of Action Comics No. 1 from 1938 set a record Wednesday night. After 50 bids the closing price was $2,161,000  the most ever paid for a comic book  to be the owner of the first appearance of Superman. (And that new owners identity is currently secret.) The copy of the book was graded at 9.0 on a scale of 1 to 10, a full grade better than a copy of Action Comics No. 1 that sold for $1 million last year. (For a look at other notable debuts, and what they have fetched, click here.)

title: Union Leader Foresees Teacher Evaluation 'Nightmare'
An Unexpected Request
description: Shortly before he died of cancer in January, the designer Charles Nolan made an unexpected request. He wanted his store in the meatpacking district to remain open, no matter what happened to his label.

title: At El Pedregal, Rain and Doves
description: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

title: Many Consumers Plan to Spend Less This Holiday Season
description: With economic concerns weighing heavily, 42 percent of Americans and 49 percent of parents  say they plan to spend less this holiday season than last year, a recent survey found.

title: Montclair Film Festival Gains Directors, and a Cheerleader Named Stephen Colbert
description: Cannes. Toronto. Park City, Utah. If these cities can each be the home of a great film festival, then why not Montclair, N.J.? Isnt it entitled to a little bit of that cinematic luster, too?

title: Fukushima Meltdown Was More Severe Than Thought, Study Says
description: Molten nuclear fuel in the No. 1 reactor at Japans Fukushima Daiichi plant burned through a steel pressure vessel and three-quarters of the surrounding concrete containment vessel, the reactors last substantial internal barrier, a report released by the plants operator and the Japanese government says. [The Australian]

title: Scandals Ramifications on Penn State Hockey
description: There are many ugly accusations and a lot of unanswered questions surrounding Penn State these days. One question was answered recently by the Buffalo Sabres owner Terry Pegula, a Penn State alumnus who is responsible for bringing Division I hockey to State College with an $88 million donation in 2010.

title: Charming Shoppes Puts Fashion Bug on the Block
description: Charming Shoppes said on Thursday that it was putting its Fashion Bug chain up for sale to focus on its Lane Bryant line of plus-size womens apparel.

title: Obama to Vie for Arizona as Latino Numbers Rise
description: PHOENIX  Republicans in the State Legislature here push a law that would require President Obama to provide his long-form birth certificate in order to get on the Arizona presidential ballot in 2012. The governor uses Facebook to denounce the presidents backdoor amnesty plan. Cars traveling on State Route 260 are treated to a giant billboard bearing Mr. Obamas mug on a mock $100 trillion bill that asks, But Who Will Pay the Piper?

title: Victims Parents Say West Memphis Three Documentary Shouldnt Receive an Oscar
description: The parents of one of the children who was killed in the so-called West Memphis Three murder case have asked the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to refuse Oscar consideration for the documentary Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory, saying that it celebrates the three defendants in that case.

title: The 1930s  Sexiest Decade in Clothing?

title: Sharper Than a Serpents Tooth
description: King Lear has problems with executive function.

title: U.S. Embassy in France Buys Four Chevy Volts
description: PARIS  The United States Embassy in France is adding four Chevrolet Volts to its fleet, promoting the American-made plug-in hybrid abroad just as federal investigators are scrutinizing the cars battery after a fire that followed a crash test.

title: The Human Race (Between Potency and Self Awareness)
description: Jeannine Cahill, a student at the Pace University Law School, caught me on campus recently for a short discussion of some of the core issues explored on Dot Earth:

title: A Shark Circles Art Basel Miami Beach
description: Miami Beach

title: Clearwire Gets Some Help From Sprint
description: Clearwire, a troubled wireless company, will be getting some help from Sprint Nextel, the countrys third-largest cellphone carrier. The companies said Thursday that Sprint would pledge as much as $1.6 billion over the next four years so Clearwire can expand its network.

title: Mexican Playoffs: Too Hot to Handle?
description: There is a hot controversy brewing in Mexican soccer, with intrigue worthy of the soap operas, or telenovelas, that that are the staple of Mexican television.

title: Societe Generale Said to Be Planning New York Job Cuts
description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale is planning to eliminate a number of jobs in New York, as the financial crisis and a changing global regulatory environment put pressure on its businesses there, a person with direct knowledge of the banks plans said Thursday.

title: Is a Tablet Computer for Babies the Worst Toy of 2011?
description: Each year, the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood nominates a few select toys for a Toady award: Toys Oppressive and Destructive to Young Children. In 2010, the award went to Nickelodeons Addicting Games Web site, not just for its games (like Perry the Sneak, which allowed players to earn points by trying to catch glimpses of naked women showering) but for its decision to market those games on its Nick Jr. Web site. In 2009, the winner was the Dallas Cowboy Cheerleader Barbie.

title: Massachusetts Sues 5 Major Banks Over Foreclosure Practices
description: Citing extensive abuses of troubled borrowers across Massachusetts, the states attorney general sued the nations five largest mortgage lenders on Thursday, seeking relief for consumers hurt by what she called unfair and deceptive business practices.

title: Before They Were Gay (at Least in Print)
description: How gay was the New York gay march in the infancy of the gay rights movement almost 40 years ago?

title: So Many Musicians Inspired by Paul Motian
description: Paul Motian

title: Missing Arms, Legs, Fathers and Mothers
description: The scars of Cambodias wars and genocide are more than psychic: this little nation in the heart of Southeast Asia is one of the most densely mined places on earth. And like those mines, the legacy of Pol Pots Khmer Rouge exacts a constant  and hidden  toll, leaving the country mostly poor, politically repressive, corrupt and violent.

title: Nooks Advertising Is Corrected
description: Last week in this column, I really let Barnes & Noble have it.

title: N.B.A. Players Union Set to Resume Business
description: A sense of normalcy is returning to the N.B.A., in ways both subtle and profound.

title: Why Do Foreign Banks Need Dollars?
description: The announcement Wednesday that the Federal Reserve, working with other central banks, will offer dollars to foreign banks at cut-rate prices surely raises the question: Why do foreign banks need dollars?

title: The Timess pop music writers discuss the return of the Black Keys and remember the jazz drummer Paul Motian.
description: This week: Alan Light discusses the return of the Black Keys; Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen remember the jazz drummer Paul Motian. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: After Duty, Dogs Suffer Like Soldiers
description: SAN ANTONIO  The call came into the behavior specialists here from a doctor in Afghanistan. His patient had just been through a firefight and now was cowering under a cot, refusing to come out.

title: Bob the Builder Goes to Haiti
description: Some good news from Haiti, or at leastsome glimmers: International investors and donors are attending an investment forum in the capital, Port-au-Prince, sponsored by the Inter-American Development Bank. As The Miami Herald reported, President Michel Martelly, Prime Minister Garry Cornille, former President Bill Clinton and the head of the I.D.B., Luis Alberto Moreno, have spent the last few days cutting ribbons and making speeches, all to emphasize the idea that reconstruction is gaining momentum and that Haiti is open for business.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Times has introduced an improved comment system, which will provide threading of comments so you can respond directly to one another, and allow you to share your comments to Twitter and Facebook. Our new system will also offer some of our most engaged readers the opportunity to post their comments on the Web site without moderation.

title: Seen on Video: A Smoke Shop Theft
description: On Black Friday, as shoppers across the nation busied themselves pepper-spraying and shooting at each other, a quieter but perhaps no less brazen crime was committed at a head shop  er, smoking accessories store  in the East Village. Several young men helped themselves to six vaporizers worth a total of about $2,500 from the store, Smoking Tattoos.

title: In Advertising, MDC Names Its First Woman as Managing Director
description: MDC Partners, which owns advertising agencies like Crispin Porter & Bogusky, is hiring its first woman to be managing director.

title: Springsteen to Make Trip to SXSW
description: Bruce Springsteen will be the keynote speaker at next years South by Southwest Music and Media Conference and Festival, Mr. Springsteen and organizers of the event, which is based in Austin, Tex., jointly announced on Thursday. His participation is scheduled for March 15 at the conferences main space, the Austin Convention Center.

title: First, Hit It Big. Then Change.
description: NASHVILLE

title: Out There | Art Basel Miami Beach Pregame Show
description: The forecast for Tuesday in Miami Beach was for overcast skies, scattered parties and a chance of art as jet-lagged travelers convened for the prelude to Art Basel 2011. The Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden in Coral Gables hosted its annual brunch, this year for the sculptor Will Ryman, whose monochromatic roses (most recently seen on Park Avenue) are scattered around the grounds in the form of petal chairs and towering, long-stemmed arrangements. Valuable trees and interesting fauna abounded, including a black crocodile and coconut-size baby raccoon mingling in dangerous proximity: what kind of omen is that?

title: Make Me a Mitt Romney Weeble!
description: Its not every day an art director is charged with this task. I came out of the meeting thinking that it seemed easy enough. Break apart Weeble toy. Hire someone to illustrate Romneys caricature. Piece Weeble together. Photograph. Done.

title: 36 Hours in Mrida, Mexico
description: Mrida, a languid city of pastel mansions and evening promenades, is in the midst of a restoration boom, and the citys cultural and restaurant scenes are flourishing.

title: 36 Hours in Mrida, Mexico
description: YUCATECANS are fiercely proud of their culture, sprinkling their Spanish with Mayan words and quick to recount the stories of resistance and revolution that set this region apart from the rest of Mexico for centuries. Somehow, those tales seem a little distant now in Yucatns capital, Mrida, a languid city of pastel mansions and evening promenades. The city, now one of the safest in Mexico, is an architectural jewel, and has one of the countrys largest historic centers outside Mexico City. Block after block of houses dating to the mid-19th century and earlier are in the midst of a restoration boom, and the citys cultural and restaurant scenes are flourishing.

title: Split Decision
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#518", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Cunningham Countdown: Saying Goodbye to the RUGs
description: Its no longer news that the Merce Cunningham Dance Company is due to shut up shop at the end of 2011. But another, attached troupe has already given its farewell. The Cunningham companys Repertory Understudy Group ended with a season of six performances in the Cunningham studio over the last six days of November. Known as the RUGs, its four dancers were never quite a second company. The group, formalized in 1990, served as an apprentice program for the Cunningham company, with whose members its four dancers shared studios and took class.

title: At Home in Hotels
description: Guy Trebay on some of the hotels he has stayed at, including the Park Hyatt in Tokyo, the Bauer in Venice, a parking-lot motel in New Mexico and the Sunset in Los Angeles.

title: Excerpt: 'Bonnie & Clyde'
description: Laura Osnes and Jeremy Jordan in the number "How 'Bout a Dance," from Frank Wildhorn's new Broadway musical. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Popcast: The Black Keys and Paul Motian
description: This week Popcast examines the return of a surprise pop juggernaut and remembers a seminal jazz drummer.

title: TimesCast | December 1, 2011
description: Islamists say they have a majority in early voting in Egypt; a Bahraini blogger stands up to the riot police; and why the Grammys are still relevant.

title: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s Atlanta Neighborhood on the Upswing
description: As a cradle of culinary and artistic innovation, the area is seeing a wave of new art galleries, nightclubs and restaurants.

title: Kicking Could Decide Oklahoma-Oklahoma State Bedlam game
description: Batten down the hatches in Oklahoma, its bedlam time again. For those outside of the Sooner state, that means the annual football showdown between Oklahoma and Oklahoma State. Its another installment in the heated Bedlam Series sports rivalry between the schools, set for Saturday night in Stillwater.

title: Obama Says He Will Seek More Money for AIDS Programs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama won plaudits from AIDS groups that have criticized him in the past with his announcement on Thursday that he is seeking additional federal money for efforts to prevent and treat the disease in the United States and globally.

title: Spain and Argentina Meet in Davis Cup Final
description: The Davis Cup final, the last major event of the tennis season, begins Friday in Seville, with host Spain facing Argentina. Rafael Nadal, coming off a disappointing fall and hoping to end his season on a high note, opens play for Spain against his good friend Juan Monaco. Fifth-ranked David Ferrer will play Juan Martn del Potro in Fridays second match.

title: Blue-Eyed Boy and His Possessed Puppet
description: JUILLIARD doesnt really prepare you for puppetry. It certainly doesnt prepare you for satanic puppetry, at least. But Steven Boyer  who plays the lead(s) in Hand to God, an acclaimed comedy about a meek teenager whose sock puppet appears to be possessed by the Devil  has been learning on the job.

title: Mazda Takeri Carries the Kodo Standard Forward
description: At the Tokyo auto show this week, Mazda unveiled the Takeri concept car, the clearest indication yet from the automaker of the future shape of the Mazda 6 midsize sedan.

title: The Impact of Grazing? Dont Ask
description: Millions of cattle graze on public lands all over the West and have done so for more than a century. But a new complaint filed by an environmental group charges that despite Clinton-era moves to examine and diminish the impact of grazing in the arid West, Interior Department employees have blocked the use of federal data on the impact in regional scientific studies.

title: A Blizzard of Tickets for Texting While Driving
description: New Yorkers who took to the roads over the Thanksgiving weekend could not keep their hands off their phones. As a result, 816 drivers received tickets for texting while driving, the governors office said on Thursday.

title: Political Holiday Gifts
description: In my inbox: Holiday Gifts from Cato! Somehow, not something I could imagine myself, or for that matter anyone, rushing to check out. But Robin and I immediately began thinking of other conservative-themed gifts:

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Myanmar, Uganda and China.

title: $3 Million Gift for New Signature Theater Company Home
description: The family foundation of Barry Diller and Diane von Furstenberg has made its largest donation to an arts organization, $3 million to Signature Theater Company for its new Off Broadway home set to open in February. James Houghton, artistic director of the theater company, announced the gift for the Signature Center complex on Thursday and said that in appreciation the centerpiece stairway would be named the Diller-von Furstenberg Grand Staircase.

title: Haul Me Up by Richard Thompson
description: A performance of Haul Me Up, by Richard Thompson Band, part of a DVD called Live at Celtic Connections, due out in January.

title: Hoping for Mammals, but Getting Mostly Ants
description: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Dallas Art Museum
description: A Federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit against the Dallas Museum of Art involving a collection of some 1,400 works of art, including paintings by van Gogh, Renoir, and Pissarro.

title: Week 13 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Ducks Look to Boudreaus Softer Touch for More Wins
description: Bruce Boudreaus unemployment lasted all of 65 hours.

title: BMW and Toyota to Collaborate on Battery Development
description: At a press conference Thursday in Tokyo, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the BMW Group jointly announced they would collaborate on specific advanced powertrain technologies. The effort would initially be focused on research in lithium-ion batteries.

title: Gingrichs Immigration Plan Could Benefit Millions, Study Finds
description: How many illegal immigrants could gain legal status under an idea proposed by Newt Gingrich? Perhaps as many as 3.5 million, according to figures published Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center in Washington.

title: Styled to a T | Richard Thompson
description: The Trend

title: Five Hotels That Get Five Stars
description: The BangalaKaraikuddiTamil Nadu, India

title: Six Ways to Master Your Hotel Stay
description: SEE THE THIRD ROOM FIRST Its anyones guess why the first room that check-in clerks invariably offer is the cubbyhole with a romantic view of the air handling system. No matter how travel fatigued, I make it a point to apply the advice of a friend with decades of international travel experience. Show me the third room first, this woman says at check-in, telegraphing a willingness to keep at it until shes offered a room she likes.

title: My Life in Hotels
description: IF you travel a lot, it happens that you are expected to keep a list of dream destinations. Friends are understandably curious to learn where somebody fortunate enough to have visited a fair number of places would voluntarily go if given the chance. It surprises people, then, to learn that where I would most like to be is often a great hotel.

title: Symbolically Attired for an Arrest on World AIDS Day
description: Demonstrators wearing Robin Hood costumes were arrested after stopping traffic near City Hall on Thursday, in an attempt to persuade elected officials to make Wall Street pay to fight AIDS at home and abroad, as one protest group put it on its Web site. Approximately eight people were taken into custody, a police spokesman said.

title: A Calculator to See if Youll Be Snared by the A.M.T.
description: Right after the holiday season comes tax season. So to help you with your year-end tax planning, Kiplinger is offering a new calculator to help you determine if you will fall prey to the dreaded alternative minimum tax.

title: Kelli OHara to Star in Bridges of Madison County Musical Workshop
description: The director Bartlett Sher and the actress Kelli OHara, who collaborated previously on the Tony Award-winning revival of South Pacific and the musical Light in the Piazza, will reunite for a developmental workshop in New York this month of their latest project, The Bridges of Madison County, a musical adaptation of the best-selling novel and hit film. The Broadway producers Jeffrey Richards, Stacey Mindich and Jerry Frankel confirmed on Thursday that they were holding the workshop; no plans for a full production have been announced.

title: Guess Where This Is?
description: Before falling into decay, this gentrifying neighborhood in an American city was a bustling hub with factories and shotgun houses.

title: TimesCast | Islamists In Egypt See Gains
description: December 1, 2011  As early Egyptian election results reveal a s strong showing for Islamist, the countrys secular voters react.

title: Even More Frugal Miami
description: Even More Frugal Miami

title: Photo Replay: Dec.1
description: A look at the day in sports, including USA Swimmings winter national championships in Atlanta and Europa League soccer matches in Germany and Greece.

title: Design Miami | Bring Your A-Game
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Art Meets Leisure in Arkansas
description: THE drive into Bentonville, Ark., from the regions airport provides vistas of cattle pastures and open fields that occasionally give way to lonely, treeless subdivisions, which in turn lead to commercial strips. A massive Wal-Mart distribution center provides the first indication of that corporations influence here, where it has its headquarters.

title: Its the Season to Earn, and Spend, Points
description: BRIAN KELLY started planning his fathers work trips  and managing his travel awards  when he was still a kid. At 13, he had collected enough points to book a family vacation in the Cayman Islands. Now Mr. Kellys blog, thepointsguy.com, helps frustrated travelers who dont know how to make the most of their awards. With so much gift-giving and family visiting, Mr. Kelly said, the holidays are the season for racking up travel points. Below are his five tips for giving  and getting.

title: Hotel Review: In Amsterdam, Hotel de lEurope
description: UPSHOT

title: Accel Invests in Brazilian Review and Search Site
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Accel Partners has invested in Kekanto, a local review and search site based here, reinforcing its interest in the booming Brazilian consumer Internet market.

title: The Island From a Board
description: A trip to St. John as seen on a stand-up paddle board offers wide-ranging views of the land and fish beneath.

title: The Life Report: Regina Titus
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

title: Everyones a Critic: Analyzing Sitcoms as Cultural Texts
description: Overview | What can television sitcoms teach us? In this lesson, students investigate the claim recently made in The New York Times that new hit sitcoms are proof that weve reached the End of Comedy. They watch sitcoms with a critical eye and ultimately choose a writing project that demonstrates a close viewing that treats the shows like literary texts.

title: Stand-Up Paddle Boarding in the Virgin Islands
description: IF John would just raise his arms skyward, I would have a better view of him streaking across the Narrows, northward toward Tortola, leaving me far enough behind that I have to squint to see him. He wants to cross the 1.5-mile strait on his paddle board, abandoning United States territory to storm British waters. This is not recommended for those who are likely to give out halfway across, like me, which is why I am still on this side of the divide, straddling my board, in a lagoon off St. John in the United States Virgin Islands.

title: Regulators Pledge New Rules After MF Globals Demise
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated

title: The Waimea Valley Reveals Its Secrets
description: ITS not often that a hike begins with a ceremonial chant. We were standing outside the visitor center at Waimea Valley, on the North Shore of Oahu, when our guide, Kahokulea Haiku, started our excursion by singing an oli, a traditional Hawaiian chant that honors the history of the land and its people, and can be used as a blessing or to give thanks. As bright morning light shone down on us, Mr. Haikus voice resonated across the gardens that surround the center. And with that, we were off.

title: Time to Accelerate the Housing Recovery
description: Its housing, stupid. More precisely, its housing finance.

title: Osteria dei Mulini in Polignano a Mare, Italy
description: The limestone entablature above the entrance to Chiesa del Purgatorio, a church in Polignano a Mare, on the Adriatic coast of Puglia, features an assemblage of skulls and crossbones and, situated squarely among them, an hourglass, a reminder that the only thing separating life from the afterlife is the slippage of a few grains of sand. Thankfully, for those who would spend as much of what precious time remains eating, right next door is a restaurant that through various iterations has been serving traditional Puglian cuisine for centuries.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach: Wednesday Night
description: Dueling beach parties for MoCA and Art.sy.

title: Rebecca Musical Names Its Mrs. Danvers and Mr. de Winter
description: The Broadway musical of Rebecca has its fearsome Mrs. Danvers in Karen Mason, who most recently played the also fearsome Queen of Hearts in the short-lived musical Wonderland.

title: My 20 Years as a Dad Columnist
description: My children have spent most of their lives under my magnifying glass. This year I pulled it away.

title: Ante Markovic, Last Premier of Yugoslavia, Dies at 87
description: Ante Markovic, who as the last prime minister of Yugoslavia tried to stave off the ethnic warfare that led to the disintegration of that nation, died on Nov. 28 in Zagreb, the Croatian capital. He was 87.

title: National Board of Review Picks Hugo
description: Theres something for everyone  except Brad Pitt, Meryl Streep and Michelle Williams. The National Board of Review picked Hugo, Martin Scorseses 3D ode to early cinema, as its top film, and named Mr. Scorsese best director, thereby ensuring that Mr. Scorsese will show up for the ceremony on Jan. 10. Also likely to appear: George Clooney, who won best actor for The Descendants, which earned a best supporting actress win for Shailene Woodley, who plays Mr. Clooneys petulant teenage daughter, and a best adapted screenplay award for Alexander Payne, Nat Faxon and Jim Rash. The incomparable Tilda Swinton was named best actress for We Need to Talk About Kevin, and Christopher Plummer will take home the best supporting actor trophy for his turn as a father coming out late in life in Mike Mills Beginners, which could signal the start of his ascent to a best supporting actor nod at the Oscars.

title: Lens: Opera
description: Lens: Opera

title: Delusional Teenagers and Other Sundance Offerings
description: LOS ANGELES  The Sundance Film Festival, aware that even the most crazed cinema fan cannot digest its girth in one sitting, likes to release its selections in bite-sized pieces. On Wednesday it was the competition lineup. On Thursday came the more esoteric stuff.

title: The Giving Spree | Claire Danes
description: Who: The actress Claire Danes.

title: Dont Worry About Social Security
description: It was surprising this morning to hear Senator Joe Manchin, Democrat of West Virginia, denounce President Obamas proposal to extend the payroll tax cut. Mr. Manchin, one of the very few Democrats to break with the president on this issue,said it would jeopardize the future of Social Security.

title: Dogs and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
description: Its well known that post-traumatic stress is one of the major problems facing many veterans returning from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. But now researchers are finding that a large number of military dogs may be grappling with the condition as well.

title: Watching the Iowa Ground Game
description: Since we first put out the call  for photos of presidential campaign material, weve received several dozen submissions from readers, many of them pictures of grass-roots support for Ron Paul, the Republican congressman from Texas. The billboard shown here is in Wisconsin, and was produced independent of Mr. Pauls presidential campaign.

title: Jane Addams H.S. Students Fear They Lack Credits to Graduate
Judges Rule Galleon Chief Must Go to Prison
description: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Kindles! iPods! Bid Now! (By Fax or Mail Only)
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has tried to keep up with its tech-inclined riders by posting helpful Twitter messages like how to get to the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade, updating its Facebook page as reliably as some teenagers, and creating a contest to let riders vote on their favorite apps.

title: Viewers Dont Hate New Fox Sitcom
description: The series premiere of I Hate My Teenage Daughter posted decent numbers for Fox on Wednesday, helping the network win the night in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Some 6.8 million viewers sampled the new sitcom while it held 75 percent of the 18-to-49 audience from its lead-in, The X Factor.

title: Movie Listings for Dec. 2-8
description: Movies

title: The Economists Progress: Better Living Through Fiscal Chemistry
description: As Sylvia Nasar tells it, the story of the dismal science of economics is a bright one of onward and upward progress. Never mind that Irving Fisher and John Maynard Keynes, two of the central figures in this book, were blindsided by the Great Crash of 1929. Never mind that lessons from the Great Depression and the warnings of a few farsighted economists were ignored by Wall Street in recent years, leading to another harrowing crash in 2008 and lingering fiscal woes.

title: Cain Says He Aided Accuser Without Telling His Wife
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated Yes, he gave her money. And no, his wife did not know.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Dec. 2-8
description: Pop

title: Winter Wonders | The Cool Class
description: We all revert a little during the holidays  we go home, childhood memories surface, and the next thing we know girlish uniforms and nave dresses have curious appeal. Here, Britains most popular sister-in-law, Pippa Middleton, takes to the skating rink in a coat with a modlike pouf skirt; the actress Sienna Miller gets gold stars for her prim A-line look; and Kate Moss sticks to the straight and narrow with a midthigh peacoat and high leather boots.

title: Write an Invitation? Be My Guest
description: My husband wants to throw a holiday party this year and promised to do all the work himself. He created the guest list, mostly from our neighborhood, and bought invitations that required him to fill in names and dates. The trouble is, he has the worst handwriting imaginable. He doesnt know some of our neighbors last names (or the correct spelling of many of their first names). Still, he got them out. Am I wrong to be bothered by his invitation etiquette? C. Z., San Francisco

title: Jazz Listings for Dec. 2-8
description: Jazz

title: Pakistani Court Bars Former Ambassador to U.S. From Travel
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Supreme Court in Pakistan barred Husain Haqqani, the former ambassador to the United States, on Thursday from leaving the country as the court initiated an investigation into a controversial memo that led to the envoys resignation and has caused a political storm in the country.

title: With an Asterisk, Chevrolet Volt Tops Consumer Reports Owner Satisfaction Survey
description: The Chevrolet Volt received the top score in the annual owner satisfaction survey by Consumer Reports.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Black Gold Records
description: A coffee and antiques shop in Carroll Gardens attracts vinyl hunters who return frequently to dig through the stores record collection.

description: THE death of the neighborhood record store has been mourned for decades now, but vinyl is alive and well on the southern edge of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.

description: Classical

description: AFTER months of rumor and speculation the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, has named a 28-year veteran of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to be its next director.

title: Carrin Is Fined $10,000 for Conflict Over Architect
description: Adolfo Carrin Jr., the former Bronx borough president and White House official, who is now a federal housing official and is a potential candidate for city comptroller, has been fined $10,000 by the citys Conflicts of Interest Board for using an architect on a personal renovation project who was also involved in a large housing development that required his approval.

title: The Palin Endorsement
description: Its what Mitt Romney needs right now, says S.E. Cupp:

title: Sentence of the Week: Holiday Weekend Election Results
description: The people have spoken, and we have an overwhelming winner: Megan Amram, the queen of Twitter one-liners, with her mash-up of Occupy Wall Street and Thomas Edison: We are the 99%  perspiration, to inspiration.

description: Lens: Samuel Aranda

title: New S.E.C. Tactics Yield Actions Against Hedge Funds
description: Financial regulators have long relied on outsiders to generate tips about potential fraud at hedge funds: disgruntled employees, news reports and disillusioned investors.

title: Programmer Raises Concerns About Phone-Monitoring Software
description: 7:18 p.m. | Updated  Adding comment from Apple.

title: $15 Million Gift Changes Miami Art Museum to Jorge M. Prez Art Museum
description: The Miami Art Museum will be renamed the Jorge M. Prez Art Museum of Miami-Dade County after a $15 million gift from Mr. Prez, the museum announced Thursday. Mr. Prez, a developer of multifamily residences, had already given $5 million to the museums capital campaign for its new downtown building, designed by Herzog & de Meuron and due to be completed in 2013.

title: Perry Zings Himself in New Ad
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been pummeled for a string of gaffes the past few weeks. But at least hes being a good sport about it.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Myanmar, Yemen and Uganda.

title: Ralph Fiennes Discusses 'Coriolanus'
description: Ralph Fiennes, the director and star of Coriolanus, talks about adapting Shakespeares play for the screen.

title: How to Police Geoengineering?
description: When people consider using engineering techniques to counter the effects of climate change, they usually think first about the technical difficulties involved. But a new report points out challenges that may be even more important: regulating the research on such technologies, and their potential deployment.

title: TimesCast | A Standoff in Bahrain
description: Dec. 1, 2011  The Ledes Robert Mackey interviews a Bahraini blogger who confronted riot police officers.

title: In Something Familiar With All Her Black
description: The actress Archie Panjabi, 39, won a 2010 Emmy for her role as the intriguing investigator Kalinda Sharma on the CBS drama The Good Wife. A native of England who grew up there and in Mumbai, India, she now lives in New York.

title: More on Cokes Role in a Shelved Bottle Ban
description: Jon Jarvis, the director of the National Park Service, has said that its decision to scuttle a planned ban on small plastic water bottles at Grand Canyon National Park had nothing to do with opposition from the Coca-Cola Company.

title: Duke Freshman Bloomed in Unlikely Place
description: A few years ago, Kelly Cobb, a freshman forward on the Duke womens soccer team, decided to go for a run in Chugiak, Alaska, her hometown. Her street was slicked with snow and ice, so she strapped ice grips over her shoes. She kept her eyes on the ground to avoid slipping and did not notice the black bear in the road until it was about 20 feet away. They stared at each other for a few seconds until the animal wandered off. Cobb ran home.

title: Spare Times for Dec. 2-8
description: Spare Times

title: TimesCast | Grammys Remain Relevant
description: December 1, 2011 - Ben Sisario on why the Grammys are still financially viable and relevant.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Dec. 2-8
description: Fantasia on the Loose

title: Also, No Sleeping Under Bridges
description: They just cant help themselves:

title: As Soldiers Leave Iraq, Bomb-Sniffing Dogs Stay
description: BAGHDAD  Dogs have emerged as the most valuable bomb detectors in Iraq and Afghanistan. As a result, some of the canines used by United States forces in Afghanistan are coming down with post-traumatic stress disorder. And in Iraq, just as the American army is leaving, a large shipment of American dogs has arrived, though the Iraqis have been slow to use them.

title: Unfurling a Thousand Years of Gods, Demons and Romance
description: Storytelling in Japanese Art, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a captivating combination of show and tell, read and look. Curatorially speaking, the exhibition takes us gently in hand and, through text panels, captions and diagrams, reveals the narrative side of Japanese art with memorable clarity.

title: YouTube Redesigns Its Web Site to Promote Personalized Video Channels
description: YouTube, though one of the most popular sites on the Web, has always been a bit overwhelming, with its avalanche of videos, more than 48 hours of which are uploaded each minute.

title: What a Scale Cant Measure
description: I HAVE outweighed most of the men Ive loved in my life. To be fair, most of them have been thin: my first boyfriend was 6-foot-2 and weighed just 135 pounds, and he was followed by a string of maddeningly slender sorts.

title: Russian Authorities Pressure Elections Watchdog
description: MOSCOW  With parliamentary elections only days away that are expected to reflect dwindling public support for Vladimir V. Putins party, Russian prosecutors have opened a case against the countrys only independent election monitoring organization.

title: Extended Interview with Zainab Alkhawaja
description: More of an interview with Zainab Alkhawaja, an opposition activist in Bahrain whose Angry Arabiya Twitter documents the protest movement.

title: Houses Sergeant-at-Arms Retires After 17 Years
description: Wilson Livingood, the sergeant-at-arms of the House of Representatives and known as Bill, is retiring after 17 years. Mr. Livingood, who spent 33 years in the United States Secret Service, was the first person to serve in the position with a significant law enforcement background; the position was historically filled by a political appointee.

title: The Physical Ecstasy of Worship, and the Travails of Those Who Tread Its Path
description: The spiritual utopian movement known as the Shakers has all but disappeared in America. (The groups tenet of celibacy does a number on recruitment.) But its allure for artists appears to be holding steady, with choreographers, including Twyla Tharp and Tero Saarinen, especially drawn to the Shaker tradition of worship through movement and song.

title: Madison Square Church Survives in Fragments
description: Madison Square Presbyterian Church was one of New Yorks shortest-lived houses of worship. Designed by Stanford White, this Palladian building opened on 24th Street in 1906 and was razed in 1919 to make way for insurance offices. Architects and preservationists mourned its demise and descended on the wreckage for souvenirs.

title: Out There | Miamis It Couple
description: Tropical, blinged-out hedonism aside, there is actually such a thing as community in Miami. After the droves who come for Art Basel pack up and go, there are folks  artists among them  who stick around, living and working here throughout the year. They do tend to be at their busiest during the fairs, and the artists Jim Drain and Naomi Fisher are no exception.

title: Starting a New Era With Graciousness, Taste and Tradition
description: When Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opened its annual season at City Center on Wednesday, it did so under a new artistic director, Robert Battle. But an Ailey gala is a set ritual, a glamorous fund-raiser as much about donors as about dancers, and in conforming to the standard of years past, this one sent a message of continuity.

title: Shadowy Lure of Scandinavia Fights the Bright Pull of Paris
description: The Armory Show was not the first or only ambitious effort to open American minds to European modern art in the early 20th century. Just two months before that shows New York debut in February 1913, another big exhibition of progressive art appeared here. Organized by the nascent American-Scandinavian Foundation, Exhibition of Contemporary Scandinavian Art offered more than 150 works by Danish, Norwegian and Swedish artists, many of whom favored Post-Impressionist, Expressionist and Symbolist modes that were still viewed with suspicion on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Funkadelic Sold Here, on Vinyl
description: The death of the neighborhood record store has been mourned for decades now, but vinyl is alive and well on the southern edge of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.

title: Shane Hope: Transubstrational: As a Smartmatter of Nanofacture
description: Winkleman

title: Mary Reid Kelley: The Syphilis of Sisyphus
description: Fredericks & Freiser

title: Lens: Moises
description: Lens: Moises

title: Hes the Hero of the People, and He Hates It
description: As soon as a thrilling Ralph Fiennes appears on Coriolanus, its clear why he chose this lesser-known Shakespeare tragedy for his directing debut. Dressed in camouflage fatigues, Mr. Fiennes  as the mythic Roman military hero first known as Caius Martius and later Coriolanus  enters a raucous scene and commands it with just a glare. What power! The citys hungry, rioting citizens, some carrying protest signs and one holding a camera phone, have descended, demanding food. Martius charges at them and then lets loose the contempt that will aid in his downfall: Whats the matter, you dissentious rogues, that, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, make yourselves scabs?

title: Bianca Beck: Body
description: Rachel Uffner Gallery

title: Ann Lislegaard: TimeMachine
description: Murray Guy

title: Tommy Thompson to Run for Senate
description: Tommy Thompson, Wisconsins longtime governor from an earlier political chapter, was expected to formally announce on Thursday evening that he will run for the United States senate next year.

title: A Rising Generation of Artistic Resistance
description: Nearly three years ago they were Younger Than Jesus. Now that generation of emerging artists (born between the mid-1970s and the mid-80s) is being called The Ungovernables, at least by curators at the New Museum, organizing its second Triennial.

title: Peter Thiels Founders Fund Raises $625 Million
description: There is no cash crunch for Silicon Valleys 1 percent.

title: Glocer, Chief Executive of Thomson Reuters, Is Being Replaced
description: Thomson Reuters said Thursday that it was replacing its chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, who had struggled to turn around the financial news and information service in an increasingly competitive market.

title: Looking Back at Lincoln
description: Once seen as a top luxury brand, Lincoln has been struggling to reinvent itself.

title: Ford Strives for Elegance in Lincoln Brand
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Every successful luxury car needs an identity for which consumers will pay a premium. Mercedes has its classic looks. Lexus epitomizes creature comforts. For BMW, performance is important.

title: For Mets, Bullpen Remains a Priority
description: The members of the Mets front office will head to Dallas this weekend for the baseballs winter meetings with their priorities in this still-developing free agent market unchanged since September.

title: An Activist Stands Her Ground in Bahrain
description: During a protest in Bahrain on Saturday, an American journalist named Matthew Cassel reported on Twitter that he had just witnessed something remarkable: a lone female protester who refused to move as police officers in riot gear charged past her, firing tear gas shells just a few feet from her head.

title: Just One Look | Michael Kors
description: The Michael Kors pre-fall collection, which was shown earlier this afternoon, paid homage to Ann Taylor  not the retail chain but the Southern socialite whom Kors described as Nan Kempner on the range. Graphic country looks came with built-in leather harnesses (rodeo-girl waistlines were key), appaloosa prints and a sinewy Chesterfield coat, all of it accessorized with cowboy hats and silver-studded satchels. Here, a dip-dyed goat-fur vest paired with wool riding shorts and a black leather bandolier bag is Southampton meets Santa Fe.

title: United Nations Says Unrest in Syria Amounts to Civil War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations declared Thursday that Syria was in a state of civil war, as the death toll from nearly nine months of bloodshed rose to more than 4,000 people and more soldiers were reported to have defected from the army to join an armed uprising against President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Tailgating Recipes: Puff Pastry Samosas
description: One thing weve learned about tailgating parties this year is that theyre inclusive  everybodys welcome. Now weve got to feed all of those people, even the vegetarians. Nithya Das, a Giants fan and vegetarian living in Brooklyn, has been to plenty of pregame festivities only to find brats and barbecue.

title: Songs About Friendship, Performed With His Pals
description: The pursuit of aloneness  in a deep-focus, self-obliterating sense  seems to mean a lot to the trumpeter Nate Wooley. An improviser with a tactile, patient, interrogatory approach to his craft, he belongs to the avant-garde jazz tradition but doesnt press the issue of lineage. His two most recent albums are solo trumpet recordings: sealed-off worlds of serenely disquieting technique, with and without electronics. His baseline tone is unvarnished and autumnal, but he does so much else, in the realm of scrunches and striations, that its a fair question whether he has a baseline tone at all.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Vulnerable Printers and Siris Politics
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web.

title: Pop Stars Dominate Major Grammy Categories
description: If the Grammys are a barometer of trends in popular music, then old-school pop songs about unrequited love made a comeback this year. The pop stars Adele and Bruno Mars dominated nominations for the top prizes  to be given out at the 54th annual Grammy Awards in February  while hip-hop and country musicians were largely shut out.

title: A Portrait of the Artist as Exuberant Collector
description: Selections From the Private Collection of Robert Rauschenberg at the Gagosian Gallery is a kind of mash note to the art world. Wending through spaces on three floors and numbering 130 items, it testifies both to the loose constellations of artists and to the congeries of artworks, objects and memorabilia that often form just in the process of living around artists, especially important, instinctively generous ones.

title: Assemblymans Chief of Staff Is Arrested in Bribery Case
description: The chief of staff to William F. Boyland Jr., an assemblyman arrested this week on charges of soliciting and accepting thousands of dollars in bribes from undercover federal agents posing as eager businessmen, was arrested on Thursday in connection with the alleged scheme.

title: Out There | Art Basel, More Parties and, Yes, Some Art
description: Wednesday morning, the 10th edition of Art Basel opened for preview. But first a stop at the Rubell Collection was in order for an experiential snack by the artist/cook/daughter Jennifer Rubell. Her breakfast installation this year is called Incubation, with yogurt incubating in a grid of sleek fermentation machines and honey perpetually drizzled from overhead  a commentary, according to the press release, on the creation of food, the creation of life and the creation of art, among other things, surely.

title: Womens Soccer College Cup Will Produce a First-Time Champion
description: The 2011 College Cup, for many, will be a weekend filled with firsts. The womens soccer N.C.A.A. semifinal games take place Friday evening at the Kennesaw State University Soccer Stadium in Kennesaw, Ga.  and though the field is filled with the traditionally successful soccer programs, none of the four remaining teams has yet won a national championship.

title: Julia Leigh on 'Sleeping Beauty'
