description: Julia Leigh, the director of the drama "Sleeping Beauty," discusses her film.

title: Benevolent Monarchs Of the Songbook Realm
description: To watch Michael Feinstein and Barbara Cook share musical lore onstage is the next best thing to attending a master class on how to sing popular standards. Ms. Cook, who actually conducts master classes on living inside a song while singing it, never hits a false emotional note. And Mr. Feinstein is the ultimate singing professor, whose perfect pitch coincides with a photographic memory for lyrics. Woe to the performer who takes liberties with words that he views almost as sacred texts.

title: Disparate Players, Evoking Familiar Sounds
description: Not so long ago female musicians effort to gain entry to major professional orchestras was a subject for hot debate. Today, however, women constitute a healthy proportion among most American orchestras and a majority in more than a few. Progress remains to be made, not least on the conducting podium. But for the most part the situation appears to have improved dramatically for rank-and-file players and even for principals.

title: Newt 2.0
description: A resurgent Newt Gingrich tops the polls in the campaign to be the Republican candidate for president.

title: State Fracking Hearings Drew 6,000, N.Y. Says
description: Proposed regulations governing the natural gas drilling process known as horizontal hydraulic fracturing drew 6,000 people to four public hearings in New York State and have so far elicited more than 10,600 written public comments, the state Department of Environmental Conservation said on Thursday.

title: An Illicit Romance, a Revenge Wrought and an Escape From Egypt
description: Some people still find Rossinis serious operas a little, well, tedious. Even the writer of the program synopsis for Mose et Pharaon (Moses and Pharaoh), which the Collegiate Chorale and the American Symphony Orchestra performed at Carnegie Hall under James Bagwell on Wednesday evening, evinced frustration with the operas plot. It takes another three acts to let the people go, he or she dryly summarized after describing the opening.

title: Hard-Core Gamers Try Building Social Games
description: Social game makers like Zynga have gotten hundreds of millions of people to play their games, but one of the big raps on FarmVille, CityVille and other Facebook time-wasters is that theyre too shallow to appeal to hard-core players.

title: Objectification Is Also in the Eye of the Beheld
description: Sexuality can be a puzzle  just ask Carl Jung, the kinky and conflicted psychoanalyst played by Michael Fassbender in A Dangerous Method, or Brandon, the sex addict played by Michael Fassbender in Shame. Or, if you insist on exploring the complexities of eros in a new movie not starring Mr. Fassbender, you might check out Sleeping Beauty, Julia Leighs sly and elusive film, which is itself something of a puzzle.

title: For Wall Street Watchdog, All Grunt Work, Little Glory
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.  Last week, when a former Boston Red Sox infielder faced accusations of insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission got credit for levying a $100,000 fine. The Department of Justice in May heralded a guilty plea from a one-time senior executive at the Nasdaq Stock Market who traded on secret information. And earlier this year, after a lawyer was accused of stealing insider tidbits, federal prosecutors in New Jersey boasted of the arrest.

title: Foot Stomping in Bluegrass Time
description: AFTER Jennifer Shaouls tae kwon do instructor died five years ago, she struggled to find a replacement for the exercise she so dearly loved. Ms. Shaoul found an unlikely substitute this fall: clog dancing.

title: Punishing Wrongdoing on Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Storytelling in Japanese Art
description: Images from the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: At Thomson Reuters, Corporate P.R. Mirrors Real Life
description: In an unfortunate bit of symbolism, Thomson Reuters is sponsoring a team race to the South Pole at the same time that the fortunes of its chief executive, Thomas Glocer, appear to be headed south, as well.

title: Opponent of Antipiracy Bill Backs Counterproposal
description: LOS ANGELES  Senator Ron Wyden, who has said that he would filibuster the antipiracy Protect I.P. Act because it threatens a free Internet, now has a counterproposal on the table: let the International Trade Commission go after those who sell pirated copyrighted material on the Web from abroad.

title: Theater Listings for Dec. 2-8
description: Theater

title: Winged Migrants in Their Brooklyn Pied--Terre
description: THERE are rumors of an owl, Michele Dreger told me in a hushed voice, as if the great bird might hear her and be scared off. Maybe, maybe, there might be, maybe, an owl.

title: The Violence That Japanese Gangsters Do: Betrayal Among the Yakuza
description: In Outrage, a new yakuza story from Takeshi Kitano, the assaults on the human body are frequent, brutal and at times accompanied by cruel comedy. One man nearly loses his sight; another surely loses his hearing (chopsticks go where none should); and a third suffers a gruesome, teeth-shattering assault during a dental exam, an attack that suggests that Mr. Kitano may have watched Marathon Man in the decade since he directed Brother, his last yakuza film. Whatever their inspirations, these baroque spasms of violence  evoking see, hear and speak no evil  are just a few of the tortures that he rains down on his characters like a vengeful, mocking god.

title: Weekend Miser
description: With the holidays coming up, the Miser has been on the lookout for entertainment to satisfy both visiting in-laws and antsy children on school break. Here is a roundup of group-friendly winter activities that will raise your spirits without gouging your budget:

title: Negotiations Under Way for Special Session in Albany on Budget Shortfall
description: Facing an increasingly worrisome budget outlook, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders are in negotiations to return to Albany for a special session later this month, an official briefed on the negotiations said on Thursday.

title: The Blood Runs Freely, but the Dogs Cant
description: This being the season for Oscar puffery and pretention, its also the time of the year when moviegoers who yearn for more action and less talk can be forgiven for thinking that whats missing from the big screen is a good beat down. It could use one: this hasnt been a memorable year for cinematic action, aside from a quicksilver move here and there and that gone-in-60-seconds moment in Drive when Ryan Gosling glides a car into park. But now theres The Yellow Sea, a rush of a movie from South Korea that slips and slides from horror to humor on rivers of blood and offers the haunting image of a man, primitive incarnate, beating other men with an enormous, gnawed-over meat bone.

title: Bloggingheads: The 3-3-3 Plan
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Mickey Kaus of kausfiles debate raising taxes and the Occupy movement.

title: Perfectly Perfect | Tory Burch
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Off the Mat, Into Court: Lawsuit Pits Bikram and Yoga to the People
description: Thursdays 11:30 a.m. session at the Bikram Yoga NYC studio in the Flatiron District began as usual: a handful of half-dressed students slowly flapped their elbows as they decelerated their breath and stared at themselves in the mirror. After paying as much as $25 each, they began their mindful workouts in the 105-degree Torture Chamber, while outside on Fifth Avenue, pedestrians scurried past in coats.

title: The Solyndra Loan Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Fury, Up Close and Personal, at the Lingering Effects From the BP Oil Spill
description: The Big Fix is an enraged expos of the crimes of Big Oil, specifically BP, which has been accused of negligence and of taking shortcuts that helped lead to the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon rig off the Louisiana coast in April 2010. Eleven workers on the platform died and nearly five million barrels of oil spilled into the Gulf of Mexico over the next five months, killing vast numbers of marine animals before much of it washed ashore, where it wrought incalculable damage.

title: In Egypt, No Alliance With Ultraconservatives, Islamist Party Says
description: CAIRO  The Muslim Brotherhoods political arm on Thursday distanced itself from a more conservative Islamist party as early vote tallies indicated that the two factions would claim the two largest roles in the first Parliament elected since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: French President Warns of Dire Consequences if Euro Crisis Goes Unsolved
description: PARIS  Saying that he wanted to tell the truth to the French people, President Nicolas Sarkozy said Thursday night that Europe could be swept away by the euro crisis if it does not change. He said that Europe would have to make crucial choices in the next few weeks, and that France and Germany together were supporting a new treaty to tighten fiscal discipline and promote economic convergence in the euro zone.

title: Dear Humans: The Planet Needs Your Help
description: Sturla Gunnarssons Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie is constructed around a speech that its Japanese-Canadian subject  an engaging, erudite scientist, educator, broadcaster and eco-activist  calls his legacy lecture. The talk, given in Vancouver last December, is a dire warning delivered in a reasonable, friendly voice about the imminent destruction of the biosphere that sustains humankind. Dr. Suzukis upbeat tone is the spoonful of sugar that makes the bitter medicine go down.

title: For Women Only; Wear Your Sorority Pin
description: THE soaring Beekman Tower Hotel, at First Avenue and 49th Street, was an out-of-place landmark for years, until the United Nations went up. These days its dramatic Art Deco profile is not quite as prominent, a streamlined orange brick shaft built in 1928 as Panhellenic House, a residence for college women. The 61-year-old developer was Emily Eaton Hepburn, a real estate novice who created one of New Yorks most distinctive skyscrapers.

title: The Loneliness of a Brothers Caregiver
description: Some fine performances and an embrace of understatement make Matthew Leutwylers oddly titled Answers to Nothing a respectable entry in the multiple-stories-that-interlock genre. Its a bit jarring that the event around which these delicately told vignettes coalesce  the kidnapping of a girl  seems borrowed from a cheesy police thriller, but the film has its satisfactions nonetheless.

title: The Dogs of War
description: The number of working dogs on active duty has risen to 2,700, from 1,800 in 2001, and the training school at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, Texas, prepares about 500 dogs a year.

title: The Time-Is-Now Apartment
description: IN an attempt to keep her living costs down in the dozen years she had lived in New York, Jessie Weber lived nomadically.

title: Higher Loan Limits, Again, for Pricey Markets
description: LESS than two months after lowering the maximum loan amount that could be backed by the Federal Housing Administration, lawmakers in Washington reversed course just before the Thanksgiving holiday and once again raised that limit, offering home buyers more financing options in a tight credit market.

title: Georgia Has a Chance to Put Its Mark on the SEC
description: ATHENS, Ga.  In Southeastern Conference play this season, No. 1 Louisiana State won its eight games by an average of 26.6 points, while No. 2 Alabamas seven victories came by an average of 29.5. The reason for this dominance was simple: the Tigers and the Crimson Tide are ruthless at the point of attack, that spot where linemen crash into linemen and where being bigger and meaner is often the difference.

title: Zero-Energy Construction Crosses the Ocean
description: ENVIRONMENTALLY friendly and conservation-minded building techniques have been around for decades. But only in recent years have standards, like the LEED certification from the U.S. Green Building Council, been developed for builders to follow.

title: Daughters Bittersweet Memoir of a Humanitarian Mother
description: The actress Dina Rosenmeiers self-distributed documentary debut begins, innocently enough, as a work of impeccably trite ambitions. Retracing the jet-setting itineraries of Jessie Rosenmeier, a Ladies Circle humanitarian with a philanthropic interest in adorable children, A Journey in My Mothers Footsteps retreads some familiar vanity-project trajectories: armchair travelogue, bittersweet filial memoir, feel-good humanitarian crusade.

title: City Councilmans Lawyer Calls Charges Speculation
description: During closing arguments in the federal corruption trial against City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook on Thursday, a defense lawyer urged the jury to weigh 30 years of public service against so-called evidence.

title: Giants See Opening vs. Packers: Vulnerability to Big Plays
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On the first play of the fourth quarter Monday night, Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz knew right away that he had the opportunity to hit what he called the receivers equivalent of a grand slam.

title: Lacrosse Player Comes Undone, and Grows
description: Ostensibly an inspirational film about a high schoolers development of character, A Warriors Heart is factory-issue jingoism, yielding no surprises and frightfully few insights. Conor Sullivan (Kellan Lutz of the Twilight franchise, toting six-pack abs and an empty emotional quiver) is a lacrosse player from California newly arrived at a Virginia prep school. A showboating hothead lacking teamwork skills, he has much to learn. Why, hes even mystified by the sight of a teammate praying before a game. (Some classmates facetiously address him by the nickname West Coast; others call him, yes, Captain America.)

title: G.M. Offers to Buy Back Hybrid Volts From Owners
description: DETROIT  In a rare move, General Motors said Thursday that it would buy back Chevrolet Volts if owners were concerned about fire risks. It also promised to comply with any changes to its battery pack recommended by federal regulators.

title: School Lunches
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Evaluations
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Heavy Rain Causes Floors to Buckle

title: Walkable Steps Into Spotlight
description: WALKABILITY is an asset of an increasing number of Island communities as the fabric of suburbia changes, and it was a must for Judy Rosenthal, a health care writer from Great Neck, when she recently sought a new home for her mother not far from her own.

title: An Intimate Tour of a Gleaming German Nuclear Plant
description: If The China Syndrome had been directed by Frederick Wiseman, it might have looked a little like Under Control, a gleamingly intimate tour of German nuclear power plants and the policies that sustain them.

title: Some Like It Hothouse
description: THE sprawling 19th-century greenhouse owned by Dr. Alvin Friedman-Kien in Garrison is more than just a place to start tomatoes in advance of spring. With its wicker and wrought-iron furniture, a dining table that seats 12 and a fireplace, the 55-foot-long greenhouse is also an inviting backdrop for entertaining friends.

title: Ex-Governor Is Said to Be Focal Point of Inquiry
description: PHOENIX  Bill Richardson, the former governor of New Mexico who ran for president in 2008, is being investigated by a federal grand jury for possible violations of campaign finance laws, according to people with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: Lincolns P.R. Coup
description: In addition to the domestic challenge it presented, the fledgling Confederacy posed a foreign policy dilemma for Abraham Lincolns administration. The Confederacy hoped to use its position as a crucial source of cotton to secure recognition from foreign powers and boost its legitimacy, and it sent commissioners abroad to sway other countries into supporting its cause.

title: Can Russia Help Us Withdraw From Afghanistan?
description: Washington

title: Are We Getting Some Money?
description: Following are excerpts from the criminal complaint against Ry-Ann Hermon, the chief of staff to Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr., in which Ms. Hermon is recorded asking a cooperating witness about money. A few days later, another conversation was recorded between Ms. Hermon and an undercover federal agent.

title: Firsthand Dangers of Reporters in Combat Zones
description: It didnt used to be like this, says a correspondent interviewed in the documentary Under Fire: Journalists in Combat. Once upon a time, Ian Stewart says, you could put press up on your window, and youd be fine, youd be safe.

title: Help Line Open for Jets Ailing Offense
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  While the Jets offense has sputtered this season, Tom Moore has been watching from his home in South Carolina, where he works as the teams offensive consultant.

title: A New Google Venture, and Another Web Boundary Line Is Nudged
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In another foray into commerce, Google is working on a delivery service that would let people order items from local stores on the Web and receive them at their homes or offices within a day.

title: Raids Dont Keep Tunnel City From Humming Underground
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  Squatting and sweating inside the latest drug tunnel found here in this Pacific border city, it was easy to understand the amazement expressed by Mexican and American officials. This one was a stunner.

title: Linked Stories From the Months of the Rwanda Massacre
description: From my heart, I ask for forgiveness, a Hutu killer says near the end of the weighty Kinyarwanda. Forgiveness would have to be a precious natural resource in Rwanda in 1994, after the genocide that left more than 800,000 dead, mostly Tutsis. Those atrocities are the horrific backdrop of the six linked story lines in this dry but thoughtful drama.

title: Court Says Some Donors of Stem Cells Can Be Paid
description: A federal appeals court ruling on Thursday could make it easier for patients with diseases like leukemia to find matching bone marrow donors.

title: Help With a Down Payment
description: WITH most lenders requiring home buyers to put down at least 20 percent  and sometimes, with more expensive properties, an even greater amount  the best holiday gift some people might receive would be help with the down payment.

title: Santa Ana Winds, Unusually Strong, Rattle More Than Nerves in California
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Raymond Chandler famously described the winds here as those hot dry Santa Anas that come down through the mountain passes and curl your hair and make your nerves jump and your skin itch.

title: Barbara van Beuren
description: Ms. van Beuren, 55, is a managing partner of Anbau Enterprises, a Manhattan developer that specializes in for-sale residential real estate. The companys projects have included 110 Central Park South and 120 West 72nd Street.

title: Two Research in Motion Employees Fined for Disruption on Plane
description: The police say that drunken unruliness by two executives of the BlackBerry maker Research in Motion forced the diversion and delay of a Toronto-to-Beijing flight on Monday. The two pleaded guilty to a criminal count of mischief and were suspended from their positions pending an investigation.

title: A Big Uranium Deposit, and a Big Debate on Mining It
description: CHATHAM, Va.  Atop Coles Hill, a crown of oak trees encircle an old plantation house from which generations of Coles have looked down gently sloping lawns to fields that once grew tobacco.

title: As a Financial Center, London Needs an Air Hub
First-Race Terrors and Last-Place Humiliations at a Horse-Racing School
description: At 5 a.m. in a very special boarding school not far from Paris, circus music blares from a bedside alarm clock. Im ill, a sleepy boy moans, hoping to postpone the rigors of his day. Once we have seen those rigors, we can hardly blame him.

title: For Jobless, Little Hope of Restoring Better Days
description: People across the working spectrum suffered job losses in recent years: bricklayers and bookkeepers as well as workers in manufacturing and marketing.

title: Coachs Plan to Rouse Ovechkin Produces Little
description: WASHINGTON  Two games into the new regime here, anxiety about the decline of the Capitals star Alex Ovechkin has yet to subside. On Thursday, Washington lost, 2-1, to Sidney Crosby and the Pittsburgh Penguins, the Capitals eighth defeat in their last 10 games.

title: As Tastes Change in Harlem, Old-Look Liquor Store Stirs a Fight
description: Many neighbors agree that their genteel enclave of brownstones in the heart of Harlem does need a shop where they can pick up, say, a good cabernet for a dinner party.

title: Gun Nuts in a Rut
description: PHOENIX  When it became clear in the early fall of 2008 that Barack Obama, son of a Kansan and a Kenyan, would be the 44th President of the United States, many citizens rushed to their gun shops, stocked up on ammo and camo, and tried to fortify their nests with all manner of lethal weapons.

title: For-Profit Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharing a Guarded Legacy
description: WHEN a curator from the Palazzo delle Esposizioni in Rome contacted Betty and George Woodman a dozen years ago, he made what would be, for most parents, a welcome request. He wanted to borrow from the Woodmans cache of rare vintage prints by their daughter  the photographer Francesca Woodman, who died in 1981  to mount a show of her work.

title: Chicanery Far Beyond a $156 Bagel
description: In the annals of deranged expense accounts, a City Council members claim of $156 for a bagel may be small in scale, but worth every cent in audacity.

title: After Pushing Gay Marriage, Cuomo Is Thanked With Money
description: In the aftermath of New Yorks legalization of same-sex marriage this summer, gay men and lesbians lionized Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, showering him with gratitude, praise and awards. Now, they are rewarding him with something more tangible: campaign cash.

title: Senate Declines to Clarify Rights of American Qaeda Suspects Arrested in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday decided to leave unanswered a momentous question about constitutional rights in the war against Al Qaeda: whether government officials have the power to arrest people inside the United States and hold them in military custody indefinitely and without a trial.

title: Health Care for a Changing Work Force
description: Big institutions are often slow to awaken to major social transformations. Microsoft was famously late to grasp the importance of the Internet. American auto manufacturers were slow to identify the demand for fuel-efficient cars. And today, the United States government is making a similar mistake: it still doesnt seem to recognize that Americans no longer work the way they used to.

title: Syracuse Criticized for Its Handling of Sexual Abuse Case
description: When Bobby Davis sent an anonymous e-mail to Syracuse University in 2005, saying that the associate mens basketball coach Bernie Fine had molested him, the university asked its legal counsel to start an investigation.

title: Ludens Recasts the Lozenge, Emphasizing Taste and Versatility
description: NOBODY wants to be on the tip of consumers tongues more than a lozenge maker, and Ludens, the brand known for its wild cherry flavor, is renewing its efforts to do just that.

title: Contractors Work Faulted at U.S. Pension Guarantor
description: A small company with a big contract to determine how much the government pays people whose pension plans have failed got the numbers wrong, a new audit has found.

title: Democrats See an Advantage in Debate Over Payroll Tax
description: WASHINGTON  After struggling all year for an economic message that resonates broadly with Americans in hard times, President Obama and Congressional Democrats have settled on one they believe can carry through next years election as they use a fight over payroll taxes to portray Republicans as defenders of the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.

title: 18 Months After Vote, Belgium Has Government
description: BRUSSELS  The financial markets have finally done what 18 months of talks, a large protest march and a series of bizarre demonstrations failed to do: broken Belgiums political deadlock.

title: The Spirit of Enterprise
description: Why are nations like Germany and the U.S. rich? Its not primarily because they possess natural resources  many nations have those. Its primarily because of habits, values and social capital.

title: The Ball Still Belongs to the Stars
description: In one of the N.B.A. lockouts signature moments, Commissioner David Stern wagged a scornful finger and Dwyane Wade snarled back. The testy exchange offered a convenient prism for viewing the labor crisis.

title: The Tantalizing Lure of the Outsider Candidate
description: In what may yet be the last turn in Herman Cains bizarre journey through the world of presidential politics, the candidate will return home to Atlanta this weekend for a meeting with his wife and family, so they can decide whether it still makes sense for Mr. Cain to continue his campaign.

title: For Afghan Woman, Justice Runs Into Unforgiving Wall of Custom
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When the Afghan government announced Thursday that it would pardon a woman who had been imprisoned for adultery after she reported that she had been raped, the decision seemed a clear victory for the many women here whose lives have been ground down by the Afghan justice system.

title: Killing the Euro
description: Can the euro be saved? Not long ago we were told that the worst possible outcome was a Greek default. Now a much wider disaster seems all too likely.

title: German Fears About Inflation Stall Bold Steps in Debt Crisis
description: BERLIN  Norbert Schulze was not yet born when the hyperinflation of the 1920s deeply scarred the German psyche. But he still remembers the Reichsmark notes denominated in millions and billions that years later were tucked into a box with the familys old black-and-white photographs.

title: The Quiet Regulators
description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, Wall Street's nonprofit self-regulator, has quietly been building a small army of market police in the wake of the financial crisis.

title: After Fetus Is Found in Trash, a Rare Charge of Self-Abortion
description: A superintendent in Washington Heights was tying up a garbage bag on Tuesday evening when he felt an errant piece of plastic. He reached into the bag to put it in the recycling bin, and to his horror, he said, thats when I saw the baby.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Bill of Rights Doesnt Come Cheap
description: Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Valentine and Red Sox Start Afresh
description: BOSTON

title: Bonnie & Clyde
description: Photos from the new Broadway musical.

title: Friday: Ones Who Might Get You Into Hot Water
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  The comedian Emo Philips once did a bit about using chocolate Easter bunnies as a diagnostic tool in psychotherapy. I dont remember exactly how it went, but to paraphrase, he was told that the first part he bit off would clue the therapist in to where his problem lies: if he bit off the ears first, for example, it meant that he was relatively normal; if he bit off the feet first, it meant he felt he wasnt getting anywhere in life. His reply: What if I bite out the eyes and scream Stop staring at me!?

title: Lebanon Sends Funds to Court
description: The United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the killing of a former Lebanese prime minister said Thursday that it had received the long-overdue half of its budget from Beirut, about $32 million. Many in Lebanons government, dominated by the militant group Hezbollah, had opposed cooperating with the court. The court has indicted four Hezbollah members as suspects in the 2005 killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. Hezbollahs leader, Hassan Nasrallah, said Thursday that although he disagreed with the payment, his party and its allies would not stop it. We reject the legality and constitutionality of financing the court or cooperating with it in any way, but we will not cause a problem in the country, and we will serve the higher national interest, he said in a televised address. He has promised, however, that the government will never arrest the indicted Hezbollah members. The court is debating whether to try them in absentia.

title: The Fed and the Euro
description: The Federal Reserves move on Wednesday to make it easier for European banks to acquire dollars shows that American policy makers understand the gravity of Europes turmoil and will do what they can to prevent a financial collapse across the Atlantic. European leaders, however, seem paralyzedand, even at this point, fail to share the Feds sense of urgency.

title: Insight Into Dropping of Charges for Developer
description: A newly released court transcript offers an unusually frank statement by a federal prosecutor in Manhattan about why the government agreed to drop charges against a real estate developer who was a co-defendant in the broad public corruption case that ensnared State Senator Carl Kruger.

title: Lots of Company After Lonely Session
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  When a team official entered the press room at the Knicks training center shortly after noon on Thursday and informed everyone that Carmelo Anthony was in the building, about half of the two dozen reporters who were waiting for some Knick, any Knick, to talk to jumped up in anticipation. And then they waited some more.

title: Woeful, Cynical Misconduct
description: The depth of prosecutorial misconduct in the 2008 trial of Senator Ted Stevens is shocking. An inquiry ordered by Judge Emmet Sullivan of Federal District Court in Washington has found serious, widespread and at times intentional concealment of evidence by the Justice Department that could have helped Mr. Stevens prove his innocence. The department has a separate inquiry that must point the way to repairing the public integrity section, which is responsible for prosecuting public officials.

title: Savoring Bogs and Moose, Fearing Theyll Vanish as the Adirondacks Warm
description: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y.  Jerry Jenkins, an ecologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society, narrates with encyclopedic precision the serene, timeless landscape of the Osgood River, as he moves past it with each dip of his canoe paddle.

title: Exam Cheating on Long Island Hardly a Secret
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  The suspected test takers came from prominent, respected families, some of them in financial distress  among the five facing felony charges were the sons of a well-known lawyer, the president of the local library board and a wealthy philanthropic family.

title: Sneaking Up on Defenses, Until Hes Past Them
description: GREEN BAY  Eleven games into his breakout season, Green Bay Packers receiver Jordy Nelson did not need a calculator or even his fingers to count the number of times that he had faced double coverage this year.

title: Louis Silverstein, Who Gave a Bolder and Airier Look to The Times, Dies at 92
description: When The New York Times began publishing on Sept. 18, 1851, it was the New-York Daily Times.  without a The but with a period. When the newspaper took its present name six years later, the hyphen stayed (until 1896), and so did the period, until 1967. That was the year that Louis Silverstein, with the nervous approval of his tradition-minded superiors, got rid of it, ending more than a decade of debate.

title: Bach to Brooklyn
description: When she first tied up an old steel barge next to the Brooklyn Bridge 35 years ago, curious longshoremen noted tiny, mop-haired Olga Bloom coming and going with a violin, mysterious as a Magritte figure. But Ms. Bloom soon charmed the men into hefting a grand piano aboard. She repaid them with what was one of her first classical musicales by the fireplace tucked in the wood-paneled coffee barge.

title: Armed and Amorous, Committing Cold-Blooded Musical
description: That Clyde Barrow is such a cutup. Why, the boy will do most anything to stir up his sluggish fellow Americans: slap at them, tickle them, shoot them in cold blood. Hell even punch his fist clean through a wall and drive a big old car right onto the stage, just to try to get a rise out of somebody. But Clyde, honey, taint nothing you can do to raise the pulse of something thats as near to dead as the show youre in.

title: Egypts Vote
description: Egyptians proved their mettle again this week by turning out in huge numbers to begin electing their first freely chosen Parliament. To get to this point, they had to force the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, and tens of thousands braved a vicious crackdown in recent days to protest the armys hold on power. Voters showed courage and will to move to build a new democratic order.

title: Drilling Down: Archive of Oil and Gas Leases
description: The New York Times has collected over 110,000 oil and gas leases and related documentation through open records requests sent about hydraulic fracturing and land leases in more than six dozen counties in which the practice is common.

title: A Laymans Guide to Lease Terms
description: Lawyers and consumer advocates say that leases often contain or lack fine print that landowners should not overlook in signing leases. Here are some examples of key clauses that landowners have come to regret:

title: Learning Too Late of the Perils in Gas Well Leases
description: After Scott Ely and his father talked with salesmen from an energy company about signing the lease allowing gas drilling on their land in northeastern Pennsylvania, he said he felt certain it required the company to leave the property as good as new.

title: Documenting Climate Change in the Adirondacks
description: Jerry Jenkins, an ecologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society, has been documenting climate change closer to home, specifically in the Adirondacks.

title: Shop at Work, and Save America?
Behind the Scenes of the Front Offices Decision
description: BOSTON  Larry Lucchino, the Boston Red Sox president, recently took Ben Cherington, the teams new general manager, to a conference in Hartford to meet Bobby Valentine for the first time.

title: Franois Lesage, Who Led Embroidery Atelier, Dies at 82
description: Franois Lesage, who for more than a half-century led the embroidery atelier that has served couture designers from Charles Frederick Worth through Karl Lagerfeld of Chanel, died on Thursday in Versailles, France. He was 82.

title: Republican Leaders Still Seem Torn About Romney
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Republican leaders remain bullish about their partys chances of winning the White House, but after spending much of this year unsuccessfully trying to recruit new candidates, they are coming to the conclusion that their eventual nominee will carry substantial flaws into the general election.

title: How the Auto Industry Fared
description: Winners and losers in the auto industry.

title: Yankees Rivera to Have Surgery
description: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera said Thursday that he would have surgery on Friday to remove polyps from his vocal cords, an ailment that for the last month had bothered him whenever he tried to speak.

title: Leader Says Qaeda Holds Abducted American Aid Worker
description: WASHINGTON  The leader of Al Qaeda said Thursday that the terrorist group was holding a veteran American aid worker kidnapped in Pakistan in August and demanded the end of airstrikes on militants and the release of prisoners held in the West in return for his freedom.

title: After Opening a Door, Watching Anxiety Fade
description: Atom Thomas leafed through his little black sketchpad filled with intricate pencil and ink drawings of landscapes, street scenes and portraits of family members and celebrities like Jay-Z and Michael Jackson. He stopped on one drawing of an angel, wings spread, standing atop a cloud.

title: Shades of the Old Woods on a Windy Day
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  Tiger Woods is the native Californian, but K. J. Choi of South Korea was the golfer who felt more at home Thursday during the first round of the Chevron World Challenge.

title: Lawsuit Is Settled in Penn State Case
description: A lawsuit by one of the accusers in the Penn State sexual abuse case, which was meant to prevent the Second Mile charity founded by Jerry Sandusky from transferring its assets, was settled Thursday.

title: South African Court Invalidates a Presidential Pick
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Jacob Zuma  at odds with the judiciary and critics who accuse him of improperly appointing loyalists to public posts  suffered a blow on Thursday when an appeals court ruled that he had violated the Constitution two years ago with his highly contentious pick for the countrys top prosecutor.

title: The Hague: New Prosecutor Picked for International Criminal Court
description: A Gambian lawyer, Fatou Bensouda, is expected to succeed Luis Moreno-Ocampo next June as chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague. She emerged as the consensus candidate after the only other finalist, Mohamed Chande Othman of Tanzania, agreed to withdraw, diplomats said. All six cases before the young court are linked to African nations, and the majority of the 119 countries that recognize the court had favored an African candidate. Elections for the prosecutor and six judges will be held at the members annual meeting on Dec. 12. Mrs. Bensouda, 50, has been deputy prosecutor at the court, and served at the United Nations tribunal dealing with the genocide in Rwanda and as minister of justice of Gambia.

title: Kentucky Sinks the Red Storm
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  The St. Johns players gathered for strength through the flashing lights and pounding bass rhythms of the Kentucky Wildcats intimidating introductions. They faced the biggest challenge of the season in their first game on the road Thursday night, coming off a Nov. 26 loss to Northeastern to take on the No. 1-ranked Wildcats.

title: China: Explosion at Bank Kills 2
description: A explosion shook a branch of the China Construction Bank late Thursday afternoon in Wuhan, a provincial capital in south-central China, a municipal police official there said, and state media reported that at least two people were killed and more than 10 were injured.

title: Christa Wolf Dies at 82; Wrote of the Germanys
description: Christa Wolf, a leading writer from the former East Germany whose novels, stories and essays explored the weight of history on ordinary individuals, especially and controversially including her own struggles with the legacy of Nazism and life in a Communist society, died Thursday in Berlin. She was 82.

title: Germany: Funds Increased for Jewish Organization
description: The German government will double its financing of the countrys Jewish community from next year on, the Central Council of Jews in Germany said in a statement. The group will receive an annual grant of $13.4 million a year, twice the current amount, for rebuilding Jewish life in Germany. The financing is part of an agreement that replaces a 2003 accord that gave the Jewish organization the same legal status as the major churches. The funds will be earmarked for the integration of Jewish immigrants; the training of rabbis, cantors and teachers; the support of religious research centers; and work with young people.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 76
description: Scared to death by Occupy Wall Street, theRepublican strategist Frank Luntz shared some strategies for discussing the protest movement at the Republican Governors Association convention Wednesday. Among his suggestions: dont say capitalism (Im trying to get that word removed), and when referring to proposed tax increases on the 1 percent, call it taking from the rich, rather than taxing. [Yahoos The Ticket]

title: Names Proposed for 2 New Elements on Periodic Table
description: Add two names to the periodic table of elements, although you may want to write them in pencil for now.

title: Craigslist Used in Deadly Ploy to Lure Victims in Ohio
description: AKRON, Ohio  They were men thrown hard against the rocks of bad fortune  out of work, their marriages broken, their youth, with its possibilities, behind them.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/02/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/02/2011

title: Formerly Outlaws, Now Artists of Renown
description: Before they were in, they were out. Before crowds swamped the galleries and celebrities wrote checks, KC Ortiz and Jordan Nickel wielded spray cans, hopped fences, provoked the citizenry, got arrested  all to make Chicagos streets, rooftops and el tracks their canvas.

title: Word of the Day | deciduous
description: deciduous \di-si-j-ws, -j-s\ adjective

title: As Tax Receipts Lag, Another Hole Opens in Budget
description: Like any government budget, Mayor Rahm Emanuels first annual fiscal plan projects exactly how much the administration expects to reap in 2012 from the recently approved tax and fee increases, including the municipal tax on every hotel room stay.

title: Education Group Tries to Rebound After Diatribe
description: An Oregon-based education group, whose deep pockets and skillful maneuvering made it a surprising powerhouse player in Springfield earlier this year, is regrouping after an embarrassing outburst by its founder forced a leadership shuffle within the organization.

title: Manuel Gilman, Influential Racetrack Veterinarian, Dies at 91
description: Dr. Manuel Gilman, a veterinarian whose procedure for examining thoroughbred racehorses in New York became standard at racetracks around the country, improving safety for horses and jockeys and bolstering the sports integrity for bettors, died on Nov. 25 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 91.

title: In Detroit, an Effort to Prevent a State Takeover
description: Facing mounting pressure from Michigans governor to solve Detroits financial crisis, Mayor Dave Bing on Thursday stood beside union representatives and City Council members in a public show of unity, a last-ditch effort to keep the states largest city out of state control.

title: Problems With Credits at School in the Bronx
description: The chances that a student at Jane Addams High School for Academic Careers in the Bronx would graduate in four years were already poor, but seniors there said this week that they had been told of a new obstacle: a problem with credits that could cost some of them their diplomas.

title: My Kind of Town, and Now Maybe Your Kind of Domain Name
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
description: The parliamentary panel drafting the anti-corruption bill has abruptly decided to exclude Indias graft-ridden lower bureaucracy, the six million municipal workers, policemen and clerks who interact most with the average person, from the proposed Lokpal bill. (Times of India). Expect the anti-corruption group Team Anna, which had fought for a tougher version of the Lokpal, to accuse the government of trying to pass a toothless law.

title: Child Labors Fashionable Face
description: Chetan and Sarju wear low-waist, ice-wash, medium-skinny jeans that cost 500 rupees (about $9.60); open-neck cotton shirts with the sleeves rolled up to their elbows (150 rupees); and medium high-top canvas sneakers (300 rupees). Chetans sneakers are pink and inscribed with the letters D&G. Sarjus blue sneakers simply say Sports. The 17-year-old cousins are from the Mumbai suburb of Jogeshwari.

title: Can We Get Serious?
description: To select someone worthy of sitting in George Washingtons chair, sleeping in Abraham Lincolns bed and governing from Franklin Roosevelts desk, Americans crave a substantial presidential campaign, as long as they dont have to endure too many boring speeches. Like every human decision-making process, presidential campaigns seesaw between the serious and the silly.

title: Fatal Suicide Attack Outside U.S. Base in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber driving a truck inflicted scores of casualties outside a small American military installation on Friday and destroyed several government buildings, but failed to enter the American base, according to witnesses and Afghan officials.

title: Hermon Complaint
description: United States vs. Ryan N. Hermon

title: Boyland Complaint
description: U.S. vs. William F. Boyland, Jr.

title: A Little Matter of 11 Weeks That Could Change Voting Results
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: New Air Quality Rules for Power Plants in Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Thursday that a series of new air pollution rules for power plants would not cause power shortages, although the expert panel designated by the government to ensure electricity reliability warns that compliance with these rules could strain generating capacity.

title: Poor Economy Leaves More Children at Risk
description: Judge Darlene Byrne sat on the bench one Monday in November hearing the 28th case of the day on her Child Protective Services docket. The young woman before her was pregnant with her ninth child and wanted to reunite with her other eight children who were scattered among various homes.

title: Schools Are Resigned to Robin Hood
description: When David Thompson is asked about Texas long history of school finance litigation, he likes to make a Harry Potter analogy.

title: Corrections: December 2
description: FRONT PAGE

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Newsom Stakes a Claim With Student Protests
description: Dozens of chanting protesters disrupted a public meeting of the University of California Board of Regents on Monday, driving all but one of the regents from the room.

title: A Few Temporary Stores or a Neighborhood
description: To Alfonso Dominguez, calling his project to populate a mostly vacant stretch of downtown Oakland with locally minded retailers Popuphood is both literal (The stores are popping up!) and a bit of a tease.

title: Dissident Leader in Myanmar Endorses U.S. Overtures
description: YANGON, Myanmar  The heroine of Myanmars democratic opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, endorsed the new American engagement with the countrys autocratic government on Friday and called on other countries, including China, to support Myanmars nascent efforts to build a freer, more open society and economy.

title: In Apartment Hunt, Looking Isnt Free
description: When Divanny Lamas decided to move to San Francisco from Silicon Valley, she knew the hunt for an apartment would be competitive  but it was far worse than she imagined.

title: Analysis Finds Incorrect Use of Ranked-Choice Voting
description: The results are in: San Francisco voters have trouble with ranked-choice elections.

title: Older People Are a Larger Portion of U.S. Population
description: WASHINGTON  Elderly people are now a greater portion of the population than at any time since the government began keeping track, with those age 65 and older rising to 13 percent of the population over the past decade, the Census Bureau said.

title: Massachusetts: Camp Allowed to Stay
description: A judge in Boston said Thursday that the Occupy Boston encampment in Dewey Square could stay for now, extending a temporary restraining order barring the city from removing tents or protesters from the area without a court order. Lawyers representing four demonstrators are seeking an injunction that would offer longer-term protection to the protesters. Judge Frances McIntyre said she would rule by mid-December, at which time the temporary order will expire.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 2, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Dec. 2, 1954 | Anti-Communist Senator McCarthy Is Condemned
description: On Dec. 2, 1954, the United States Senate voted, 67-22, to condemn Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, a Republican from Wisconsin, on two counts for conduct that tended to bring the Senate into dishonor and disrepute. The New York Times explained that he was condemned for contempt of a Senate Elections subcommittee that investigated his conduct and financial affairs, for abuse of its members, and for his insults to the Senate itself during the censure proceeding.The Senates resolution used the word condemn rather than the traditional censure, which sparked a debate over whether Mr. McCarthy had actually been censured  one senator went so far as to read from Websters Dictionary. The Times reported that, when asked if he thought he had been censured, Mr. McCarthy replied, Well, it wasnt exactly a vote of confidence.

title: Hazing Suspected in Death of Drum Major
description: WHO died at Florida A&M?

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 2, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article A Familys Billions, Artfully Sheltered.

title: Intimate Moments Among Grand Gestures
description: How imperfect a pairing it seems: the silent, still, small-scale, black-and-white photograph and the sonorous, tumultuous, extravagant and kaleidoscopic opera.

title: What Would You Put in Your Emergency Go-Bag?
description: A go-bag is defined by the New York City Office of Emergency Management as a collection of items you can use in the event of an evacuation, but in a recent Styles article, a reporter asked some well-known New Yorkers what other items theyd put in their bags besides basic emergency provisions. If you were leaving your home in a hurry in the event of a disaster, what items  irreplaceable because of their practical, sentimental or monetary value  would you make sure to include in your bag?

title: Merkel Seeks Swift Action on What May Be Long Job to Save the Euro
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel on Friday called for swift action to amend European treaties to address the underlying causes of the debt crisis that has shaken Europe and jeopardized the future of the common currency.

title: Indian History and Mystery in Lizs Jewels
description: A part of Indian history is being auctioned off on December 13th in New York City when the late Elizabeth Taylors legendary jewelry will be up for bidding at Christies: the Taj Mahal diamond from 1627. Taylor received the stone, which is set as pendant, as a gift on her 40th birthday in 1972 from Richard Burton, whom she was married to at the time. Burton bought it from Cartier for 350,000 pounds, and Taylor had the jeweler replace its original silk chord with an adjustable diamond and ruby chain.

title: Does Romney Have a Moderate Problem?
description: Mitt Romney is enduring a tough week. He now trails Newt Gingrich by 20 or more points in some state and national surveys. He had a testy interview with Brett Baier of Fox News, and then compounded the problem by complaining about Mr. Baiers questioning later. A candidate whose presence in the race probably helped Mr. Romney, Herman Cain, is now in jeopardy of dropping out. Both Democrats and Mr. Romneys opponents are putting out ads that hit Mr. Romney on what is perhaps his core vulnerability, his reputation for flip-flopping. Meanwhile, one of Mr. Romneys greatest strengths, his strong positioning in New Hampshire, is at least a bit less certain now following the endorsement of Newt Gingrich by the Manchester Union-Leader.

title: Not to be Outdone by Santa, St. Mikulas Brings Cheer to Prague
description: On the night of Dec. 5, dont be nervous if you spot a bishop, angel and devil sitting together in a pub in Prague. Saturday is the celebration of St. Mikulas (Nicholas)  a Czech figure similar to Santa Claus  and while primarily an evening for children, it still brings a smile of remembrance to adults faces.

title: Graffiti Muralists Reach Settlement in Case of Contentious Fiat 500 Commercial
description: After a series of highly public missteps over a Fiat commercial featuring Jennifer Lopez, in which the entertainer was depicted cruising past a copyrighted graffiti mural in the Bronx, a settlement has been reached with local artists who claimed to have never granted permission for their mural to be used in the spot.

title: The Early Word: Framing the Fight
description: Todays Times:

title: Sports for Dorks, and the Missing Ingredient in Football
description: The second of two excerpts from a new book, Sports for Dorks College Football, co-edited by Ferhat Guven and Mike Leach, the former Texas Tech coach who was hired this week by Washington State. The book is an anthology of ideas by various experts on innovations taking place in college football.

title: Week 13 Matchups: We Dont Want to Brag
description: Packers (11-0) at Giants (6-5)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Packers by 7.

title: Student Loan Debt: Who Are the 1%?
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Zynga Sets Offering Price at $8.50 to $10 a Share
description: 8:03 p.m. | Updated

title: Student Contest | Celebrate 2011 by Writing Raps About the Years News
description: The Year in Rap: 2010 from Flocabulary.

title: Opening Big Without Spending a Fortune
description: This year, there was one Thanksgiving leftover that stuck with me more than the buttermilk pecan pie. It was a story my sister shared of a turkey-related grand opening event that sounded especially memorable. When Academy Sports and Outdoors, a Houston chain, opened a location in Auburn, Ala., a few years ago, it teamed up with a couple of local radio personalities to host a turkey-tossing event.

title: For Federer, No Fading Away
description: After winning on the indoor courts in Europe for most of November, Roger Federer was in the sunshine at a distant, undisclosed resort with his wife, Mirka, and twin daughters. But even with sand between the toes and the rackets in temporary storage, tennis remained part of the lounge-chair conversation.

title: Hope for the Giant Manta Ray
description: Efforts to protect declining populations of the giant manta ray are advancing: the sea animal, a peaceful cousin of the shark, has gained protection under the United Nations Convention on Migratory Species of Wild Animals.

title: Profligate Zombies
description: Dean Baker has a series of posts about bad reporting on the euro crisis; he is evidently, and with good reason, upset at the way just about every report states as a fact that excessive borrowing caused the crisis.

title: R.B.S. Sells Pub Business to Heineken
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland announced Friday the sale of its British pub chain to the Dutch brewing giant Heineken for 412 million, or $646 million.

title: Cain Support Plummets in Iowa
description: As Herman Cain returns to Atlanta on Friday to discuss the future of his Republican presidential campaign with his family, a new poll in Iowa shows that his support has dramatically fallen in the state that opens the Republican nominating contest on Jan. 3.

title: Your Questions for Indias Temp Workforce Guru
description: A recent article by Vikas Bajaj about Indias labor market has sparked a fierce debate about the difference between American and the Indian capitalism. We would like to know what you think and invite you to pose questions to Manish Sabharwal, the chairman of TeamLease, the company profiled in the article.

title: Now Reading | DarkMarket
description: If style, per Gore Vidal, is about not giving a damn, then one might say cybercriminals have lots of style. DarkMarket (Knopf, $27), the new book by the T contributor Misha Glenny, disturbingly catalogs the capabilities of these nefarious Internet trolls  imagine, as Glenny does, that they could not only clog your in-box and steal your financial identity but attack your government, cripple your power grid or disable your national banking system. Still, the most common illicit activity on the Interwebs  pornography aside  seems to be some form of personal credit card fraud. In fact, Glennys title, DarkMarket, comes from the name of a Web site where thousands of hackers coordinated the cloning and selling of credit card numbers and pins, often culled from illegally placed skimmers in A.T.M.s and card machines. The site was infiltrated by an F.B.I. agent and taken down in 2008, resulting in many arrests.

title: Walking New Yorks Public Spaces
description: The best public spaces encourage diverse urban experiences, from people watching to protesting, daydreaming to handball, eating, reading and sunbathing to strolling and snoozing.

title: Treasuring Urban Oases
description: Alexander Garvin, natty in bowtie and jacket, watched commuters hustle through the gray, sunken concrete plaza at Citigroup Center on Lexington Avenue. Across 53rd Street, in the fading afternoon light, more New Yorkers ducked into a faceless subway kiosk on the triangular patch of wind-swept sidewalk  ostensibly a second public plaza  that occupies the southeast corner. This is the citys public realm, or part of it.

title: Taking Back the Favelas
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Not long ago a city bus drove me by Rocinha, a sprawling favela of 100,000 people in southern Rio with a global reputation for violence. From the safety of my seat I watched the chaos. Beauty parlors were packed. Young people on motorcycles crisscrossed the paths at shocking speeds. A group of school girls giggled as they took pictures with their phones of flirtatious boys strutting by. Funk and samba music blared out of the bars. I loved the scene, but I wasnt about to get off the bus for a walk.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: U.N. Says Action Needed to Prevent Civil War in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations high commissioner for human rights on Friday called for international intervention to protect Syrian civilians from the governments crackdown, amid warnings that the country is headed toward civil war.

title: Building a Weather App That Sees the (Near) Future
description: Weather forecasts are great at letting you know whether to grab an umbrella before leaving the house  but what if you needed to know if you had enough time to sprint to a car before a thunderstorm hit?

title: X Factor Watch: Payback for Simon Cowell
description: Simon Cowell finally paid a price on Thursday night for the weeks of verbal abuse he has hurled at his fellow X Factor judges, as they formed a voting bloc against him and tossed the first of his contestants from the competition. To say that he looked displeased at the end would be an understatement. He looked as if he were ready to bust some heads open.

title: Opinion Report: Ted Stevens
description: From the editorial page

title: Jobless Rate Dips to Lowest Level in More Than 2 Years
description: Somehow the American economy appears to be getting better, even as the rest of the world is looking worse.

title: Design Miami | Back to the Future
description: Among Buckminster Fullers visionary designs was the Flys Eye Dome, a prefabricated fiberglass structure that was meant to be mass-produced and energy-efficient. This 24-foot prototype of the dome, which is now part of the Craig Robins Collection, is on display during Art Basel Miami Beach and Design Miami at the Palm Lot, at 140 Northeast 39th Street in the Miami Design District, which Robins developed; the dome will ultimately be installed in a pedestrian plaza in the district. Its being shown along with a reconstruction, by the British architect Norman Foster, of the Dymaxion car, Fullers omnidirectional transport system, in the exhibition Architecting the Future: Buckminster Fuller and Norman Foster, curated by Daniel Reiser and Elizabeth Thompson. Heres a time-lapse film that shows the domes installation in Miami.

title: If Teaching Improves, Bloomberg Says Large Classes Are Fine by Him
Cookie Tray Theory Propels Student to D.C.
RIM Says It Will Take a $485 Million Writedown on Heavy Discounts for Its PlayBook Tablets
description: OTTAWA  Research In Motion said on Friday that its previously unwanted BlackBerry PlayBook tablet was finally selling. But the steep discounts that prompted consumer interest in the device have forced the company to restate its earnings expectations.

title: Verizon Wireless Buys Spectrum for $3.6 Billion
description: Verizon Wireless said Friday it had agreed to purchase spectrum licenses for $3.6 billion from a group of companies that included Comcast and Time Warner Cable, part of a push to meet growing consumer demand for wireless services.

title: If This Acting Thing Doesnt Work Out, Tilda Swinton Has a Plan B
description: The Bagger was lucky enough to interview Tilda Swinton the other night, for a TimesTalk, and sartorially and conversationally, she was a thrill, as always. Among La Swintons revelations: she hates the theater; doesnt believe in the notion of fixed identity; prefers to think of herself as a schizophrenic writer-performer rather than an actor; and used to make a bundle betting on horses. (Thats her Career Plan B.) Ms. Swinton also talked about her work in We Need to Talk About Kevin, Lynne Ramsays controversial adaptation of Lionel Shrivers novel about the mother of a son who goes on a Columbine-style rampage. In this clip, Ms. Swinton explains why she believes the film, which recently won the top prize at the London BFI Film Festival, is about more than the familiar facts of that story. Its about the inside of someones mind, she said. If you go into the film expecting that, you are much more likely to have a good trip.

title: Daily Report: Google May Step on Amazons Turf
description: In Fridays New York Times, Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton report that Google is developing a package delivery service geared toward near-instant gratification. The service would let people order items on the Web from nearby stores and receive them within a day.

title: What Were Reading
description: Hitchhiking to Heaven: Quince are in season, people: the ones I bought yesterday at the Greenmarket are destined for this recipe. And yes, they are supposed to have a downy gray fuzz on the outside.  Julia Moskin

title: Its More Than Holiday Spirit; Its Having a Place to Call Home
description: As the afternoon sun sinks behind a row of two-family cookie-cutter houses on White Plains Road, Ana Jimenezs front yard stirs to life. Within minutes, pancake-flat plastic blobs plump up with air, revealing jiggling Santas and a Nativity scene rising alongside wire-frame robo-reindeer, all ringed by strands of twinkling lights.

title: The Breakfast Meeting for Dec. 2
description: The news and financial services giant Thomson Reuters announced a shakeup in its leadership late Thursday afternoon, Amy Chozick reported, replacing its chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, after he had struggled to turn around the company in an increasingly competitive market. The Wall Street Journal put those declining fortunes starkly, quoting the projected 2011 breakdown of the $24 billion financial-data market by Burton-Taylor International Consulting: Thomson Reuters at 31.4 percent of the market, down from 37.4 percent in 2005; Bloomberg LP at 30.8 percent of the market, up from 25.1 percent in 2005.

title: Parties Can Look to 92 as a Guide for 2012
description: It was the last time a challenger defeated an incumbent to take the White House. The campaign was dominated by unemployment and the budget deficit. The party out of power coalesced around a nominee and drove him to victory only after a tumultuous primary season and complaints that the best potential candidates were sitting it out.

title: Case Study | Gifts for Drinkers
description: As the season draws nigh, the calls begin from friends asking what they should get their bibulous spouses. Gifting, as a verb, needs a strategy, of course, and the one at work here supposes that most people have a semi-bar at home, a bit of this and a bottle of that, but could use another well-chosen item to connect the dots, to add a dash of panache to the occasional drink. Thats what 6 p.m. was made for, right?

title: Commenting Shifts Into a New Gear
description: A new day has dawned in the comment-sphere on City Room and across nytimes.com, as many of you may have noticed when youve reached the bottom of an article or post, with a host of added features aimed at enriching the group conversation.

title: Twelfth Tibetan Self-Immolates, but Survives
description: BEIJING  A former Tibetan monk set fire to himself as an anti-China political protest in Tibets Chamdo township on Thursday but survived, according to reports on Friday by Tibet advocacy groups. It was the 12th self-immolation by a Tibetan this year and the first inside Tibet.

title: A Personal Walk Through Public New York
description: For my Arts & Leisure essay on public space in New York, I talked to Alexander Garvin. At Zoning the City, a recent conference held on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the citys landmark 1961 zoning resolution, Mr. Garvin, a veteran urban planner, kept hammering away at the notion that government should zone more  and more wisely  for public space, as opposed to private development. Mr. Garvin is well known as a big fan of Paris, which Baron Haussmann largely demolished and redesigned for Napoleon III in the 19th century around grand boulevards, streets and pedestrian-friendly spaces. Paris today has become a museum city, for all its glories. Still, Mr. Garvin thinks Haussmanns priorities provide a lesson for New York.

title: SAT Cheating Investigation Continues on Long Island
description: Jenny Anderson and Peter Applebome take a deeper look in Fridays Times at the SAT cheating scandal on Long Island.

title: Friday Reading: A Laymans Guide to Oil and Gas Leases
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: On Our Radar: China Hints at Emissions Timetable
description: For the first time, a Chinese official suggests that Beijing is likely to agree to a target for limiting its greenhouse gas emissions after 2020. But that depends on the outcome of international climate change negotiations in Durban, South Africa, he says. [China Daily]

title: Israel Cancels Ad Campaign Aimed at Luring Expats Home From U.S.
description: Updated | 12:37 p.m. In response to anger from leading figures in the American Jewish community, on Friday Israels government halted an ad campaign that aimed to persuade Israelis living in the United States to return home by suggesting that living among Americans is a sad and lonely experience.

title: With Leaves Gone, the City Comes Into View
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last weeks image.

title: Should Children Write Their Own Holiday Gift Lists?
description: Writing to Santa is an iconic holiday tradition, and one of the few that I dislike. Sure, that carefully penned letter  Dear Santa, please bring me a pony  is cute, what with the backward letters and the lopsided picture of a sleigh and such. But why should Santa, whose gifts come from the goodness of his heart, be told what to give? And how can someone whose toys are made by elves in a workshop be expected to produce a Wii? Then, theres the obvious fact that a pony will never fit in the sleigh. (Please dont ask for a puppy.)

title: Pros and Cons of a Two-Bedroom
description: Vivian Toy has visited nearly 600 Manhattan co-ops and condos, mainly for the Real Estate sections On the Market page. Here she casts a critical eye on a typical Manhattan two-bedroom.

title: The Apartment Critic
description: RESTAURANT critics eat, and film critics watch movies. I check out apartments.

title: Tinker, Tailor and the Smell of Damp Tweed
description: 11:47 a.m. | Updated The Bagger has already discussed how difficult it was to adapt Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy, John le Carrs classic thriller. But it was also difficult to cast the right actor to play the dour intelligence expert George Smiley, who had been memorably portrayed by Alec Guinness in the 1979 British mini-series.

title: Q. and A. With Vivian Toy: The Apartment Critic
description: 7:07 p.m. | Updated  We are no longer accepting questions. Stay tuned for Vivian Toys answers on Friday.

title: Loans Without Profit Help Relieve Economic Pain
description: When Hirshy Minkowicz was growing up in a Hasidic enclave of Brooklyn 30 years ago, he often noticed visitors arriving after dinner to meet with his father. They would withdraw into the study, speak for a time, then part with some confidential agreement having been sealed.

title: Ethics Office Releases Report on Jacksons Push for Senate Seat
description: House investigators examining the 2008 push by Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. to take the Senate seat being vacated by Barack Obama found probable cause that Mr. Jackson, an Illinois Democrat, directed one of his supporters to raise money for Rod Blagojevich, who was then the Illinois governor, in exchange for the appointment to the Senate, a detailed investigative report released Friday shows.

title: Apple, and Planet, Low on Cats
description: Heres a note I just posted on Twitter, with a bit of expanded context below:

title: Honda Adds 273,000 Vehicles to Long-Running Air Bag Recall
description: In its fifth action to handle the same defect, Honda announced that it would recall 273,000 vehicles for defective air-bag deployment systems, a problem that has led to the recall of nearly 2 million Hondas since 2008.

title: Weekend TV Guide, Dec. 2-5: Tracking U.S. Players  4 Games in 4 Days
description: For fans of the United States national soccer team, there is usually a dearth of televised activity during the week and then a flurry of interesting games to watch on Saturday and Sunday. This weekend, not so much.

title: Will 5,000 Passing Yards Eventually Be the Norm?
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers questions:

title: Weekend Fare
description: A holiday tradition continues this weekend, when Le Parker Meridien hotel, 119 West 56th Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues) in Midtown West, will display gingerbread houses created by bakeries and restaurants across the city in its lobby. The exhibit, which runs through Jan. 6, is free but the public can vote for its favorite with a $1 ticket, to benefit City Harvest, sold at the concierge desk.

title: Dispatch From a Hydrofracking Hearing
description: Governor Andrew Cuomos administration is considering whether to allow drilling companies to blast millions of gallons of water and other chemicals into underground shale formations in New York State to extract natural gas. His Department of Conservation put out 2,000 pages of documents about this process, known as hydraulic fracturing or hydrofracking, in September, and wants all public comments by January 11.

title: Come and Get It!
description: Ts Sally Singer discovered the work of Walter Martin and Paloma Muoz, the artists who designed the T for our holiday issue, at the Museum of Art and Design, where a selection of their whimsical snow globes was on display as part of the group show Otherwordly: Optical Delusions and Small Realities. Indeed, the duo known for fabricating and photographing miniwinters in glass seemed a perfect fit for the season at hand. Here, the artists talk about their favorite storms, their preferred presents and the resolutions that rarely get made in the new year.

title: House Panel Subpoenas Corzine to Testify in MF Global Inquiry
description: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

title: Chennais Magical, Musical Season
description: Come December and Chennai begins to hum with the start of the kutcheri (classical music concert) season, referred to in the city simply as the Season. Its one of the largest music festivals in the world, with more than 1,500 concerts over six weeks at various locations.

title: With Verizons $3.6 Billion Spectrum Deal, Cable and Wireless Inch Closer
description: In a deal that could remake the boundaries of the cable and wireless industries, Verizon Wireless said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire wireless spectrum from three cable companies at a cost of $3.6 billion.

title: The Radical Transparency of Tilda Swinton
description: The Swintons are a distinguished old Scottish family. I heard that you guys have been living in the same home for over 1,000 years.

title: Mom and Pop and More
description: MEETINGS of the leadership of A Childs Place  a family-owned day care center, elementary school and afterschool program in northern Queens  do not always follow an agenda.

title: Third-Generation Businesses
description: Three family businesses in New York City have managed to survive for three generations and counting.

title: The Ninja Gold Miners of Mongolia
description: Theyre called ninja miners not for their stealth but for the ubiquitous green panning bowls they sling over their backs.

title: Nik Cohns Fever Dream
description: Barely a month after his 22nd birthday, the British reporter, novelist and pop critic Nik Cohn hunkered down in a cottage in Connemara, on Irelands craggy western coast. It was the spring of 1968. Political storms were whipping up in Prague and Paris and America. Connemara couldnt have been farther away from it all, and that was the idea: writing 10 hours a day, no distractions and no breaks, and, at the end of a mere seven weeks, a book.

title: Nerves or Something Worse?
description: It felt like a knife slicing through his right side. The young man lay in bed and tried not to move. Hed had this pain off and on for years  usually when he was nervous, and he was very nervous that Sunday morning. He was supposed to start a new job the next day.

title: The Reckoning
description: After reading an article on Bosnias tourism boom, my brother, Eldin, and I decided it was time to face down our past. We reasoned that we were really doing this for our 72-year-old father, Senahid. If he didnt see the country of his birth or his childhood friends soon, he never would. Yet within days I became obsessed with creating a to-do list for our trip: 1) Take a picture of the concentration camp my brother and father survived; 2) visit the cemetery where the karate coach who betrayed us was buried; 3) confront Petra, the neighbor who stole from my mother.

title: Caveat Vendor
description: I work for a small retail company that is on the verge of going under. Some suppliers have already cut us off for nonpayment. The owner has asked me to place large orders with our remaining vendors, to buy some time to turn the company around. I think its more likely that these vendors (many of whom are sole proprietors or small businesses themselves) will never be paid. Placing those orders without telling the vendors about our situation isnt illegal, but I think its unethical. What should I do? NAME WITHHELD

title: Diablo Cody and Adult Onesies
description: Also: Matt Bai on F.D.R.-lust and Adam Sternbergh on things neither hot nor not.

title: Hot Toddies at the Beagle in the East Village
description: With a snap in the air, the classic cocktail revival turns to traditional warmers like hot toddies. In the old days, theyd warm the drink by putting a hot poker into the glass, said Matthew Piacentini, who owns the Beagle in the East Village, which just started serving what he calls twilight toddies.

title: Heaven Is a Place Called Elizabeth Warren
description: Elizabeth Warren may not be able to get huge, important bills through. That is not under the control of one person, even a senator. But imagine a really good law professor asking the questions in hearing after hearing after hearing. So many of the current members of Congress spend their time listing dull talking points. A good law professor knows how to call out a student who tries to duck a question. I want to see her do the same thing with a few bankers.

title: Teaching Good Sex
description: As a 17-year-old girl, I have always found the traditional approach to sex ed, both in school and from parents, to be rather counterproductive. They aim to educate you in a manner that will allow you to have safe sex, but I feel that it teaches girls to feel bad about sex. It becomes a question of pleasing your parents or your boyfriend and not yourself. This article literally had me shedding tears of joy to think that an educated adult recognizes the confusion surrounding sex and seeks to address it in a manner that is free from shame or the pressure to do the right thing, whatever that may be. Its not that Im going to go out and sleep with someone tomorrow; I simply feel that I am free to operate how I see fit, regardless of cultural stereotypes that could make sex a negative experience.

title: The Cardboard Beginnings of the Credit Card
description: In Looking Backward, Edward Bellamys 1888 novel about a socialist utopia more than a century hence, citizens are issued credit cards entitling them to shares of the national wealth. In todays dystopian reality, people use a different sort of card to buy stuff on the Internet. Yet according to Robert Manning, a historian and author of Credit Card Nation, plastic remains one of the top 10 innovations in the post-World War II period. Even if it owes its ubiquity, in part, to a New York businessman named Frank X. McNamara, who forgot to bring cash to a lunch meeting. In 1950, McNamara introduced a cardboard charge card. He called it the Diners Club.

title: The Foul Reign of Emersons Self-Reliance
description: My first exposure to the high-flown pap of Ralph Waldo Emersons Self-Reliance came in a basement classroom at the private boys school where I enrolled to learn the secrets of discipline and because I wanted, at age 14, to wear a tie. The class was early American literature, the textbook an anthology with the heft of a volume of the Babylonian Talmud; a ribbon for holding your place between Rip Van Winkle, by Washington Irving, and Young Goodman Brown, by Nathaniel Hawthorne; and a slick hardcover the same shade of green as the backside of a dollar bill.

title: New Pollution Rules for Boilers and Incinerators
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday released its much-delayed and oft-revised air quality regulations for industrial boilers and incinerators. The proposal is a modest refashioning of boiler rules introduced earlier this year, which were themselves a major revision of a 2010 plan by the agency that drew heavy political and industry opposition.

title: The Bon Iver Grammy Quandary
description: One of the final topics that came up over the course of many sit-downs with Justin Vernon of Bon Iver when I was working on my magazine profile of him was the Grammy Awards. Or more precisely, his discomfort with them, and his incredulity that hed ever be in contention for one.
