title: Justice Department Approves Googles Purchase of Admeld
description: The Justice Department on Friday approved Googles roughly $400 million acquisition of Admeld, an online display advertising company.

title: Bad Mothers and Worse Mothers
description: For the first five years of my twin boys lives, I visited our towns library each week, but only to scoop up heaps of picture books, diversions, when all else failed, that filled the time and calmed down their fighting. Now the boys are in kindergarten, learning to read, and so, in a way, am I again. On a recent Saturday, I let my sons page through books on their own in the childrens area of the library while I finally wandered among the tall shelves of fiction, which is where I stumbled on Penelope Livelys Moon Tiger, a Booker Prize winner in 1987. Just a few days earlier, I had heard the writer Moni Mohsin on NPR describe the book on a terrific weekly segment called You Must Read This. So inspired had she been by the novels ambitious, selfish, literary hero, Claudia Hampton, Mohsin, at age 22, had quit the worthy, dreary job she had accepted shortly after finishing university and jumped into a job at an upstart newspaper. Like Claudia, she said, I was determined to lead my life, not be led by it.

title: Syrians Say They Are Feeling the Grip of Sanctions
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The walls are suddenly closing in around enterprising young Syrians who bought into the idea of a modernized economy promised by President Bashar al-Assad  their simplest money transfers are blocked, and their credit cards are useless outside Syria as the growing list of international sanctions darkens their financial future.

title: The Strategy and Consequences of the N.F.L. Coin Toss
description: There are many ways to measure the lucklessness of the Cleveland Browns. The team has suffered through freakishly botched fourth-quarter field goals in each of the last three games, losing two of them as a result. Peyton Hillis, arguably the teams best player, has come down with a severe case of the Madden Curse, and it seems likely that he will play for another team next season. During a trip to Indianapolis in September, the team showed up four hours later than expected after its plane got stuck in mud at the Cleveland airport.

title: The Despair Index
description: President Obama never expected to campaign for re-election on lowering the jobless rate to pre-recession levels; all he really needs is a trend in the right direction. He got that this morning with the announcement that unemployment had fallen to 8.6 percent from its sticky 9 percent level most of the year, and you can expect to hear about that drop from the president and his surrogates for some time. Its one of the best job reports in a long while.

title: Aileys Torch Bearer Honors Another of His Inspirations
description: ON a recent afternoon at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, where dancers were about to perform a run-through of Arden Court, the sunny studio was a little too glaring for comfort. The choreographer Paul Taylor, 81, his scruffiness offset by a pair of twinkling blue eyes, watched as state-of-the-art automatic blinds worked their magic. My new studio has an elevator, he told Robert Battle. Im not even sure where it is.

title: In Yemen, a Photographer With No Name
description: It has been hard much of this year for Western photojournalists to enter Yemen to cover the political turmoil of the Arab Spring. It took Samuel Aranda more than a month to find a safe way into the country, giving him plenty of time to ponder what it would be like working in the deeply divided nation, where hundreds have died in protests.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 13s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Quarterbacks in Motion
description: Vince Young threw four interceptions in Thursdays loss to the Seahawks, a figure that matches the Eagles victory total this season. The Vikings released quarterback Donovan McNabb, who could go to the Bears, who, with Caleb Hanie at quarterback in place of the injured Jay Cutler, play the Chiefs on Sunday. Kansas City will have Tyler Palko (yes, the Tyler Palko) at quarterback, unless the recent arrival Kyle Orton starts. Orton, of course, was released by the Broncos after he lost his starting job to Tim Tebow. He used to be a Bear  before Cutler, who once started for the Broncos himself.

title: The 100 Notable Books of 2011
description: This week, the editors of the Book Review on the 100 Notable Books of 2011; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Andrew Graham-Dixon talks about his new biography, Caravaggio: A Life Sacred and Profane; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Plants That Attack, and a Well-Traveled Rat
description: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

title: Off the Charts: The Charm of the Third Year
description: Since World War II, investors in American stocks have always made money during the third year of presidential terms. But with one month left, 2011 could be the first such year to see losses since 1939.

title: Jobs: Good Headline, Better Details
description: The job market seems to be getting better, and it is doing so in surprising areas. Jobs seem to be going to people with less education, and the number of long-term unemployed is coming down.

title: We Are Everywhere
description: Each year, the numbers get bigger. There are 42 million family caregivers now, a cohort that includes more than just adult children watching over their aged parents, although they predominate. Tens of millions of us are engaged in this hard, transformative task; this dance in which who leads and who follows changes by the minute; this time in life that cant be over quickly enough and that we want to last forever; this labor of love.

title: Viggo Talks and Talks
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: From Pariah, an Ingnue in Her First Fancy-Fancy Dress
description: The ingnue is an established category in Oscars best actress race: the performer who comes out of nowhere, often with her first film, to charm and beguile audiences and Academy voters. Think Gabourey Sidibe in Precious, Jennifer Lawrence in Winters Bone and Carey Mulligan in An Education.

title: In This Mardi Gras, the Beads Are Made of Pearls
description: WHAT is that, like a cult or a religion or something? Angel L. Calle, a Miami Beach taxi driver asked a fare exiting the Wolfsonian museum, where the venerable art journal Artforum was hosting a dinner, one of many competing for the same time slot and the same group of deep-pocketed art worshipers almost every night this week.

title: Hollywoods Own Hollywood Endings
description: IN 1937 Frank S. Nugent, a film critic for The New York Times, cast an amusing and jaundiced look at what had become a favorite subject for the movies: Movies! Before our somewhat astonished eyes, he wrote, Hollywood has begun shedding its 7 and 70 veils, dropping a shoulder strap here, discarding a wrap there. But Nugent, who went on to write films like The Searchers, was wise to this crafty tease. In the end back-studio pictures like A Star Is Born, he wrote, flounced offstage with protective hands over the greatest of its mysteries.

title: A Trusted Market Predictor Falters
description: ONE of the most reliable guides to investing in the American stock market  to buy during the third year of a presidential term  is in danger of failing for the first time since the Great Depression.

title: Oh, for the Good Old Days of Rude Cellphone Gabbers
description: Is talking to a phone the same as talking on it?

title: 10 Questions for Haley Barbour
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi has been engrossed in presidential politics since dropping out of college to work on Richard Nixons second run for the White House in 1968. From county committees to the West Wing, he has been in the middle of Republican politics at every level.

title: When Family or Close Friends Miss a Milestone Celebration
description: WHILE Im no professional event planner, I do play one in my personal life. Or at least on occasion, like last Saturday when my younger son had his bar mitzvah.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 77
description: Philip Glass delivered a statement (or perhaps more of a poem) in support of Occupy Wall Street at Lincoln Center via the Peoples Mic. rotesters invited audience members leaving the performance of Mr. Glasss opera Satyagraha, about the life of Gandhi, to come down the stairs and join them, shouting, Your life is the play! Your life is the opera! [The Rest is Noise via West Side Rag]

title: Trump to Moderate Republican Debate
description: Its officially a reality television Republican primary now.

title: Draw Sets Stage for Euro 2012
description: In many quarters, the European Championship is the soccer tournament, ahead of the World Cup, because there is no fluff, no Saudi Arabia, no United States, no Paraguay, no North Korea, no Honduras, no New Zealand, but also no Brazil and Argentina.

title: TimesCast | December 2, 2011
description: The Republican race for president focuses on Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney; the unemployment rate drops while many stop looking for work; and wildlife conservation efforts in Afghanistan.

title: Give Teague a Chance
description: Throughout the 2010-2011 season, Atlanta Hawks Coach Larry Drew demonstrated a startling lack of faith in the second-year guard Jeff Teague. Initially, Drew preferred Mike Bibby over Teague for most of the minutes at point guard, despite Bibbys defensive failings and limitations as a creator.

title: Minaya Is Hired by the Padres
description: Fourteen months after he was fired by the Mets, Omar Minaya is back in baseball. Minaya accepted a job with the San Diego Padres to assist General Manager Josh Byrnes with player acquisitions at all levels, according to a baseball executive with direct knowledge of the agreement.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.2
description: The day in sports included rugby in Dubai, biathlon in Sweden and USA Swimmings winter national championships in Atlanta.

title: Kathy Mabry and Tom Prost
description: WHAT if?

title: A Glimpse of Death Row in China
description: A group of Chinese women, photographed inside death row at a Chinese prison, engage in seemingly banal tasks  painting their nails, brushing their hair, discussing clothes with uniformed guards  that take on tragic resonance in the final 12 hours before the womens execution.

title: Miss Piggy Is a Dude
description: Several of our articles, on Elizabeth Warren, on the Muppets and on morning people set Twitter off:

title: Russian Court Fines Election Monitor $1,000
description: MOSCOW  A Moscow court on Friday ruled that the countrys sole independent election watchdog had broken Russian law by publishing citizens complaints of campaign abuses during the run-up to parliamentary elections this weekend.

title: House G.O.P. Is Split on Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON  Deep rifts among House Republicans over a payroll tax break became evident Friday as rank-and-file members of the caucus told their leaders that they did not want to extend the cut in Social Security taxes for another year, as demanded by President Obama.

title: Two Velzquez Works Gallop Back to Prado Walls
description: When the Prado completed the rehanging of its unparalleled Velzquez collection last year two works were conspicuously missing from the walls. But now, after several months of restoration work long urged by experts, the paintings, Philip III on Horseback from 1634-35 and Margaret of Austria on Horseback, created during the same years, have returned to the company of Velzquezs royal portraits.

title: Living In | Oradell, N.J.
description: A central Bergen County community with a wide variety of housing, from grand Victorians to split- and bilevels to Dutch and center-hall colonials.

title: Latin America, the Land of Opportunity and Caution
description: ISPENT the late 1990s and early 2000s reporting on the financial crises in Latin America, when Argentina, overwhelmed by foreign debts, defaulted and Brazil narrowly avoided the same fate. But in the last month or so, Latin America kept coming up in conversations I had with various money managers and investment strategists as a place that has new opportunities.

title: Bloomberg on Cutting Teachers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested to an audience of academics that New York City schools would do well with half as many teachers. Video courtesy of the Office of the Mayor.

title: Face Time | Ashley Greene
description: I recently chatted with Ashley Greene at a photo shoot for Mark Cosmetics. (Shes worked with the brand since 2010.) The fourth installment in the Twilight series, Breaking Dawn  Part 1, just opened, and her next two movies are wrapped and ready to go. Fans, take note: she appears this Sunday on the TV show Pan Am. Greene was warm and easy to talk to, and we were able to touch on many topics in a short amount of time.

title: Wifes Word to Decide Cain Campaigns Fate
description: What will Gloria say?

title: Dec. 4-10
description: Film

title: Waiting for a Decision in Nebraska
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The fight for control of the United States Senate will intensify next year, with Republicans trying to capture a majority by seizing upon the political headwinds facing Democrats. The pieces to the puzzle are nearly all in place, with one exception: Nebraska.

title: Town May Activate Your Homing Device
description: IS Oradell, in central Bergen County, endowed with a magnetic field? That would be one explanation for why so many residents choose to stay, and so many others who grew up there but left now find themselves coming back. Another, probably more likely, is Oradells reputation for good schools, attractive neighborhoods and an easy commute into the city.

title: Michael Kors Readies to Go Public
description: Michael Kors, the fashion apparel and accessories maker, disclosed plans to go public, an offering that could value the company at $3.63 billion.

title: Channel Surfing: A 3-D Look at the Civil War
description: Fields of Valor: The Civil War is being billed as the first Civil War documentary presented in 3D technology, but the three-dimensionality of it isnt all that compelling. There are scenes in which it results in impressive images, but with the still-evolving technology of 3-D television there are also scenes in which it detracts.

title: Video Celebrating Euro Anniversary Draws Anger and Mockery
description: With Europes debt crisis threatening the cohesion of the euro zone, it is an awkward time to celebrate the tenth anniversary of Europes single currency.

title: Few Avenues for Justice in the Case Against Citi
description: Is anyone going to be held legally accountable for the financial crisis? When the Securities and Exchange Commission announced recently that it was settling fraud charges against Citigroup for a paltry (for Citigroup) $285 million, the only person actually named in the S.E.C.s charges was Brian Stoker.

title: The Education of a Quarterback
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  In his rookie season, in 2005, Aaron Rodgers almost never played on Sundays. Instead, he played on Wednesdays, Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, in practice, against increasingly agitated teammates.

title: Inside the List
description: MAN VS. NATURE: Michael Crichton died in 2008, but he hasnt let a little thing like that keep him from the best-seller list. His first posthumous success was Pirate Latitudes, a daffy high-seas adventure discovered among his files, which hit No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list in December 2009. Now Crichton returns with Micro, a techno-thriller left mostly unfinished at the time of his death; to complete it, his estate turned to Richard Preston of The Hot Zone fame. The novel, at No. 6 in its first week, is vintage high-concept Crichton  a group of science graduate students, hoping to score jobs with a nanotechnology start-up, are instead reduced in size to half an inch and have to battle the microfauna in a Hawaiian rain forest. Think of it as Honey, I Shrunk Jurassic Park, with spiders in place of T. rex and wasps in place of raptors. Did Preston have a hard time filling Crichtons shoes? Not really. He told NPR recently that when he was working with an editor on an earlier book, at one point she put her hands on her head and said, Oh, Richard, youre just a 14-year-old boy who likes to gross out the girls. I think Michael Crichton had something of that in him too.

title: Wheelies: The Me-Too Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Caucus Video: A Two-Man Race?
description: Richard W. Stevenson, the Timess political editor, reports as the Republican race for president narrows to Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney.

title: Editors Choice
description: AND SO IT GOES. KURT VONNEGUT: A Life,  by Charles J. Shields (Holt, $30.) This diligent but sad biography presents Vonnegut as a Man of Sorrows, haunted by wartime experience, unhappy marriages and lack of respect from the literary establishment.

title: Paperback Row
description: HERO: The Life and Legend of Lawrence of Arabia,  by Michael Korda (Harper Perennial, $17.99.) The Englishman T. E. Lawrence (1888-1935) was a scholar and a warrior, a politician and a rebel, a publicity seeker and a recluse. Separating myth from reality, Korda presents a rousing account of Lawrences leadership of the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Empire during World War I and his diplomatic championing of Arab nationalism.

title: Read It Again, Sam
description: My dear Lady Kroesig, I have only read one book in my life, and that is White Fang. Its so frightfully good Ive never bothered to read another. (Nancy Mitford, The Pursuit of Love, 1945)

title: A Remarkable Season by Any Measure
description: Aaron Rodgers may be having the quietest record-shattering season for an undefeated team in N.F.L. history.

title: In Turkey, Biden Talks About Iran and Syria
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. completed his 16th trip to Iraq this week to inaugurate a new, postwar relationship. But as he left behind the farewell rituals with troops for meetings in neighboring Turkey, crises afflicting relations with two nearby countries, Iran and Syria, were already replacing Iraq as Mr. Bidens major preoccupations.

title: The Graveyard Shift
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Presaging the Occupation, and Intersecting With It
description: In an only-partly-intentional case of life imitating art imitating life imitating art, We Are the Hartmans, an indie movie about an occupation made before Occupy Wall Street by people who later took part in the demonstrations is being screened Friday night at the Lower East Side bar where it was filmed.

title: Parkour Gaza
description: With the politics on both sides raging around them, Gaza youths turn to a novel form of athleticism and self expression.

title: Even on the 11th Floor, Theres Parking Right Out Front
description: FROM two expansive windows in Glauco Lolli-Ghettis 11th-floor condominium in West Chelsea, there are sweeping views of the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building. But visitors will not find an inviting sofa in this room, no place where a guest might sit back and admire the cityscape.

title: Parking With a View
description: Suburban drivers have long been able to park their car in an attached garage. A new Manhattan luxury condo building with an auto elevator makes driving home, even on the 13th floor, possible.

title: Nurturing Wildlife in War-Torn Afghanistan
description: When Wildlife Conservation Society scientists talk about their work in Afghanistan, they typically draw puzzled reactions. Wildlife conservation in Afghanistan?

title: Visuals
description: These are indeed happy holidays for film-title fans like me, who have spent sleepless nights anticipating the arrival of SAUL BASS: A Life in Film and Design (Laurence King, $75), by Jennifer Bass and Pat Kirkham. Weighing in at 424 pages, with a foreword by Martin Scorsese, this collection is gratifyingly complete. It ought to be: Jennifer Bass is Saul Basss daughter, and she has unlimited access to the treasures of his archive.

title: Embracing Home: Books About Cooking
description: See America First. Or, better, Cook America First. And cook at home. Thats how chefs, food writers and publishers are reacting to the economy this year: with continuing exploration of American regionalism and a near-universal embrace of home cooking, even by chefs who are so modernist  the new preferred term for molecular gastronomy  that you mightve assumed they didnt have home kitchens, or at least not stoves.

title: The Antarctic
description: On this day in 1911 Robert Falcon Scott, en route to the South Pole, was on the Ross Ice Shelf near the gateway to the Beardmore Glacier. One has a horrid feeling that this is a real bad season, he wrote in his diary. It would get worse. When he finally reached the pole on Jan. 18, 1912, he found that his party had been beaten by Roald Amundsens Norwegian expedition, which had arrived a month before. By the end of March, Scott and his four companions would have perished on the return journey, only 11 miles from a lifesaving depot.

title: Reliable Resources: Books About Gardening
description: When I was the editor of House & Garden, I was often asked what every gardener should have on her shelves. Contrary to popular belief, gardeners are bookish sorts  all those fallow winters, you know. It just so happens that this holiday season, publishers are offering a whole librarys worth of collectibles.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach: Thursday Night
description: Aby Rosen hosts A-list dinner and after party at the W.

title: Music Chronicle
description: RIFFTIDE  The Life and Opinions of Papa Jo Jones.  As told to Albert Murray.  University of Minnesota, paper, $18.95.

title: Harsh Adventures: Books About Travel
description: A passion for adventure in some of the worlds harshest environments courses through many of this seasons travel books. Following in the footsteps of polar explorers, wandering novelists and tropical archaeologists, writers test their mettle in spots as varied as Greenland, Peru and Liberia. Along the way, they offer a wealth of cautionary tips to would-be extreme adventurers: dont slip even the smallest ancient artifact into your backpack, be careful of unlabeled cans of food and never wear only one pair of socks when hiking through the jungle.

title: Album Covers
description: As strange as it may now seem, not only were albums once the state-of-the-art format for recorded music, but they were once literally albums: booklike objects, similar to photo or stamp albums, that contained multiple 78-r.p.m. discs  and whose covers rarely bore anything more than words. Presumably someone would eventually have thought of decorating those covers with original illustrations if Alex Steinweiss hadnt, if only because the idea made so much sense from a marketing standpoint. But Steinweiss was the person who got the ball rolling, and who showed the world that album covers could be works of art in their own right.

title: Private Colleges That Keep the Average Student Debt Low
description: While the average college student graduates with about $28,000 in personal debt and two out of every three students borrow money for school, according to the College Board, the extent to which a student is in the red at graduation can vary dramatically by institution.

title: Notable Crime Books of 2011
description: Im always stumped when someone asks me to find them a good mystery, because I might recommend a serial killer thriller like Jo Nesbos fiendishly clever novel THE SNOWMAN (Knopf, $25.95) to someone hankering for a civilized British detective story like Peter Loveseys STAGESTRUCK (Soho Crime, $25)  So lets play favorites  but pick your poison first.

title: Ticketmaster Offers Credits to Settle Lawsuit Over Fees
description: 6:30 p.m. | Updated Ticketmasters various fees and surcharges, which sometimes add 40 percent or more to the cost of a ticket, have long infuriated its customers. But next year, thanks to a recent class-action settlement, many of those fans will be able to get some money back.

title: Picture Books About Hanukkah
description: I believe in scaring children a little. My daughter has never totally forgiven me for reading to her when she was not yet 3 Maurice Sendaks Outside Over There, with its faceless goblins and their theft of a little girls baby sister. I like to think, though, that being haunted by that macabre book led to my daughters fanatical devotion to fairy tales, with which she now alarms her dolls. So I was disposed to adore The Golems Latkes, by Eric A. Kimmel, a Hanukkah story entwined with the legend of the golem, the Jewish Frankenstein. And I like the book fine. But it would be too tame for my daughter.

title: Picture Books About Christmas
description: Whats with Christmas? So anxious. So self-conscious. Always fretting about its true spirit. Always taking its own temperature or rummaging around for the real meaning of. Increasingly paranoid about the war against. Begging, inevitably, to be saved  December after December after December. Does any other holiday demand magic when a mere day off and a pleasant dinner would suffice? If Christmas were a friend, Id beg her to go on Zoloft or maybe Thorazine  at least talk to someone, for Gods sake. Or eat some fudge and shut up.

title: TimesCast | Protecting Afghan Wildlife
description: December 2, 2011 - Despite decades of war and environmental destruction, scientists discover several large cat species in Afghanistan, once thought to be extinct.

title: Bookshelf: Nativity
description: Childrens books about the birth of Jesus.

title: Bookshelf: Nativity
description: ONE STARRY NIGHT  By Lauren Thompson. Illustrated by Jonathan Bean.  32 pp. Margaret K. McElderry. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 1 to 5)

title: Up Front
description: This years Holiday Books issue includes, once again, our selection of 100 Notable Books, drawn from all those reviewed in our pages since last years big winter issue. The nonfiction choices feature a wide range of biographies  many of them of 20th-century giants like Clarence Darrow, Mahatma Gandhi, Pauline Kael, George F. Kennan, Malcolm X and Kurt Vonnegut, not to mention the ageless Rin Tin Tin.

title: Kennedys Cuba Crises
description: To the Editor:

title: Culinary Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Updike the Incomparable
description: To the Editor:

title: Listening to the Doors
description: Within an electrifying few years during the 1960s, rock n roll was transformed from a brash diversion of antsy teenagers into a serious genre that threatened to rival the traditional fine arts. Instrumental in this swift development was a Los Angeles band, the Doors, whose charismatic but tormented and self-destructive lead singer, Jim Morrison, attained cultlike status after his mysterious death at age 27 in Paris in 1971, only four years after the release of their first album.

title: Judy Collins: Sweet Soprano
description: Gentle voice amid the strife is how Life magazine described the folk singer Judy Collins on the cover of its May 2, 1969, issue. The label accompanied a photo of a young woman whose distant, blue-eyed gaze hinted at strife of her own. Just months before, Collins had scored a top-10 hit with Joni Mitchells pained lament Both Sides Now. The record broke through in an age of Vietnam protesters and social revolutionaries, out to save the world but often floundering personally; of young Americans caught between the conformity of their parents generation and the pressure to rebel. Collins spoke to the lost soul in all of them when she sang, in Mitchells words, I really dont know life at all.

title: The Rock Days of Disco
description: Although Nile Rodgers makes the grade as a B-list celebrity, he isnt as famous as the musical record warrants. A longtime co-leader of the so-called disco band Chic, hes best known for the bass line his partner Bernard Edwards devised for the monster single Good Times, which later drove the seminal Rappers Delight and several lesser records. But many A-listers have capitalized on his talents and quite a few valued his friendship. And as this eventful and engaging autobiography emphasizes, that was how he and Edwards planned it. Chic cultivated anonymity. They saw their way to success as an opening act.

title: The Age of Def Jam
description: Never mind Kevin Bacon. Lets play six degrees of Def Jam.

title: The Look of Life
description: The frenzy that usually erupts when a new iPhone hits stores  wild anticipation, long lines, jacked-up resale prices  was more than matched 75 years ago in the exuberant public reaction to the launching of an innovative (how quaint it sounds today) print magazine. When the first issue of Life appeared on Nov. 23, 1936, the 200,000 newsstand copies sold out within 24 hours, leaving disappointed customers and vendors clamoring for more. Defying expectations in the midst of the Depression, the magazines circulation rapidly soared to nearly two million readers.

title: Spencer Tracy: Leading Man
description: If youre going to hunker down with a thousand-page biography of Spencer Tracy  specifically, James Curtiss Spencer Tracy: A Biography  you may be somewhat interested in Tracys youth and school years, his career as a young actor in stock theater, his courtship of, and subsequent marriage to, his fellow actor Louise Treadwell. But what you really want to hear about is Tracys complex and sometimes fraught relationship with Katharine Hepburn, an open secret that spanned some 25 years, even though Tracy never divorced his wife.

title: On the Climate High End, Methane Time Bombs and the Lure of the New
description: Most attention on climate science is focused on the new and the provocative, while the picture of growing risk from rising levels of greenhouse gases is best delineated by decades of work that is old and not contentious. That makes for a bad fit between this scientific enterprise and the world of public opinion, policy and politics. It can also produce a chronic feeling of intellectual whiplash.

title: The History of Caricature
description: Nobodys sure who invented the caricature. It might have been Leonardo da Vinci, whose studies of bizarre heads led his admirers to the realization that distorted aspects of physiognomy could serve a satirical purpose more directly than strict representation, or so INFINITE JEST: Caricature and Satire From Leonardo to Levine (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale University, $45), by the Met curators Constance C. McPhee and Nadine M. Orenstein, suggests. Scholars still puzzle over the function of these drawings, which appear to have had a comic intent, Orenstein deadpans in her commentary on an etching of a pair of grotesque heads copied from Leonardo. Or it might have been some kid who noticed that if you draw somebodys nose and chin bigger it looks pretty funny.

title: The Joys of BAM
description: Twenty-five years ago my husband and I moved to Brooklyn, lured by the promise of more space than we could afford in Manhattan. We loved our big, sunny apartment and its proximity to Prospect Park, but if we wanted to eat in a restaurant that was not a pizzeria, or see a movie whose protagonist was not a superhero, we had to return to our old neighborhood, the Village.

title: Getting to Carnegie Hall
description: To celebrate the 120th birthday of Carnegie Hall, whose very name is synonymous with musical excellence, its overseers have put together a lavishly illustrated volume and accompanying trove of memorabilia. CARNEGIE HALL TREASURES (Harper Design/HarperCollins, $75), by Tim Page and the Carnegie Hall staff, is a sort of glorified publicity kit  the kind of thing you might give donors as a souvenir or sell to members of the public who wish they had been there. Do not look for complexity, skepticism or critical analysis, much less sober institutional history. What we have here is an orgy of self-congratulation that is both awkward and touching.

title: The N.F.L.s Highlight Reel
description: In 2010, The Wall Street Journal reported that after you take away commercials, clock stoppages, huddles and just about everything else, a typical three-hour National Football League game contains merely 10 minutes and 43 seconds of actual playing time. The average play, between the snap and the whistle, lasts but four seconds and, The Journal found, the ratio of inaction to action is approximately 10 to 1. Which helps explain why nobody likes to watch professional football on television. Heh.

title: Howard Cosell: Admired and Abhorred
description: Once upon a time, Howard Cosell roamed television draped in the canary-colored blazer of ABC Sports, smoking a cigar the length of a sequoia, covering his baldness with a toupee the size of a featherweight boxer and speaking of sports in a way no one ever had. He was loud, audacious, obnoxious, perspicacious, brilliant, narcissistic, provocative and haughty. He would doubtlessly agree with those descriptions  and add more if only to prove that he was, as he was wont to enunciate slowly, HOW-id Cyo-SELL.

title: Cecil Beaton in New York
description: Almost anyone would have hankered to have a personal portrait shot by Cecil Beaton. He made his subjects, many of them distinguished or celebrated to begin with, seem impeccably elegant and disarmingly good-looking, seldom employing any of the irony or social commentary that other photographers often used.

title: The Magic of Magnum
description: Its not often that a lavish coffee-table book comes trailing equally lavish doubts about the wisdom of its existence. Its generally rather depressing to look at my contacts, Elliott Erwitt tells Kristen Lubben, the editor of MAGNUM CONTACT SHEETS (Thames & Hudson, $150), a magnificent compendium of raw images from the photography cooperative. One always has great expectations, and theyre not always fulfilled. Henri Cartier-Bresson, a Magnum founder, so hated the idea of someone pawing through his outtakes that he once bragged about throwing out his negatives in the same way as one cuts ones nails. Contact sheets are mostly a waste of money, the photographer Leonard Freed once declared, though he added: Because it is a waste of money, I love them.

title: Looking Back in Vogue
description: The fashion world is, with apologies to William Butler Yeats, no country for old men  or for anything old, really. It traffics in the new because it has to: if styles never changed, Barneys and Bergdorf would have nothing to sell us. But its single-minded celebration of the now (the latest look, the fresh new face, the next big thing) also betrays a philosophical bias against the then. Perhaps nowhere has this bias been more memorably expressed than in a quip often attributed to Karl Lagerfeld, whose career with Chanel has consisted precisely in reinventing and refreshing an aesthetic the companys founder developed almost a century ago: The worst is when friends say, Remember the good old days? Forget about the good old days! . . . What is interesting is now.

title: The Golden Age of the Paparazzi
description: Sometime in the last couple of decades, paparazzi became not so much the buzzing mosquitoes their namesakes in La Dolce Vita were meant onomatopoeically to conjure, as the predatory peckers of The Birds. Since descending on Princess Dianas crashed limousine in 1997, they seem to have entered a cruel purgatory: the endless stakeout of reality-show contestants  Kendra! Amber! Over here!  in the parking lots of Whole Foods. And now that anyone can snap a gotcha picture with his smartphone, what possible status remains in being a professional celebrity chaser?

title: The Making of Maus
description: Survival is having children even if they hate you, Art Spiegelman wrote in his notebook in 1985, while still working on his two-volume comics masterpiece, Maus, which would eventually win a Pulitzer Prize. Subtitled A Survivors Tale, Maus recreated the horrors of the Holocaust  as experienced by Arts father, Vladek, and mother, Anja  casting Jews as mice and Germans as cats. But it also explored the difficult relationship between tetchy skinflint Vladek and his resentful son with touching and discomfiting honesty.

title: Spinoza, Plums, and Why We Draw
description: In the spring of 2008, while sketching at the National Gallery in London, John Berger rested his satchel on an empty chair. A security guard approached Berger and asked him to remove it. Berger placed the bag between his feet, but the guard was not satisfied, and insisted that the bag be carried. Berger became obstinate and was thrown out of the museum.

title: A Museum in a Book
description: The more popular digital books become, the bigger print books grow, or so it seems, especially around holiday time when jumbo is at a premium. THE ART MUSEUM (Phaidon, $200), the size and weight of a suitcase filled with rocks, is the latest piece of material evidence.

title: Diane Keaton: Soulful, Unselfish Maturity
description: Diane Keaton is admired for her ease in performing the difficult and for making the sensible glamorous. She minted a wildly original style of dressing while moviegoers were just learning her name. For three and a half decades, shes starred in films spanning from younger womans nightmare (Looking for Mr. Goodbar) to older womans fantasy (Somethings Gotta Give), while somehow not being punished for the fact that no role ever quite equaled the luster of her Best Actress-winning turn in Annie Hall. She sashayed into arty endeavor  working on books about architecture and photography, directing a documentary on concepts of heaven  without waxing aloof. She rode out the age thing (shes 65) that all female stars face, with minimum humiliation. And shes been self-sufficient. She forthrightly says, I never found a home in the arms of a man. Yet shes furnished an awfully big home in these pages.

title: Wall St. Groups Sue Regulator to Challenge New Trading Rule
description: 9:06 p.m. | Updated

title: How We Got to Dessert
description: Eel in marzipan and goose-liver macaroons may sound like outtakes from Monty Pythons Crunchy Frog skit, but in SWEET INVENTION: A History of Dessert (Chicago Review Press, $24.95), Michael Krondl tells us that the eel was offered at a 16th-century Italian banquet while the cookies, known more elegantly as foie gras macaroons, are the creation of a 21st-century Parisian pastry chef. These two dishes show how the relationship between sweet and savory has come full circle  from medieval and Renaissance Europe, when there was no division between them, to their segregation during the 20th century and back again to the current era, in which cutting-edge chefs delight in toying with our expectations.

title: Think Before You Eat
description: The three subjects in its subtitle are sure to propel Adam Gopniks new essay collection, THE TABLE COMES FIRST: Family, France, and the Meaning of Food (Knopf, $25.95) stockingward. But a word of advice to those seeking a book of heartwarming tales and wry culinary observations in the vein of Gopniks popular 2000 collection, From Paris to the Moon  babies and baguettes it is not. This is Gopnik as gastronomist.

title: The Novelist Who Loved Food
description: When Balzacs Eugnie Grandet falls in love, she defies her maniacally miserly father  for the first time  by taking the sugar hes hidden and returning it to the breakfast table so her beloved can take another lump. Most certainly, we are told, the Parisian lady who holds up a silken ladder with her fragile arms to help her lover escape shows no greater courage. For Balzac, food expresses character and class; and meals provide high drama.

title: Robert Hughes Tours Rome
description: If we could be reborn wherever we chose, how crowded Rome would be, populated by souls who had spent their previous lives longing to inhabit a villa on the Janiculum Hill or a room overlooking the Piazza Navona. I intend to be among them. And Robert Hughess ambitious, panoramic paean to the Italian capital suggests he may have similar plans for the afterlife, despite his complaints  the noise, the traffic, the tourist hordes in the Sistine Chapel!  about the 21st-century version of the Eternal City.

title: Italys Fragile Union
description: Recent fissures in the European Union remind us that no political union is historically inevitable. Such federations are human creations, established either for expediency or through expansionism, frequently artificial: sometimes so much so that, as in the case of Yugoslavia, they simply fall apart.

title: The Lure of Everest
description: Nothing endures quite like a mystery frozen in time at the top of the world. The story of George Mallorys pursuit of Mount Everest in the 1920s has done just that. But behind the legend, of which most of us know only the bullet points, is a heap of story: the gruesome realities and bitter fallout of a nation gutted by World War I, the character of hegemony in pursuit of a peak, the gasping of empire.

title: Miranda July Is in Your House
description: PennySaver is a classified rag that arrives weekly in American mailboxes. It inspired the artist and filmmaker Miranda Julys latest book, IT CHOOSES YOU (McSweeneys, $24), a revolving adventure that takes July and the photographer Brigitte Sire into strange Los Angeles homes and the sad, joyous, weird lives of the people who dwell in them  like Michael, a 60-something man in a magenta blouse whos going through a gender transformation and happens to be selling a large black leather jacket for $10.

title: P. J. ORourke on the Road Again
description: In March 1998, right here in the pages of the Book Review, the humorist P. J. ORourke wrote a satire de force entitled Putting the Moi Back in Memoir. It contained jokes like: My parents also neglected to abuse me. Theyre gone now, alas. . . . Ive thought about asking my wifes parents to abuse me, but it seems too little, too late. I did have a stepfather who bowled. And: Ive had to endure enormous prejudice. True, since Im a middle-aged white male Republican, most of the prejudice came from me. But I still had to endure it. And two dozen or so others we dont have time for.

title: Pinocchios Tribe
description: No one better illustrates the evolution of academic literary criticism into poetry than Kenneth Gross. An admired Shakespeare scholar (as well as the author of a kind of precursor to this new book called The Dream of the Moving Statue), he moves in Puppet way out there beyond mere scholarship. There are myriad internal references (as Susan Stewart suggests), back-of-the-book footnotes and a generous bibliography, yet Gross rises serenely above his apparatus, shaping his own vision. He dreams and muses, offering endless insights into the strange and archaic world of puppets, inanimate things breathed to life. This is a book of literary mysticism, rich with accrued culture yet never weighed down by it. Its a summation of what Gross calls the vast literature about puppets, yet never didactic or preachy. It makes arguments and tells stories about wildly diverse puppet traditions, but it can also be dipped into like a book of poetry, savored for its lapidary insights on every page.

title: Revisiting Camelot
description: Peter Ackroyds vigorous retelling of the Arthur legends, based on Thomas Malorys 15th-century classic Le Morte dArthur, begins with a reptilian king, a dragon in wrath as well as in power, lasciviously whispering in the ear of another mans wife. This dragon will not bite, he assures her, but shes grossed out anyway  who wouldnt be?  and complains to her husband. Kings tend to get what they wish for, especially if Merlin is available to make the magic happen. The husband is killed off, and three hours later the dragon, assuming the dead mans shape, sleeps with the oblivious woman. Presto, Arthur is conceived, not quite a bastard, as Merlin explains, on a technicality clear only to him. The price for Merlins matchmaking is baby Arthur, whom Merlin entrusts to a rustic knight. Only when Arthur, in search of a sword for his foster brother, Sir Kay, conveniently finds one stuck in a stone, is his special destiny disclosed.

title: The iPhone, Weaponized
description: The setting for iBoy, in the projects and high-rises of South London, as well as its violence, meted out by marauding pubescent gangs, cannot help cutting close to the bone after this past summers riots in England. Kevin Brookss iBoy, his latest gritty sci-fi thriller (Black Rabbit Summer, The Road of the Dead), is a vengeance tale that even offers a philosophical take on the criminal actions of these young offenders, a prescient view currently shared by many British politicians: The application in my iBrain doesnt care why they do it. It doesnt care if theyre poor or uneducated or bored or addicted or troubled or lonely or if they simply dont know any better.

title: Post-Apocalyptic Teenagers in Love
description: Overpackaged, overhyped first novels are done a disservice by their publishers, with untested authors expected somehow to justify all the gloss and glitter of a full-bore prepublication promotional blitz. Too many just dont merit the attention. I could only stand up and cheer, therefore, for Marie Lus Legend. A fine example of commercial fiction with razor-sharp plotting, depth of character and emotional arc, Legend doesnt merely survive the hype, it deserves it.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $11.5 Million
description: A duplex penthouse apartment overlooking Union Square, with an outdoor fireplace and an infinity pool on its more than 2,000 square feet of terrace space, was the biggest apartment sale of the week, at $11.5 million, according to city records.

title: The Archaeologist as Titan
description: His introduction to the wonders of the ancient world could hardly have been less auspicious. While in Cairo in the summer of 1815, awaiting an audience with Mohammed Ali Pasha, Turkish viceroy of Egypt, the Italian monk-turned-peddler-turned-hydrologist-turned-circus impresario Giovanni Belzoni paid a visit to the Great Pyramid and became so tightly wedged in one of its internal passages that his guides had to forcibly extract him. It was merely the first of many indignities endured by this 6-foot-6 giant, whose adventures in the Nile Valley would yield some of the most imposing treasures in the British Museum. They would also earn him the undying enmity of his successors in a field that only later acquired the polish of a professional discipline  archaeology.

title: The Caucus | Two-Man Race
description: The Republican race for president focuses on Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney.

title: Study Says Wall Street Pay Is Tilted Toward White Men
description: To get rich on Wall Street, it may help to be white and male.

title: Awakenings Caused by Sleeping Pills
description: Ambien is one of the nations most popular sleep medications, widely used to treat insomnia. But this weeks New York Times Magazine explains how the drug is being used to help awaken patients in comalike states. One of them is Chris Cox, a 26-year-old who suffered brain damage after an accidental overdose of pain medication.

title: Pizza Brutality: Police Devour Protesters Pies
description: First there was pepper spray. Then came the batons. But on Thursday night, bad relations between the police and protesters entered a new dimension. While arrested demonstrators sat in their cells at a Lower East side station house, the police, protesters say, stole their pizza and drank all their soda pop.

title: Bloomberg Eulogizes Aide Who Led Office for Disabled
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg paid tribute on Friday to a close aide, Matthew P. Sapolin, his disabilities commissioner, who died of cancer on Tuesday at age 41. At a funeral at St. Patricks Cathedral, the mayor praised Mr. Sapolin, who was blind from the age of 5 as a result of his cancer, as someone who refused to feel sorry for himself and who fought up until the end of his life to improve the lives of disabled New Yorkers.

title: Parental Quandary: The Broken iPod
description: Parenting, as so many have so famously said, isnt something we do alone. It takes a village, and in that village we sometimes find ourselves faced with, well, situations. Sticky situations. Dilemmas, of a perplexing ethical nature. Moments when were not sure how to do right by our kids, other kids, our fellow parents, and the people around us.

title: Valentine to Cashman: Its On
description: Maybe they will call it High Noon. When Brian Cashman went to the top of a 22-story building in Stamford, Conn., on Friday to practice what will be his second annual holiday descent down the buildings side, he issued a mischievous, but friendly, challenge to Bobby Valentine: come and join me next year.

title: Fill-In | December Events in History
A Diesel for the Long Haul
description: FIFTY miles per gallon may not be a big deal for a tiny hybrid. But it seems like a minor miracle in a big, road-tripping sedan.

title: Achtung, Kmart Shoppers
description: VOLKSWAGEN, a slugger around the globe but a bench player in the United States, has redesigned its Passat to suit American tastes. If those tastes run to fast food, Toyotas and Costco family packs, so be it.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, West Bank, Myanmar and India.

title: Design Miami | Radical Chic
description: The 16-year-old Wolfsonian-Florida International University museum has become a favorite Miami Beach destination, thanks to its intriguing Mediterranean Revival architecture and consistently impressive exhibitions, the latest one of which  Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity  opened last week. It represents a tiny revolution in exhibition design, which is led by the French!

title: Sothebys Workers in Labor Dispute Confront Mayors Girlfriend
description: Art handlers for Sothebys, locked out of their jobs since August in an increasingly bitter union contract dispute with the auction house, have been both inventive and voluble in their protest tactics, traveling to London to picket auctions and even showing up at businesses owned by Sothebys board members.

title: A Credit Score That Tracks You More Closely
description: Theres no hiding now.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Israel, Myanmar and India.

title: Studying, Testing or Paying Their Way In
description: I was as shocked as anyone to read the recent news that a sophomore at Emory University was arrested for getting paid to take the SAT exam for some students at Great Neck North High School. But it wasnt the crime that shocked me; it was that a person could be arrested for such a thing. When I was in high school, back in 1987, my best friend, Liz, came home from taking the SATs at the next town over and reported that during attendance, some anonymous administrator had called out the name of a boy wed known since kindergarten, someone who was supposed to be sitting next to Liz. Just as she was about to call out, Absent, a boy shed never laid eyes on raised his hand casually.

title: In a Brooklyn Church, Lining Up to Erase Legal Sins
description: George Walker was sitting outside his brothers house, drinking beer with his buddies, as he has for decades on the block of brownstones in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where he grew up.

title: The Many Faces of Coco
description: LET the Coco catfight begin.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Clinton condo, a Gramercy area co-op and a Clinton Hill double carriage house.

title: The Bobcats Should Use Maggette  Just Not Too Much
description: It didnt take long for Rich Cho, the Charlotte Bobcats new general manager, to make a substantial mark on the future of the franchise. After years of the Bobcats toiling away on the fringe of playoff contention, Cho took one huge step toward a team reboot in his first weeks on the job by trading Stephen Jackson and Shaun Livingston for the right to select intriguing young big man Bismack Biyombo with the seventh pick in the 2011 draft. Biyombo  along with Kemba Walker, whom the Bobcats selected with the ninth pick  figures to be a substantial part of Charlottes rebuilding future.

title: The Bronx Savors Its Second-Place Marathoner
description: Buzunesh Deba enjoyed the South Bronx on Friday at a lot more leisurely pace than the last time she was there. Granted, that was during the New York City Marathon, where she was on the way to a second-place finish among the elite women. This time, she was savoring the praise and love of students and fans at a luncheon in her honor at Hostos Community College.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in New York City for this week: A Beekman area co-op with a garden; a Battery Park City condo with many amenities; and a Ditmas Park Victorian built in 1910.

title: An Interview With Diane Von Furstenberg
description: At the I.H.T. Luxury Conference in Brazil, Suzy Menkes talks to the designer about her label and her love of jewelry.

title: TimesCast | Good News on the Job Front
description: December 2, 2011  The United States unemployment rate unexpectedly dropped 8.6%, the lowest level in two and a half years.

title: Courtship of Cuban Prospect Yoenis Cespedes Intensifies
description: The suitors for the outfielding prospect Yoenis Cespedes, who defected from Cuba to the Dominican Republic over the summer, appear to be lining up in baseballs off-season. Cespedes is carrying serious buzz, thanks to his speed, power and fielding abilities shown of in a promotional video put together by his representation.

title: On the Markets in the Region
description: A five-bedroom contemporary in Westport, Conn., and a two-bedroom co-op in Yonkers.

title: X Factor Lifts Fox Past CBS
description: With CBS in repeats Fox was the No. 1 broadcast network on Thursday night in total audience and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the age group most coveted by advertisers.

title: Alan Sues, a Laugh-In Cast Mainstay, Dies at 85
description: Alan Sues, an actor whose loud, clownish comedic style made him an invaluable cast member on Rowan & Martins Laugh-In, one of the top-rated shows on television in the late 1960s, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles.He was 85.

title: Gifted | Big and Bigger
description: What a year! For these talented 10, name recognition at last. See our slide show >>

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in the region for this week: A Huntington Bay cottage on a wooded half-acre and a Greenwich colonial with a stone fence and heated pool.

title: To Tell a Dark Tale, Avoid Bright Stars
description: AT first the Polish film director Agnieszka Holland wanted nothing to do with the script that became In Darkness, a new drama based on the true story of Jews in Poland who escaped the Nazis by hiding in sewers. She had already made two films about the Holocaust, Angry Harvest in 1985 and Europa Europa in 1990, both of which were nominated for Academy Awards, and she had no desire to revisit that wrenching subject.

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: There were no madcap stampedes to the cash register. But at the symbolic start of the online holiday shopping season, consumers encountered a far more sinister scourge.

title: This Weeks Tryptophan-Induced Links
description: Best news of the week? Dutch researchers have found that cheese doesnt raise but actually lowers LDL (or bad) cholesterol.

title: A French Auteurs Bleak Visions of Confinement
description: WATCHING a film by the French master Henri-Georges Clouzot, you often feel as if the walls were closing in on you  even when there are no walls. The Wages of Fear (1953), the movie that opens the Museum of Modern Arts Clouzot retrospective on Thursday, takes place almost entirely out of doors, yet its as claustrophobic as a stretch in solitary confinement. This picture, which was his first big international success, and which remains one of his most popular, tells the story of four men driving truckloads of nitroglycerine over some very poorly maintained South American roads.

title: Hard Plastic Bottles, Reborn as a Bridge
description: The town of York, Me., is putting up what could be a bridge to a better future, not because of it where it goes but because of what it is made of: plastic.

title: A New Credit Report Tracks More of Your Financial Life
description: This weeks Your Money column discusses a new credit report from a company called CoreLogic, which includes all sorts of information about your financial life that is not captured by the reports from the traditional credit reporting agencies.

title: 1964 Pontiac Banshee: A One-of-a-Kind Concept Looks for Love, Again, on eBay
description: The 1964 Pontiac Banshee prototype bears many attributes of a blue-chip collector car, yet blue-chip sale prices have eluded its owner, the longtime Pontiac collector Len Napoli. The one-of-a-kind concept was recently listed by Mr. Napoli on eBay at the buy-it-now price of $750,000.

title: A Singular View of Movie History
description: ONE of the major works of Jean-Luc Godard, the eight-part essay film Histoire(s) du Cinma has revealed itself slowly over a period of more than 30 years, as a sort of intellectual striptease.

title: Volkswagens Everyman Sedan
description: The 2012 Passat overcomes its bland styling with interior comforts and a smooth driving experience.

title: Mistrust of Institutions May Touch G.O.P. Itself
description: Perhaps the fundamental challenge in analyzing this years Republican nomination race is the unusual divergence between the popular support for the various candidates, as can be measured through opinion polls, and their support among the party establishment, as can be measured through endorsements.

title: High-Profile Conservative Endorses Romney
description: Newt Gingrich may have The Union Leader of New Hampshire, but on Friday, Mitt Romney landed his own high-profile media endorsement  Ramesh Ponnuru, a senior editor at National Review.

title: War Dogs of Guam
description: In response to our article about military working dogs that get post-traumatic stress disorder and our post Thursday about bomb-sniffing dogs in Iraq, the writer and historian Chris Dickon pointed out that American military working dogs played an important role in World War II. In his book, The Foreign Burial of American War Dead, Mr. Dickon notes that 25 dogs were killed in Guam while serving alongside American troops. Those American-born and bred dogs were buried and reburied in three different locations and have been memorialized on plaques and in ceremonies, Mr. Dickon says.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 2
description: Subjects include developments in the Occupy movement, a bribery case, American Pie and building blocks.

title: Grim Findings in Latin Crash Tests
description: SOME of the best-selling cars in Latin America and the Caribbean provide extremely poor crash protection, new safety tests show.

title: In a Rollover, Youre Safer Inside
description: HOLLYWOODS action heroes may thrill audiences with well-timed leaps from crash-bound cars, but trying such a stunt in the real world is bound to be painful. In fact, federal statistics make it clear that exiting a vehicle in the course of an accident almost always leads to serious injury  and is often fatal.

title: Q&A: Banking by Mobile Phone
description: Q.

title: Show of Support | Seven Miami
description: At Seven Miami, now in its second edition, seven progressive galleries  Hales Gallery, Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, Postmasters Gallery, PPOW, Winkleman Gallery, BravinLee Programs and Pierogi  from New York, Los Angeles and London have banded together to prove that an art fair doesnt have to be a sardine-can-style trade show. Art fairs are noise, says Postmasters Magdalena Sawon. Unless a collector shops for names, its not easy to spot, take in and think about works on display. We want to slow it down a bit and bring back what seeing and buying art in galleries means.

title: Whos That Great Performer?
description: We already gave you one sneak peek at our Great Performers shoot. Now, with this years set of original short films set to go live next week, were willing to let you get a little bit closer. Can you guess who this is? Predictions are welcome in the (newly redesigned!) comments section below. The winner gets to see this actor star in an online film.*

title: U.S. Official Says Missile-Defense Shield Will Move Forward
description: WASHINGTON  The American ambassador to NATO on Friday dismissed recent expressions of outrage from Moscow over proposed missile defenses in Europe, saying that the NATO deployment will proceed whether Russia likes it or not.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Feel Me Flow: An Invitation to Rhyme
description: For high school seniors scrambling to shape a snappy, modern  perhaps rhythmic  application statement by Jan. 1, The Choice is glad to suggest a source of inspiration and a road-map for loosening up in the writing process.

title: Producers Guild Offers Its Documentary Nominations
description: Documentary-watchers, keep your eyes on Project Nim and Bill Cunningham New York: both films made the cut for the Academys documentary shortlist and today they were also named to the Producers Guild list of candidates. The stories of an ape experiment gone terribly awry and our own beloved street style photographer join Senna, The Union and Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest on the Producers Guild shortlist. The latter three films did not make the cut for the Oscars.

title: Little Overall Change in Credit Scores
description: The distribution of FICO credit scores showed little change from 2006  before the financial crisis  to 2011. While some peoples credit scores declined during the economic crisis, many others scores remained high or actually improved, because they became more conservative in managing their finances.

title: The Latin American Alternative
description: The stock market has been volatile, to say the least, for much of this year, as investors follow each bit of news about the finances of countries in the euro zone. Some investors, looking for an alternative, have started to consider Latin America, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week  quite a turn of events since the 1990s and early 2000s, when countries there were in dire financial straits.

title: Firebrand Attracts Votes in Congo, Dismaying West
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Could tienne Tshisekedi, a 78-year-old career rabble-rouser who is immensely popular in the streets of his country but definitely unpopular inside Western embassies, actually win the presidential election in the Democratic Republic of Congo?

title: Week in Pictures for Dec. 2
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include developments in the Occupy movement, a bribery case, American Pie and building blocks.

title: One More Thing Goes to the Web: Subway Ogling
description: AS a personal trainer, Ed Norman knows he has good biceps. But he didnt realize they had their own secret admirers until he rode the London Underground earlier this year.

title: Top Agents Show True Grit in a Tough Market
description: COLDWELL BANKER honored one of its agents recently with a party at the Alpine Country Club in Demarest.

title: The Giving Spree | Frdric Fekkai
description: Who: The hair mogul Frdric Fekkai.

title: Readers Responses
description: After this article ran in the Think Like a Doctor column on the Well blog on Nov. 17, more than 300 people wrote in with their suggested diagnoses. Nearly one in four of the amateur diagnosticians came up with the right answer. Others looked to more common causes of such symptoms  including diet and stress.

title: Easier Linzer Cookies
description: Cutting out cookie rings to expose the marmalade filling makes for very pretty linzer cookies. But if rolling out cookies isnt your thing, there is an easier way. Simply form the dough into logs instead of disks, and wrap it in plastic. Chill until quite firm, at least 6 hours or up to 5 days. Then unwrap the logs and use a sharp knife to slice off 3/16-inch-thick rounds of the dough. Bake as directed for in the recipe, then form sandwich cookies with the marmalade filling. Sprinkle with confectioners sugar. Just as tasty, much quicker. You could even skip the marmalade. But I wouldnt.

title: The jobs and unemployment report may not be as positive as it seems.
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with David Gillen on the Nobel in economics, Catherine Rampell on jobs and unemployment, Gretchen Morgenson on bailouts, and Greg Mankiw on a walkout from his Harvard classroom.

title: A Swinging Time at P.S. 75
Yemens Opposition May Be Caught by Its Own Double Game
description: SANA, Yemen  For years, Islah, the countrys largest and best organized opposition group, played a double game in Yemeni politics, maintaining close ties to the government of President Ali Abdullah Saleh while it also cultivated a network of supporters to defeat him.

title: Experimenting With a Holiday Favorite
description: IN my pre-motherhood years, I approached the holidays like some butter-crazed elf, creating a sugary mountain of dainty morsels. Id tint royal icing in a dozen hues, dredge up the drages, pipe out decorations.

title: Italian Prime Minister Is Set to Unveil New Austerity Plans
description: ROME  Prime Minister Mario Monti enjoys broad popular support as he takes on the daunting mandate of turning around the moribund Italian economy. But the honeymoon may end as soon as Monday, when he is scheduled to announce austerity measures aimed at saving up to $25 billion to balance the budget by 2013.

title: Bill Cunningham | Off Leash
description: Young men showed no signs this fall of being shoved back into the cage of fashion conformity.

title: Older Workers and Joblessness
description: As I wrote in an article on Friday, even those who are back at work are not necessarily doing so well: only 7 percent of those who lost jobs after the financial crisis have recovered their income and standard of living. Whats more, the downturn and its aftermath have disproportionately hit people with less education. Even though the unemployment rates of high school dropouts and graduates have fallen from recent highs, they are still much higher than the rate for college graduates.

title: Head of ABCs Daytime Programming Is Leaving
description: Brian Frons, the ABC executive who angered legions of soap opera fans earlier this year by canceling All My Children and One Life to Live, will leave the network next month when his contract expires.

title: Island Life | Raquel Zimmermann on Brazil and Brooklyn
description: The model Raquel Zimmermann recently visited the island of Fernando de Noronha in Brazil for a shoot with T. Here, she dishes about life in Brooklyn, her love for moqueca (a traditional fish stew) and what to play if you want to get her dancing.

title: The Full Brazilian
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Ex-Police Chief Loses Appeal of Conviction in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  An appeals court on Friday upheld the corruption conviction and 15-year sentence against South Africas former national police commissioner, making him the most senior public official forced to serve jail time since this country became a democracy 17 years ago.

title: Gary Oldman, Fan of Glam Rock and SpongeBob
description: Its been a good week for memorable TimesTalk interviews.

title: Spain Gains 2-0 Lead Against Argentina in Davis Cup
description: SEVILLE, Spain  Spain took a commanding 2-0 lead against Argentina in the Davis Cup final on Friday, with Rafael Nadal and David Ferrer winning  albeit in contrasting ways.

title: Childs Play for Voice and Orchestra
description: THE last time the New York Philharmonic performed music by the Austrian composer H. K. Gruber, in June 2010, it involved the use of a cows horn in a solo role.

title: Ives: Sonatas for Violin and Piano
description: IVES: SONATAS

title: Apollos Singers Handel: Messiah
description: HANDEL: MESSIAH

title: Ruffalo Embraces a Role Closer to Home
description: CALLICOON, N.Y.

title: On This Game Show, There Is No Right Answer
description: Some shows this season have tried to entertain with pricey special effects (Terra Nova) or drawer-dropping stars (Two and a Half Men). But Would You Rather ...? With Graham Norton on BBC America proves that a fair amount of fun can be generated simply by putting people in chairs and letting them crack wise. All you have to do is ask them the right questions. Ridiculously incongruous questions.

title: Two Men Shot Dead, One on a Bus in Queens
description: Updated 12:03 a.m. | A gunman killed two people  one on a crowded city bus  in Queens on Friday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: Raquel in Brazil
description: Behind the scenes at Angelo Pennettas photo shoot of Raquel Zimmermann in Brazil for T Magazines Holiday 2011 issue.

title: After the Years Ups and Downs, Beginning Again
description: TOM NISHIOKA twirled his wife, Alexandra Bloom, up and down the aisles of the Park Slope United Methodist Church on a recent Saturday afternoon in Brooklyn. As Dr. Bloom danced, the skirt of her strawberry red silk dress fluttered, and her cheeks glowed. She and her husband were there to renew their vows after eight years of a marriage that has included twin daughters and her diagnosis of breast cancer.

title: At the End of the Night, Satisfaction
description: PASTA at midnight. Its not a new idea, but its definitely worth remembering, rediscovering or reinventing.

title: Out There | ABMBs Second Wind
description: Thursday brought dramatically high winds to Miami, but also more art. At 10 a.m., the New Art Dealers Alliance (NADA) Art Fair opened its door for preview at the Deauville Beach Resort. Since relocating to the beach a couple years back, NADA has gotten better and better with an influx of very young galleries like West Street and 47 Canal (where Josh Klines three consumer-conceptual infusions  Blue Listerine With Dentyne Ice, Mountain Dew With Claratin-D and Red Bull With Vivarin  were displayed on a pedestal in Bodum coffee presses). The Night Gallery, from Los Angeles, took advantage of the fairs hotel setting, luring collectors and company back to a boudoir (Room 1010) upholstered in black velvet and hung with artwork, all of which was for sale, naturally.

title: The Only Way to Put Time in Reverse
description: THE list of truly classic watches  the timeless icons of the watchmakers art  is quite short, and what belongs on it is always arguable. A Patek Philippe Calatrava and a Cartier Santos will make it onto most collectors lists, alongside the Audemars Piguet Royal Oak, Rolex Submariner and Omega Seamaster.

title: From Cop to Serial Killer, With Stops Along the Way
description: LONDON

title: Art Basel 2011
description: The contemporary art fair, now in its tenth year, began this week in Miami Beach.

title: Getting Far, Far Away From It All
description: ON a Friday morning in October  Oct. 21, to be exact  Mark Trippetti, an advertising consultant from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, surrendered his laptop and iPhone to storage at a remote mountainside center in southern Colorado and prepared to drop out of human contact for a month.

title: Podcast: Econometrics, Bailouts, Jobs and Mankiw
description: The economics profession has been blamed for failing to predict the global financial crisis, much less prepare for it or resolve it.

title: Book Review Podcast: 100 Notable Books of 2011
description: In this Sundays Book Review, the editors choose their 100 notable books of 2011. The selections are drawn from all the books reviewed in our pages since last years big winter issue.

title: Egyptians Want Justice for Protesters Shot in the Eyes
description: As thousands of Egyptians rallied in Cairos Tahrir Square on Friday, some members of the crowd wore bandages over one eye. The demonstration was part of an ongoing campaign to draw attention to the dozens of protesters who sustained serious eye injuries last week, after being hit in the face with pellets or rubber bullets fired by police officers.

title: Whats in Store | Bloomingdales
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Nothing Succeeds Like Contentment
description: IT was a chilly evening when I first visited Taste Restaurant and Lounge in Buchanan, but before I even walked across the entrance I could tell Id be warmed by the experience. Through a large window facing the street, I saw a softly lighted front room filled with diners who seemed right at home.

title: Cain Builds Suspense Another Day
description: Herman Cain says he will have something to say about the future of his campaign on Saturday.

title: Obama Announces Backing for Energy-Efficiency Initiative
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama joined former President Bill Clinton on Friday to announce $4 billion in government and private-sector commitments to finance building renovations to make properties energy efficient and to create tens of thousands of jobs in the process.

title: Two Last-Minute Partners Go On to Win a National Title
description: SEATTLE  At the Fall Nationals here on Thursday, the winners of the three-day Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs were Joshua Donn of Las Vegas and Roger Lee of Pasadena, Calif. They finished more than two boards ahead of Billy Cohen of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and Brad Moss of San Anselmo, Calif. Third were Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y., and Thomas Bessis from France.

title: The Building Blocks of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: An Innovative Chef Looks South to Oaxaca
description: SINCE 2000, diners have come to know Prasad Chirnomula as the chef and owner of the innovative Thali Indian restaurants in New Canaan, Ridgefield and New Haven, as well as two casual, vegetarian eateries, called Thali Too, in New Haven and Westport. Last year, he turned his considerable energies to Mexican cuisine. The result is Oaxaca Kitchen, in New Haven. Here, Mr. Chirnomula interprets traditional Mexican cuisine through the bright contemporary lens that characterizes the food at his other restaurants. Some of his dishes work better than others, but given the chefs creativity and the excellent service, the experience is well worth the adventure.

title: Art Fair: Business Over Activism
description: MIAMI BEACH  Would this years edition of Art Basel Miami Beach be a private spectacle or a public one? I wondered that as I headed off to the art worlds ritualistic week of gawking, power schmoozing and peacocking, which is now a decade strong.

title: Riveras Vocal-Cord Surgery Goes Well, His Agent Says
description: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera had surgery Friday to remove a polyp, or polyps, from his vocal cords at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, said his agent, Fernando Cuza.

title: From J.F.K.s Grandson
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 2
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Greek Debt and Ratings
description: To the Editor:

title: Dogs Traumatized by War
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor Accused of Crimes Against Mice and Lab
description: Though not quite in the league of real estate, modeling and Wall Street, academic medicine is not immune to cutthroat behavior.

title: Unable to Raise Financing, Aptera Shuts Down
description: Aptera, the would-be electric car manufacturer founded in 2006, which was best known for its aerodynamic 2e three-wheeler prototype, announced its dissolution Friday. The company cited an inability to raise private financing to match a $150 million conditional offer of federal financing.

title: Now Online | T Holiday 2011
description: Celebrate the holiday season with Ts cover star, Viggo Mortensen, as he speaks his mind in an in-depth interview with Zo Heller. Inside, Miranda Kerr, Richard Thompson and Taissa Farmiga wear the latest fashions, Sarah Mower meets Her Highness and The Selby drops in on Copenhagens Noma. Need shopping tips? Read our gift guide, which offers groupings of joy for the people on your list. When youre done, settle back and enjoy Will Selfs take on whether hotels are new community centers, join Joan Juliet Buck as she reminisces about a Christmas in Venice, visit with the model Raquel Zimmermann as she returns to her roots in Brazil and meet the Gifted, the breakout talents of 2011, including Charlie Day and Tyler, the Creator.

title: The U.S., the Palestinians and U.N. Agencies
description: To the Editor:

title: Rethinking Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Whale Songs and Drone Swarms
description: Interesting things that Bits reporters and editors found on the Web. More here.

title: Korean Barbecue in a Smoke-Filled Room
description: STEP into the dining room of Kimchi Hana Korean-Japanese Restaurant in South Plainfield, and right away you notice the smoke.

title: Photo Prodigy
description: A selection of work from Francesca Woodman, a photographer who committed suicide at age 22.

title: Will China Stumble? Dont Bet on It
description: HARDLY a day goes by without news of yet another economic problem facing China. A frothy real estate market. Quickly rising wages. A weakening manufacturing sector. Tightening lending standards. The list can seem endless and frightening.

title: This Sunday: A Picture You Can Feel
description: I dont usually pay attention to people trying to be the first to, say, circumnavigate the world on a raft made of Wikki Stix. So while I had vaguely heard the name Diana Nyad, I never gave much thought to her or why she felt the need to swim very long distances. Until the magazines photo department showed me some pictures that Catherine Opie had taken of Nyad after a failed attempt at swimming from Cuba to Miami. Then I became very interested.

title: Letters
description: Black Atheists
