title: Facing Challenges in Multiple Languages
A Familys Irreparable Loss for the Crime of Being Sikh
description: Once there were two eras, B.C. and A.D., says an aging, grieving Indian woman at the start of I Am Singh, sitting in a graveyard near ground zero in Manhattan. Now there is before and after Sept. 11. And with that, this drama commences its impassioned if melodramatic jeremiad against anti-Sikh sentiment in America. More than a plea for tolerance, it is an assertion of pride in Punjab, home to much of Indias Sikh population.

title: A Tribute on World AIDS Day, With Moves From the Street and the Clubs
description: Given Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters predilection for celebrating the human spirit, every program the company presents can seem like a homage. Revelations alone, which ends most performances, reinforces this feeling of honoring those who have come before.

title: Peter Pan, Before the Magic
description: The news of a new Peter Pan origin story inspires several questions. Such as: why? Isnt the murkiness of Peters origins part of the charm of the classic tales?

title: Embracing the Contradictions, Ambiguities and Anguish of Mahlers Final Work
description: We are long past the time when extensive podium experience is regarded as an absolute prerequisite for performance of the symphonic repertorys grandest works. Even so, when the British conductor Daniel Harding stepped onto the podium at Avery Fisher Hall to lead the New York Philharmonic in Mahlers 10th Symphony, on Thursday evening, you had to readjust any lingering preconceptions about what a Mahler conductor should look like.

title: No Place Like Home, a Theater Believes
description: One of the greatest frustrations for Off Broadway producers is having a popular show with money-making potential, only to end its run because their theater has another booking. Such was the predicament of the MCC Theater company in recent years with the plays Grace and The Pride, at its rental, the Lucille Lortel Theater in Greenwich Village.

title: A Young Pianist, Holding Listeners Close
description: There are reasons to feel optimistic about Kris Bowers, who won the most recent Thelonious Monk International Jazz Piano Competition in September.

title: Rearranging a Few Limbs When Not Shaking Bodies
description: The name of the partnering theater may have changed to New York Live Arts from Dance Theater Workshop, but the rest of the Barnard Project remains the same. Dance students from Barnard College and Columbia University get to work with experienced choreographers for a semester. The choreographers get rehearsal space and their pick of dancers. Audiences get a crapshoot. (But dont they always?)

title: Tiny Bubbles in Big Vintages
description: As Long Islands sparkling wines have become increasingly sophisticated, their prices have steadily risen. Still, the regions best compare favorably with many of their counterparts from California and France.

title: A Family Affair With Latin Roots
description: LA CASA LATINA, which opened in Westbury at the end of July, has steadily grown in popularity with both Latino and non-Latino customers. On a recent Friday night, half the restaurant was taken up with a bar mitzvah celebration.

title: Chic in Review | 365 Days of Lady Gaga
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Reviewing the Volkswagen Passat
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2012 Volkswagen Passat, the first vehicle to be produced at the German automakers new $1 billion facility in Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: A Howard Hawks Mystery: Case of the Red River Buckle
description: LOS ANGELES  In the 1948 film Red River, there is a scene in which John Wayne traces the outlines of a new cattle brand in the dirt. He draws a D for Thomas Dunson, the rough and rowdy rancher he portrays, next to two wavy lines, for the banks of the Red River.

title: International Prosecutor Seeks Sudanese Officials Arrest in Darfur Violence
description: PARIS  The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court put new pressure on the government of Sudan on Friday by seeking an arrest warrant for the countrys defense minister on charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

title: A View of the Nile, in Imagination and Reality
description: Around the time Albert Bierstadt painted Looking Down Yosemite Valley and Edouard Manet exhibited Le Djeuner sur lHerbe (Luncheon on the Grass), the American artist Elihu Vedder, who had never visited Egypt, created a brooding, emphatically plain canvas, The Questioner of the Sphinx.

title: Loving Portrayal of a Beiruti Matriarch
description: In the delightful, all-too-brief documentary Grandma, a Thousand Times, the director Mahmoud Kaabour turns his camera on his spirited Beiruti grandmother and her rich memories of raising a large, loving family.

title: Facebook Plans Engineering Hub in City, Its First Outside West Coast
description: Facebook announced on Friday that it planned to open an engineering office in New York City in early 2012, establishing the companys first such outpost beyond the West Coast.

title: After American Jewish Outcry, Israel Ends Ad Campaign Aimed at Expatriates
description: JERUSALEM  One video advertisement shows a Jewish elderly couple distraught that their Israeli granddaughter in the United States thinks Hanukkah is Christmas. Another shows a clueless American boyfriend who does not get why his Israeli expatriate girlfriend is saddened on Israels memorial day. A third shows a toddler calling Daddy! Daddy! to his napping Israeli expatriate father, who finally awakens when the child switches to Hebrew: Abba!

title: Games to Watch on Saturday
description: NO. 12 GEORGIA VS. NO. 1 LOUISIANA STATESoutheastern Conference championship, Atlanta4 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Miller Takes Risks, and This Time They Pay Off
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Waiting at the start shack on the Birds of Prey World Cup downhill course Friday morning, Bode Miller said he was super nervous. He knew he was about to do something stupid  that is, commit to an aggressive line that he described as risk full.

title: Redefining an Observer of a Burgeoning Empire
description: In the same way the first sentence of a story sets the tone for a work of literature, paintings hung at the entrance to an exhibition offer crucial clues. The first five canvases on view at Johan Zoffany, RA: Society Observed at the Yale Center for British Art take as their subject classical myth, portraiture, colonialism and the French Revolution. This is not a random selection: The curators are being up-front, literally, about realigning Zoffany, a painter known for pleasant portraits and conversation pieces, with the larger events and movements of his day. Adapting the Eye: An Archive of the British in India, 1770-1830, a companion exhibition, follows a similar pattern, with a group portrait leading us into an archive of objects and images made during the colonial era.

title: Meh. And I Say That With Feeling
description: A belated reaction to todays employment report (Ive been closeted in a room with a bunch of men in suits, myself included, talking about the depressed and depressing world.) In a word: meh.

title: Last Nude Column (for Now, at Least)
description: Hey, thanks for the well-considered, enthusiastic, thoughtful, skillfully written responses to last times Posture Pictures column.

title: Weedens Leadership, Refined by Years, Keeps Cowboys Clicking
description: STILLWATER, Okla.  Invoking the image of Brandon Weeden, perhaps in a robe and fuzzy slippers, shuffling down his driveway seemed a strange way to punctuate a pep talk. Yet as Oklahoma State Coach Mike Gundy gauged his teams psyche after its upset loss to Iowa State, he knew he could rely on Weeden, his senior quarterback, for some much-needed levity.

title: Michigan: State to Study Detroits Finances
description: State officials said Friday that they would begin examining Detroits finances, a first step in what might put Michigans largest city under the control of an outside manager. While we have long hoped the mayor and City Council would agree on a viable recovery plan, given the mayors description of the citys financial condition and the prospect the city may run out of cash in mere months, it has become clear that a preliminary financial review is not only warranted but necessary, said Andy Dillon, the state treasurer. The review, which is to start next week, will go on even as Detroit officials try to agree on cuts.

title: From Ceremonial Figure to Italys Quiet Power Broker
description: ROME

title: Friday Night Music: Civil Wars
description: I always feel a bit guilty about listening to The Civil Wars  shouldnt music be a bit more difficult, not so gorgeous? But sometimes you really need a hit of sheer uplift; and after a day at the Group of 30, I definitely do.

title: Defense Chief Says Israel Must Mend Arab Ties
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta spoke sternly on Friday to Americas closest ally in the Middle East, telling Israel that it is partly responsible for its increasing isolation and that it now must take bold action  diplomatic, not military  to mend ties with its Arab neighbors and settle previously intractable territorial disputes with the Palestinians.

title: Panel Says Chinese Imports Hurt U.S. Solar Firms
description: WASHINGTON  American solar panel manufacturers won a round against China on Friday when the United States International Trade Commission reached a preliminary conclusion that they were being harmed by imports.

title: High-Level Goldman Executive Is Leaving the Firm
description: 8:44 p.m. | Updated

title: After an Explosion in Iraq, Competing Ideas About the Target
description: BAGHDAD  On Monday, a spokesman for the speaker of Parliament said that an explosion in the heavily fortified Green Zone here had been aimed at the speaker, Osama al-Najafi.

title: Over Here! An Exhibition of Patriotic World War I Posters
description: Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.

title: Once on Top, American Now Fights to Keep Up
description: American Airlines simply couldnt keep up.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,829 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Stanford Women One Win Away From College Cup
description: There are 101 N.C.A.A. trophies sitting in the Stanford Athletic Hall of Fame Room, none of them for womens soccer.

title: Been Down So Long ...
description: The unemployment rate dropped to 8.6 percent in November from 9 percent in October in the jobs report released Friday. The economy added 120,000 jobs and job growth was revised upward in September and October.

title: While Albany Vacations
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York says he wants to call the Legislature back before the end of the year to deal with a $350 million shortfall in the 2011 budget. That isnt all that lawmakers left hanging when they raced out of Albany in June. Here are a few matters that cant wait until the next session starts, likely in mid-January:

title: After Lean Acorn Crop in Northeast, Even People May Feel the Effects
description: In Central Park, more than 1,000 trees in the red oak family were spangling the scenery with the colors of autumn.

title: The True Costs of Privacy Invasion
description: The Privacy Act of 1974 allows a person to sue a federal agency for intentionally disclosing personal, confidential information without permission. But the government is trying to limit the force of that law and make it harder to hold agencies accountable for such violations.

title: The State of the Union Is Bad
description: On Dec. 3, 1861, President Abraham Lincoln delivered his first Annual Message, the equivalent of our modern State of the Union. In the 19th century, presidents summarized progress at the end of the year rather than the beginning, which gives a little more perspective on things. The phrase the State of the Union dates from 1934, when Franklin D. Roosevelt used it for the first time. Nor was it spoken, as it has been, generally, since Woodrow Wilson chose to travel down Pennsylvania Avenue and deliver his message verbally in 1913. (Jimmy Carter sent his in in 1981, a confession that things had not gone so well.) Instead, Lincoln composed a long written document, and sent it to Congress.

title: Profit-Taking Inside Congress
description: The ghost of George Washington Plunkitt, the 19th-century Tammany Hall boss who cynically defined honest graft, is in the air as bipartisan panic suddenly sweeps Congress over an ethical matter that is old news on Wall Street: insider trading.

title: By Raising Roof, Marlins Hope Interest Will Follow
description: MIAMI  If statistics were kept on the most rain delays endured by fans, Jeff Mandler would have some sort of record. After all, he has been a Marlins season ticket-holder since the team entered the major leagues in 1993, and the teams former home at open-air Sun Life Stadium left him at the mercy of the heat and humidity. And the incessant rain showers.

title: Much Like the One You Used to Know
description: A woman in the middle of Row D, looking up from her program, waved to her friend about 10 seats away. Judy Garlands daughter! she called out. Her friend nodded in appreciation.

title: U.S. Urges Creativity by Colleges to Gain Diversity
description: The Obama administration on Friday urged colleges and universities to get creative in improving racial diversity at their campuses, throwing out a Bush-era interpretation of recent Supreme Court rulings that limited affirmative action in admissions.

title: Chinese Allow Play on Pentagon Papers, but Not a Talk About It
description: BEIJING  As far as dramatic timing goes, the text message from the powers that be announcing the sudden cancellation of a post-performance discussion of Top Secret: Battle for the Pentagon Papers was, well, perfectly timed.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Sells Pub Chain to Heineken
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland announced Friday the sale of its British pub chain to the Dutch brewing giant Heineken for 412 million ($646 million). The deal is part of an aggressive sale of noncore assets by the struggling British bank, which is 83 percent owned by the government after receiving a 20 billion bailout in 2008. The bank bought the chain of 918 pubs, known as the Galaxy Pub Estate, in 1999 and 2000, as it looked to expand its operations into property to take advantage of rising prices of British commercial real estate.

title: Pakistan Refuses to Help as U.S. Sorts Out a Fatal Attack
description: WASHINGTON  The American airstrikes that killed two dozen Pakistani soldiers last week were called in during a skirmish in which both sides thought they were under attack by the Taliban, American officials said Friday. But efforts to sort out precisely what happened  and in the process ease the latest crisis to strain the tenuous alliance between the United States and Pakistan  are being hindered by Pakistans refusal to cooperate with the American-led military investigation into the attack, the officials said.

title: Western Digitals Stock Surges on Flood Recovery
description: The Western Digital Corporation, a maker of disk drives and networking products, raised its quarterly revenue forecast, citing its recovery from flooding in Thailand, setting off a 7 percent gain in its share price Friday. Western Digital said after the close of trading on Thursday that revenue in the current quarter would be at least $1.8 billion, above the $1.05 billion to $1.25 billion it forecast in October after flooding in Thailand had devastated factories.

title: Justice Department Counters Claim That It Misled Congress in Gun Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Friday turned over to Congress nearly 1,400 pages of highly deliberative internal communications about the drafting of a February letter in an effort to show that agency officials did not knowingly mislead lawmakers in connection with a disputed gun trafficking investigation called Operation Fast and Furious.

title: Go Online, Beat a Puzzle and Become a British Spy
description: LONDON  Psst! Wanna be a spy?

title: A Choirmaster With Many Masters
description: Sundays are always work days for  Kent Tritle, arguably the busiest choirmaster in the city, but his commitments hit a crescendo from Thanksgiving to Christmas. Mr. Tritle, 51, is in his first season as music director and organist at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, which has its annual Cathedral Christmas concert on Saturday. He is also music director of Musica Sacra and the Oratorio Society of New York and organist for the New York Philharmonic, and has a Sunday program, The Choral Mix With Kent Tritle, on WQXR-FM. He lives on the Cathedral Close with his partner, Arthur Fiacco, 56, a cellist; two cats; and a Moluccan cockatoo, Precious. The couple also have a 1906 cottage in Cragsmoor, in the Catskills.

title: Virtually Educated
description: Its weird how you can lose track of our ever-changing world. For instance, until recently, I thought reality TV meant games about people who were stuck on an island or locked in a house together for the summer. Then, suddenly, I noticed that there were seven different regularly scheduled shows about real housewives, three about people who bid on abandoned storage lockers and two about people who kill wild hogs for a living.

title: New Jersey High School Plays for Title, Minus 9 Players
description: WAYNE, N.J.  When Wayne Hills High School takes on Old Tappan in its state sectional football championship Saturday night at MetLife Stadium, chances are its community at large will not feel satisfied about the outcome of the season, win or lose.

title: Washington State Democrats Hope Voters Have New Attitude on Taxes
description: OLYMPIA, Wash.  A strange sound rang out from the Senate Democratic caucus meeting at the State Capitol here this week.

title: New Pose on the Mat: The Sleuth
description: THE mild-mannered woman on a mat wedged into a crowded yoga studio on the West Side of Manhattan on a recent Saturday was not who she seemed. Brette Popper was no ordinary yoga student who had carved out an hour and a half to get to class. She was the Yoga Sleuth, in hot pursuit of a tip, confirmed by several informants, that out of the multitudes of yoga teachers in New York, this one was special. There was only one way to find out: Go undercover.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Among the weeks news: The spillover from Occupy Wall Street, the official start of the holiday shopping season and a global stock rally fed by euphoria over a concerted effort by central banks to stabilize credit markets in Europe.

title: Democrats and G.O.P. Seize on Competing Narratives
description: WASHINGTON  The drop in the unemployment rate last month opens up a new front in the presidential campaign, with the White House getting a first big opportunity to define an improving trend in the economy and Republicans emphasizing that conditions still remain unacceptably bad.

title: He Brought Him a Head, but Not the Right One
description: Children get the first look at much of this city in the morning, and a group of them found the body, wedged between a loading dock and a trash bin behind their elementary school in Brooklyn. A garbage bag covered the top of a dead man, and today, 24 years later, there is blessed little reason to believe those children looked underneath.

title: Its Not Just Penn State
description: In 1972, Marvin Barnes attacked Larry Ketvirtis with a tire iron. I remember it like it was yesterday.

title: After Tolls Rise, Less Traffic and More Train Riders Into Manhattan
description: The rise in tolls on Port Authority of New York and New Jersey bridges and tunnels in September may have caused many commuters to leave their cars at home and switch to public transportation, early reports from the agency show.

title: Spanning New York, Old Hotels and a Reborn District
description: NEW YORKs Golden Age of Bridges (Fordham University Press) uses paintings by Antonio Masi and essays by Joan Marans Dim to span the gaps in the skyline by focusing on the physical connections that helped create Greater New York.

title: For Giants, Pressuring Rodgers Is a Must
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Aaron Rodgers, a master of efficiency at quarterback, has thrown 362 passes this season, and only 4 have been intercepted. Some 260 passes have been caught by his teammates, 33 for touchdowns.

title: Congressman Says Staff May Have Violated Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. of Illinois has acknowledged to House ethics investigators that his Congressional staff may have inadvertently violated ethics rules in late 2008 by helping him wage a public campaign to be appointed to the Senate seat then being vacated by Barack Obama.

title: He Was a Contender
description: EDWIN VIRUET does not have to talk about what he accomplished in the ring. His career lies laminated on a small ringside table that stakes out the spot where he trains fighters at Johns Boxing Gym in the South Bronx.

title: Connecticut Utility Faulted by Report on Storm Efforts
description: Connecticuts biggest utility had not contemplated an autumn snowstorm anywhere near as destructive as the one that paralyzed the state in late October, and mobilized too slowly once it arrived, according to a report that the governor released on Friday.

title: Newts War on Poor Children
description: Newt Gingrich has reached a new low, and that is hard for him to do.

title: Two-Game Suspension of Suh Is Upheld
description: Ndamukong Suh, one of the most disruptive defensive tackles in the N.F.L., will miss the next two games of the Detroit Lions playoff push after his appeal of a suspension for stepping on an opponent was denied Friday.

title: Detective Who Led Ticket-Fixing Inquiry Faces Internal Charges
description: An investigation into ticket-fixing has already led to indictments against 16 New York City police officers and implicated some 600 others. Now it is creating problems for one more: the Internal Affairs Bureau detective who was the driving force behind the inquiry.

title: Lottery Numbers
Economic Revival, Without the Fancy Cheese?
description: There is a certain queasiness to be felt every time one enters Brooklyn Bridge Park  a sense that the whole enterprise isnt quite morally tenable.

title: Privilege and Poison on the Upper East Side
description: Alice Hauptmann is one of those commanding, complacent women who draw you close to make sure you keep your distance. Her surface warmth is so great that, even though you should know better, its a shock when you become aware of a core of ice within her that leaves you frostbitten. Shes supremely charming company and shes scary as hell. It is probably a blessing that they dont make them like her anymore.

title: Little Change in Totals in Annual Drug Report
description: BOSTON  Fourteen months after he was fired by the Mets, Omar Minaya is back in baseball. Minaya accepted a job with the San Diego Padres to assist General Manager Josh Byrnes with player acquisitions at all levels.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Jim Rathmann, 1960 Indianapolis 500 Winner, Dies at 83
description: In his 1979 book about Americas first generation of astronauts, Tom Wolfe spoke of the quality they most prized, an uncritical willingness to face danger. They called it the right stuff, a phrase that became the books title.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Programs That Tie Funds to Effectiveness Are at Risk
description: WASHINGTON  Policy experts and academics consider home-visiting programs  where nurses counsel teenage mothers and other at-risk parents  to be among the most effective social interventions. The programs slash the incidence of neglect, bolster infant health and in some cases save taxpayers money by cutting costs.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Jury at Impasse on First Count in Councilmans Trial
description: The jury deliberating in the trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook reported on Friday afternoon that it was at an impasse on the indictments first count, which charges him with accepting thousands of dollars in illegal gratuities from a Bronx businessman whom he helped to obtain a boiler contract for the new Yankee Stadium.

title: Facing Scrutiny, Liu Will Disclose Names of Fund-Raisers
description: The New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, whose campaign finances are under federal investigation, plans to reveal the names of his biggest fund-raisers sometime next week, a spokesman said Friday.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Mayor Hits Nerve in Remarks on Class Sizes and Teachers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg faced tough questions for a second day Friday on comments he made about two of the most sensitive issues in New York City education: teacher quality and class sizes.

title: Zdenek Miler, Creator of Krtek the Mole, Dies at 90
description: Krtek, a snub-nosed, wide-eyed mole, has delighted cartoon lovers around the world for more than 50 years. Gently, cheerfully and almost always wordlessly, he has prodded bureaucrats, come to the aid of those in need and lamented the destruction of the environment.

title: Troops and Tribesmen Battle in Central Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  At least eight people were killed on Friday in fighting between government forces and opposition tribesmen in the central city of Taiz, threatening an internationally brokered agreement that was intended to remove President Ali Abdullah Saleh from power and bring calm to Yemen after months of turmoil.

title: Possible Forging of Modern Art Is Investigated
description: Federal authorities are investigating whether a parade of paintings and drawings, sold for years by some of New Yorks most elite art dealers as the work of Modernist masters like Robert Motherwell and Jackson Pollock, actually consists of expert forgeries, according to people who have been interviewed or briefed by the investigators.

title: Capuano Leaves Mets for Dodgers
description: Chris Capuano is officially an ex-Met. Although it became clear in recent weeks that the Mets were not in the running to re-sign Capuano, a veteran left-hander, he remained without a new team until Friday, when he signed a two-year, $10 million deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: N.F.L. Matchup That Began in High School
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When the Jets play the Washington Redskins on Sunday, one of the most intriguing matchups will take place right in the middle of the action. That is where the entwined paths of Jets center Nick Mangold and Redskins defensive tackle Barry Cofield will cross yet again.

title: William L. Waller, Ex-Governor of Mississippi, Dies at 85
description: William L. Waller, who as a prosecutor in 1964 twice tried to convict the segregationist  Byron De La Beckwith of murdering the civil rights leader Medgar Evers, and who in 1971 forged a coalition of poor whites and newly enfranchised blacks to become governor of Mississippi, died Wednesday in Jackson, Miss. He was 85.

title: Plant to Make Fertilizer That Eases a Threat
description: An Idaho company will operate a new factory to manufacture a type of fertilizer that will be less useful in making bombs, the products inventor, Honeywell, announced on Friday.

title: Police Officers Find That Dissent on Drug Laws May Come With a Price
description: PHOENIX  Border Patrol agents pursue smugglers one moment and sit around in boredom the next. It was during one of the lulls that Bryan Gonzalez, a young agent, made some comments to a colleague that cost him his career.

title: A Protesters Uneasy Presence at Occupy Wall Street
description: Brandon Watts, the Occupy Wall Street protester photographed with a bloody face after a confrontation with the police at Zuccotti Park, became a symbol of the movement for supporters and detractors alike. Mr. Wattss lawyer and family, though, say he is not an inspired activist but a deeply troubled young man.

title: In Shaking Queens Hand, Opportunity Slips Through Fingers
description: On the rarest of occasions, Nocturnalist messes up.

title: Man Pleads Not Guilty in Thefts of Art From Hotels
description: By the looks of the New Jersey apartment where he used to live, accented with a Picasso piece here and a Fernand Lger sketch there, Mark Lugo was every bit an art aficionado, with expensive tastes and deep pockets to match.

title: Habitable Zones
description: Astronomers are searching for planets orbiting distant stars at the right distance to support surface water and life.

title: Michael Bensons Planetary Landscapes
description: A multimedia artist digitally processes raw image data from deep-space missions to create large-format landscapes that sometimes resemble places on Earth.

title: Hot on Trail of Just Right Far-Off Planet
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  What does Goldilocks want?

title: Taking the Tiny House Movement Tinier
description: LOUISVILLE, Colo.  For many Americans who bought more home than they could really afford in the giddy days before the crash, the big-house dream has become a nightmare in the ashes of foreclosure and regret.

title: Income Taxes for Wealthy May Increase in Albany Deal
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders, seeking ways to shore up a state budget strained by the weak economy, are ironing out the details of a deal that would raise income taxes on the wealthy and cut them for the middle class.

title: Home-Grown Star Leads Duke to Final
description: The local star led Duke to the College Cup final.

title: A Womans Illness Recurs, but She Still Tries to Inspire Others
description: Wonder Pearson knew something was wrong when her typing speed began to drop. She had averaged 95 words a minute while working as an administrative assistant at the Internal Revenue Service in Atlanta. But in fall 1995, not only did she get drastically slower, but she also found it hard to remember what others said in meetings while she took notes, and she struggled to keep her balance.

title: Magic Johnson Lines Up Financing for Dodgers Bid, Newspaper Reports
description: Magic Johnson said he had lined up financing for a bid to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers and had added Stan Kasten, the former president of the Atlanta Braves and the Washington Nationals, to his group, The Los Angeles Times reported Friday. Johnson, the former Lakers star, said he was a big Dodgers fan.

title: Testing Family Boundaries
description: The Coles family runs A Childs Place, a day care center and school in Queens.

title: Billups, Pleased With N.B.A. Deal, Wants to Stay Put
description: Chauncey Billups was yanked from his hometown and dropped into New York in February because of a superstars discontent. Now another superstars wanderlust could send him packing again.

title: Corrections: December 3
description: NATIONAL

title: Japan: Reactor Withstood Quake, Power Company Report Says
description: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant largely withstood the March 11 earthquake, but succumbed to the tsunami that followed, according to an internal study released Friday by the plants operator, Tokyo Electric Power. The report concluded that there was no evidence to suggest that the main facilities at the site were compromised by the quake before the tsunami waves hit. The company has been eager to show that the site was relatively unscathed by the quake. A finding that the quake had caused the damage would heighten concerns about nuclear plants in other areas, where big quakes are far more frequent than tsunamis. A panel of experts that reviewed the study for the company said it had been unprepared for a tsunami of that scale, which slowed its response and made the disaster worse. The government is also conducting its own investigation.

title: Totals Change Little in Baseballs Annual Drug Report
description: The annual report issued by baseballs independent drug program administrator, Bryan Smith, showed no drastic changes in the number of positive tests from the previous year.

title: Mexico: Party Official Resigns
description: The president of the party that ruled Mexico for seven decades resigned Friday in the face of a financial scandal that threatened to taint the partys prospects for reclaiming the presidency next year. Humberto Moreira stepped down from his post at the Institutional Revolutionary Party, saying news media coverage connecting him to a large debt and loan irregularities in his home state, Coahuila, which he governed until January, were hurting the party. The partys candidate, Enrique Pea Nieto, is the front-runner in most presidential polls, and it is striving to convince voters that it has moved past a history of corruption.

title: Duke Reaches Womens Soccer Final
description: In a battle of old conference foes playing the biggest game in the rivalrys history, Atlantic Coast Conference powerhouses Duke and Wake Forest put on a performance worthy of the occasion  one that featured five goals, penalties, yellow cards and more than a few game-saving tackles. In the end, though, it was the A.C.C.s regular-season champion that claimed a spot in the national championship game.

title: Iran: Diplomats Leave London
description: Facing a Friday expulsion deadline, Iranian diplomats vacated Britain. Britains Foreign Office, which ordered the expulsion and the closing of Irans embassy after the attack on British diplomatic facilities in Tehran on Tuesday, said the Iranians had left in a chartered aircraft. The Iranian authorities, meanwhile, warned the European Union against elevating sanctions against Iran over its disputed nuclear program. They also denounced the Security Council for siding with Britains protest of the embassy attack, which has reduced Iran-Britain relations to their lowest point in years. If you have just a bit of wisdom, you wont tie your rope to the rotten rope of Britain, the militant cleric Ayatollah Ahmad Khatami, above, warned the West in a speech at Tehran University, news agencies reported.

title: Spain Asks U.S. and El Salvador to Extradite Murder Suspects
description: The Spanish government asked the United States and El Salvador Friday to extradite 15 former Salvadoran military officers in the 1989 murders of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her teenage daughter. The arrest warrants were issued in May by Judge Eloy Velasco of the Spanish National Court in a case brought under Spains universal jurisdiction law. The case was one of the most notorious of El Salvadors civil war. Two of the defendants are in the United States and one of them, Inocente Orlando Montano, a former vice minister of public security, is in custody, facing immigration charges. The remaining 13 defendants are in El Salvador.

title: The Graying of a Biker Club
description: The Ching-a-Ling Nomads motorcycle club, which emerged from a 1960s street gang in the Bronx, is helping out with a church toy drive this holiday season.

title: McGovern Hospitalized After Fall
description: Former Senator George McGovern, the 1972 Democratic presidential nominee, was flown to a hospital in Sioux Falls after he fell and hit his head Friday before a planned television appearance on C-Span. His condition was not yet made public.

title: S.E.C. Subpoenas Details on Marlins Stadium Financing
description: As the Marlins new stadium nears completion in Miami, the wreckage from the deal to finance it continues to mount.

title: Man in Fake Beard Fires at Officers in Queens, Police Say
description: A man disguised with a fake beard and wearing a dark trench coat pulled a gun from his pocket and shot at two police officers who approached him in Queens on Friday afternoon, the police said.

title: Sandusky in His Own Words
description: Jerry Sandusky, accompanied by his lawyer, Joseph Amendola, gave a wide-ranging interview over two days.

title: Sandusky Describes the Steps Taken in Inquiries Over the Years
description: In a four-hour interview, Jerry Sandusky, in addition to explaining his lifes work with children and denying charges that he molested young boys, shed light on several key aspects of the Pennsylvania attorney generals investigation of the crimes he is accused of and the actions, or inaction, of officials at Penn State University and the Second Mile charity where Sandusky had worked for decades.

title: Center of Penn State Scandal, Sandusky Tells His Own Story
description: The former Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky, in his first extended interview since his indictment on sexual abuse charges last month, said Coach Joe Paterno never spoke to him about any suspected misconduct with minors. Mr. Sandusky also said the charity he worked for never restricted his access to children until he became the subject of a criminal investigation in 2008.

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: Vidya Balan redefines the Hindi film heroine this week with The Dirty Picture, in which she plays the frankly sexual, cheerfully sleazy 1980s starlet Silk. Ms. Balan answered a few questions about the film:

title: An Interview With Jerry Sandusky
description: The Timess Jo Becker sat down with the former Penn State assistant football coach before he was found guilty on 45 counts of child sex abuse.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Casualties among civilians and military personnel due to terrorism are down more than 50 percent this year from the year before, according to a state home ministry report. The report said 158 people, including 99 whom it characterized as terrorists, had been killed as of Nov. 15 this year, while 323 people were reported killed in the previous year (Kashmir Live).

title: The Weekend Word: Rifts
description: Todays Times

title: Giants Tough Schedule: A Pass for Coughlin?
description: Six points from around the Web, with an extra point from the Fifth Down:

title: How the Internet Is Ruining Everything
description: The ongoing argument about whether the Internet is a boon or a bust to civilization usually centers on the Webs abundance. With so much data and so many voices, we each have knowledge formerly hard-won by decades of specialization. With some new fact or temptation perpetually beckoning, we may be the superficial avatars of an A.D.D. culture.

title: In Atlanta,  Waiting for Herman Cains Decision
description: ATLANTA  Barbecue is on a grill and a blues band is tuning up to play songs about Herman Cain outside of a large stucco building that used to be a display room for selling floor tiles on the north side of town here. If this is the way a presidential campaign ends, it is certainly a new chapter in the annals of politics.

title: Bankrupt Dodgers Will Benefit From Robust TV Marketplace
description: When the Los Angeles Dodgers signed their local cable television contract in 2001 with the network now called Prime Ticket, the team could not predict how the business would change in the succeeding years or how the payments would end up being more appropriate for a middle-market baseball franchise.

title: Spaghetti at Midnight
description: You went to a holiday party but realize you didnt actually get much to eat. Or after having Christmas cookies for lunch you went to a play and youre starving, but none of the post-theater options really appeal. Solution: go home and make a fine bowl of pasta. Everything you need is in your pantrypasta, olives, capers, garlic, anchovy, hot pepper, olive oil. So much better than take-out or a slice of so-so pizza, and ready in minutes. See how in this weeks City Kitchen.

title: OConnell, Third-String Quarterback, First-String Adviser
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez cannot throw a touchdown pass or an interception, visit a nightclub, pose for a magazine or even snack on a hot dog without seeming to stir the passion of New Yorkers.

title: In Free-Agent Shopping, Temptation and Remorse
description: Imagine, for a moment, that the principal figures of the baseball winter meetings were cartoon characters. Team executives would be gullible rubes with straw hats, overalls and sacks full of money. Agents would be silver-tongued hucksters in fedoras and sharp suits, smoothly peddling their shiny free agents.

title: A College Scholarship, Wrapped in Fake Fur
description: When I was in college, I would do anything for money. Well, almost anything. I had three jobs to pay my tuition at New York University, about $10,000 a year, which seems like a bargain by todays standards.

title: The Giants Have History as Spoilers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Roman Oben still remembers his speech in 1998. Coach Jim Fassel had asked if he would address the Giants after a Saturday walk-through.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Leaders Look to I.M.F., Again, as Euro Crisis Lingers
description: WASHINGTON  European leaders are looking outside the Continent for help solving the longstanding crisis over the euro, but while the International Monetary Fund may be able to help, it will not be the magic wand they seek.

title: Live Analysis: Conference Championship Weekend
description: Paul Myerberg will be reporting on all of the days action in college football. Check back throughout the day for updates and analysis, to ask questions or to give us your observations, whether from your couch or from the bleachers. You can alsofollow Paul on Twitterfor additional updates throughout the afternoon and evening.

title: 25 Reported Dead in Syria as Violent Clashes Continue
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An intense and extended battle before dawn on Saturday between army defectors and Syrian security forces left at least 15 people dead in Idlib Province, a region in northwestern Syria that has proved to be one of the most restive since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad began nearly nine months ago, a Syrian opposition group said.

title: Broadcast of Good Deed Becomes Casualty of N.B.A. Lockout
description: A tale of unspeakable anguish and symbolic rebirth unfolded for two hours on national television Friday night, as the ABC show Extreme Makeover: Home Edition focused on the Walker family of Springfield, Mass.

title: Jets at Redskins: Matchup to Watch
description: Jets (6-5) at Redskins (4-7), 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

title: Variety: A Pulp Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Its a lonely job, blogging crosswords. In my business, a blogger is only as good as her last post, and any wannabe could be waiting just around the next corner, ready to slip a sharpened pencil in between the ribs and take her place. Not a job for the faint of heart. Not a job for any normal person, to be honest.

title: For Golfers, 6-Round Fight With Huge Stakes
description: LA QUINTA, Calif.  If you are the golfer Erik Flores, this is how you feel: like a fledgling actor who makes it to the final stages of a huge audition only to discover that the competition includes an Academy Award winner.

title: Egypts Vote Puts Emphasis on Split Over Religious Rule
description: CAIRO  To Sheik Abdel Moneim el-Shahat, the Muslim Brotherhoods call to apply only the broad principles of Islamic law allows too much freedom.

title: SAP to Buy SuccessFactors for $3.4 Billion
description: SAP of Germany announced plans on Saturday to buy SuccessFactors, a Web-based enterprise software company, for $3.4 billion.

title: Dogs Evidence Stands as Woman Waits in Jail
description: COLDSPRING  At 16, Megan Winfrey dreamed of being a country music star. She was boy-crazy and rebellious, obsessively primping and monopolizing the family phone.

title: Herman Cain Suspends His Presidential Campaign
description: An unapologetic and defiant Herman Cain suspended his presidential campaign on Saturday, pledging that he would not go away, even as he abandoned hope of winning the Republican nomination. Instead, Mr. Cain announced what he called a Plan B, continued advocacy of his tax and foreign policy plans.

title: Outside Cain Headquarters
description: Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain is keeping supporters in suspense ahead of his expected announcement Saturday about whether he will quit the race after a string of sexual harassment allegations and a claim of an extramarital affair.

title: Things People Said
description: The rating agencies are just lying in wait to see who they can downgrade to make up for their past mistakes.

title: Explaining Business Investment
description: One of the charts I prepared for my presentation at the G30 was intended to debunk the notion that we need some kind of special factor aside from the depressed economy to explain low business investment. On the x-axis of the figure below I show the ratio of actual GDP to the CBO estimate of potential GDP. On the vertical axis I show the ratio of nonresidential fixed investment  basically, business investment  to potential GDP. The blue dots show data from 1985 to 2007, during which there was a strong relationship: a depressed economy led to low business investment. The red dots show subsequent data; if anything, business investment has been stronger since the Great Recession began than you might have expected.

title: Tenants at Chelsea Hotel File Suit Against Owner Over Renovations
description: The heated battle between the new owner of the Chelsea Hotel and a group of the buildings long-term tenants has moved to Manhattan Housing Court.

title: Salt Lake Countys New Dividing Lines
description: The map passed by Utah Republicans divides Salt Lake County, and its concentration of Democrats, among three districts. Salt Lake City was kept whole.

title: Representative Dan Borens Natural Gas Ties
description: Representative Dan Borens campaign contributions from the growing oil and gas industry in his state.

title: Irving Fisher Rules
description: Adair Turner and I were in a competition over who could praise Irving Fishers classic debt-deflation analysis (pdf) more. Its truly astonishing how relevant it is to current conditions  and how thoroughly conventional wisdom seems determined to ignore its lessons for policy.

title: Health Official Takes Parting Shot at Waste
description: WASHINGTON  The official in charge of Medicare and Medicaid for the last 17 months says that 20 percent to 30 percent of health spending is waste that yields no benefit to patients, and that some of the needless spending is a result of onerous, archaic regulations enforced by his agency.

title: Gingrich Accepts Invite to Debate Moderated by Trump
description: With Herman Cains tumultuous and troubled quest for the presidency seemingly over, the 2012 Republican primary campaign can move on to its next distraction: Donald Trump as a debate moderator.

title: Plaintiffs Lawyers in a Bitter Dispute Over Fees in Gulf Oil Spill Cases
description: Lawyers routinely battle each other, representing the conflicting interests of plaintiffs and defendants. But lately in the vast tangle of federal litigation over last years Deepwater Horizon oil spill, lawyers on the same side  for the plaintiffs  are fighting one another.

title: Amid Historic Homes, New England Moves to Preserve a Modern Heritage
description: LINCOLN, Mass.  In a region that prizes center-chimney Colonials, shingled Capes, saltboxes and other homes that have helped shape New Englands unmistakable sense of place, Polly Flansburghs boxy, low-slung house does not leap out as historic.

title: Newt Gingrich on Herman Cain
description: Newt Gingrich commends Herman Cain on launching the 9-9-9 plan.

title: Announcing Win-a-Trip 2012
description: My Sunday column is devoted to my annual humanitarian holiday guide, but it also notes that Im now accepting entries for Win-a-Trip 2012. In the past, Ive occasionally taken more than one person (such as a member of the over-60 crowd last year), but this year itll be just a university student. So heres how to enter the contest.

title: Cain Suspends Campaign
description: The Republican candidate Herman Cain suspended his presidential campaign.

title: Win a Trip 2012
description: The columnist Nicholas D. Kristof invites students to enter a contest for an international reporting trip in 2012.

title: A Defiant Herman Cain Suspends His Bid for Presidency
description: An unapologetic and defiant Herman Cain suspended his presidential campaign on Saturday, pledging that he would not go away even as he abandoned the Republican presidential race in the face of escalating accusations of sexual misconduct.

title: Some Cities Object to Being Carved Up by Redistricting
description: There are no guard towers, or Checkpoint Charlies, or even walls. But scores of American cities, counties and metropolitan areas are being divided again  splitting apart families, neighbors and, most important, voters with similar interests and needs  as states engage in the once-a-decade process of drawing the lines of new Congressional districts.

title: In Turkey to Strengthen Ties, Biden Refuses to Ignore a Hosts Economic Boast
description: ISTANBUL  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. came to this ancient city that spans Europe and Asia to talk about building bridges between the United States and the Islamic world. But on Saturday, he felt compelled to brush back a challenge from his Turkish hosts.

title: A Lucky and Unlucky Contender
description: Edwin Viruet, once a promising lightweight contender and now a boxing trainer in the Bronx, has little left but his memories of those he beat, and those he didnt.

title: How the Food Industry Eats Your Kids Lunch
description: An increasingly cozy alliance between companies that manufacture processed foods and companies that serve the meals is making students  a captive market  fat and sick while pulling in hundreds of millions of dollars in profits. At a time of fiscal austerity, these companies are seducing school administrators with promises to cut costs through privatization. Parents who want healthier meals, meanwhile, are outgunned.

title: When the Police Go Military
description: RIOT police officers tear-gassing protesters at the Occupy movement in Oakland, Calif. The surprising nighttime invasion of Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, carried out with D-Day-like secrecy by officers deploying klieg lights and a military-style sound machine. And campus police officers in helmets and face shields dousing demonstrators at the University of California, Davis with pepper spray.

title: Riding the Republican Roller Coaster
description: RICHARD STEVENSON, the political editor who has overseen national election coverage for The New York Times since 2006, was explaining why this presidential contest was not the stunted affair I told him I thought it was.

title: The Decadent Left
description: IN the days when Tea Party activists were crowding town hall meetings and Glenn Becks fans were thronging the Washington Mall, a kind of existential despair settled over the American left. The country was mired in an economic crisis that most left-wingers believed was caused by the excesses of free-market capitalism, yet the only major protest movement belonged to the political right. What was the left good for, if it couldnt even persuade people to take to the streets? Why didnt American liberalism have a Tea Party of its own?

title: The New Digital Divide
description: FOR the second year in a row, the Monday after Thanksgiving  so-called Cyber Monday, when online retailers offer discounts to lure holiday shoppers  was the biggest online sales day of the year, totaling some $1.25 billion and overwhelming the sales figures racked up by brick-and-mortar stores three days before, on Black Friday, the former perennial record-holder.

title: Cities Beyond the Law
description: Washington

title: Riot Gears Evolution
description: Just as the styles of protest have changed from one generation to the next, so have the styles of protest policing. Technological advances, training innovations and changing attitudes toward the right to assemble have all shaped the way the police handle the challenges of large demonstrations. During the 1960s and 70s, police officers treated many protests as a threat to the social order and responded with brute force. In the 1980s and 90s, demonstrations tended to be less confrontational and the police responded with more accommodating tactics.

title: Kelly Slater
description: Kelly Slater is a professional surfer who recently won his 11th world title. At 39, he has won more major competitions and prize money than any surfer in history. Over his 20-year career, he has been the sports youngest and oldest champion.

title: Newt Gingrich on Attending Trump Debate
description: Newt Gingrich says he will attend the debate because Donald Trump is a unique American character.

title: Packers at Giants: Matchup to Watch
description: Packers (11-0) at Giants (6-5), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Out of Africa and Into Iowa
description: WASHINGTON

title: Gifts That Say You Care
description: GIVE Grandma a bit of credit! These holidays, would she rather receive a silly reindeer sweater or help a schoolchild acquire glasses to see the blackboard clearly for the first time?

title: This Is a Big Deal
description: IN many ways, President Obama has been a disappointment on energy and the environment. He has been completely missing in action on the climate debate. His decision to block his own Environmental Protection Agency from setting new rules to cut smog levels was disappointing. And, while I believe in using the balance sheet of the U.S. government to spur clean-tech research and start-ups, Solyndra was a case of embarrassing excess  precisely what happens when you rely too much on government push not consumer pull, spurred by price and regulatory signals.

title: Britains Failed Experiment, Repeated
description: A year and a half ago, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain came to office promising to slash deficits and energize economic growth through radical fiscal austerity. It failed dismally. But no lessons were learned, and instead of reversing course, Mr. Camerons Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition plans to make the pain worse by pushing even tougher austerity measures on the weakening economy.

title: What About Premium Support?
description: As the election campaign progresses voters can expect to hear a lot of hype  and if we are very lucky some good ideas  about how best to reform Medicare. It will take stamina and well-honed skepticism to sort it all out.

title: Remember Kyoto? Most Nations Dont
description: Delegates from 194 countries will meet this week in Durban, South Africa, to see whether the world can do a better job of controlling the man-made greenhouse gases that scientists believe will lead to sea-level rise, floods, drought and famine. Over the years, there has been far more talk than action.

title: Irans First Great Satan Was England
description: Boston

title: And Now ... Professor Gingrich
description: OF all the please-God-not-Mitt surges in the Republican contest, Newt Gingrichs is the strangest.

title: Talking Face to Face Is So ... Yesterday
description: ADMIT it. The holiday season has just begun, and already were overwhelmed by so much ... face time. Its hard, face-to-face emoting, face-to-face empathizing, face-to-face expressing, face-to-face criticizing. Thank goodness for less face time; when it comes to disrupting, if not severing, lifetimes of neurotic relational patterns, technology works even better than psychotherapy.

title: Powerball!
description: There are three ways to make a living in this business, says Jeremy Irons, playing a Wall Street C.E.O. in Margin Call. Be first, be smarter, or cheat."

title: An Enforcers Story
description: Derek Boogaard fought his way to center ice as one of the N.H.Ls most feared fighters. But the role exposed him to repeated head traumas.

title: Derek Boogaards Notes
description: After becoming the N.H.L.s top enforcer, Boogaard hand-wrote 16 pages of notes about his memories of childhood.

title: Exposing Spains Flaw, Argentina Stays Alive
description: SEVILLE, Spain  Argentina kept alive its chances of winning its first Davis Cup with a clear-cut victory over Spain in doubles on Saturday.

title: Derek Boogaard: A Boy Learns to Brawl
description: DEREK BOOGAARD was scared. He did not know whom he would fight, just that he must.

title: The Life in Juniors
description: Junior hockey is considered a rite of passage for Canadas most promising young players.

title: T. Franklin Williams, Early Geriatric Specialist, Dies at 89
description: Dr. T. Franklin Williams, a former director of the National Institute on Aging and an early proponent of geriatric care as a medical specialty, died at his home in Rochester on Nov. 25, the day before his 90th birthday.

title: Growing Up in Melfort
description: A life in hockey took root in the windswept plains of Saskatchewan.

title: Voting Rights and Texas
description: Texas grew so much over the last decade that it qualified for four new House seats. Almost all of that growth  more than four million people  came from new Hispanic residents, but when the Republicans who control the State Legislature drew the new districts last summer, they reduced the number of districts where minorities could elect the candidate of their choice to 10 from 11.

title: Im Sorry: The Scariest Words in Politics
description: ONE of the great tropes of Republican criticism of Barack Obama is that the president goes around the world apologizing for Americas past misdeeds. Have we ever had a president, Mitt Romney asked in a foreign policy speech this summer, who was so eager to address the world with an apology on his lips and doubt in his heart? Mr. Romney repeated the allegation at last months national security debate. He even embedded his claim in the title of his campaign book: No Apology: Believe in America.

title: The Junking of the Postal Service
description: A FEW weeks ago a petition appeared next to the mailboxes in my buildings lobby in Upper Manhattan. It read: Save Saturday Delivery! ... Save the U.S. Postal Service! Over the next 24 hours signatures poured onto the sheet of paper.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Higher Taxes, or Lower?
description: Readers debate how the rich and corporations should be taxed.

title: Our Microbiomes, Ourselves
description: IMAGINE a scientist gently swabs your left nostril with a Q-tip and finds that your nose contains hundreds of species of bacteria. That in itself is no surprise; each of us is home to some 100 trillion microbes. But then she makes an interesting discovery: in your nose is a previously unknown species that produces a powerful new antibiotic. Her university licenses it to a pharmaceutical company; it hits the market and earns hundreds of millions of dollars. Do you deserve a cut of the profits?

title: 8-Year-Old American Wins a World Championship
description: America has a new world champion, and he is only 8 years old.

title: A Rival Enforcer: Mat Sommerfeld
description: Mat Sommerfeld, a rival enforcer in the Western Hockey League, on concussions and the role of the enforcer

title: Punched Out | Part One
description: Derek Boogaard fought his way to center ice as one of the N.H.L's most feared fighters. But, the role exposed Boogaard to repeated head traumas, chronic pain and a deadly drug addiction.

title: Tom Lynn on Boogaards Appeal
description: Tom Lynn, former assistant general manager of the Minnesota Wild, on Derek Boogaards popularity in Minneapolis.

title: Jeremy Clark
description: Jeremy Clark, a close friend and trainer from Minneapolis, on Derek Boogaard off the ice and Boogaard's relationship with his brother Aaron.

title: Jim Swanson
description: Jim Swanson, former sports editor for the Prince George Citizen, on the role of hockey in Western Canada.

title: A Danger in Plain Sight but Oh So Alluring, the Death Cap Is Here in Abundance
description: You dont have to wander very far off the road this time of year before stumbling upon Amanita phalloides, the deadliest mushroom in California.

title: On Land and in the Bay, Innovation Tackles Truancy
description: On Monday morning, the start of the school week, five teenagers rowed toward the breakwater leading into San Francisco Bay.

title: Sunday: Swapping Partners
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle by Kelsey Blakely is called Swapping Partners, and I must admit that I started solving with some trepidation, because who knows what one might find in a puzzle by that name?

title: Sea Life Skate Stoppers
description: An invasion of sea life creeps across the Embarcaderos Rincon Park. But the bronze sculptures of starfish, turtles and octopuses do double duty: the whimsical art at waters edge also deters skateboarders with a lust for concrete ledges. LOUISE RAFKIN

title: Romney Tries to Show His Strength in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mitt Romney came to New Hampshire on Saturday to, in the parlance of a new campaign catchphrase, Earn it.

title: Caf Gratitude Chain Is Closing in the Region, Prompting Jeers as Well as Tears
description: When Matthew and Terces Engelhart, owners of the Caf Gratitude raw-food chain, announced on Facebook last week that they would close all eight of their Northern California restaurants, the publics response was passionate  and polarized.

title: Finally Accepting Her Celebrity
description: Chelseas life as a Clinton.

title: Campaigns for Rocks Pantheon
description: A selection of the fifteen artists who have been nominated for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Five winners will be announced on Wednesday, Dec. 7.

title: Mitt Romney in New Hampshire
description: Mitt Romney says the right course for him is to continue talking about his vision for the country.

title: Chelsea Clinton, Living Up to the Family Name
description: OVER a series of casual dinners at neighborhood restaurants near her Flatiron District apartment in the spring, Chelsea Clinton began talking to a couple of longtime friends about something shed been mulling for a while.

title: A New Hotel, Where the Stay Used to Be Mandatory
description: UMM QASR, Iraq  The road approaching the Basra Gateway hotel in southern Iraq crosses a landscape so blighted with trash and spilled crude oil, which shimmers in gigantic pools in the sand, that it is difficult to imagine any guests ever passing this way.

title: Many Texas Republicans in Washington Hold Back on Presidential Endorsements
description: WASHINGTON  As the long slog toward the presidential nomination continues, at least 10 Texas Republicans in Congress have yet to pick a candidate.

title: Modest Bonus Year on Wall St., but Stock Could Yield Fortunes
description: Buffeted by lackluster profits and turmoil in the global markets, Wall Street is bracing for one of the worst bonus seasons in recent memory. But in the alchemy of high finance, bankers are hoping to turn the slump to their advantage.

title: When R on the Ballot May Not Be Enough
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: From Indie Record Stores, Holiday Gift Thoughts
description: Last month, more than 60 independent record stores across Texas kicked off the holiday shopping season with a Black Friday edition of Record Store Day, an annual promotion that features special vinyl and CD releases made exclusively for mom-and-pop record stores. It is intended to bring shoppers back to independent record stores, which offer human interaction between customers and clerks that often results in the discovery of a new favorite album. Better still, what makes small record stores different is their emphasis on selling locally produced music.

title: Cook County Refines Tools to Fight Shoplifting
description: In T. J. McCarthys 17 years as Orland Parks police chief, he has tracked the rise of retail-theft gangs,mainly by tallying the arrests at Orland Square Mall. But it wasnt until the arrest of a shoplifting ring last year that he realized how organized the thieves had become and how unprepared his department was to stop them.

title: For a Long-Term Afghan-American Accord, Night Raids Are a Sticking Point
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government has been talking about ending the American militarys controversial campaign of night raids for years, but now they see an opportunity to actually do something about it.

title: Selling Books by Their Gilded Covers
description: Even as more readers switch to the convenience of e-books, publishers are giving old-fashioned print books a makeover.

title: The Economy Is Painful in Skokie, Even in High School
description: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Plan to Close or Restructure 21 Chicago Schools Draws Quick Reaction
description: Mayor Rahm Emanuels education team made its first attempt at improving struggling schools last week, and the negative reviews came quickly. State legislators and community leaders called the proposed closing or restructuring of 21 schools very troubling and said administrators were violating the intent of a new state law.

title: An Abductees Daughter Speaks Out About an Unhealed Korean Wound
description: SEOUL, South Korea  On a sidewalk in central Seoul recently, Lee Mi-il and several other older South Koreans took turns at a microphone, calling out what seemed like an endless list of names. They began in the morning and continued through the night, announcing one name after another  83,000 in all  their voices ringing out and melting into the cacophony of the citys busiest district.

title: First Latino White Sox Star Gets Another Shot
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Lost and Found in Prince George
description: Traded to a junior hockey team in British Columbia at age 17, Derek Boogaard struggled on and off the ice. Then he met the Tobins.

title: Rock Music Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of the 15 musicians who are vying for a nod from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Museum.

title: Myanmars Courts Subvert Rule of Law, Activists Say
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton concluded her visit to Myanmar on Friday by telling reporters at the American Embassy that she was cautiously hopeful that Myanmar was emerging from decades of military dictatorship. But that was little solace for U Phoe Phyu.

title: National Gas Boom Brings Change and Commerce to Oklahoma
description: An extraordinary boom in the natural gas industry has brought new wealth and commerce to Oklahoma, but drilling rigs and construction sites have altered the landscape of communities large and small.

title: Know What Youre Protesting
description: HOW do you feel about the walkout?

title: U.S. Agents Launder Mexican Profits of Drug Cartels
description: WASHINGTON  Undercover American narcotics agents have laundered or smuggled millions of dollars in drug proceeds as part of Washingtons expanding role in Mexicos fight against drug cartels, according to current and former federal law enforcement officials.

title: I Was Impossible, but Then I Saw How to Lead
description: This interview with  Ruth J. Simmons, president of Brown University for the last 11 years, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Dr. Simmons is stepping down at the end of this academic year and will continue as a professor of comparative literature and Africana studies.

title: Natural Gas Boom Benefits Oklahoma and a Congressman
description: Representative Dan Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, has been a key champion of the natural gas industry for years, defending it against proposed federal regulations, pushing for subsidies and trying to block cuts in existing tax breaks. But he and his family also have extensive financial ties to the industry.

title: In Realignment, Little Is Simple
description: The N.H.L. board of governors meets Monday and Tuesday in Pebble Beach, Calif., with two major items on the agenda: realignment and the collective bargaining agreement that expires in September.

title: Battle of the Bands (and Egos) for the Rock Hall of Fame
description: OLD rock n rollers dont fade away. They just hope for a nod from Cleveland.

title: Films Focus on a Flawed Russian Figure Brings Ire With Putin Into View
description: MOSCOW  Khodorkovsky, a German filmmakers documentary on the saga of the jailed former oil magnate Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who for some has become a symbol of opposition to Vladimir V. Putin, made its official premiere in Moscow on Friday, in a theater just blocks from the Kremlin and just two days before parliamentary elections that are expected to hurt Mr. Putins party.

title: As Gas Riches Remake Plains, Lawmaker Shares in Bounty
description: CALUMET, Okla.  Gas money is transforming vast stretches of Oklahoma. Here, 40 miles west of the state capital, crews work through the night drilling new wells deep into the earth, and a small army of laborers rips through just-planted fields of winter wheat to install miles of gas pipeline.

title: College Football Replay: Dec. 3
description: A look at the day in college football, from major conference championships to the F.C.S. playoffs.

title: Secrets of the Bailout, Now Told
description: A FRESH account emerged last week about the magnitude of financial aid that the Federal Reserve bestowed on big banks during the 2008-09 credit crisis. The report came from Bloomberg News, which had to mount a lengthy legal fight to wrest documents from the Fed that detailed its rescue efforts.

title: Betty Haas Pfister, a Woman With Wings, Dies at 90
description: No, no, you cant go up! Betty Haass father insisted that day in 1940 when the family went to an air show in Bennington, Vt. But when her parents left, Ms. Haas, then 19, sneaked back to the airfield, paid a dollar and, as she liked to say, squished into a seat for a ride on a tiny plane.

title: On the Trail With Jon Huntsman
description: Jim Rutenberg reports from New Hampshire, where the biggest political advertiser in the state is a Super PAC funded partly by Jon M. Huntsman Jr.s billionaire father.

title: Huntsman Campaign Gets Aid From Group Tied to Father
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  In the most frequently shown Republican campaign commercial here so far, a grouchy cast of characters complain that no one has shown up we can trust as a conservative. The presidential candidate they are searching for, the commercial concludes, is former Gov. Jon M. Huntsman Jr. of Utah, to which one of the characters harrumphs, Why havent we heard of this guy?

title: Neediest Cases | Jonathan Ferreira
description: Jonathan Ferreira, 19, grew up poor in the Bronx, sharing a small room with his mother. But years of focusing on his education have paid off. He was accepted into 15 colleges and is now a freshman at Utica College.

title: From a Cold Apartment to a Utica College Dormitory
description: The bullies in middle and high school did not care much for Jonathan Ferreiras love of Beyonc, the singer with the enviable moves. When he performed her dance steps, other students called him gay.

title: Inspired by Bode Miller, a Bold Victory
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  A postrace video interview with Fridays World Cup downhill winner, Bode Miller, resonated with a young Swiss racer named Sandro Viletta before Saturdays World Cup super-G race on the same steep and technical Birds of Prey course.

title: L.S.U. Moves a Step Closer to Perfection
description: ATLANTA  Les Miles, the Louisiana State coach, stood in the hallway outside his teams locker room here Saturday after the Tigers 42-10 ruination of No. 12 Georgia in the Southeastern Conference championship game and was presented with the idea that L.S.U. was in the midst of the greatest season in college football.

title: Gingrich Leads in Latest Iowa Poll
description: Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich appears to have benefited from the troubles facing Herman Cain. Less than a month before the Iowa Republican caucuses, Mr. Gingrich has the strongest support among the voters who plan to participate in the partys first nominating contest, according to the latest Iowa Poll by the Des Moines Register, released Saturday evening.

title: Coaches Key to Duke-Stanford Matchup in Womens Soccer Title Game
description: The two best teams in womens college soccer will play for the N.C.A.A. national championship at 1 p.m. Eastern on Sunday  and with two evenly matched squads taking the field, the difference in the game may come down to the contrasting philosophies of two of the nations premier coaches.

title: Good Morning. Youre Nobel Laureates.
description: CHRISTOPHER A. SIMS, a prodigious mathematician and a path-breaking economist, was fast asleep at his home near Princeton University when the telephone rang.

title: Lottery Numbers
That Eternal Question of Fairness
description: THE growing gap between the top earners and everyone else is agitating our society in newly public ways. The Occupy Wall Street movement is one example. The anger spilling out over deficit reduction  or lack thereof  in Congress is another.

title: Those Euro Bets Have Many Ifs
description: THE European fiscal crisis isnt just raising investor concerns about how much foreign exposure to have, but also about how those bets should be made.

title: Dont Just Sit There, Work Out at Your Desk
description: EVERY day, millions of American workers do something dangerous to their health: they sit down.

title: Software That Listens for Lies
description: SHE looks as innocuous as Miss Marple, Agatha Christies famous detective.

title: Letters: Women at the Forefront of Union Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcoming the New Folks
description: WHEN I was 14, I worked on a farm, picking tomatoes. I was paid 50 cents an hour and made enough to buy a pair of skis.

title: Republican Candidates Pressed to Prove Their Conservatism
description: Six Republican presidential candidates faced tough questioning on their ideological bona fides and the coherence of their proposals during a policy-heavy forum shown on Fox News Channel on Saturday night.

title: Corrections: December 4
description: NEW YORK

title: Lauren Scarantino, Brian Hulla
description: Lauren Anne Scarantino and Brian Gerard Hulla were married Friday by the Rev. James L. Dugan at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Katie Rouff and John Ward IV
description: Katie Gitlin Rouff and John Andrew Ward IV were married Saturday evening in New York. The Rev. Robert E. Reiser, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Union League Club, where he was assisted by Rabbi David L. Reiner.

title: Leah Altman, Todd Soiefer
description: Leah Meredith Altman and Todd Daniel Soiefer were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Stephen A. Klein at Studio 450, an event space in New York.

title: Catherine Lauto, Neil Martin
description: Catherine Frances Lauto and Neil Joseph Martin were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Kazimierz A. Kowalski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, where he is pastor.

title: Susan Meyers, Kevin Clerkin
description: Susan Patricia Meyers and Dr. Kevin James Clerkin were married Saturday afternoon at the Church of St. Elizabeth of Hungary in Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Robert J. Clerkin, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Casey Flaherty, Jose Baos III
description: Casey Claire Flaherty, a daughter of Paula J. Flaherty and Kevin M. Flaherty of New York, was married Saturday to Jose Luis Baos III, the son of Adele Kaars-Sypesteyn of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Mr. Baos Jr. of New Orleans. The Rev. Raymond Fitzgerald, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Church in New Orleans.

title: Benjamin Schlechter, Kevin Bolduc
description: Benjamin Louis Schlechter and Kevin Matthew Bolduc were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz at the InterContinental Hotel in Boston.

title: Alyson Sachs, Joseph Schwartz
description: Alyson Emily Sachs and Joseph Harold Schwartz, are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Shmuel Lewis at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Betty Tsan and Benjamin Ngo
description: Betty Ca Tsan and Benjamin Van Ngo were married Saturday afternoon at the Church of the Nativity in Menlo Park, Calif. Msgr. Steven Otellini, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Logan Clare and Michael Weiss
description: Logan Victoria Clare and Michael Laurence Weiss were married Saturday evening at the SmogShoppe, an event space in Los Angeles. Aaron D. Tracy, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Heather Abramson and David Symons
description: Heather Barkan Abramson, the daughter of Lisa B. Abramson and Andrew B. Abramson of North Caldwell, N.J., was married Saturday evening in New York to David Hiram Symons, a son of Carol Symons and Leonard B. Symons of Plainview, N.Y. Rabbi Alan Silverstein officiated at the Plaza.

title: Charlotte Hillman, Drew Warshaw
description: Charlotte Portia Hillman and Drew Scott Warshaw were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Beth S. Kalisch at the Bowery Hotel in New York.

title: Mary Voehl, Damien Hirsch
description: Mary Ruth Voehl and Damien Hirsch were married on Saturday by the Rev. Mark A. Olenowski at St. Pius X Church in Montville, N.J.

title: Ginette Lospinoso, Matthew Dean
description: Ginette Marie Lospinoso and Matthew William Dean were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. Benjamin P. Flavin, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Elana Hoenig, David Glasner
description: Elana Pamela Hoenig and David Glasner are to be married Sunday at the LaMalfa Centre, an event space in Mentor, Ohio. Rabbi Lyle A. Fishman is to officiate.

title: Samantha Topping and John Gellert
description: Samantha Stark Topping and John Matthew Gellert were married Saturday evening at St. Jamess Church in New York. The Rev. Ryan C. Fleenor, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony with the Rev. David P. Marcotte, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

title: Jacqueline Bork and Eric Ginsberg
description: Dr. Jacqueline Toby Bork and Dr. Eric Solomon Ginsberg were married Saturday evening at 583 Park Avenue, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Scott A. Hoffman officiated.

title: Oklahoma State Makes Its Case, Point by Point
