description: STILLWATER, Okla.  The chant of L.S.U., L.S.U. that erupted in the third quarter of Oklahoma States rout of Oklahoma on Saturday night sounded more like wishful thinking for the third-ranked Cowboys.

title: How the Top 25 Fared
description: 1. LOUISIANA STATE (13-0)  beat. No. 12 Georgia, 42-10

title: Cotto Stops Margarito in Rematch
description: Antonio Margarito started with the taunting early, at the opening bell, or thereabouts. The more Miguel Cotto landed his fists on Margaritos face, the more Margarito shook his head, the more he smiled, even as blood dripped from his right eye down his cheek.

title: For Stanford Womens Soccer Team, the Time to Win Is Now
description: Entering Sundays game against Duke (22-3-1), here are five things that Stanford (24-0-1) has to do if it wants to win the universitys first womens soccer championship.

title: Ohio Wesleyan Celebrates After a Week When All Seemed Lost
description: Ohio Wesleyan beat Calvin, 2-1, on Saturday night in San Antonio to win the N.C.A.A. Division III national championship. The title was the second for Ohio Wesleyan and its coach, Jay Martin, who earned his 608th career victory in the final. That set a record for the most wins by any coach at any level in college mens soccer.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Ashok Malik of Tehelka  analyzes the costs and benefits of Indias decision to allow foreign retailers to open stores in the country in an even-handed essay. He argues that many of the opponents of the policy change are trying to scare Indians by raising the bogey of the foreigner. But he also points out that allowing foreign retailers will likely also put pressure on some domestic businesses and industries. Every economic initiative is a mixed blessing, he writes. Even if it expands the cake, there will still be some losers.

title: In London, a Festival for Chocolate Lovers
description: A lifelong lover of chocolate, Yael Rose is as happy sipping a cup of hot chocolate as she is nibbling sea-salted caramel or cocoa nibs. To be honest, I think its an addiction, she said. Theres something about the smell and colors of chocolate I simply cant resist every single time.

title: Is It Bad Strategy for Fans to Boo?
description: In a little bit of turnabout, Giants and Jets fans have been booed recently.

title: Steering Telecom Italia With a Steady Hand
description: ROME  In April 2007, as the global economy was beginning to unravel, Telefnica, the Spanish telecommunications company, led a group of Italian investors who bought a 22.4 percent stake in Telecom Italia, one of the pioneering mobile operators in Europe.

title: With Cain on Sideline, His Rivals Try to Prove Their Conservatism
description: With the Republican field reshaped by the suspension of Herman Cains campaign, six Republican presidential candidates tried to show their conservative credentials during a policy-heavy forum shown on Fox News Channel on Saturday night.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, December 4
description: Herman Cain  suspended his presidential campaign on Saturday amid accusations of sexual harassment and of an affair, thinning the Republican field. This latest development and the strategies of the other Republican candidates as they head into the Iowa caucuses are expected to dominate the Sunday shows.

title: Japan Poll Finds Record Good Will for U.S.
description: A record 82 percent of Japanese report having friendly feelings toward the United States, according to results of an annual government poll released Sunday, in the first such survey taken since the American militarys huge humanitarian effort last spring in Japans tsunami-ravaged northeast.

title: China Signals Reluctance to Rescue E.U.
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government over the weekend sought to tamp down international expectations that Beijing might use its large financial reserves to help ease the European debt crisis.

title: To the Battlements, Mark Ruffalo
description: Major environmental groups are lobbying for strict regulations on natural gas drilling in New York State, which could begin as early as next year. But activists like the actor Mark Ruffalo are seeking an all-out drilling ban, arguing that the country should move quickly toward reliance on renewable energy sources rather than reinforce dependence on a fossil fuel.

title: Italys Leader Unveils Radical Austerity Measures
description: ROME  Telling Italians that the fate of their country and the euro was at stake, Prime Minister Mario Monti unveiled a radical and ambitious package of spending cuts and tax increases on Sunday, including deeply unpopular moves like raising the countrys retirement age.

title: Evgeny Starodubtsev: Piano Recital
description: EVGENY STARODUBTSEV: PIANO RECITAL

title: How Safe Is Gingrichs Lead in Iowa?
description: Two new surveys out this morning, from the Des Moines Register and NBC News, show Newt Gingrich with the polling lead for the Iowa Republican caucuses. Although these results are broadly in line with other recent polls of the state, it is good to get the confirmation since these are extremely high-quality surveys. On average, Mr. Gingrich is at 25 percent in the two polls, with Mitt Romney and Ron Paul each at 17 percent.

title: Alarmed by Independent Candidates, Chinese Authorities Crack Down
description: BEIJING  Periodic elections to neighborhood Peoples Congresses are as close to participatory democracy as this nation comes. Of the many grass-roots candidates running here this year, Qiao Mu, an energetic 41-year-old journalism professor in the capital, seemed one of the better bets.

title: Long Lines and Scalpers: Rock Star? No, Leonardo
description: LONDON  Its hard to think of anything that Alexander McQueen and Leonardo da Vinci have in common. One made clothes out of feathers, flowers, shells and lace. The other painted intensely naturalistic religious scenes and animated portraits. But both, it seems, have the rare power to please modern crowds.

title: Latest Twilight Remains Leader at Box Office
description: It was a weekend of Thanksgiving leftovers at the multiplex. With no new broad-audience movies arriving in theaters, The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn  Part 1 (Summit Entertainment) repeated as the No. 1 picture in North America for the third weekend, taking in an estimated $16.9 million for a new total of $247.3 million. The Muppets (Walt Disney) was second with about $11.2 million in ticket sales, bringing its two-week total to $56.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics.

title: Carbon Emissions Show Biggest Jump Ever Recorded
description: Global emissions of carbon dioxide from fossil-fuel burning jumped by the largest amount on record last year, upending the notion that the brief decline during the recession might persist through the recovery.

title: Obama Offers Condolences in Deaths of Pakistanis
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama phoned the president of Pakistan on Sunday to offer condolences for the deaths of two dozen soldiers killed in NATO airstrikes along the Afghan border, the White House said.

title: Current Cuts Staff of Vanguard Documentary Series
description: As Current TV turns itself into a channel for liberal talk, it is turning away from its original source for news, a critically acclaimed documentary unit called Vanguard.

title: British Debt History
description: Ive been playing around with the IMFs historical public debt database, which has long-term information on ratios of debt to GDP. And you really have to marvel, given that historical record, at the deficit panic now so widespread. Heres debt as a percentage of GDP in Britain, back to 1830:

title: Scrates, Brazilian Soccer Star and Activist, Dies at 57
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Scrates, the soccer great and medical doctor who transcended the sport through his involvement in Brazils pro-democracy movement and his outspoken defense of his own bohemian excesses, died on Sunday in So Paulo, Brazil. He was 57.

title: A Scramble for Cains Supporters
description: The Republican presidential candidates were competing on Sunday, openly or more subtly, for the backing of former supporters of Herman Cain, a day after he suspended his presidential campaign with the defiant vow that, accusations of sexual misconduct aside, he would not go away.

title: Majority for Putins Party Narrows in Rebuke From Voters
description: MOSCOW  United Russia, the governing party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, suffered surprisingly steep losses in parliamentary elections on Sunday and was barely clinging to a 50 percent majority, with 95 percent of the votes counted.

title: Nadal Leads Spain Past Argentina for Davis Cup Title
description: SEVILLE, Spain  Rafael Nadal mounted a comeback Sunday to beat Juan Martn del Potro of Argentina and secure Spains fifth Davis Cup title.

title: Lives Crisscross Through Tumult in Hungary
description: The physical copy of Peter Nadass Parallel Stories does not hold up well to a particularly aggressive reading. In at least one readers experience, cracking the books spine to make the 1,133-page tome into a more manageable bedtime read caused pages to break loose from their binding; by novels end piles of disordered pages were scattered every which way.

title: Lies, Damned Lies, And Elections
description: As we wait to see whether the GOP nominates the guy who claims that his health plan was nothing like Obamacare, oh no, or the guy who claims that Freddie Mac paid him $1.6 million as a historian, one thing is obvious: this election is going to pose a major challenge to the news media. How will they handle the lies problem?

title: Airwaves Getting Crowded in Early Nominating States
description: 4:50 p.m. | Updated The airwaves in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina are about to become a lot more crowded with political ads this week.

title: Behind the Scenes at a Forum for Republican Candidates
description: Backstage can be something of an inner sanctum at a presidential debate: even though they are appearing on live television before millions of Americans, the candidates are used to having their clubhouse hermetically sealed from the public before and after they take the stage.

title: New Plan on Payroll Taxes Expected From Reid
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Democratic leader, Harry Reid, is expected to offer a new plan on Monday for extending the payroll tax cuts and jobless benefits that otherwise would expire this month, a fellow Democratic senator said on Sunday.

title: Brazils Scrates Is Dead at 57
description: Scrates, the elegant midfielder and Renaissance man who served as captain of Brazils 1982 World Cup team, died Sunday in So Paulo. He was 57. In addition to playing soccer, Scrates practiced medicine and dabbled in coaching and painting. He also wrote newspaper columns, delving into subjects as varied as soccer, politics and economics, and made forays into writing fiction and acting on the stage.

title: Where the Tangos Heat Finds a Home in the Sauna
description: A Finnish tango? That may sound like an oxymoron. But there has been a tango craze in Finland since World War II, especially since the 1980s. And not for mere imports from Argentina, but for home-grown varieties.

title: Art and the Limits of Neuroscience
description: What is art? What does art reveal about human nature? The trend these days is to approach such questions in the key of neuroscience.

title: At Fall Nationals, a Redouble Wins a Board
description: SEATTLE  The last two major championships at the Fall Nationals here, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams and the Keohane North American Swiss Teams, finished on Sunday evening.

title: Jets Still in Running for A.F.C. Berth After Ragged Win Against the Redskins
description: LANDOVER, Md.  Rex Ryan, the Jets full-time coach and part-time philosopher, is fond of talking about the lasting effect that a victory has on a team. For days, he says, food tastes better, cars drive faster, sleep comes easier.

title: On the Trail of a Murderer Still Alarmingly at Large
description: Whether you have been following the continuing Long Island multiple-murder case closely or only somewhat, the bluntly titled documentary The Long Island Serial Killer, Monday night on A&E, will hold a grim fascination.

title: Films Clash Over Access in Crime Case
description: A newly announced documentary about the West Memphis Three murder case in Arkansas carries the imprimatur of Peter Jackson, the Academy Award-winning director of the Lord of the Rings movies, and the goal of exonerating three men who were released from prison in August.

title: Giants Andrews Is Hospitalized
description: Stacy Andrews, a reserve offensive lineman for the Giants, missed Sundays game against the Green Bay Packers after being hospitalized with pulmonary embolisms in his lungs.

title: After Prison, a Squeaky-Clean Return to Reality
description: Aint I been to jail enough times for you to know how to treat me when I come home? the rapper T.I. asks his wife, Tameka, better known as Tiny, on the first episode of T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle, which has its premiere with back-to-back episodes Monday night on VH1, about two months after his most recent incarceration.

title: Stars Peruse a Shoeboxs Worth of Childhood Memories
description: Everybody has a shoebox. You know the one: its deep in the closet or attic and has your second-grade report card in it, perhaps a couple of kiddie drawings in pencil or crayon.

title: Monday: Midnight Visits to the Refrigerator
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  We havent seen a puzzle from Kenneth J. Berniker since 2010 (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but we welcome him back today as he offers us a very simple short vowel run theme. What do I mean by a vowel run?

title: Bent Notes Suffused With Blues
description: The Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, long in effect the resident chamber group at the 92nd Street Y, is touring some of New Yorks other halls this season and bringing new music to each stop. Having already offered the premiere of a Stanley Silverman work there in September, the trio turned up at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening with a lively new work by Ellen Taaffe Zwilich. Still to come are performances at Town Hall, with a fresh Richard Danielpour score, and at Alice Tully Hall (as guests of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center) with the latest from Andr Previn.

title: ABC Daytime Chief to Leave Network
description: Brian Frons, the ABC executive who angered many soap opera fans this year by canceling All My Children and One Life to Live, will leave the network when his contract expires next month. The Disney/ABC Television Group said that Vicki Dummer, ABCs senior vice president for current series and specials, would take over Mr. Fronss responsibilities for daytime programming. The soap opera General Hospital and talk shows like The View will be incorporated into Times Square Studios, a division of the ABC/Disney Television Group that will manage and create daytime and syndicated shows. Ms. Dummers title will be executive vice president of Times Square Studios. General Hospital, which has an uncertain fate as ABCs remaining soap opera, looks like the odd one out at Times Square Studios: a news release on Friday said the division would mostly develop nonscripted lifestyle and health programming. Along with The View, it will manage the two shows that are replacing the soap operas  The Chew and The Revolution  as well as the game show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire and Katie Courics forthcoming syndicated talk show. The Chew, which features a panel of five chefs and foodies who cook and drink and chat, began in September in place of All My Children; The Revolution, described by ABC as a talk show about health and lifestyle transformations, is to begin in January in place of One Life to Live. Mr. Frons has headed the daytime hours of ABC since 2002. While my decision to try something new was not arrived at easily, nine years is a long time in television terms, he said in a statement.

title: Town Hall Season Is Announced
description: The 30 Rock comedian and Tony Award winner Jane Krakowski, below,  is set to return to the stage for a one-woman show as part of Town Halls 91st anniversary season, the theater announced. Ms. Krakowski will perform a range of musical numbers on June 8 in a season that will also include solo concerts from Lea Salonga (Miss Saigon) on May 4 and the Grammy Award winner Loudon Wainwright III on May 18. Other highlights include the musical-comedy troupe Capitol Steps (March 23) and a double bill of Judy Collins and Madeleine Peyroux on June 1. Information: the-townhall-nyc.org.

title: More Radioactive Water Leaks at Japanese Plant
description: TOKYO  At least 45 tons of highly radioactive water have leaked from a purification facility at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, and some of it may have reached the Pacific Ocean, the plants operator said Sunday.

title: Punched Out | Part Two
description: A long shot to even make the N.H.L., Derek Boogaard embraced the violent role of enforcer for the Minnesota Wild. But, it was a brutal way to make a living.

title: Anatomy of a Hockey Fight
description: An analysis of a D.J. King - Derek Boogaard fight

title: Todd Fedoruk on Addiction
description: Todd Fedoruk, former N.H.L enforcer and Boogaard teammate, on addiction.

title: Derek Boogaard: Blood on the Ice
description: I DIDNT SEE it coming at all. I was in a bad position and he hit me hard, hardest Ive ever been hit. I instantly knew it was broken. I didnt lose consciousness, but I went straight on the ice. And I felt where it was, and my hand didnt rub my face normally. It was a little chunky and sharp in spots and there was a hole there about the size of a fist.   TODD FEDORUK, former N.H.L. enforcer

title: Footnotes
description: Performers and other protesters, above, gathered in the theater district from Friday night to Saturday for Occupy Broadway, called by the organizers a 24-hour creative resistance action to promote the right to assemble in privately owned public spaces. Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, the scene of Occupy Wall Street, is also such a space. ... The Public Theater has announced a five-week reprise of The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, Mike Daiseys exploration of Apple and Mr. Jobs, who died in October. The second round is to run from Jan. 31 to March 4.

title: One Woman, Three Works
description: The suggestion behind The Heist Project, a one-woman show created by the dancer Belinda McGuire, is that it shares something in common with a jewel heist. Alas, the choreography on display at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night  three solos in total is hardly tempting swag.

title: A Fado Traditionalist, Embracing Torment, Suffering and Song
description: Fado, the Portuguese tradition of elegant, emotive songs filled with tragedy and longing, was named to Unescos Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity list in late November. By happy coincidence the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music had scheduled two nights of fado that began Friday with a concert featuring the United States debut of Caman, 44, a major star in Portugal who is one of his generations leading fado singers, or fadistas. At this concert fados past was never far from its present.

title: Private-College Presidents Getting Higher Salaries
description: Presidents at 36 private colleges earned more than $1 million in 2009, up from 33 the previous year, according to a study by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: Couples Loving and Fighting Between Multiple Pirouettes
description: At City Center this month Robert Battle, the new artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is introducing himself to Ailey audiences. And for at least the first three evenings of the season he has done so in person, speaking from the stage. Amiable and welcoming, he has that part of the job down.

title: Melancholia Picks Up European Film Awards
description: The European Film Awards, voted on by 2,500 members of the European Film Academy, offered its year-end prizes on Saturday in Berlin. Melancholia, starring Kirsten Dunst, below, from the Danish director Lars von Trier, was named best picture; it also won awards for cinematography and production design. Last years big Oscar winner, The Kings Speech, which was released in Europe in 2011, earned another best-actor prize for its star Colin Firth; Tilda Swinton took home best actress for playing the mother of a son who goes on a Columbine-style rampage in We Need to Talk About Kevin. Susanne Bier won best director for In a Better World, which also won best foreign film at the Oscars last year. Pina, Wim Wenderss 3-D take on the choreographer Pina Bausch, won best documentary. Mr. von Trier sent his wife, Bente Froge, to accept the award on his behalf. Ms. Froge said that Mr. von Trier had taken a vow of silence after he made comments sympathizing with Nazis at the Cannes Film Festival. I should say from Lars that he has no statement for you, Ms. Froge said, according to The Guardian of London. But he did ask that I should wave to you in a kind and gentle way.

title: Fedoruk to Answer Readers Questions
description: Updated | Answers can be found here.

title: Music United Couple; Now It Helps Surviving Spouse Cope
description: When Philip Thomas visits the esplanade at Carl Schurz Park in Manhattan, memories of his late wife, Abby, rush in.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: College Presidents Compensation Has Risen Rapidly
description: The compensation of many college presidents has grown faster than that for professors and some of them now receive more than $1 million a year  representing a large share of university budgets.

title: Where Facial Hair Is a Serious, or at Least Competitive, Subject
description: The singer flirted loudly, blond hair bobbing behind her head, asking attendees to pose for photographs with her.

title: Cities, Suburbs and Changing Attitudes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Law School Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Pfizers Investments
description: To the Editor:

title: New NPR Chief Faces Tough Landscape
description: On Thursday, his first day as president and chief executive of NPR, Gary E. Knell took questions on Twitter and NPRs Talk of the Nation  and he got an earful.

title: Saving the Postal Service in the Internet Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Nurturing Talent
description: To the Editor:

title: Books and Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Away From N.B.A., Finding Success and Serenity in China
description: Stephon Marbury sounded content and tranquil last week as he described his new life in China. Perhaps it was because he was tired; after all, it was nearly midnight in Beijing.

title: At UConn, Teaming Pledge and Anthem, to Mixed Reviews
description: HARTFORD  Before Connecticut, the defending N.C.A.A. mens basketball champion, began its game against Arkansas on Saturday at XL Center, a rare and polarizing request preceded the national anthem: the 14,333 fans, coaches and players were asked to join in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: Chicken Chain Says Stop, but T-Shirt Maker Balks
description: For Bo Muller-Moore, a folk artist from Vermont, the T-shirts he hand-screens with the slogan Eat More Kale are a dream fulfilled: a quirky project that has emblazoned this leafy mandate across the chests of people worldwide, and one he wants to trademark.

title: Packers Are Unbeaten; Giants Are Unbowed
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Was it better for the Giants on Sunday? Of course it was. After last week against the New Orleans Saints, it almost had to be. Some of the players grudgingly said as much in the locker room after the game, whispering slivers of positivity through gritted teeth.

title: Maybin Gives Jets Key Lift With Big Sack
description: A capsule look at the Jets 34-19 victory at Washington on Sunday:

title: Investors Anticipate Clearer Picture From Europe
description: After weeks of pressure from investors, European leaders won themselves a breather last week amid hopes for quick action on the debt crisis there. For the markets, the question this week is whether they can deliver.

title: After Two-Year Drought, Woods Wins With Flourish
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  The scoreboard showed Tiger Woods locked in a duel with Zach Johnson over the final holes at Sherwood Country Club on Sunday. In fact, Woodss real battle down the stretch was with himself.

title: 31 Are Arrested at Occupy D.C. Building Site
description: WASHINGTON  Police arrested 31 people on Sunday night and tore down a barnlike building Occupy D.C. protesters began to erect that morning in a park two blocks from the White House where they have been camping out. The episode, in which police officers plucked some protesters from the buildings rafters with a cherry picker or coaxed them to jump off it onto an inflated cushion, lasted into the evening.

title: Underwater Drones Giving More Eyes to Police Harbor Unit as Searches Grow
description: With President Obama in town last Wednesday, things were busy for the New York Police Departments Harbor Unit. Federal security agents were disseminating lists of city locations that had to be swept for bombs, cleared and guarded.

title: Bring Health Care Home
description: ONE of my patients called me with a high fever, chills and dropping blood pressure. He was 48 and had been a quadriplegic since he was shot during a robbery in the hardware store he owned. I called an ambulance and admitted him to the hospital, where we soon brought his urinary tract infection under control. But he developed a bedsore, which became infected with an antibiotic-resistant bacterium that breeds in hospitals. He didnt survive the hospitalization.

title: Charismatic Church Leader, Dogged by Scandal, to Stop Preaching for Now
description: LITHONIA, Ga.  At the height of his power, Bishop Eddie L. Long would pack tens of thousands of people into his megachurch in the suburbs of Atlanta.

title: Moral Victory for Giants?
description: A capsule look at the Giants 38-35 loss to Green Bay on Sunday:

title: Bowl Championship Series Standings
description: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a teams B.C.S. Score.

title: Send in the Clueless
description: There are two crucial things you need to understand about the current state of American politics. First, given the still dire economic situation, 2012 should be a year of Republican triumph. Second, the G.O.P. may nonetheless snatch defeat from the jaws of victory  because Herman Cain was not an accident.

title: Weekly Grind Pays Off in a Rematch for the Title
description: College footballs quarterback-centric offenses, with their multiple formations and 30-plus passes a game, were dropped out of a second-story window Sunday. They landed with a thud, and will have nothing to do with deciding the national championship.

title: What, Is It Because Hes Slow? This Time, an Animal Escape Elicits Shrugs
description: They swooned over the Egyptian cobra, gone rogue inside the Bronx Zoos Reptile House last March. They cheered the peacock from the Central Park Zoo, who crossed Fifth Avenue to spend an August day on the ledge of an Upper East Side apartment building, only to return, on his own, the following morning.

title: Leaders Piece Together an Effort to Keep the Euro Intact
description: PARIS  European leaders are working overtime on a tentative deal to try to save the euro, which they hope to complete at a crucial summit meeting in Brussels this week. But rather than one transformative leap, the deal will have several moving parts, together meant to show resolve to protect Italy and Spain, revise the economic governance of the euro zone and prevent further debt crises, officials involved in the talks say.

title: The Role of Youth
description: The filmmaker Matt Wolf and the writer Jon Savage reflect on the history of youth in times of crisis.

title: The Role of Youth
description: This video draws on ideas and material from a larger film we are making called "Teenage. That project examines the history of youth and shows how teenagers, as we know them today, were born.

title: Lessons in Coping for Children of Deployed
description: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C.  Can we talk about deployment? Gregory Bole, a counselor, asked the kindergartners last week at Tarawa Terrace Elementary, one of seven schools on the Marine base here.

title: Tent to Vanish, Taking With It Some Bowery Spirit
description: Billy Leroy stood outside his antique shop on East Houston Street on Saturday afternoon wearing a brown overcoat with a fur collar and holding a long brass hunting horn. Raising it to his lips, Mr. Leroy used the horn as a speaking tube, announcing, Billys Antiques is having a sale.

title: Why School Choice Fails
description: Washington

title: Another Win, but a Blueprint for Defeat
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: The X Factor Connects With Its Audience
description: Shelby Worthington and Kelly Le are both 18 and are both Fox viewers. But they have very different feelings about the networks two biggest reality shows, the nearly 10-year-old hit American Idol and the brand-new hit The X Factor.

title: Lloyd J. Old, Champion of Using Cells to Fight Cancer, Dies at 78
description: Dr. Lloyd J. Old, who made seminal discoveries about the relationship between cancer and the immune system, and despite setbacks in the field steadfastly promoted the development of vaccines and other immunological means to fight cancer, died on Nov. 28 at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: What Gingrich Didnt Learn in Congo
description: San Francisco

title: 10 Fans Injured After Oklahoma State Beats Oklahoma
description: STILLWATER, Okla.  A number of people were injured Saturday night when fans stormed the field to celebrate Oklahoma States victory over its rival Oklahoma in their annual Bedlam game.

title: Why Does the SAT Endure?
Text Messages to Woo Patrons
description: With the holiday shopping season in full swing, retailers are trying everything to get consumers into stores. Now consumers who visit any of the 27 open-air malls owned by DDR, the commercial real estate company, will be able to receive text messages offering deals from any one of the hundreds of retailers in each of those malls.

title: Cuomo Pushes New Tax Rates for Big Earners
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday called for comprehensive reform of New Yorks tax code that would mean higher tax rates for the wealthy and a tax cut for the middle class, according to officials briefed on the plan.

title: Print Empire Embraces a New Order
description: There have been creeping indications that the magazine business isnt really about magazines anymore. In 2010, Hearst Magazines bought iCrossing, a digital marketing agency, and the company has since christened publications that have no print version. Every day, my in-box swells with announcements that this or that glossy now has an iPad app, nearly all of them trumpeting amazing interactive features that take you far beyond a traditional magazine experience. Over and over we are told that a magazine is really just one vehicle for a brand that scales across platforms.

title: Billys Antiques
description: Billy Leroy of Billys Antiques and Props prepares to tear down his tent on East Houston Street.

title: Judd Woldin, Raisin Score Composer, Dies at 86
description: Judd Woldin, a pianist and theater composer who wrote the score for the Tony-winning musical Raisin, died Nov. 27 in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Ted Ligety Finishes Second in World Cup Giant Slalom
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. Ted Ligetys surgeonlike precision on giant slalom racecourses has prompted rivals to pore over his technique on video. And that mechanical, mistake-free style was on display during Sundays World Cup giant slalom race here  Ligety won the first run in just that fashion.

title: Anti-Abortion Groups Are Split on Legal Tactics
description: A widening and emotional rift over legal tactics has split the anti-abortion movement, with its longtime leaders facing a Tea Party-like insurrection from many grass-roots activists who are impatient with the pace of change.

title: Pain in the Public Sector
description: Buried in the relatively positive numbers contained in the November jobs report was some very bad news for those who work in the public sector. There were 20,000 government workers laid off last month, by far the largest drop for any sector of the economy, mostly from states, counties and cities.

title: Cashmans Stunt Could Be Yankees Off-Season Highlight
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  For all the attention that the Yankees brand commands, there are some institutions that are hard to outdo. And so it was that General Manager Brian Cashman was an afterthought next to Santa Claus for the hundreds of children at a Christmas tree lighting Sunday night.

title: Lottery Numbers
In Southern Arizona, Rare Sightings of Ocelots and Jaguars Send Shivers
description: PHOENIX  The Serengeti is associated with safaris. The Maasai Mara, too. But southern Arizona?

title: A Broken, Dangerous System
description: After reports of chronic abuses  of detainees beaten and sometimes left to die of untreated injuries and illness  the Obama administration in 2009 vowed an overhaul of the nations immigration detention system, the sprawling patchwork of prisons and prison-like institutions that confines nearly 400,000 people a year as they await deportation or asylum.

title: A Surprising Conversation
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Online Learning, Personalized
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Jesse Roe, a ninth-grade math teacher at a charter school here called Summit, has a peephole into the brains of each of his 38 students.

title: Undermining the Executive Branch
description: The House will soon consider a bill called the Regulations From the Executive in Need of Scrutiny Act, Reins for short. Its proponents  more than 200 co-signers, mostly Republicans  may hope the stupefying title will lull voters into forgetting what the bill would do. That would be a mistake. Reins is a terrible piece of legislation that would undermine a functioning regulatory system that protects people from harm. It would also do a great disservice to Congress itself.

title: Explosion Seen as Big Setback to Irans Missile Program
description: WASHINGTON  The huge explosion that destroyed a major missile-testing site near Tehran three weeks ago was a major setback for Irans most advanced long-range missile program, according to American and Israeli intelligence officials and missile technology experts.

title: Where Schools Fall Short
description: Millions of students attend abysmally weak school systems that leave them unprepared for college, even as more jobs require some higher education. The states have an obligation to help these students retool.

title: Breaking the Fourth Wall to Let Chekhov Out
description: Is anybody listening, or am I just talking to myself?

title: The Force of a Personality Can Conjure Up a World
description: Thats an awful lot of space for one mere mortal to fill up. The stage that has been created at St. Anns Warehouse for Misterman  Enda Walshs gripping (as in by the throat) monologue of a play  looks to be roughly half the size of a football field. And Cillian Murphy, the sole and slender actor who appears in it, is definitely not as big as your average football player.

title: The Cherry Orchard
description: Photos from the Classic Stage production, starring Diane Wiest and John Turturro.

title: With a Click of the Remote, Impulse Purchases
description: Giving television viewers the ability to buy products they see on their screens with a click of a remote control  say the Manolo Blahniks on Carrie Bradshaws feet or Rosss sweater on Friends  has been talked about by advertisers for years without much success.

title: Stanford Edges Duke to Win Its First Womens Soccer Title
description: KENNESAW, Ga.  Avenging consecutive 1-0 losses in the N.C.A.A. tournament final, Stanford held on to beat Duke by that same score on Sunday to win its first national title in womens soccer.

title: City Cracking Down on Performers in Washington Square Park
description: Colin Huggins was there with his baby grand, the one he wheels into Washington Square Park for his al fresco concerts. So were Tic and Tac, a street-performing duo, who held court in the fountain  dry for the winter. And Joe Mangrum was pouring his elaborate sand paintings on the ground near the Washington Arch.

title: Despite Surge, Gingrich Faces Major Hurdles
description: Surging in polls is one thing. But as Newt Gingrich seeks to turn his impressive performance in surveys into votes, he is scrambling madly to build the kind of organization that Mitt Romney has methodically put in place for a year, one that will let him compete through all 50 contests, often in multiple states at once.

title: Reasons to Stop a Utility Merger
description: Northeast Utilities, New Englands biggest electric utility, failed in the duties that come with its monopoly. With the release of a new report, regulators have all the evidence they need to stop Northeast Utilities $4.7 billion takeover of Massachusetts rival Nstar.

title: Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the ISM nonmanufacturing index for November and factory orders for October (Monday); consumer credit for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and wholesale trade inventories for October (Thursday); the trade deficit for October and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for December (Friday).

title: Vice President of Harvard Will Lead Bates College
description: Clayton Spencer, the vice president for policy at Harvard University, has been named the eighth president of Bates College, a small liberal arts institution in Lewiston, Me., effective July 1.

title: Yankees Interest in Free-Agent Pitchers Is Not High
description: DALLAS  As baseball executives began to assemble Sunday at the Hilton Anatole for the annual winter meetings, the man with the biggest checkbook in the sport and with a long history of bold off-season transactions was not among the early arrivals.

title: At TV and Radio Outlets, Little-Known Trove of Kudos and Complaints
description: Angered by the tendency of Judith Sheindlin, the television jurist Judge Judy, to address young women as babies, an elderly man wrote to WCBS-TV (Channel 2) in protest, proclaiming that it was Balderdash! and proceeding, in neat cursive script, to chronicle his marriage, and the war service he rendered, when he was just 21.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: For Turkey, Lure of Tie to Europe Is Fading
description: ISTANBUL  As economic contagion tarnishes the European Union, a newly assertive Turkey is increasingly looking east instead of west, and asking a vexing question: Should Turkey reject Europe before Europe rejects Turkey?

title: Plan to Close Westchesters Nature Centers Meets Resistance
description: It has become as much a ritual for nature lovers in Westchester County as it has for salamanders: every spring at Cranberry Lake Preserve, a county sanctuary in West Harrison, residents arrive, armed with flashlights, to watch the amphibians emerge from their winter dens.

title: Book Shopping in Stores, Then Buying Online
description: Bookstore owners everywhere have a lurking suspicion: that the customers who type into their smartphones while browsing in the store, and then leave, are planning to buy the books online later  probably at a steep discount from the bookstores archrival, Amazon.com.

title: Two Giant Radio Groups Form Daily-Deal Alliance
description: Two of the fastest-growing trends in media have been daily-deal Web sites and the aggregation of entertainment content online. Now the two biggest radio companies have formed an alliance to compete on both fronts.

title: Biden, in Visits to Middle East and Europe, Tries to Reassure Allies of U.S. Support
description: ATHENS  As he traded the political upheaval of the Middle East for the economic storms of Europe, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has preached a consistent message on his travels: The United States isnt going anywhere, as he put it on Sunday.

title: Reyes Is Set to Leave Mets for Marlins
description: DALLAS  Jose Reyes has been a member of the Mets organization since he signed with the organization as a 16-year-old out of the Dominican Republic, but he has finally grown out of the struggling franchise. With the Mets unable to meet his financial demands, Reyes had agreed in principle to a six-year, $106 million contract with the Miami Marlins on Sunday night, according to a person with direct knowledge of the talks.

title: Jets Replay: Week 13
description: After a slow start, the Jets offense finally caught fire in the fourth quarter as they beat the Redskins, 34-19.

title: Visiting the Titanic
description: Footage shot by Rob Goldsmith in July 2005 for the History Channel. (Courtesy of The History Channel, UK  Copyright 2011)

title: Plunging Deep (in Pockets) to See Titanic at 100
description: Down, down, down you go, for two and a half hours, jammed with two other people in a tiny submersible, all the way to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean  and all for a glimpse, through a five- or eight-inch porthole, of the ravaged remains of the once-grand ship where the Astors and the Strauses played, dined and, in some cases, died.

title: More Principals Join Teacher Evaluation Protest
How to Use Blocks to Teach
Reyes, Longtime Mets Star, Is Set to Join the Marlins
description: DALLAS  Jose Reyes has worn only the blue, orange and white of the Mets, the team that signed him as a 16-year-old in 1999 and the organization with which he has played his entire distinguished career.

description: BAGHDAD  The American Embassy in Baghdad has placed sharp new restrictions on how government workers can travel inside the walled-off International Zone, citing serious threats of kidnapping and terrorist attacks across Iraq and near the embassys own doorstep.

title: Blast in Bahrain Near British Post
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A canister containing what Bahrain officials described as highly explosive material damaged the front of a minibus on Sunday near the British Embassy in the capital, Manama, though there were no injuries or serious damage.

title: Kennedy Center Honors Five Virtuosos
description: WASHINGTON  On Nov. 29, 1962, a 7-year-old named Yo-Yo Ma gave a dazzling cello performance here at a televised concert that kicked off fund-raising efforts to build what is now the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Xbox Live Challenges Cable Box
description: The old-fashioned cable television set-top box  long the hub of living-room entertainment for most people  is about to become less relevant.

title: Sending of Sexual Images by Minors Isnt as Prevalent as Expected, Study Finds
description: One in 10 children ages 10 to 17 has used a cellphone to send or receive sexually suggestive images, but only 1 in 100 has sent images considered graphic enough to violate child pornography laws, a new study found.

description: There had been some dread in the Good Wife community before Sunday nights episode, Parenting Made Easy (otherwise known as the kidnap episode), but it turned out there was nothing to worry about. Graces temporary disappearance  a plot device to crystallize all the troubles in Alicias life, bringing together Alicia, Peter, Will, Kalinda and both of the children (only Jackie was absent, conspicuously)  was suspenseful but not overplayed; no sharks were jumped.

title: Sarkozy and Merkel Push for Changes to Europe Treaty
description: PARIS  Under the pressure of financial crisis and with the euro currency at stake, the two main leaders of the euro zone said Monday that they would together push to remake the European Union into a more integrated political and economic federation, with tight legal restraints on how much debt national parliaments can issue.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 5, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: U.S. Asks South Korea to Cut Petrochemical Imports From Iran
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A senior American diplomat urged South Korea on Monday to suspend imports of Iranian petrochemicals as Washington tried to rally international pressure on Iran tostop its nuclear program.

title: Dec. 5, 1933 | Ratification of 21st Amendment Ends Prohibition
description: On Dec. 5, 1933, national Prohibition came to an end, as Utah became the 36th state to ratify the 21st Amendment to the Constitution. The amendment repealed the 18th Amendment, which had taken effect nearly 14 years earlier.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 5, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article Congress Blocks New Rules on School Lunches.

title: Even in Egypt, a Long Way to Go
description: Moises Saman has been covering the Arab Spring for The New York Times since its beginning in Tunisia. In July, he moved to Egypt  where, for the last four weeks, he has been photographing the run-up to the Egyptian elections. Mr. Saman, a nominee for membership in the Magnum Photos cooperative, spoke with James Estrin and David Furst last Wednesday. This conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: Commercial Metals Rejects Icahns Bid
description: LONDON  The Commercial Metals Company on Monday rejected a proposed takeover by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, calling his offer, which values the company at more than $1.7 billion, a bargain basement price.

title: WikiLeaks Founder Can Make Final Bid to Avoid Extradition
description: LONDON  The High Court gave permission on Monday for Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks antisecrecy organization, to begin a final appeal to Britains highest judicial authority against extradition to Sweden on allegations of sexual abuse, the latest step in a yearlong legal battle in which he has been under house arrest at a friends country mansion.

title: Chelsea Clinton Steps Into the Spotlight
description: WHO is Chelsea Clinton?WHO are her famous parents?

title: South Korea to Send $5.7 Million in Aid to North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said Monday that it would resume sending aid to the North through Unicef, the United Nations childrens agency, which it had halted more than a year ago amid tensions over the sinking of a South Korean warship.

Do you think this years nominees are good choices?

title: After 85 Years, Y&R Plans to Leave Madison Ave. for Columbus Circle

title: India Asks Google, Facebook to Screen User Content
description: The Indian government has asked Internet companies and social media sites like Facebook to prescreen user content from India and to remove disparaging, inflammatory or defamatory content before it goes online, three executives in the information technology industry say.

title: Gore Has Niners Record, but Where Does He Rank?
description: Heres a discussion for Niners fans to have: Where does Frank Gore rank on your teams running back list? Statistically, hes now No. 1. His 73 yards rushing Sunday gave him 7,396 for his career, moving him past Joe Perry. Its difficult to compare Gore to Perry given that Perry played some 50 years ago. As for comparing Gore with more modern Niner running backs

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

description: Four straight trips to the womens soccer Final Four for Stanford have ended in 1-0 games. Only this time, the Cardinal walked away with the College Cup in hand.

title: Complaint Box | Overperfumed
description: As any New Yorker can attest, our city is permeated by smells: curbside garbage, street carts selling nuts or kabobs, impromptu barbecues, fresh marijuana and the odoriferous mlange produced by the subway system, especially in the summer.

title: Australian Mining Companies in Talks on $5 Billion Merger
description: LONDON  The coal developer Aston Resources said on Monday that it was in discussions with another Australian miner, Whitehaven Coal, on a potential merger valued at almost $5 billion.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 5
description: Madonna is to perform during the halftime show at Super Bowl XLVI in Indianapolis, set to air Feb. 5 on NBC, the network announced on Sunday night during its football broadcast. The idea had been in play  for some time, with Madonna seen as fitting the N.F.L.s trend of looking to older performers since the controversy over the wardrobe malfunction of Janet Jackson in 2004. She will collaborate with a team from Cirque du Soleil, the choreographer Jamie King and artists from Moment Factory, The Associated Press reported.

title: Jason Garrett Too Cautious in Cowboys Defeat
description: Forget that the regular-season overtime rules prevented the Cowboys from even touching the ball after regulation of a 19-13 loss at Arizona  that was merely karmic justice. Any coach that mismanages timeouts and field position as spectacularly as Dallas Coach Jason Garrett did in the final minutes deserves to lose. First, Garrett seemingly iced his own kicker by calling a timeout just before Dan Baileys 49-yard field goal on what would have been the games final play. (Bailey made the initial kick, but couldnt repeat it.) Analyzing timeout usage as it pertains to a kickers rhythm is like analyzing how your day might have been different if youd only brushed your teeth three minutes earlier. Its a fruitless practice thats all hindsight and presumption.

title: Those Romantic Wood Stoves
description: Were one cord into an expected six-cord winter and starting the colder part of our year in the Maine woods off the grid with three kids and two cats from the New Jersey suburbs. Its the first time I have heated with wood, and I miss the simplicity of a thermostat connected to a furnace.

title: HSBC Fined for Selling Unsuitable Investments to the Elderly
description: LONDON  British authorities on Monday fined HSBC 10.5 million, or $16.4 million, for selling inappropriate financial products to elderly customers, the largest penalty related to a retail product.

description: TAIZ, Yemen  The cease-fire lasted a day.

description: The Jets know they need to keep winning as long as a playoff berth isnt locked up. But for fans, it doesnt mean scoreboard watching cant be part of it.

description: JOHANNESBURG  An advocacy organization that helped to establish an international certification program to prevent the sale of so-called blood diamonds withdrew from the coalition on Monday, saying the effort was no longer effective.

title: The Help Stars Improvise on the Lunch Script
description: There are a lot of commonalities at the awards season lunches organized by Peggy Siegal, the PR doyenne: the seating is highly managed, the guests are notable and the desserts, poor things, go largely untouched. One thing the Bagger doesnt usually see: impromptu Q & As between stars and sports legends.

title: The Super Bowl Gets Its (Material) Girl: Madonna to Perform at Halftime Show
description: Having been burned by artists who proved too controversial, the National Football League has chosen a halftime performer for Super Bowl XLVI with a nice, safe, biblically inspired name. Well, not exactly.

title: Gingrich in New York, and Cain in the Dust
description: There was a rare political development in New York on the weekend: A Republican candidate for president did some campaigning in the city. He didnt come just to raise money, or just to meet with the well-known reality television personality with implausible hair. No, Newt Gingrich actually met New Yorkers on Saturday.

title: SAPs Strategy with SuccessFactors
description: SAP made a big move into the cloud computing world over the weekend, buying the human resource management software company SuccessFactors for $3.4 billion. But its first steps after the purchase are going to involve a lot of old-time selling.

title: Auction Alert | The Goddess Adorned
description: Gaia, the ancient Greek earth goddess, is being sold to the highest bidder, but its for a good cause. A collaboration between the Turkish home accessories company Gaia & Gino, the New York designer Harry Allen and Swarovski Elements has produced The Goddess Adorned, an auction of 15 of Allens shapely Gaia vases, which have been customized by a glittering list of celebrities in the worlds of fashion, design and style, including Ashley and Mary Kate Olsen for  Elizabeth and James, Kenneth Jay Lane, Doo.Ri, Waris Ahluwalia and Allen himself. The vases will be auctioned online for two weeks starting Tuesday to benefit Housing Works, and will be on view at the Swarovski Crystallized concept store, at 499 Broadway in SoHo. The original vase, which was designed by Allen for Gaia & Gino but never produced, was always meant to be dressed, with jewelry or ribbons, for instance. I designed the vase to be transformed, Allen explains, citing Gaye Cevikel, Gaia & Ginos fashionable founder, as his inspiration. A number of samples of the vase were made, and Allen had the idea to auction them for charity.

title: Fielders Weight Is the $150 Million Question
description: With the winter meetings opening Monday, speculation will be rampant as to where the high-profile free agents will end up.

title: Gimme an E! Gimme a C! Gimme a B!
description: Markets clearly believe that the Europeans have found a formula that will make it possible for the ECB to step in and buy lots of Italian bonds.

title: No, Its Not The Welfare State
description: Dean Baker takes on a favorite pet peeve of mine  the incessant claim that Europes woes are being caused by the burden of the welfare state.

title: Syria Offers to Allow Observers, With Strings
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syria said Monday that it would agree to allow an Arab mission of military and civilian observers into the country as part of an Arab League proposal to end months of bloodshed there, but it attached a number of conditions, among them the cancellation of economic sanctions decreed by the league.

title: Are Parks a Boon to State Economies?
description: Challenging the notion that protecting public land locks it up, more than 100 economists, including three Nobel laureates, are calling on the president and Congress to create more parks and other protected preserves in the West as a way to bolster state economies.

description: The Chicago Tribune: Can you say: Tavern on the Green in Central Park? Rahm Emanuel, Chicagos Mayor, is trying to jack up the fees the city gets for the Park Grill at Millennium Park, suing to invalidate a generous 2003 concession deal the city made under former Mayor Richard M. Daley.  Glenn Collins

title: Monday Reading: Hotels Add Perks as Airlines Cut Back
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Tebow, Numbers Geeks and Yet Another Victory
description: In his Monday Morning QB at Sports Illustrateds site, Peter King wrote:

title: Cunningham Countdown: A Monday With Merce
description: On Monday Merce Cunningham will appear on screen in the first public showing of his final interview. It is 18 minutes long and unedited. The interview was filmed in June 2009, the month before his death. When his face first appears on screen  he was 90, had been largely confined to a wheelchair for some years, and in recent months had suffered various medical setbacks  youre aware of the depredations of age. Then he talks, and its evident that the mind was still sharp, the interest in precise verbal articulation still alert, the passion for dance unrelenting. It is an exciting revelation of his unflagging intelligence.

title: The Get | Mark Cross Madison Mini Doctor Bag
description: As far as shapes go, the Madison Mini Doctor bag from the all-American leather goods label Mark Cross is an interesting one  extra-long strap, compact size, structured handles. Its a saddle bag (the company was established in 1845 as a source for saddles and harnesses) turned on its head. We want all of our bags to reflect the brands legacy and history, says the company president, Neal Fox, about its strategy and recent re-entry into the marketplace. This one reflects an especially modern approach to classicism. At $1,495, it is a princely price to pay for timeless style. The only question is, where to wear it first, Los Angeles or Monaco?

title: On Our Radar: Smog Grounds Flights in Beijing
description: Thick smog prompts officials to cancel hundreds of flights and shut down some major highways in Beijing. The American Embassy describes current air quality there as hazardous, and the official Xinhua news agency says the pollution is likely to reach dangerous levels. [Agence France-Presse]

title: Big Brother in the Home Office
description: Tens of thousands of programmers, writers, accountants and other workers labor at home doing contract work for companies like Google, Hewlett-Packard and NBC. The computers they use contain software that takes snapshots of what they are doing six times an hour. The snooping occurs randomly, making it impossible for the computer user to game the system.

title: The Philosophy of Dev Anand
description: Dev Anand wasnt a star. He was a philosophy. The 88-year-old actor, who died of cardiac arrest on December 4, symbolized six decades of Hindi cinema and a spirit that insisted that the show must go on. No matter that the films ceased to seduce or that viewers stopped showing up decades ago. Dev Anand continued to create and despite the mostly substandard quality of his output, he never lost his icon status or the affection of his audience and colleagues.

title: Street Style: Playing With Proportions
description: The best of readers street style for the week of Nov. 28.

description: For weeks, attitudes toward Europes debt crisis have gone through a recurring cycle: markets flail, spurring leaders to gather and confer; grim-faced, they issue statements of guarded optimism and determination. Rinse. Repeat.

title: The Monday Matchup: Could the Jaguars Get Any More Jumbled?
description: Chargers at JaguarsMonday, 8:30 p.m.Line: Chargers by 3.

title: At Conference, Afghans Say Theyll Need Aid for Years
description: BONN, Germany  As dozens of nations and organizations met here on Monday to plan a transition beyond the withdrawal of American and other international forces from Afghanistan in 2014, the Afghan government had a new deadline in mind: 2024.

title: Keeping Score: Bad Day for Mets, Good Day for Kranepool
description: As the Mets get dressed up for their 50th anniversary season, it is worth noting that they have never had a standout position player who stuck around long enough to produce big career statistics for the team. The departure of shortstop Jose Reyes, who is set to join the Miami Marlins as a free agent, continues this trend.

title: The Film With the Broken Embargo
description: David Denby, rule breaker? That is exactly what the folks at Sony are saying about that film critic at The New Yorker.

title: Zynga Rival in Japan Prices $1.2 Billion I.P.O.
description: TOKYO  The online game company Nexon, a fast-growing Asian rival to Zynga, on Monday set the price for its initial public offering at 1,300 yen a share, a debut that could value the company at 560 billion yen, or $7.2 billion.

title: Astronomers Find Biggest Black Holes Yet
description: Dont get too close.

title: Daily Report: Online Learning, Through the Khan Academy
description: In Mondays New York Times, Somini Sengupta reports on the Khan Academy, a program of math and science lessons developed by Salman Khan that has become a YouTube hit, attracting up to 3.5 million viewers a month. This fall, at least 36 schools across the country are using software to try out Mr. Khans lessons in the classroom, combining traditional teaching with computer-based lessons and exercises.

title: Author Says Shes Found a Portrait of Jane Austen
description: For as few novels as Jane Austen published in a literary career that has long outlasted her brief 41 years, even fewer portraits of her are believed to have survived. Only two are officially recognized as representations of Austen, including a watercolor sketch by her sister, Cassandra, and neither looks particularly like Anne Hathaway. (But really, who does?)

Lake Wobegon, Europe
description: Ezra Klein reports on his conversations with Germans:

title: Honda Recalls 126,000 Gold Wing Motorcycles for Rear Brake System Flaw
description: Honda is recalling 126,000 touring motorcycles because of a braking problem that could potentially lead to a crash or a fire, according to a report filed by the manufacturer with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Spot Pornography on Facebook for a Quarter-Cent an Image
description: Companies like Google, Facebook and Travelocity have plenty of money and armadas of smart people. There are plenty of tasks they do not mind outsourcing, however, and a look at some of those jobs presents an interesting picture of where work is going.

title: Next-Day Mail Faces Postal Service Cuts
description: The post office had bad news on Monday for all those who like to pop a check into the mail to pay a bill due the next day: dont count on it.

description: SOUTHBURY, Conn.  Judy Plouffe and her mom are big on mother-daughter outings in this picturesque suburb off Interstate 84.

title: Right Back Where We Started
description: For all the action of the weekend, all the dramatic games and frantic finishes, today feels a bit anticlimactic. Because for everything that felt like a crazy twist and turn, we are essentially left back where we started. The Packers are still undefeated. The Bowl Championship Series is still designed to keep the power conference teams on top. Fighting is still a part of the N.H.L., although the more people who read about Derek Boogaards heart-rending fate, the less defensible that is, and the Mets fortunes are still sinking like a rock.

title: At $106 Million, Mets Were Wise to Pass on Reyes
description: After news broke Sunday that the Miami Marlins and Jose Reyes had agreed on a contract, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson made a revelation of his own: the team had lost $70 million last year.

title: Have N.B.A. Questions? Howard Beck Has Answers
description: Are the Heat the favorites for the N.B.A. championship this season? Will Chris Paul stay in New Orleans? Do the Nuggets have anyone or anything left? Howard Beck, the N.B.A. reporter for The New York Times, will answer questions from readers.

title: Senators and Congressmen, All Trying for a Laugh
description: As I was working on my argument about political parody on Saturday Night Live, I traveled to our nations capital to see if the humor of our political elite was also suffering from malaise. Wednesday was the 18th annual Funniest Celebrity in Washington Contest, a benefit whose proceeds go to the Susan G. Komen for the Cure, which fights breast cancer. The evening featured a bipartisan bill of stand-up performances by politicians, journalists and lobbyists who all seem to agree on one thing: People from Washington are not funny.

description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog. His new book, The Behavior Gap, will be out in January.

title: In Japan, 8 Ferraris Reportedly Involved in Sunday Smash-Up
description: A group of supercars traveling on rain-slicked roads in Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan, were involved in a crash Sunday, in what many have called one of the most expensive automotive accidents ever recorded.

title: South Bronx Gym Is Going Down for the Count
description: High on the wall above the two sparring rings at Johns Boxing Gym in the South Bronx is a crucifix hung in the middle of a photo gallery of brawling boxers slugging it out.

title: Labor Department Seeks Tougher Rules on Multiple-Employer Plans
description: Federal officials hope to crack down more effectively on operators of multiple employer health plans that have defrauded small businesses and their workers of hundreds of millions of dollars, often leaving them stuck with unpaid medical bills, according to new rules proposed Monday by the Obama administration under the health care legislation.

title: Cain Supporters in Iowa Examine Options
description: With Herman Cain suspending his presidential campaign, the other campaigns are making a play for his supporters, particularly on the ground in Iowa. Much of the speculation is that Newt Gingrich stands to benefit the most as conservatives look for a viable candidate, but Cain supporters in the state say they are up for grabs.

title: Another Tablet Bites the Dust: Dells Streak 7
description: Dell announces the conclusion of its Android tablet experiment with the shutdown of the Dell Streak 7. The PC maker joins just about every other tech company in a distinguished list of failed and misbegotten tablet endeavors.

title: Welfare Ministers Tears Show Italians Pain of Austerity
description: As my colleague Rachel Donadio reported, Italys new government, hastily assembled after Silvio Berlusconis departure, announced sweeping austerity measures Sunday night. The package of deep spending cuts and tax increases is intended, said Prime Minister Mario Monti, to save Italy.

title: Chipper Remnants of a Life Turned Sour
description: She didnt leave much behind. Thats the inescapable fact of Amy Winehouses posthumous collection, Lioness: Hidden Treasures.

title: Notes From the Underground | Austra
description: Austras recent sold-out performance at the Echo brought the club to a thundering halt with heavy beats and ethereal vocals, provided by the bands Katie Stelmanis. Flanked by bejeweled identical twin backup singers, Stelmanis, who previously performed as a solo artist, flaunted her prowess for fronting an act, taking Austra through a tight, deep set, each song better than the last.

title: Dear Best Buy: Dont Mock Santa
description: I would like to come straight out and say that I am a delicate flower on the matter of Santa Claus and the magic of Christmas. I would prefer that you not show any disrespect to the big guy in a mainstream setting, both because I have children who still believe, and because as much as I worry that Christmas has become a season of getting, I think Santa creates, for kids, an atmosphere of giving, as well.

title: Entergy to Spin Off and Sell Electric Transmission Unit
description: Entergy said on Monday that it planned to sell its electric transmission business to ITC Holdings in a two-step process that avoids taxes.

title: An Elderly-Based Community
description: The Times reports on Monday on the transformation of Southbury, Conn., into a town of senior citizens  a foreshadowing of the changes to come in many American towns.

title: Excerpt: A Major Award
description: A excerpt from the number A Major Award from A Christmas Story: The Musical, based on the 1983 holiday film. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Are the Jets Back?
description: LANDOVER, Md.  Once upon a time, I covered baseball for The Times, and while reflecting on the Jets victory Sunday I was reminded of something I wrote about the Mets in September 2008:

title: Smog Closes Beijing Airport
description: BEIJING  Capital International Airport in Beijing was forced to cancel hundreds of flights on Monday because of heavy smog and weather conditions. The cancellations were the latest sign that pollution in Chinas largest cities, among the worst in the world, is leading to significant economic losses.

title: Pumpkins of Kane Street, Twisted and Shriveled
description: Wrinkled and tortured, the pumpkins of Kane Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, are all the more frightening. They persist at their posts, five full weeks after Halloween. City Room will continue to follow their inevitable decline.

title: Bittersweet Moment as Santo Is Elected to the Hall
description: Ron Santo was elected to the Hall of Fame on Monday, barely a year after his death.

title: For a Veteran, Finding Reasons to Move Forward
description: I cannot place where it became an instinct. An inherent part of who I am, where I pray Oh Lord, I wanna go  the old call-and-response taught by drills. I still count my lefts from rights. Something that clicks and passes on each step without hesitation. A reminder of years passed.

title: Beirut Blues
description: BEIRUT  The crisis in Syria is crossing the border into Lebanon. Beirut has regularly witnessed bloody clashes between pro- and anti-Syrian groups since the Syrian Army withdrew from Lebanon in 2005. But with the Syrian revolution intensifying, pro-Syrian groups in Lebanon have dispatched their thugs, known as the shabiha, to keep an eye on Beiruts main streets.

title: Touring Valentinos Museum, Virtually
description: Valentino Garavani is expected to unveil what he is describing as a virtual museum this morning with a to-do at the Museum of Modern Art. (Anne Hathaway is presenting, along with Amit Sood, the creator of the Google Art Project.)

title: Sexting Among Teenagers Not as Common as Thought
description: Despite perceptions, sexting among teenagers and adolescents may not be quite as common as many people believe.

title: Facebook Acquires Gowalla, a Location-Based Social Service
description: 2:11 p.m. | Updated  Adding background information and details of the deal.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Mitt Romney
description: Robert Draper, the author of Sundays cover story on Mitt Romney, is a contributing writer for the magazine. He is the author of Dead Certain: The Presidency of George W. Bush.

title: On Two Continents, the Prize Machine Works Overtime
description: Do you think the awards elite rest over the weekend? Au contraire! The work of the trophy-hungry is never done.

title: A Parker Reviewer Departs After Questions About Payments
description: Jay Miller, who covered Spain, Oregon, Washington, South America and Australia for Robert M. Parker Jr.s Wine Advocate, has stepped down in the wake of allegations  that his representatives in Spain sought payments in return for appearances.

title: Former N.H.L. Enforcer Todd Fedoruk Answers Questions from Readers
description: 8:09 p.m. | Updated The recently retired N.H.L. player Todd Fedoruk answered questions from readers of the Punched Out series about Derek Boogaard and the role of enforcers. Fedoruk, 32 and now an assistant coach with the minor league Trenton Titans, engaged in more than 100 fights in his nine-year N.H.L. career. Off the ice, Fedoruk, like Boogaard, battled an addiction to prescription painkillers. He sustained a career-altering injury in a 2006 fight with Boogaard, but they later became teammates and close friends. (Questions are no longer being accepted for this feature.)

title: Tory Burch's Love Letter to New York
description: The fashion designer reveals her favorite haunts.

title: Rooftop Films Gives Occupy Wall Street Its Own Film Series
description: As a political movement, Occupy Wall Street has attracted plenty of headlines, buzz and creative energy. Now, this being New York, it has its own film series. Rooftop Films, in partnership with several movie houses throughout the city, is presenting a free series of four films from Dec. 13 to 16 featuring issues that ignited the demonstrations.

title: Now Playing | Tory Burchs Love Letter to New York
description: In a film by Tabitha Denholm, Tory Burch takes a heartfelt tour through the city she loves most. From JG Melon to the Frick and Lincoln Center, Burchs New York is all about surprises and newness and evolution, she says. Inspiring and nostalgic, the short film makes its debut here on The Moment.

title: Gifts to Savor, Bite by Bite
description: This year Im giving edible Christmas gifts, and Ive already begun to make them. Im focusing on flavored oils and marinated things right now, as theyll benefit from a few weeks of steeping.

title: A Spouses Bill of Rights
description: My wife lost the use of her legs when radiation to shrink a growth destroyed part of her spinal cord. I have confidence in our physicians and had no doubt that a malpractice suit would be a mistake, but her disability led to another ethical issue. A marketing person for the lifetime-care institution we selected understated its price by $300 a month. Should we hold them to it? We would have come regardless, and we can afford the higher price. DON CELL, CEDAR RAPIDS, IOWA

title: Why Start-Ups Need Crowd-Funding
description: Are you familiar with crowd-funding? You should be. I have been following the progress of new crowd-funding platforms in recent months, and it is now clear that this new financing mechanism can help strapped early-stage ventures, especially social enterprises. In case youre hearing about crowd-funding for the first time, let me bring you up to speed.

title: A Catalog of Six-Stringed Cool
description: Hendrix, transcendent. Slash, in repose. Elvis  well, being Elvis.

title: Supreme Court Wont Hear Case on Churches Use of Schools
description: Updated, 2:26 p.m. | The United States Supreme Court declined Monday to hear a Bronx churchs appeal of a city ban on holding worship services in public schools.

title: Bloomberg Wary of Reports on Cuomos Tax Agenda
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reacted cautiously but skeptically Monday to reports that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was considering raising taxes on the wealthy to help close a looming budget gap.

title: Power in Numbers: China Aims for High-Tech Primacy
description: BEIJING  In an otherwise nondescript conference room, Wu Jianping stands before a giant wall of frosted glass. He toggles a switch and the glass becomes transparent, looking down on an imposing network operations center full of large computer displays. They show maps of China and the world, pinpointing Chinas IPv6 links, the next generation of the Internet.

title: A Maine Farmer Speaks to Wall Street
description: Jim Gerritsen lives a far piece from New York City, in a remote part of northern Maine that what was once known as the Potato Empire. But there he was on Sunday  at age 56 making his first trip to the city  to speak at the Farmers March on Wall Street.

title: In Sports Car Pileup, a Spotlight on Japans Rich
description: TOKYO  A botched lane change led to a spectacular traffic pileup in Japan over the weekend that left a highway strewn with the smashed wreckage of eight Ferraris, a Lamborghini and three Mercedes sports cars.

title: The Bookends of Reyess Mets Career
description: Jose Reyes began his Mets career with a single, batting ninth and leading off the third inning in an interleague game against the Texas Rangers on June 10, 2003. Eight years later, Reyes said goodbye with a single, too, beating out a bunt against the Cincinnati Reds in the first inning of the final game of the season, on Sept. 28, 2011.

title: TimesCast | December 5, 2011
description: Western monitors criticize Russian elections; France and Germany push for fiscal discipline; and presidential parodies on Saturday Night Live.

title: Newt Gingrich Meets With Donald Trump and Other Strange Events
description: I was out of the country last week, and I think I may have developed unreasonably high expectations for the American primary campaign.

title: Monday Motorsports: Ferrari and Red Bull Abandon Formula One Teams Association
description: The body created to represent the mutual goals and grievances of Formula One teams is losing two highly visible members of its rank and file.

title: Huntsman to Miss Debate in Iowa
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. will once again watch from the sidelines on Saturday night as his Republican rivals debate, a victim of poll numbers so low in Iowa that he failed to qualify for the televised event in Des Moines.

title: Susan Loomiss Lemon Olive Oil
description: I was introduced to this fragrant oil by my friend and fellow cookbook author Susan Hermann Loomis, who runs a cooking school called On Rue Tatin in her wonderful home in Normandy. I went to visit her one summer evening, and she served roasted peppers doused with this oil and garnished with fresh thyme leaves as part of a first course. The lemon oil goes beautifully with vegetables or fish, and is lovely on a salad or drizzled over bread.

title: Seabrook Jurors Say They Cannot Reach a Verdict
description: Halfway through the second full day of deliberations on Monday, the jurors deliberating in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook sent a note to the judge saying they were at an impasse in considering all of the counts against Mr. Seabrook.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Steve Albertini joined the Star Group, Philadelphia, in a new post, managing partner for strategic initiatives. He had been running his own consultancy, the Albertini Group, and before that worked in Philadelphia for agencies like Tierney Communications and Earle Palmer Brown.

title: New Endeavor for Trevor Project
description: An organization that provides young Americans with suicide prevention and crisis intervention services is adopting a new identity.

title: The Search for an Era of Labor Peace
description: When the Boeing Company announced its far-reaching, precedent-setting agreement with the machinists union last week, all the talk was about the ushering in of a new era of labor peace between a company and union that were long known for their horrendous labor relations record. That record included five strikes since 1977, among them a 58-day walkout in 2008 that cost Boeing $1.8 billion.

title: A Little Confection Behind the Ear
description: TWENTY years ago, when a roomful of perfumers smelled the sweet scent Thierry Mugler Angel for the first time, most of them were crinkling their noses in disgust.

title: The Many Mutations of Beck
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Students and Principal Are Pepper-Sprayed at Bronx High School
description: Updated, 4:33 p.m. | A student at a Bronx public high school pepper-sprayed at least 14 people, including students and the principal, in the cafeteria and hallway Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.5
description: The day in sports included the world handball championships in So Paulo, Brazil, and the European curling championships in Moscow.

title: Stifling Returns Beyond Expectations
