description: When the Green Bay Packers Randall Cobb returned a kickoff 108 yards for a touchdown in the N.F.L. season opener in September, it played out as a rejoinder to the hand-wringing over a rules change that seemed destined to nearly eliminate returns by moving the kick to the 35-yard line from the 30. The adjustment was made to improve player safety  few hits are as explosive as the ones delivered at full speed on kickoff returns  and the N.F.L. figured it was willing to sacrifice the thrill of a possible highlight for fewer concussions.

title: When Minny Met Talley
description: At Peggy Siegals lunch for The Help on Friday, what is usually a highly managed affair went off-script, as we noted here, with Billie Jean King getting in on the act. She wasnt the only guest with something to say. Andre Leon Talley, the Vogue editor and king of pronouncements, played a lively role, commenting, from his seat, about the look of the film, set in the early 1960s, and praising the costume designer, Sharen Davis.

title: Making Noise About People Who Talk to Their Cellphones
description: My article in Saturdays New York Times, Oh, for the Good Old Days of Rude Cellphone Gabbers, stirred a vocal response among readers, many of whom decried the boorishness of cellphone users in all of its many forms in several hundred comments posted over the weekend. The piece was about people who use voice technologies like Siri in the new iPhone 4S to orally search for restaurants, dictate texts and schedule appointments while in public.

title: A Magic Number for the Rangers: 2,500
description: The Rangers are seeking the 2,500th victory in club history Monday night when they host the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. Theyre also out for their sixth straight win, their eighth straight at home, and the 13th victory in their last 15 games over all. If they do win, theyll maintain their position as the team with the N.H.L.s best overall winning percentage.

title: The Latest A.T.M. Skimmer Scam
description: Thieves using card readers and hidden cameras stole more than $250,000 from 11 Chase A.T.M.s near New York Citys Union Square earlier this year, according to a recently unsealed indictment.

title: Students, Principal Pepper-Sprayed in the Bronx
Lions Lose Their Cool, Another Game
description: 4:23 p.m. | Updated Appearing on NBCs Sunday night game could have been an opportunity for the Detroit Lions to showcase how much progress the team has made.

title: Beware of Female Drivers
description: Many ridiculous reasons have been given over the years for Saudi Arabias de facto ban on women drivers (de facto because there is no formal law, but women cannot obtain licenses). If women drive, its been said, they will lose their modesty and overcrowd the streets. In a sad Thelma and Louise meet Ishtar moment, it is also said that women who drive will find it easier to rebel against their husbands.

title: TimesCast | Russian Elections
description: Election monitors and everyday Russians document blatant fraud in the weekends parliamentary vote.

title: The Giving Spree | Hamish Bowles
description: Who: The Vogue editor at large Hamish Bowles

title: In Ireland, Austerity Is Praised but Painful
description: DUBLIN  As European leaders scramble to overcome the Continents debt crisis, many are pointing to Ireland as a model for how to get out of the troubles.

title: Bronfman Is Stepping Down as Warner Music Chairman
description: 8:48 p.m. | Updated  Edgar M. Bronfman Jr., who has been a top executive in the music industry since the mid-1990s, is stepping down as chairman of the Warner Music Group.

title: Amid New York History, Caff Storico Speaks Italian
description: Stephen Starr, the Philadelphia restaurateur who also owns Buddakan and Morimoto in Manhattan, won the contract to create a restaurant in the newly renovated New-York Historical Society. The result, named Caff Storico (Italian for historic), will open on Saturday.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach: Friday Night
description: Parties for VMan, Dsquared and Visionaire bring out supermodels and artists.

title: The Maxx for the Minimum? Discount iPads at TJ Maxx
description: Reports are surfacing about $399 16GB iPads being sold at TJ Maxx tomorrow. Thats a $100 discount, people. Limited supplies (like, 15) are expected at each store, so check it out and get up early.

title: Inattentional Deafness Disorder
description: Weve all had the experience of being so engrossed in something (a book, an e-mail, an episode of Dexter) that we simply dont hear our partner trying to remind us that the trash needs to go out. But when our children do the same, who else secretly believes that theyre doing it on purpose?

title: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Russia, South Africa, Yemen and France.

title: Republicans Critical of Trump Debate
description: 9:07 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

title: Irelands Efforts to Turn Itself Around
description: Despite praise for Irelands adherence to austerity measures, growth forecasts continue to be downgraded.

title: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Russia, South Africa, Yemen and France.

title: Democrats Say They Will Try Again on Payroll Tax
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats said Monday that they would try for the fifth time in two months to raise taxes on top earners to pay for legislation that would reduce Social Security payroll taxes, as President Obama sought to keep Congressional Republicans on the defensive, asserting that their intransigence could cause a tax increase for tens of millions of American workers.

title: Wealthy New Yorkers Are Staying In State, Census Shows
description: As Albany debates whether to raise taxes on the wealthy, there appears to be little conclusive evidence that the so-called millionaires tax imposed in 2009 on individuals who make more than $200,000 drove New Yorkers out of state. The tax is scheduled to lapse on Dec. 31, but Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is negotiating revisions in the tax code with legislative leaders that would raise taxes on wealthier New Yorkers.

title: Preparing for College, and Kindergarten
Lens: Brazil
description: Lens: Brazil

title: Occupy Davis, as Covered by High School Journalists
description: Dec. 6 1:05 p.m. | Updated

title: The future of computing and the poetry of medicine.
description: The future of computing and the poetry of medicine.

title: Saving the Euro
description: French and German leaders proposed changes to Europes governing treaties to save the currency.

title: Death Knell for the Lecture: Technology as a Passport to Personalized Education
description: Our education system is in a state of crisis. Among developed countries, the United States is 55th in quality rankings of elementary math and science education, 20th in high school completion rate and 27th in the fraction of college students receiving undergraduate degrees in science or engineering.

title: Study Finds Voters Erred Often in Using New Machines
description: As many as 60,000 of the votes cast in New York State elections last year were voided because people unintentionally cast their ballots for more than one candidate, according to a study being released this week. The excess-voting was highest in predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods, including two Bronx election districts where 40 percent of the votes for governor were disqualified.

title: Taking Faster and Smarter to New Physical Frontiers
description: The value of computers is often measured with terms like gigahertz, petaflop and exabyte  the speed, scale and efficiency with which they perform computations.

title: A New Challenge for Rose and the Bulls
description: When given any amount of momentum, Derrick Rose is an absolute terror. His foot speed dwarfs most opponents neural reaction times. His ability to change directions quickly renders even the leagues better individual defenders irrelevant. His adaptable arsenal of spins, dekes and crossovers can turn any man in front of him into a practice cone.

title: Journalists Should Be Government Mouthpieces, Chinese Media Leader Says
description: The new president of Chinas largest television network, the state-run organization known CCTV, drew fire over the weekend from Chinese press advocates and others online over comments urging journalists to drop their pretensions of professionalism and submit to being mouthpieces of the government.

title: Arts Group Hands Out Grants to 52 Artists
description: The United States Artists, a nonprofit organization that gives annual no-strings-attached grants to artists, composers, writers and performers has announced this years list of recipients who will receive grants of $50,000.

title: Spike Lee and Other Big Names Make Sundances List
description: Spike Lee makes his Sundance debut as a director. The former indie queen Parker Posey returns in a big role. Rashida Jones (Parks and Recreation) tries her hand at screenwriting. Comedy, comedy and more comedy.

title: S.E.C. Seeks More Power, but Does It Need It?
description: Even as Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan rejected the Securities and Exchange Commissions proposed settlement with Citigroup because he did not find it in the public interest, the agencys chairwoman, Mary L. Schapiro, sought to enhance the S.E.C.s authority to impose higher financial penalties to deter securities violations.

title: In Planning Digital Defenses, the Biggest Obstacle Is Human Ingenuity
description: Security is a curious concept, part perception and part prognostication. Websters captures both sides of this dichotomy in its definition: freedom from danger; freedom from fear.

title: More on the Sensitive Climate Question
description: Here are some fresh thoughts on the enduring and important questions surrounding climate sensitivity how much warming will result from a substantial buildup of greenhouse gases.

title: In New Jersey, Loaded for Bear
description: New Jerseys annual black bear hunt, which resumed last year after a five-year hiatus, began Monday morning and will continue until Saturday. About 6,400 people registered for this years hunt, and based upon the 2010 success rate, officials predict that the hunters will bag around 450 bears.

title: An Evolution Toward a Programmable Universe
description: Over the next 10 years, the physical world will become ever more overlaid with devices for sending and receiving information.

title: Turnout Falls as Egypt Casts Runoff Ballots
description: CAIRO  Turnout plunged Monday as Egyptians in Cairo, Alexandria, and seven other governorates voted in runoffs to decide the initial round of the first parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak almost nine months ago. The lines at the polls were far shorter than when the voting began a week before, and at the same time, the Egyptian election commission said that the turnout last week was in fact much lower than initially reported.

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center Director to Step Down
description: Adrian Ellis, the executive director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, has told that organizations board he will step down in early January.

title: Syria Reportedly Detains Outspoken Blogger
description: Updated | 5:27 p.m. An outspoken Syrian blogger was reportedly arrested on Sunday on her way to a conference in neighboring Jordan on press freedom in the Arab world.

title: In an Open-Source Society, Innovating by the Seat of Our Pants
description: The Internet isnt really a technology. Its a belief system, a philosophy about the effectiveness of decentralized, bottom-up innovation. And its a philosophy that has begun to change how we think about creativity itself.

title: Design Miami | Art Is Still in Fashion and Vice Versa
description: Im from that generation of artists who tries to think very hard about new sets of relationships between people and spaces and how people work with artwork, said the artist Liam Gillick, who was one of several artists in Miamis Design District this year exploring a relationship with a big fashion brand. Cross-disciplinary collaborations, often accompanied by pop-up stores, are the name of the game during Art Basel Miami Beach, with often brilliant  and on occasion, less-than-brilliant  results. This years brilliant moments included Gillick and Pringle of Scotland; Beatriz Milhazes and Cartier; and Anselm Reyle and Dior.

title: Full Speed Ahead, Without a Map, Into New Realms of Possibility
description: More and more people are looking to computers to save the world, but the people who run them certainly dont know how. Nobodys in charge, not even Google, though everyone in the dot-com world pretends. Theyre all too busy with I.P.O.s and market share, trying to start fads or come up with idiotic names.

title: Quantum Computing Promises New Insights, Not Just Supermachines
description: When people hear that I work on quantum computing  one of the most radical proposals for the future of computation  their first question is usually, So when can I expect a working quantum computer on my desk? Often they bring up breathless news reports about commercial quantum computers right around the corner. After I explain the strained relationship between those reports and reality, they ask: Then when? In 10 years? Twenty?

title: Transportation Chief Steps Into Prime-Time Spotlight
description: In its first few weeks on the air, Rock Center With Brian Williams, the new NBC newsmagazine show, has tackled topics of major national import: starvation in Africa, cheating on standardized tests, child abuse in college football.

title: Leave the Driving to the Car, and Reap Benefits in Safety and Mobility
description: The Jetsons had them in the 1960s. They were the defining element of Knight Rider in the 1980s: cars that drive themselves. Self-driving cars appear in countless science fiction movies. By Hollywood standards, they are so normal we dont even notice them.

title: Casting Director Says She Didnt Pick Actors to Play Latino Roles
description: The casting director for the Hartford production of The __________ With the Hat said on Monday that she was not involved with the choice of two white actors to play the roles of two Puerto Rican characters in the play by Stephen Adly Guirgis, who last week went public with his concerns about that productions casting.

title: In Riverdale, More For Sale Signs Than Sales
description: The home required no gentle embellishment, no agent-speak tucked into the description beside the property listing. The five bedrooms and marble center hall were supposed to speak for themselves. The sprawling patio and yard space would look quite at home in one of the wealthy suburban hamlets a few miles to the north.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Too Much E-Mail and More Woes for RIM
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web.

title: Out of Galleon Scandal and Wall St. Excess, a Book
description: A former trader at the Galleon Group has signed an agreement with Crown Business, a division of Random House, to publish a memoir about his career on Wall Street and time spent working for Raj Rajaratnam, the head of Galleon who was convicted of running a huge insider trading conspiracy.

title: About Your Comments
description: Over the past few days, as you may have noticed, weve implemented a new commenting system here at The New Old Age. Among its features:

title: City Moves to Halt Church Meetings at Schools
Just One Look | Carolina Herrera
description: The guest of honor at Carolina Herreras prefall presentation earlier today was none other than her black miniature poodle, Gaspar. He has been here since this morning, Herrera said, hes the star today. And the muse, apparently. Among the collections multicolor tulle evening dresses, copper-colored sequin sheaths and the tortoiseshell-inspired metallic pencil skirts that Herrera called lunch looks was this: a springlike silk twill shirtdress with sweet sleeves featuring  surprise!  a whimsical poodle print on a royal blue ground. Fetching, indeed.

title: Iran, Facing New Sanctions, Warns of Oil at $250 a Barrel
description: Alarmed by the possibility of new Western penalties that could abruptly reduce or even halt its oil exports, Iran issued a warning on Monday that crude oil prices could more than double to $250 a barrel if such sanctions were given serious consideration.

title: Inside the CTE Damaged Brain
description: How CTE could lead to dementia and other symptoms in athletes like Derek Boogaard

title: A Promise of Gain Without Pain
description: ANYONE who has erased years of coffee and wine stains from their teeth knows that a pageant-worthy smile can come with a price: tooth sensitivity.

title: Caring for Chris, Now That He Has Opened His Eyes
description: The photographer Stephanie Sinclair, who is known for her ability to connect with the subjects of her pictures, was able to bring even more than her usual empathy to her most recent assignment for the magazine, photographing the minimally conscious patient Chris Cox. Thats because Sinclairs own mother suffered a brain injury in 2001. When you share the experience of someone you love having a brain injury  of becoming a different person  theres an instant intimacy, Sinclair says. My mom has recovered a lot more than Chris has, but I had to do a lot of the things theyre doing.

title: N.H.L. Commissioners Response
description: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman speaks with New York Times reporter John Branch on the role of fighting in hockey and the recent death of enforcer Derek Boogaard.

title: City Opera Calls for Mediator in Impasse With Unions
description: New York City Opera announced on Monday that it was seeking the help of a federal mediator in a deadlock with the unions representing its chorus and orchestra. The companys management declared an impasse last Thursday when the two sides were unable to come to terms on new contracts. City Opera has reduced its budget by nearly two thirds and has moved out of its Lincoln Center home to save money. It is seeking to pay the chorus members and musicians for each rehearsal and performance, with reduced health benefits, while the unions want to be compensated by the week and are seeking stronger guarantees of employment.

title: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company in Illinois
description: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year legacy tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Years Day 2012. This is the 21st in a series of graphite drawings that Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the companys journey. This weeks entry is from Champaign and Chicago.

title: A Christmas Story: The Musical
description: Scenes from the stage adaptation of the 1983 film.

title: S.&P. Warns Euro Zone of Ratings Downgrades
description: Standard & Poors on Monday warned that it might strip the euro zones two biggest economies, Germany and France, of their top-notch AAA long-term credit ratings because of the Continents economic crisis. The agency also said the ratings of 13 other euro zone countries were vulnerable.

title: Punched Out | Part Three
description: In 2010, N.H.L. enforcer Derek Boogaard signed a multimillion dollar contract with the New York Rangers. But, nobody predicted how far and how fast the Boogeyman would fall.

title: Was the destruction of an Iranian military base last month an accident or sabotage?
description: Was the destruction of an Iranian military base last month an accident or sabotage?

title: Scottish Artist Martin Boyce Wins Turner Prize
description: Martin Boyce, an artist known for creating sculptural installations that pay homage to Modernist design, has won this years prestigious Turner Prize. The winning entry from Mr. Boyce, 44, was an installation that looks like both an interior space and a municipal park, with trees crafted of geometric aluminum leaves along with a desk, based on a library table by the French modernist designer Jean Prouv. The desk has letters scratched into its surface, as though they were the carvings of a naughty school child.

title: Derek Boogaard: A Brain Going Bad
description: THROUGH THE NIGHT and into the next day, as the scrolls across the bottom of television screens spread the news of Derek Boogaards death last May, the calls of condolences came, one after another.

title: After Jailhouse Bar Mitzvah, Rabbi Is Fined for Accepting a Gift
description: If you cant bring the father to the bar mitzvah boy, then bring the bar mitzvah boy to the father.

title: After Fire, N.H.T.S.A. to Inspect Jeep Grand Cherokee Involved in Deadly Crash
description: As part of an effort to determine whether millions of Jeep Grand Cherokees from the 1993-2004 model years should be recalled because their gas tanks may be susceptible to rupturing in rear impacts, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating a recent crash in which a Florida man died.

title: Out There | ABMBs Last Gasp
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Things That Never Happened In The History Of Macroeconomics
description: Via Mark Thoma, David Warsh finally says what someone needed to say: Friedrich Hayek is not an important figure in the history of macroeconomics.

title: Forte Should Not Rush Back
description: During Sundays loss to the Kansas City Chiefs, Bears running back Matt Forte was forced to leave the game due to a Grade-2 sprain of his MCLan injury that typically keeps a player out between two and six weeks. The Bears are not saying when the team expects the star running back to return.

title: Vermonts Speedy Recovery
description: Snapshots of Vermonts progress in repairing roads and bridges damaged by Hurricane Irene.

title: State of the Art
description: A snapshot of the rapidly changing world of computing, communications and technology.

title: Parks Dept. Forfeited Millions in Revenue, Audit Says
description: The New York City Parks and Recreation Department could have attracted an additional $8.8 million in revenue in the last three fiscal years through better management of its retail, recreational and dining concessions, according to an audit released Monday by John C. Liu, the city comptroller.

title: Softly, Softly, Like the Lapping of Waves
description: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times. ... O.K., maybe thats overdramatizing. But Dickensian oppositions of incredulity and belief, darkness and light, surely applied when the music of Morton Feldman gently swelled once again at Bargemusic in Brooklyn on Thursday evening. At hand was a performance of Feldmans longest solo piano work, Triadic Memories (1981), by Blair McMillen, a terrific young pianist and a prominent ambassador for new music.

title: Concerns Over Merger in Pharmacy
description: Express Scripts proposed $29 billion acquisition of Medco Health Solutions is expected to face intensified scrutiny on Tuesday when a Senate panel examines potential antitrust concerns raised by the merger of two of the countrys largest pharmacy benefit managers.

title: 3 Modern Collaborators Add a Victorian Shadow
description: LONDON  The Victorian motion-study photographs of Eadweard J. Muybridge feel oddly ubiquitous right now. Theyre featured in the Degas show at the Royal Academy here, in the Danser Sa Vie exhibition at the Pompidou Center in Paris, and they are a central theme in the new piece Undance by Wayne McGregor, Mark-Anthony Turnage and Mark Wallinger that completed a too-brief run at Sadlers Wells on Saturday.

title: The Civil War Through Southern Eyes
description: Richmond, Va., the former capital of the Confederacy, is host to multiple museums about the Civil War.

title: Just One Look | Oscar de la Renta
description: Oscar de la Rentas prefall collection defied all carryall catchphrases and instead knowingly addressed his customers great and varied needs with everything from work pants and jackets to smart, colorful day dresses and sparkling black-tie gowns. Here, the latter: a sweeping coral evening dress that, when it lands in stores in May, will be exactly the bright, fluid and summery thing youll want to wear indoors or out.

title: The South Reinterprets Its Lost Cause
description: RICHMOND, Va.  In the climate-controlled archives of the Museum of the Confederacy, here in the city that was once the capital of the Confederate States of America, thousands of artifacts are carefully laid out in protective drawers. There are rag dolls and lace finery, folded uniforms scarred by bullet holes and sword slashes, well-maintained revolvers and gleaming sabers. Also from the Civil Wars front lines are the cherished rations of long-dead officers: a handful of colorless coffee beans, a block of chewing tobacco with a musky smell.

title: That Wish for a BB Gun, Set to Song and Dance
description: DETROIT  The world of holiday movie lovers used to be divided into Its a Wonderful Life people and Miracle on 34th Street people. But for the past few decades the nostalgic comedy A Christmas Story has become a holiday film fix for a group of obsessive fans.

title: Changing Midstream
description: States that have enacted significant revisions to at least one statewide retirement plan.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 80
description: Amid increasing closings of encampments, some Occupiers are calling for parks to be reoccupied on Dec. 17, the three-month anniversary of the movement. [CBS New York]

title: Chants of Putins a Thief! Ring Out in Moscow
description: Last Updated | Tuesday | 8:05 p.m. As my colleagues Michael Schwirtz and David Herszenhorn reports from Moscow, on Monday evening thousands of demonstrators gathered to protest election results in the Russian capital, chanting, among other things, Putins a Thief!

title: Tchaikovsky Rendered Anew, Steadily and Elegantly
description: Lincoln Center doesnt have a permanent performance hall quite like Le Poisson Rouge or Galapagos Art Space, where you sit at tables and can order wine (or harder stuff) while you listen to the music. But the center and its constituent organizations do what they can with the smaller, more malleable rooms in the Rose Building, which looms over the Juilliard School.

title: Former Ivory Coast Strongman Appears at Hague Court
description: PARIS  Seven months after artillery fire from United Nations and French troops drove him from his fortified compound, Laurent Gbagbo, the former president of Ivory Coast, appeared in public for the first time on Monday, as he faced courtroom cameras and a panel of international judges in The Hague.

title: Handel, Illustrated With Americana
description: PITTSBURGH  Since the elements of oratorio  recitative, aria, chorus, sinfonia  and its overall scale resemble those of opera, and since Handel was eminently fluent in both, it might seem a simple matter to stage a Handel oratorio, and periodic attempts have been made. Unlike most of his operas, after all, the oratorios are in English.

title: After Playing, Music as a Career Option for N.F.L. Veterans
description: Many football players struggle to find meaningful work after they stop playing. The N.F.L.s latest attempt to help them develop a post-retirement career will take place in February when the 20 current and former football players will join the first-ever Business of Music Boot Camp.

title: China Is Poised for an I.T. Golden Age
description: BEIJING  Chinese universities graduate more than 600,000 engineering students a year. China has consistently placed at or near the top of programming competitions. And while we have not seen China become a leader in information technology and computing, I expect that this will change in the coming decade.

title: President Gathers College Leaders to Discuss Access and Affordability
description: Continuing his calls for college affordability, President Obama met privately with university presidents and chancellors at the White House on Monday. According to The Chronicle of Higher Education, the group gathered to discuss opportunities to bring down overall campus costs across the United States.

title: Computer Scientists May Have What It Takes to Help Cure Cancer
description: The war against cancer is increasingly moving into cyberspace. Computer scientists may have the best skills to fight cancer in the next decade  and they should be signing up in droves.

title: When Dreamers Were Breaking the Music Apart
description: You have to admire Will Hermess Love Goes to Buildings on Fire  the reference is to the first single by Talking Heads  for refusing to oversell the importance of its subject. True, the subtitle calls the period from 1973 to 1977 Five Years in New York that Changed Music Forever, but thats actually a modest claim: what five years of the 20th century didnt change music forever? The five years previous, for instance, saw Bitches Brew, Abbey Road, Exile on Main Street, the Velvet Underground and James Browns Sex Machine. The subsequent five produced Off the Wall and Thriller; hip-hops first hit, the Sugar Hill Gangs Rappers Delight; and the debuts of R.E.M., the Replacements and Hsker D.

title: As the Republican Race Heats Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Exposing Self (and Skin)
description: In the opening scene of the DIY meta-production Caitlin Plays Herself, the performance artist Caitlin Stainken defends quick-turnaround techniques and her unfiltered aesthetic as an attempt to make new work about something that is happening right now. Shes less interested in the final product, she explains, than in the exploratory process, which you can see in the way she slowly massages her breasts with a washcloth: Not everything I make is going to be good, you know?

title: For Filipinos, an Abrupt Directive Alters a Christmas Ritual
description: Those who complain that the Christmas season starts earlier and earlier each year might find solace in hearing how Filipinos traditionally celebrate the season  theirs can stretch from as early as September to late January.

title: Mind Games: Testing Your Willpower
description: To the Editor:

title: At Harlem Arts School, New Chief Hits Her Stride
description: An ordinary Saturday at the Harlem School of the Arts finds children in black tights learning dance moves, pecking away at keyboards or torturing clay into intricate shapes. Given its recent travails, ordinary is most desirable here.

title: Ford of Tech Companies, AOL, Must Keep Innovating, C.E.O. Says
description: Its not easy being the Ford Motor of the Internet. And that, in short, is the predicament facing AOL, according to its chief executive, Timothy M. Armstrong, who spoke Tuesday as part of the three-day UBS media conference in New York.

title: Yes, Racial Profiling Is Illegal
description: If you know what racial profiling is, and why its illegal, youre a step ahead of Representative Steve King, the Iowa Republican who believes white men face grave exclusionary policies in Obamas America.

title: With a Little Help, East London Embraces Tech
description: LONDON  When Eventbrite, a start-up based in San Francisco that sells tickets online, decided to open its first international office, the founders turned to the East End of London.

title: Nets Williams Makes a Pitch for Howard
description: Deron Williams pronounced his affinity for the Nets on Monday  a declaration that will do absolutely nothing to quell the franchises concerns  or the rumors about  his future.

title: New Tools for New Computing Challenges
description: The world has moved to a data-centric paradigm, the era of Big Data, in which hundreds of millions of computers and mobile devices are continuously creating staggering amounts of information about people and everything else. This can only accelerate.

title: Q&A: Ditching Dial-Up for 3G
description: Q.

title: Stuyvesant Student Takes Second in Siemens Competition
School Choice? A Question of Time and Money
Rethinking the SAT: The Experts Weigh In
Lawmakers to Open an Inquiry on Undercover Drug Operation
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans said Monday that they would open an investigation into undercover operations by the Drug Enforcement Administration in which agents have laundered and smuggled millions of dollars in drug money as part of an effort to help Mexico fight organized crime.

title: When Gingrichs Big Thoughts Backfire
description: Ideas erupt from the mind of Newt Gingrich  bold, unconventional and sometimes troubling and distracting.

title: With a Leaner Model, Start-Ups Reach Further Afield
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  Lee Redden, 26, a Ph.D. student in engineering at Stanford, recently decided to shelve his education and help found a start-up company. His skills lie in a couple of red-hot niches of artificial intelligence, computer vision and machine learning. Yet he is not applying his talents to Internet search, online commerce or intelligence surveillance.

title: N.Y.C. Police Maligned Paradegoers on Facebook
description: They called people animals and savages. One comment said, Drop a bomb and wipe them all out.

title: Ex-Players Suing N.F.L Over Use of Painkiller
description: In the latest lawsuit based on medical issues against the N.F.L., a dozen former players have accused the league and its teams of repeatedly administering the painkiller Toradol before and during games, worsening high-risk injuries like concussions.

title: Vast and Fertile Ground in Africa for Science to Take Root
description: He might have been content simply to teach thousands of university students in Uganda how to use computers, assemble them into networks, manage them and write basic software programs. In a poor African country with one of the worlds fastest-growing populations and rising Internet use, that alone would have been an enormous achievement.

title: Foster Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Creating Artificial Intelligence Based on the Real Thing
description: Ever since the early days of modern computing in the 1940s, the biological metaphor has been irresistible. The first computers  room-size behemoths  were referred to as giant brains or electronic brains, in headlines and everyday speech. As computers improved and became capable of some tasks familiar to humans, like playing chess, the term used was artificial intelligence. DNA, it is said, is the original software.

title: Cardinals, Marlins  and Cubs?  in Play for Pujols
description: DALLAS  If the St. Louis Cardinals wanted to talk tough about Albert Pujols, they could. If Pujols leaves, the Cardinals have replacements handy: Lance Berkman could shift to first base, and Allen Craig, a World Series hero, could start in right field. So credit the St. Louis owner, Bill DeWitt, for taking the opposite approach at the winter meetings Monday.

title: Wal-Mart Debate Rages in India
description: JALANDHAR, India  For multinational merchants like Wal-Mart, it seemed to be the long-awaited opportunity to jump into India with both feet. But on Monday that moment appeared to be delayed once again.

title: Looking Backward to Put New Technologies in Focus
description: BELLINGHAM, Wash.  More than most of us, the science historian George Dyson spends his days thinking about technologies, old and very new. His 1986 book Baidarka was a meditation on an ancient Aleut kayak.

title: A High-Stakes Search Continues for Silicons Successor
description: STANFORD, Calif.  In a cluttered chip-making laboratory on Stanfords campus, Max Shulaker is producing the worlds smallest computer circuits by hand.

title: Out of a Writers Imagination Came an Interactive World
description: Neal Stephenson doesnt like talking about how he predicted the future.

title: Captain McCornal Trades His Brush for a Saber
description: In an often-repeated scene across the North during the massive military buildup in 1861, newly formed organizations gathered in the nearest town and struck out for the South. One such group, a company of New York cavalrymen from the Hudson River Valley village of Middletown, left the state on Dec. 6.

title: Advancing Womens Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Hailing a Cab
description: To the Editor:

title: Newts Nostalgia  and Amnesia
description: Newt Gingrichs new Iowa ad has everything. And nothing.

title: Its Tone, Not Taxes, a Tycoon Tells the President
description: Leon Cooperman, a 68-year-old Wall Street veteran, says he is for higher taxes on the wealthy. He would happily give up his Social Security checks. He voted for Al Gore in 2000. He says the special treatment of investment gains, or so-called carried interest, for private equity and hedge fund managers is ridiculous. He says he even sympathizes, at least to some extent, with the Occupy Wall Street protesters.

title: Vonn Leaning on Family for Support
description: After winning three World Cup races over the weekend, Lindsey Vonn paused Monday to consider the changes in her life, which have included divorce proceedings against her husband, Thomas, who acted as a coach and adviser during the couples four-year marriage.

title: Jury in Councilmans Trial Says Its Split Has Widened
description: Halfway through its second full day of deliberations, the jury in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook indicated on Monday that it was at an impasse on all 12 counts in the case.

title: Twists in a South Africa Corruption Case Prove Telling
description: JOHANNESBURG  This is a country that has more than had its fill of corruption. These days, every allegation of misuse of authority and privilege is closely scrutinized by a public hungry for accountability.

title: A Mayor Sure of Himself, if Nothing Else
description: There is an autumn of the patriarch feel to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg these days.

title: Romney Embraces Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
description: 11:25 p.m. | Updated  On Monday, Mitt Romney embraced one of President Obamas signature proposals  another one-year extension of a cut in payroll taxes, after just weeks ago deriding the idea as little Band-Aids that offered only a temporary fix.

title: In Less Than a Minute, a Season Full of Injuries Catches Up to the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants arrived at their practice facility on a muted Monday after a 38-35 loss to the Green Bay Packers that was promising but for the final 58 seconds. That was all it took for a possible win to turn into a moral victory.

title: Quadrennial Effect Could Make 12 a Very Good Year
description: IT sounds like the title of a thriller by Robert Ludlum: The Quadrennial Effect. Actually, it is something that may make 2012 less of a nail-biter for media and advertising companies.

title: Tensions Rise in Congos Capital as Ballots Pile Up
description: KINSHASA, Congo  Sacks of newly arrived ballots lay piled in the mud at decrepit fairgrounds at the edge of town on Monday, a day before officials here were supposed to declare a winner in this countrys presidential election  and nearly a week after the vote.

title: Marlins and Mets at Opposite Ends of the Spectrum
description: DALLAS

title: Fund-Raising Gains New Urgency for Gingrich Camp
description: With just four weeks to go until the Republican primary season begins, Newt Gingrich spent his Monday not on the hustings of Iowa, New Hampshire or South Carolina, but in Midtown Manhattan, prospecting for what his newly resurgent campaign needs most desperately: money.

title: Why Selling Kidneys Should Be Legal
description: San Francisco

title: Around the World in One Movie: Film Financings Global Future
description: POTSDAM, Germany  The German craftsmen on Stage 15 in the Babelsberg studio were hard at work on a recent afternoon building a dystopian Korean slum, the thud of a nail gun and a whiff of sawdust in the air. Next door, Andy and Lana Wachowski, the American-born team behind the Matrix movies, were filming black-clad storm troopers from an imagined future for their latest feature, Cloud Atlas.

title: G.O.P. Strategists Fret Over Circus of Trump Debate
description: Republican strategists on Monday bemoaned the prospect of a presidential debate hosted by Donald J. Trump even as Newt Gingrich, surging in recent polls, made a pilgrimage to see Mr. Trump, the billionaire real estate mogul and reality TV star.

title: Campaigns Take Ad War to TV After Months of Holding Fire
description: After months of relative quiet, the Republican presidential candidates have started to increase their television advertising, bringing a new competitive dynamic to a fight that has largely remained off the commercial airwaves until now.

title: Forget the Airlines Name; Its All About Alliances
description: ABOUT 18 months ago, G. Bruce Hedlund, a captain with American Airlines, looked out the window of his 757 as it rolled toward a taxiway at Kennedy Airport and spotted what he considered the future of commercial aviation.

title: The Early Ad Race in Iowa
description: With less than a month to go before the Iowa caucuses on Jan. 3, presidential candidates are producing new campaign advertisements and increasing their media buys throughout the state.

title: How to Rescue Education Reform
description: THE debate over renewing No Child Left Behind, the education reform act that will be 10 years old in January, has fallen along partisan lines even though school improvement is one of the few examples of bipartisan cooperation over the last decade.

title: An Awkward Moment Waiting to Happen
description: IVE been flying a lot for business for the last 11 years. Now that I have two small children, I miss them and my wife a lot while Im gone. But I do enjoy seeing new places.

title: An Argument Wal-Mart Has Heard Before
description: A move to open India up to multinational retail giants like Wal-Mart and Tesco has inspired some resistance.

title: Dr. Berwicks Pink Slip
description: Dr. Donald Berwick was already in Massachusetts when I spoke to him Sunday afternoon. He was back in the Newton home where hed lived for 30 years, being pleasantly interrupted during our conversation by his 2-year-old grandson. His last day in Washington as the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services had been Thursday. Friday was packing day. Saturday was moving day. And, by Sunday, he was already talking about his too-short, 17-month tenure as the nations top Medicare official in the past tense. Which, alas, it was.

title: Museum Wades Into Politics With a Fund-Raiser
description: Just as the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum is seeking to expand onto state property in Midtown Manhattan, some of its trustees have been pressing the rest of the board to contribute to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos re-election campaign by buying tickets to his birthday party on Tuesday night.

title: College Leaders Meet With Obama to Discuss Costs and Productivity
description: In a private meeting on Monday, President Obama and his secretary of education, Arne Duncan, conferred with a dozen college presidents, mostly from public institutions, and leaders of two nonprofit education organizations, about how to curb the rising cost of college and improve graduation rates.

title: Ciscos Lesson for Oracle
description: Empires built through acquisitions can run into problems as they sprawl. Thats doubly so in technology, where obsolescence is a risk. Oracle has used profits from its database stronghold to expand. Its acquisitions have worked well so far  thats one reason its German archrival SAP has become more active itself, buying SuccessFactors for $3.4 billion on Saturday. But the sad experience undergone recently by Cisco Systems suggests that Oracles boss, Lawrence Ellison, needs to stay on his toes.

title: 2 RIM Executives Are Fired for Disturbance on Flight
description: OTTAWA  The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion said on Monday that it had fired two executives whose drunken belligerence forced a flight to China to return to Canada for their removal and arrest last week.

title: Network of Indian Entrepreneurs Now Backs Start-Ups
description: In 1992, a handful of immigrant engineers from the Indian subcontinent who lived in the Bay Area formed a group called the Indus Entrepreneurs  or TiE  with what now seems like a quaint mission: to inspire one another to establish their own technology start-ups and cash in on the Silicon Valley dream.

title: Jets Are Letting Games Go to the Last Minutes
description: On Sunday, the Jets beat Washington. Or was it Buffalo? Or San Diego? Or did they lose to Denver? Their games are blending together, one barely distinguishable from the next, with every week showcasing their split personality.

title: Justices Hear Arguments in a Police Search Case
description: WASHINGTON  Police officers in Los Angeles stormed Augusta Millenders home early one morning in 2003. They were looking for Ms. Millenders foster son, Jerry Bowen, and for a shotgun he had used in a domestic assault.

title: F.A.A. Chief Goes on Leave After a Charge of Drunken Driving
description: WASHINGTON  The head of the Federal Aviation Administration has been placed on leave after he was arrested over the weekend in Virginia on a drunken driving charge.

title: Mr. Romneys Missing Details
description: The biggest whopper in Mitt Romneys fiscal plan comes right at the beginning of the description on his Web site: We will level with the American people about what it will take to truly cut spending and balance our budget. Actually, Mr. Romney never tells voters the full cost of his plan to balance the budget while cutting taxes: popular programs would be slashed or eliminated, vital state and local services would disappear, misery would be inflicted on the poor and the working class.

title: Champions League Tuesday Preview: Feet Up, or Feet to the Fire
description: Tuesday is essentially a rest day for Barcelona and three other Champions League teams. Barcelona has already won its group, so Coach Pep Guardiola will sit nearly all of his regulars in advance of this weekends Clsico against Real Madrid. A breather is also in order for A.C. Milan, Arsenal and APOEL, who are all safely through to the next round.

title: Sprucing Up at the Inn
description: As hotel bookings and prices climb from their recession-era troughs, many chains are taking on the renovations they postponed when money was tight.

title: Pakistan Fans the Flames
description: Pakistan is refusing to help calm public fury  or help figure out what led to a NATO attack that left 24 Pakistani soldiers dead. It has rejected American entreaties to participate in a joint investigation. On Monday, it boycotted an international conference in Bonn that laid plans for Afghanistans future. Both moves are self-defeating.

title: With Reyes Gone, Mets Look Forward
description: DALLAS  One day after Jose Reyes agreed to join the Miami Marlins, the news continued to cast certain existential questions upon the Mets, his former team.

title: Supreme Court to Consider the Arrest of a Cheney Critic
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether Secret Service agents protecting Vice President Dick Cheney may be sued for violating the free speech rights of a member of the public who made critical remarks about the Bush administrations war policies.

title: Lawyers in Capital Cases
description: Problems with lawyers routinely plague death penalty cases. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear a case involving a California death-row inmates request that his court-appointed lawyer be replaced. The court should not use this narrow case to limit the ability of defendants to get the representation they need.

title: Patricia C. Dunn Dies at 58; Led H.P. During Spying Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Patricia C. Dunn, who rose from a secretary to lead Barclays Global Investors and then serve as chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard only to have her career eclipsed by her involvement in an attempt to stop boardroom leaks by spying on directors, journalists and employees, died on Sunday at her home in Orinda, Calif. She was 58.

title: Boston University Doctor to Answer Readers Questions About Boogaard Series
description: Dr. Robert A. Stern, a neuropsychologist and a co-director for the Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, will answer questions Tuesday afternoon about C.T.E. and John Branchs series Punched Out. (Questions are no longer being accepted for this feature.)

title: Tuesday: Extravagant, Like a W.C.
description: Administrivial Avatar Alert!  The ability to upload a photo to your Times account has been fixed. Please powder your noses, take a snapshot of yourself, and upload it by going to the upper-right-hand corner of this page. Notice that your screen name now features a drop-down menu. Click that drop-down arrow, go to My Profile, click on Edit My Profile, and you will see a box where you can upload a photo that is no larger than 5 cruciliters, or megaspleens, or something like that. At any rate, you can upload a photo now.

title: Life Is Grim, and Then Things Tend to Get a Lot Worse
description: Mix two ounces of misanthropy, one ounce of anomie and a jigger of acrid humor. Add two splashes of bitters and serve with a twist of tedium. Thats the nightly special  three for the price of one  at Happy Hour, a wearying evening of short plays by Ethan Coen that opened on Monday night at the Peter Norton Space.

title: Should Workplaces Curtail E-Mail?
Partys Losses Raise Concerns About Putins Bid
description: MOSCOW  Vladimir V. Putin was not the subject of Sundays bruising vote in Russia, but you would not have known it from watching him when the early results came in. He looked like someone who has just received very bad news, and stumbled his way through a speech to his supporters, barely forcing a smile before stepping off the podium.

title: A Recipe for More Homelessness
description: The draft version of the Section 8 Savings Act released earlier this year by the majority staff of the House Financial Services Committee includes several excellent proposals that would cut administrative costs for public housing authorities, allowing them to more efficiently manage the programs that subsidize rents for more than three million of the countrys poorest families. But one damaging provision that crept into the draft would undo all of that good.

title: The Wonky Liberal
description: Republicans have many strong arguments to make against the Obama administration, but one major criticism doesnt square with the evidence. This is the charge that President Obama is running a virulently antibusiness administration that spews out a steady flow of job- and economy-crushing regulations.

title: Predicting the Future of Computing
description: Readers are invited to make predictions and collaboratively edit this timeline on the future of computing.

title: Aid Agencies in Afghanistan Fear Reversals After U.S. Exit
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Even as President Hamid Karzai beseeched nations at a conference in Germany on Monday to continue aid to Afghanistan for another decade, the American withdrawal from Afghanistan is already being felt among civilian aid workers, raising anxieties that Afghanistan will be abandoned and that the hard-earned development gains will be reversed.

title: Churches to Lose Use of School Space After a Legal Push Fails
description: A small Bronx evangelical church on Monday lost the final round of its 16-year legal battle to force New York City to permit religious worship services in public schools, setting the stage for the city to eject dozens of churches and religious organizations that have been using schools for prayer.

title: Lottery Numbers
Yankees Coming Up Empty in Search for Trade Partner
description: DALLAS  Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman, in an effort to illustrate why he is not optimistic about trading for a good starting pitcher at the winter meetings, provided insight into the kind of dialogue he is having with other general managers.

title: Getting Her Dream Home, but Missing the Furniture
description: Natasha Sydneys new home has a sunset view of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and three Happy Birthday balloons hovering near the living room ceiling, but not much else.

title: Task Force Says BP Oil Spill Fines Should Go to Gulf Restoration
description: A Gulf Coast task force appointed by President Obama recommended on Monday that a significant portion of the billions of dollars in fines that BP is expected to pay for last years Deepwater Horizon oil spill go to ecological restoration.

title: In Essay, Cuomo Offers His Case for Amending States Tax System
description: ALBANY  Laying out his case for raising taxes on the wealthy, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday criticized New York States tax system as unfair and said it should be revised now.

title: Critics Picks: The Manchurian Candidate
description: A.O. Scott discusses paranoia in John Frankenheimers political thriller.

title: Search Resumes for Evidence of Life Out There
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Thank you for holding, our operators are no longer broke.

title: Toronto Snaps Rangers Home Winning Streak at 7
description: After 10 games at Madison Square Garden, only one team has beaten the Rangers in regulation, the Toronto Maple Leafs. And now they have done it twice, with a 4-2 victory Monday night that snapped the Rangers seven-game home winning streak and their five-game overall streak.

title: Familiarity Breeds Newt
description: In accordance with the rhythm of the Republican contest so far, its time to ask when Newt Gingrich, the unlikely race car of the moment, will run out of gas.

title: A Few Salient Points
description: Anyone whos stared long enough at a map knows the experience: eventually, your eyes settle on a feature so strange that you immediately rush to the history books for the back story. And nothing gets a border-watcher going quite like a salient.

title: New Districts for Voters in Colorado Are Approved
description: DENVER  Under a new map of Colorado Congressional districts approved on Monday by the states highest court, a once-safe Republican seat in the Sixth District, which had been spread across a sprawling area south of Denver, got tucked in tighter toward the citys edge, making it much more Hispanic and politically diverse.

title: More Pressure on Euro Countries Ratings
description: Standard & Poors warned that it might cut its ratings on the long-term sovereign debt of 15 of the 17 countries that use the euro.

title: Life in a Graying America
description: Southbury, Conn., is home to Heritage Village, a condominium complex with about 2,600 units for people 55 and older. More than 30 percent of Southburys population is over 60, and that figure is expected to rise.

title: Many Workers in Public Sector Retiring Sooner
description: MADISON, Wis.  As states and cities struggle to resolve paralyzing budget shortfalls by sending workers on unpaid furloughs, freezing salaries and extracting larger contributions for health benefits and pensions, a growing number of public-sector workers are finding fewer reasons to stay.

title: Vermont Rebounding Quickly From Hurricane Irene
description: BETHEL, Vt.  The raging White River that chewed up seven miles of Route 107 has gone back to being tame and lovely.

title: Hubert Sumlin, Master of Blues Guitar, Dies at 80
description: Hubert Sumlin, the guitarist whose slashing solos and innovative ideas galvanized the blues of Howlin Wolf and inspired rock guitar players like Jimmy Page, Robbie Robertson and Eric Clapton, died on Sunday in Wayne, N.J. He was 80.

title: ESPN Hires Francona
description: Terry Francona, who won two World Series in eight seasons as the manager of the Boston Red Sox but was fired after their September collapse this season, has joined ESPN as an analyst, the network said.

title: Bill McKinney, Actor in Deliverance, Dies at 80
description: Bill McKinney, a character actor whose most recognizable performance was as a menacing hillbilly in the 1972 film Deliverance, died on Thursday at a hospital near his home in Van Nuys, Calif. He was 80.

title: Numberplay: The Math Behind the Magic
N.H.L. Approves Realignment
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The Devils, the Rangers and the Islanders would join Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Washington and Carolina to form one of four conferences in a significant, more geography-friendly realignment plan approved Monday by the N.H.L.s Board of Governors during the first day of their winter meetings.

title: Sultan Khan, Indian Classical Musician, Dies at 71
description: Sultan Khan, a renowned Indian classical musician who carried forward the tradition of a disappearing instrument, the bowed lute called a sarangi, and who performed with Western musicians like George Harrison and Ornette Coleman, died on Nov. 27 in Mumbai, India. He was 71.

title: A Struggling School Gets a Lift From a Visiting Professor
Four Killed in Gunplay in Bayonne
description: A toddler and two adults were killed on Monday night by a gunman who then shot himself in a residential neighborhood in Bayonne, N.J., the mayor said.

title: For Children of Service Members, Help With Deployment
description: When a soldier is deployed overseas, it is an adjustment and sacrifice for entire families. Mondays Education section looked at the impact of deployment on children  and how schools are helping them cope with having a parent away at war.

title: Elisabeth Young-Bruehl, Who Probed Roots of Ideology and Bias, Dies at 65
description: Elisabeth Young-Bruehl, a philosopher, psychoanalyst and biographer known for her lives of two influential women, Hannah Arendt and Anna Freud, died on Thursday near her home in Toronto. She was 65.

title: For Local NBC Stations, Collaborative Journalism
description: In a sign of increasing collaboration between journalism groups, NBC on Tuesday will announce a series of partnerships between its television stations and nonprofit news organizations.

title: Word of the Day | hackles
description: hackles \ha-klz\ noun

title: FDI in Retail: Another Reform By Stealth Failure
description: If the Indian government decides to undo or indefinitely delay its decision to let foreign retailers into the country, as government sources now quietly predict, proponents of modernization will probably blame the opposition political parties and allies of the government like the Trinamool Congress party, as well as small retailers and wholesale traders.But a portion of the blame should also be set aside for another target: the cloak-and-dagger way in which this and many other free-market policies are often made in New Delhi, a process often described as reform by stealth. Faced with politically unpalatable proposals, Indian politicians and bureaucrats often go quiet, enact reforms in the dead of the night and then pray that the opposition is either too lazy or preoccupied to react.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/06/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/06/2011

title: Multiple Bomb Attacks in Iraq on a Day Holy to Shiites
description: BAGHDAD  Bomb blasts ripped into throngs of religious pilgrims on Monday as they streamed through Iraqs streets to honor one of the most sacred holidays of Shiite Islam, in what has become almost an annual spilling of blood and stirring of sectarian anger.

title: Dev Anand, Bollywood Star, Producer and Director, Dies at 88
description: Dev Anand, a dashing, charismatic Bollywood star, producer and director who was known in his heyday for his striking good looks, died on Saturday in London. He was 88.

title: France: Activists Breach Nuclear Plants
description: Activists from the environmental group Greenpeace infiltrated two nuclear power plants on Monday, and breached or tried to breach security at least two other nuclear sites, authorities said. Nine activists were arrested at a site in Nogent-sur-Seine, southeast of Paris, and two in Cruas, in the south. Greenpeace called security measures at the plants insufficient, and called for French leaders to shut down the countrys 58 nuclear reactors, which account for more than three quarters of the electricity consumed in France. French officials acknowledged a need to reinforce security around nuclear facilities.

title: The Future of Computing
description: A special report on the future of technology:

title: Mexico: Presidential Candidate Is Asked to Name Influential Books. Oops!
description: The leading candidate in next years presidential election drew ridicule from critics over the weekend when, in response to a question at Latin Americas biggest book fair, he was unable to completely name three books that had influenced him. The stumble played into the image that the candidate, Enrique Pea Nieto of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, has tended more to his looks than his books. He mentioned parts of the Bible, erred on the author of another book and was not able to come up with a third. On Monday, the gaffe was compounded when his teenage daughter sent out a Twitter message calling his critics a bunch of idiots who form part of the proletariat. Mr. Pea Nieto apologized for the tweet, calling it an emotional reaction.

title: Corrections: December 6
description: NEW YORK

title: News Quiz | Dec. 6, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Rangers Streak Ends on a Busy Night for Hockey
description: It was an odd evening at Madison Square Garden Monday. So many things converging at once, but what went practically unnoticed was perhaps the biggest thing of all  the news that Derek Boogaards brain had extensive damage from chronic traumatic encephalopathy when he died last spring of an accidental drug overdose, that Boogaards father reported seeing several pill bottles of painkillers prescribed by Rangers doctors at his drug-addicted sons Manhattan apartment, and that, according to Boogaards father, Boogaard once received a call from the Rangers warning him of a random drug test coming in four days time.

title: Dec. 6, 1923 | Calvin Coolidge Delivers First Presidential Address on Radio
description: On Dec. 6, 1923, the first presidential address was broadcast on the radio. President Calvin Coolidge delivered what is now known as the State of the Union address to a joint session of Congress.

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 6, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article A Connecticut Town Adjusts to a Graying Population.

title: Rare Attacks on Shiites Kill Scores in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Pakistan-based extremist group claimed responsibility for a series of coordinated bombings aimed at Afghan Shiites on Tuesday, in what many feared was an attempt to further destabilize Afghanistan by adding a new dimension of strife to a country that, though battered by a decade of war, has been free of sectarian conflict.

title: Visit the Titanic on Its 100th Birthday
description: WHEN did the Titanic sink?

title: In Brazil, Finding Dignity in Horror
description: I must have been 11, maybe 12 years old. I was staring out the big glass window in the big apartment I lived in Rio de Janeiro, looking at homes made out of wood and broken pieces of plastic and, sometimes, clay bricks, impossibly perched on the hillside ahead. It was a leg of one of the citys largest slums, Rocinha, which had draped over the mountains top, crossing from one neighborhood to the next.

title: Which Republican Candidate Will Win the Presidential Nomination?
description: Newt Gingrich is ahead of the other potential Republican presidential nominees in recent polls. After Herman Cain suspended his campaign, many of his supporters rallied behind Mr. Gingrich. However, eight other candidates  remain in the field.  Who do you think will eventually win the nomination?

title: Raising Taxes on the Rich: Not Whether, but How
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book The Benefit and the Burden.

title: Questions for the SATs Top Cop
description: In response to the standardized-test cheating scandal on New Yorks Long Island  which began with arrests related to the SAT, and has since come to encompass the ACT, too  I initiated an e-mail exchange last week with Ray Nicosia of the Educational Testing Service. Mr. Nicosia is director of testing integrity for E.T.S., which administers the SAT. What follows are edited excerpts from our electronic conversation. (At the end of this post, readers will find contact information for Mr. Nicosias office as well as a short cut to post comments on this blog in response to his remarks.)

title: In U.S., Hydrogen Cars May Line Up With Few Places to Fill Up
description: Last week at the Tokyo auto show, Toyota unveiled its FCV-R concept. According to a Toyota spokesman, John Hanson, the vehicle was designed to give the public an impression of the hydrogen-powered fuel-cell sedan it expected to make available in 2015. With a projected range of more than 400 miles, a production version of the FCV-R would surely dodge the range-anxiety stigma that afflicts battery electric vehicles.

title: New Istanbul Aquarium Offers Views From Under the Sea
description: In a city surrounded by bodies of water, the new Istanbul Akvaryum, or aquarium, offers a peek at what lies beneath.

title: The Early Word: Gingrich
description: Todays Times

title: A Slow Exodus From Nursing Homes
description: If youve helped an older relative move into a nursing home in the past year, youve likely heard a nurse or administrator pose The Question: Do you want to talk to someone about the possibility of returning to the community?

title: Manish Sabharwal Answers Readers Questions
description: India Ink asked Manish Sabharwal, chairman of the temporary-employment agency TeamLease, who was profiled in a recent New York Times article, to answer readers questions about the Indian labor market and his companys philosophy. Readers posed tough queries about his business model, his competitors and the hurdles that employers and job seekers face in India. The questions and Mr. Sabharwals answers have been edited.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 6
description: The production of Cloud Atlas, a film version of the David Mitchell novel that has a $100 million budget, is an example of how sophisticated filmmakers are turning to a globe-straddling independent finance system for their most expensive projects, rather than American studios, Nicholas Kulish and Michael Cieply report. The talent connected to the project includes Andy and Lana Wachowski, the American-born team behind the Matrix movies, and Tom Hanks and Halle Berry. But investors from China, South Korea, Singapore and beyond contributed roughly $35 million, without which the film could not have been made. German subsidies account for $18 million more.

title: New Iowa Poll: Who Can Beat Obama?
description: Just weeks before the first votes are cast in the 2012 presidential campaign, likely Republican caucus-goers in Iowa are closely divided over which candidate has the best chance of defeating President Obama, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds.

title: My Health Insurance Rates Just Went Down Again
description: I got an e-mail last week with my health insurance renewal rates for 2012. (I have written extensively on this subject: on previous rate declines, on the subsequent feedback, on the health care overhaul, and on rates for older workers.) I opened the e-mail with some trepidation, given the general trend of substantial increases every year. Surprise! Another decrease: 6 percent less for single workers, married couples, and families.

title: Newark Receiving Billions From N.Y.C. Taxpayers (for a Few Hours Each Day)
description: Over the next five years, Newark can expect to receive tens of billions of dollars intended for the New York City treasury and paid by New York City taxpayers, it has been learned.

title: What We Think We Learn as an N.F.L. Season Progresses
description: Its tempting to think that we know much more than we did at the start of the season. As of Sunday night, we learned  or, at least, we thought we learned  that San Francisco was really good, that San Diego had gone from unlucky to just plain bad and that the Rams were again one of the leagues doormats. One day later, and maybe the Chargers are getting ready for another late-season run.

title: Researchers Question Coverage for a Spine Procedure
description: What happens when a medical treatment is not found to clearly benefit patients? The answer may depend on whether the barn door is already wide open, according to a new analysis that reviews the history of a common spine procedure that was shown to be of unclear value long after Medicare and other insurers chose to pay for it.

title: European Inquiry Focuses On Setting of E-Book Prices
description: BRUSSELS  The European antitrust authority said Tuesday that it was investigating possible collusion between Apple and five large publishing houses in the growing market for electronic books.

title: Any Normal Human Being Would Be Offended
description: The Indian government has asked social media operators to delete information on the Internet that might offend the sensibilities of people in India,Kapil Sibal, Indias minister of communications and information technology, said Tuesday, confirming an earlier India Ink report.

title: Economic Troubles in Europe and U.S. Start to Affect Asia
description: HONG KONG  An interest rate cut in Australia and lowered economic growth estimates by the Asian Development Bank on Tuesday highlighted the extent to which the economic woes of Europe and the United States are spilling into the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Is Gingrich This Years Huckabee?
description: In 2007, Mike Huckabee snuck up on Mitt Romney. He surged in Iowa in December and ended up robbing Mr. Romney of a victory that he desperately needed.

title: Russia Cracks Down on Antigovernment Protests
description: MOSCOW  The Russian authorities acted decisively to quash a second day of protests against the government and Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday, flooding the appointed site with throngs of pro-government activists who banged on tin drums, drowning out the chants of Russia without Putin!

title: The Slang Patrol
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: The Slang Patrol
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: E-Commerce Sales Are Booming, Thanks to Discounts and Free Shipping
description: Online, at least, shoppers are spending money. Lots of it.

title: The Culture Was Corrupt at Olympus, Panel Finds
description: TOKYO  An outside panel appointed by Olympus to investigate its financial scandal issued a harsh report Tuesday, calling the companys recently departed management rotten to the core.

title: Bombings Kill Scores of Shiites in Afghanistan
description: Bombers struck Shiite religious observances in three cities, in the first such sectarian attacks in Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban.

title: A Mismatch Between Grid Regulation and Modern Needs
description: Rooftop solar power is unfairly subsidized yet draws excessive opposition from utility companies because of the way the grid allocates costs for power distribution, according to a new study released by the Massachusetts Institute for Technology.

title: A Word to the Wise and Honest on Washington Sq. Park
description: For lovers of tranquillity, Washington Square Park was a splendid place to be Monday afternoon. Tourists snapped pictures. Young mothers pushed strollers along the paths. Homeless men dozed on benches. Even drug dealers preserved the peace, resorting to a sort of pantomime to hawk their wares.

title: Opinion Report: Romneys Hazy Plan
description: From the editorial page

title: Weekend Roundup of Racing News
description: The Formula One season ended just a week ago, but the news has been piling up. In fact, much of the news coming through now is probably information that some put off announcing until after the season.

title: Weekend Roundup of Racing News
description: The Formula One season ended just a week ago, but the news has been piling up. In fact, much of the news coming through now is probably information that some put off announcing until after the season.

title: Hypothetically, What Would Your Ideal School System Look Like?
Mine Owner Will Pay $209 Million in Blast That Killed 29 Workers
description: In what officials say is the largest settlement ever in a government investigation of a mine disaster, Alpha Natural Resources agreed to pay $209 million in restitution and civil and criminal penalties for the role of its subsidiary, Massey Energy, in a mine explosion last year that killed 29 men in West Virginia.

title: Irish Pfizer Smiling
description: The Times has a good article on Ireland, focusing on the dissonance between the praise of outsiders and the grim realities for the Irish themselves. And as the Times notes, all this successful austerity has still left the interest rate on Irish debt at a completely unsustainable level.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Now Booking | Papaya Playa Project
description: The pop-up phenomenon may be old news in retail and restaurants, but temporary hotels is a concept just gaining ground (makeshift bedrooms in Kreuzberg or Nakameguro art galleries excepted). Today the Berlin-based Design Hotels group is staking the first big claim to the trend on the beach in Tulum, Mexico. The companys founder, Claus Sendlinger, who moved with his family to Tulum last year, is spearheading the opening of Papaya Playa, a spiffed-up campus of cabanas once belonging to three now-shuttered resorts on about a half mile of beachfront land.

title: A Setting, and Score, Befitting a Thoroughbred
description: If any premiere had the cinematic sweep and heft  and orchestration  of a John Williams score, it would have to be War Horse at Lincoln Center. Oh wait: the premiere did have exactly that; the music of Mr. Williams  which even a casual moviegoer would recognize from Superman, Jaws and E.T., among many, many others  was piped into the afterparty on Sunday night. The soundtrack was just one reason that the world premiere of War Horse, Steven Spielbergs adaptation of the childrens book-turned-theatrical hit felt grand.

title: Hearing May Be an Ex-Governors Last Stand
description: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, is expected to speak on his own behalf on Wednesday before the federal judge who will decide his sentence for 18 felony corruption convictions, including trying to sell or trade the Senate seat that President Obama left behind when he moved to the White House.

title: In Surprise Move, China Jails Australian for 13 Years
description: BEIJING  An Australian businessman whose business dealings with a state-owned Chinese company soured last year has been sentenced by a Chinese court to 13 years in prison on bribery and fraud charges, his lawyer and Australian officials said Tuesday.

title: Tuesday Reading: Public Workers Retiring Earlier in Tight Times
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Kuwaiti Leader Dissolves Parliament
description: The emir of Kuwait dissolved Parliament on Tuesday, setting the stage for elections in the oil-rich Persian Gulf nation that has faced some protests but has thus far been spared the revolutionary wave of the Arab Spring.

title: Grammys Statement Deepens Mystery of Promised Band Reunion
description: 1:16 p.m. | Updated

title: Policy Indifference
description: One crucial thing you need to understand about political journalists is that with some honorable exceptions, they dont know or care about actual policy. In a way, that makes sense  the skills needed to cultivate contacts, to get the inside scoop on whats going on in Congressional scheming or campaign war rooms, are very different from the skills needed to interpret CBO spreadsheets. The problem, however, is that all too often political journalists mistake the theater of policy for reality (or dont care about the difference).

title: European Leaders Question Timing of Credit Downgrade Warning
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders reacted angrily Tuesday over the timing of a warning of a broad credit rating downgrade days before a European summit meeting. And German officials portrayed the threat by Standard & Poors as impetus for leaders to make a deal to rescue the euro.

title: What Were Reading
description: 2 Minutes to Dinner: A writer and cooking and teacher finally comes out and says it: Shes tired of pork belly. Also offal. And a few of the other rich, fatty meats that chefs love.   Julia Moskin

title: Graphic Content | Good Chemistry
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Imposing Presence on Iraqs Streets
description: The streets of Baghdad looked like a different place in 2008--both to the American soldiers peering down and the Iraqis looking up.

title: Markets Optimistic a Resolution To the Euro Crisis Will Be Found
description: Stocks rose on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index higher a second day, on speculation that European leaders may act to contain the debt crisis after S.& P. put 15 euro nations on review for possible downgrade.

title: You Like Walking in the City? So Do Plenty of Others
description: Feeling congested? Not your nose, your toes. City surveys confirm that sidewalks are becoming more crowded. And transportation officials say thats good for the economy, the environment and for your physical, if not necessarily emotional, health.

title: Video From Kabul Shows Shock as Bomb Explodes
description: Updated | 12:20 p.m. As Sharifullah Sahak and Rod Nordland report for The Times from Kabul, a suicide bomber killed dozens of people watching a religious ceremony in the Afghan capital on Tuesday.

title: Whalen Joins Tangent Capital as Money Manager
description: Christopher Whalen, the outspoken bank analyst known for his critical industry research, has joined an investment bank after nearly a decade as a managing director of Institutional Risk Analytics, the firm he co-founded.

title: City Bungled Tavern on the Green Concessions, Audit Says
description: New York City has badly mishandled the creation of concessions at the former Tavern on the Green, said an audit released on Monday by the citys comptroller, John C. Liu.

title: City Policies Undermined Jane Addams High
In Nepal, Farmers Struggle as City Dwellers Fight Monsanto
