description: Kashish Das Shrestha is a Nepal-born, New York-based photographer and writer who alternates between covering fashion shows and Maoist rebels, celebrities and refugees. In recent e-mail exchanges he alerted me to a building protest effort in Nepal following an announcement in September by the United States Agency for International Development that it was teaming up with Monsanto and Nepali agricultural agencies to promote the benefits of high-yielding hybrid corn varieties and to train Nepali farmers how to grow such crops.

title: Other Than That, Mr. Cain, How Was the Campaign?
description: This chart should tell you pretty much everything you need to know about the rise and fall of Herman Cain:

title: Villagers Become Refugees in Myanmar as Rebels Clash With Troops
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Intensifying clashes between ethnic rebels and Myanmars army have forced tens of thousands of villagers into refugee camps near the Chinese border, according to aid workers and members of the clergy.

title: At Dans Le Noir, Dining in the Dark
description: This gives a whole new meaning to mystery meat. At Dans Le Noir, which started in Paris eight years ago and has branches in London, Barcelona and St. Petersburg, Russia, customers dine in a pitch-dark room without knowing the details of the menu. The waiters are all blind or visually impaired.

title: Tiny Tax on Financial Trades Gains Advocates
description: They call it the Robin Hood tax  a tiny levy on trades in the financial markets that would take money from the banks and give it to the worlds poor.

title: Asked & Answered | Lexi Thompson
description: With her five-stroke victory at the Navistar L.P.G.A. Classic in Prattville, Ala., in September, Lexi Thompson became, at age 16 years, 7 months and 8 days, the youngest winner by nearly two years in the tours 61-year history. She made more history shortly thereafter when the L.P.G.A. commissioner, Michael Whan, waived the minimum age requirement of 18 years to allow Thompson to become a full-fledged tour member in 2012.

title: For Havelange, a Reckoning Long Delayed
description: With a resignation so covert it had to be virtually pried from FIFA and the International Olympic Committee, the Brazilian Joo Havelange appears to have finally left the scene of high-ranking governance over global sports.

title: Gifts for Foodies, Cyclists, Geeks and More
description: Whether you are looking to reduce the environmental impact of your gift-giving or win the heart of a green-minded friend, the hunt for holiday gifts that are legitimately planet-friendly can be daunting.

title: Wheelies: The Unlicensed Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Blunt Talk by Regents Chief for Citys Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott was preparing to meet with the chancellor of the State Board of Regents, Merryl H. Tisch, when a reporter called.

title: Clinging to the Egyptian Army
description: NAG HAMMADI, Egypt  The citizens of Cairo learned a small lesson in the banality of evil last week when they saw the face of Mahmoud al-Shennawy, the police sniper who allegedly aimed for Tahrir Square protesters eyes. When Shennawys photo came out, the city gave a collective gasp at his youth. He looks about 15. Is it really possible that that those rosy cheeks were fed by such icy blood?

title: On the Streets of Baghdad, an Invisible American Withdrawal
description: BAGHDAD  Only a few miles to the west of here, Camp Victory, the vast American military headquarters, was handed over to the Iraqis just a few days ago and the remaining American bases, soldiers and equipment will follow soon.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Manchurian Candidate
description: The democratic process can often seem like the theater of the absurd, A. O. Scott says in this weeks Critics Picks video, which looks back at John Frankenheimers political thriller The Manchurian Candidate. The film tells the story of Raymond Shaw (Laurence Harvey),  a soldier who is given the Congressional Medal of Honor for his heroism in Korea, but more about what happened to him in battle soon emerges. Shaw and his troop were kidnapped and brainwashed by Chinese and Soviet Communists who sent Shaw back to the United States as a pawn for their plans of world domination.

title: Shopping for a Better Deal on Home Services With WhiteFence
description: One of my least favorite tasks is dealing with utilities and other service providers, like the cable company, to see if I can get a better deal. Its unpleasant, but something that needs to be done periodically  especially when you notice your monthly bills ticking inexorably upwards.

title: Racial Profiling Versus Affirmative Action
description: My post yesterday about Representative Steve King and racial profiling drew a few responses from readers who argued that racial profiling is no different, really, than affirmative action.

title: Bank of England Urges Cuts in Bank Pay and Dividends
description: 7:33 p.m. | Updated

title: Sharp Spate of Killings Traumatizes a Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In one of the worst episodes of sectarian carnage in Syria since the uprising began nine months ago, dozens of corpses were recovered from the streets of Homs this week, some of them dismembered, decapitated and bearing signs of torture, activists and residents said Tuesday.

title: First Leg of Ocean Race Is an Adventure
description: The last place the professional sailor Ryan Godfrey expected to be this week was hiking around a remote volcanic island in the South Atlantic in long underwear and a T-shirt.

title: As Seabrook Awaits Verdict, His Lawyers Are Cautioned by Judge
description: Prosecutors in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook have accused defense lawyers in the case of making comments outside of court that could influence the jurys deliberations.

title: Myths of the Hispanic Vote
description: Not every liberal is publicly chortling over the prospect of facing Newt Gingrich in the general election. According to the Washington Post, some Democratic strategists fear Gingrichs ability to  win Hispanic voters:

title: Macarons for What Ails You
description: THOSE delectable pastel macarons from Ladure, the French patisserie open in New York since late summer, with lines still up the block, have been given the Judith Leiber treatment. That is, the Leiber company, known for its sparkling evening bags, has modeled a collection of crystal pillboxes after the iconic confection. The inspired idea came about after Jana Matheson, the creative director of Judith Leiber, returned from a trip to Paris with macarons for her office. Over a tea and macaron meeting, we matched crystal colors to the desserts, she said. It was one of our most delicious meetings. The pillboxes, true to size, come in 14 flavorful colors including champagne, lemon, rose and mint.

title: Horses That Should Have Their Own IMDB Page
description: The Bagger has already noted that, to our delight, its an animal-heavy awards season. Well, theres a new creature in the celeb barnyard: the star of War Horse.

title: Ciscos Bigger Bundle of Networking
description: Cisco introduced a comprehensive collection of computer networking hardware for cloud computing on Tuesday. The parts are not particularly new, but the packaging is  and that matters for both customer education and sales.

title: Minor Bounce for Commercial Metals as Icahn Goes Hostile
description: 5:03 p.m. | Updated

title: Chinese Bank Pairs Up With Private Equity
description: LONDON  The state-owned China Development Bank announced strategic agreements on Tuesday with the private equity firms K.K.R., TPG Capital and Permira as it continued its international expansion.

title: A Breakdown at Sea
description: A broken mast forced the Puma race crew and boat to a remote island, where crew members awaited assistance during the first leg of the Volvo Ocean Race, from Alicante, Spain, to Cape Town.

title: Leading Off: The Sounds of Mostly Silence (So Far)
description: As the final installment in the story of the life and death of the hockey enforcer Derek Boogaard by The Timess John Branch rolls out Tuesday, the waiting begins. Waiting to see if the sport reacts to something that has laid out the devastating effects of fighting in painful detail. Waiting to see if fans will continue to cheer fights, knowing they are likely trading those players brains for their entertainment. Waiting to see if pundits can still manage to proffer the absurd arguments about the violence preventing more violence.

title: Sunos New Footprint
description: Remember what we said about printed shoes this season? Now from Suno, the out-of-Africa label designed by Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, come five pairs of supercolorful, print-happy sneakers. By doing this we can further our companys mission to create jobs within Kenya, and by using excess fabric from past productions we can make darn cute shoes at a really attractive price, Osterweis says. Darn cute is right. These classic slip-ons and lace-ups not only have names like clustered caviar and bandana flower, but their soles are made from recycled rubber, too. And were helping baby elephants, adds Beatty, noting that a portion of all of the shoes proceeds will go to the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust in Kenya. Heres to walking the walk.

title: Tax Deal Expected Between Cuomo and Lawmakers
description: Update, 2:05 p.m. | A tentative deal has been reached to raise taxes on the wealthy and cut taxes on the middle class. See article here.

title: Boston University Doctor Answers Questions from Readers
description: Dr. Robert A. Stern, a neuropsychologist and a co-director for the Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, is answering questions Tuesday afternoon about C.T.E. and John Branchs series Punched Out.

title: An Encore in Los Angeles for Follies
description: The Beautiful Girls are headed west: the Center Theater Group announced on Tuesday that it will transfer the acclaimed Broadway revival of Follies to the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles for a six-week run beginning May 3, 2012. The Broadway production, which opened in September, will continue its run at the Marquis Theater through Jan. 22, as scheduled.

title: Some Perspective on Reyes
description: The animation team at NMA.tv has done it again, with a clear and concise wrap-up of Jose Reyes signing with the Marlins, the Mets future plans, Miamis pursuit of Albert Pujols and for good measure the news that the Mets and Red Sox are now (apparently) rivals.

title: Wall Street Women Optimistic About Investment Opportunities
description: Its been a difficult year for the alternative investment industry, as hedge funds, private equity firms and venture capital funds have been buffeted by worldwide market volatility.

title: Bipartisan Push for Vast Transportation Bill
description: While Republicans and Democrats fight over how to pay for the extension of a payroll tax cut  or whether to let it continue at all  a bipartisan cadre of House members has quietly been coalescing around the notion of a large-scale, long-term transportation bill to address the countrys myriad infrastructure needs.

title: U.S. to Aid Gay Rights Abroad, Obama and Clinton Say
description: GENEVA  The Obama administration announced on Tuesday that the United States would use all the tools of American diplomacy, including the potent enticement of foreign aid, to promote gay rights around the world.

title: Gingrich on Climate  The 2007 Version
description: Now that Newt Gingrich is a front runner, his foes from both parties are sifting for past statements that clash with his current agenda. On climate, there are plenty of examples of his shifts. I offer some fresh fare  a video interview I conducted with him in 2007 on climate science and policy (related to a much-discussed article of mine on the middle ground in climate policy). It had been off the grid for awhile but is restored here. Have a listen and see whether hes changed his tune on global warming.

title: Travel Lessons From the World of Academia
description: If Ive said it once, Ive said it thousands of times: Substantial Amounts of Domain Importance Heterogeneity exist in the contribution of vacations to peoples Quality of Life.

title: Talking Restaurants and Closings, One Owner to Another
description: Southfork Kitchen is closed for the season. It took weeks to complete the physical task, what with inventory, cleaning, canceling vendors and preserving whatever foods we could. Its taking much longer to shut down internally. I miss the hustle and bustle. I miss the staff. Change was never my friend, especially unscheduled change, a change that brought unexpected sadness, a sense of failure and an empty freedom.

title: Android Marketplace Tops 10 Billion App Downloads
description: Android continues to nip at Apples heels. On Tuesday, Google announced that more than 10 billion applications had been downloaded to Android devices from its mobile software shop.

title: Hezbollah Leader Backs Syrian President in Public
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, made a rare public appearance on Tuesday in Beirut, reiterating his support for Syrias government and saying that his group was better trained and armed than ever.

title: Nadler Wants Police Activity at Wall St. Protests Scrutinized
description: Representative Jerrold Nadler, ranking member of the House Judiciary Committees Subcommittee on the Constitution and representative of the district that includes Zuccotti Park, sent a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday urging him to examine reports of police misconduct at the Occupy Wall Street protests.

title: Campaign Ads Show Sharp Declines From 2008
description: At this point in 2007, Iowa residents had been subjected to 26,037 television commercials from presidential candidates and political groups in a barrage of advertising that was unparalleled.

title: A Campaign Against Bed Sharing
description: Last month, Milwaukee introduced two public service announcements intended to stop parents and caregivers from bringing infants into their beds. In the wake of nine infant deaths associated with an unsafe sleep environment in 2011 (including one discovered on the day the new campaign was announced), two ads went up citywide on buses and billboards, each showing a young baby (one white, one black) asleep in an adult bed amid much soft bedding, with a butcher knife tucked in alongside. Your baby sleeping with you can be just as dangerous, the ads say.

title: Plus/Minus: The N.H.L.s Realignment Plan
description: Gary Bettman is well aware the N.H.L.s drastic realignment into four conferences is ripe for criticism from league commentators, fans, and even some of the team executives that voted on it.

title: City Opera, Leaving Lincoln Center, Will Have Offices in Lower Manhattan
description: The New York City Opera, which is moving out of Lincoln Center, said on Tuesday that it had found office space in Lower Manhattan. The company said it would move its administrative operation to 75 Broad Street on Dec. 16, taking residence in temporary quarters there before occupying 14,000 square feet of renovated space in March or April. The company is also renting 4,000 square feet of storage space in the building, partly for its archives.

title: The Giving Spree | Pat McGrath
description: Who: The makeup artist Pat McGrath

title: Plan for Online Freedoms Stalls at European Meeting
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania  The United States and two dozen other nations called for the adoption of a declaration of freedoms in cyberspace at a European security conference here on Tuesday, but the proposal stalled in the face of opposition from Russia and countries that view the Internet as a threat to their political systems.

title: Gingrich Holds Strong Lead in South Carolina Poll
description: Although the political world is laser-focused on the coming presidential contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, the South Carolina primary is looming on Jan. 21, and former Speaker Newt Gingrich now holds a commanding lead in the state, according to a new poll released Tuesday.

title: Lens: 7 Bill Final
description: Lens: 7 Bill Final

title: Marni Store Enlivens Sleepy Stretch of Meatpacking District
description: Whether it is because of its unusual triangular footprint or the fact that a sumptuous Yohji Yamamoto boutique occupied it previously, the new Marni space at 1 Gansevoort Street, (646) 532-6015, empty for many months, seemed destined for a special tenant. Indeed, Consuelo Castiglionis quirky Marni Edition designs for women and men, as well as her childrens collection, have enlivened the space and a sleepy stretch of the meatpacking district. Though there are Marni outposts in SoHo and on the Upper East Side, this is the first United States location for Marni Edition, a slightly less expensive line with prices that may still keep us waiting for Ms. Castiglionis H&M debut in March.

title: Can The Raptors Turn It Around?
description: The Toronto Raptors were a truly unfortunate team last season, plagued by performance deficiencies in virtually every facet of the game. Their league-worst defense turned the Air Canada Centre into a sanctuary for visiting teams, and the Raps offense was only slightly less hospitable. Overall, Toronto managed the fifth-worst efficiency differential in the entire N.B.A. last year, a mark truly representative of their failings in some of the games most crucial areas.

title: On Our Radar: Gingrich on Climate Change
description: Three years after appearing in a commercial with Representative Nancy Pelosi to warn that human-caused climate change is under way, Newt Gringrich, the Republican presidential hopeful, tells Glenn Beck that there is evidence on both sides of the climate change argument. [Huffington Post]

title: Albany Tax Deal to Raise Rate for Highest Earners
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced on Tuesday that they had reached an agreement to overhaul New York States income tax, creating a higher tax bracket for the highest-income residents and reducing the tax rate for millions of middle-class residents.

title: Orchestra of St. Lukes Names Conductor
description: Pablo Heras-Casado will become the principal conductor of the Orchestra of St. Lukes, the ensemble said on Tuesday. Mr. Heras-Casado, a 34-year-old Spaniard, has been making guest appearances with major orchestras recently and is considered a rising talent.

title: 70 Years Later: Using Historic Times Articles and Social Media to Remember Pearl Harbor
description: Overview | What happened on Dec. 7, 1941? Why is the attack on Pearl Harbor such a historically important event? In this lesson, students learn about the 1941 attack by reading an archival Times article from the day after, and then either create a series of Twitter posts that document the attack and resulting declaration of war, or write a Historic Headlines-style summary and analysis of the event and its repercussions  and their connection to today.

title: Chris Wallace to Interview Mitt Romney
description: After a much-panned interview with Bret Baier of Fox News Channel last week and facing a growing perception that he has kept potentially tough interviews to a minimum, Mitt Romney has agreed to sit for a Dec. 18 interview on Fox News Sunday with Chris Wallace.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.6
description: The World Cup mens Alpine skiing circuit continued in Beaver Creek, Colo.

title: Paul Takes On Gingrich in New Ad
description: Representative Ron Paul of Texas has emerged as the Republican presidential candidate most willing to attack his rivals with hard-hitting commercials.

title: From Russia, With Fraud
description: Having spent four years covering the Soviet Union in the mid-1980s, and as a student of Russia and Russian history since I was in my teens, Ive been watching the elections in that long-suffering country with fascination.

title: Vain Glorious | Home Fragrance
description: Who: The designers Shipley & Halmos and the perfumers D.S. & Durga

title: City Sidewalks, Busy Sidewalks
description: Traffic congestion isnt just for the highways. In New York City, its the sidewalks that are overcrowded.

title: Dodge Dart: A Familiar Name Returns From an Unlikely Place
description: 3:31 p.m. | Updated

title: Council Committee Endorses Cuomos Tax Plan
description: As elected officials in Albany put the final touches on a deal to raise taxes on wealthy New Yorkers, they got a vote of support from the New York City Council finance committee, which passed a resolution Tuesday morning endorsing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos effort to institute a more progressive tax code.

title: TimesCast | December 6, 2011
description: Three sectarian bombings in Afghanistan; a study shows brain damage in some N.H.L. players; and a poll shows Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney competing for the Iowa Republican caucuses.

title: Banks Rely Too Heavily On Social Security Numbers, Report Finds
description: Banks can do better at protecting their customers from the risk of identity fraud, a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds.

title: The World Is Ending, Please Update the Home Page
description: Lets say, just for giggles, that the word was ending. Could be an alien invasion, a pandemic or nuclear annihilation. If one of those scenarios became a news event, how would it be covered?

title: New European Bank Chief Takes a Bold Approach
description: FRANKFURT  For someone with a reputation for caution, Mario Draghi is off to an audacious start as president of the European Central Bank.

title: Angelina Jolie on the Red Carpet
description: Angelina Jolie discusses her directorial debut "In the Land of Blood and Honey" at the film's premiere.

title: Postal Service Cutbacks Add New Light to Netflix Saga
description: Maybe Reed Hastings wasnt so confused after all.

title: Gingrich Surges Ahead in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  A month before the Republican nominating contest opens here, former Speaker Newt Gingrich holds a substantial lead among voters who say they are likely to participate in the Iowa caucuses, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: TimesCast | Attacks On Afghan Shiites
description: December 6, 2011 - Three coordinated bombings in Afghanistan targeted Shiites celebrating a holy day, in the first such sectarian attacks since the fall of the Taliban in 2001.

title: Girl Walk//All Day': A Conversation With the Director
description: Last January, Jacob Krupnick posted online a nearly eight-minute video featuring a young woman with cropped brown hair dancing with abandon on the Staten Island ferry. A few passengers gawk, but for the most part shes ignored. The video soon went viral. Now, almost a year later, its a feature film called Girl Walk//All Day. In the last few weeks, chapters of the movie have been released on the Gothamist Web site, while the Dia Art Foundation featured several of the performers at its gala. And on Thursday the film will make its public debut at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple.

title: Just One Look | Jason Wu
description: Charles Harpers Birds and Words (Ammo) by Charley Harper set the tone at Jason Wus prefall presentation, where rich peacock colors and jersey tees with sporty palm frond appliqus stood out most. There were day looks: a double-stripe sweater with skinny pants or leather pencil skirt; a number of knee-length dresses with pockets and belts attached. Meanwhile, dramatic evening looks inspired by a maharajah coffee table book featured lavish details like silver lead collars and floaty, handkerchief hemlines. Here, a glowing blue brocade suit. Its a bit darker and more sinister, which I love, Wu says about the collection. She totally has a raspy voice!

title: Reviewing Family Recipe
description: What should we call the cuisine offered by chef Akiko Thurnauer at Family Recipe, an idiosyncratic little restaurant on one of the less trafficked blocks of the Lower East Side (and the subject of this weeks $25 and Under)?

title: Israeli Ex-President Avows Innocence on Eve of Prison
description: KIRYAT MALACHI, Israel  A day after Moshe Katsav, Israels former president, turned 66, his modest home in this immigrant town was filled on Tuesday with grandchildren and well-wishers. Phones rang. Neighbors with sun-creased faces offered hugs. Rabbis in tall hats gave their blessings.

title: British TV Crew Reports From Homs, a Syrian City Under Siege
description: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, In one of the worst episodes of sectarian carnage in Syria since the uprising began nine months ago, dozens of corpses were recovered from the streets of Homs this week, some of them dismembered, decapitated and bearing signs of torture, activists and residents said Tuesday.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Cameras in the Court?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakers Courting Both Paul and Howard?
description: Could the next mega-star team, a sequel to the Miami Heat, be in the works?

title: Conclave to Open on Mekongs Fate
description: The Laotians call it Mae Nam Khong, the Mother of Water. The Vietnamese refer to it as Song Cuu Long, or the Nine Dragons River. The Khmer prefer Tonle Thum, or simply Great River. Whatever its name, the Mekong River is a lifeline for millions in the countries touched by its muddy waters, the worlds largest inland fishery.

title: Family Recipe
description: ON top of the pancake, something was writhing: a clew of bonito flakes in silent riot, the diaphanous curls lurching and shuddering. A diner whipped out her iPhone and started shooting. (For the kids, she explained.)

title: Meanwhile, in the Race Involving Pandas and Geese
description: The nominations for the Annies, the animation worlds Oscars, were announced on Monday, and it was a good year for DreamWorks. The studio  which won the first-ever animation Oscar, with Shrek, in 2002  has two films in the running for best feature Annie, Puss in Boots and Kung Fu Panda 2, both considered Oscar hopefuls. The competition is strong though, with Rango, from Paramount and Nickelodeon; Cars 2, from Pixar; Arthur Christmas, from Sony, and The Adventures of Tintin, from Steven Spielbergs Amblin Entertainment, all making the cut. (The complete list of nominations is here.)

title: Text: Obamas Speech in Kansas
description: Following is a text of President Obamas speech in Osawatomie, Kan. on Tuesday, as released by the White House:

title: Morphing Into Hilary Swank on New Years Eve
description: And now a movie review from Lori Raimondo. More in a moment about why she is supremely well qualified to assess New Years Eve, the new Garry Marshall film with a cast almost as sprawling as the crowd in Times Square  and why this may be one of the, um, nicest reviews that New Years Eve is going to get.

title: Mama and Papa Versus Life Upon the Wicked Stage
description: The Jazz Singer is best known as the first feature-length talkie, a 1927 cinematic artifact assigned in every introductory film class. Before it was a movie, though, it was a hit Broadway play.

title: App Smart Extra: 10 Android Apps for a Buck
description: Since its appearance in March, Amazons Appstore has offered app giveaways to Android users, stealing some thunder from Googles Android Market.

title: Obama Strikes Populist Chord With Speech on G.O.P. Turf
description: OSAWATOMIE, Kan.  Laying out a populist argument for his re-election next year, President Obama ventured into the conservative heartland on Tuesday to deliver his most pointed appeal yet for a strong governmental role through tax and regulation to level the economic playing field.

title: Touch-Up Software for Smoothing Over Imperfections Like a Pro
description: THE professional photographers dirty little secret is that not all photos look so professional straight from the camera. The pros make digital touch-ups to profoundly enhance their shots.

title: The Get | Moncler + Mykita Sunglasses
description: Today, the winter-sports outfitter Moncler announced its collaboration with Mykita, the sunglasses brand best known for shading Lady Gaga and Sarah Jessica Parker from sun and camera flashes alike. The two styles, both of which are oversize and fabulously buglike, come in three colors: black, blue and red. We see stocking stuffers!

title: Week 13 Film Review: Cowboys Thrown Off Rhythm
description: A closer look at some of the games from Week 13, with the benefit of film review:

title: A New Secret Weapon for Electronics Shoppers
description: IF only shopping for electronics were as easy as buying a car.

title: A Reputation Staked, and Shattered, on the Forged Diaries of Hitler
description: The English historian Hugh Trevor-Roper (1914-2003) is best remembered, if at all, for a humiliating blunder. He was the Oxford and Cambridge scholar who, in 1983, was called upon to authenticate diaries, discovered by the German magazine Stern, said to be Hitlers. Trevor-Roper didnt merely pronounce the Hitler diaries genuine. He also declared them the most important historical discovery of the decade. He maintained that they were, in an odd comparison, a scoop of Watergate proportions. The diaries turned out to be crude forgeries, and his reputation was shattered.

title: Channel Surfing: Hidden City
description: In the early part of the century, one of my primary guilty pleasures was A&Es City Confidential, a true-crime show that was the closest thing on television to a dirty little B-movie. Theres been no lack of docu-reality crime shows since it went off the air in 2006, but none has had the same combination of regional flavor, hard-boiled attitude and lurid, literate narration. City Confidential made your skin crawl in the best way.

title: Amazon Acquires Childrens Book Titles
description: Amazon expanded its publishing ambitions on Tuesday by acquiring more than 450 titles from Marshall Cavendish Childrens Books, a niche publisher.

title: Beijing's Smoggy Skies
description: As a brownish gray haze sits atop the Chinese capital, people are starting to ask if the government is giving the public an accurate picture of the country's air quality.

title: CBS Wins Monday Night Ratings
description: With the most recent season of ABCs Dancing with the Stars completed, CBS dominated the remaining competition in prime time on Monday and won every half-hour in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for a ratings sweep. How I Met Your Mother started the night off with its largest audience since Jan. 12, 2009, (11.7 million total viewers), followed by 2 Broke Girls and its largest audience (12.8 million) since its premiere. Two and a Half Men was the most-watched program of the night with 15 million viewers.

title: The Turtleneck Comes Out of Its Shell
description: Chalk it up to a need for a little sartorial dignity in an overly confessional culture; or to the grass-is-greener yearning for a cold-weather garment when 60-degree temperatures have steadily been reported on the East Coast; or even to Steve Jobs.

title: When Will We Stop the Scapegoating?
description: As the 2012 presidential election approaches, it has been difficult for me to listen to the political scapegoating of Muslims and those perceived to be Muslims. A decade ago, as an attorney at the Department of Justice, I worked with colleagues in the civil rights division to address the unprecedented backlash in the wake of the 9/11 attacks. We investigated complaints of brutal hate crimes in neighborhoods, vandalism at places of worship, bullying at schools, and discrimination in the workplace aimed primarily at those who traced their origins to South Asia and the Middle East, or those who practiced Islam, Sikhism and Hinduism.

title: Video Games for All Tastes and Attention Spans
description: It wasnt long ago that video games were on the verge of being marginalized in American culture  like comic books. (When was the last time you saw an adult reading a comic book, err, excuse me, a graphic novel, in public? Never?)

title: Some Instant Motivation for the Fitness Conscious
description: LOOKING for something to place under the tree for the health buff in the family? Skip the Zumba DVDs and consider a fitness gadget. They can make a great present for anyone on your list, whether that person is an ardent athlete or simply wants a little help working off holiday indulgences like eggnog and pecan pie.

title: Are You Now or Have You Ever Been a Muppet?
description: Theres a certain breed of right winger who likes to pick on Hollywood. Who says its a bastion of liberal thinking that promotes lefitst ideas in movies and on television. And who claims this leads to the brainwashing of Americans, especially children, with liberal values.

title: Coming Out of Its Shell Once More
description: AT the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards last month, where the red carpet teemed with actresses and designers dressed in complicated evening numbers of varying slits and cuts, the designer Rachel Roy was covered neck to toe in a floor-length black skirt from her own collection and a sheer, flesh-colored turtleneck by Stella McCartney.

title: Former Schools Official Is Fined for Ethics Violation
Outrage Grows Over Air Pollution and Chinas Response
description: BEIJING  The statement posted online along with a photograph of central Beijing muffled in a miasma of brown haze did not mince words: The end of the world is imminent.

title: On the Calmest Red Carpet With Angelina Jolie
description: It has been a good few days for getting a glimpse of highly glam directors: On Sunday, Madonna was totally zen as she screened her new movie, W.E., at the Museum of Modern Art (It seemed like she entered the Modern after taking a yoga class, said Stephen Schaefer, a reporter who covered the scene for Variety) and on Monday night, Angelina Jolie was the picture of placidity as she strolled the red carpet for the premiere of her directorial debut, In the Land of Blood and Honey.

title: When Daddys Cafeteria Is in Afghanistan
description: Marine stoicism is no longer expected from the kindergartners at schools on the Marine base at Camp Lejeune, N.C., who are waiting for Dad or Mom (women make up 11 percent of forces serving in Iraq and Afghanistan, and 40 percent of them have children) to come home. Instead, an impressive array of high-quality support services are available for children with parents at war. How much can any club or counseling do to help a child manage the hopes and fears and confusion that come with watching a parent get on that plane, or come home injured or changed (or not at all)? Maybe not much, but the military is trying. In 2008-9, it spent $6 million to train 420 school counselors and psychologists in methods for helping children affected by parents serving in wartime. Michael Winerips recent article in The Times, Lessons in Coping for Children of Deployed, is a reminder that not all sacrifices come from our troops.

title: Livestreamed Me
description: The Times tells me that tonights event  a discussion of the economy by Carmen Reinhart, Joe Nocera, and me me me, moderated by Tom Friedman, will be livestreamed from the opinion front, starting I assume at 7:30.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 81
description: Occupy Our Homes began nationwide demonstrations on Tuesday to protest the foreclosure crisis. Protesters in New York are visiting neighborhoods with high foreclosure rates and plan to reoccupy a foreclosed home. [Mother Jones, The Guardian]

title: Iran Promises Better Protection for Embassies
description: Irans foreign minister promised that Iranian protesters will not overrun and vandalize any more embassies in Tehran, the way they did Britains diplomatic facilities in Tehran last week.

title: Universal Studios in Hollywood Adding Harry Potter Attraction
description: NBC Universal is counting on the boy wizard to revive another one of its aging theme parks.

title: Voices of Fukushimas Evacuees
description: About 88,000 people have been evacuated from around the Fukushima nuclear plant. Nine months after the tsunami, many are still unemployed and live in temporary housing.

title: Conditions at Fukushima Plant Improve, but Return Home Will Take Years
description: Some predict that one area around the plant, about twice the size of Manhattan, will be uninhabitable for at least two decades, though steps like removing soil could shorten that time.

title: Japanese Tests Find Radiation in Infant Food
description: TOKYO  Traces of radioactive cesium thought to be from the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant were detected in Japanese baby formula on Tuesday as concerns about food safety continue almost nine months after the accident.

title: Employed Women, Dropping Out of the Labor Force
description: 12/7/11 | Updated to correct figure for net number of dropouts in November.

title: Japan Split on Hope for Vast Radiation Cleanup
description: FUTABA, Japan  Futaba is a modern-day ghost town  not a boomtown gone bust, not even entirely a victim of the devastating earthquake and tsunami that leveled other parts of Japans northeast coast.

title: Romney Will Not Attend Trump Debate
description: 11:43 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

title: Being President Is Tough but Usually Not Fatal, a Study Concludes
description: WASHINGTON  Finally, some happy news for President Obama.

title: Welcome to the Club
description: NOT everybody yearns for Brooklyn, or even for what Brooklyn has come to represent among New York restaurants. The guys in beards and knit hats have their place, as do the tattooed servers, the avant-garde wines and turn-of-the-last-century cocktailians, and all the rest.

title: Reviewing Monkey Bar, and Its Wines
description: With few exceptions, wine lovers complain regularly that restaurant reviews pay short shrift to wine. I understand the position, yet Im not exactly sure what the wine lovers would have restaurant critics do.

title: Poll Shows Age Gap in G.O.P. on Immigration
description: With immigration now a front-burner issue in the Republican presidential contest, a new poll shows a substantial age gap among Republican voters over whether there should be a path to citizenship for immigrants who are in the country illegally.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Russia, Iraq and Iran.

title: The Stuff That Dream School Is Made Of
description: The touchstones seem to be everywhere these days: the plaid-wearing, goateed bicycle messengers of Portlandia; the grunge heiress Frances Bean Cobains recent Hedi Slimane photo shoot; the chortling return of Beavis and Butthead to MTV. Yes, the 90s are totally back  so much so that some culture observers are probably busy deciding at this very moment that theyre already over again. And theres no doubt that Dream School (Figment), Blake Nelsons sequel to his beloved 1994 teenage bildungsroman, Girl, owes its publication, at least partly, to our current fascination with that halcyon age of mix tapes and Doc Martens. Nelson himself said, I finished writing the book in 2000, but nobody would publish it, so it sat in my drawer for 10 years.

title: Fukushimas Ripple Effects Continue
description: The triple meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in March startled many people in the American nuclear industry, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Tuesday, although the success in ultimately gaining control of the reactors did not.

title: Amazon Gives Price-Checking Shoppers a Bigger Discount
description: Price comparison apps  which allow shoppers in physical stores to quickly find out if they can get a better price online  have been called offline retailers worst nightmare. And that was before Amazon.coms newest promotion.

title: CameraBag Desktop App Is Free  for Now
description: CameraBag, the popular iPhone camera filter program (and an alternative to Hipstamatic), is going desktop.

title: In Kansas, Obama Relishes His Deep Roots
description: On a trip to his mothers home state to discuss the economy, President Obama showcased his Kansas lineage on Tuesday.

title: Heres Your Logo, Whats Your Hurry?
description: Many teams love to celebrate their history, not least of all because their fans love to buy shirts, hats and other gear emblazoned with commemorative logos. The Nets, however, are in the awkward position of trying to embrace their 35 years in New Jersey while preparing to depart for Brooklyn at the end of the season.

title: Colbert Pushes Corporations Are People Referendum
description: Ever since August, when Mitt Romney declared that corporations are people, Stephen Colbert, the host of The Colbert Report on Comedy Central, has taken a particular interest in the matter of corporate personhood, and has argued, among other things, that parents should allow their daughters to date corporations.

title: Pro-Huntsman PAC Takes Credit for Boost in New Hampshire
description: Our Destiny PAC, formed to support Jon M. Huntsmans bid for the presidency, is taking credit for helping to double the candidates poll ratings in New Hampshire since starting its advertising campaign on his behalf a couple of weeks ago.

title: Fed Lashes Out at Errors in Reporting
description: 6:27 p.m. | Updated with elaboration on Bloomberg News response.

title: The Lives They Lived: Sharing Your Photos With Us
description: For our upcoming The Lives They Lived issue, we welcome submissions of photographs that illustrate a story or moment from the life of someone close to you who passed away this year. We will run submissions on the New York Times Web site or in the issue of the magazine that comes out on Dec. 25, 2011. Please see this submissions page for more details and to upload your photograph. Thank you for sharing these stories with us.

title: Obama to Address Reform Jews
description: President Obama will speak next week to a large gathering of North American Jews, the Union of Reform Judaism announced on Tuesday.

title: The Hollywood Issue | George Clooney
description: george clooney

title: Recapping TimesOpen: Hack Day
description: Over 80 developers visited the Times Building on Saturday for TimesOpen: Hack Day. They were joined a couple dozen developers from The New York Times. The combined crowd occupied every available seat in the conference facility on the 15th floor. Practically everybody was there to program, and they all brought their coding chops and their creativity.

title: A Hiccup for a Gauge of Beijing Pollution
description: 4:23 p.m. | Updated  The air monitor was back up and running on Wednesday after what Richard Buangan, an embassy spokesman,  described on Twitter as technical difficulties that lasted for much of the day before.
