title: Limited Choices for Yahoo, Each One With Its Own Risks
description: Yahoo shareholders should brace themselves again for disappointment. While the board is seeking a deal for the company, Yahoo faces limited options  all with significant downsides and risks.

title: Save a Tree, Eat a Panettone
description: Panettone, the yeasty, lightly sweetened mound with a smattering of dried fruits, usually has a shelf life surpassed only by that of fruitcake. But here is a panettone that will be reduced to crumbs in a short time. Scarpato, a pastry company founded in Legnano, Italy, in 1888, is baking a not-so-traditional Christmas version, using organic olive oil in the dough. The result  moist, rich and aromatic  is excellent plain with a glass of sweet wine after dinner, or turned into French toast for breakfast. The olive oil comes from a company called Nudo, which supports a collection of small growers in Central Italy, and encourages the public to adopt an olive tree to help the farmers  in return for tins of oil.

title: Pairings: Poached Fruit Flamb
description: Typically smoky Islay Scotches may be a little more challenging to pair with food than something from Speyside, but as long as the food is assertive  perhaps briny, meaty, sharp, earthy, even sweet, and especially if it has a whiff of smoke to complement the drink  an Islay will fit right in. Oysters, smoked salmon or other smoked fish, mushrooms, barbecue, cheeses, steak, offal, game, roast chicken, Caesar salad, chocolate cake, the list goes on and on.

title: Vodka Thats More Eastern Parkway Than Eastern Europe
description: Its name, Brooklyn Republic Vodka, radiates the boroughs prickly pride. And though this crystalline new spirit does not begin life in Kings County, it achieves its clean aroma, bright flavor and smooth finish there. Its the work of a troika of resident Brooklyn vodka lovers: Gary Shokin, who came to New York from Lithuania some 30 years ago; his daughter Kary Laskin, born and raised in Brooklyn; and Mark Krupkin, originally from Latvia. The vodka starts in Missouri, where it is distilled from corn mixed with organic upstate New York wheat. The overproof distillate is shipped to Brooklyn Republics Clinton Hill plant, where it is brought down to 80 proof with filtered Brooklyn tap water, then filtered several more times before being sealed in handsome bottles.

title: From Scotland, Fog and Smoke and Mystery
description: TASTING whiskies can be a clinical, prosaic task, nosing and assessing, jotting notes, reconsidering, lips compressed in concentration, brow furrowed. Yet, as the spirits panel tasted 20 single malts from Islay, we reminded ourselves to step back a moment, to contemplate with no small amount of awe the magic of what was in the glass. Islay demands a sense of wonder.

title: Methods for Finding a Lost Fresco by Leonardo Lead to a Protest
description: ROME  More than 300 scholars have signed a petition to Florences mayor and that citys top art authority to stop a project that hopes to find a Leonardo da Vinci masterpiece behind a fresco by Giorgio Vasari in the Palazzo Vecchio, now city hall.

title: Touch of Evil: Cinematic Villainy From the Years Best Performers
description: A video gallery of cinematic villainy featuring the best performers from the year in film.

title: The Myths of the Bar, Debunked
description: EDUCATING the average drinker on the qualities of firewater, and how to best enjoy it, has been one of the central credos of the new generation of mixologists. Knowledge! they cry, as they throw back shots of Fernet-Branca.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: A New Name Hits the New-Music Scene
description: New York Citys new-music world is densely populated, with groups of just about every size, instrumentation and stylistic persuasion jostling for the spotlight. But there seems always to be room for more, and on Sunday evening the Ensemble Moto Perpetuo introduced itself with a short but alluring program at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music in Manhattan.

title: Verizon Is Reported to Be Planning a Streaming Service
description: On Tuesday, Reuters reported that Verizon planned to introduce a service that would let customers stream television shows and movies over the Web. The service could be introduced as early as next year, according to the report, and would offer a limited lineup of movies and television shows.

title: Sycamore Makes Takeover Bid for Talbots
description: 6:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Behind the Camera, but Still the Star
description: Once the red carpet follies were over, the war correspondent Christiane Amanpour introduced the film, calling it remarkable and courageous while warning that there was no way to sugarcoat the atrocities it portrays. The afterparty, at a nightclub high atop a hip New York hotel in the meatpacking district, complete with the usual supercilious doormen, rotating disco ball and thumping music, was co-sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations and the human rights group Women for Women International.

title: When the Country Was Attacked, and There Were No TV Updates
description: A disastrous attack catches the United States by surprise, and in the hours that follow, the president and other leaders must make major decisions hindered by communication problems and a lack of clarity as to what exactly has occurred and whether more attacks are coming. What? Someone is still commemorating the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11?

title: New Breast Cancer Test May Help Curtail Treatments
description: A new test might allow some women with the earliest phase of breast cancer to forgo the most aggressive treatment, researchers are reporting this week.

title: With Rude Names, Wine Stops Minding Its Manners
description: ITS peppery and full of fight. The tannins have grip. The nose takes no prisoners. This shiraz is a bitch.

title: Fleet Fingers Illustrating Eclectic Influences on Composers From Bach to Ligeti
description: The choice of encores reveals much about a musicians programming aesthetic. Instead of a popular bonbon, the pianist Jeremy Denk rewarded the audience at his recital at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening with a thoughtful interpretation of The Alcotts, the third movement of Ivess Concord Sonata.

title: To Artfully Capture Memories, Try These Cameras
description: CAMERA phones are terrific for documentation, capturing those spur of the moment snapshots of your pals downing sushi, your child finding a turtle in the driveway or even the damage someone did sideswiping your car. But the images you get probably are not frame quality.

title: Resisting Renaming of Miami Museum
description: MIAMI  Walking across a sun-baked construction site in his hard hat the other day, Jorge M. Prez said he was proud that this citys major art museum, whose new home is being built here beside Biscayne Bay, is now going to bear his name.

title: Netflixs Chief Sees HBO as Its Main Rival
description: As Netflix starts to stock up on original TV shows, it is identifying its biggest competitor as HBO, the premium cable channel.

title: The Roots: 2 Albums, One Quest
description: One mission isnt enough for the Roots, who have released two albums almost simultaneously. Undun (Def Jam), the Roots own 13th studio album, arrived on Tuesday, and a collaboration with the soul singer Betty Wright, Betty Wright: The Movie (Ms. B/S-Curve) came out on Nov. 15.

title: In Wake of Terror Attacks, Unlikely Bonds
description: Rachid Boucharebs tidy little two-character film, London River, demonstrates how great acting can infuse a banal, politically correct drama with dollops of emotional truth. This cozy tale of the rapprochement between two cultures, each personified by an individual, is likable in the same way as Driving Miss Daisy, though London River is tougher and sadder and not as well written.

title: New York Times Poll on Iowa Voters
description: Two-thirds of likely Iowa voters say they are remain open to changing their minds, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll said.

title: How the Iowa Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted with 642 likely Republican caucusgoers throughout Iowa from Nov. 30 to Dec. 5.

title: In Iowa, Gingrich Is Gaining Favor, New Poll Shows
description: DES MOINES  Newt Gingrich enters the final four weeks of campaigning before the Iowa caucuses with Republican voters in the state viewing him as more prepared to be president than Mitt Romney, more attuned to their concerns and just as capable of defeating President Obama, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Bus Workers Rally at City Hall
Plummeting, Surfing, Off-Roading, and Getting It All on Camera
description: VIDEO is all about capturing the moment to relive later, but some moments are not exactly camera-friendly. You may not want to have your hands on a camera with your eyes glued to an LCD screen while hurtling around a racetrack, plummeting earthward on a bungee cord or surfing a 20-footer in Maui. Especially if you want to live long enough to relive the moment.

title: Voices From the Iowa Poll
description: Jeff Zeleny reports on the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, focused on Iowa voters. In one month, the states caucuses will kick off the presidential election cycle.

title: Going the Distance to Make Craft Cocktails at Home
description: IT was while my station wagon sat stuck behind a dump truck as I inched across Westchester County trying to find a bottle of Italian chestnut honey distillate that I realized I was probably not cut out for this mixology thing. I had the passion, to be sure, even if my after-work bartending adventures only sporadically get beyond the pour-bourbon-on-top-of-ice stage. And the mission had seemed simple enough. The idea was to attempt to make a few recipes from the most buzzed-about cocktail guide in the country, The PDT Cocktail Book (Sterling Epicure; $24.95) by Jim Meehan.

title: Mix-and-Match Headphones from Fanny Wang
description: If you have ever looked at a garish pair of over-the-ear headphones and thought, I could design something better than those clown cans, heres your chance.

title: A Tech Gift for the Kitchen, and for the Bath...
description: THE gadget-obsessed spend a lot of time thinking about the living room, especially this time of year, when new devices for watching television and movies and listening to music are destined to take up prime real estate under the Christmas tree.

title: E-Ink on Your Wrist
description: E-ink, the passive displays popular on many e-readers, just found a home on your wrist.

title: Tip of the Week: Changing Outlooks Navigation Pane
description: That column full of buttons (officially known as the Navigation Pane) on the left side of the Microsoft Outlook 2007 and 2010 window makes it easy to jump around among Mail, Contacts, Calendar and the other parts of the program. You are not stuck with the default version of the Navigation Pane, though, and if you like to put the buttons in your own preferred order, you can customize it.

title: Mixing Drinks for Credit
description: IN the typical culinary classroom, students go through their paces slicing, dicing, butchering and baking. If they mix a martini it will probably be to relax after all the hard work.

title: Cans of Wine Join the Box Set
description: FIRST, winemakers poured their vintages into bottles and corked them. Then they lost the corks and added screw tops. Then they lost the bottles and sold wine in boxes, next to beer and pretzels at supermarkets. And now, winemakers seeking some pop are canning wine.

title: Putting Technology to Work for Play
description: TOYS embedded with technology are everywhere. It seems every toy can light up, talk, walk and sing, occasionally in your choice of languages. They can even sell themselves, via motion-activated displays that see you coming and respond with a commercial. This is the age of the iPad, and children have no shortage of things pulling at their limited playtime, which, lets hope, includes some time to build a snowman.

title: Smartphones Graduate to Higher Level
description: IS that certain someone on your shopping list still carrying a sad little flip phone? Are you?

title: Untether Your Music With a Wireless Stereo
description: THE digital age has made our musical lives more complex. Subscription services and online radio mean that our music is coming from many sources, and the proliferation of smartphones and tablets means that it is stored in more places than ever.

title: Gadgets to Outfit Everyone
description: TECHNOLOGY is a bit like clothing. Heres how: Hundreds of thousands of years ago, a single item of clothing (a well-tailored pelt or loincloth) would probably suffice. Clothing did one thing, provide cover.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Even Before Off Broadway Opening, Once Announces a Move to Broadway
description: Just as the musical Once was about to open at New York Theater Workshop Tuesday night, the shows commercial producers announced that it would go directly to Broadway after the Off Broadway run.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Help the Greenmarket

title: After a Break to Run Somalia, Back at His Cubicle
description: BUFFALO  At his cubicle at the State Transportation Department building here, Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed recounted what he did during a recent leave of absence. He trimmed the size of the federal government. He instituted regular paychecks for the military. He campaigned against corruption. And he avoided being shot.

title: Occupy Protesters Move Indoors to Fight Home Foreclosures
description: Participants of the Occupy Wall Street movement began a new campaign of protests against the banking system on Tuesday called Occupy Our Homes, which is focused on the liberation of vacant bank-owned homes for those in need, and the defense of families under threat of foreclosure and eviction.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Ultraslim Laptops and a Facebook Glitch
description: Interesting things that Bits reporters and editors found on the Web. More here.

title: The Hollywood Issue: Behind the Scenes
description: Home wrecker. Madman. Sociopath. Menacing dummy. Vixen. Hothead. Tyrant. Vamp. Asylum nurse. Fire starter. Invisible man. Outlaw. Tycoon.

title: Citigroup to Lay Off 4,500 Workers
description: Facing stalling growth prospects around the globe, Citigroups chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, said on Tuesday that the bank would lay off 4,500 workers in the coming months.

title: A Rogues Gallery
description: A few of the icons who inspired the photographs.

title: The 2011 Spectrum of Villainy
description: The years notable bad guys, from the absolutely evil to the morally murky.

title: Riffs: The Year in Movies
description: Michael Bays Transformers: Dark of the Moon touched off a debate in film-blogger circles: does this assaultive approach to action-film-making signal the coming annihilation of narrative logic? Or the emergence of a visual grammar thats 2 fast and 2 furious for fusty old movie grumps to understand? In a much-passed-around video essay, the critic Matthias Stork even gave this aesthetic a name: Chaos Cinema.

title: Our Own Worst Enemies
description: Earlier this year, one of the defining villains of the age met his end. A generation of children grew up frightened by his legend and haunted by the image of his face. More than just an evildoer, he seemed at times to be the embodiment of evil itself, the ruthless leader of a vast and shadowy network whose very principle was terror. His death was unsurprisingly violent, widely celebrated (with a few qualms expressed here and there) and also curiously anticlimactic. His diabolical charisma  the power of his name alone to inspire shudders of dread and revulsion  dissipated almost instantly. Life resumed its ordinary, anxious course.

title: Vamps, Crooks and Killers
description: The best performers from the year in film, recast as nefarious villains.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Mia Wasikowska
description: Mia Wasikowska as the Home Wrecker.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Michael Shannon
description: Michael Shannon as the Tycoon.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Rooney Mara
description: Rooney Mara as the Sociopath.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Kirsten Dunst
description: Kirsten Dunst as the Siren.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Brad Pitt
description: Brad Pitt as the Madman.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Viola Davis
description: Viola Davis as the Vengeful Caretaker.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Glenn Close
description: Glenn Close as the Vamp.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Jessica Chastain
description: Jessica Chastain as the Fire Starter.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Gary Oldman
description: Gary Oldman as the Menacing Dummy.

title: The Hollywood Issue | George Clooney
description: George Clooney as the Tyrant.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Ryan Gosling
description: Ryan Gosling as the Invisible Man.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Adepero Oduye
description: Adepero Oduye as the Outlaw.

title: The Hollywood Issue | Jean Dujardin
description: Jean Dujardin as the Hothead.

title: Congress, Compromise and the People
description: To the Editor:

title: TouchFire Adds a Physical Keyboard to iPad Screen
description: The iPad isnt the easiest gadget to type on. Although it comes with a large on-screen keyboard, some people find it difficult to write large amounts of text, opting instead for a physical keyboard with actual buttons.

title: When America Apologizes (or Doesnt) for Its Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: Confronting Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: A New York Map Service Saves Brokers Shoe Leather
description: Location, location, location did not become the most overused slogan in real estate without reason: a propertys surroundings are as important as the property itself. So for decades, most commercial brokerage firms have had full-time canvassers or even entire departments of agents relentlessly pacing city blocks to keep up-to-date maps of fast-changing storefront businesses.

title: N.B.A. Schedule a Cram Course for Teams
description: An N.B.A. schedule unlike any other  short, compressed, frantic, unwieldy in some spots and incomplete in others  was finally unveiled Tuesday night. It may be greeted with as much angst as excitement.

title: Presidential Aging Doesnt Cut Life Short
description: Even when a study calculated presidential life expectancy by subtracting two days of life for every day in office, it found that presidents who died of natural causes lived longer than predicted.

title: The Defense Department in Their Midst
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  On a recent Friday afternoon, employees trickled out of two new office buildings here; some waited at bus stops, while others retrieved cars from a sprawling above-ground garage. Traffic leaving the office complex and turning onto public streets was light.

title: Virginia: Man Jailed for 27 Years Is Exonerated
description: The Virginia Court of Appeals on Tuesday exonerated a man convicted in a series of sexual assaults in 1984. DNA evidence showed that the man,  Thomas Haynesworth, could not have committed the crimes in which such evidence had been preserved, and it pointed to another man. Gov. Bob McDonnell released Mr. Haynesworth on parole in March, but Mr. Haynesworth petitioned for full exoneration. Prosecutors in the counties where the assaults occurred supported his effort, as did the commonwealths attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli. The Court of Appeals initially heard the appeal and then asked for further briefs. Shawn Armbrust, executive director of the Mid-Atlantic Innocence Project, said, After serving nearly 27 years for crimes that he didnt commit, Mr. Haynesworth has had to register as a sex offender and abide by degrading conditions while the Court of Appeals took nearly nine months to conclude that the attorney general and the prosecutors were right that Mr. Haynesworth didnt commit these crimes.

title: Canceling Stay, U.S. Orders 72 Indonesians in New Jersey to Leave
description: Two years ago, a community of Indonesians in central New Jersey was spared deportation after a Protestant pastor brokered an unusual agreement with immigration authorities that allowed them to stay in the country temporarily. The agreement was clear: The Indonesians would be able to stay and work, but the permission could be rescinded at any moment.

title: U.S. and South Korea Renew Talks on Nuclear Technology
description: SEOUL, South Korea  United States and South Korean negotiators on Tuesday resumed their low-key but highly sensitive talks on whether South Korea should be allowed to do what Washington has tried to stop North Korea from doing: enrich uranium and reprocess spent nuclear fuel.

title: Chinas Allure in Drug Research
description: Drug research tends to follow spending. Take Mercks pledge on Tuesday to invest $1.5 billion in research and development in China over five years. Citizens of emerging economies are growing wealthier and living longer, while the fiscal health of their governments is robust. Mercks step suggests that the pharmaceutical industrys center of gravity is shifting eastward accordingly.

title: A Reluctant Enemy
description: San Francisco

title: Ohio: Charges Planned in Craigslist Killings
description: Prosecutors in Akron will file charges accusing Richard Beasley, 52, of the murders of three men who were lured to their deaths through a fake Craigslist advertisement, a spokeswoman for Sherri Bevan Walsh, the Summit County prosecutor, said on Tuesday, adding that Ms. Walsh would seek the death penalty. Mr. Beasley, who was arrested this month on other charges and is being held without bail, will also be charged with the attempted murder of Scott Davis, 48, of South Carolina, who responded to the advertisement but escaped after being shot in the arm. The Craigslist advertisement offered $300 a week, a trailer to live in and a stocked fishing pond for someone who would serve as a caretaker on a farm near Caldwell, in Noble County. Brogan Rafferty, 16, was also charged this month in connection with the murders. A Noble County judge will decide next week whether Mr. Rafferty will be tried as an adult.

title: F.A.A. Chief Leaves Job After Arrest
description: WASHINGTON  The chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, J. Randolph Babbitt, resigned on Tuesday after being arrested and accused of drunken driving over the weekend. Aviation experts said he was unlikely to be permanently replaced soon, raising concerns about the agencys progress in modernizing air traffic control, maintaining vigilance on safety and completing a recent reorganization.

title: Egypt, the Beginning or the End?
description: The fact that the Muslim Brotherhood and the even more fundamentalist Salafist Nour Party have garnered some 65 percent of the votes in the first round of Egypts free parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak should hardly come as a surprise. Given the way that the military regimes in the Arab world decimated all independent secular political parties over the last 50 years, there is little chance of any Arab country going from Mubarak to Jefferson without going through some Khomeini.

title: The Wisdom of George McGovern
description: George McGoverns impact on food policy could have been greater, but not through more effort on his part. The 1972 presidential candidate, now 89, was a bomber pilot at the end of World War II when the decision was made to distribute remaining medicine and food to Europeans before heading home. We were feeding our former enemies two days after bombing them, he told me over breakfast last week, two days before falling and being hospitalized. It was an unprecedented gesture of good will.

title: Remembering Scrates, Who Made the Game Beautiful
description: Scrates is dead, at 57. He taught me to love an entire sport, and that is no small thing.

title: Council Hears Transit Plans for a Blizzard
description: For the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, an A train in the Rockaways, stranded for hours during the blizzard last December, became an enduring example of the agencys bungled response to the storm.

title: Remembering Pearl Harbor
description: It was only a few days after the attack in December 1941 that the phrase Remember Pearl Harbor first appeared in The New York Times. It took barely a week for Hollywood to register it as a movie title. Today that film is justly forgotten. The phrase lives on, and 70 years have not dimmed the meaning and memory of that day.

title: The Wrong Fix
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France issued an ultimatum on Monday demanding that all 17 nations using the euro agree to a change in European treaties that would force them to move toward balanced budgets or face sanctions.

title: Cardinals Hold on Pujols Put to Test
description: DALLAS

title: For Family on the Mend, a Dinette to Gather Around
description: When the new dinette set and the chest of drawers arrived in October at Desire Baezs apartment, she took photographs and showed them to friends as if they were snapshots of her newborn children.

title: Online Insults Lead to Calls for Inquiries of N.Y.C. Police
description: Politicians and officials criticized the New York Police Department on Tuesday and called for investigations after the release of comments on Facebook in which users claiming to be officers heaped scorn on revelers at the annual West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn. But, despite repeated requests, one person refused to comment: the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

title: Scenes: Leo Friedman
description: A look back at the career of the photographer Leo Friedman.

title: Caught Out of Time
description: One hundred and fifty years after the Civil War, historians have the benefit of a perspective not accessible in earlier remembrances. One interesting angle is to look at older histories of the war, tracing its place in our national consciousness and rediscovering details that take on new relevance today.

title: Celebrated in Asia, Little Known in America
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  It is the all-American girls study as conceived by a Hollywood set director. In addition to her growing collection of trophies, Yani Tseng has displayed two dozen Starbucks mugs from all over the world, an ad for a local pizzeria and a plush Angry Bird scowling from a loving cup. Only the 8 -by-11 certificate noting Tsengs completion of a Level 4 English class hints at her deepest roots.

title: Whimsical Texting Icons Get a Shot at Success
description: Say you wanted to invite a friend to happy hour. You could send a simple text message, but that would be boring. Instead, why not send a cartoony picture of two clinking beer mugs?

title: Amazon Publishing Push Grows to Childrens Books
description: Amazon expanded its publishing ambitions on Tuesday by acquiring more than 450 titles from Marshall Cavendish Childrens Books, a niche publisher.

title: Republican Candidates Aim at Obama Foreign Policy
description: A small but revealing episode unfolded in the closing minutes of the last Republican presidential debate. After the candidates were asked to name the national security issue they most worry about, which had not yet been discussed, Rick Santorum cited radical Islamists in Central and South America.

title: Leo Friedman, Photographer of Broadways Glamour Years, Dies at 92
description: Leo Friedman, whose photograph of an ebullient Carol Lawrence and Larry Kert as lovebirds chasing down a Manhattan street became the enduring emblem of the musical West Side Story and the signature image of a career spent taking pictures of actors in action, died on Friday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 92.

title: After a Son Is Killed, Facing a Police Runaround
description: The Lefevres  mother, father and one of their surviving sons  took the first flight to New York, spent the night with a friend, and the next morning went directly to the city morgue on Winthrop Street in Brooklyn. The second of the Lefevre sons, Mathieu, 30, had been run over by a truck two days earlier, just after midnight on Oct. 19, while he was biking home to Williamsburg. The truck did not stop.

title: Lottery Numbers
G.O.P. Leadership Job Is Contested
description: The fifth-ranking leadership position for Congressional Republicans is up for grabs, setting the stage for a battle between two freshmen senators. Senator Roy D. Blunt of Missouri announced on Tuesday that he would compete against Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin for the job of vice chairman of the Senate Republican Conference.

title: Congress Discusses Enacting Stricter Insider-Trading Laws
description: Democrats and Republicans on the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday advocated new restrictions on insider trading to help lift waning public trust in Congress.

title: Johnson Becomes Face, and So Much More, of Bid for the Dodgers
description: For a moment, imagine Magic Johnson, the symbol of Showtime, as a part-owner and the public face of the Los Angeles Dodgers. He stands outside Dodger Stadium greeting fans numbed by the Frank McCourt era. He sits by the Dodgers dugout listening to fans telling him how to improve the team.

title: Albanys Tax Deal
description: Less than a month before New Yorks so-called millionaires tax is set to expire, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has managed to convince Republican legislators to agree to a new, supposedly fairer tax structure. It is expected to bring in about $2 billion in new revenue  or about half of the $4 billion that would have come from extending the income tax surcharge for New Yorks wealthier residents.

title: Study Raises Concerns About a Faster Radiation Therapy for Breast Cancer
description: A faster form of radiation therapy that is becoming increasingly popular for women with early-stage breast cancer may not be as effective and safe as conventional radiation treatment, according to a study being presented on Wednesday.

title: Good, Old Times for Valentine and Ventura
description: He was later fined $5,000 and suspended two games for doing so.

title: Filibuster by Senate Republicans Blocks Confirmation of Judicial Nominee
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Tuesday blocked confirmation of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to be a federal appeals court judge, raising the question of whether a political deal to prevent the filibuster of most judicial nominations has broken down.

title: Iowa Poll: The Candidates and the Issues
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll poll found that Newt Gingrich is rated more favorably than the other candidates among voters who say they are likely to attend the Republican caucuses in Iowa, but two-thirds remain open to changing their minds.

title: Safety Nets for Freelancers
description: This is a follow-up to Fridays column, Health Care for a Changing Work Force.

title: At Top Public Schools, the Arts Replace Recess
description: In the art room at P.S. 188 in Bayside, Queens, a group of 9-year-olds was busily putting the finishing touches on an enormous poster for the fourth-grade play. Its topic: saving the Earth. Down the hall in the music room, beneath portraits of Mozart and Bach, classmates were breaking into a spirited rendition of Hear Those Bells on fluorescent-colored recorders. Cheerleaders in the gym were perfecting a victory chant, jumping, twisting and stamping their feet. And in the library, children in a Suzuki violin class were toiling away at Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star, while their music teacher, a professional violist from Iceland, coached them to stand straight and tall.

title: Bettman: Fans Like the Level of Physicality
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The N.H.L. board of directors met for three and a half hours Tuesday and never broached the subject of fighting, Commissioner Gary Bettman said. Fighting is an aspect of the game that has come under scrutiny by others in the wake of the recent deaths of three of the games enforcers.

title: A Moment in the Sun for Television
description: THIS week, about 2,000 people are attending an annual event known as the UBS global media and communications conference. Based on the presentations so far, perhaps it ought to be renamed the global television and video festival.

title: Greenpeace Leader Visits Boardroom, Without Forsaking Social Activism
description: DURBAN, South Africa  The bearded South African in the blood-red dashiki took a seat in the front row amid a sea of dark-suited executives on Monday morning at a side meeting of the United Nations climate change  conference here.

title: Obama in Osawatomie
description: After months of Republican candidates offering a cascade of bad ideas about the economy, President Obamas speech in Osawatomie, Kan., Tuesday came as a relief. He made it clear that he was finally prepared to contest the election on the issues of income inequality and the obligation of both government and the private sector to enlarge the nations shrinking middle class.

title: Judge Chides Defense in Officials Trial
description: The jury in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook was sent home on Tuesday evening after deliberating for a third full day without reaching a verdict.

title: Dip in Consumer Spending Slows Growth in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils kinetic economy sputtered in the third quarter, officials announced Tuesday, ending a long stretch of growth and pointing to some of the headwinds now facing Brazil and big economies in Asia, notably India and China.

title: Mets Deal Pagan Away and Overhaul Bullpen
description: DALLAS  Swiftly and significantly, the Mets altered their roster Tuesday night, adding three right-handed relievers and a center fielder within a couple of hours.

title: Wednesday: Lose Ones Marbles
description: Administrivial Avatar Alert!  The ability to upload a photo to your Times account has been fixed. Please powder your noses, take a snapshot of yourself, and upload it by going to the upper-right-hand corner of this page. Notice that your screen name now features a drop-down menu. Click that drop-down arrow, go to My Profile, click on Edit My Profile, and you will see a box where you can upload a photo that is no larger than 5 cruciliters, or megaspleens, or something like that. At any rate, you can upload a photo now.

title: A Love Affair With Music, Maybe With Each Other
description: Charm is fragile. Whats enchanting in one context, subjected to stress, exaggeration or self-consciousness, can seem soppy or strident in another.

title: Pearl Harbor Still a Day for the Ages, but a Memory Almost Gone
description: HONOLULU  For more than half a century, members of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association gathered here every Dec. 7 to commemorate the attack by the Japanese that drew the United States into World War II. Others stayed closer to home for more intimate regional chapter ceremonies, sharing memories of a day they still remember in searing detail.

title: Silence Is Golden
description: WASHINGTON

title: Sectarian Violence Worsens in Homs
description: In one of the worst episodes of sectarian violence in Syria since the uprising began nine months ago, dozens of corpses were recovered from the streets of Homs this week.

title: Its Official: 3 Asset Managers Will Share Huge Jackpot
description: A lottery drama may be coming to a close.

title: Gathering to Remember for the Last Time
description: For the members of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association, the 70th Anniversary of the World War II attack will be their last gathering. The New York Times has documented final commemorations by other survivors of tragic events.

title: Working Out the Final Details in an Effort to Reopen on Friday
description: The final chaotic days of a chaotic N.B.A. off-season are winding down, with the league pushing to reopen business Friday after a flurry of last-minute negotiations and formalities.

title: Yankees Still Searching for Rotation Help
description: DALLAS  Joe Girardi joined the Yankees staff at the winter meetings Tuesday, and he did not sound any more optimistic than his general manager about obtaining a top-end starter to slot in behind C.C. Sabathia in the rotation.

title: Paul Doty, Biochemist and Arms Control Advocate, Dies at 91
description: Paul Doty, a biochemist who furthered understanding of the chemical secrets of heredity, then became a leader in bringing Soviet and American scientists together to try to control nuclear arms, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91.

title: Basketball Power Takes Football Title
description: Brooklyn football was in the House That Steinbrenner Built on Tuesday evening.

title: Proposed Changes to State Income Tax Rates
description: Legislative leaders announced an agreement on Tuesday to raise taxes on New York States wealthiest residents.

title: Knicks Schedule: Making Up for Lost Time
description: The Knicks 66-game schedule for the 2011-12 lockout shortened season has them playing four games in five nights on four occasions.

title: Merkels Path: Brinkmanship for Debt Crisis
description: BERLIN  When the ratings agency Standard & Poors warned this week that it might lower the credit ratings of 15 euro zone countries, including Germany, Chancellor Angela Merkel seemed unmoved. What a rating agency does is the responsibility of the rating agency, she told reporters in Berlin on Tuesday.

title: How to Help the Post Office
At the Garden, the Guest List Looks a Bit Incomplete
description: Carmelo Anthony will not return to Denver for a visit this season. Nor will Amare Stoudemire go back to his old home in Phoenix.

title: Pakistan: President Travels to Dubai for Medical Tests
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An unexpected announcement that President Asif Ali Zardari has left Pakistan for a medical checkup in Dubai caused a swirl of wild rumors on Wednesday about his hold on power.

title: Admissible Evidence, or a Backdoor Ploy? Justices Ask
description: WASHINGTON  The lawyers were listless and the justices lively at a Supreme Court argument on Tuesday on how prosecutors may use crime laboratory reports at a trial.

title: Big East Is Poised to Add Five Teams for Football
description: The Big East will expand in 2013 to include Boise State and San Diego State as football-only members and Houston, Southern Methodist and Central Florida in all sports, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: City Champs
description: The Railsplitters of Lincoln High School used their smothering defense to shut down Erasmus Hall in the second half.

title: Romney Tells Trump He Cant Make Debate
description: Mitt Romney said Tuesday that he would not take part in a debate moderated by Donald J. Trump, casting doubt on whether other candidates would take part.

title: The Tempting of the Christian Right
description: More than any other Republican constituency, religious conservatives have good reasons to be wary of Newt Gingrich. As the leader of a right-wing insurgency in the early 1990s, he often kept their causes at arms length  deliberately excluding issues like abortion and school prayer from the Contract With America, for instance. As Speaker of the House, he undercut their claim to the moral high ground by carrying on an extramarital affair even as his party was impeaching Bill Clinton for lying under oath about adultery.

title: Flipboard Introduces an iPhone App for Killing Time Standing in Line
description: Updated 3:50 p.m.: Added information about Flipboards service problems on Wednesday, which delayed access to the iPhone app for new users.

title: Champions League Wednesday Preview: In Manchester, Nail-Biting Time in Red and Blue
description: On Matchday 6, four teams are playing only for bonus money and four teams are playing for precious spots in the group stage.

title: Big Firms Limit Paying State Taxes, Study Finds
description: As states have struggled to balance their budgets by cutting services, laying off workers and raising taxes, a study to be released on Wednesday suggests that many profitable Fortune 500 companies have not been paying as much in state corporate income taxes as the average levied on American companies, with some big firms paying none at all in recent years.

title: Criminal Justice Expert Named to Lead Soros Foundations
description: George Soros, the billionaire investor, on Wednesday named Christopher Stone, a well-known expert on criminal justice, the new leader of his unconventional philanthropic empire.

title: J.C. Penney to Buy Stake in Martha Stewart Living
description: 4:01 p.m. | Updated J.C. Penney confirmed on Wednesday that it would buy a 16.6 percent stake in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, drawing the two companies closer together in an effort to lift their sagging fortunes.

title: A New Worry for Soccer Parents: Heading the Ball
description: What happens inside the skull of a soccer player who repeatedly heads a soccer ball? That question motivated a provocative new study of the brains of experienced players that has prompted discussion and debate in the soccer community, and some anxiety among those of us with soccer-playing offspring.

title: Word of the Day | glacial
description: glacial \gla-shl\ adjective

title: New Details in Dodgers Sale
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers asked a federal bankruptcy court judge Tuesday to approve the agreement to sell the team reached last month with Major League Baseball.

title: Homeless In Delhi, Victims Of Gender Disparity
description: Invisible Among the Uncounted, Nilanjana S. Roy writes about the plight of homeless women in Delhi, a city of sixteen million people.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/07/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/07/2011

title: Indian Network in Silicon Valley Backs Start-Ups
description: In 1992, a handful of immigrant engineers from the Indian subcontinent who lived in the Bay Area formed a group called the Indus Entrepreneurs  or TiE  with what now seems like a quaint mission: to inspire one another to establish their own technology start-ups and cash in on the Silicon Valley dream.

title: Corrections: December 7
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: News Quiz | Dec. 7, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Rock Hall Welcomes Guns N Roses, Red Hot Chili Peppers and the Beastie Boys
description: Three American groups that helped to shape pop music in the 1980s and early 90s  Guns N Roses, Red Hot Chili Peppers and the Beastie Boys  will be inducted into The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in the spring, the Hall was to announce Wednesday.

title: Varanasi Found
description: I had been living in India for more than two years when a visiting friend wanted to see Varanasi. I had never been, but I had seen hundreds of pictures of it. There are the famous bathing ghats, where thousands of people daily take their purifying dips into the Ganges, or attend to more quotidian tasks, like brushing teeth, shampooing hair and washing clothes.

title: Avowing Innocence, Israeli Ex-President Enters Prison
description: KIRYAT MALACHI, Israel  A day after Moshe Katsav, Israels former president, turned 66, his modest home in this immigrant town was filled on Tuesday with grandchildren and well-wishers. Phones rang. Neighbors with sun-creased faces offered hugs. Rabbis in tall hats gave their blessings.

title: Dec. 7, 1941 | Japan Attacks Pearl Harbor
description: On Dec. 7, 1941, Japanese warplanes attacked the home base of the American Pacific fleet at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii, drawing the United States into World War II. More than 2,300 Americans were killed.

title: Found: Biggest Black Holes Ever
description: WHO did not believe in the existence of black holes?

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 7, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article Learning to Play the Game to Get Into College.

title: Chilling Impact of Indias April Internet Rules
description: Kapil Sibals demand that Internet companies self-censor users content is just the latest move by the Indian government to restrict information on Facebook and other social media Web sites.

title: Rare Attacks on Shiites Kill Scores in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Pakistan-based extremist group claimed responsibility for a series of coordinated bombings aimed at Afghan Shiites on Tuesday, in what many feared was an attempt to further destabilize Afghanistan by adding a new dimension of strife to a country that, though battered by a decade of war, has been free of sectarian conflict.

title: The Wild West of Finance
description: Human beings, at heart, are wild animals in love with the thrill of the hunt. I can prove it merely by pointing to the existence of the exchange-traded fund FAZ, which one friend calls day traders crack. For most of us, the stock market has been moving far too much, far too quickly. For those who buy FAZ, though, that speed is not fast enough.

title: Syria, Under Siege Inside and Out, Does Not Budge
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  During his most recent news conference, Foreign Minister Walid al-Moallem interrupted the flow of questions by waving a small white piece of paper indicating that he had important news.

title: Whats Next for Computing?
description: The Science Times section is looking back to innovations in computing, as well as into the future, and they are asking Times readers to look into their proverbial crystal balls, too. What lies ahead for computing? What predictions and hopes do you have for what computers will be able to do in the future?

title: British Police Arrest Man in Scandal Over Hacking
description: LONDON  A 41-year-old man arrested Wednesday in connection with the phone hacking scandal that has rocked Rupert Murdochs media empire was identified in British news reports as Glenn Mulcaire, the private detective at the scandals center.

title: Industry Group Sees Tough Year for Weakened Airlines
description: A collapse of the euro could suppress growth in global air traffic next year and push airlines into a collective loss of more than $8 billion, an industry group said Wednesday.

title: In Paris, Celebrating London on the Big Screen
description: New York, with its glittery skyline, yellow cabs and steaming potholes, and Paris, with its cafe-lined streets, Eiffel Tower, and winding Seine, have been the objects of rapturous attention from filmmakers all over the world. If London  sprawling, grey and less predisposed to visual clichs  has not been fetishized on the big screen in the same way, it has nonetheless provided a vibrant setting for movies spanning virtually every mood, genre and style.

title: Species Protection and Technology
description: Advances in genetics may change aspects of environmental policy in the future.

title: The Early Word: Populist
description: Todays Times

title: India Suspends Plan to Let in Foreign Retailers
description: NEW DELHI  Facing a harsh political reaction that has paralyzed the Indian Parliament, the governing Congress Party announced on Wednesday that it would suspend plans to allow foreign multibrand retailers like Wal-Mart to open stores in India.

title: Mine Attack Kills 19 Civilians in Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Nineteen civilians, some of them women and children, were killed on Wednesday by a mine planted on a highway in southwestern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said.

title: Maybin and Rodgers: The Accidental Aarons of the N.F.L.
description: As Chase Stuart wrote on Tuesday, we think we know more than we actually doduring an N.F.L. season.

title: This Christmas, Atheists Billboard Tries a Softer Tack
description: Nearly $40,000 was spent during the last Christmas season on a billboard war between atheists and Roman Catholics at the New Jersey entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel. But so far, this years version of the atheist billboard has failed to generate much of a fight.

title: Why I Swore Off Debt (for a While)
description: Breakups are never pretty. It was September 2008, and the economy, the stock market, real estate, and my business were all crashing (as did many businesses). Like an engineer figuring out how much oxygen is left in a mine tunnel after a collapse, I turned quickly to cash analysis.

title: U.S. and China Meet in Annual Military Review
description: BEIJING  Top American and Chinese military officials began an annual review of major issues here on Wednesday pledging to seek greater cooperation and trust in a relationship that, to many, more resembles a budding rivalry.

title: Pakistanis Taking to the Streets
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Its an unusual sight for a Sunday morning: a dozen Karachiites armed with brooms, rakes, sand and rubble crouch along a road on which none of them live or work in order to mend a large, sewage-filled pothole. The workers come in all shapes and sizes: a man in his 80s uses his walking stick to knock large rocks out of the way; a boy of 12 watches for traffic and waves passing cars to the side of the street. They are members of the Greener Karachi Trust, a volunteer group committed to showing its fellow Karachi dwellers that they neednt wait for the government to repair the citys crumbling infrastructure.

title: A Wish List for Cooks, Bug Lovers and the Well-Shod
description: On Tuesday, we offered several ideas for inspirational green gifts for gastronomes, cyclists, spa rats and others. For those still seeking the perfect holiday present for that environmentally minded someone, here are more suggestions for a range of ages and interest groups.

title: Romney Losing Among Fox News Viewers
description: If there were a Fox News primary, Mitt Romney would be losing it.

title: Forecasting Playoff Chances for Giants and Jets
description: According to the playoff race simulations at NFL-Forecast.com, the Giants have a 36.3 chance of making the playoffs, and the Jets a 29.6 percent chance.

title: Obsession, Reignited
description: IN anticipation of the movie version of Stieg Larssons Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, which stars Daniel Craig and Rooney Mara and opens Dec. 21, Knopf has printed two different tie-in editions of the original novel, more than a million copies all told.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 7
description: One of the takeaways from the annual UBS global media and communications conference in Midtown Manhattan, Stuart Elliott and Amy Chozick report, is the primacy of video content regardless of the type of screen on which it is watched. Based on the talks there, marketers remain keen on buying commercial time during video programming despite the uncertain outlook for the economy. Spending on TV ads around the world next year will increase 6.7 percent from 2011, said one forecaster, Vincent Ltang, as compared with a predicted overall 5 percent increase in advertising. (Online ads will have the greatest growth, he predicted, 11.2 percent.)

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: In Rare Interview, Assad Denies Ordering Crackdown in Syria
description: PARIS  A defiant President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, speaking in a rare television interview broadcast on Wednesday, denied ordering the bloody crackdown that has convulsed his land for the past nine months and disputed a United Nations estimate that 4,000 people had been killed as protesters took to the streets of cities across his land demanding that he step down.

title: I Was a Suburban Mixologist
description: Back in his college years in Wisconsin, Jim Meehan would find himself working at a bar and wondering about the odd bottles that kept gathering dust on the back shelves.

title: David Finchers Embargo Solution
description: Dragon Tattoo-gate (Denby-Rudin-gate? Rudin-Denby-gate? Ruby-gate?) continues to roll along. In an interview with The Miami Herald, David Fincher, the director of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, weighed in on the controversy involving David Denby, a film critic for The New Yorker, positively reviewing his movie before he was supposed to, defying an embargo hed agreed to  in writing, apparently  and angering the studio, Sony, and the producer Scott Rudin in the process. (There: just saved you having to click a link to get the back story.)

title: Santander to Sell Colombian Unit for $1.23 Billion
description: Grupo Santander, seeking to bolster its capital reserves, announced on Wednesday that it would sell its Colombian unit to CorpBanca of Chile for $1.225 billion.

title: Wednesday Reading: Campaign Against Co-Sleeping Sparks Controversy
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Its My Birthday! (Said With Hand Outstretched)
description: Its your birthday, so how do you celebrate? Maybe you gather a few close friends. Or you go out for a quiet dinner with your spouse or partner or significant other or lover or whatever term suits your situation and temperament. Or perhaps  it happens  the passage of time has you down, and you just want to be alone.

title: Opinion Report: European Austerity
description: From the editorial page

title: When It Comes to the Greats, Who Do You Remember?
description: Sport endures on first impressions. We all remember the first time we walked into a stadium and saw the green grass. Saw Walter Payton or Barry Sanders break into the clear. Saw Evert and Navratilova pick up where they had left off in the last tournament. Saw Wayne Gretzky slip between two defenders.

title: Callers Take Issue With Mayor's Teacher Comments
Recess Has Some New Competition
Plastic Fantastic
description: In this photograph and stop-motion video, the French-born artist Damien Florbert Cuypers translates his longtime fascination with Legos into a quirky version of our trademark logo. Cuypers, who splits his time between Lyon, Berlin and New York, is refreshingly down-to-earth about working with the toys. You can end up with some dramatic color/shape structure, he says. Or a stupid-looking bunch of bricks.

title: Gingrich and the Christian Right
description: My column for Campaign Stops this week argues that religious conservatives should think twice about their flirtation with Newt Gingrich:

title: Dollar-Loan Demand Swells In Europe After Rate Cut
description: The European Central Bank said demand for three-month dollar loans surged after it cut the cost of the financing almost in half in a coordinated action last week with five other central banks including the Federal Reserve.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Post: An entertaining roundup of high-end restaurants in Hong Kong, including the first Michelin three-star in China.  Julia Moskin

title: They Have Made A Desert, And Called It Adjustment
description: It continues to be a source of amazement to see what passes for a success story among austerity advocates. Ireland is proclaimed a huge success despite 14 percent unemployment and a very slow recovery in incomes. And then theres Latvia.

title: A Devil of a Time to Root for the Mets
description: Based on five decades of field research, Ive reached this careful conclusion: Joan Payson, the original owner of my beloved Mets, probably did something really nasty with the devil atop the dugout at the old Shea Stadium.

title: Daily Report: Holiday Gadgets
description: The most important period for consumer electronics is, of course, the holiday shopping season. For anyone wanting to understand how the industry is doing in the here and now, there is no better place to study than a holiday buying guide.

title: BBC Adds More Hours and More Characters to The Hour
description: The British love their period pieces and meta-media dramas as much as Americans, it appears. The BBC has ordered a sequel to The Hour, its hit mini-series about the competitive world of 1950s British television journalism, which will add new cast members and which BBC America will co-produce and broadcast in the United States, that cable channel said on Wednesday.

title: China Clears Nestles Deal for Candy Maker
description: Chinese regulators have approved Nestls $1.7 billion acquisition of a 60 percent stake in the confectioner Hsu Fu Chi International, in a sign that Beijing may be warming to large cross-border transactions.

title: Taylor Rules
description: Via Mark Thoma, Noah Smith reports on a conference held at Hoover in which right-wing economists reached right-wing conclusions. Surprise!

title: Last Nights Event
description: Thanks to a commenter who found the video here. I dont know if this is official or sanctioned, although it looks like it; I also dont know why the Times tech people didnt alert me. But anyway, it seems that those who missed the discussion can watch it via that link.

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: Will the Lions make the playoffs? Houston? Just how good (or bad) are the Falcons? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

title: Despite Economic Slump, Europe Gets More Tech Start-Ups
description: While Europe as a whole continues to suffer major economic troubles with slow fiscal growth and abnormally high unemployment rates, one industry continues to grow steadily: tech.

title: Vain Glorious | Dolces Velvet Hour
description: What: Velvet, Dolce & Gabbanas new fragrance collection.

title: New Yorks Math Scores Dip on U.S. Student Tests, Diverging From Trend in Other Big Cities
description: New York City students scored slightly lower on federal math tests this year compared with two years ago, according to results released on Wednesday, even as test scores of their counterparts in other big cities inched upward.

title: MythBusters Turns Into House Buster With Wayward Cannonball
description: A MythBusters stunt went awry on Tuesday, leaving cannonball-shaped holes in the wall of a home and in the window of a minivan in Dublin, Calif. Or, as the local sheriffs department spokesman put it, The cannonball took a few unfortunate bounces.

title: Have Yourself a Retro Little Christmas
description: This is a season for nostalgia  and also for picture books that can and should mean more than just  Twas the night before Christmas. Three splendid reissues of Christmas tales from the 1950s, 60s and 70s offer old-timey takes on the evergreen theme of All I want for Christmas is . . . .

title: Gorbachev Calls for New Vote in Disputed Russian Elections
description: MOSCOW  Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, added his voice to a nascent anti-Kremlin protest movement on Wednesday, calling for the results of increasingly disputed parliamentary elections last weekend to be scrapped.

title: A Deer and a Minivan: A Holiday Travel Story
description: 2:20 p.m. Updated to add details about insurance coverage.

title: Mets Fans Can Tolerate Pain, but This Much?
description: On City Room, Michael Powell wonders if the Mets once made a deal with Mephistopheles. Just one reason for that question: We have professional hitters who bang their heads and forget how to hit  see Church, Ryan, and Bay, Jason. Read more at City Room.

title: Goodbye to Quail, for Now
description: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

title: Crowds at Hller Exhibition Force Price Increase
description: Participatory art, as it turns out, is not all fun and games. The New Museum, whose exhibition of the work of the Belgian-born artist Carsten Hller has been packing in crowds since it opened last month, has raised its general admission price to $16, from $12. The higher price will help it pay for the extra staff needed to shepherd museumgoers through Mr. Hllers carnival-like pieces, which take up all the museums floors: goggles that turn the world upside down; a three-story tubular slide; and a heavily salinated sensory deprivation tank (complete with a shower and hooks for the clothes of those who decide to undress and get in for a float).

title: Former Marvell Employee Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
description: 2:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Q&A: Controlling iTunes Remotely
description: Q.

title: How Dangerous Is Heading a Soccer Ball?
description: Soccer parents, watching their children use their head to send the ball rocketing in an age of increased worry about the long-term effects of minor sports concussions, have been arguing for years about the practice. On the Well blog, Gretchen Reynolds reports on new research showing frontal lobe damage and weaker verbal and visual recall among players who had headed a ball more than a thousand times in the last year, even those who reported no concussion, and among college players who were frequent headers in a Division 2 program.

title: A Business Ponders Whether Its Location Is Perfect, or a Disaster
description: Pulling Down the Moon provides services like yoga classes, acupuncture, massage therapy and nutritional counseling to women undergoing fertility treatments. Based in Chicago, with satellite locations in Arlington Heights, Ill., and Rockville, Md., the nine-year-old company has grown to 35 employees with $1.3 million in annual revenue.

title: Gangster in Italy Arrested After 16-Year Manhunt
description: The Italian police on Wednesday arrested a powerful leader of a criminal group based outside Naples, dealing the group, known as the Camorra, one of its most powerful blows in years.

title: The French Flock to a Feel-Good Movie
description: PARIS  When it was released last month, Intouchables seemed an unremarkable, lowbrow French comedy, a small-budget film with actors little known outside France hamming it up in a story about a stodgy, disabled aristocrat and the good-humored ex-con whom he hires as his aide.

title: On Climate Change, a Gloat and a Warning
description: DURBAN, South Africa  If anyone at the United Nations climate change conference here wondered why the United States is unwilling or unable to take decisive action on the warming of the planet, they could tune in to the Web site of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee on Wednesday morning.

title: Harry Morgan, Colonel Potter on M*A*S*H, Dies at 96
description: Harry Morgan, the prolific character actor best known for playing the acerbic but kindly Colonel Potter in the long-running television series M*A*S*H, died on Wednesday morning at his home in Los Angeles. He was 96.

title: Is It Worth Risking Disaster for the Perfect Location?
description: We just published a case study that describes the dilemma faced by Pulling Down the Moon, a Chicago business that was hit by not one but two floods in just less than a year. Tamara Quinn and Beth Heller, co-owners of the company, a provider of supplemental holistic services like yoga, acupuncture, and massage therapy to women undergoing fertility treatments, chose to facilitate referrals by subleasing first-floor space just down the hall from one of the countrys biggest fertility clinics.

title: Lousy Filibusters: Caitlin Halligan Edition
description: Fifty-four Senators voted yesterday to confirm the nomination of an experienced and accomplished lawyer, Caitlin Halligan, to the D.C. Circuit, which in the twisted and blindly ideological world of the United States Senate means she didnt get confirmed.

title: Share Your Stories of Sleep on the Subway
description: Have you slept through your stop only to awaken at the end of the line? New Lots Avenue or 179th Street Jamaica, perhaps? Or do you shudder at the thought of R.E.M. on the IND, for fear of lush workers?

title: To Sleep on the Subway, Maybe, but to Dream? Poor Chance
description: A ride on the New York subway can be a sensory overload: musicians perform for change; conductors plead to those who hold open train doors to relent; and passengers, often in unimaginably close proximity, subject one another to all sorts of sights, sounds, smells and touches, preferably inadvertent.

title: Apple Readies New Store in Grand Central
description: Apple unveiled its newest store on Wednesday, one that looks out over the main hub and busy concourse of the historic Grand Central Terminal in New York.

title: Iran Blocks American Virtual Embassy
description: Not even the virtual embassies are safe in Iran.

title: After Six Months as Anchor, Pelley Is Still Taking In the View
description: Tuesday marked six months for Scott Pelley as anchor of the CBS Evening News, the nightly newscast he inherited from Katie Couric.

title: This Democrat Prefers Gingrich
description: The Democrat responsible for helping the party retake control of the House next year said on Wednesday that he would rather have Newt Gingrich at the top of the Republican ticket.

title: Iowa and New Hampshire Stand Apart
description: With much of the political field focused on the testing grounds of Iowa and New Hampshire, its easy to forget that these two early states  in economic and demographic makeup  are markedly different from much of the rest of the country.

title: Below the Line: The World-Ending Sounds of Melancholia
description: What might the moment before world annihilation sound like? While most would prefer not to experience the sound firsthand, it is one that has been imagined and portrayed cinematically in several ways, from a whimper (Sidney Lumets Fail-Safe) to a bang (the 1983 TV movie The Day After, which didnt depict the end of everything, exactly, but did portray the unthinkable). Lars von Triers Melancholia, the apocalyptic drama that has received as much critical praise as its director has received public scrutiny, chooses to end the world with Wagner.

title: How to Find Lift Tickets for Less
description: IF you are waiting until the last minute to buy lift tickets, you are probably missing out on major savings.

title: The Dating Travails of Young Bankers
description: Between Excel marathons and 3 a.m. pitchbook proofreads, some young finance guys find the time to look for romance. But that may not be a good thing in some cases.

title: The Giving Spree | Elettra Wiedemann
description: Who: The model and food activist Elettra Wiedemann, who opened the pop-up restaurant Goodness during New York Fashion Week in September.

title: Beard and All, a Rabbi Is Joining the Army
description: There are, to be sure, fellow Hasidic rabbis with much more impressive beards. But Rabbi Menachem Stern has had his for years, so he had no intention of getting rid of it to join the army.

title: Plot to Smuggle Qaddafi Son Into Mexico Is Disrupted, Government Official Says
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican government said Wednesday that it had broken up a plot to smuggle into Mexico one of the sons of the former Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and hide him and his family at a Pacific beach resort.

title: At Climate Talks, a Familiar Standoff Between U.S. and China
description: DURBAN, South Africa  China, the worlds biggest greenhouse gas emitter, has once again emerged as the biggest puzzle at international climate change talks, sending ambiguous signals about the role it intends to play in future negotiations. This week, the nations top climate envoy said that China would be open to signing a formal treaty limiting emissions after 2020  but laid down conditions for doing so that are unlikely ever to be met.

title: Military Reads
description: Nytimes.com has an array of military-related items around the site today that are worth reading.

title: Gingrich Surge Brings Added Scrutiny
description: DES MOINES  A year ago, as Newt Gingrich was beginning to seriously explore whether to seek the Republican presidential nomination, he bristled a bit when asked how his three marriages would be viewed by conservative voters.

title: Excerpt: 'Maple and Vine'
description: Marin Ireland and Trent Dawson in a scene from Jordan Harrisons new play at Playwrights Horizons. (Video courtesy of the theater.)

title: Bernie Fine Cant Be Charged, District Attorney Says
description: The former Syracuse assistant mens basketball coach Bernie Fine cannot be prosecuted for allegations that he sexually abused two boys in the 1980s because the statute of limitations had run out, William Fitzpatrick, the district attorney for Onondaga County, N.Y., said Wednesday. Fitzpatrick added he believed the accusers were telling the truth about the abuse.

title: CNL Adds Stevens Pass to Its Ski Resorts
description: Stevens Pass, a snow-smothered ski area 78 miles east of Seattle that is beloved by Northwesterners, was sold last month. It wasnt big news, unless you noticed the buyer: CNL Lifestyle Properties.

title: Romney Ad Highlights Stable Family
description: 11:35 p.m. | Updated  Read the full report here.

title: Is the Tools of the Mind Curriculum Effective?
The First Marking Period Is Over. How Did SchoolBook Do?
Karzai Says He Will Talk to Pakistan Over Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai paid an emotional visit on Wednesday to a hospital full of survivors of a series of suicide bombings claimed by a Pakistani extremist group, and he promised to pursue the issue with Pakistans government.

title: Tax Cut or Tax Increase?
description: The overhaul of the states income tax structure agreed to by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders will tax income over $2 million (for married couples filing jointly) at 8.82 percent. That is significantly higher than the states highest base income tax rate, which is 6.85 percent, but slightly lower than the 8.97 percent rate that for the last three years has been imposed on high incomes under a surcharge that was set to expire Dec. 31.

title: Blagojevich Sentenced to 14 Years in Prison
description: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois who for years proclaimed he was innocent of federal corruption charges, apologized on Wednesday for his crimes. He apologized to his trial judge. He apologized to his family. He apologized to the residents of Illinois, who had heard his voice on secretly recorded phone calls as he crassly spoke of what he might get in exchange for a United States Senate seat.

title: 2011 Versus 1910, an Editorial Change of Heart
description: One of the marvelous things about my job as the editorial page editor of a 151-year-old newspaper is that I occasionally happen upon curious editorial positions from days of yore. Im not talking about the papers onetime opposition to womens suffrage, although that was strange.

title: Top Agent in Hip-Hop Is Leaving William Morris
description: Cara Lewis, the top booking agent for hip-hop and R&B acts, with a client roster that includes Eminem, Kanye West and Rihanna, is leaving her longtime job at WME, the agency formerly known as William Morris Endeavor.

title: On Our Radar: Weakening Brazils Forest Protections
description: Brazils Senate approves a controversial forestry bill supported by growers and ranchers that would relax limits on tree-cutting. If it becomes final, environmentalists say, the measure would undo recent progress in reining in the deforestation of the Amazon. [The Wall Street Journal]

Dickey, the Mets pitcher, will climb Mount Kilimanjaro in January, in part to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats.

Rick Perry of Texas is broadcasting a new campaign ad that seems to contrast Christianity with homosexuality, vows to end what he calls Obamas war on religion, and highlights Mr. Perrys criticism of overturning the dont ask, dont tell policy for gays serving in the military.

description: Credit card agreements are typically something youd want to read only if you suffered from insomnia. A glance at a few lines of the dense type, printed on filmy paper, is sure to help you drift off.

title: First Look | Valentinos Timestrings Collection
description: At first glance its hard to find a common thread running through Valentinos spring capsule collection, Timestrings. The studded peep-toe booties, satin flats, polka-dot platforms and bow-embellished kitten heels carry many of the brands signatures, but share none of them collectively. What all of the shoes do share is a handwritten time stamp  a numerical record of the amount of time it took to make each pair. For example, the sequence etched into a pair of silver chain wedge heels is 47.4150, denoting 47 hours, 41 minutes and 50 seconds. When we talk about luxury and time, its clear that theres a strong connection between the two, says Maria Grazia Chiuri, one of the houses two co-designers. Time is the new luxury, and luxury does not exist without time and the consciousness of a unique tradition. Classic Italian craftsmanship still exists (Valentino is known for its old Florentine factories), but in an age of fast everything its easy to forget our Old World cobblers: the one devoted to flowers, the one who specializes in crystals and another with expertise in lace, for example. Pierpaolo Piccioli, Chiuris design partner, adds, Its nice to know that youre buying a kind of cultural process. Milled plexiglass and velvet wedges marked 38H? At $1,295, thats $34 an hour, if you break it down. And yes, its worth it.

title: Plan to Widen Availability of Morning-After Pill Is Rejected
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time ever, the Health and Human Services secretary publicly overruled the Food and Drug Administration, refusing Wednesday to allow emergency contraceptives to be sold over the counter, including to young teenagers. The decision avoided what could have been a bruising political battle over parental control and contraception during a presidential election season.

title: Romney Faults Obamas Focus on Entitlement
description: Mitt Romney used an address before the Republican Jewish Coalition on Wednesday to draw a contrast between himself and President Obama, accusing the president of seeking to transform the nation into both an appeasement and an entitlement society.

description: LONDON  Pity the European bond trader.

description: HERITAGE, as much as denim designers love to throw that word around, is a hard thing to come by, particularly when youre a new label. An antique wash and a whisker effect can make any pair of jeans look old, but is that heritage  or just a patina?

description: An exhaustive new report meant to address public fears about possible links between breast cancer and the environment finds evidence strong enough to make only a few firm recommendations, most already well known and none with a large proven benefit.

title: Portal to Off Off Broadways Early Days
description: JOSEPH CINO didnt set out to be a pioneer. He began presenting plays at his Cornelia Street cafe on a whim, as an offshoot of the poetry readings that expressed his desire to create a place where artistic types would want to spend time. A dreamer and newcomer to Manhattan by way of Buffalo, he opened that establishment, Caffe Cino, in 1958 and over time became a veritable spokesman for the intimate and uncommercial productions mounted on its shabby, makeshift stage.

title: Gingrichs Unimpeachable Conservative Credential
description: I have seen a lot of other commentators bring up versions of this point, but there is a reason why Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, see Newt Gingrich as by far their most qualified nominee and why they have been willing so far to excuse his periodic lapses from conservative orthodoxy.

title: Lowering Breast Cancer Risk
description: A new report aimed at identifying environmental risk factors for breast cancer urges women to avoid unnecessary medical radiation, avoid certain hormone treatments for menopause, limit alcohol and keep their weight down. As Denise Grady, the New York Times health reporter, writes:

title: David Hallberg to Appear on The Colbert Report
description: The ballet dancer David Hallberg has been busy the past few weeks performing with his new company, the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow. He is the first American to join the company on a permanent basis. But, lucky for his fans here, he has returned to United States to dance with American Ballet Theater in Alexei Ratmanskys The Nutcracker at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Dec. 23 and 28, and to appear on Wednesday night on The Colbert Report on Comedy Central. Dancing is on the shows agenda, in addition to an interview, and we cant wait to assess Stephen Colberts technique. Hee Seo, a soloist with American Ballet Theater, will also perform. Mr. Hallberg, an avid tweeter, is apparently excited too.
