title: Underworld to Create Music for Opening of 2012 Olympics in London
description: The members of the electronic dance music group Underworld have been named the musical directors for the opening ceremony of the 2012 Olympics in London, organizers announced on Wednesday. The duo, Rick Smith and Karl Hyde, will work alongside the artistic director, the British filmmaker Danny Boyle, to produce the music for the three-hour performance on July 27. It is not the first time Mr. Boyle has chosen Mr. Smith and Mr. Hyde to provide the soundtrack for one of his projects. The group is perhaps best known for its dance track Born Slippy, which first appeared in a scene from Mr. Boyles 1996 film Trainspotting. Since then, they have created music for four other projects by Mr. Boyle, including a National Theater production of Frankenstein that received high praise from critics. Mr. Boyle said the hiring of Underworld to write music for the Games was the last piece of the jigsaw puzzle and praised the duos creative range. Mr. Hyde said the chance to compose for the Olympics was a great honor. We want to leave people with a musical memory of the show rather than a purely visual one, he said in a statement.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 8
description: Leather dresses; matching socks and bags; and macaroon-like pill boxes.

title: 21st-Century Frocks | Azzedine Alaa at the Groninger Museum
description: Azzedine Alaa has never obeyed the fashion calendar and shows only when he  and his clothes  are good and ready. In fact, in recent years, the designer, who is now in his 70s, has probably had as many runway presentations as museum exhibitions, including the one that opens this weekend at the Groninger Museum in the Netherlands. Azzedine Alaa in the 21st Century focuses solely on his output from roughly the past decade, and yet there is more substance there than many designers could ever hope to achieve in a lifetime, including the fierce tailcoat above and a toothsome evening dress with a zipper that spirals suggestively around the body from the neck to the floor. Always the perfectionist in the pursuit of beauty (hes often referred to as a sculptor of womens bodies), Alaa apparently recut or totally remade many of the pieces in the show to the exact proportions of the mannequins. In an open love letter to the designer, Mark Wilson, who curated the exhibition, writes, Im sure that certain people may wonder why we are doing this one more time? referring to a massive Alaa exhibition at the Groninger Museum back in in 1997-98. Wilson promptly answers his own question: Because you are the last great couturier working today.

title: By Winning a Fourth, U.S.C. Records a First in Water Polo
description: As the clock ticked down to the final seconds of the 2011 N.C.A.A. water polo championship game, the U.S.C. fans present started chanting four-peat, the U.S.C. fight song rang out through U.C. Berkeleys Spieker Aquatics Complex and the U.S.C. water polo starters turned to face their fans from their positions in the pool with fists raised. The announcer couldnt be heard once the clock hit zero and every Trojan player poolside jumped into the water.

title: Olive Oils Growers, Chemists, Cooks and Crooks
description: A few pages into Tom Muellers new book, Extra Virginity, theres a funny moment when an olive oil expert holds up a bottle thats covered with dubious claims: 100 percent Italian, cold-pressed, extra virgin. The man shakes his head and says, perhaps with a hint of Don Rickles in his voice, Extra virgin? Whats this oil got to do with virginity? This is a whore.

description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers said Wednesday that they would control the process of writing a constitution and maintain authority over the interim government to check the power of Islamists who have taken a commanding lead in parliamentary elections.

title: Sandusky Arrested on Charges Involving Two New Accusers
description: Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach charged last month with 40 counts of sexually abusing eight boys, was arrested Wednesday on new sexual abuse charges involving two additional accusers. The two testified before a grand jury that they were molested or raped by Sandusky over a period of years, the authorities said.

title: A Master Plan for N.J.s Energy Needs
description: The final version of Gov. Chris Christies master plan on energy for New Jersey is in, reflecting only minimal tweaks since a draft was released over the summer.

title: Happy Little Bluebirds May Fly, but Judy and Mom Just Crashed and Burned
description: After the countless drag queens who have paid tribute to Judy Garland, youd think her stardust might be running low. But no, the actor and performance artist John Fleck grabs a handful in his spirited, heartfelt, one-man show Mad Women at the Club at La MaMa. Mr. Fleck and three other artists  Karen Finley, Holly Hughes and Tim Miller  were at the center of a controversy over content in the early 1990s when the National Endowment for the Arts revoked their grants. There is no controversy in Mad Women, only affection for Garland and bittersweet recollections of Mr. Flecks past.

title: A Guidebook Based on Michelle Obamas Style
description: TO most people, there is only one O as far as icons from Chicago are concerned. But when Mikki Taylor, the former beauty editor at Essence, speaks of O, there is no doubt whom she is talking about.

title: More on Labor Force Dropouts
description: On Tuesday I wrote about how the entirety of the net decline in the labor force last month could be explained by women dropping out. I also puzzled over why a majority of women who left the labor force happened to have been employed before they opted out, because the stereotypical labor force dropout is usually an unemployed worker who got discouraged and gave up looking for a new job.

title: Just One Look | Reed Krakoff
description: Theres still a place for minimalism in the fashion world according to Reed Krakoff. His pre-fall collection, which debuted Monday, is wonderfully strict and linear, with fur coats on one end of the spectrum and simple knits on the other. The pieces are two of his strongest offerings. In terms of colors, the clear alligator green and orange-y pink looked surprisingly wearable and cool next to all of the black and tan. Pictured here is a compact wool dress with leather collar and sleeves is finished with the collections most effective accessory  a pair of black leather gloves.

title: A Good Night for Fox Despite Little Joy From Glee
description: Based on early Nielsen estimates, Glee and New Girl dropped to season lows in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic on Tuesday night but Fox was still able to claim the top spot in the advertiser-beloved category over all. Glee drew 7.1 million total viewers, a far cry from the 11.1 million that tuned in to a comparable episode a year ago, while New Girl fell to 6.8 million viewers, a series low. CBS finished first in total viewers, with repeats from its NCIS franchise.

title: In Quebec, Winter Tire Law Reaps a Modest Measure of Success
description: OTTAWA  Its the annual crunch time at tire shops and garages throughout the province of Quebec. Drivers must fit passenger vehicles with four winter tires by Dec. 15 and keep them on until March 15, or risk fines of 200 to 300 Canadian dollars.

title: The Predictability of Tantrums
description: Of course you knew that kids have tantrums. But you probably didnt know that kids who have tantrums mostly have them in a neat, predictable pattern. Michael Potegal, a neurology professor, teamed up with James Green, a developmental psychologist, to look not at what causes tantrums but at how they work. They found three standard phases (video documented on NPRs Shots blog). Phase 1: yelling and screaming. Phase 2: physical actions. Phase 3: crying and whining.

title: On Eve of Key Meeting, New Rifts on Euro Emerge
description: PARIS  Disagreements over how to enforce better economic discipline and centralized oversight over nations in the European Union emerged on Wednesday, the day before a crucial summit meeting to deal with the euro crisis, including disputes over how extensively and how quickly to change European treaties.

title: Mice, and iPads and iPhones, in Grand Central
description: Apples newest store, on the busy concourse of Grand Central Terminal, will open to the public on Friday. The company will be offering travelers services designed to speed them through the new store at its elegant perch in the historic station. Read about it in the Bits blog.

title: African Fashion in Its Multifaceted Designs
description: A new book called New African Fashion highlights designers  some established, some fledgling  whose work is African made or inspired.

title: Designers Take a Fresh Look at Africa
description: IN the years since Yves Saint Laurent showed his iconic 1967 African collection, fashion designers have repeatedly tapped the heritage of Africa in search of inspiration. Just last season Burberry and Michael Kors were among several labels that mined the continent as a source of ideas. Yet in the popular imagination, especially in the Western hemisphere, African fashion more often than not means animal prints, mud cloth and cowrie shells. In her new work, New African Fashion (Prestel; $35), Helen Jennings, a fashion journalist, hopes to broaden that view. Part coffee-table book, part glossary, it highlights designers  some established, some fledgling  whose work is African made or inspired.

title: Electric Room
description: A PUNY bar wedged beneath a sleek hotel, accessed through a garbage-strewn loading dock, doesnt sound overly compelling. But with cagey calibration, Electric Room, a new lounge under the popular Dream Downtown hotel, has become one of the citys toughest doors to breach.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: A Sustainable Home in Scotland
description: Jim Lucas and Jennifer Mole, and their two daughters, have settled into their two-story cantilevered home in Coldingham, Scotland, designed to be energy efficient.

title: Cellphones Test Strength of Gym Rules
description: LIKE movie theaters and libraries, many fitness clubs have insisted for years that their workout areas should be cellphone-free. Their logic is as simple and straightforward as a push-up: they want to prevent people from yakking on their phones and annoying the fitness buffs who want to crank out reps and mileage in relative peace. Safety is another reason, because texting while running on a treadmill can be hazardous to your health.

title: Flops Pile Up in the Tablet Market
description: Its been a gloomy holiday season for tablet makers  unless, that is, you are Apple, Amazon or Barnes & Noble.

title: A Sustainable Home Lives Up to Its Name
description: COLDINGHAM, Scotland  The surprising thing about visiting Sunnybank, a light-drenched home in Coldingham, a picturesque village near Scotlands southeast coastline, is that its entrance is barely visible. That detail, admits Jim Lucas, one of the homes owners, was quite deliberate.

title: Poet to Poet: Graywolf To Publish Bly-Transtromer Correspondence
description: English-language admirers of Tomas Transtromer, the Swedish poet who will receive this years Nobel Prize in Literature in a ceremony in Stockholm on Saturday, will soon have to make room on their shelves for another book.

title: Sweat and Tears
description: FOR the better part of 10 years, I have dressed almost exclusively in black shirts. Not out of choice, but out of necessity. I have incessantly sweaty armpits, you see, and thats the only way to conceal them.

title: Entrepreneurs Rival in China: The State
description: SHANGHAI  It was the kind of entrepreneurial breakthrough that China counts on to make it a global leader in innovation.

title: Ask David Barboza About Chinas Economy
description: David Barboza has been a correspondent for The New York Times based in Shanghai, China, since November 2004. In a series of recent articles, he has examined Chinas system of government-managed capitalism in depth. He will be answering questions from readers in connection with these articles. Submit your question via the comments section below. Mr. Barboza will respond to a selection of questions in the days ahead.

title: LivingSocial Looks to Raise $400 Million
description: LivingSocial disclosed in a regulatory filing on Wednesday that it had raised $176 million as part of a broader financing effort.

title: That 33-Carat Ring Would Look Nice on Me
description: The exhibition of Elizabeth Taylors jewelry is bringing out the star-struck, the nostalgic and the just plain curious.

title: Central Park, the Soundtrack
description: Clamp on headphones, start up the iPhone app by the musical duo Bluebrain and walk into Central Park. The music does not begin until you pass through an entrance and head into the trees. Then it sounds like an orchestra tuning up, a chaotic jumble of wind chimes, electronic moans and discordant strings. Push farther into the park, and a sweet violin melody emerges over languid piano chords.

title: Ice Cube Is in the House!
description: In the late 80s, before he became famous as a member of the Compton, Calif., gangsta-rap group N.W.A., Ice Cube studied architectural drafting at a trade school in Arizona. This biographical detail makes the rappers appearance in a new video celebrating midcentury design icons Charles and Ray Eames only slightly less incongruous.

title: Ice Cube Celebrates the Eames House
description: The rapper pays tribute to the midcentury design icons Charles and Ray Eames.

title: Discord Over Dean Rocks Columbia Engineering School
description: Columbia University is grappling with a rare faculty revolt against the dean of its engineering school, who has helped the school grow in size and stature since his 2009 hiring, but has also been accused of ignoring professors concerns and worsening a chronic space shortage.

title: Scene City: A Peek at the Pirelli Calendar
description: Julianne Moore, Adrien Brody and Others Toast 2011 Pinup.

title: Destination Unknown, but a Quest Pushes Gentle Motion to the Fore
description: A woman in white is roaming, searching. Slowly her movements fill each of the long, unusual, quiet chords of The Unanswered Question, by Charles Ives. Now she advances through space; now, staying on the spot, stretching her upper body, she arches her neck up to face the sky. Theres a sense that she does not know what she is seeking, but that she cannot stop her quest. It does not, however, agonize her: her motion has gentleness, and a strange mixture of restraint and luxuriance.

title: After Vote, Congo Braces for Expressions of Discord
description: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo  With a contentious election still unresolved more than a week after the voting, an uneasy quiet held here on Wednesday, punctuated by occasional blasts of tear gas, hurled rocks, gunshots and promises of more intense confrontations to come.

title: A Big Party for a Big Calendar
description: ITS always important to know what you cant have, especially for the holidays.

title: The Futility Of Bipartisan Outreach
description: President Obama has tried  desperately, and far beyond the point at which it made any kind of sense  to reach out across the partisan divide. He has bent over backwards to be nice to bankers. He has clearly been uncomfortable with any kind of populist rhetoric, although that may finally be changing.

title: Winter Wonders | Sunglasses Optional
description: The coat that does the most usually comes in a neutral color  black, white, camel  and leans a little (or a lot) toward one of three classic styles: trench, peacoat or blazer. Here, Angelina Jolie steps out in New York in a crisp white version of the latter with just the slightest bit of sheen; the actress Liv Tyler wears the seasons lengthy proportion on a version of the perennial peacoat; and the actress Jessica Biel pairs black with orange and blue  note the matching bag and shoes  in the most effortless way.

title: Penguins Say Crosby to Miss Next Two Games as Precaution
description: Sidney Crosby will be held out of the Penguins lineup for the next two games, the team said in a statement released late Wednesday afternoon.

title: Wisecracks, Scattered Among Slow Tunes
description: Now Im going to play a ballad, Ryan Adams deadpanned partway through his solo concert on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. The joke was that he had been playing virtually nothing but ballads: one slow, perfectly poised song after another, presented so quietly that listeners leaned forward to catch each delicate moment. Between songs he wisecracked, drawing hoots and guffaws. I dont know why I write these kinds of songs, he said. Im not sensitive at all. Im a bastard. Then the next song would create another gorgeously hushed communion.

title: Frdric Malle | On Perfume Making
description: Have you ever walked down Madison Avenue, stumbled upon a grungy overfilled trash can and inhaled the scent of roses? It may very well have been the work of the renowned perfumer Frdric Malle of Les Editions de Parfums.

title: Venerable Choir and Its Guests Burnish a Holiday Tradition
description: For listeners who prefer the historical approach to Baroque style, the annual performances of Handels Messiah at St. Thomas Church set a standard that is hard to surpass. Granted, there are other period-instrument Messiah readings in town, most notably those offered by Trinity Church. (This years run begins on Sunday and includes a performance at Alice Tully Hall on Dec. 19.) But where St. Thomas has the edge is in its use of a chorus of men and boys, the younger singers drawn from its own choir school, a British tradition that stretches back beyond the time when Handel worked in England. Not that the superb, fully professional Trinity Choir has any reason to feel second best. But there is a purity in the sound of trained boy sopranos that a mixed adult choir cannot match.

title: Amid a Horrific Scene, Tears
description: Massoud Hossaini has never cried like this before.

title: Foreclosed in Brooklyn: House Repairs as Protest
description: With a soggy cluster of balloons floating beside him, a shaggy-haired demonstrator kept watch on Wednesday inside the front gate of a dilapidated two-story home in East New York, Brooklyn. The residential block was mostly empty, except for a police car idling at the curb.

title: Grassley Wants Justice Official Ousted
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, called Wednesday for the resignation of the head of the Justice Departments criminal division, Lanny A. Breuer, in the latest flare-up connected to the disputed gun trafficking investigation known as Operation Fast and Furious.

title: Pacific Sunwear Gets Private Equity Loan and Closes Stores

description: Don Giovanni had just gone to hell, and the rest of the characters in Mozarts opera of that name were singing of his final moments.

title: Now Exposing | The 2012 Pirelli Calendar
description: For most every year since 1964, Pirelli, the Italian tire maker, has bankrolled a very unusual, very expensive promotional calendar. It typically involves a coterie of the worlds hottest models jetting to an exquisitely remote clime  the Seychelles, say, or Botswana  to be photographed, nude, by an elite fashion photographer. The calendar began inauspiciously as a pinup that grease monkeys would post at continental service stations. But just like in the case of Michelins influential guidebook, it took on a life of its own and now its connection to motoring seems completely incidental. (One must give props to all these European tire makers for their enduring contributions to world culture; the best thing our own Goodyear has come up with so far is a blimp.)

title: A Ticket to East Egg, Please
description: YOU could be forgiven for thinking that the spring 2012 fashion collections were an open call for costumes for the Baz Luhrmann remake of The Great Gatsby, in theaters late next year. Flapper shapes and Art Deco lines lindy-hopped down runways from New York to Milan. There was flapper fringe at Etro and Marchesa, Glad-wrapped chorus girls at Marc Jacobs, zigzagging patterns at J. Mendel, BCBG and Alberta Ferretti. And at Gucci there were so many flapper numbers, their architectural patterns outlined in black and gold, that the show was a study in Jazz Age opulence.

title: Making Short Work of Shopping for Tablet Users
description: Those days of dashing through the mall on Christmas Eve, searching for the perfect book or DVD, may be history. Procrastinators this year can sit at home, alone and unruffled, and send books, music and even video in time for Christmas delivery  on tablets like the Kindle Fire, the Nook and the iPad.

They finished four boards ahead of Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness, who represent Monaco.

She is frequently photographed at fashion galas and charity balls, including the recent M Missoni for OrphanAid Africa party and the fall benefit for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

Taken through his own flowing tears, Mr. Hossainis gripping pictures of the aftermath were striking enough to appear on the front page of this newspaper, as well as The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post. You can read Mr. Hossainis very personal recollection of the chaos here.

title: From Rick Owens, Fashion to Sit On
description: Anyone creating their own environment is following a utopian vision, the fashion designer Rick Owens said of his new furniture collection, introduced this week at Maxfield Gallery in Los Angeles. Mine is a Brutalist fur on a Brutalist rock next to a Brutalist fire in a Brutalist cave. It includes 15 shamelessly big pieces (including chairs, a screen, a couch, a table and a bed), made from materials like black plywood, 500,000-year-old petrified bark and alabaster. Making furniture is my version of couture: its time-consuming artisanal work made in limited quantities in rare materials, customized for my favorite client, my better half, the Hun, Mr. Owens said, referring to his wife, Michele Lamy. Prices start at about $10,000 (the Boudeuse couch, pictured, is $78,750). Maxfield, 8818 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles; (310) 275-8818 or maxfieldla.com.

title: China: Hundreds Arrested on Child-Selling Charges
description: More than 600 people across China have been arrested on suspicion of selling children, according to a statement released Wednesday by the Ministry of Public Security. The statement also said 178 children had been freed. There has been greater scrutiny of trafficking in children this year, in part because of news reports by Caixin Century Weekly that shed light on child abductions and child-selling in Hunan Province. Some children were later adopted by foreigners, Caixin reported. Experts say the kidnapping and sale of children is a problem in China because of the countrys one-child policy and the cultural preference among many parents for boys. Families in many areas are fined heavily if they have more than one child and refuse to give up the others, and some officials have abducted children from such families. In addition, some parents are willing to sell girls so they can keep or try to conceive a son as their only child.

title: 4 Accused in Theft of Aid Meant for Nonprofit
description: In 2006, a Queens state senator, Shirley L. Huntley, set up a nonprofit group called Parent Workshop that was intended to help parents navigate the inner workings of New York Citys school system. Then she began funneling state aid to the group, whose executives had close ties to her.

description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  There is a sign hanging on a wall in the office of Mike Westhoff, the Jets special-teams coordinator, that reflects one of his favorite sayings: You cant win with the players you dont have.

description: Rising to speak to the Senate on Dec. 4, 1861, the third day of the Congressional session, Henry Wilson of Massachusetts brandished a report on the sordid conditions in the Washington jail and, in particular, on 60 African-American prisoners held within it. Wilson had been to the jail to witness the stunning scene of degradation and inhumanity.

description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo.  Even after three consecutive wins last weekend in Lake Louise, Alberta, Lindsey Vonn was unusually nervous as she waited at the start of Wednesdays super-G race. The super-G was the first running of a womens World Cup event in this location  almost an extension of Vonns hometown, nearby Vail. With friends and family looking on, the pressure was compounded.

description: London

title: Democrats See a Two-Horse G.O.P. Race, Adding a Whip

description: MIAMI  When Gov. Rick Scott rolled out his budget on Wednesday, it was to a group of reporters at a news conference at the Florida Capitol in a room packed with staff members, a far cry from the Tea Party crowd that cheered him on during his first budget announcement early this year.

title: Millions? Private Jet? Columbia Offers New York
description: Early one morning last week, inside Columbias subterranean athletic center in Upper Manhattan, M. Dianne Murphy leaned over a conference table and wrapped her fingers around a disposable cup of coffee. There was no time to sleep these days, she said.

title: Drone Crash in Iran Reveals Secret U.S. Surveillance Program
description: Crash of Stealth C.I.A. Drone in Iran Reveals Secret U.S. Surveillance Effort | The C.I.A. RQ-170 drone that crashed in Iran last week has blown the cover off of one of the United States most secret intelligence-collection efforts against the country. While American and Iranian officials dispute the cause of the drones demise  Iranian officials say the military hacked into the drones control systems, Americans say the drone malfunctioned  an essential question remains: What will happen with the centerpiece of a once covert program, now that the aircraft is in Irans hands? Scott Shane and David E. Sanger report that the United States considered it too risky to retrieve or destroy the drone, which leaves open the possibilities that Iran could reverse-engineer the drones technology, or turn the aircraft over to China or Russia. You can read the full report here.

title: Always a Bed-Wetter, Never a Bride
description: As a travel writer for a luxury magazine, I get to sleep in exotic locations on top of memory-foam mattresses with 800-thread-count sheets. It is a major indulgence, since for most of my childhood and my early teens, I slept on the floor on wet sheets and a rubber mat.

title: Hope in the Age of Man
description: SCIENTISTS interested in drawing attention to the human transformation of planet Earth have begun calling the current geological epoch the Anthropocene  the age of man. Naming an epoch is serious business  and in this case the new name is well deserved, given humanitys enormous alteration of the Earth.

description: WASHINGTON  Election year has arrived on Capitol Hill. Please keep your seatbelts securely fastened for the duration of the flight.

description: Naomi Klein, the author of a string of provocative and popular books including The Shock Doctrine, recently took on global warming policy and campaigns in Capitalism vs. the Climate, a much-discussed cover story for The Nation that has been mentioned by readers here more than once in the last few weeks.

description: Prime Minister Vladimir Putin of Russia has cynically dominated his countrys politics for the last 11 years and intends to do it for many more years to come. Given the way he has muzzled independent media and hobbled opponents, it looked as though nothing could challenge his reign. Then came Sundays parliamentary election in which a surprising number of voters made clear that they are tired of the status quo and Mr. Putin.

title: Politics and the Morning-After Pill
description: Once again, the politics of birth control have trumped science and sound public policy. On Wednesday, the Obama administration overruled a carefully reasoned decision by the Food and Drug Administration to make the so-called morning-after pill available without prescription to adolescent girls below the age of 17.

title: Pakistani President Is Said to Be in Dubai for Heart Tests

description: Even in the days when the American economy was running smoothly, before Mindy Shapiro lost her dream career and then a backup job, her heart was never far from home.

title: 2 Character Models for a Single Cinematic Point: Winning Elections at Any Cost

Jay Carson, a onetime Washington Democratic operative, was walking through the Los Angeles premiere of The Ides of March when his girlfriend, Sarah Treem, a television writer and playwright, tugged at his elbow. How many times are you going to get to attend a preview of a movie that is based on part of your life? she asked, looking over a crowd that included Ryan Gosling, who plays the character modeled on Mr. Carson.

title: Eyeing 2012, White House Presses Europe on Debt
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited Prime Minister Lucas Papademos of Greece in his Athens office on Monday. Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, hopscotched across Europe on Tuesday and Wednesday, urging leaders to address the European debt crisis more urgently. And President Obama has been on the phone almost every other week  including on Wednesday  with either Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany or President Nicolas Sarkozy of France.

title: Constantly Checking In, Without Ever Checking In
description: This summer and fall, I spent 156 hours in some of New Yorks finest hotels. I did not sleep, or shower, or earn rewards points. I was not, in the vernacular of the service industry, a guest. At times, I felt more like a hostage, subsisting on a diet of stale pizza, trail mix and anonymous sources.

title: Waging War on Wages

description: WASHINGTON  The leading Republican candidates drew enthusiastic applause from Republican Jewish leaders here on Wednesday after accusing President Obama of falling short in his support of Israel while coddling its adversaries. But it remained to be seen how far those arguments will carry them, especially given the candidates rightward tilt on other issues that have traditionally been important to American Jews.

title: Britain Suffers as a Bystander to the Euros Crisis
description: LONDON  No matter what happens at the European summit meeting on the euro in Brussels that begins Thursday, Britain is sure to lose.

title: Moves Show Mets Are Moving On After Losing a Star
description: DALLAS  While Jose Reyes flitted through the halls of the Hilton Anatole on Wednesday, giving a succession of interviews in a Miami jersey after being introduced as a Marlin, the Mets announced a comparatively modest move of their own.

title: Free Money for the Packers
Two Drugs Appear to Delay Progression of Breast Cancer
description: Two drugs can delay by several months the time before advanced breast cancer worsens, potentially providing new options for women with that disease, researchers reported Wednesday.

title: U.S. Agency Is Ordered to Change Wind Rules
description: WASHINGTON  A federal power agency discriminated against wind operators in the Pacific Northwest when it unplugged their generators to cope with a surplus of renewable energy on its transmission system this year, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ruled on Tuesday. It ordered the agency, the Bonneville Power Administration, to rewrite its rules.

title: Supreme Court Hears Case on Patents for Individualized Medicine
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday considered a major patent case, one that asked whether observed correlations between drug dosages and medical treatment were subject to patent protection.

title: Jets Consultant Takes a Closer Look
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  In his 49th season of coaching, Tom Moore described himself as a football junkie. And for football junkies, this is the best time of year. The postseason is near. Every play of every game is magnified, particularly for teams seeking a playoff berth, teams like the Jets.

title: Crosby Out for Two Games
description: Sidney Crosby will be held out of the Penguins lineup for the next two games as a precaution, the team said. Crosby appeared to have difficulty putting weight on his right leg after he collided with his teammate Chris Kunitz in the third period of Pittsburghs 3-1 loss to the Boston Bruins on Monday. Crosby played the remainder of the game.

title: Turkey: More Trade Measures Imposed Against Syria
description: Turkey will levy taxes of about 30 percent on Syrian goods after President Bashar al-Assad of Syria suspended a free-trade agreement and imposed taxes on Turkish exports, Hayati Yazici, the Turkish minister of customs and trade, said Wednesday. Relations between the two countries have deteriorated since August, when Mr. Assad failed to take steps to end a deadly crackdown on dissent. Since then, Turkey has halted joint energy exploration, joined the Arab Leagues sanctions against its once-close ally, threatened to expand embargoes, and started shipping routes to Egypt and Lebanon to circumvent Syria, which has blocked Turkish trucks.

title: Iran Shutters U.S. Embassy on the Web
description: Iranians shut down the United States Tehran embassy 32 years ago. They shut down its virtual Tehran embassy on Wednesday.

title: Dobie Gray, Singer Known for Drift Away, Dies
description: Dobie Gray, a versatile singer and songwriter who had a handful of hits in various pop genres but who was probably best known for his enduring 1973 soul anthem, Drift Away, a wistful paean to all songwriters and their songs, died on Tuesday in Nashville. He was believed to be 71.

title: Florida: Punishment Delayed in Drum Majors Death
description: At the request of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, Florida A&M University said on Wednesday that it was delaying disciplinary action in the wake of the possible hazing death of a marching band drum major. Earlier, the university fired its longtime band director, Julian White, and said it would suspend some students in the death of the drum major, Robert Champion. Those moves have been halted for now while the investigation continues into the death. Mr. Champion was found unresponsive on a bus parked outside an Orlando, Fla., hotel last month after a football game. He was vomiting and had complained he could not breathe before he collapsed.

title: F.B.I. Board Votes to Broaden Definition of Rape
description: An F.B.I. advisory board voted this week to modernize an archaic definition of rape that the agency has used for more than eight decades in its tally of national crime statistics. The current definition used by the F.B.I., carnal knowledge of a female, forcibly and against her will, has been criticized by law enforcement officials and womens advocates as far too narrow, with the result that many rapes are excluded from the yearly Uniform Crime Report. The new definition approved by the advisory board, which met in Albuquerque on Tuesday, includes the rape of men and crimes that involve oral or anal penetration or penetration with objects. The definition must be approved by the F.B.I.s director, Robert S. Mueller III, before it is adopted.

title: Woman Is Fatally Struck by a Sanitation Truck in Brooklyn
description: A sanitation truck struck and killed a woman on Wednesday night in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the police said. No crime was suspected, they said.

title: Dugald Stermer, Illustrator and Ramparts Art Director, Dies at 74
description: Dugald Stermer, who achieved renown and sometimes angered the government as the art director of the influential left-wing magazine Ramparts in the 1960s, died on Dec. 2 in San Francisco. He was 74.

title: Marion Dougherty, Hollywood Star-Maker, Dies at 88
description: Marion Dougherty, who cast some of Hollywoods biggest stars in their earliest parts, including Al Pacino, Dustin Hoffman and Warren Beatty, and who suggested Carroll OConnor for the role of  Archie Bunker in the long-running hit television show All in the Family, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: G.E.-Microsoft Venture to Create Windows for Health Care
description: Any discussion of the challenge of trying to improve health care and curb costs with computer technology quickly turns to silos. Not the kind that store corn in Midwestern farms, obviously.

title: I.B.M. Using Bits of Watson for Drug Research
description: When I.B.M.s Watson computer beat two human Jeopardy! champions earlier this year, it was a triumphant demonstration of the companys technology. It was great for Big Blues image, but it was not a moneymaker on its own.

title: Researcher Creates Online Library About Concussions
description: Saying that parents whose children play contact sports should not accept public health policy from the N.H.L., but do it for themselves, a doctor heading a team of Canadian concussion specialists on Thursday created an online concussion library fully accessible to both the public and to research and medical professionals.

title: Scott Boras on the Thrifty Mets
description: DALLAS  In another economic climate, Prince Fielder might be the perfect addition for the Mets. They are coming off three losing seasons, they could use a power hitter, and Fielder is only 27 years old.

title: X Factor Watch: A Glitch and Then the Singers Are on Their Own
description: The X Factor didnt even try to make its manufactured drama convincing on Wednesday nights show, which was supposed to include performances of songs chosen by viewers. There was a problem with the public voting, the host, Steve Jones, announced midway through the show, not even making a pretense of giving details or a reasonable explanation. The result, he said: Just 24 hours before going live, each of the five remaining contestants had to prepare a new song of his or her choice.

description: The Indian governments most recent attempt at censorship may be mired in controversy, but it is hardly unusual.

In Delhi, this theorizing often arrives at an intriguing answer: Indian politicians often do one thing in order to accomplish something else altogether.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Dec. 8, 1991 | Republics Declare End of Soviet Union
description: On Dec. 8, 1991, leaders of three of the 15 Soviet Republics, Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, Ukrainian President Leonid M. Kravchuk and the Belarusian leader Stanislav Shushkevich, released a declaration known as the Belavezha Accords, which declared that the Soviet Union was to be dissolved and succeeded by the Commonwealth of Independent States, a loose confederation of former Soviet states.

description: Do you use emoticons when you text, send e-mail or post on social networks? Which symbols are you most likely to use? For what emotions, situations or activities do you wish there were emoticons? If you were to invent a new emoticon (or an emoji, the more elaborate Japanese cousins of emoticons featured in this article), what would it look like?

title: Markets End Lower Ahead of European Summit
description: Stocks fell sharply on Wall Street on Thursday after the European Central Bank appeared to dampen expectations for an expanded bond-buying program and as leaders gathered for a summmit meeting in Brussels aimed at resolving the sovereign debt crisis in Europe.

description: In Todays Times:With no plans to let up on Mitt Romney, President Obamas campaign operatives are increasingly focused Mr. Romneys foremost rival, Newt Gingrich, as polls show him leading the Republican presidential field, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg report.

title: Dickens Anniversary Kicks Off in London
description: Charles Dickens, considered by many to be the first great novelist of the modern city and the age of mass culture, will be widely celebrated throughout Great Britain in 2012, the 200th anniversary of his birth. The first major exhibition will take place from Dec. 9 to June 10 at the Museum of London (150 London Wall; www.museumoflondon.org.uk/dickens). He will be commemorated with paintings, photographs, costumes and objects that illustrate themes from his works, as well as rare, hand-written manuscripts of his novels Bleak House, David Copperfield and Great Expectations. Visitors will also get a chance to see his writing desk and chair. And William Rabans documentary film The Houseless Shadow compares his London with the London of today.

title: Indian Fashion Expands Online
description: Last June, the Web site Exclusively.in debuted in the United States with much fanfare. The concept seemed promising: Indians and Indophiles stateside could choose from a range of India-style clothing, art and home furnishings in a flash-sale format similar to Gilt.coms and receive their purchases in three to five business days.

description: John Madden, the former coach, has long since left the TV booth, and Jon Gruden, the former coach, has become one of the countrys more popular N.F.L. TV analysts.

title: Glogg Before Nog
description: Long before I was old enough to enjoy fully the pleasures of glogg  the Swedish yuletide wine mulled with orange peel and spices  its aroma had made me an admirer. I can still summon that first whiff, when, as a child, I stepped inside a small inn where a caldron of the stuff was simmering. Though this admission will make Scandinavians cringe, the fragrance evoked a warmed-up bowl of Froot Loops, a 10-year-old girls idea of olfactory heaven.

title: In a Dusty Drawer, a Trove of Theatrical Voices
description: Something got twisted about a minute after Seth Cotterman turned on a machine that was no longer new when he was born in 1989.

title: The Frustrations of Trying to Connect On the Go
description: Not so long ago, I could handle being without an Internet connection as long as I could check e-mail and do bare-bones browsing on my cellphone. But now that I keep moving more and more of what I do to the cloud, from accounting to scheduling to collaborating to storing books and documents, I find myself practically incapacitated when Im cut off from a laptop connection.

description: This column appears in the Dec. 11 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Quiz: Do You Have a Generous Relationship?
description: How does your relationship rate on the generosity scale? Here are four questions researchers from the University of Virginias National Marriage Project used to measure generosity, high levels of which are predictive of a stronger relationship. Click on the box in front of your answer and then check your score. And to find out more about how generosity affects your relationship, read the New York Times Magazine column, The Generous Marriage.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A pipeline carrying oil to a refinery in the tense Syrian city of Homs was blown up Thursday, activists and the official Syrian news agency said, casting a huge pillar of black smoke over the citys cloudy horizon.

title: Most European Leaders Agree to Work on Fiscal Treaty
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders, meeting until the early hours of Friday, agreed to sign an intergovernmental treaty that would require them to enforce stricter fiscal and financial discipline in their future budgets. But efforts to get unanimity among the 27 members of the European Union, as desired by Germany, failed as Britain and Hungary refused to go along for now.

description: Readers of The Caucus are political junkies who need to know the latest from the campaign trail and the halls of Congress  and they dont want to wait for it.

title: Once a Prom Queen, Still a Spoiled Princess
description: Shorter than a bad blind date and as sour as a vinegar Popsicle, Young Adult shrouds its brilliant, brave and breathtakingly cynical heart in the superficial blandness of commercial comedy. More radically than J. Edgar or even Greenberg, this movie, written by Diablo Cody and directed by Jason Reitman, challenges the dreary conventional wisdom that a movie protagonist must be likable. Along the way, it systematically demolishes a china shop full of shopworn sentimental touchstones about  for starters  high school, small-town life, heterosexuality, Minnesota and the capacity of human beings to change, learn and grow.

title: Week 14 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Cowboys vs. Giants
description: One of the more overlooked statistics in football is penalty rate. Penalty yards per play is one of the more consistent attributes of N.F.L. teams, second only to offensive pass efficiency. Penalty rates effect on game outcomes isnt as large as that of other team attributes, but in terms of predicting winners its consistency makes it as important as things like running efficiency and interception rates.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 8
description: Adam Nagourney writes about Jay Carson and Chris Lehane, two former Democratic operatives in Washington who serve as the models for political consultants in different Hollywood movies. The Carson-inspired character was at the heart of The Ides of March, directed by George Clooney; Mr. Lehane is a writer and producer of Knife Fight, slated for release early next year, which also focuses on a political consultant. Both worked for President Bill Clinton, Mr. Nagourney writes, and not surprisingly, each movie has an older male candidate who has sexual relations with an intern. But more generally, he writes that the movies go beyond the usual Hollywood glorification of political consultants, offering dark and at times unsettling accounts of what is done in the name of winning elections.

OnLive is one of a few companies that are delivering games over the Internet, with the hard work being done by servers in the cloud. This allows them to be played on devices like the iPad and Kindle Fire that do not have the computing horsepower of a traditional gaming console or PC.

Mr. Corzine, also the former head of Goldman Sachs and a former New Jersey governor, had been called to testify Thursday morning about his most recent role as the former head of MF Global Holdings, a brokerage firm whose collapse in October stemmed from the European debt crisis.

title: Seeing Things | Matthias Merkel Hess
description: Buckets, trash cans, gas cans, laundry hampers and milk crates. Matthias Merkel Hess, a Los Angeles artist, reimagines mundane containers, made to hold everything from gasoline to dirty socks, as ceramic sculptures that are clever, quirky and surprisingly graceful. In his show Bucketry, at L.A.s Acme Gallery, on view through Dec. 21, he has expanded his quotidian repertory to include several new forms, including those of Styrofoam coolers and laundry hampers, the latter rendered in stoneware in various shapes and sizes.

title: 36 Hours: Lake Placid, N.Y.
description: Over the last few decades, this two-time Winter Olympics host has been adding non-Olympic attractions.

title: 36 Hours: Lake Placid, N.Y.
description: LAKE PLACID can feel cryogenically frozen in time  1980 to be exact, which was when this secluded pocket of the Adirondacks hosted its second Winter Olympics. The towering ski jumps and toboggan runs, not to mention the Miracle on Ice hockey rink, look much as they did when Jimmy Carter was in office. But over the last few decades Lake Placid has quietly been adding non-Olympic attractions, including sophisticated farm-to-table restaurants, higher-grade lodgings and a gleaming convention center. Luckily the downtown has not lost its aura of Adirondack authenticity, with A-frame cottages and unpretentious boutiques drawing plenty of nonskiers. If the town were not smothered in Olympic logos, visitors might forget about its Olympics connections and think they had wandered into an idyllic Swiss hamlet.

title: A Veteran in Billy Crystals Corner
description: The director Garry Marshalls career has spanned 50 years of television and movies and produced classics and blockbusters from Happy Days to Beaches and Pretty Woman. He is a member of Hollywoods old guard, which means hes a transplanted New Yorker with a borscht belt sense of humor, and hes still on his first wife (49 years and counting). Hes also a veteran of ensemble pieces (Valentines Day) and light, family-pleasing fare (The Princess Diaries).

title: Bill Maher Concert Will Introduce New Yahoo! Comedy Channel

title: Need a Pardon? Donate to a Congressman. Being White Also Helps
description: Its been a decade since the uproar over President Bill Clintons eleventh-hour pardon of Marc Richthe fugitive financier whose ex-wife gave $450,000 to the Clinton Presidential Libraryprompted his successor to reform the pardons process. President George W. Bush increased the role of career officials in the Justice Departments small pardons office in recommending which applications should be granted.

A locavore praised the taste of edible weeds picked along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. And a food publicist fretted that a photographers flash might compromise the integrity of the foods color story.

title: Huntsman Lashes Out at Romney and Gingrich

description: DALLAS  The Los Angeles Angels rattled the baseball world Thursday by reaching agreement on a 10-year contract for a reported $254 million with Albert Pujols, the premier player in the game.

title: Hugh Jackman Keeps His Pants On
description: IT takes two to be Hugh. The most adored performer on Broadway at the moment is, without question, Hugh Jackman, both of him. Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway, at the Broadhurst Theater, has created this seasons most virulent case of box office fever by presenting the snazziest single double act New York has known since Alice Ripley and Emily Skinner played Siamese twins in Side Show 14 years ago.

title: A Case of Whines
description: Fans of college sports have to wonder what rabbit hole they stepped into on days like Wednesday, when the headlines are full of developments involving sexual abuse charges against coaches, alongside the news that the Big East just absorbed five teams whose only common trait is that they are east of Guam. Not that they are remotely comparable events, but put them together with the N.C.A.A.s sudden belief that it can step in and cure everything and more rumblings that a so-overdue-the-fines-are-tripling football playoff is inevitable, and well, were expecting Alice to join our Wonderland any minute now.

title: The Holiday Finger-Food Combination Generator
description: Unless you have servants, there is an inclination toward panic when guests drop by, invited or not. I get that. But given that you are likely to entertain at some point in the next two weeks, you might as well arm yourself, by which I mean: buy some stuff. If you lay in a few good-tasting and versatile supplies, you can produce some pretty mean little canaps (or canap-like creations) without much effort.

title: U.S. Climate Envoy Seems to Shift Stance on Timetable for New Talks

title: Ovechkin Scores, but Is He Back on Track?

title: Kids, Want Some Cereal With Your Sugar?

But its all too easy to agree to a little experimentation and come home with a box of Honey Nut Cheerios, only to realize that a serving contains more sugar than three Chips Ahoy cookies.

title: Signing for Rodriguez Money Is the Easy Part
description: It appears as if the Albert Pujols sweepstakes is over and that Arte Moreno and the Angels have landed baseballs greatest active hitter for a whopping 10 years and at least $250 million.

title: Radio Had a Voice. Louie Gave It a Face.
description: Someone had to take the promotional picture for the Mutual Broadcasting Systems Deadline program, showing the host, Louise Snyder, holding a large turkey. (It was Thanksgiving, after all.) Mutuals publicity photographer in the 1950s and 60s was Louis Nemeth, who had a much greater talent  and a much more interesting story  than his 8-by-10 glossies ever revealed. Over the course of 93 years, he moved all of three blocks in Hungarian Yorkville, from East 68th Street to East 65th Street. But his career also took him to the Buchenwald concentration camp during World War II. There, in April 1945, as a member of the 165th Signal Photo Company, he spent three days documenting the horrors uncovered after the camps liberation. Maybe he used the next decades to create so many innocuous photo fantasies because he had already seen enough reality to last a lifetime. A video and a longer article are on Lens.

title: New N.B.A. Deal Is Expected to Be Approved Thursday
description: The second-longest labor crisis in N.B.A. history is expected to reach its conclusion Thursday afternoon, with a vote to adopt a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Pearce to Ride for First Time Since 2009 Accident
description: In the weeks and months after the champion snowboarder Kevin Pearce sustained a traumatic brain injury while training on a halfpipe, and even while he was in a coma in a Utah hospital nearly two years ago, his friends and fans provided support through a simple slogan: I Ride for Kevin.

title: Extreme Cleaning for the Holidays
description: Children love to wake up to a house full of presents during the winter holidays. But for the grown-ups, one of the best gifts of all is waking up to a clean house. Todays Home section offers advice from extreme cleaners.

title: Romney Super PAC Assails Gingrich
description: 7:31 p.m. | Updated A well-financed but largely unseen independent political group supporting Mitt Romney surfaced on Thursday in a big way, saying it was putting $3.1 million down on advertising in Iowa.

title: The Case Against Ending Food Drives
description: Over on Slate yesterday, the new Moneybox columnist Matthew Yglesias sounded off on food drives. Having to pick up or sort your donations of random cans is highly inefficient. Much of the stuff that people remove from their pantries is unusable because its old or its junk food, he said. Plus, most food banks, he noted, can buy highly discounted bulk food in a variety of ways.

title: Dispatch | Eating in Barbados
description: There are worse fates than being stuck in Barbados for a long weekend, as I was last month, having tagged along with my lady friend to a conference at the University of the West Indies. I had been told that Barbados, the most British of Caribbean isles, is also among the most delicious, so I resolved to eat my way across it, a journey that involved much driving on roads with no signs and much sipping of Mount Gay Extra Old rum, but of course never at the same time. (If you visit Barbados, you will be extolled the virtues of house-made rum punch  it is often poured out of bottles that look as if they once held bleach  but this cloying potion guarantees a terrible hangover. Instead, drink the local rums neat or with fresh juice.)

title: The Nursing Home Exodus, Part 2
description: In January, when he was only 91, Edwin Murphy awoke in a hospital in Albuquerque, N.M., and learned that hed had a heart attack.

title: Now 80, George Washington Bridge Will Undergo Repairs
description: The George Washington Bridge is a cathedral of steel cables and beams, a stark, glimmering span that has become a civil engineering landmark, not to mention the busiest vehicular bridge in the world.

title: Record Number of Journalists in Jail, Report Finds
description: A new report from the Committee to Protect Journalists found that the number of journalists and employees imprisoned for doing their jobs around the world rose sharply in 2011, with the largest jump seen in the Middle East, where popular uprisings have toppled governments and dominated the news.

title: John Hurt in 'Krapp's Last Tape'
description: John Hurt in Samuel Becketts Krapps Last Tape, now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The video was recorded by the Shakespeare Theater Company during the shows run in Washington.

title: The Heisman View From Wisconsin: Montee Ball
description: Throughout the day Thursday, The Quad will feature posts about Heisman Trophy contenders by sports writers at the candidates universities.

title: Audio of Egyptian Military Briefing to Foreign Reporters
description: As my colleague David D. Kirkpatrick reports, the Egyptian military leadership on Wednesday held a news conference with foreign journalists in which it revealed its intention to control the constitutional process despite the results of parliamentary elections, which have been dominated so far by Islamist parties.

title: Lens: Alex Webb 2
description: Lens: Alex Webb 2

title: Commissar Putin Speaks
description: I said half-jokingly the other day that its sometimes hard to tell the difference between Soviet-era Russia and Putin-era Russia. Prime Minister Vladimir Putin has proved me wrong. If you ignore the relatively bountiful supply of toilet paper, its impossible to tell the difference. His reaction to the elections on Sunday and his complaints about foreign agitators were straight from Pravda.

title: Taiwan Vote Draws Mainland Interest, and One Mainlander
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  A resident of mainland China was apparently so beguiled by this islands coming elections and the promise of democracy that he spent seven hours paddling through the sea in an effort to see them with his own eyes.

title: City Targets Jane Addams High for Closing
An Earth Where the Droids Feel at Home
description: THE images simmering in the French photographer Cdric Delsauxs Dark Lens series are an unsettling confluence of hyper-real cityscapes, a post-postmodern sense of humor ... and characters from Star Wars.

title: Keep Watching the Skies
description: The cityscapes of the photographer Cdric Delsaux are infiltrated by characters from Star Wars.

title: Alex Webbs Dialogue With the Streets
description: Alex Webbs photographs have the compositional complexity befitting the best street photographers. But instead of wandering among urban canyons or cosmopolitan boulevards  which he has  he has redefined the genre over the course of three decades in dusty border towns and tropical climes where the streets may not even be paved.

title: Europe Disappoints. Again.
description: This week some smart people thought they knew what was going to happen in Europe.

title: Gingrich, Ahead in Polls, Is Still Selling Books
description: Even as he widens his lead in the polls, Newt Gingrich spends substantial time on an activity that raised questions about his ultimate motive when he was a back-of-the-pack candidate: selling and signing $25 copies of his books.

title: Iran Shows Video It Says Is of U.S. Drone
description: Iran paraded what its military described as a captured C.I.A. stealth drone on national television on Thursday and lodged an official diplomatic protest, portraying the visual images as an intelligence and propaganda windfall in its conflict with the West over its nuclear program.

title: TimesCast | December 8, 2011
description: Russias prime minister accuses the United States of inciting election protests, and Mexicos booming business of recycling car batteries leads to growing cases of lead poisoning.

title: Two Dead in Shooting on Virginia Tech Campus
description: For more on the shooting, see the later report, Violence Revisits Virginia Tech After Two Are Killed in Shooting.

title: Stress Test Reveals European Banks Need More Capital
description: 8:59 p.m. | Updated

title: Fees Climb in Tribune Company Case
description: Thursday is the third anniversary of the bankruptcy case of the Tribune Company, which was purchased in a highly leveraged deal by the real estate magnate Sam Zell in 2007 and went broke a year later. The lack of resolution in the $13 billion deal has tested the patience of employees, but according to a report issued on Wednesday by Fitch Ratings, the credit agency, theres been plenty of upside for the lawyers involved in the case.

title: Boston Mayor Issues Deadline to Occupy Protesters
description: BOSTON  Protesters at Occupy Boston began preparing for the possibility of a police raid on Thursday, after Mayor Thomas M. Menino issued his first ultimatum for them to decamp.

title: Coaching Searches Continue at U.C.L.A. and Arizona State
description: The coaching searches at Arizona State and U.C.L.A. have recently taken more more twists than a low-budget reality show.

title: Could a Reconceived Cinderella Get Invited to a Broadway Ball?
description: The first Broadway production of Rodgers and Hammersteins Cinderella is in the works for the 2012-13 theater season, with a new libretto by Douglas Carter Beane (Lysistrata Jones, Sister Act) based on the 1957 television musical that starred Julie Andrews, the producer Robyn Goodman said on Thursday.

title: Trailer: In Darkness
description: The trailer for "In Darkness," a drama based on the true story of Jews in Poland who escaped the Nazis by hiding in sewers.

title: Obama Backs Limit on Sale to Teenagers of Morning-After Pill
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, noting that he was the father of two daughters, threw his wholehearted support on Thursday behind a decision by his health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, not to allow emergency contraceptives to be sold over the counter to young teenagers.

title: NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Borse Consider Deal Options
description: LONDON  The $9 billion merger between Deutsche Brse and NYSE Euronext could be in jeopardy if European antitrust authorities force more concessions from the exchanges, including the potential sale of lucrative derivatives businesses.

title: Perry Would Not Demand Discharge if Dont Ask Returned
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has sharply criticized President Obamas repeal of the dont ask, dont tell policy on gays serving in the military. But if the policy were reinstated, he would not demand the expulsion of service members who have disclosed their homosexuality since the policy was repealed in September.

title: Trading Anthony and Calling Nets Makes Sense for Knicks
description: Finally and fittingly, the Knicks appear to have woken up to a not-so-harsh reality and to a world of immediate possibility. Gone, apparently, is their three-superstar agenda, replaced by a more original, and practical, championship-contending blueprint.

title: The Heisman View From Baylor: Robert Griffin III
description: Throughout the day Thursday, The Quad will feature posts about Heisman Trophy contenders by sports writers at the candidates universities.

title: Finding Reasons to Deploy to Afghanistan
description: I distinctly remember how sunny it was on the beach in Barcelona, Spain, when I received the e-mail about deploying to Afghanistan. It was May 2011, and I was living in Barcelona partly to improve my Spanish, but mostly to just enjoy life.

title: Perry and Bachmann Also Pass on Trump Debate
description: 6:51 p.m. | Updated MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Representative Michele Bachmann have joined other candidates, including Mitt Romney, in passing on Donald Trumps Dec. 27 debate in Iowa. Mr. Perrys campaign issued this statement on Thursday:

title: Jay-Z to Hold Benefit Concerts at Carnegie Hall
description: 6:03 p.m. | Updated

title: 12 Schools Named for Closing
State Taxes Rise Across the U.S.
description: State tax revenues rose last quarter compared with a year earlier, according to preliminary data from the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University at Albany. This was the seventh straight quarter of growth, and is happy news for states struggling with budget shortfalls in the wake of the Great Recession.

title: Warner Music Says Losses Grew in the Quarter
description: The Warner Music Group reported increased losses for its fourth quarter and fiscal year on Thursday, with growth in digital music not enough to offset the companys interest costs and lagging overall music sales.

title: Excerpt: Stick Fly on Broadway
description: A scene from Lydia R. Diamond's play at the Cort Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Republicans Unveil Plan for Payroll Tax
description: WASHINGTON  Pivoting to challenge President Obama and Senate Democrats, House Republicans said Thursday that they would forge ahead with a payroll tax holiday bill that includes an oil pipeline opposed by the president and that looks to changes in social programs to pay for the tax cut and added unemployment benefits.

title: Pictures of the Day: Congo and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Congo, Syria and Russia.

title: Fte Accompli | Valentino Goes Virtual
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: All That Work for 2 Points
description: When Minnesota Vikings defensive end Jared Allen tackled Denvers Willis McGahee in the end zone last Sunday, he rose to his feet and clapped his hands together over his head, the instantly recognizable signal for a safety.

title: Ford, Feeling Secure, To Resume Dividends
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company on Thursday said it would resume paying quarterly dividends to its shareholders for the first time since 2006, as it closes out its third consecutive profitable year.

title: Despite Higher Admission Fee, Hller Show Draws Record Crowds to New Museum
description: The New Museum, which recently raised its general admission price to pay for extra workers to accommodate the crowds for its exhibition of the work of Carsten Hller, said Thursday that the show  a highbrow funhouse with a slide, a sensory deprivation tank and a slow-motion carousel  had become the most highly attended show in the museums 35-year history.

title: In $2.5 Million Judgment, Court Finds Blogger Is Not a Journalist
description: Academics and Web thinkers have spent a lot of time jawboning about whether a blogger fits the definition of a journalist. Its an endless discussion, but this week in Oregon, the debate turned costly for one blogger.

title: N.F.L. Fast Forward: Week 14 and Beyond
description: Judy Battista sits down with Connor Ennis to discuss the playoff chances of the Giants and Jets, whether any team can stop the Green Bay Packers and the future of Peyton Manning and the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Three Artists Expanding Their Horizons
description: This week we talk to three artists who are expanding their horizons: the jazz violinist Jenny Scheinman, the Australian pop star Gotye and the indie folk singer-songwriter Sharon Van Etten.

title: Lyons Walkover Untainted by Fraud, UEFA Says
description: Lyons eye-popping 7-1 win at Dinamo Zagreb on Wednesday, which helped it rescue a spot in the 16-team knockout round of the UEFA Champions League, was untainted by suspicious gambling patterns that could indicate match-fixing.

title: In Uniform at Protests, and in Trouble as a Result
description: Among the more colorful protesters to emerge from Occupy Wall Street was a uniformed former police commander from the Philadelphia police. His name is Ray Lewis, and, after retiring as a captain in 2004 after 24 years of service, he became active in the world of social justice.

title: Twitter Tries to Simplify Its Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitter unveiled an ambitious new design on Thursday that is intended to draw new users, keep them on the social network longer and attract more advertisers.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.8
description: Toronto Raptors forward Linas Kleiza prepared for the coming N.B.A. season, and the European short course swimming championships began in Poland.

title: A Community on the Cliffs
description: In 2008, Ester Jove Soligue, a Spanish photographer, began documenting a collection of shacks tucked along cliffs in Union City, N.J.

title: Field Notes From This Years Application Season
description: To get an on-the-ground glimpse of this years admissions cycle, The Choice reached out this week to a handful of college counselors across the country to hear what trends they had been observing.

title: Fight Fans, Get Ready for Thatcher vs. Nobbs
description: Do we have a diva showdown on our hands? Next week awards-o-philes will have a difficult choice between The Iron Lady (Meryl Streep as Margaret Thatcher) and Albert Nobbs (Glenn Close as a woman passing as a male butler in Victorian Dublin), whose premieres and splashy afterparties are scheduled for the same night. (Never fear, the Bagger will miraculously figure out a way to be in both places at once.)

title: Quiet Riot | The Art of Wilfredo Prieto
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Answers to Questions About Chinas Economy
description: On Wednesday, Economix asked readers to submit questions for David Barboza, who has reported for The Times from Shanghai since 2004. Mr. Barbozas article, Entrepreneurs Rival in China: The State, was published on the front page of Thursdays paper.

title: Why Nene Should Be in Demand
description: Free agency officially begins on Dec. 9, but the chase has already begun. There are no traditional superstars in the bunch, but the best relative talents will still land maximum or near-max contracts under the leagues new collective bargaining agreement. Heres look at one of the terrific  if likely overpaid  candidates for such a deal.

title: TimesCast | Putin Blames Sec. Clinton
description: December 8, 2011 - In a strikingly personal tone, Russia's Prime Minister accuses Secretary of State Hillary Clinton of inciting election protests.

title: Identity Theft and a Happy App
description: Daniel Mohan of ID Watchdog explains how peoples identities can be stolen (and what to do about it) and Will Lucas discusses Thankyouaga.in, a new social app for positive posts.

title: Irish Archbishop Who Died in 73 Is Linked to Abuse
description: DUBLIN  The former archbishop of Dublin, John Charles McQuaid, widely regarded as the most powerful Catholic prelate in modern Irish history, stands accused of serial child sexual abuse, The Irish Times newspaper said Thursday.

title: Europes Debt Crisis Brings Two Former Foes Closer Than Ever
description: BERLIN  In the battle over how to save the euro, Germany has plenty of leverage but not many friends. Among its staunchest supporters is also one of the most surprising, its historic enemy, Poland.

title: Lousy Filibusters: Richard Cordray Edition
description: It seems like only yesterday that Republicans blocked President Obamas nominee for the D.C. Circuit appeals court, Caitlin Halligan, for no good reason. Actually, it was two days ago, and the Republicans have already moved onto yet more obstruction. Today, they blocked the confirmation of Richard Cordray: President Obamas pick to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

title: A Somber New Years Eve for Solar?
description: While renewable energy advocates have long argued that government subsidies for the sector are dwarfed by those for more traditional energy industries, they have had a more poignant complaint since the onset of the recession: one of the subsidies they do get, an investment tax credit, has been rendered nearly useless by the general business downturn.

title: The Jig Is Up, Or Is It? Bonnie & Clyde Only Selling Tickets Through End of the Year
description: In an unusual business move, a lead producer of the new Broadway musical Bonnie & Clyde said on Thursday that performances beyond December have been cancelled and tickets are only on sale through Dec. 30  yet a closing notice for the show has not been posted.

title: In Syria, Expelling the Peacemakers
description: Jerusalem

title: What Wasnt Passed On
description: THREE years ago, while my mother was recovering from major abdominal surgery, I made a trip to upstate New York to help my parents. The visit went surprisingly well. Within 48 hours, my mother was up and about. In the evenings, my brothers stopped over to drink beer and eat whatever my father and I had cooked up. Things seemed easier with us than they had been in a long time.

title: Virginia Tech Shootings
description: Two killed in shootings on Virginia Tech campus.

title: Five Ways to Flip Your Classroom With The New York Times
description: What is a flipped classroom?

title: Wheelies: The Leap-Year Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Lens: Darshan by Niko
description: Lens: Darshan by Niko

title: The Presidents Osawatomie Speech
description: A little over a month ago, I wrote a column about the problems with contemporary liberalisms prescription for what ails the American middle class. My argument, in a nutshell, was that wage stagnation and social immobility are real issues, but that simply soaking the rich in order to invest more money in our existing public institutions (propping up Medicare and Social Security, preserving and expanding government employment, etc.) wouldnt necessarily do much to increase prosperity and mobility for the next generation of Americans, and might actually have perverse consequences instead.

title: Former Bon Apptit Editor to Run Digital Food Magazine
description: Barbara Fairchild, who stepped down last year as editor of Bon Apptit, was named editor in chief of Real Eats, a weekly digital magazine about food.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 83
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared Representative Jerrold Nadlers call for a federal investigation of police conduct at Occupy Wall Street ridiculous. This is not a federal issue, the mayor said. There are plenty of investigations going on. He added, regarding Mr. Nadler, If he would spend more time getting us homeland security money, maybe hed make the streets safer. [Inside Politics]

title: Pretzel Twists Onstage, Not at the Snack Bar
description: Wonderment comes roughly in four-minute intervals at the New Victory Theater these days.

title: Rare Ten Commandments Text Added to Dead Sea Scrolls Exhibition
description: Discovery Times Square  the crowd-pleasing exhibition space on West 44th Street that is now the host to The Dead Sea Scrolls: Life and Faith in Biblical Times   announced that it planned to briefly add a new scroll to the show, one of the oldest and best-preserved manuscripts of the Ten Commandments.

title: Viewpoint: Large Troubled Schools Are Better Off Closed
Lucky Chengs, East Village Drag Cabaret, Is Moving Uptown
description: Lucky Chengs, the popular East Village cabaret restaurant where drag queens entertain tourists and assorted other partiers, is going uptown. Its owner, Hayne Suthon, said Wednesday that it would move in the next six months to a spot on West 52nd Street.

title: 2011: The Year in Memes
description: What Internet memes and online fads captivated the Web in 2011?

title: In Vail, a Burger Gets a Lift
description: IT has always been a challenge to serve good food at ski resorts, where restaurants and cafeterias might be 10,000 feet above sea level. Part of the problem is that much of the food in this snowy environment arrives at the mountaintop, appropriately enough, completely frozen.

title: Just One Look | Maria Cornejo
description: Becoming one with an urban environment is not something easily achieved through clothes alone, but thats what Maria Cornejo sought to do with the pieces in her pre-fall collection. The prints  a photorealistic rendering of the Brooklyn Promenade (abstracted from a picture that Cornejo snapped with her iPhone); a stretched camouflage; a pixilated jacquard that looks equally industrial and luxeall mimic city landscapes in ways that might let their wearers fit seamlessly into the citys graphic sprawl. Mix the collections stripe-like jacquards, like so, and leave the countryside behind.

title: Star Turnout for Valentino, Rain or Shine
description: Wednesday nights torrential rainfall had a few unexpected effects at the party for Valentino Garavanis new virtual museum at the IAC Building. For one thing, many of the late-arriving guests were torn between watching the streaming videos of the designers career highlights along one wall and the streaming deluge of rain on the West Side Highway, seen through the opposite wall of windows.

title: Matta: A Centennial Celebration
description: Pace Gallery

title: From Kenwood House, Borrowed Treasures
description: Kenwood House in North London is known for its extraordinary collection of paintings by Rembrandt, Vermeer, van Dyck and Gainsborough. Its last owner, Edward Cecil Guinness, the first Earl of Iveagh, was a passionate collector who bequeathed Kenwood along with its art to Britain when he died in 1927. A year later the neo-Classical house and gardens opened to the public, and they have been a magnet for tourists ever since, attracting a million visitors a year.

title: Corin Hewitt: Medium/Deep
description: Laurel Gitlen

title: American Letters 1927-1947: Jackson Pollock & Family
description: Jason McCoy Gallery

title: Paul McCarthy: The Dwarves, the Forests
description: Hauser & Wirth

title: What Sets Us, and Keeps Us, Apart
description: What are we all so afraid of? From spiders to rogue asteroids and beyond, but certainly people would be near the top of any list. Of particular concern would be people who are not like us. Speaking in different languages, dressing oddly, believing in strange gods, motivated by shadowy purposes and desires, they threaten everything we hold dear. So we build walls to keep them away. But since they often live among us, we also create internal systems to police them and keep them under surveillance, lest they conspire and act on their alien intentions.

title: Jean-Frdric Schnyder
description: Swiss Institute Contemporary Art

title: The Life of 'Stick Fly'
description: Condola Rashad talks about performing in Lydia R. Diamond's new Broadway play.

title: Columbia Hires Coach With Ivy and N.F.L. Ties
description: Columbias two-week search for a football coach culminated Thursday with the hiring of Pete Mangurian, a former Ivy League head coach who has worked as an assistant with five N.F.L. teams.

title: The Coming Car Electronics Revolution
description: On Wednesday, Broadcom announced  a series of products that will bring the same kind of communications connectivity seen in home appliances and large data centers to cars.

title: Despite Losses From Strike, Detroit Symphony Voices Optimism
description: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra detailed the financial effects of last seasons bitter six-month strike on Thursday, citing lost ticket sales and donations, but found optimism in many new audience members and better than expected revenues so far this season. The signs this fall have been enormously positive, said Anne Parsons, the president. Another sign was the recent three-year extension given to Leonard Slatkin, the music director, who now will have the title through the 2015-2016 season.

title: Knicks Pursuit of Chandler Could Be Costly
