description: Two years ago this long-neglected cousin to Deer Valley and Park City received a makeover, complete with near chair lifts, food carts and restaurants.

title: Answers From Vivian Toy: The Apartment Critic
description: Vivian S. Toy, a real estate reporter for The Times, answers some questions readers submitted about buying, selling and renting in the city.

title: Reaching for the Sky in Utah
description: A FEW years ago, I packed my skis and did something every winter sports enthusiast should do at least once in a lifetime: take a trip to Utah, a place known for its powder. I met a friend in Salt Lake City and spent a week bouncing between four resorts. We flew around aspens at Deer Valley and nailed jump turns off a ridge at Robert Redfords Sundance Resort. At Snowbird I sailed weightlessly through three feet of the airiest, steepest, untracked powder Id ever skied.

title: Hotel Review: Viceroy Snowmass, Snowmass Village, Colo.
description: UPSHOT

title: Faith and Family Values at Issue for Republicans
description: For the first time in American history, a major political party may be choosing between two leading presidential candidates who are not Protestant. If current polling holds through the Jan. 3 Iowa caucuses and beyond, the Republican nomination will come down to a choice between a Latter-day Saint, or Mormon, and a Roman Catholic.

title: Now Do You See the Smog?
description: BEIJING  This week, as smog forced the closure of roads and the cancellation of flights in northern China, my Beijing landlord called. The pollution is awful, he said. Dont open your windows, and definitely dont go outside.

title: With Trade Voided, Score One for the Laker Haters
description: 9:25 p.m. | Updated

title: Ford Recalls 129,000 Fusions and Mercury Milans After Studs Fracture on Steel Wheels
description: Ford is recalling almost 129,000 of its 2010-11 Ford Fusions and Mercury Milans because the wheel studs on vehicles equipped with 17-inch steel wheels could break, potentially leading to a wheel coming loose and falling off.

title: Ski Trivia!
description: Number of ski areas in New York (the most in the U.S.): 52

title: On Ledge and Online: Solitary Sport Turns Social
description: Last month the climber Tommy Caldwell lived on a nylon ledge hung 1,200 feet up El Capitan, the massive sweep of granite that stands sentinel over Yosemite Valley, for more than two weeks.

title: On the Road with Jamie Oliver
description: While plenty of people know all about Jamie Olivers Food Revolution, the controversial ABC series in which the British chef and activist butted heads with bureaucrats as he quixotically endeavored to improve school lunches in West Virginia and Southern California, fewer Americans know that Mr. Oliver created a whole other TV series about the United States and its food.

title: The Ten Best Books of 2011
description: This week, the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2011; Gerald Marzorati on Love Goes to Buildings on Fire, Will Hermes book about the New York music scene in the 1970s; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; the Timess Susan Chira discusses No Higher Honor, the new memoir by Condoleeza Rice; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Announcing the Lives Contest Winners
description: Back in October we announced a contest, in collaboration with our friends at Figment, in which students were invited to use first lines from The Times Magazines weekly Lives column to start their own short work of fiction.

title: The Giving Spree | Sasha Pivovarova
description: Who: The model and artist Sasha Pivovarova.

title: Zite Introduces a Personalized Magazine for the iPhone
description: Updated 6:05 p.m.: Clarified the business relationship between Zite and Lululemon.

title: In Baseball, Star Power; in the N.B.A., Not So Much
description: If you thought that the N.B.A., which had just spent months proving itself arrogant and remarkably tone-deaf with its nonsensical lockout, would enter the era of labor peace with a desire to prove it was worthwhile for the good of the game, well, the league just proved you dead wrong. Apparently, it decided the season for arrogance and tone-deafness has just begun because it promptly squelched any budding good will by squashing the trade of Hornets guard Chris Paul to the Lakers.

title: Obama Tries on the Cowboy Hat
description: Its been clear for years that President Obama hates the crass salesmanship of American politics, the desperate need to absorb personal credit for governing, like a mayor who puts his name on every new railroad trestle. Although that diffidence has had a priceeven now, most Americans have no idea what road projects were in the presidents 2009 stimulus actit also kept him from appearing insecure in office, and made him look occasionally magnanimous.

title: In Rejecting Treaty, Cameron Is Isolated
description: LONDON  When he rejected a new European accord on Friday that would bind the continent ever closer, Prime Minister David Cameron seemingly sacrificed Britains place in Europe to preserve the pre-eminence of the City, Londons financial district. The question now is whether his stance will someday seem justified, even prescient.

title: Congo Leader Is Declared Winner in Disputed Vote
description: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo  Columns of black smoke from burning tires rose over parts of this capital on Friday as Joseph Kabila, the incumbent president, was declared the official winner of Congos troubled election, defeating his nearest rival by more than 16 percentage points in an outcome that many here feared would stoke new spasms of political violence.

title: Morning T | Nicholas Kirkwood
description: Ts Jane Herman talks to the shoe designer Nicholas Kirkwood about his early days in fashion and some of the shoes that have made him a star.

title: Reining In the Soft Costs of Solar
description: Reducing the cost of installing solar power systems for homes and small commercial properties remains near the top of the Department of Energys to-do list. Early this year, Steven Chu, the energy secretary, unveiled the departments SunShot Initiative, fashioned at least in spirit on the moon shot program, in which the Kennedy administration set out to put a man on the moon.

title: Labor Board Drops Case Against Boeing After Union Reaches Accord
description: The National Labor Relations Board announced on Friday that it was dropping its politically charged case against Boeing, in which it had accused the company of violating federal labor law by opening a new aircraft production plant in South Carolina instead of Washington State.

title: Painting Ryan Gosling, the Video
description: For our video of Ryan Gosling as the Invisible Man, the directors sister, Vanessa Prager, created a painting of the actor. Gosling liked it so much, he bought it.

title: A Coffee Shop Loses Its Nighttime Alter Ego
description: Anybody want to buy a custom-made portable bar, cheap?

title: Club Kids Are Storming Music Museums
description: WE critics have long argued vehemently that if major musical institutions hope to be regarded as vital, modern institutions, they must keep their listeners (and performers) in touch with the ideas, trendy or otherwise, that excite the composers of their time. But truth be told, we are a little bipolar on that subject. Though we criticize the big organizations for fostering a museum culture, we actually value the museums they have become.

title: Tell Them That I Love Photography
description: Jose Gaytan wore lots of hats  dog lover, camera salesman, guitarist. But he topped off all of that by being a dedicated photographer who chronicled the ever-changing Brooklyn waterfront. A masterly colorist, he found beauty in unlikely places and could render the Gowanus Canal into something worthy of Renoir.

title: Arpaio Is Criticized Over Handling of Sex-Crimes Cases
description: GUADALUPE, Ariz.  Although Joe Arpaio calls himself Americas Toughest Sheriff, a growing chorus of local critics want another title for him: Retired.

title: Dont Mess With Gloria Allred
description: During a news conference with your client Sharon Bialek, you said that Herman Cain decided to provide her with his idea of a stimulus package. Are humorous phrases a hallmark of yours? In some instances? Yes. Is it in every? No. Is it appropriate in every one? No. Is it appropriate in some? Yes. Do feminists have a sense of humor? Yes.

title: The Fracturing of Pennsylvania
description: I take issue with Eliza Griswolds description (Nov. 20 )of the farmland in Washington County, Pa., as hardscrabble. As a young man, George Washington surveyed this land for Virginia, of which state Western Pennsylvania was then part. He purchased huge tracts for himself, because he knew it was valuable. Rich and prosperous farms developed, once he sold the land to settlers, and these continued to flourish well into the 20th century.

title: The Dixie Ghostbusters
description: Except for the eerie flickering of our flashlights, we batted away low branches and overgrown shrubs of the old cotton plantation in total darkness. There was no moonlight. It was, Grady Carter noted, a perfect night for ghosts. At that point his nephew Andy held up a hand and pointed into the woods. I heard voices, Andy said. We all stopped. Chris Carter, his cousin, whispered, I see a red light. The spirits of dead slaves, Grady confirmed. A demonic orb.

title: Can the Bulldog Be Saved?
description: Benoit Denizet-Lewis highlights the lifetime of misery that bulldogs have to endure. In my eight years of clinical veterinary practice, 100 percent of the bulldogs I have seen suffer respiratory distress. Anybody persuaded by this article to place welfare first  and disregard what is deemed to be cute  when it comes to choosing a dog saves one more deliberately handicapped animal a lifetime of struggle.

title: The Stop Sign Wasnt Always Red
description: In the early automobile age, American streets existed in a Hobbesian, drive-or-be-plastered state of anarchy. Not only were the streets in those days completely disgusting and filthy, but there were horses and bicycles, and it was just completely chaotic, says Joshua Schank, C.E.O. of the Eno Transportation Foundation, whose namesake and founder, William Phelps Eno, is widely credited with conceiving the stop sign at the turn of the 20th century.

title: Everyone Speaks Text Message
description: When Ibrahima Traore takes his sons to a park in Montclair, N.J., he often sits on a bench and reads. He reads English, French and Arabic, but most of the time he reads NKo, a language few speakers of those languages would recognize. NKo is the standardized writing system for Mande languages, a family of closely related tongues  among them Traores language of Mandinka, but also Jula, Bamana, Koyaga, Marka  spoken, for the most part, in eight West African countries, by some 35 million people. NKo looks like a cross between Arabic and ancient Norse runes, written from right to left in a blocky script with the letters connected underneath. Traore types e-mail to his family on his laptop in NKo, works on his Web site in NKo, tweets in NKo on his iPhone and iPad and reads books and newspapers written in NKo to prepare for the NKo classes he teaches in the Bronx and for his appearances on an Internet radio program to discuss cultural issues around the use of NKo.

title: Weekend TV Guide, Dec. 10-11: Catching Up With Clint
description: Clint Dempsey is the one to watch.

title: A Building With a Heart of Gold
description: ON Columbia Place in Brooklyn Heights, improbably sandwiched between a Sardinian restaurant and a brick-walled cafe, stands a landmark in the history of housing for the poor. Its name is Riverside Houses, and it was created by the 19th-century philanthropist and urban visionary Alfred Tredway White.

title: Elizabeth Lee Sample
description: BACKGROUND The child of a deep-pocketed, deep-rooted family  she is a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution  she came to New York City via Alabama, Bronxville, N.Y., and Fairfield County, Conn. Im just a dumb American, she says.

title: Enjoy the Horses; Skip the Urban Circus
description: THEY may have lost a lot of pastureland to subdivisions over the years, but Connecticuts horses arent galloping off in retreat. There are 11 of them per square mile, according to the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources at the University of Connecticut. That makes the states horse population among the densest in the country (Kentucky has a mere eight per square mile).

title: Brenda S. Powers
description: BACKGROUND The daughter of a Swiss diplomat, she came to New York via the world: Canada, India, Switzerland and Morocco, she says, not mentioning other ports of call, including Bordeaux, London, Rio de Janeiro and So Paulo.

title: A Miss Golden Globe Who Gets It
description: We came to the party with every intention of pooh-poohing it. The annual naming of Miss Golden Globe? With pomp and circumstance? Its frankly the kind of event we wait all year to mock.

title: The Big Spender? Theyll Never Tell
description: ON the list of lifes many mysteries, Manhattan real estate can rank high. Yes, there are the usual metrics  supply, demand and location, location, location  but best not to look to them to explain why something costs what it does, because the answer ultimately is in the cosmos.

title: Emboldened Orchestras Are Embracing the New
description: RECENTLY Bartok trounced Schubert in an impromptu audience poll at Carnegie Hall. I was surprised and delighted. It seemed an indicator, albeit fanciful, that the battle for contemporary music had been won.

title: Mixed Messages at the Puck Building
description: Since September, Jared Kushner has been trying to win approval from the Landmarks Preservation Commission to construct a residential penthouse atop the Puck Building, at Houston and Lafayette Streets, which his family has owned for many years. His first proposal was all but tossed off the roof by the commission in October.

title: Falcone Receives Wells Notice From S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is putting Philip A. Falcone on alert.

title: Just One Look | Thakoon
description: When asked what the focus of this collection is, the designer Thakoon Panichugal pointed to its textures  the cable knits, heathers, mohairs and wool felts; even the prints have a roughness to them. Favorites from the group include a yellow A-line cable-knit dress (bonded to give it bounce, Panichugal says), an oatmeal colored wool coat thats tucked in the back in the prettiest way and a number of pieces made from a combination of crisp white shirting and soft grey cashmere. Here, a shrunken knit-leather jacket over a shirtdress with a built-in sweater and the coolest cable-embellished loafers.

title: Rats to the Rescue in Cage Experiment
description: In the Chinese zodiac, rats are considered witty, imaginative and curious. Now scientists have discovered another attribute.

title: Marc Gasol: A Big Man Worth Big Money
description: Free agency officially begins on Fridayth, but the chase has already begun. There are no traditional superstars in the bunch, but the best relative talents will still score max or near-max contracts under the leagues new collective bargaining agreement. Heres an in-depth look at one of the candidates for such a deal.

title: Big Deal | Where Holly Golightly Maddened Mr. Yunioshi
description: The film Breakfast at Tiffanys spawned many iconic items. The little black dress. The oversize sunglasses. The wide-brimmed black straw hat.

title: A Nighttime Pop-Up in Brooklyn, Nanny Goat Hill Closes
description: It popped up, seemingly out of nowhere, most evenings in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, then disappeared during the day. And now Nanny Goat Hill, a portable wine bar and restaurant, has closed after two and a half months.

title: An App to Take You Deep Into Dickenss London
description: A tourism app that evokes slums, starveling waifs, child labor, pickpockets, brutal jails and gallows might not be everyones idea of a good way to promote their citys past. But for Charles Dickens fanatics  who began Friday to flock to the Museum of Londons exhibition celebrating the 200th anniversary of his birth on Feb. 7, 1812  it will undoubtedly be Dickensian in the best sense of the word.

title: Boston Police Pass on Evicting Occupy Protesters
description: BOSTON  Relieved protesters at Occupy Boston let out cheers and danced in the streets early Friday morning after learning that, despite an eviction notice, the police would not evict or arrest members of the tent city that has existed here since Sept. 30.

title: Undriving.org: Combatting the Associative Guilt of Car Love
description: No matter where you live or what you drive, we all share a common problem: driving can be annoying.

title: A Ghostly Architecture of Naked Trees
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last weeks image.

title: Popcast: Jenny Scheinman, Gotye and Sharon Van Etten
description: The violinist Jenny Scheinman is most often associated with jazz  this week shes performing in a trio with Bill Frisell and Brian Blade at the Village Vanguard  but her eclectic career has taken her all over the musical map. Shes played on projects ranging from country tracks and tours with artists like Rodney Crowell and Jimmie Dale Gilmore to less easily definable efforts like Lulu, this years collaboration between Lou Reed and Metallica. Shes not only an accompanist  her last album, 2008s Jenny Scheinman, was her first vocal record.

title: Spotted on the Street | Ana Lisboa
description: The Girl: Ana Lisboa, a model with IMG Worldwide.

title: Heidi Mount's Utah
description: The model Heidi Mount scales the heights of Moab, Utah.

title: Nearly a Knick, Chandler Will Fill a Big Need in the Teams Middle
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Seven players, none of them named Tyson Chandler, worked out Friday as the Knicks officially opened training camp.

title: Four Afghan Men Held in Acid Attack on Family
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It was after dark when the four gunmen battered their way into the small home in the northern city of Kunduz, threw the father of the family into his cowshed and broke into his house to throw corrosive acid on his three school-age daughters.

title: Tebow, Eli Manning, Rex Ryan: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers questions:

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 9
description: Subjects include Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos birthday, a beard competition and a study of sleep on the subway.

title: U.N. Chief Pays Surprise Visit to Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Ban Ki-moon became the first United Nations secretary general to set foot in this war-ravaged country in almost 20 years on Friday, and he promised to relocate the United Nations political office for Somalia to Mogadishu next year, though other United Nations officials were skeptical.

title: Pay for Our Mistakes? Not Us
description: It is nice to have the power to never have to pay for your errors. To get that kind of clout, you have to have a credible threat to make the rest of the world miserable if you are inconvenienced.

title: Library President Loses License in D.W.I. Case
description: The president of the New York Public Library had his drivers license revoked after he pleaded guilty on Friday to having driven while intoxicated last month.

title: On Our Radar: A European Warning to Big Emitters
description: The European Union warns that unless China, the United States and India agree to commit themselves to setting a legally binding target next year for restricting emissions, United Nations climate talks could collapse. [Reuters]

title: Weekend Fare
description: Alain Ducasse will be the first chef to be awarded the Trophee des Arts, which the French Institute Alliance Francaise established in 1992 to recognize a person who enhances the cultural relationship between France and the United Sates. The presentation is a black-tie gala at the Institute, 583 Park Avenue (63rd Street), on the Upper East Side, and starts at 7 p.m. Some tickets are still available and can be purchased by calling (646) 388-6632. They are $500 for those 34 and under and $1,500 for patron tickets.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $9.79 million
description: A five-bedroom penthouse at the Laureate, a new condominium at Broadway and 76th Street, was the biggest sale of the week, going for $9.79 million, according to city records.

title: The Euro Has Been Very Good  for Germany
description: In the first years of the euro, which was introduced in 1999, countries on the edge of the euro zone benefited economically more than Germany. But over the last five years, the situation has been reversed. The charts show data for euro zone countries divided into four groups. Germany and France, the two largest countries, are shown individually. Five Northern Europe economies, which some have speculated could join Germany and France in a new strong euro zone, are shown as a group labeled Northern countries. The other 10 countries are combined in a group labeled Peripheral countries. These include all the countries currently receiving European assistance, as well as Spain, Italy and other countries.

title: More Post-Season News and a Look Back at 2011
description: The post-season news is still piling in this week as Formula One makes a slew of announcements before taking a break for Christmas.

title: More Post-Season News and a Look Back at 2011
description: The post-season news is still piling in this week as Formula One makes a slew of announcements before taking a break for Christmas.

title: Inside Aldea
description: Although this Portuguese restaurant has a clean, sleek and relatively spare look, it has a much more complex taste.

title: TimesCast | December 9, 2011
description: The European Union members agree to modify a treaty, but Britain refuses; the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof in Cairo; and Russian opposition activists plan a protest in Moscow for Saturday.

title: Bloomberg Defends Police Treatment of Reporters
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday vigorously defended the New York Police Departments treatment of the news media during the clearing of the Occupy Wall Street encampment from Zuccotti Park.

title: Gingrich Calls Palestinians an Invented People
description: Does Newt Gingrich believe in a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict? Democratic and Republican administrations have adopted that framework, but Mr. Gingrich raised the possibility he might break with it, calling Palestinians an invented people and the current stalled peace process delusional.

title: Elis Bread Opens at Grand Central Terminal
description: The departures and arrivals have come quickly this fall for Grand Central Terminals shops and vendors. Now Eli Zabar has opened a bakery, Elis Bread in the Grand Central Market space previously occupied mainly by Corrado Bread and Pastry.

title: A Now-You-See-It, Now-You-Dont Ad Attacks Gingrich
description: Its one of the oldest political tricks in the book. And it seems to have worked brilliantly.

title: French Press | Laurence Dolig Makes Her Stateside Debut
description: The Parisian designer Laurence Dolig makes exactly the kinds of clothes that give French dressing a good name: not too complicated, not too self-conscious, but still a little sexy. Now in its sixth season, Doligs namesake line will finally be made available stateside this spring, at Mick Margo in Greenwich Village, Jill Roberts in Los Angeles and at shopbop.com. To be sold in America feels like such an achievement, says the designer. If you make it in the U.S., you can make it anywhere. The collections clean white boat neck sundresses, plaid trousers and workmans denim jackets pair beautifully with her handbags, which come in two basic styles: a two-tone tote and a more structured satchel. My collection is literally my wardrobe says Dolig. I love designers like Poiret and Yves Saint Laurent, but my collection is special to me because I can actually afford to wear it every day!

title: Corzines Testimony Came With Plenty of Caveats
description: MF Globals former chief executive, Jon S. Corzine, was gingerly questioned by the House Agriculture Committee for almost three hours on Thursday, in the end saying little enlightening about the firms collapse or the customer money that has gone missing.

title: Police Crack Down on Prospect Park Bicyclists
description: The bright orange barrels appeared last month, making a short, downhill section of Brooklyns Prospect Park seem like a highway construction zone. And still not everybody slowed.

title: Forget DiCaprio, Another Leonardo Will Be a Film Star
description: If you cant get into Leonardo da Vinci: Painter at the Court of Milan, now at the National Gallery in London  and you cant unless youre willing to get in line at dawn with all the other people hoping to snag one of the 500 tickets a day not sold in advance for the blockbuster exhibition  then soon you might at least be able to go see the movie.

title: YouTube Buys Company That Processes Music Royalties
description: 5:53 p.m. | Updated In an effort to streamline its often complex relations with music publishers, YouTube has acquired RightsFlow, an upstart company in New York that processes royalties for the music industry.

title: When Thoughts Turn to Sex, or Not
description: The Gist Men dont think about sex all day.

title: Curtain Up on Act II for the Tooth Fairy
description: AFTER months of buildup, the moment arrived without fanfare. My 6-year-old daughter, Tybee, was reading a book after dinner, mindlessly wiggling her first loose tooth, when suddenly it popped out in her hand.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 14s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Vintage Skiing
description: From Vermont to Colorado to New Mexico, a photo essay on skiing from another era.

title: Mary Boyle and Matthew Long
description: DURING the transit strike of 2005, the New York City firefighter Matt Long hopped onto his bike to ride from his East 48th Street apartment to the Randalls Island fire academy where he helped train the citys bravest. As he crossed 52nd Street, a chartered bus made a right turn from a middle lane and hit him. When he awoke a month later, he learned the grisly details: he had been impaled by his bike and dragged under the bus, his body held together by little more than his bike shorts. He was given 68 pints of blood and a 1 percent chance of survival.

title: Getting a Grip on Taxes Before the Storm Hits
description: THIS has been a year of financial uncertainty, both here and abroad. But one thing is sure for next year: taxes will definitely be on politicians agendas and voters minds.

title: 25 Schools Could Be Closed or Truncated
Redistricting Roundup: Walsh to Run in His Current District
description: So kids, its Friday; time for a little redistricting roundup!

title: Long Roads That Led, Finally, to the Altar
description: GUESTS are expected to get misty-eyed at weddings, but during a recent ceremony at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Sacramento, even the minister was moved to tears.

title: While Germany Prospers, Unemployment Strangles Others
description: DURING the first nine years of the euros existence, it seemed to be a great success for what are now called the peripheral countries of the euro zone. Able to borrow at low rates  in some cases for the first time  and benefiting from a buoyant global economy, many countries boomed.

title: Wal-Mart Discloses an Internal Inquiry
description: Wal-Mart said in a filing Thursday that it might have violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and that it had begun an internal investigation, hired outside counsel and alerted the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Just One Look | Donna Karan
description: Donna Karan came to this collection by going back to the beginning: a black and white palette (on tuxedo jackets with plunging necklines, for example), the meeting of masculine and feminine (with boxy coats atop leggy skirts with high slits) and utter elegance (like an exaggerated bow on an all-out evening dress). Here, a 50s-inspired full skirt and cotton cross blouse remind us how simple and sexy a cinched waist can be.

title: New Steps Ahead in the South of France
description: Cannes, France

title: Stern Says Owners Did Not Influence Veto of Trade
description: In the wake of the N.B.A.s controversial decision to veto a three-team trade involving Chris Paul, Commissioner David Stern issued the following statement Friday:

title: Illinois Hires Toledos Beckman
description: Illinois has found its new football coach, and the Illini are not going for the big-name splashy hire. Tim Beckman, now the former coach of Toledo, will be introduced by the universityFriday afternoon at a news conferencein Champaign, according to The Chicago Tribune.

title: The Most Important Election Ever
description: While campaigning in New York last weekend, Newt Gingrich described the 2012 presidential race as the most important election since 1860. He told Tea Party activists gathered in Dallas the same thing in October. Perhaps out of modesty, Mr. Gingrich did not explicitly compare himself to Abraham Lincoln, who won that particular contest.

title: On TV, Nice Guys Finish First
description: THIS seasons highest-rated reality show was not some sleazefest of pixeled images and bleeped-out words, but a piece of soothing, neo-vaudevillian family entertainment: ABCs Dancing With the Stars.

title: Commuting Puzzle: Why Driving Is Rewarded Over Taking the Bus
description: This is the story of a tax break that can be worth four figures each year per household. And its not just any four-figure break.

title: Samsung Wins a Round in Patent Fight With Apple
description: Apple has failed to prevent its competitor Samsung from selling a touchscreen tablet in Australia. An Australian court on Friday lifted a temporary sales ban on Samsungs tablet, in time for the holiday shopping season, Reuters reported.

title: Dec. 11  17
description: Theater

title: Lens: Uelsman
description: Lens: Uelsman

title: Jawbone Recovers Good Will After Tumble
description: When I reviewed Jawbones Up, an exercise-monitoring wristband, I loved the concept, but not the execution. I was especially critical of the fact that it dumps its data into an iPhone via the headphone jack.

title: Readers Share Their #MyWipeOut Stories
description: As part of the Travel sections special Ski issue, were asking readers to share their craziest #MyWipeOut stories. We want to hear about your death-defying runs, your scariest spills or that time you went off piste and got lost. Leave a comment below or tweet using the hashtag #mywipeout. Next week well post some highlights.

title: What Can the Government Do?
description: India Ink spoke to Gopal Chandra Misra, the chief fire officer for the Delhi fire department, to find out more about fire safety measures in India, in the wake of a fire at a private hospital in Kolkata that killed at least 94, government officials say.

title: Why You Dont Have the Commuter Tax Break

title: Who Counts as Rich?
description: Weve written plenty of times about how little Americans know about the distribution of income in the United States, and how many rich people dont realize theyre rich, at least relative to the rest of the country.

title: An Orange and Black Eye for 2 Banks
description: Princeton University, the alma mater of financial bigwigs like Carl C. Icahn, is not typically thought of as a hotbed of anticorporate ardor.

title: Newsmax Says Trump Debate Is Full Steam Ahead
description: The Great Donald Trump Debate (well, maybe slightly less great than its organizers had hoped) is still going forward even with just two committed candidates, its organizers said Friday.

title: Just Getting On With It
description: FOR the last few days Ive been in London on assignment, staying at the Portobello Hotel, where  my friend Tim Blanks tells me  he used to visit Nico in the 70s. It may have been the first boutique hotel in London, he said, recalling that the front-desk man in the Nico era wore a cropped Vivienne Westwood top with feather trim.

A Season Dedicated to the Memory of a Fallen Teammate
Broken, Briefly

title: Photo Replay: Dec.9
description: The day in sports included the European Curling Championships in Moscow and the synchronized swimming World Trophy in Beijing.

title: A World War II Soldier Enters the Post-Iraq Age
description: This is a longer version of an interview that will run in the Arts & Leisure section.

title: Cultural Osmosis Pop Quiz About Pop Music: The Results Show!
description: A few weeks back we invited you to take our Cultural Osmosis Pop Quiz, to see just how much youve absorbed about the current world of pop music. The answer: Quite a bit, sort of.

title: Officer Wounds Groping Suspect in Harlem Subway Station
description: An off-duty police officer shot and wounded a man suspected of groping a woman and a teenager in a Harlem subway station Friday, said a police official who offered the following account.

title: Just One Look | Burberry
description: Its Burberry, its pre-fall and we want to see jackets. Here, a shearling-lined tweed bomber with an asymmetrical fur collar and heavy-duty hardware layered over an intarsia sweater (of which there are a few) and skinny, cropped pants. As for the men? They get a few cute sweaters, too (different dogs) and slim everything  pant, trench coat, shirt collar, tie and envelope clutch, even.

title: TimesCast | Russia's New Activism
description: Opposition activists in Moscow are planning large protests for Saturday, encouraged after unusually high turnouts at rallies earlier in the week.

title: Grand Central, 10:28 A.M.
description: With much fanfare, the Apple store opened on Friday.

title: With Jury Deadlocked, Mistrial Is Declared in Councilmans Corruption Case
description: A federal judge declared a mistrial on Friday in the corruption case of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, who had been charged in an elaborate scheme to direct more than $1 million in New York City taxpayer money to a network of nonprofit organizations that he controlled, purportedly for community programs.

title: Corporate Bankruptcy Raises a Question of Ethics
description: The ethics of corporate bankruptcy are a tricky thing and rarely thought about in much detail. So I was intrigued that the issue surfaced twice in The New York Times during the past week.

title: Parental Quandary: The Broken iPod, Resolved
description: Last week, Nicks mom told us about Nick, whod taken his iPod to school, left it in his backpack, and then saw his gadget fall victim to horseplay with a friend when the friend dropped the backpack over a balcony. (Read the full Broken iPod Quandary.) Who, we asked, should pay for Nicks new iPod?

title: French Songwriters British Muse, Onstage Again
description: PARIS  She played a deaf mute in Graham Greenes Carving a Statue, posed naked handcuffed to a radiator, marched in demonstrations against the death penalty, inspired a Herms bag and sang for children in the Palestinian territories.

title: On Cookies for Breakfast
description: Theres a personal back-story to the cookies and cereal thing some of you might find amusing.

title: A Clip From 'Pina'
description: A clip from the Wim Wenders documentary "Pina," about members of the Pina Bausch dance company.

title: CBS Sunday Morning Re-Signs Osgood and Promotes Rocca
description: CBS News said on Friday that it had renewed its contract with Charles Osgood, the long-time anchor of CBS Sunday Morning, and had promoted one of the shows contributors, Mo Rocca.

title: Polishing Up Latkes With Apples
description: MY mother is a latkes innovator.

title: Aiming for Brevity: Quirky Application Prompts
description: College applications are increasingly testing students brevity, as The Chicago Tribune pointed out on Friday.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Bahrain, Kazakhstan and South Africa.

title: H.P.s Nondecision Decision on WebOS
description: Hewlett-Packard is out of the operating system business  sort of.

title: Wind in the Willows Musical in the Works
description: Two classic British childrens stories separated by several decades and a huge difference in sensibility  though both share an affection for rodents (a water rat in one, an army of trained squirrels in the other)  appear to be coming to the stage.

title: Theater Talkback: Diminishing The Hat? About That Casting Controversy
description: Last month the playwright Stephen Adly Guirgis went public on Facebook with his concerns about the casting of non-Hispanic actors in the roles of Puerto Rican characters in a production of his play The __________ With the Hat at TheaterWorks in Hartford, Conn. After attending a recent performance, Mr. Guirgis said that while the two actors were talented and dedicated, he found the production to be dangerously close to a minstrel show. ArtsBeat asked Mr. Guirgis to write about why he raised the issue publically.

title: A Vision of Dance, Preserved in 3-D
description: PINA is a dance movie like no other. This documentary, by Wim Wenders, focuses on the German choreographer Pina Bausch and her company Tanztheater Wuppertal, but in a disarming twist it uses 3-D technology to take audiences inside the artists universe. Its an immersive experience that at moments makes viewers feel as if they were dancing too. The film, one of 15 on the shortlist for the best documentary feature Oscar, was in the works when Bausch died unexpectedly at 68 in 2009. So Mr. Wenders, director of Buena Vista Social Club and Wings of Desire, decided to cancel it. Only after her dancers pressed him did he decide to finish the movie, which features excerpts from four major pieces and scenes of the performers in and around Wuppertal, Germany  on hilltops, in coal mines, in monorails and on medians  bringing to life a dreamscape only Bausch and Mr. Wenders could have conjured. Julie Bloom spoke with Mr. Wenders in New York about the film, which opens on Dec. 23. Heres an edited version of their talk.

title: What Bill Clinton Would Do
description: Bill Clintons new book, Back to Work, is less a bold plan to create jobs than it is a passionate rebuttal of our 30-year antigovernment obsession. That obsession, he insists, is public enemy No. 1. He also seems to be sending a barely disguised message to Barack Obama to join him in confronting the antigovernment chorus.

title: Condoleezza Rice Looks Back
description: They were an unlikely pair: the cerebral A-student from a striving black family and the son of privilege who as a candidate for president couldnt name Pakistans military ruler. But together they forged a vision of a muscular United States striking out on its own.

title: William F. Buckley Jr.: Right Man, Right Time
description: William F. Buckley Jr. was an immodest man with much to be immodest about. Not only was he the high priest of the modern American conservative movement and the founding editor in chief of its leading intellectual publication, National Review; he was also a gifted polemicist, best-selling novelist, sesquipedalian speaker, television star, political candidate, yachtsman, harpsichordist, wit and bon vivant. Small wonder that I once saw him nod approvingly when a tongue-tied freshman referred to his 1951 autobiographical best seller as God as Man at Yale. He performed his many roles with such panache, and such obvious enjoyment of being William F. Buckley Jr., that he captivated people who otherwise would have despised someone who did much to move the United States politically to the right from the early 1950s until his death in 2008. But even liberals had to laugh when Buckley, asked whether he slouched in his chair as host of the TV program Firing Line because he couldnt think on his feet, drawled, It is hard . . . to stand up . . . under the weight . . . of all that I know.

title: Anita Desai on Longing and Striving
description: Sometimes a mango is just a mango. This is rarely the case in Indian novels, where mangoes tend to be luminescent orbs dangling in steamy air, glistening with sweetness, sex and Being itself, waiting to be plucked, caressed, birthed. Either that or theyre muddy and rotten and piled high on a dirty road, surrounded by rancid garbage, rank cooking fires, beggar children and grinning, greasy swindlers. In other words, mangoes in Indias literary fiction are much like India in literary fiction: distinguished by pleasing aromas or permanent anarchy, if not some chutneyed combination.

title: Searching for Love in the Windy City
description: Love and Shame and Love: It looks more like a line of free-form, possibly adolescent, poetry than the title of a novel, with the repeated love trying to buffer the fragile shame-filled center. Then again, that verbal image applies well to Alexander Popper, known to all simply as Popper, the melancholy, searching main character of Peter Orners third work of fiction. With its short and evocative chapters, its charged and playful language, its movement to and fro in time, the novel is indeed poetic. Its epic too, encompassing Poppers life from childhood into his early 30s as well as chunks of the life spans of his parents and two of his grandparents, with check-ins on various other relatives.

title: The Deputy Sheriff as Misfit
description: New Mexico is a place of great beauty and great melancholy, and, like all of the American West, a magnet for misfits. Willa Cather captured these aspects in her classic 1927 novel Death Comes for the Archbishop. Now Percival Everett, author of genre-bending novels like I Am Not Sidney Poitier and Glyph, vividly evokes the same elements in Assumption, his new trilogy of interwoven murder mysteries. Investigating all three cases is the enigmatic Ogden Walker, deputy sheriff in Plata, a fictional county in the northern part of the state, physically not far from the health farms and art galleries of trendy Taos, but in all other respects a world away. Plata is the opposite of trendy. Its a blink-and-you-missed-it burg of shabby adobe dwellings and aging pickup trucks and trailers like the one Ogden lives in.

title: Before the Wall Fell
description: The novelist Ingo Schulze was born in 1962 in Dresden. He was born, therefore, into a country called the German Democratic Republic  a country that no longer exists. The Berlin Wall fell on Nov. 9, 1989, and when Schulze was 27 East Germany disappeared.

title: The Rediscovery of Luis de Gngora
description: But what is this poem about? This dread question stalks almost every poetry classroom, and its vanquished only to return with a tenacity that would intimidate Michael Myers. Most recently, Ernie Lepore, a professor at Rutgers, took a swing at it in The New York Timess philosophy blog, The Stone. Lepore is interested in whats sometimes called the heresy of paraphrase  the idea that what a poem is really about is best represented by the poem itself. He concludes that while the usual reasoning behind the heresy claim is suspect, the idea itself is basically right. Poetry, Lepore argues, is not just about its paraphrasable data (and what we might make of that data), but also about the way that data is articulated. So Frosts Mending Wall is about a not-so-bright farmer, a bunch of rocks and their various symbolic accouterments; yet its also about the break between the word balance in Line 18 and Stay in Line 19.

title: Grim Tales of Clarity and Chaos
description: Bradford Morrows work has won him acclaim, but this inescapably grim collection of stories may not bolster that reputation. Heres a taste of what his readers will encounter.

title: The Risks and Rewards of Exploring the Nile
description: In the early 1870s in what is now Zambia, David Livingstone, the greatest of all Victorian explorers, led several expeditions in search of the source of the Nile. At times, he could barely walk, ulcers having chewed through the muscle, tendon and bone of his feet. Riddled with malaria, plagued with piles and weakened by pneumonia, he had pulled out several of his rotting teeth using strong thread and a heavy pistol. He had been attacked by roasting heat, pouring rain, tick fever, hostile slavers and leeches as close as smallpox. By 1873, he had an excruciatingly painful blood clot in his intestine the size of a fist. In this extremity of suffering, he found time to appreciate the sweet voice of a tree frog, but it is another entry in his diary  of truly towering understatement  that most perfectly sums up the wry fortitude of men like Livingstone: It is not all pleasure this exploration.

title: The CBGB Effect
description: The first record made by Talking Heads, a single released in February 1977, was called Love  Building on Fire. If you knew about Talking Heads then, you might have been the kind of person who thought the formula-like vector tucked into the title was inspired by the deadpan propositions that the conceptual artist Lawrence Weiner was stenciling at that time on the walls of SoHo galleries  which, in turn, might have made you think that the song itself was some sort of self-conscious concept art, sonically and lyrically examining the idea of a soulful pop song even as the insistent beat and David Byrnes strained shouts and warbles made the song a real one, exuberant, funny in its way, and infectious.

title: A Novel of Sisters Unbound
description: The ties that bind three generations of women also wrench them apart in The Sisters, Nancy Jensens first novel, which spans almost a century, from the 1920s to the current moment. Like so many painful family stories, this one begins with a miscommunication. The novel opens in 1927. Two sisters live in the hardscrabble town of Juniper, Ky. Bertie, about to receive her eighth-grade diploma, dreams of marrying her beau, Wallace, just maybe, in another year. Meanwhile her older sister, Mabel, secretively plans to leave home and escape their monstrous stepfather. Alas, things go wrong  disastrously and not quite plausibly. The stepfather is found dead. Mabel and Wallace vanish. Bertie assumes she has been betrayed. The sisters are lost to each other.

title: The Unmaking of Israel
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The African-American Experience
description: Several years ago I gave a talk, or attempted to, at Fisk University on a book Id written about the Billie Holiday song Strange Fruit. The reaction was, to put it mildly, hostile. Who was I, a white man, to write on such a topic? I beat a hasty retreat that night, not even bothering to open the box of books Id brought with me.

title: A Sloth, an Opossum and Two Puppies
description: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: BIG DADDY BARNES: As literary prizes go, nothing beats the Pulitzer for securing a novels place on the best-seller list: 9 of the last 10 fiction winners have spent time here. (The exception is Geraldine Brookss March, which won in 2006 but never cracked the list.) What about the Man Booker Prize in Britain? Its almost as powerful. Seven of the last 10 winners have gone on to become New York Times best sellers, including this years pick, The Sense of an Ending, by Julian Barnes, which has logged five weeks thus far and is still lurking on the hardcover extended list at No. 18.

title: Up Front
description: This week we present our 10 Best Books of the Year, drawn from all the books reviewed in these pages in the past 12 months. Choosing the 10 was not an arbitrary process, but neither was it a scientific one. How could it be, when the editors here are, first and foremost, readers, whose responses to any work of fiction or nonfiction are inevitably subjective and, as is the case with all readers, captive to predilections and tastes, histories and habits?

title: Editors Choice
description: INTO THE SILENCE: The Great War, Mallory, and the Conquest of Everest,  by Wade Davis (Knopf, $32.50.) This exhaustive and defining book presents the gruesome realities behind the legend of George Mallorys pursuit of Mount Everest in the 1920s.

title: Look of The Moment | Charlize Theron
description: The Look: Perfect Figure. A sexy, wrap-around-the-ankle stiletto is exactly what this blushing body-conscious dress requires.

description: Having conceded that poor gas mileage has hurt sales, Subaru has responded with the new Impreza, which offers an astounding increase in fuel efficiency.

title: Next Stop for Cain? Foxs Door Is Open
description: Fox News is publicly signaling an interest in hiring Herman Cain, the former Republican presidential candidate whose loose-lipped conservative talk always seemed perfectly suited for a cable television round table.

title: Riding Out Tax Uncertainty
description: The subject of Paul Sullivans Wealth Matters column this week is tax strategies for the new year. The problem is that with Congress at loggerheads again about fiscal policies, tax advisers are not even trying to guess what will happen in the next year or so about matters like the estate tax and the expiring Bush-era tax cuts.

title: Please Check for Snakes When Exiting the Cab
description: WITH foot-deep potholes, jagged pavement and rough cobblestones reminiscent of the rough-riding streets of the meatpacking district, the road is unmistakably New York  except for the road runners and coyotes.

title: What to Read Till the Snowplow Comes
description: AMONG the latest automobile books are many titles with broad appeal, but some are aimed at car buffs with very specialized interests. To help you cull the current crop  and perhaps select a holiday gift  here are brief reviews of seven recent books about cars and the people who built and raced them.

title: The Girl Past the Dragon Tattoo
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

title: Slow Learners
description: The WSJ has an article today pointing out that the euro crisis isnt really about fiscal irresponsibility:

title: Mostly (But Not Entirely) Depressing Food Links
description: The U.S. Army has developed a sandwich that stays fresh for two years. Yum.

title: Batman Soars to No. 1
description: Batman: The Black Mirror enters our hardcover graphic books best sellers list at No. 1. The story features Dick Grayson, the former Robin, filling in for the Dark Knight and encountering a new evil: a man called the Dealer who traffics in the weapons of supervillains. Complicating things is the return of Commissioner Gordons son, James, who is a psychopath. The story, written by Scott Snyder and illustrated by Jock, is incredibly compelling and reads even better as a collected edition than it did as single issues. You can read our profile of Mr. Snyder here.

title: Happy Golden Days of Yore
description: WITH its bleak, film-noir imagery and barely suppressed undertone of suicidal despair, Frank Capras Its a Wonderful Life has somewhat mysteriously assumed an unshakable position as Americas official holiday film. But for those in search of a more vibrant, warmhearted and subtly melancholic seasonal celebration there is Vincente Minnellis 1944 musical Meet Me in St. Louis, which Warner Home Video will release this week in a superbly restored Blu-ray edition.

title: The Cost of Cutting the Public Transit Benefit
description: Many employees are allowed to set a certain amount of money aside each year for commuting costs before paying taxes on it. Starting Jan. 1, however, the monthly cap on that public transportation contribution may be cut roughly in half to $125. Heres what that could cost one family, in a particularly bad case.

title: Romney Taps Brake on Gingrich Attacks
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Wrapping up a week of varied and hard-hitting attacks on Newt Gingrich, Mitt Romney on Friday stepped back his assault at a town-hall-style meeting here, contrasting himself with Mr. Gingrich but never forcefully criticizing him.

title: Former Notre Dame Quarterback to Visit Kansas
description: Charlie Weis became known as a prolific recruiter when he was the head coach at Notre Dame, luring highly touted prospects like Michael Floyd, Jimmy Clausen and Manti Teo to campus. In search of his first big recruiting coup as the new coach at Kansas, Weis may go back to one of his highly regarded prospects at Notre Dame: quarterback Dayne Crist.

title: James Levine Withdraws From Conducting at the Met, Until at Least 2013
description: James Levine, the Metropolitan Operas ailing music director, has withdrawn from conducting this season and the next at the house, where he has been a musical force for 40 years, the Met and Mr. Levine said on Friday.

title: Latkes Party Planning
description: Latkes really do taste best when savored immediately after frying while they are still crisp-edged and brittle. Still, frying them during your average holiday party can be a somewhat arduous endeavor.

title: Just One Look | Calvin Klein
description: Buy now, wear now, is a phrase we hear a lot during the pre-fall presentations, with designers showing clothes better suited to summer (when theyll be delivering to stores) than to the fall theyre prefacing. Not so at Calvin Klein, where Francisco Costa showed a stunning and focused collection of wool and leather suits, dresses and coats (lots of coats), all of which carried their tight seams and rather 90s silhouettes with terrific poise, and all of which will transition beautifully into chillier climates. Here, a wool felt single breasted coat over a sleeveless dress of the same fabric with a skirt tucked into the softest, rolling pleats says it all.

title: Perry and Romney Seek Iowa Papers Endorsement
description: Mitt Romney and Rick Perry both appeared before The Des Moines Register editorial board on Friday, hoping for an endorsement by the influential newspaper in the weeks before the Iowa caucuses.

title: Gospel Themes and Punkish Dirges
description: Jason Nelson

description: DULUTH, Ga.

title: Inflating Your Way To Prosperity
description: One thing I often see in comments is people attributing to me, or to others, the notion that you can inflate your way to prosperity  which is presented as self-evidently absurd.

title: Bon Iver, Fitness Guru?
description: If you sometimes suspected that the fitness guru Richard Simmons was actually perpetrating a hoax, then wait until you see the trailer for a workout video that has recently been making the rounds, featuring the auto-tuned folk singer Justin Vernon, known as Bon Iver.

title: In Poll, Fans Still Have Favorable Opinion of Paterno
description: College football fans in Pennsylvania are evenly divided over the firing of Penn State football coach Joe Paternoin the wake of the child sex-abuse scandal, although most still have a favorable opinion of him, according to a recent Quinnipiac University poll.

title: Parental Quandary: Drinking (or Not) in the Basement
description: This weeks parenting dilemma finds a mom unsure of how much to tell another parent about her childs possible drinking, and how to show her teenage daughter the best way to respond to rumors about another student.

title: Death Penalty for 2nd Man in Connecticut Triple-Murder Case
description: One of Connecticuts most agonizing courtroom dramas came to an end on Friday as a jury voted to impose the death penalty on the second of two killers of three family members after an ordeal of violence and sexual assault that challenged suburban ideals of safety.

title: Rustic French Pork and Chicken Pt
description: Time: About 2 hours

title: A French Butcher at Home (That Would Be You)
description: O.K., this is a little bit of a project, but not too taxing for an adventurous home cook. How about making your own pt for the holidays?

title: Institutions that are too big to fail, and improving government agencies.
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Diana Henriques on Bernard Madoff, Gretchen Morgenson on institutions that are too big to fail, and Robert Frank on improving government agencies like D.M.V.s.

title: Perry Survived Even as His Big Plan for Texas Failed
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In the bachelor-style apartment of his legislative years, where Rick Perry liked to kick back and watch football with a cold one, the future Texas governor forged a lasting bond with a hard-charging roommate who preferred smoking a pipe, studying flip charts and strategizing.

title: Scenesters and Occupy Wall Streeters, Together at Last
description: It was Radical Chic  redux. This week, the Bagger stopped by an event organized by a slew of New York scenesters and hot young things  including Alexa Chung, the MTV host turned designer; the photographer Aaron Stern; Zoe Kravitz, the young actress, and her boyfriend, Penn Badgley, a star of Gossip Girl and Margin Call  in support of the Occupy Wall Street movement. It was held at the swank Bowery Hotel, in a space normally reserved for Strokes afterparties and other downtown bacchanals. There were doormen and bowtied waiters (but no open bar).

title: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega
description: Suzanne Vega was actually at the reception before Tuesdays event  and I, of course, was completely inane on meeting her, with nothing to say except how much I love her music.

title: Editors and Critics Pick Their Favorite Books of 2011
description: To complement the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2011, we asked assorted editors and critics at The Times to name their own favorite book from the year nearly past. We received a variety of answers, including works by a Booker Prize winner, a confessional rapper and a global optimist.

title: So Long, Water Cooler; Hello, Hashtag
description: IN one of the feistiest arcs on Parks and Recreation this season Tom returns to his old workplace at City Hall to pick up his former co-worker Donna for their yearly day of pampering and conspicuous consumption. Their motto: Treat yo self.

title: Now Playing | Mr. Favela
description: I just hope that New York feels what I feel, the Brazilian rapper Criolo said just before making his American debut on Wednesday night at Nublu in the East Village. I hope they feel my heart and soul. Now 36, Criolo was born Kleber Gomes in So Paulo and grew up (and still lives) in one of the citys poorest neighborhoods, the infamousGraja favela. Its a place where one million people fight for life every day, he said.

title: Caption Contest: Showdown in Madison Square Park
description: What did the squirrel say to the red-tailed hawk? And/or vice versa. Answers below please.

title: Its the Holidays  Make a Pt
description: In this weeks City Kitchen, were not featuring a quick delicious meal. Or actually, we are, but it will require a 2 hour investment of time (though not necessarily consecutive hours). For cooks who want to have a little fun, heres a recipe for a pork and chicken pt  the rustic, old-fashioned kind a French grandmother might make. True, its a bit of a project, but the end result provides easy hors doeuvres for a holiday gathering, a great first course, or a fine sandwich. And once your pt is made, it can wait in the refrigerator for a week before serving, all the while improving in flavor.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: A look back on our reporting of the past weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: How a Music Site Disappeared for a Year
description: 11:42 a.m. | Updated

title: Space Travelers and Dragonflies, in Galaxies of Life and Death
description: More than two years after his death, the choreographer Merce Cunningham has grown only more unknowable. Even if you can keep track of the restless ways in which he made formal inventions with human movement over the course of 60 years, the ways in which he shaped choreography as drama keep defying categorization.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 9
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

More School Choice Questions From Parents
