description: In the recent financial crisis, the federal government spent billions of dollars bailing out institutions that were deemed too big to fail.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 9
description: More Photographs

title: Rousing Russia With a Phrase
description: MOSCOW  The man most responsible for the extraordinary burst of antigovernment activism here over the past week will not speak at a rally planned for Saturday, or even attend it, because he is in prison.

title: Traffic Deaths Fall to Lowest Level Since 1949
description: Americas traffic safety numbers are in for 2010, and they are, with some qualifications, good. Last year, the rates of roadway fatalities and injuries fell to their lowest recorded levels and to their lowest numbers since 1949.

title: Lens: Canadas NFB
description: Lens: Canadas NFB

title: Chic in Review | Pizza Spas and Angry Birds Black Tie
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: For Anchorwomen, Family Is Part of the Job
description: WHEN Megyn Kelly was starting out in television, a prominent TV newswoman told her, Youre going to need to choose: you can either have a family or you can be a major anchor.

title: A Risk Once Unthinkable
description: Are customer accounts at brokerage firms safe?

title: Totes as It Bags
description: The tote bag has become a recessionary, post-luxury status symbol and useful social identifier.

title: A Message on Every Arm
description: BEFORE the Fendi baguette grew stale and Marc Jacobs Stam knockoffs were sold on Canal Street, a young woman in the citys creative fields might have considered a luxury bag a necessary investment. These days, thanks to the ascent of the humble cloth tote, she can save her shoe budget and still look, well, smart.

title: Russia Allows Protest, but Tries to Discourage Attendance
description: MOSCOW  The calls started coming in the afternoon and tied up phones for hours at the headquarters of at least two organizations strongly critical of the Kremlin. Putin is life; Putin is the light; love Putin and your life will have meaning; Putin will give you happiness; Putin will open your eyes, a womans ethereal voice chanted over and over and over.

title: Excellent Play by Declarer Helps Win the Fall Nationals
description: SEATTLE  The Keohane North American Swiss Teams was won last Sunday at the Fall Nationals in Seattle by Les and Gloria Bart, a married couple from Bradenton, Fla.; Nader Hanna of Toronto; and Piotr Klimowicz of Edmonton, Alberta.

title: An Ordinary Woman Knowingly Enters a Serial Killers Gruesome World
description: Lets get one thing straight: Appropriate Adult is Emily Watsons movie. She plays the title character, shes on screen nearly throughout and everything thats important happens in her face as she signals the worry, grief, excitement and terror of an ordinary woman thrust into extraordinarily ugly circumstances.

title: Book Review Podcast: CBGB and Condoleezza Rice
description: In this Sundays Book Review, the editors choose their 10 Best Books of 2011, which include four first novels, Stephen Kings 52nd novel (by our count), and nonfiction books that are models of their various forms  biography, memoir, history, argument and scientific analysis. The issue also includes Gerald Marzoratis review of Love Goes to Buildings on Fire, Will Hermes book about the New York music scene in the 1970s. Mr. Marzorati writes:

title: The Superhighway Texas Rejected
description: Gov. Rick Perry intended his plan for a public-private $175 billion toll road and railway system to be a major part of his political legacy. Instead, the Trans-Texas Corridor was unpopular and finally abandoned.

title: A Writer Faces Something Far Scarier Than Ghosts
description: The title may be Stephen Kings Bag of Bones, but the reason to watch, if any, is Pierce Brosnan.

title: Bill Cunningham | Frosty
description: Outerwear moved onto center stage with last weeks blast of wintry weather. The cloth coat, swathed in fake or real fur, was a standout.

title: Gauging the Strength of a European Firewall
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has applauded the euro zone for moving to save its common currency and enforce fiscal discipline among its members. Yet the deal has done little to calm American concerns about an inadequate firewall  financing put up by European governments to ensure that all euro zone countries maintain access to the debt markets at sustainable interest rates.

title: Occupy Boehners Doorway
description: On Thursday, the police cleared dozens of protesters from the hallway in front of House Speaker John Boehners Congressional office, but a woman from St. Paul, Minn., returned to continue knocking.

title: Amazon Backlash
description: Amazons effort to pay shoppers to scorn physical stores is promptinga bit of a backlash. The retailer is offering a bounty for those whoventure to the mall or Main Street on Saturday and compare the priceof items against Amazons price. Customers who use a special pricecheck app on their smartphone will get up to $5 off on up to threequalifying products from Amazon in eligible categories (electronics,toys, sports, music and DVDs).

title: Todays Scuttlebot: War Propaganda and Facebook Fury
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors at The New York Times have been reading on the Web. For more, go to the right column of this page.

title: Afghanistan Play, With Experts in the House
description: Blood and Gifts, J. T. Rogerss play about the history of Americas involvement in Afghanistan in the 1980s, has gotten strong reviews from the critics, who have praised its subtle depiction of a Central Intelligence Agency operative who thinks he is financing anti-Soviet freedom fighters only to see them morph into something more menacing.

title: A Hands-On Art Exhibition
description: MIAMI BEACH

title: Reliving the Year in Notable Automotive Books
description: For these short, chilly days, this weekends Automobiles section offers a potential cure for enthusiasts exhibiting symptoms of driving-fun withdrawal.

title: A Composer Still Vital in His Second Century
description: If the composer Elliott Carter had been able only to attend a concert in celebration of his 103rd birthday, that would have been remarkable enough. But on Thursday night, Mr. Carter, who turns 103 on Sunday, was not only in the audience at the 92nd Street Y for a tribute presented by a top-notch roster of musicians under the artistic direction of the cellist Fred Sherry, but he had also written five works this year that were included in the program.

title: Reviewing the Subaru Impreza
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reviews the 2012 Subaru Impreza, which is available as a four-door sedan or a four-door hatchback.

title: At the Heckscher, Works Torn From Life
description: The title Ripped: The Allure of Collage hinges on a bit of clever wordplay, suggesting gym-toned bodies and six-pack abs. Of course, collage originally involved torn paper rather than taut muscles. But the hint of sexiness is appropriate, since collage is one of modern arts most seductive mediums, in which cast-off and non-art materials are assembled into avant-garde objects.

title: Holidays and Song Hand-in-Hand
description: FROM a strictly musical perspective, holidays and the human voice are a match made in heaven. As if to prove the point, Westchester County will, in the coming weeks, resonate with a rich and varied mix of vocal offerings  among them musical-theater classics, 20th-century British choral works and jazz versions of seasonal favorites.

title: This Sunday: Actors Turn Villainous
description: From the moment we asked Bill Murray to let us decorate his beard with fake flowers  an image dreamed up by Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, the photographer couple who shot our Great Performers portfolio for the first three years  weve had lots of fun with some very game actors. Clint Eastwood endured several rounds of being blasted with huge clouds of smoke. Charlize Theron sat for a portrait in the nude, painted in gold. William Hurts face was made up to resemble Francis Bacons painting of a death mask of William Blake.

title: An Abused Boy, Betrayed by a Societys Willful Blindness
description: Audience members heading for the restrooms before performances of James X at 45 Bleecker Theater in the East Village may feel uncomfortable about being directed there by a prominent arrow-shaped sign on the lip of the stage reading, Commission to Inquire Into Child Abuse.

title: Airport Security Thats Not Surly
description: To the Editor:

title: A Parody That Turns on Jokes, Not on Toes
description: Two score and several Christmases ago, three boys were growing up in Needham, Mass. Childhood friends, they went on to forge individual careers in show business.

title: Messages Hidden in Notes
description: The New York Philharmonic opens its current program at Avery Fisher Hall, conducted by Daniel Harding, with that rarity this season: a new work. Well, not quite. Flourish With Fireworks is actually from 1988, but at least its composer, Oliver Knussen, is still alive.

title: Performers in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Brief Encounter: Modernists Take on Egyptian Myth
description: Every major international orchestra visiting Carnegie Hall of course wants to make a big impression. But that is hard to do with as curious a program as the one the Russian conductor Vladimir Jurowski presented with the London Philharmonic Orchestra on Wednesday night.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach Wraps Up Its 10th Year
description: The art for Art Basel Miami Beach, which ran from Nov. 30 to Dec. 3, was provided by 260 galleries from 30 countries spread across five of the seven continents.

title: Molire Meets Punch and Judy
description: You have never seen a bosom like this one. It begins at the armpits and droops down to the waist, a sort of humpback in reverse. Like any good bosom, it can heave on cue. And its rhythmic flappings signal the kind of lewd-icrous jokes we are in for at the Yale Repertory Theaters production of Molires classic comedy A Doctor in Spite of Himself.

title: Hip-Hop Universe, Expanding
description: This is independent hip-hops New Weird America moment, where rappers in every city are pursuing idiosyncratic tangents, sustaining themselves with Internet-generated fan bases that vary in size from extremely tiny to medium.

title: School Lunches
description: To the Editor:

title: The SAT Cheating Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: With Lobbying Blitz, For-Profit Colleges Diluted New Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Last year, the Obama administration vowed to stop for-profit colleges from luring students with false promises. In an opening volley that shook the $30 billion industry, officials proposed new restrictions to cut off the huge flow of federal aid to unfit programs.

title: Afghanistan: Suicide Bomber Kills 6 Security Officers at Prayer
description: A suicide bomber in eastern Afghanistan killed six Afghan security officials, including a district police chief, during Friday Prayer in Ghaziabad District, a remote area of Kunar Province where there was an extensive NATO operation in October to clear the area of the Taliban. The bomber struck just outside a mosque where the officers had gone to pray. Two civilians were also killed, the Kunar governor said. In southern Afghanistan, seven detainees being held on narcotics trafficking charges escaped from a prison in Helmand Province, local officials said. Four employees at the prison, which is inside the police headquarters in Lashkar Gah, the provincial capital, were arrested in connection with the escape.

title: Medicare and Private Health Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: The How of an Internment, but Not All the Whys
description: POWELL, Wyo.  In a region of inspiring landscapes, this certainly isnt one of them. If you stand near where the barracks once were, not far from the Heart Mountain Interpretive Learning Center that opened last summer, this barren expanse, with its craggily eccentric mountain in the distance, could almost seem cruelly mocking.

title: A Warm Welcome, Made in a Whisper
description: IL SOGNO is in many ways surprising. Tucked within a gantlet of brightly lighted gas stations and fast-food operations, this roadside restaurant hardly shouts its presence. Its location  just past a complicated intersection where Boston Post Road meets Regent Street  creates an additional distraction for first-timers trying to find the place.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 9
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos birthday, a beard competition and a study of sleep on the subway.

title: My Mother-in-Laws One High Day
description: WHEN my mother-in-law was in the final, harrowing throes of pancreatic cancer, she had only one good day, and that was the day she smoked pot.

title: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 84
description: New York City was briefly reoccupied on Thursday, after a Zuccotti Park-like set for the television franchise Law & Order was taken over by protesters. [City Room]

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,833 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Waiting to Leave, Last U.S. Troops in Iraq Stay Vigilant
description: BAGHDAD  Every other American soldier in Iraq, it seemed, was strapping duffel bags to the roofs of armored trucks, dismantling bases and joining the convoys hurtling south through the desert, toward the Kuwaiti border and the promise of home.

title: Confiscated Money Helps Create Haven for Students in the Bronx
description: From her window on a hill in the Bronx, Verdell Mack watches her grandchildren walk the few blocks to Intermediate School 229 each morning. Otherwise, she doesnt let them outside alone in a neighborhood where violence is common.

title: For 29 Dead Miners, No Justice
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Armys Goal Is Win First, Sing Second
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  New white jerseys hung in a row in the Army football teams equipment room this week. Each bore an American flag on the right sleeve, the seal of the United States Military Academy seal on the left, a United States Army unit patch near the right shoulder and the words West Point above the numbers on the back.

title: Feeling Welcome, Even Before the Wine
description: THE first thing to meet your eye as you enter Bacchus is a large trompe loeil painting of a wine cellar interior. There was something about those wine barrels that prompted a feel-good response from the moment we arrived at this lively Italian restaurant, which re-opened last April in the historic district of South Norwalk after a two-and-half-year hiatus (a result of a legal dispute). The good food and wine that followed confirmed our initial impression.

title: Iran Complains to Security Council About Spy Drone
description: Iran said Friday that it had formally complained to the United Nations Security Council about what it called the hostile and aggressive behavior of the United States in sending a sophisticated radar-evading spy drone over Iranian territory, one that Irans military said it had intercepted and captured last weekend.

title: Giants Guard Mitch Petrus Rocks on the Field and on the Bass
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  At the end of a long day of studying film, lifting weights and trying to fend off mobile and mammoth defensive linemen, Mitch Petrus likes to go back to his apartment in Clifton, N.J., take out his Fender Stratocaster guitar and slide his weathered, callused fingers over the strings.

title: Plenty of Peppers, Pickles and Oils
description: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y.

title: Rescue for the Gulf
description: The Obama administration this week officially began what it hopes will be a sustained push to reverse decades of man-made degradation in the Gulf of Mexico. The trigger for this effort is last years disastrous BP oil spill. But the administrations strategy goes beyond repairing immediate damages, to the task of restoring the entire ecosystem to good health.

title: Canadian Charged in Iraq Bombing
description: A federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted a house painter in Edmonton, Alberta, on Friday for aiding in a 2009 suicide bombing that killed five American soldiers in Iraq. In addition to five murder charges, the suspect, Sayfildin Tahir Sharif, was charged with conspiring to kill Americans abroad and providing material support to a terrorist conspiracy. Mr. Tahir Sharif, 39, who also goes by other names, has been jailed since his arrest in Edmonton in late January. His lawyer, Bob Aloneissi, said Mr. Tahir Sharif denied the charges, adding that officials seem to have exaggerated the impact of his clients remarks about the war in Iraq. Its hard to understand how he had a hand in murder in Iraq when he was here in Edmonton, Mr. Aloneissi said. An extradition hearing is scheduled for next month.

title: Court to Hear Texas Dispute on Drawing New Districts
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday evening agreed to hear a tangle of lawsuits over how Texas should conduct elections for its Legislature and for Congress next year.

title: Trades Are Linked to Missing MF Global Funds
description: The trustee liquidating MF Globals brokerage unit has spotted suspicious trades in customer accounts that appear connected to a $1.2 billion shortfall, the trustees lawyer said Friday.

title: Expanding the Fight Against AIDS
description: Important new findings show that very early treatment of people infected with H.I.V. enhances their health and greatly lessens the likelihood that they will spread the virus that causes AIDS. We welcome the Obama administrations announcement of a farsighted effort to treat millions more infected people abroad, especially in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: At an Upscale Hangout, a Menu Built for Speed
description: MORRISTOWN needed a place like Urban Table: a hangout for young professionals desiring better dinners than the towns post-collegiate watering holes dish out with their drafts. A place where medical residents and corporate clamberers could tear into a fun meal at a fair price. Where they could enjoy a citified setting that is dressed for success in subway tile, herringbone hardwood floors, hip lighting and artistic touches large and small.

title: Euro Zone Agrees to Follow the Original Rules
description: BRUSSELS  In the fiscal accord reached here on Friday by members of the European Union, the nations that use the euro essentially agreed to go back to Plan A  that is, the principles and rules with which they created their common currency two decades ago. Only this time, they said, they mean it.

title: Swatch, Supplier to Rivals, Now Aims to Cut Them Off
description: GENEVA  The Swatch Group may be best known for its playful, plastic watches. But it also produces mechanical movements and other watch components that it sells to most of its rival timepiece makers.

title: Longer Standardized Tests Are Planned, Displeasing Some School Leaders
description: Students across New York State will sit longer for high-stakes standardized tests in language arts and math this April compared with past years, education officials indicated Friday, drawing criticism from school leaders and parents who believe that lengthier tests are a move in the wrong direction.

title: Reality and Re-election Sharpen Obamas Zigzags
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama thrilled liberals on Tuesday when, blending Theodore Roosevelt with Occupy Wall Street, he renewed his commitment to temper untrammeled, youre on your own capitalism.

title: N.B.A. Reopens to Business as Unusual
description: The N.B.A. reopened to general mayhem Friday, with enough controversy, anger and allegations to make the public nearly forget about the five-month lockout.

title: She Finds Refuge in Art
description: Leironica Hawkins recalls always having social problems, sensory issues and bouts of depression, while growing up in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as well as behavioral tics like self-rocking and involuntary hand twitches. Finally, at age 28, she was given a diagnosis: Aspergers syndrome, a form of autism, for which she has never received treatment.

title: S.E.C. Looks at Harbingers Dealings With Goldman
description: 8:04 a.m. | Updated

title: Europes Latest Try
description: Were losing count of how many European Union summit meetings have ended with historic agreements to contain the euro-zone debt crisis only to see them fall apart as markets judged they were inadequate or irrelevant to the problem of making good on old debts and generating enough growth to pay off future obligations.

title: Parade Keeps Its Boom
description: APP Unsilent Night

title: Chances for Sisterly Connection
description: Park Avenue Winter, which changes its name, dcor and menu with the seasons, began its ode to winter on Nov. 29. The entrance on 63rd Street gives way to an icily elegant dining room inspired by the Arctic Circle. A murmur of conversation warms the room, as do the chef Kevin Laskos offerings.

title: A Different Kind of Container Store
description: Starbucks is about to unveil a new store in suburban Seattle built primarily of four used shipping containers  the large steel boxes used to store goods as they are transported long distances on boats and trucks.

title: Compassion Under Fire
description: Clara Barton, a 39-year-old single woman with New England written all over her dignified demeanor, could not rest easy until she found a way to join the Army. From the first day blood was spilled in 1861  some of her old Massachusetts schoolmates were among the Yankee soldiers besieged in Baltimore by a mob of Southern sympathizers  the Civil War was what she lived for. She left a job in Washington as a Patent Office copyist for scenes of mass misery that broke all the record books.

title: Gingrich Suggests a Reversal of Mideast Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Does Newt Gingrich believe in a two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict? Democratic and Republican administrations since the 1990s have adopted that framework for peace in the Middle East, but Mr. Gingrich suggested that he might break with it, calling Palestinians an invented people and the current stalled peace process delusional.

title: Egypts Military Retracts Plan to Extend Influence Over Constitution
description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers on Friday night appeared to withdraw a plan for extending their influence over the writing of a new constitution, evidently bowing to a chorus of criticism just days after the proposal was unveiled.

title: Sununu, a Romney Supporter, Attacks Gingrich as Not Stable
description: John H. Sununu, the former governor of New Hampshire who recently endorsed Mitt Romney, has spent the past two days attacking Newt Gingrich on Mr. Romneys behalf. But speaking on the Scott Hennen Show Friday, Mr. Sununu intensified his criticism of the former House speaker after the radio host asked him about comments Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma had made recently that were critical of Mr. Gingrichs leadership abilities.

title: Ruling Expected on Whether Madoff Trustee Can Appeal
description: A ruling is expected in federal court as soon as next week on whether the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs massive fraud can appeal a decision that would make it difficult to recover potentially hundreds of millions of dollars from the owners of the Mets.

title: Chinese Manufacturer Restricts Business With Iran
description: Huawei Technologies, a leading Chinese maker of telecommunications equipment, said it would voluntarily restrict business in Iran because of what it called the increasingly complex situation there.In an announcement on its Web site, Huawei said it would not seek new customers in Iran and would limit business activities with existing customers.Huawei, a privately owned company that has been seeking access to the American market, did not elaborate on its reasons for the pullback from Iran, which has become the target of increased sanctions by the United States and the European Union over its disputed nuclear program. Last year, some American lawmakers expressed concern over reports that Huawei had supplied communications technology to Iran and had sold equipment to Iraq during the regime of Saddam Hussein, in violation of United Nations sanctions.

title: Still Active, With a Little Help
description: Henrietta Edwards prays that she may live to 100. After that, I want to find out whats on the other side, she said. Ms. Edwards will celebrate her 91st birthday on Christmas Day with her energy and wit intact. To reach her goal, she eats carefully, exercises, takes dance and yoga classes, and writes poetry at the Lincoln Square Neighborhood Center next door to her apartment.

title: On Quiet Roosevelt Island, Unease Pays a Sudden Visit
description: You hear about places where people dont bother to lock their front doors, and maybe you smile and think of home, or, if youre a certain breed of New Yorker, you just shake your head. Rubes with nothing worth stealing. Give me three deadbolts and a chain in the big city any day.

title: Somalis Still Flood Yemen, Going From Worse to Bad
description: ADEN, Yemen  For two decades, Somalis fleeing their failed state found in Yemen a safe haven, a place to work, and a gateway to wealthier gulf states.

title: House Republicans Bill Sets Up Pipeline Battle
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans moved Friday toward a showdown with President Obama over the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which they included in their bill to extend tax relief for 160 million American workers through 2012.

title: Real Madrid Threatens Barcelonas Reign
description: MADRID  The most dominant club in soccer in recent seasons will face the biggest challenge to its reign Saturday.

title: Saturday: Step on the Scale
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Corey Rubin has not been seen in the New York Times since mid-2010 (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but his last puzzle was a delightful rebus influenced by Beethovens Ode to JOY.

title: Japanese Islanders Cling to a Life Under Their Volcano
description: MIYAKE, Japan  I turn on the machine when the house smells of sulfur, Yuki Kitagawa said, pointing to an air purifier in her living room.

title: At Elite Prep School, Abuse Case Wont Go Away
description: To a distant observer through the years, it would have seemed that the benefits of a private school education in New York had accrued generously to Philip Culhane. The son of a CBS News correspondent, Mr. Culhane, who is now in his mid-40s, grew up in the Cobble Hill neighborhood and from fifth grade on went to Poly Prep, the well-regarded school in Brooklyn where his great-grandfather had gone as well.

title: Jets Ryan Expecting Big Cheers for Sanchez
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan is defiantly sticking to his plan to have the offensive starters introduced before Sundays game against the Chiefs. The last time he did that at MetLife Stadium, Mark Sanchez was greeted with thunderous booing.

title: An A.T.V. With Extra Room, and Maybe More Risks, Too
description: They started out decades ago as handy vehicles for farmers and builders to haul things like lumber and fertilizer.

title: Coach Hoping to Forget Decision That Cost Dallas a Victory
description: IRVING, Tex.  Cowboys Coach Jason Garrett sounded as if he were reading from the employee handbook, tersely explaining team policy for dealing with situations like a recent overtime loss to the Arizona Cardinals.

title: China: Nobel Winners Demand Release of Imprisoned Dissident
description: A group of five Nobel laureates has called on China to release Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned winner of the Nobel Peace Prize last year. In 2009, Mr. Liu was sentenced to 11 years on charges of trying to subvert the state. He was a main author of a manifesto circulated online, Charter 08, that called for gradual democratic reforms. His wife, Liu Xia, is under house arrest in Beijing.

title: Thousands Sterilized, a State Weighs Restitution
description: LINWOOD, N.C.  Charles Holt, 62, spreads a cache of vintage government records across his trailer floor. They are the stark facts of his state-ordered sterilization.

title: The Ghosts of Boyfriends Past
description: New unnerving development in Congress: Some senators are claiming that a woman nominated to be ambassador to El Salvador cant have the job because they dont like a boyfriend she lived with almost 20 years ago.

title: The Brutal Side of Hazing
description: The tragic loss of Robert Champion may be another sad case of a college student literally dying to belong.

title: He Covered the Waterfront
description: Jose Gaytan was the consummate salesman. How good was he?

title: For Chase, a TV Show to Promote Its Charity
description: When a television network broadcasts an awards show created by a multinational banks marketers, what is it? An advertisement? A tribute to deserving charities? An entertainment spectacle?

title: Dancer as Walker, Baker, Reader
description: The first time she performed the role of Dewdrop in George Balanchines The Nutcracker with the New York City Ballet, Ashley Bouder was 17 and made a memorable entrance: she fell on her face. Now 27 and a principal dancer for the company, Ms. Bouder is in her eighth season as the Sugarplum Fairy and her 11th as Dewdrop. She will perform that role in a live City Ballet broadcast in movie theaters on Tuesday and on the PBS program Live From Lincoln Center on Wednesday. Ms. Bouder lives on the Upper West Side with her boyfriend, Matthew Dibble, 35, now touring in Twyla Tharps Come Fly Away, and their dogs: Scout, a Beagle; and Enid, a Boston terrier. On nonperforming Sundays, she unwinds with the dogs, naps, posts to Twitter and has a big dinner.

title: Law & Order: SVU Imitation Occupation Draws Real Protesters, and Citys Ire
description: Law & Order helped give the phrase ripped from the headlines as much of a place in the consciousness of New York as detectives chatter about perps and vics. Or that clang-clang noise at the beginning of each scene in the television show.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Europe pushes to save the euro currency, Jon Corzine testifies about MF Globals collapse and the United States Postal Service announces new cuts.

title: Trade Rejected, Lakers Begin on Subdued Note
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Chris Paul, the point guard the Lakers thought they had acquired before the N.B.A. rejected their trade, did not make the opening of their training camp after all.

title: Corrections: December 10
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Lottery Numbers
Mavericks Open Camp With Many Missing Pieces
description: DALLAS  Even as they spoke of repeating as champions, the Dallas Mavericks were not sure exactly who would embark on the defense of their title on Christmas Day here against the Miami Heat.

title: Cuomo, Praised for Tax Deal, Takes Victory Lap to City
description: Hours after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo won overwhelming approval of a package to overhaul the states income tax, an undertaking he had first informed the public about only three days earlier, his lieutenant governor, Robert J. Duffy, described Mr. Cuomos achievements as nothing short of a miracle.

title: Orthodox Jewish Students Tale of Premarital Sex, Real or Not, Roils Campus
description: It all started with a provocative, anonymous essay about premarital sex published by an online student newspaper on Monday, the kind of first-person tell-all that would probably pass without much mention at the average secular university.

title: An Ugly Undercurrent as Barcelona and Real Madrid Meet
description: MADRID  Barcelona and Real Madrid will meet on Saturday for the first time in four months, and the soccer world will be watching. The clubs not only tower over the rest of the Spanish league but are considered the best collections of talent in the world. Both teams are stocked with players who helped Spain win the World Cup in 2010 and each has one of the greatest players  Real Madrids Cristiano Ronaldo and Barcelonas Lionel Messi  now playing the game.

title: A Wanderer, the Singer Dion Returns to the Bronx
description: DRESSED in black with shades to match, Dion DiMucci stood on East 187th Street and pointed to Grandma Marias apartment building. In the 1940s, that corner fire escape was the best perch in Belmont for the street fairs where big guys sang big songs.

title: In Bags at J.F.K., Handlers Found Niche for Crime
description: It was not so much the crime that was surprising, but who was behind it.

title: Whats in a Name? For an Actor, Start With His Roles
description: Lantern-bearers led the crowd through the darkened streets of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, on Tuesday night to a lavish dinner after a performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Next Wave Gala.

title: Internal Dissension Unsettles the Nuclear Regulatory Commission
description: WASHINGTON  Another chapter is out in the continuing and very public story of conflict within the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which has now taken the form of a battle of snail mail.

title: Ad Attacking Gingrich Reappears Online
description: The disappearing attack ad by a Super PAC backing Mitt Romney appears to have appeared again.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Treatment of McCoy Is Questioned
description: Cleveland Coach Pat Shurmur said Friday that the Browns were proceeding as if quarterback Colt McCoy had a concussion, even though he was allowed to return to Thursday nights game against the Pittsburgh Steelers just two plays after receiving a helmet-to-helmet hit.

title: Soul in Rhythm, Even When Life Isnt
description: When the stress of being homeless becomes overwhelming, Demetrice Gumbs dances in the small room of the Brooklyn shelter where she has lived for the past year.

title: List of Schools Targeted by City for Closing Is Up to 19
description: Three months into a federal grant program designed to improve some of the countrys lowest-performing schools, New York Citys Education Department has instead moved to close two troubled high schools and replace them with new schools.

title: Barcelona at Real Madrid: Two Looks Ahead to the Clsico
description: Saturday brings the biggest game of the Spanish season  maybe of the European season  so far, as Barcelona travels to the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in the capital to take on Real Madrid.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Five Strike Pose, but Baylors Griffin Has Heisman Edge
description: The five finalists for the Heisman Trophy, which will be awarded Saturday night in New York, constitute a field that has been as interesting, entertaining and accomplished as any in recent memory.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Seasonal

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Top For-Profit College Spenders
description: For-profit colleges and associations have spent millions since the start of 2010 on lobbying.

title: Tracing a Mothers Vagabond Path to Murder and Suicide in Texas
description: LAREDO, Tex.  Months after being denied food stamps, Rachelle Grimmer grabbed her two children, a .38-caliber revolver and 50 rounds of ammunition and walked into the state social services office here on Monday to demand answers.

title: The Republican Primary Campaign in Iowa Is Right at Home on Fox News
description: Theres a reason Fox News is beginning to look like a meet-the-candidate pancake breakfast in Council Bluffs, Iowa.

title: Conviction Is Reversed in 1992 Rape and Murder
description: The conviction of a man in the 1992 rape and murder of an 11-year-old baby sitter, a case that his supporters have long believed was the result of a false confession, was reversed Friday night by an Illinois appellate court.

title: Muriel Petioni, 97, Prominent Harlem Physician, Dies
description: In her last days, Dr. Muriel Petioni summoned to her bedside many of the colleagues, protgs and political allies she had amassed during a lifetime as a Harlem physician and community activist. She gave each a set of marching orders: Make sure the new geriatric center at the hospital has the homey atmosphere we agreed on. Have you recruited new volunteers for the Harlem Elders program, as we discussed? The new clinic on 146th Street  lets make sure it has the equipment it needs.

title: The Caucus | Mitt Romney on the Trail
description: Ashley Parker reports from Iowa on Mr. Romneys week on the campaign trail ahead of Saturdays debate, as he grapples with the surging candidacy of Newt Gingrich.

title: Bob Burnett, 71, Performer in the Original Highwaymen, Dies
description: Bob Burnett, who blended his smooth tenor tones into the harmonies of the original folk-revival group the Highwaymen (original because another group later, somewhat contentiously, adopted the name), died on Wednesday at his home in East Providence, R.I. He was 71.

title: An All-Carolina Soccer Final
description: HOOVER, Ala.  U.N.C. Charlotte will play North Carolina in the N.C.A.A. mens soccer final on Sunday after both teams advanced on penalty kicks in Friday nights semifinals.

title: View From the Inside
description: Between 1933 and 1974, North Carolina ran one of the countrys most aggressive eugenics programs. Records from one patient and interviews with social and health service workers detail the the inner workings of the program.

title: Caucus Video: Mitt Romney on the Trail
description: Ashley Parker reports from Iowa on Mitt Romneys week campaigning as he grapples with the surging candidacy of Newt Gingrich.

title: The World This Week, Part 2
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper West Side condo, a Chelsea studio and a Brooklyn co-op.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A two-bedroom contemporary in West Orange, N.J., and a five-bedroom farm ranch in Glen Cove.

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: The Lady: The director Luc Besson and the actress Michelle Yeoh were at the International Film Festival of India in Goa last week for the Indian premiere of their new film, The Lady. Based on the life of the Burmese Nobel Peace laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the film looks at how an Oxford housewife was transformed into an iconic political figure.

title: China and Neighbors Begin Joint Mekong River Patrols
description: BEIJING  Chinese border guards began joint patrols on Saturday on the Mekong River with their counterparts from Laos, Myanmar and Thailand, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. The effort is a significant step by China toward playing a larger role in regional security.

title: Rex Ryan Excerpts: We Can Do Some Damage
description: A few outtakes from Rex Ryans news conferences Thursday and Friday, which are available in full at Jets.com.

title: Whos the Best Baddie of Them All?
description: After completing work on this weekends Hollywood Issue, we asked the staff for their favorite movie villains. Here are ours. Who is yours?

title: Rally Defying Putins Party Draws Tens of Thousands
description: MOSCOW  Tens of thousands of Russians took to the streets in Moscow on Saturday shouting Putin is a thief and Russia without Putin, forcing the Kremlin to confront a level of public discontent that has not been seen here since Vladimir V. Putin first became president 12 years ago.

title: U.S. Troops Could Stay in Afghanistan Past Deadline, Envoy Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American ambassador to Afghanistan on Saturday raised the possibility that United States combat troops could stay in the country beyond the 2014 deadline that the White House had set for their withdrawal.

title: Police Evict Protesters From Occupy Boston Site
description: BOSTON  The police swept into Occupy Bostons campsite early Saturday morning, bringing one of the countrys largest continuous demonstrations inspired by New York Citys Occupy Wall Street protest to an end.

title: Riding, Artfully, Into the Sunset
description: MIAMI BEACH

title: Holiday Spending Stress
description: Holiday spending is a source of concern and stress for many Americans, even as they plan to spend less money, according to recent CBS News polls. A third say they feel more stress than usual about the amount they plan to spend on gifts, and half are concerned they will not be able to afford the gifts on their list this season. And with these anxieties, few anticipate spending any more this year than last year.

title: Updates on Protests in Russia
description: The Lede followed developments on Saturday in Russia, where tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Bolotnaya Square in Moscow and other cities in what organizers said were the largest anti-Kremlin protests since the fall of the Soviet Union.

title: Giants Cant Find Right Formula for Consistent Special Teams
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. This season, when the Giants special-teams coaches screened the film from last years brutal loss to the Philadelphia Eagles for the first time, the players in the room were appropriately solemn. Those who had lived through DeSean Jacksons punt return for the winning touchdown winced, while those who did not  like the rookie Jacquian Williams  were nonetheless sensitive to what they were watching.

title: Packers May Find Lessons in Perfection From Two That Werent
description: The game had been over for just a few moments, and the players were still struggling out of their shoulder pads when the murmuring finally reached full pitch. For weeks, the Green Bay Packers had existed in a blissful bubble, insulated by their good nature and their distant locale from the ceaseless questions, the ballooning expectations and the mounting fatigue of a chase for footballs most elusive goal. They have been dominant this season but not domineering, oddly under the radar for a defending champion on the path to something even greater.

title: Orwellian Currency Area
description: Kevin ORourke has a very good point: what European leaders are describing as fiscal union is very nearly the opposite:

title: A Miserable Month in the World of Sports
description: Who are the ultimate villains in the terribly sad story of Derek Boogaard?

title: Fighting Poor Recycling in Other Countries
description: When Americans turn in their old car batteries for recycling, they probably think they are doing good for the planet. And done well, recycling batteries is certainly environmentally responsible, since lead mining and processing cause far greater emissions of carbon dioxide than extracting lead from old car batteries for re-use.

title: Hockeys History, Woven With Violence
description: MONTREAL  It is one of sports biggest mysteries: how did hockey come to tolerate fighting? Hockey historians say that no one knows why or even exactly when the game decided long ago to tolerate fighting while other violent-collision sports like rugby and football did not.

title: Serge Ibaka Is Back on the Block
description: MADRID  As a cable network taped an interview in a hotel lobby, two Spaniards peered over a railing from a raised lounge to get a glimpse of the interview subject.

title: Russian Protests
description: Russians rallied across the country against election fraud in the biggest protests in Prime Minister Vladimir Putins 12 years in power.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Young men with tattoos anywhere but on their hands will not be recruited into the army, said a senior army official on a visit to Akhnoor town. The official said the Defense Ministry had announced the policy in a circular last month amid concern about the spread of disease through needles (Kashmir Live).

title: Proposed Gondola Would Link Utah Ski Resorts
description: A Utah ski lift proposed last month could be the first step in a decades-old vision of interconnecting seven Wasatch Mountain ski resorts near Salt Lake City and creating a European-style valley-to-valley ski experience in North America.

title: Punched Out: Readers Have Their Say
description: The three-part series by John Branch, Punched Out: The Life and Death of a Hockey Enforcer, profiled Derek Boogaard, a six-year N.H.L. veteran who died of an accidental overdose of alcohol and painkillers last May at age 28. A post-mortem study revealed that he had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease. Here is a sampling of readers responses to the series and to the N.H.L.s reaction. (The articles, with videos and slide shows, are at nytimes.com.)

title: Youngsters Lead the Way
description: EMERSON, N.J.  At the start of most road races, youngsters are sent to the back of the pack.

title: A Bumpy Road to Realignment
description: The N.H.L. board of governors quick approval of the planned realignment, which still needs the consent of the players union, surprised many who expected much debate and rancor.

title: Forever Henry at Arsenal
description: Thierry Henry claims to not be an emotional guy. But the former French international and star of Arsenal who now plays in Major League Soccer for the Red Bulls, was brought to tears on Friday when his former club in North London unveiled a statue of the striker outside its Emirate Stadium.

title: Rambunctious Lions Try to Rein In Tempers
description: ALLEN PARK, Mich.  When Jim Schwartz was hired as the coach of the Detroit Lions in 2009, he said he wanted to develop them into a tough team that played with an edge.

description: Olympia Snowe talks nonsense:

title: Coaching Gives Abusers Opportunity and Trust
description: When details of sexual abuse allegations against two prominent college assistants  Penn States Jerry Sandusky and Syracuses Bernie Fine  became public last month, the news hit sports like a thunderbolt.

title: 2011 Proving to Be a Bad Year for Air Quality in Texas
description: Nestled near subdivisions north of Fort Worth stands equipment that measures air pollutants. On 26 days this year, readings at the site showed higher concentrations of lung-damaging ozone than allowed by federal air-quality standards.

description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There is a Notepad on this puzzle that reads: This diagramless is 15 squares wide by 15 squares deep and has left/right symmetry. 1-Across begins in the 7th square of the first row.

description: PARIS  In a ceremony in Oslo that repeatedly invoked gender equality and the democratic strivings of the Arab Spring, the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize was presented to three female activists and political leaders on Saturday for their nonviolent struggle for the safety of women and for womens rights as peacemakers.

title: On Day 1, New Lakers Coach Plays It Straight
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Lets have a big Lakers welcome for Coach Mike Brown!

title: Homeless Families in Illinois Walking a Hard Road
description: Samantha Caballero cannot remember the last time she slept well. Some nights she nodsoff in a chair. She has slouchedin the front seat of her brothers station wagon or huddled between boxes in her mothers storage unit. Sometimes she squeezes onto a friends extra bedwith five of her six children.

title: In Glare of Climate Talks, Taking On Too Great a Task
description: DURBAN, South Africa  For 17 years, officials from nearly 200 countries have gathered under the auspices of the United Nations to try to deal with one of the most vexing questions of our era  how to slow the heating of the planet.

title: Young Voices Reverberate at Indeterminate Climate Talks
description: Youve been negotiating all my life.

description: There is a great tale about a commissioner quashing a big player deal.

description: Yankees outfielder Curtis Granderson, the pride of Thornton Fractional South High School in Lansing, Ill., returned there Friday night for a ceremony to retire his No.14 Rebels jersey.

description: BERLIN  Even as European leaders put together their latest response to the euro crisis last week, a German-American clash over how best to manage a vast financial crisis and put the world economy back on a sound footing was set in stark relief.

description: This interview with  Amy Schulman, executive vice president, general counsel, and president of nutrition at Pfizer, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  At 7 a.m. sharp on Friday, Dustin Keller took his seat in the Jets tight ends meeting room and opened his backpack, pulling out a ballpoint pen and a red spiral notebook. On the front, five letters were written in blue ink: TMbok.

title: In Egypt, a Conservative Appeal Transcends Religion
description: SHABRAMANT, Egypt  Voters attending a political rally by ultraconservative Islamist sheiks might expect a pious call for strict religious rule  banning alcohol, restricting womens dress, cutting off the hands of thieves.

title: The Fattest or the Fittest?
description: ELIMINATING the benefits reaped by institutions that are too politically powerful and interconnected to fail has been an elusive goal in the aftermath of the credit crisis. Institutions most likely to receive assistance from the federal government if they become troubled  behemoths like  Bank of America or Wells Fargo  have grown only larger in recent years. Efforts to pare down these banks have met well-financed resistance among policy makers.

description: To the Editor:

title: With Chandler at Center, the Knicks Defense Gets an Infusion of Grit
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The smiles, hugs and handshakes were passed around like a basketball in transition: Carmelo Anthony to Tyson Chandler, Chandler to Amare Stoudemire, Stoudemire to Anthony.

description: DES MOINES  A punchy and jovial Mitt Romney made a surprise visit to his Iowa headquarters just hours before he is set to take the stage at a Republican debate, joking with the crowd and his wife, Ann, and son Josh who joined him Saturday afternoon.

title: Socialisms Sacred Cows Suffer Zombie Attack in Popular Cuban Film
description: HAVANA  The day after Havana is invaded by the living dead, Juan and Sara emerge from their dilapidated apartment building to find the streets filled with people roving aimlessly, their wide eyes blank.

title: Christopher Logue Dies at 85; Modernized the Iliad
description: Christopher Logue, an English poet acclaimed for his multivolume modernization of the Iliad  a literary endeavor noteworthy for lasting four times as long as the Trojan War itself; even more noteworthy for its use of evocative anachronisms like Uzis, helicopters and aircraft carriers to conjure the world of Homers Bronze Age warriors; and still more noteworthy for having been accomplished without his knowing a word of Greek  died on Dec. 2 at his home in London.

title: Scientists Say Cod Are Scant; Nets Say Otherwise
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass.  Federal regulators are considering the unthinkable in New England:severely restricting  maybe even shutting down  cod fishing in the Gulf of Maine, from north of Cape Cod clear up to Canada. New data suggest that the status of the humble fish that has sustained the region for centuries is much worse than previously thought.

title: Two Self-Declared Leaders Help Keep Congo on Edge
description: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo  Police were going door to door on Saturday, taking youths out of houses in an opposition neighborhood and pushing them into unmarked vehicles, a day after the incumbent was declared the winner in a disputed presidential election here.

description: The gleaming Manhattan skyline rising over the Hudson River is about as real as a stage prop to Cruz, Emilio and their friends. They can see this illusory panorama from their wind-swept perch  a collection of shacks tucked along cliffs in Union City, N.J.

title: Oscar Griffin Jr., 78, Pulitzer Prize Winner Who Brought Down Scheming Texas Tycoon, Dies
description: Judge Roy Bean, the 19th-century Texas justice of the peace and saloonkeeper, called himself the law west of the Pecos. Not until the 1960s was Judge Beans legend challenged  by Billy Sol Estes.

title: Philip Burrell, Influential Jamaican Record Producer, Dies at 57
description: Philip Burrell, one of the most prolific and influential Jamaican record producers of the last 20 years, died on Dec. 3 in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 57.

title: Disillusioned Young Immigrant Kills Himself, Starting an Emotional Debate
description: MISSION, Tex.  On the last night of his life, Joaquin Luna Jr., 18, filled the pages of a spiral notebook with goodbyes. In brief letters to relatives, friends and teachers, he asked one of his brothers to take care of his nephews and his niece and told a friend he had left a memento for her in his Bible.

title: A Shoppers Companion, Still Going Strong
description: BORN in 1936, Consumer Reports had a very happy 75th birthday this year. Its business has never been better.

description: Danion Jones, who performed at the Apollo Theater a year after undergoing a daylong operation to remove most of a brain tumor, died last Sunday from complications related to the tumor, his family said.

description: MOSCOW

description: GOVERNMENT gets no respect.

description: YOUVE heard of the Chicago Six? The Haggler would like you to meet the Palau 300.

description: FINANCIAL markets are transfixed by events in Europe, and no wonder. The euro zone is under severe stress. A breakup could make recent volatility look like a day at the beach.

description: I made the tragic mistake of trying to change the way money was managed and was successful at the start, but lost my way after a while and refused to admit that I failed.

description: Is there something wrong with Viswanathan Anand?

description: Orange, Calif.

title: Americans: Undecided About God?
description: THE holidays are upon us again  it sounds vaguely aggressive, as if the holidays were some sort of mugger, or overly enthusiastic lover  and so its time to stick a thermometer deep in our souls and take our spiritual temperature (between trips to the mall, of course).

title: Treatment for Blood Disease Is Gene Therapy Landmark
description: Medical researchers in Britain have successfully treated six patients suffering from the blood-clotting disease known as hemophilia B by injecting them with the correct form of a defective gene, a landmark achievement in the troubled field of gene therapy. Hemophilia B, which was carried by Queen Victoria and affected most of the royal houses of Europe, is the first well-known disease to appear treatable by gene therapy, a technique with a 20-year record of almost unbroken failure.

title: Fire and Ice
description: WASHINGTON

title: Help Graduates Find Their Footing
description: ITS understandable that many of todays college graduates view themselves as the generation that opportunity forgot.

title: The Next First (and Only) 100 Days
description: IVE been saying this for a while, but now it feels even more acute: Americas democracy has shrunken to the only 100 days. Since F.D.R., weve measured presidents by their first 100 days. But now its really the only 100 days. Presidents lately seem to have just those 100 days to lay down a transformational agenda and get it passed in their first year  before they have to tailor their politics to the midterm elections  and then, if, as often happens, their party loses the midterms they have to focus on the next presidential election. China has five-year plans. We have 100 days every four. So all Im thinking about now is how we get the most out of the first 100 days of 2013  our next quadrennial chance to make serious policy (barring a crisis that forces our hand).

title: Democracy in the Brotherhoods Birthplace
description: ISMAILIA, Egypt

title: Tim Tebows Gospel of Optimism
description: CAN God take credit for the victories of a thick-set N.F.L. quarterback who scrambles in a weirdly jittery fashion, throws one of the ugliest balls in the game, completes fewer than half of his passes and has somehow won six of his teams last seven games?

title: A Pentagon the Country Can Afford
description: If you listen to defense industry lobbyists, hawks in Congress and the Pentagon, the sky is falling and with it, American security. It isnt.

title: Sprinkles of Pixie Dust
description: GROWING up in Brazil, I developed a high tolerance for ambiguity. The country had a history of political instability and was volatile and complex. You never knew what you were going to find from day to day, from the price of gas to whether your parents would still have jobs.

title: Readers Comment on Sundays Egypt Column
description: My Sunday column is from Ismailia, Egypt, the birthplace of the Muslim Brotherhood. It tries to look at why so many Egyptians voted for Islamic parties, and my bottom-line feeling is that Americans are feeling a bit more panicky than is justified. Its not that Egyptians seek a harsh Islamic regime; rather they think the Islamic candidates have a better record working in their neighborhoods and may be a little less likely to take bribes than other candidates. Plenty of the hand-wringing seems to be coming from Americans whove never actually met a Muslim Brotherhood member or a Salafi, and Id suggest not overdoing the rhetoric. The picture is more complicated than some Americans seem to think (although I must acknowledge that plenty of Egyptian liberals are worried as well). Read the column and post your thoughts.

title: Unfit for Execution
description: To the Editor:

title: Professor vs. Professor
description: IN 2004, the Democrats were furious at what they considered the fraud to end all frauds: the selling of George W. Bush as a decisive military leader and all-American tough guy. So they nominated John Kerry for the presidency, hoping that having a real combat veteran as their standard-bearer  a bemedaled war hero, no less, who began his convention speech by announcing that he was reporting for duty  would finally expose Bush as the tinhorn chicken hawk that liberals believed him to be.

title: Consultant Nation
description: FOR decades before Mitt Romney arrived at Harvard Business School in the fall of 1972, the traditional path for Harvard M.B.A.s had been a straight one: join a major company right out of school and climb the ranks.

title: Black, Female and Single
description: FEW things in life are more irritating than the unsolicited comments I get that black women, like me, are unlikely to marry. Family members ask, Are you ever going to get married? as if I am remaining single purposely to keep them from attending my wedding. Well-meaning married friends try to sell me on the idea that being single is liberating. And then there is my octogenarian aunt whom I love, but who also manages to unintentionally sucker punch me whenever I visit with the comment, Maybe if youd just straighten your hair youd be able to find a man.

title: The Art of Listening
description: Maputo, Mozambique

title: The National Womb
description: IN 2008, the de facto government in Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed region in the southern Caucasus, introduced a birth encouragement program, which distributes cash payments to newlyweds for each newborn, with the aim of repopulating the region more than a decade after a devastating war.

title: Chinas Spies Are Catching Up
description: Washington

title: Lady Gaga Rewrites the Script at Jingle Ball
description: Even early in Z-100s Jingle Ball on Friday night, when the girl-screams at Madison Square Garden were not yet full-blooded, Elvis Duran, the Z-100 D.J. and the evenings principal M.C., looked like a cat who had swallowed an eagle. He was sitting on an apotheosis, something that made Jingle Ball seem like much more than a promotional orgy for Top 40 radio and its advertisers, a place for pop acts to ram home their hits between screened advertisements for Splat hair color and Sweethearts Jewelry.

title: If My Dad Could Tweet
description: My dad cant tweet because hes dead. He died in 1982, when telephones were about the only way to have a conversation with someone who was not in the same place you were.

title: What Latin America Can Teach Us
description: IN a Bertelsmann Foundation study on social justice released this fall, the United States came in dead last among the rich countries, with only Greece, Chile, Mexico and Turkey faring worse. Whether in poverty prevention, child poverty, income inequality or health ratings, the United States ranked below countries like Spain and South Korea, not to mention Japan, Germany or France.

title: The Pipeline We Actually Need
description: LISTENING to the debate over the proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline, you might think that all pipelines are bad. But thousands of miles of pipeline already crisscross the United States. Without them, there would not be gasoline at filling stations, or natural gas in restaurant kitchens. It is 100 percent certain that new pipelines must be built.

title: Goodbye House, Hello Pot Plantation
description: A MANS home is his castle  except when it becomes someone elses marijuana plantation, crack den, movie set, homeless shelter, farm or public park.

title: Mr. Gingrichs Attack on the Courts
description: In any campaign season, voters are bound to hear Republican candidates talk about activist judges  jurists who rule in ways that the right wing does not like. But Newt Gingrich, who is leading in polls in Iowa, is taking the normal attack on the justice system to a deep new low.

title: Tebowing on the Gridiron, and Off
description: As football zealots channel-switch across the grim winter solstice, they are agog at the unorthodox form of Tim Tebow. He is a charismatic journeyman quarterback who cannot throw reliable forward passes, yet has run up (literally) a 6-and-1 record for the Denver Broncos after being summoned in desperation from the bench.

title: In Euro Era, Opening Bell Is a 2:30 A.M. Alarm
description: As the European debt crisis roils the markets, American traders who once awoke at dawn are now rising in the dead of night to gain an edge when business begins in London, Paris and Frankfurt.

title: The 1 Percent Clubs Misguided Protectors
description: The Republican right is pushing back hard against the 99 percent movement and its focus on the widening chasm between the fortunes of the few at the summit of the income scale and everybody else. Newt Gingrich, who led the field of Republican presidential candidates last week, argued that the concept of the 99 percent versus the 1 percent is un-American. His rival Rick Perry, who led the Republican pack in September, answered a question about taxes and inequality by saying I dont care about that.

title: Two Romneys: Wealthy Man, Thrifty Habits
description: BOSTON  Soon after Mitt Romney handed out eye-popping bonuses to top performers at his private equity firm in the early 1990s, a young employee invited him to ride in his brand-new toy  a $90,000 Porsche 911 Carrera.

description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Sunday: Taking Half-Steps

title: Lessons From Europe
description: Let me return for a minute to Kevin ORourkes recent piece on the European summit. Aside from pointing out just how bad an idea the new super-stability pact is, ORourke makes an important observation about what the European experience teaches us about macroeconomics:

title: BMW 6 Series Gran Coupe: A Swept-Back Response to Audi A7 and Mercedes-Benz CLS
description: With the introduction of the 6 Series Gran Coupe, BMW joins a growing list of companies, mostly German, offering swept-back sedans with coupelike silhouettes. Mercedes-Benz, Audi and Volkswagen got there before the 2013 sedan, which is scheduled to go on sale in the United States next summer. The Gran Coupe joins the recently updated 6 Series convertible and coupe models, both of which went on sale earlier this year.

title: St. Marys Park
description: Tucked between Bernal Heights and the Excelsior, the 320 homes in St. Marys Park are laid out on streets shaped like a bell. This spacious neighborhood of detached homes with sidewalks and well-kept yards seems to be from a bygone era. In some ways, it is.

title: Several Efforts Under Way to Measure Effect of Texas Budget Cuts on Schools
description: Since well before the 2011 legislative session began, one question has dominated conversations about the state budget cuts to public education: How will they affect public schools?

description: Protesters gathered in Moscow to challenge what they called fraudulent elections.

title: For the Engineer, a Death on the Tracks Means Horrifying Memories
description: The number of deaths is spiking this year on the tracks of the 77-mile Caltrain commuter line between San Francisco and Gilroy. With the 15th and 16th fatalities taking place within an hour of each other on Dec. 3, the total is nearing the 1995 high of 20 fatalities.

title: SantaCon 2011
Tough Questions After Audit of Arts Panel
description: An official audit by the city controllers office has confirmed what employees and the local arts community have suspected for years: The operations at the San Francisco Arts Commission are a mess.

title: Retrieving Valuables Left Behind After a Raid
description: Robyn Kralique sat on a curb in front of the Department of Public Works storage yard on Wednesday, massaging a left hand made numb by zip-tie handcuffs worn during a five-hour stay in jail. She was lamenting the possible loss of her favorite possession, a half-century-old tambourine that had belonged to a Gypsy uncle who died two years ago.

title: Drafthouse Founder Tries Hand at Film Distribution
description: Christopher Kelly wrote this column for texasmonthly.com.

title: Court Reverses Conviction of Man Jailed for 19 Years in Rape and Murder
description: In an opinion that harshly criticizes the tactics of the police and prosecutors, an Illinois appellate court on Friday night reversed the conviction of Juan Rivera, who has spent 19 years in jail for the 1992 rape and murder of an 11-year-old baby sitter in a suburb of Chicago.
