description: TOP STORIES

title: Half-Filled School Bus Crashes in China, Killing 15 Children
description: BEIJING  A half-filled school bus ferrying students home from a primary school in rural China rolled into an irrigation canal, killing 15 children and injuring 8 others, officials said.

title: Settlers Riot, Attacking Israeli Base and Post
description: JERUSALEM  Dozens of radical Jewish settlers, reacting to a rumor that several of their outposts would be dismantled, attacked an Israeli Army base in the West Bank on Tuesday, lighting fires, vandalizing vehicles and throwing stones, hours after another group of settlers occupied a border post with Jordan.

Now, in one of the less-anticipated developments of e-commerce, the mobs gather online to vent while Christmas shopping.

The headline inflation number was running quite high, but even a bit of analysis showed that this largely reflected temporary shocks, mainly hikes in VAT and commodity prices plus some effects from the depreciation of the pound. Yet there was much hysteria, with many claiming that Britain was on the verge of a 1970s-type inflationary spiral. I concluded,

Some of the quarterbacks on those teams are getting pretty good at this comeback thing. Scott Kacsmar, who writes the Captain Comeback column for Cold, Hard Football Facts (and has contributed his comeback research to Pro-Football-Reference.com), e-mailed me some additional notes on Monday:

Jon S. Corzine, the former leader of the brokerage firm who testified before a House panel last week, is appearing before the Senate Agriculture Committee on Tuesday. Lawmakers will also hear, for the first time, from two of Mr. Corzines former top deputies: Bradley Abelow, MF Globals chief operating officer, and Henri J. Steenkamp, the firms chief financial officer.

description: Cold weather and holidays bring the opportunity to shoot those enchanting firelight pictures, rich with amber hues that make every frame warm and inviting. But Vincent Laforet, Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer, filmmaker and author of Visual Stories: Behind the Lens with Vincent Laforet, warns its not as easy as rolling off a yule log. Here are his seven tips to get that shot of your family lit by hearth, menorah or blinking Christmas tree lights.

title: Surrounded by Poverty, a Lifeless Capital Stands Aloof
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  The road leading to Myanmars giant Parliament building is 20 lanes wide, well suited for military processions but eerily empty the rest of the time. A half-hour drive away, down this citys manicured avenues, is another immense edifice, still under construction: a military museum that will serve as a shrine to the countrys generals and admirals. Across the way is a military training academy; farther down the road are rows of barracks and a vast parade ground.

title: I.R.S. Denied Lesbians Legitimate Adoption Credit
description: Since the federal government does not recognize same-sex marriage, such couples are viewed as strangers in many spheres of their financial lives. They need to file separate federal tax returns, for instance. And sometimes, that can come with certain advantages.

title: Drive Picks Up Momentum With Broadcast Critics Nominations
description: Drive careened into a top spot with the Broadcast Film Critics Association, receiving nods for best picture and best director, among 10 nominations over all. Two other films surpassed that: Hugo and The Artist each earned 11 nominations (including best picture and best director). But Drive, Nicolas Winding Refns vehicular thriller, has been an outlier thus far in this awards race, though the Bagger thinks it could get some love from members of the Academy, who have been known to reward a violent automotive movie.

title: Table Talk | The Catbird Seat in Nashville
description: Within weeks of opening, the Catbird Seat has diners in Nashville and beyond abuzz with its bold, daring approach to high-end cuisine. Run by the co-executive chefs Erik Anderson and Josh Habiger (whove trained in the worlds top kitchens, including Noma, the Fat Duck and the French Laundry), the restaurant offers a simple menu: one multicourse, prix fixe dinner that changes weekly.

description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: To the Citys Top 1%, a Third of the Income
description: The very rich are, well, very rich. A new study says the 34,000 or so New Yorkers who constitute the top 1 percent of earners collected more than one-third of all the income earned in the city in 2009. Their average income was $2.2 million, and they reaped 58.3 percent of dividends and interest, 84.6 percent of business income, and 84.7 percent of capital gains.

title: The Trouble With Debates (II)
description: O.K., I take it back. No sooner did I write a post suggesting that future primaries would benefit from more intimate debates  featuring smaller group of candidates rather than the whole field, longer answers rather than short ones, and so on  than yesterdays Jon Huntsman-Newt Gingrich Lincoln-Douglas debate went and demonstrated why that could turn out to be an absolutely terrible idea. Trip Gabriels writeup for the Times does a good job of capturing the droning deadliness of the affair, the painful seminar-room quality, the absence any spark in the candidatess answers to the exquisitely-polite questions. (After an hour and a half, when the moderator offered the candidates a chance to hit the remaining five topics in a lightning round and they declined, the audience seemed to collectively sigh with relief.) If Gingrich made good on his pledge to teach an online class while in the Oval Office, I imagine that it would turn out something like this. And if Huntsmans supporters want to know why their man has struggled to inspire any excitement or strong support, despite an impressive record and solid conservative bona fides, the answer begins with the fact that he just spent 90 minutes on a stage with the candidate leading in the polls and never once said anything that might actually make some real news for his own struggling campaign. (And yes, I understand that it was all about tag-teaming Romney. But thats no excuse for being lights-out boring.)

title: The Year in Media | Hollywood Backs Down on Video on Demand
description: Staff members of The Timess media news department are highlighting the most significant developments this year in the industries they cover.

title: New iOS Games Mix the Physical With the Virtual
description: Have you ever wanted to fly in sorties over the South Pacific, blow up aliens, or fight off angry homeowners after eating their garbage? WowWees upcoming AppGear collection of toys will allow you to do all that and more.

title: Bamboozle Festival Returning to Asbury Park
description: Bon Jovi, Foo Fighters and Blink-182 will be the big acts leading the lineup for the three-day Bamboozle festival in May, which is returning to the boardwalk in Asbury Park, N.J., for the first time since 2006, the organizers announced Tuesday.

title: Reader Photos: The Spreading 99 Percent
description: The phrase the 99 percent has become an ingrained part of the cultural lexicon. Readers submitted pictures of surprising places the words have popped up.

title: Former Siemens Executives Are Charged With Bribery
description: WASHINGTON  Shell companies, Swiss bank accounts, double-crossing middlemen and cash being smuggled across borders were all part of a decade-long bribery scheme aimed at helping Siemens, the German industrial giant, secure a $1 billion contract to produce national identity cards for Argentina, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

title: Q&A: Peace While Traveling? Not Impossible.
description: AS founder and guiding teacher of the Community Meditation Center in New York, Allan Lokos has an arsenal of tools for coping with stressful situations. When it comes to travel, he said, acceptance and awareness are key. Accept that you cant make the plane take off, he advised; and when dealing with other travelers, give yourself time to be gracious.

description: Martin Marietta Materials $4.8 billion hostile offer for Vulcan Materials is anything but gentle.

description: Extending todays fish theme:

title: Theres Plenty of Room in Coach
description: The N.F.L. has apparently gotten early holiday shopping fever. Because instead of following the wisdom of the ages  which says there is not much point in firing your head coach until the season ends because A) your season is already lost and B) almost everyone you want to interview is employed by another N.F.L. team and cant talk to you early anyway  teams are festively dumping their coaches because apparently they expect some Black Friday-like deal on their next one. So if you see Bill Cowher propped on a bargain table at Wal-Mart, please alert the Jaguars, Chiefs and Dolphins.

title: How Would You Brand 21st-Century Teachers?

title: Boston Universitys Trivino Arrested, Kicked Off Team
description: Corey Trivino, a Boston University center and the leading goal scorer in the Hockey East conference, was thrown off the team by Coach Jack Parker after being arrested Sunday on charges of indecent assault and battery. Parker told BU Today that Trivino had been dismissed from the team.

title: A Soldier's Hope for Security
description: To mark the pullout of American forces from Iraq we asked Iraqis questions about the war and their countrys future. Sgt. Maj. Ahmed Salman wants the army to hold its ground after the Americans leave.

title: A Correction From the Way Back Machine
description: An article on July 20, 1981, about the failure of the transmitter serving the Columbia University radio station, WKCR-FM, misspelled the name of the stations general manager. He was Michael Silberstein, not Silverstein. This correction was delayed because we heard from Mr. Silberstein only last week.

title: U.S. Shift May Push Afghans Into Lead Role
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The senior American commander in Afghanistan said Tuesday that his plans for next year would emphasize deploying American and allied military trainers directly within Afghan security units, which could lessen the direct combat role of NATO and accelerate local forces taking the lead in a growing number of missions.

title: Holder Signals Tough Review of New State Laws on Voting
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday entered the turbulent political waters of voting rights, signaling that the Justice Department would be aggressive in reviewing new voting laws that civil rights advocates say will dampen minority participation in next years elections.

title: New Perry Ad Assails Washingtons Political Correctness
description: DES MOINES  Much of the thrust of Gov. Rick Perrys campaign message has drifted in recent weeks to his proposal to overhaul Washington. It includes stripping federal judges of lifetime tenure  which legal scholars say means getting 38 states to pass amendments rewriting Article III of the Constitution  and he also calls for somehow persuading members of Congress to cut their own salaries by 50 percent to 75 percent.

title: Inside Our Plan to Open in Brooklyn
description: Hunting and gathering in Brooklyn has been swift and successful. An existing restaurant recently became available  a 45-seater with a small garden in the back, located on a bustling street in a cosmopolitan section of the borough. It is in excellent condition, though not perfect.

description: If you sat out Black Friday and Cyber Monday, theres one more holiday-shopping-related date you may want to mark on your calendar: Free Shipping Day.

title: Bigger Share of State Cash for Medicaid
description: Medicaid has steadily eaten up a growing share of state budgets over the past three years, while education has been getting a smaller slice of the pie.

title: Courting Athletes
description: Yesterday, Advertising Age published its list of the 10 best magazine covers of 2011, and among their number is the one at right, from August, which featured Andy Samberg channeling both Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe for us. You can revisit some behind-the-scenes pictures from its creation here.

title: Bright Lights for the Party
description: Party pants, in updated styles from the resort collections, feel fresh for the holidays. Lanvins silk-print pants, with a high waist and tapered legs, are shiny and festive, as are Balenciagas metallic models, which look rather like track pants, with the contrasting fabric insets down the sides. The British label Reiss also has glittery holiday trousers, cropped with a high waist, in a dark gold sequin print. For style guidance, look to Charlotte Gainsbourg, who, for the premiere of Melancholia, wore her Balenciagas with a loose black shirt. For additional options, you might check out the denim brands: AG, Siwy and Genetic Denim all have versions of sequin jeans in stores now.

title: The Get | Jennifer Fisher Charms
description: As an alternative to the sentimental letter-stamped gold coins that have been dangling from necklaces long and short in recent years, the New York-based jewelry designer Jennifer Fisher created these great, street-inspired gothic script charms. They remind me of the skate and Latino cultures in Santa Barbara, California, where I grew up, Fisher says. The Black Letter type style was the predominant font for skin art and tattoos. Every letter in the alphabet comes in yellow gold, rose gold and diamond pav, and is sold separately so you can customize your chain. Consider the message above a not-so-subtle hint.

title: Xavier-Cincinnati Brawl Could Bring Criminal Charges
description: It has been three days since the final buzzer sounded on the Xavier-Cincinnati mens basketball game, but it is clear the reverberations are far from over.

title: Can It Be Done? Midtown on a Budget
description: The best way to save money in Midtown is to spend more time downtown  advice many a New Yorker has foisted upon visiting friends. But I spend enough time in other peoples cities to know that certain zones get tagged as tourist traps for a reason: they have attractions worth seeing. Such is the case in the heart of Manhattan.

title: The Bold and the Hopeful at Fox

The studio and its subsidiary Fox Searchlight have released The Descendants and The Tree of Life, as well as Martha Marcy May Marlene and Shame, which are earning their stars, Elizabeth Olsen and Michael Fassbender, all the right attention. (Each received a Critics Choice nomination on Tuesday).

description: One of the richest men in the world is going to build the biggest airplane ever.

title: On Our Radar: Tensions Over Chinese Fishing Attack
description: Public anger rises a day after a Chinese boat captain who was illegally fishing in South Korean waters kills a coast guardsman and seriously injures another as they try to stop the boat. One man smashes his sport utility vehicle into a police bus guarding the Chinese Embassy in Seoul, and South Korean headlines denounce the growing violence by Chinese fishermen in Korean waters. [ABC News]

title: Projecting a Lot of Light on Bad Situations
description: Last week I reviewed the Epson Megaplex, a versatile, bright home-theater projector with a connector for an iPad, iPhone or iPod Touch. I was already impressed with it when I wrote my column  but wait till you hear what happened afterward.

title: The Facebook Resisters
description: Tyson Balcomb quit Facebook after a chance encounter on an elevator. He found himself standing next to a woman he had never met  yet through Facebook he knew what her older brother looked like, that she was from a tiny island off the coast of Washington and that she had recently visited the Space Needle in Seattle.

title: Immoral and Impractical
description: Three recent stories have moved me to write about the death penalty, a clearly immoral and impractical method of punishing criminals that we should have abolished ages ago, along with virtually all other developed democratic nations.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.13
description: The day in sports from a courthouse in Bellefonte, Pa., to the slopes in in Breckenridge, Colo.

title: At Rikers Island, a Lens Is a Mirror
description: Photographer Clara Vanuuci spent Thanksgiving and Christmas with domestic abuse victims awaiting trial in jail on Rikers Island.

title: Just One Look | Vera Wang
description: Vera Wang cited Jane Birkin and YSL as inspirations for her prefall collection, with both icons interpretations of boy/girl sexiness being represented equally. Here, a perfect blend of the two: Birkinesque schoolgirl socks and a Saint Laurent-like bolero paired with a felted chiffon mini and the collections most seasonally appropriate accessory, the detachable leather sleeve.

title: U.S. Safety Board Urges Cellphone Ban for Drivers
description: A federal agency on Tuesday called for a ban on all cellphone use by drivers  the most far-reaching such recommendation to date  saying its decision was based on a decade of investigations into distraction-related accidents, as well as growing concerns that powerful mobile devices are giving drivers even more reasons to look away from the road.

title: What Iraqis Think of the American Withdrawal: Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  As American forces start to pull out of Iraq, we asked Iraqis around the country three questions: Will Iraq be better or worse off after American troops leave? What did the Americans achieve in Iraq? And what have they personally lost or gained since the 2003 invasion? Some answered only one or two questions. Although the respondents varied from area to area and across social and religions divides, some clear patterns emerge.

title: Trump Wont Go Forward With Debate
description: Donald J. Trump has dropped plans to moderate a presidential debate, but dont expect him to fade quietly from the political scene.

title: Concussion Sidelines Giroux, N.H.L.s Leading Scorer
description: The concussion news continued to get worse for the N.H.L. on Tuesday, with the Flyers announcing that Claude Giroux will be out indefinitely with a head injury.

title: A Threatened River
description: The Mekong Rivers ecosystem and a way of life are threatened by a proposal to construct a massive dam in Laos.

title: Curried Cauliflower Soup
description: It will take you only about 10 minutes to prep the ingredients for this comforting soup. Curry flavors and cauliflower always make a good match.

title: Nutcracker Season is Here: An Interview With American Ballet Theaters Little Mouse
description: If you saw American Ballet Theaters new production of The Nutcracker at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last year, odds are you remember the mouse. Yes, there was new choreography by Alexei Ratmansky, snowflakes and bumblebees, and beautiful dancing by Gillian Murphy, David Hallberg and others. Alastair Macaulay called it, a production like no other. Made with complete theatrical authority from first to last. Even so, it was hard to forget the little Ratatouille-like creature, scurrying around the stage in Act I with great conviction he nearly stole the show.

title: Fed Takes No Action, Citing Signs of Moderate Growth
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve said Tuesday that it was closing the books on 2011, maintaining its existing efforts to increase growth but adding no reinforcement amid evidence that the American economy was chugging back toward health.

title: Fear Factor Returns and Makes a Ratings Splash
description: How much do television viewers like being grossed out? Well, the last time NBC pulled in better ratings than Fear Factor at 8 p.m. Monday, George W. Bush was the president.

title: Wine Books Worth Reading
description: ALONG with top 10 lists, columns on sparkling wines (next weeks treat) and gift roundups, the end of the year would not be complete without a torrent of new books on wine and spirits. Here are four of the most notable.

title: Sweet Potato Soup With Ginger, Leek and Apple
description: This was our favorite recipe test of the soup batch. Inspired by a sweet potato and apple pure I make every year for Thanksgiving, the soup also has savory overtones. For a spectacular finish, garnish each bowl with a squeeze of lime and a sprinkle of medium-hot chili powder or chipotle chili powder.

title: If a Tree Falls, Can it Win an Oscar?
description: This fall, I was fortunate to attend a screening of If a Tree Falls  A Story of the Earth Liberation Front, an extraordinary documentary by the brilliant young filmmakers Marshall Curry and Sam Cullman that explores the prosecution of members of the Earth Liberation Front for a series of costly arson fires. The trailers and some descriptions of the film made me a bit concerned that it would be a one-sided depiction of environmental heroes going to extremes. It was nothing of the kind.

title: O.E.C.D. Calls on Members to Defend Internet Freedoms
description: PARIS  As a rising tide of digital dissent raises alarms in many capitals around the world, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development on Tuesday called on member countries to promote and protect the global free flow of information online.

title: Pured White Bean Soup With Pistou
description: White beans and pesto or pistou (pesto without the pine nuts) always make a nice marriage. Thin the pistou with a little extra olive oil so that you can drizzle it over the rich-tasting pure.

title: SACs Cohen Weighs In on Insider Trading
description: Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital, called the rules that govern insider trading very vague, according to a deposition the hedge fund titan gave in a long-running case, Reuters reports. Mr. Cohens firm has been under a cloud of scrutiny amid a federal crackdown on Wall Street insider trading. Read more

title: The Caucus Click: Cain Closes Up in Iowa
description: On Monday, Herman Cains Iowa headquarters invited supporters to come to the office and take home memorabilia. Pins, signs, branded plastic cups were all given away.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Bank Executives Settle F.D.I.C. Lawsuit
description: Former executives at Washington Mutual have reached a $64 million agreement to settle a civil lawsuit with the government, according to officials with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which pursued the case after the savings and loan collapsed in 2008.

title: Alderson Works Through Mets Woes
description: Daniel Murphy strode into a lounge at Citi Field on Tuesday and aimed a wisecrack at his boss that might only work in the setting of a company holiday party.

title: Reasons to Love New York
description: Apparently include me, at least according to Jonathan Chait.

title: E-Commerce Sites Cater to Procrastinators by Extending Free Shipping
description: Free shipping has become a necessary evil for online retailers, and this year many are extending their free shipping cut-off dates for Christmas gifts.

title: TimesCast | Sandusky Waives Hearing
description: Former Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky waives his right to a preliminary hearing, facing over 50 counts of child sex abuse.

title: Despite Budget Squeeze, Arts Are Still Robust, Ed Department Says
Unlike New York, Some Districts Embrace Social Media
Top Editor Resigns at Los Angeles Times
description: Russ Stanton, who was put at the helm of The Los Angeles Times to guide the paper through a series of wrenching newsroom cuts, will step down as its editor on Dec. 23, the paper said Tuesday. The current managing editor, Davan Maharaj, a frequent presence in the newsroom and a champion for the papers growing Web site, will take over.

title: The Long Life of the Vampire Squid
description: 7:54 a.m. | Updated

title: TimesCast | Inside Myanmar's Capital
description: Six years after Myanmar inaugurated this new capital, Naypyidaw remains austere and often lifeless, a costly monument to military rulers who are no longer in charge.

title: Amanpour to Leave ABCs This Week and Rejoin CNN
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Christiane Amanpour is leaving the anchor chair of ABCs This Week and returning to her old network home, CNN, as the anchor of an evening newscast on CNN International.

title: Out There | Nel Beloufas Brave New World
description: Like many artists responding to our duplicitous marketing- and infotainment-driven world, Nel Beloufa, a young French Algerian video artist based in Paris, works in the interstices of fact and fiction. In Kempinski (2007), which was on view last year at the New Museum, Beloufa uses a simple tweak in tense to build an eerie alternate reality. Shot at night in Mali, Kempinski features interviews with local inhabitants in rural settings  in a crowd of oxen, in bushes, in dusty courtyards  who speak about things from telepathic communication with stars, animals and machines to teleportation via light and sound, as if they were present-day realities. The scenes are lit by handheld, corded fluorescent lights that could, if you squint, be mistaken for alien technology, and the subjects assertions register as farcical deadpan: Beloufas tone of choice. The narration plays on a viewers superficial ideas of where primitive magic and futuristic science might meet, hinging on that rhetorical switch from will be to is.

title: Should We Occupy Education?
description: Dramatic disparities separate the performance of privileged and disadvantaged students, and as complex as the education equation is, one factor  poverty  is consistently associated with lower scores for districts, schools and individual children.

title: New Challenge to a Murdoch Over Hacking
description: LONDON  Rupert Murdochs son James received and responded to e-mail messages in 2008 that referred to a nightmare scenario of legal repercussions from widespread phone hacking at the tabloid The News of the World, a chain of e-mail messages and replies released Tuesday by a British parliamentary panel shows. It is the first documentation that Mr. Murdoch had been notified of a wider hacking problem long before he has admitted.

title: Politics Beats Science, Again
description: Heres a scene you may find familiar: Government experts carefully study a problem, and come to a conclusion based on scientific evidence. They get over-ruled by bureaucrats who seem more concerned about politics than science. This isnt a historical anecdote from the Bush administration. Im talking about the Obama administration.

title: Fear Factor on NBC Draws Big Audience in Return
description: After a five-year hiatus, NBCs gross-out competition Fear Factor delivered strong numbers for over a two-hour period with an average of 8.6 million total viewers. It also matched the highest 8 p.m. rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for a non-sports program on NBC since February 2008.

title: Dragon Tattoos New Date and Other News From the Circuit
description: The news today in awards land is all about anticipation. Fans of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo  or anybody looking to see whether Denbygate was merited or not  get to scratch their itch sooner: Sony announced on Tuesday  via Twitter  that the film will now open a day earlier, with tickets available to showings beginning at 7 p.m. on Dec. 20.

title: Freedom of Expression, Online: Outlining the First Amendment for Teenagers
description: Overview | What are the First Amendment rights? Does freedom of speech mean you people can publish whatever they want on the Internet? In this lesson, students consider what they know about the First Amendment and a court case involving a blogger. They then research the rights and responsibilities of young bloggers and create a primer for teens who blog.

title: Austrian Tradition, With Ambition
description: I AM not one to sneer at the manifest pleasures of a Wiener schnitzel. I have friends, however, who are not nearly so accepting of these simple joys.

title: No. 7 Sub to Open in Brooklyn
Welcome to Brooks Brothers, a k a Fraternity Row
description: Dear Critical Shopper,

title: Quinn Attacked Over Councils Discretionary Funds
description: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, widely viewed as a leading contender in New Yorks 2013 mayoral race, found herself on the defensive on Tuesday as another candidate attacked her over her management of the City Councils discretionary funds.

title: Media and Entertainment Companies Add Support to Proposed Antipiracy Legislation
description: Big media companies have ratcheted up the pressure on Washington to support legislation that would protect online content.

title: Reviewing Sesonal
description: In my review this week of Sesonal, an ambitious Austrian restaurant near Carnegie Hall, I mention that it most likely offers the best list of Austrian wines in New York.

title: For Sparrows, Terror Has Grim Consequences
description: Fear makes the wolf look bigger, or so goes a German proverb. And new research underlines the scientific basis for the adage: the mere hint of the presence of a predator can have life-or-death consequences for the terrorized prey, regardless of the true threat.

title: Hit on McCoy Earns Harrison a One-Game Suspension
description: James Harrison and the Pittsburgh Steelers have thought that the N.F.L. has unfairly singled him out for penalties and fines since it began cracking down on hits to the head in the middle of last season.

title: 2 Leaders in Russian Media Are Fired After Election Articles
description: MOSCOW  A high-ranking editor and a top executive from one of Russias most respected news publications were dismissed on Tuesday after an apparent conflict over coverage that appeared to highlight widespread anger with the results of parliamentary elections this month.

title: Walk Through Earthquake Rubble Online
description: A toppled building; mangled cars and miles and miles of debris:Google has uploaded scenes from the Japanese tsunamis aftermath to its Street View service, offering a unique if heart-wrenching virtual peek into the destruction along Japans Pacific coast.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from China, Iraq, Russia and Pennsylvania.

title: Look of The Moment | Rooney Mara
description: The Look: Sublime. A floating white dress with cutout detailing and the slightest train needs no further embellishment (i.e. bag, jewels, lipstick or statement heel).

title: Mama at Gradisca, 126 West 13th St.
description: Caterina Schenardi, mother of owner Massimo Galeano, comes to NYC a few times a year to make pasta at Grandisca, 126 West 13th St.

title: Small Businesses Plan to Increase Hiring
description: Some good news in the job market: Small businesses plan to increase hiring, according to the latest report from the National Federation of Independent Business.

title: BMW and G.M. Discuss Collaboration on Advanced Technologies, Including Fuel Cells
description: Citing unnamed sources, a recent report in the German business magazine WirtschaftsWoche said that General Motors and BMW would collaborate on hydrogen fuel-cell technology for passenger cars. Specifically, BMW would contribute toward research costs in exchange for the technology developed by G.M.

title: In the Shadow of the 59th Street Bridge, 8:10 A.M.
Craig Hopson Prepares for a Chinatown Opening
description: When Craig Hopson leaves Le Cirque in about a month, after three years, he will begin working on a springtime opening for the Brewster, at 177 Mott Street (Broome Street). His partners are Frank Roberts, who managed the Rose Bar, and Ross Morgan, who is developing the building, which once housed a fine horse-carriage maker.

title: Overnight Makeover for a Kosher First Kitchen
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Koshering of the White House
description: How far would you go to assure that your dinner guests could follow their dietary needs?

title: Extreme Ecology in a Polar Desert
description: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier fed streams.

title: We Are the 99 Percent as Told in Pictures
description: Even as many of the Occupy [Your City/Street Here] encampments around the country have been expelled by local police forces, one of its central refrains  We Are the 99 Percent  has become part of the national dialogue. The National Desk invited readers to submit pictures incorporating the phrase and produced a slide show.

title: Junior Flores Shines for U.S. U-17 Team
description: Earlier this month at the Nike International Friendlies in Florida, the United States under-17 national team drew a lot of attention as it defeated Brazil and Turkey on the way to winning the tournament.

title: Its Almost-Presidents Day!
description: Eleven years ago today, Al Gore, for one important moment, was the most powerful man in our republic. The day before, the Supreme Court, in a 5-4 vote, halted the partial recount of presidential ballots in Florida that Gore had requested. But that did not mean the 2000 presidential election was over. George W. Bush could not declare victory until Gore conceded defeat.

title: The On Again, Off Again Donald
description: Donald Trump has announced that he will not, after all, be moderating a debate in Iowa for the Republican presidential candidates with the right-wing magazine Newsmax. He says the party wanted him to promise he wouldnt run as an independent, and he wants to preserve that possibility.

title: JPMorgan Shares Fall as MF Global Trustee Suggests Inquiry of Bank
description: After a couple of ups and downs, shares in JPMorgan Chase were trading in positive territory by Tuesday afternoon. And then they took a quick and sharp tumble.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from China, Iraq, Russia and Pennsylvania.

title: California, With Revenue Shortfalls, Will See More Budget Cuts
description: LOS ANGELES  The California Legislature passed a budget in June relying on optimistic projections of how much money the state could bring in with a growing economy. But to the surprise of few, not all of that money has materialized.

title: Just One Look | Helmut Lang
description: Spider webs, beetles, cicadas and other creepy crawlers inspired Helmut Langs Nicole and Michael Colovos this prefall season. In between quintessential Helmut Lang pieces  leather leggings and biker jackets, open-weave linen shirts and asymmetrical jersey tops and dresses  are collection-defining prints based on insects exoskeletal-esque wings and amphibious camouflages, as seen on this extremely graphic and sporty chiffon dress.

title: Glamour and Munitions: A Screen Sirens Wartime Ingenuity
description: Did you hear the one about the actress and the composer who tried to invent a remote-controlled torpedo? It sounds like the opening line of a bar joke, but its actually the premise of Richard Rhodess slim new book, Hedys Folly.

title: Loeb Reiterates Opposition to a Yahoo Minority Investment
description: As Yahoos board continues to ponder its next strategic steps, one of its biggest shareholders would like to remind directors that hes opposed to including any plan to sell a big minority stake to an outside investor consortium.

title: Small Businesses Plan to Increase Hiring
description: Our colleagues at the Economix blog have have just published a post about a new National Federation of Independent Business survey indicating that the net share of companies planning to hire workers is at its highest point in 38 months. In fact, the net percentage of companies that say they have already increased their employment in the last three months  that is, the percent saying they increased their staff minus the percent saying they decreased it  was positive for the first time in nearly four years.

title: Tuck Everlasting Musical Sets Sights on Broadway
description: A musical adaptation of the 1975 childrens novel Tuck Everlasting is aiming for Broadway next season with the Tony Award winner Casey Nicholaw (The Book of Mormon) as director, according to theater executives who attended staged presentations of the show for producers and investors on Friday.

title: Investigation of Chevy Volt Prompts Opel to Delay Sales of Ampera
description: The Opel Ampera, Europes version of the Chevrolet Volt, will sit in showrooms pending resolution by American investigators of a battery fire question related to crash tests of the Volt, according to Andrew Marshall, director of product development communications at Opel.

title: A Starring Role for the Little Humble Herring
description: IN a fancy womens department store in Osaka, Japan, earlier this year, shoppers lined up for one of the latest food fads in the country, jars of pickled herring.

title: Giving Awards From JPMorgan Chase Draws Small Audience
description: Will JPMorgan Chase pay for another televised award show for charities next year? After seeing the ratings for its American Giving Awards, that is far from a sure thing.

title: Philosopher Sticks Up for God
description: There are no atheists in foxholes, the old saying goes. Back in the 1950s, when the philosopher Alvin Plantinga was getting his start, there were scarcely more religious believers in academic philosophy departments.

title: Leading the Way Through the Smoke
description: Straight-shooting, hard-hitting and fuming with contempt for the tobacco industry, Addiction Incorporated would be almost too exhausting to watch were it not for the folksy charm of its star witness. Nestled at the center of this relentless documentary, guiding us through a deluge of scientific evidence and corporate bobbing and weaving, is the scientist and whistle-blower Victor J. DeNoble, who reveals himself to be a born raconteur. His easygoing, self-deprecating narration is the films most valuable asset and the viewers best friend.

title: App Smart Extra: A New Weight-Loss App
description: The Quick Calls section of last weeks App Smart column briefly mentioned a new weight-loss app called Noom.

description: Seventy-some years ago, the nonstop machine-gun fire of one-liners in The Man Who Came to Dinner, by Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman, was fresh and topical. Today  in a revival at the Theater at St. Clements  not so much.

title: Stony Brook University to Get $150 Million Gift
description: James H. Simons usually shuns publicity, though some attention is inescapable for a hedge fund billionaire and major philanthropist. But on occasion, he allows one cause to draw him into public view: Stony Brook University, where he was a mathematics professor long ago.

title: Now Booking | The Yeatman, Portugal
description: Proud residents of Porto, Portugal, will tell you that the only good thing about Vila Nova de Gaia, the town across the Douro River, is its view of Porto. Thats not inaccurate  its just half the story. For port wine lovers, the south-bank town is a sacred place of oak-barreled Burgundy aging to perfection in a cobblestone warren on wobbly, centuries-old port lodges. Above them sits the new Yeatman Hotel, an 82-room resort and spa that takes the idea of a wine hotel (see also the Hotel Marques de Riscal) to new heights. Certainly its easy to get that impression after a visit to the hotels cork and wine museum or after a stay in suites sponsored and decorated by various Portuguese wineries. The Fladgate master suite ($430 per night) features a 50,000-liter port barrel repurposed as a king-size bed.

title: California Creates Special Unit to Fight Computer Crimes
description: California has long led the nation in technological innovation. A lesser-known fact: It also leads the country in cybercrime.

title: ITunes Opens in Latin America, Challenging Rival Services
description: Apple quietly announced on Tuesday that it had opened its iTunes store in Brazil and 15 other countries in Latin America, including Argentina, Venezuela, Chile, Colombia, Nicaragua and Peru. Apple now operates the iTunes music store in 51 countries.

title: Reviewing Pulqueria
description: Pulqueria , one of this weeks Dining Briefs, is the latest venture by Heather and Christopher Tierney, the siblings behind Apothke. The restaurant and bar is the citys first to focus on pulque, the fermented agave sap that Mexicans have been drinking since pre-Columbian times, here mixed with fresh juices and smoky mezcal. A lively crowd dines on chef Nacxitl Gaxiolas friendly, mildly authentic accompaniments: masa gorditos and empanadas, savory little tacos, selections of salsas from throughout Mexico, and larger, more robust plates like pork shank confit. Some of the dishes are a bit too tame, but theres also a lot of interest. The Yucatecan pumpkin seed spread, sikil pak, and the tuna tostadas are real winners.

title: Tere OConnors Cover Boy
description: Tere OConnors new dance is an all-male affair. It is performed by four men, features only one woman among its collaborators and even has the title Cover Boy.

title: A Buoyant Bouquet Tossed to France
description: Donizetti knew how to make himself beloved. For his first French opera, La Fille du Rgiment, he composed a shamelessly jingoistic ode to France, a work so ingratiating that for years it was performed in Paris on Bastille Day.

title: An Almost-Presidents Day Quiz
description: Why should we care about presidential losers? Because losing candidates often change American history in more profound ways than some of the men elected president.

title: A First Iowa Forecast: Race Is Still Wide Open
description: Were a few days away from releasing the official version of our polling-based forecasts for the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary. But the statistical work behind the model is done, so I can give you a preview of what the forecasts will look like. Conveniently, this will also serve as an overview of the current state of play in Iowa.

title: Exploring Eliots Poem Cycle Anew
description: If youve had the feeling that Elliott Carter has been particularly prolific lately, an essay in the program book for a concert by Axiom at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening confirmed it. Mr. Carter has written 15 new works since his 100th birthday.

description: 138 North Eighth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 384-1904; bettonyc.com

title: U.S. Leaving Iraqi Comrades-in-Arms in Limbo
description: RAMADI, Iraq  Meeting various neighbors and supplicants on a recent evening, Americas staunchest ally in Iraq, Sheik Ahmed Abu Risha, sat in a tent sipping tea from an implausibly tiny glass cup. He greeted each new visitor with a hearty outburst of dear one and a kiss on the cheek.

description: Adapted from Denise Moseley on peaceandloveinthekitchen.com

description: THE baking life is one of many sorrows, and I have seen or tasted them all.

description: The Slap Shot contributor Chris Botta talks New York area hockey and previews HBOs 24/7 in the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast.

description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors at The New York Times have been reading on the Web. For more Scuttlebot, go to the right-hand column of this page.

title: Elis Bread Is at the Station
description: The departures and arrivals have come quickly this fall for Grand Central Terminals shops and vendors. Now Eli Zabar has opened a bakery, Elis Bread, in the Grand Central Market space previously occupied mainly by Corrado Bread and Pastry. Everything sold at Elis Bread is made at Mr. Zabars bakery on the Upper East Side; construction of a kitchen one floor above the market is expected to be done in a few weeks, and all the breads, breakfast pastries and coffee cakes for Elis Bread will be baked there. That way we can deliver fresh bread to the market several times a day, Mr. Zabar said. Fancy pastries will still be made uptown. Among the highlights at Elis Bread is what Mr. Zabar calls the Grand Central baguette, a handmade bread sold plain or with a liberal scattering of green or black olives in the dough. Its the same as the Amagansett baguette he sells in the Hamptons in summer.

title: Tired of Hanukkah Gelt? Try a Chocolate Menorah
description: Michel Cluizel, the French chocolatier, has introduced a line of chocolates and pastries made under kosher supervision in a New Jersey plant. For Hanukkah, he has come up with a pareve chocolate menorah that allows you to observe the tradition in reverse, eating one candle each night instead of adding one. The central candle, or shamus, which is used to kindle the others, is fitted with a small container of almond oil so it can actually be lighted.

title: Give a Gift, Help a Charity
description: Looking for a gift that will please more than just the recipient? This year there are teas, calendars and a grab bag of Brooklyn-made treats that benefit charitable groups.

title: My Brothers Hazing
description: To the Editor:

title: House Passes Extension of Cut to Payroll Taxes
description: WASHINGTON  Defying a veto threat from President Obama, the House on Tuesday passed a bill extending a cut in Social Security payroll taxes for 160 million Americans for another year. But the Democratic majority in the Senate vowed to reject the measure because of objections to other provisions, including one to speed construction of an oil pipeline from Canada to the Gulf Coast.

title: Just One Look | Narciso Rodriguez
description: The linear black and pale blue (and red) color-blocked sweaters at Narciso Rodriguezs prefall collection were hard to ignore. Weve never stopped doing knits, the designer says. But yes, I guess there are more of them this season. Other noteworthy pieces include the detachable (read: wonderfully transitional) fox fur sleeves and hooded toppers, and the black body-con leather-blocked dresses that are accented with a graffiti-splash print in black, white and yellow.

title: File-Sharing Company Sues Record Label, for a Change
description: The way the cats-and-dogs legal fights of the entertainment industry usually work, its the big record company or movie studio that sues the offshore Internet corporation, accusing it of violating its rights.

title: A Perfect Place for a Photo Shoot, With One Catch
description: The client wanted a grand, winding staircase for the photo shoot, something mansionlike and visually distinctive.

title: Readers Weigh In on Life With and Without Facebook
description: Soon after my article about people who resist the lure of Facebook was posted on The Timess Web site on Tuesday afternoon, more than 700 people had liked it  on Facebook itself. Many left comments about it on The Timess Facebook page and on our site.

title: Wall St.s Odd Couple and Their Quest to Unlock Riches
description: Private equity and public pensions are one of Wall Streets most peculiar love affairs. Recently, the two have tried to become even closer. But dont get mushy  this relationship is about money, not romance.

title: Private Lives To Close on Broadway At Years End
description: The new Broadway revival of Private Lives, starring Kim Cattrall (Sex and the City) and Paul Gross, will close five weeks earlier than planned because of weak ticket sales, the producers announced on Tuesday night. The production of the classic Noel Coward play, which opened on Nov. 17 to generally good reviews, will now end on Dec. 31 instead of the original closing date of Feb. 5, 2012.

title: Crowded Sidewalks
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston University Star Is Off Team
description: Corey Trivino, a Boston University center and the leading goal scorer in the Hockey East conference, was thrown off the team by Coach Jack Parker after he was arrested Sunday on charges of indecent assault and battery. Trivino pleaded not guilty to all the charges at his arraignment Monday in Brighton District Court. Assistant District Attorney Cameron Merrill of Suffolk County said in court that witnesses described an intoxicated Trivino breaking into the room of a female student and trying to kiss and grope her. He was charged with three counts of indecent assault and battery, two counts of breaking and entering and one count of assault with attempt to rape. Trivino, a senior, was drafted by the Islanders in 2008.

title: Gingrich the Historian
description: To the Editor:

title: Have Evangelicals Lost Their Sway?
Massachusetts: Gambling Agency Chairman Is Named
description: Gov. Deval Patrick appointed Stephen Crosby on Tuesday to head the new Massachusetts Gaming Commission, a five-member body formed by the same legislation that legalized three resort-style casinos and one slots parlor in this state. Mr. Crosby, currently the dean of the McCormack Graduate School of Policy and Global Studies at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, previously served as a senior aide to Paul Celucci and Jane Swift, both former Republican governors. The committee will give out licenses for the states new gambling spots and set some of the rules that will govern their operation.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,836 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: Text of the Federal Reserves Interest Rate Statement
description: The following is the full text of the statement released on Tuesday by the Federal Reserve:

title: City Says Few Jane Addams Seniors Lack Credits
N.B.A. and Its Conflicts Cloud Getting Best Deal for Hornets
description: Imagine for a moment that George Shinn still owns the New Orleans Hornets. His team is struggling financially and competitively. His franchise star wants out and is threatening to leave as a free agent next July.

title: Controversy Drives Advertisers From  All-American Muslim  Or Does it?
description: At least two advertisers have withdrawn commercials from All-American Muslim, a new series on the TLC cable channel, since an activist organization called the Florida Family Association condemned the show. But others cited by the organization as pulling out as sponsors are disputing the claim.

title: Hezbollahs Hypocritical Resistance
description: Exeter, England

title: Ron Paul Rising
description: The race for the Republican nomination may be coming down to Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney, but in the contest for the Iowa caucuses, their high-profile battle might still turn out to be a sideshow. The national party has spent the last two weeks resigning itself to a choice between the former speaker and the former Massachusetts governor. But Iowa Republicans may end up choosing between Gingrich and Representative Ron Paul.

title: Park Tae-joon, Founder of a Giant in Steel, Dies at 84
description: Park Tae-joon, a former South Korean general who created Posco, one of the worlds largest steel companies, helping to lay the foundation for his nations rise from an impoverished postwar society into an industrial powerhouse, died on Tuesday in Seoul. He was 84.

title: As Rivalry Tightens, Romney Is Reflective
description: MADISON, N.H.  Mitt Romney  he of the inscrutable, overly polished and occasionally robotic mien  is striving mightily to humanize himself just three weeks before the first round of voting begins. And that means no topic, be it his experience with humble toilets (a bucket affair) or his faith, is off limits.

title: Bidding for Japanese Players Is a Denigrated Risk
description: Shortly after the Boston Red Sox won the rights to negotiate with the star right-hander Daisuke Matsuzaka in November 2006, the Yankees did the same with the left-hander Kei Igawa.

title: Avon Announces Plans to Seek a New Chief Executive
description: After years of tepid earnings and turmoil, the cosmetics giant Avon Products announced late Tuesday that it planned to look for a new chief executive to replace its longtime leader, Andrea Jung.

title: In Boxing, Not All Olympic Trial Winners Become Olympians
description: Ever since Jose Ramirez started boxing, he placed one goal above all others: to represent the United States in the Olympics. To that end, he declined to turn professional, won more than 100 amateur bouts and studied videos of past Olympians like Oscar De La Hoya.

title: Former Gingrich Aide Forms Fund-Raising Group
description: A former top aide to Newt Gingrich formed a Super PAC on Tuesday to help bolster Mr. Gingrichs resurgent presidential campaign, giving him a potentially powerful tool as he seeks to maintain his lead in key primary states against a flurry of attacks from other candidates and Super PACs.

title: Democrats Find a Welcome Distraction
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama bluntly acknowledged Tuesday that winning a second term was not a slam-dunk, but a development outside his control is bolstering Democratic spirits: the prospect of a drawn-out Republican battle between Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich.

title: Bursts of Economic Growth in Panama Have Yet to Banish Old Ghosts
description: PANAMA  Gleaming new skyscrapers line the waterfront like a mini-Dubai, as boosters say, including a new 70-story Trump tower that is the tallest building in Latin America.

title: Immigration Crackdown Also Snares Americans
description: A growing number of United States citizens have been detained under Obama administration programs intended to detect illegal immigrants who are arrested by local police officers.

title: Brackman, Former Top Pick, Signs With Reds
description: 10:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Selling Swipes May Be a Swindle, but Dont Call It Larceny
description: It is a classic subterranean swindle, up there with turnstile hopping and token sucking: the selling of contraband swipes from an unlimited MetroCard to unquestioning subway riders.

title: 11th Body, Believed to Be of Missing Woman, Is Found
description: They had planned to gather on Tuesday, on the barren shore along Ocean Parkway on Long Island, to remember the victims of a suspected serial killer, the remains found scattered among the areas shrouded thickets over the past year.

title: A Delisting for Olympus Puts Japan in a Debate
description: TOKYO  Scandal-racked Olympus has cleared the first hurdle to avoiding expulsion from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. But a final decision on whether the exchange will carry out its threat to delist Olympuss shares may still be months away.

title: Egypt Drops Some Charges Against Blogger
description: Updated | Wednesday | 6:38 p.m. A civilian court in Cairo dropped two charges against a prominent blogger and activist, Alaa Abd El Fattah, the Egyptian newspaper Al-Masry Al-Youm reported on Tuesday.

title: Anthonys Hurt Knee Further Unsettles Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks are days away from their first exhibition game but do not appear any closer to fully figuring out a roster that is still in flux. They have sought to add free agents, and have not given up. Now they are also trying to work around injuries that have made it more difficult to gather a sense of what they are working with.

title: Archdiocese Can Demolish SoHo Church, Court Rules
description: A nearly five-year struggle over the future of a Roman Catholic parish in SoHo that began with a sudden padlock on the church doors ended on Tuesday, when New York States highest court affirmed that the Archdiocese of New York had the right to demolish the shuttered building despite opposition from the former parishioners.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Troubled Girl Then, a Proud Woman Today
description: When Carmen Roman used to look in the mirror, she hated what she saw.

title: Confusion Follows Claim That Corzine Knew of Funds Transfer
description: WASHINGTON  A Senate hearing into the collapse of MF Global was thrown into confusion on Tuesday after a main witness implied that Jon S. Corzine, its former chief executive, knew the firm had been misusing customer funds, an accusation that could not be substantiated.

title: $4.8 Million Sought From Morgan Stanley in Price-Fixing Case
description: WASHINGTON  An electricity price-fixing scandal thought to have cost New York consumers about $300 million has led to a proposed settlement with Morgan Stanley for $4.8 million. But the proposal has brought complaints from a consumer group, which points out that the company took in four times that much in the scheme.

title: Patents and the Public Interest
description: Next week, in a case closely watched both by analysts and retailers, the International Trade Commission will decide whether the handset maker HTC should be allowed to import its products into the United States. The controversy? A claim by Apple that HTC infringed on two of the estimated 250,000 patents covering smartphone technology. If the commission agrees, it is likely to issue an exclusion order, which would in effect say keep out (of the United States) to HTCs Android phones during the Christmas season.

title: With Port Actions, Occupy Oakland Tests Labor Leaders
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In most cities, the Occupy movement has been thrown on the defensive, struggling to regroup and plan new protests after being evicted from its encampments by the police.

title: A Tiger Execution
description: At 11:30 a.m. on the beautiful, crisp morning of Dec. 9, 1861, several thousand somber Confederate soldiers in Gen. Edmund Kirby Smiths division formed a three-sided square around a slight natural depression outside their camp near Centreville, Va. Outside the ranks, both soldiers and civilians climbed into trees and onto rooftops to get a better view, for this was no ordinary muster. A military court had convicted two men for attacking an officer and trying to free some prisoners from a guard house. The sentence was death by firing squad.

title: To Maintain Water Pumps, It Takes More Than a Village
description: This is a follow-up to Fridays column Keeping the Water Flowing in Rural Villages.

title: Two Views of Aqueduct
description: The longtime racetrack now offers patrons slots and electronic table games, but some fans seem to prefer the horse racing.

title: Aiding Disabled, Nonprofits Rake in State Money
description: Every day across New York State, thousands of part-time workers visit the homes of developmentally disabled people to teach them simple tasks, like grooming or how to take a bus.

title: Offices With More Breathing Room
description: The 28th floor of the office building at 499 Park Avenue has 17-foot-high windows that run from floor to ceiling on four sides, and they offer views clear to the George Washington Bridge and to airplanes taking off from La Guardia and Newark airports.

title: Morgan Stanley Has More to Do
description: Morgan Stanleys settlement with the bond insurer MBIA leaves behind another big chunk of the financial crisis. At $1.8 billion, it doesnt come cheap for James Gorman, Morgan Stanleys chief executive. But it puts Mr. Gormans company on the right track by increasing regulatory capital and tidying up a very messy second year for him.

title: Keep Antarctica as It Is
description: Oslo

title: Free the F.D.A.
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: After Officers Killing, a Focus on a North Carolina Warrant
description: Despite his being wanted for a shooting in North Carolina, the man accused of killing a police officer in Brooklyn on Monday was twice released from jail in New York this fall because the authorities in North Carolina declined to have him extradited, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Tuesday.

title: Providence Puts Focus on Making a Home for Knowledge
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  When Brown University opened its new $45 million medical school in August about a mile from its campus here, it was the institutions first academic department to be located away from its home on College Hill overlooking downtown Providence.

title: No Pain, No Gain? Not So Fast
description: Los Angeles

title: Aid for Child Care Drops When It Is Needed Most
description: BALTIMORE  With states under pressure to cut their budgets and federal stimulus money gone, low-income working parents are facing a paradox. Just when they have to work longer hours to make ends meet, they are losing access to the thing they need most to stay on the job: a government subsidy that helps pay for child care.

title: James B. Buslik
description: Mr. Buslik, 61, is a principal of Adams & Company, a property manager and commercial brokerage firm that specializes in Manhattan office space, primarily in the fashion district and the Flatiron and Chelsea neighborhoods.

title: Still on Patrol After Two Decades, Valued but Rare
description: They may be a little less swift on their feet or nimble in a fight, but despite the perils of their job, many have never lost their love for the electricity and unpredictability of the streets.

title: Titus Andronicus
description: Photos from the production at the Public Theater.

title: Wednesday: Alphonses Comics Partner
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! In tomorrows puzzle, there will be a Notepad that reads: Parts of 15 answers in this puzzle are missing, in a manner for you to discover.

title: I Wouldnt Touch That Pie, if I Were You
description: The torture-porn movie business has an ancient and revered progenitor in the immortal Shakespeare himself. His early tragedy Titus Andronicus is a careering pileup of gothic horrors in which great ingenuity is shown in the matter of violent murder. Heads and hands are lopped off at regular intervals; the body count practically defies computation; and the finale is a banquet that only the meat-pie-making Mrs. Lovett of Sweeney Todd could love.

title: At Aqueduct, Clubhouse and Casino Are Different Turfs
description: The opening of Resorts Worlds new neon-blazing casino at the graying 117-year-old Aqueduct Racetrack  the racino  is more of a culture clash than a gambling hybrid.

title: A Face Wash Campaign for the iPhone Set
description: WHAT do teenagers and young adults hope to get as holiday gifts? Smartphones? Tablet computers? Video games? If a giant marketer has its way, they may instead find face wash dispensers under the Christmas tree or Hanukkah bush.

title: Shining Light on the Role of Drivers in Prostitution
description: Sofia, a sweet-voiced and cherubic 24-year-old, was one of the lucky ones: She managed to escape much of the suffering shared by the millions of sex workers trafficked throughout the world, and even saw two of her traffickers forced out of the country and back to Mexico.

title: New Law Bans Mail-Order Drug Mandates
description: Mom-and-pop pharmacies will be better able to compete with mail-order companies because of a bill that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has signed into law.

title: Newt, Mitt, Bibi and Vladimir
description: I have a simple motto when it comes to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. I love both Israelis and Palestinians, but God save me from some of their American friends  those who want to love them to death, literally.

title: Why Was He Still Free? A Clue in a Shot to the Foot
description: One day over the summer, RayShawn Maberson, walking toward his home in Greensboro, N.C., was shot in the foot by a stranger who got away.

title: Money Laundering at Lebanese Bank
description: The chart below shows the intricate money-laundering system the Lebanese Canadian Bank used to divert money to the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, according to United States officials.

title: Richards Is Held at Bay by the Stars, His Former Team
description: The game did not go according to the script Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. Brad Richards, the Rangers $60 million man, was facing his former team, the Dallas Stars, and instead of a night of fireworks, it was a sleepy affair.

title: Honeymoons in Space
description: WASHINGTON

title: Beirut Bank Seen as a Hub of Hezbollahs Financing
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Last February, the Obama administration accused one of Lebanons famously secretive banks of laundering money for an international cocaine ring with ties to the Shiite militant group Hezbollah.

title: Italian Leader Revises Plans for Austerity
description: ROME  Prime Minister Mario Monti on Tuesday announced changes to a pension overhaul and reintroduced a property tax to gain parliamentary support for a budget that he hopes will calm world markets and rein in Italys public debt.

title: The Insidious Fine Print
description: It looks like a small throwaway line in a 2012 spending bill: no federal funds may be used to carry out chapters 95 or 96 of the Internal Revenue Code. A little digging shows that those chapters happen to authorize the presidential election public financing system. A few House Republicans, who have long hated the system, thought they could get rid of it by inserting the line in a bill to keep the government from shutting down this weekend.

title: Stopping the Free-for-All
description: The Supreme Courts decision to review a federal court ruling blocking parts of Arizonas notorious immigration law is troubling. It is arguably premature to take this case because there is no split among the federal appellate courts over states powers to enact such laws.

title: Donald Is Seeking Validation in Winning Majors, Not Money
description: The Englishman Luke Donald cemented his place in golf history last weekend by becoming the first player to win the money titles on the European and PGA Tours. In a teleconference call with reporters Tuesday, Donald sounded as if he would trade that coup for the one feat that eluded him during a sparkling season that culminated in his winning the PGA Tour player of the year in a vote of his peers.

title: Candid Advice From a Health Care Visionary
description: Dr. Donald Berwick, who was blocked by Republicans from serving a full term as the administrator of the agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, has been speaking out. He makes a compelling case about the harm caused by partisan demagoguery and about the need for health care professionals to take the lead in implementing reforms.

title: A Cab in Brooklyn
description: As any seasoned New Yorker knows, its almost impossible to find a yellow cab outside the heart of Manhattan. Instead, livery cars cruise the streets of the outer boroughs and pick up passengers illegally. They haggle over rates, deal in cash and nobody knows whether the city sees any of this money as tax revenue.

title: More Than 30 Are Killed Across Syria as Sectarian Tensions Grow
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At least 32 people were killed across Syria on Tuesday, including seven members of the security forces, amid rising sectarian tensions in some places, opposition groups said.

title: Corrections: December 14
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Survey of Democratic Presidential Strategies
description: President Obamas political strategists have identified a variety of paths to reach the 270 electoral votes he needs to win re-election.

title: A New YouTube, Herding the Funny Cats
description: If youre looking for evidence that the world just keeps moving faster, try this:

title: J. Lynn Helms, Who Led the F.A.A., Dies at 86
description: J. Lynn Helms, who as head of the Federal Aviation Administration supported President Ronald Reagans decision to fire more than 11,000 striking air traffic controllers and who subsequently helped restore the nations crippled air traffic control system, died on Sunday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 86.

title: Bert Schneider, Producer Whose Films Reflected an Era, Dies at 78
description: Bert Schneider, a producer of Easy Rider and other films that reflected and helped define the social unrest of the late 1960s and early 70s, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 78.

title: Erica Wilson Dies at 83; Led a Rebirth of Needleworking
description: Erica Wilson, the Julia Child of needlework, who brought the gentle art of crewel  as well as cross-stitch, needlepoint and other traditional embroidery techniques  to an international audience through her books, television shows, correspondence courses, syndicated column and retail shops, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Pot of Gold
description: New York State increased financing for a home care program but the number of clients has risen only modestly.

title: TaskRabbit Plans to Multiply
description: How many tasks can you perform with nearly $18 million dollars? TaskRabbit, a San Francisco-based start-up that helps people run errands, is about to find out. The company announced Wednesday that it hadreceived$17.8 million in financing.

title: With States Desperate to Keep Jobs, Companies Have Upper Hand, Report Shows
description: As the unemployment crisis grinds on, states are trying to both lure and retain businesses by offering tax breaks, grants, cheap loans  just about anything (short of candy and foot massages) they can think of. But how many jobs do these expensive incentives actually create?

title: How Coffee Can Galvanize Your Workout
description: Can a cup of coffee motivate you to relish your trips to the gym this winter? That question is at the heart of a notable study of caffeine and exercise, one of several new experiments suggesting that, whatever your sport, caffeine may allow you to perform better and enjoy yourself more.

title: Word of the Day | embezzlement
description: embezzlement \im-be-zl-mnt\ noun

title: NYT Front Page for 12/14/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/14/2011

title: Something for Louis C. K. to Smile About: His Internet Comedy Special Is Profitable
description: In a question-and-answer session with the online community Reddit, the comedian Louis C. K. fantasized about the possibility of making eight million bucks through sales of an Internet-only comedy special, money that could then be applied to other projects like making a feature film or amassing a collection of really nice camera lenses.

title: F.A.A. Approves iPads in Cockpits, but Not for Passengers
description: 6:43 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from American Airlines.

title: Europa League Preview: Yanks Still in the Hunt
description: 10:16 a.m. | Updated When English Premier League frontrunners Manchester United and Manchester City crashed out of the 2011-12 Champions League last week, they didnt exactly get sent home. No, they were sent to Europes second-tier competition, the league formerly known as UEFA and currently called Europa.

title: Devils Rally From Two-Goal Deficit, Topping Panthers in Shootout
description: The concussion news continued to grow worse for the N.H.L. on Tuesday, with the Philadelphia Flyers announcing that Claude Giroux would be out indefinitely with a head injury.

title: The Panchatantra Guide to Getting Ahead
description: Young Indian professionals are big consumers of management and how-to books to get ahead in the business world, India Ink contributor Saritha Rai wrote recently. We sat down with Rashmi Datt, the author of books aimed at 20 to 35 year olds whose titles include Managing Your Boss.

title: New Orleans Jazz Festival Announces 2012 Lineup
description: If you want to know just how far jazz has slipped in the hierarchy of pop music, just look the line-up for next years New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. Sure, Herbie Hancock is a headliner, but the rest of the names at the top of the bill to be announced Wednesday morning are a hodge-podge of pop, rock and R&B stars from various eras.

title: Leaving the Sunni Awakening in Limbo
description: Sheik Ahmed Abu Risha is seen as Americas staunchest ally in Iraq. An article in Wednesdays Times reports on how the withdrawal of the United States will leave Mr. Abu Risha and the militia units he commands, known broadly as the Sunni Awakening, to navigate increasingly troublesome relations with the central Shiite-led government of Iraq.

title: Google Celebrates the Season by Promoting Its Charitable Grants
description: Google.org, the search giants philanthropic arm, has struggled, but Google continues to give away money.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 14, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Police Link Belgian Gunman to a Killing Before Rampage
description: LIGE, Belgium  Belgians sought to make sense on Wednesday of a spasm of killing by a man with a history of trouble with weapons and drugs who unleashed his attack near a Christmas market at a historic square, bringing random death to a familiar scene of European holiday bustle.

title: Dec. 14, 1981 | Israel Annexes Former Syrian Territory of Golan Heights
description: On Dec. 14, 1981, Israel annexed the territory on the Golan Heights that it had seized from Syria in 1967. The New York Times called it an abrupt move that came as a surprise not only to international observers, but also to many Israelis who felt that it was hastily pushed through parliament by Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: Nasrallahs Fighting Words
description: BEIRUT  The Shiite holy day of Ashura, which commemorates the death of the Prophet Muhammads grandson Hussein at the Battle of Karbala in 680, marks the birth of the schism that still divides Sunnis and Shiites. This year, Ashura had a special echo in Lebanon: on Nov. 28, Hezbollahs secretary general, Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, gave a speech rife with sectarian overtones, casting Husseins ancient tragedy as a parable of contemporary Lebanese politics.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 14, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article After Lean Acorn Crop in Northeast, Even People May Feel the Effects.

title: A Mumbai Homebuilder Finds Success by Reshaping a Neighborhood
description: Like Mumbai, the city where he lives, Pankaj Guptas success has been incremental.

title: Antarctic Exploration
description: WHO was Roald Amundsen?WHO was Robert Falcon Scott?

title: Neighborly Portraits in Mexico
description: A change of scenery made Russell Monk see Mexico in a new light.

title: The Pakistanis Have a Point
description: As an American visitor in the power precincts of Pakistan, from the gated enclaves of Islamabad to the manicured lawns of the military garrison in Peshawar, from the luxury fortress of the Serena Hotel to the exclusive apartments of the parliamentary housing blocks, you can expect three time-honored traditions: black tea with milk, obsequious servants and a profound sense of grievance.

title: What Nail Polish Sales Tell Us About the Economy
description: Economics is all about consumption. People either spend money now or they use financial instruments  like bonds, stocks and savings accounts  so they can spend more later. A healthy economy is largely a result of a reasonable balance between consumption today and consumption deferred, and its pretty clear that balance has been ridiculously out of whack for a while.

title: What Places in Your Past Do You Appreciate More Now, From a Distance?
description: Sometimes, returning to places we knew in the past can surprise us: We might notice new details, or appreciate aspects we didnt at the time. When have you ever seen a place youve lived or spent time in with new eyes? Do you think you are conscious of whats special in your current environment, or does the tedium of daily life make you forget to notice these details? In his Op-Ed column Time, Distance and Clarity, Frank Bruni reflects on the phenomenon of experiencing a familiar place in a new and different way:

title: What Holidays? An Application Checklist as Jan. 1 Looms
description: Carol E. Wasden is director of college counseling at The Hockaday School in Dallas and a member of the Association of College Counselors in Independent Schools.

title: City Voters Approve of Mayors Overall Job Performance
description: Most voters in New York City disapprove of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs handling of the Occupy Wall Street protests and continue to believe that he has lost focus in his third term, according to a survey released Wednesday morning by Quinnipiac University.

title: Week 14 Film Review: Softly Go the Bears
description: A closer look at some of the games from Week 14, with the benefit of film review:
