description: Todays Times

title: Banner-Making Vending Machine Lands at Schiphol
description: As travelers to Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam know, its not uncommon when entering the Arrival Hall to see an assortment of homemade signs welcoming friends and family members home.

title: Hiring, Quits and Layoffs
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Putin Ally Resigns Speakers Post Amid Vote Furor
description: MOSCOW  The chairman of Russias governing party, United Russia, resigned from his post as speaker of the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday in an apparent effort to quell some of the uproar over perceived fraud in parliamentary elections last week.

title: Meet the New Motherlode Blogger
description: Welcome to Motherlode? Hardly. It is you who I hope will welcome me. Although Ive been a reader since the beginning (and occasionally a contributor), stepping into what I think of as the big boots of Motherlode is daunting and thrilling. As a writer and blogger, Ive always thought of Motherlode as, well, the motherlode: the ultimate place to start or join a conversation about the way we raise children now. Im very happy to be here.

title: Despite 2 Floods, a Business Decides to Stay Put
description: Last week, we published a case study abouttwo disaster-frazzled entrepreneurs seemingly in need of some of the calming supplemental holistic health services  yoga and massage  that they offer at Pulling Down the Moon, a Chicago business that was hit by two floods within a year.

title: Village Revolts Over Inequities of Chinese Life
description: BEIJING  A long-running dispute between farmers and local officials in southern China exploded into open rebellion this week after villagers chased away government leaders, set up roadblocks and began arming themselves with homemade weapons, residents said.

title: German Coalition Figure Quits Abruptly
description: BERLIN  A senior figure in Germanys junior coalition partner resigned abruptly on Wednesday, presenting Chancellor Angela Merkel with a potential political distraction as she leads European efforts to combat the euro crisis, warning that there will be no simple and fast solutions to rescue the beleaguered common currency.

title: Daily Report: Safety Board Urges Cellphone Ban for Drivers
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is urging states to ban drivers from using hands-free devices, including wireless headsets. The concern was heightened by increasingly powerful smartphones that people use to e-mail, watch movies and play games.

title: Was N.F.L.s Suspension of James Harrison the Right Call?
description: Seeking opinions from Fifth Down readers on the one-game ban imposed on the Steelers James Harrison. Here are a few links to get started:

title: Inevitable, or in Limbo? A Dam for the Mekong
description: As The Times reported last week, environment ministers from Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand and Laos have decided to await the results of further studies before making a decision on whether to proceed with construction of a dam in the Mekong River. Conservationists argue that damming the river, a vital and biologically diverse lifeline for people in all four countries, would be irresponsible. (Check out our slide show to get a sense of the rivers centrality to people in the basin.)

title: Critics Picks: Movies of 2011
description: A look at some of the years top films, as selected by the co-chief film critics A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis.

title: Old-Fashioned Glories in a Netflix Age
description: MANOHLA DARGIS As we know, its become ritualistic for critics to whine about the end of the year being crowded with Oscar hopefuls. Oh, pity the poor movie critic forced to watch a new Martin Scorsese movie, a new David Fincher and two from Steven Spielberg in short succession! Yet while this period seems jammed with Important Movies From Harvey Weinstein, the rest of the year looks dire only if audiences count on the major studios and usual suspects for their film fixes. The problem is that the race to the Oscars now so profoundly consumes everyones attention that it has distorted the perception of whats actually available.

title: OPEC Opts to Increase Its Level of Output
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on Wednesday to increase its production target for the first time in three years, a move that appeared to signal that Saudi Arabia and Iran had put aside their recent differences on oil policy, at least temporarily.

description: From the editorial page

Corzine, its former chief executive, knew the firm had been misusing customer funds, an accusation that could not be substantiated.

description: Christine ODonnell may not be a witch, but she is a Mitt Romney supporter.

title: A New York-Centric Bookstore Is Reborn, in Pixels
description: Once upon a time, not so long ago, there was a bookstore that was the best place  often the only place  to find anything on just about everything that had been written, photographed or sketched in regard to this city.

title: Wednesday Reading: Visiting Manhattan on a Budget
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: U.S. Envoy Relieved by Climate Talks Outcome
description: The senior American climate change envoy, Todd D. Stern, is back in Washington from the double-overtime United Nations negotiations in Durban, South Africa, and has declared himself pretty well satisfied with the result, although closing the deal wasnt easy.

title: Live Blog: MF Global Bankruptcy Hearing
description: The MF Global case heads to bankruptcy court again on Wednesday. Lawyers for Louis J. Freeh, the trustee overseeing MF Globals bankruptcy, are asking for permission to continue using the firms cash on hand.

title: Vote Set on Cobble Hill Charter School
Face Time | Laura Osnes
description: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

title: Olympus Restates Earnings, Showing Loss
description: TOKYO  Hours before a critical deadline Wednesday, Olympus, Japans chastened camera maker, released revised financial results, owning up to more than $1 billion in losses it hid for more than a decade.

title: Interest Rates, Inflation, and the Way the World Works (Slightly Wonkish)
description: Newish commenters here often fail to understand why I highlight things like falling inflation in Britain or the extremely low interest rates at which the governments of non-euro nations can borrow. Is it just I-told-you-so? No. Its about economic models  how the world works. And of course such models have policy implications.

title: Syrian Army Defectors Ambush Soldiers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian military defectors killed at least eight members of the security forces on Wednesday in an ambush near the city of Hama, in central Syria, according to opposition groups.

title: Actors Guild Unveils Its Nominations
description: The many critics groups have had their say, now the actors are weighing in with their picks for awards season. Nominations for the Screen Actors Guild Awards were unveiled this morning, with The Artist, The Descendants, Bridesmaids and Midnight in Paris all getting nods for outstanding cast performance.

title: What Were Reading
description: SF Weekly: Hooters and San Francisco are breaking up. Somehow we knew it was never going to work out.  Jeff GordinierMSNBC: Smithfield says it will finally stop using confinement pens for its pregnant sows.  Nick Fox

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 14
description: A British parliamentary panels release of e-mails from 2008 are the first documentation that Rupert Murdochs son James had been notified of a wider phone-hacking problem at the tabloid The News of the World long before he has admitted. In a statement, James Murdoch said he had received and replied to the message on his BlackBerry, but he said he did not read the full e-mail chain, Ravi Somaiya reported, adding this context:

title: Credit Agricole to Eliminate Up to 2,300 Jobs
description: 4:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Public Work, in Private
description: The Supreme Court needs to deliberate about itself. In November, after the court agreed to hear a constitutional challenge to President Obamas health care reform law, C-Span wrote to Chief Justice John Roberts requesting permission to televise oral arguments. Since then, several news organizations, including The New York Times, have chimed in to support C-Span.

title: Deck the Walls
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Marijuana Use Growing Among Teenagers
description: One out of every 15 high school students smokes marijuana on a near daily basis, a figure that has reached a 30-year peak even as use of alcohol, cigarettes and cocaine among teenagers continues a slow decline, according to a new government report.

title: For Groupon, Faint Praise From Its Underwriters
description: 8:17 p.m. | Updated

title: In Sandusky Case, Yet Another Sad, Strange Turn
description: To the series of sorry spectacles that has been the Jerry Sandusky/Penn State child sexual abuse scandal, we add one of the sorriest yet. To call Tuesdays preliminary hearing-that-wasnt a circus would be insulting the actual circus. Under this metaphorical big top, Sanduskys lawyer all but stood on top of a car with a bullhorn urging everyone to come attend his clients hearing  including dragging in a set of alleged victims who had to skewer up the courage to testify in open court  and then waived the hearing after theyd all arrived.

title: Lloyds Chief to Return in January From Medical Leave
description: 5:01 p.m. | Updated

title: Frenchman to Join Board of Europes Bank
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank might become more open to intervention in bond markets after European lawmakers on Wednesday approved Benot Coeur, a French economist and longtime Treasury official, for a seat on the policy making executive board.

title: Windows Phone 7 Caught in Mobile App Catch-22
description: Designers and start-up tech firms seem to agree on two things when it comes to Microsofts Windows Phone 7 mobile platform. First, its gorgeous and uniquely designed. Second, they wont be building an app for it in the near future.

title: A Closer Look at the Actors Picks
description: During all the awards hoopla, actors often talk about how meaningful it is to be recognized by their peers, and the Screen Actors Guild, which announced its nominees today, may be the highest expression of that sentiment, or at the least the ceremony where you hear it repeated in acceptance speeches the most.

title: Woman Fatally Crushed in Midtown Elevator Accident
description: Read the updated version of this article that appears in the newspaper.

title: Outright Ban on Cellphone Use in Car: A Recommendation Too Far?
description: On Tuesday, the National Transportation Safety Board, an independent federal agency responsible for promoting traffic safety and investigating accidents, recommended that states ban drivers from using hands-free devices, including wireless headsets. As noted Tuesday by The Times, it was the first time that a federal agency urged an end to the practice completely, rather than endorsing a partial ban, as some state legislatures have adopted to permit hands-free talking.

title: Riding Off Into Civilizations Sunset
description: IT was the season of apocalypse. Whether your idea of the end is reconciliatory (a family reunion on a misty far shore in The Tree of Life) or punishing  the collision of Earth with another planet in Melancholia; extinction in a metaphysical tornado in Take Shelter  2011 was the year of brooding cosmic consciousness in serious films. Even the mystical Tree of Life is shadowed with the notion of a fearsome, authoritarian God.

title: A Paul-Gingrich Showdown?
description: In this weeks column for Campaign Stops, I look at what could be the defining battle of the Iowa caucuses  Newt Gingrich versus Ron Paul:

title: No Word on Presidents Return to Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan, who unexpectedly flew to the United Arab Emirates on Dec. 6 for what was officially described as medical treatment, will be discharged from a hospital there on Thursday, according to his aides and physician.

title: Staging Your Own Theatrical Table Reading
description: Im a fan of reading plays  new ones, old ones  as literature, and I have written before about how Americans are missing out by not keeping up, on the page, with the best theater in New York City and elsewhere. The only thing better than reading a play yourself is reading it with people you like, a fact I am reminded of by the opening tomorrow of Roman Polanskis new film Carnage.

title: Elizabeth Taylors Collection Breaks Records at Christies
description: Elizabeth Taylors stardust lent a profitable glow to the first night of Christies auction of the movie stars extensive collection of jewelry and clothing. The sale of Taylors Legendary Jewels grossed just under $116 million, more than doubling the previous record for a private jewel collection sold at auction. The jewels of the Duchess of Windsor garnered about $50 million in 1987.

title: Nerve.com Introduces a Hip Dating Site  Again
description: Before there were hip dating sites like OkCupid, Grindr and Grouper, there was Nerve Personals, the racy dating section of the online magazine Nerve.com, which billed itself as a home for literate smut.

title: Report Seeks Far Tighter Safety System for Oil Drilling
description: Companies involved in offshore drilling and the government agencies that regulate drilling should take a more robust and systematic approach to ensuring safety, a team of scientific experts advised on Wednesday in a report on last years Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: As Gas Drilling Spreads, Towns Stand Ground Over Control
description: SOUTH FAYETTE, Pa.  As energy companies move to drill in densely populated areas from Pennsylvania to Texas, battles are breaking out over who will have the final say in managing the shale gas boom.

title: Pop-Up Book Roundup
description: New pop-up editions of Puff the Magic Dragon, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and others.

title: At Least for Reid, Gingrich Is the 2012 Republican Pick
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada may not be a pollster, but he has already decided who President Obama will be facing next year. Mr. Reid, the Democratic majority leader, in describing on the Senate floor his distaste for Republican legislative techniques, alluded to a possible government shutdown, and then proclaimed former Speaker Newt Gingrich as the Republican near-nominee for the 2012 presidential race.

title: Christmas a Good Time to Buy Used Cars, Analysis Shows
description: If youre waiting to shop for a used car until after the busy holiday season, you might want to reconsider. An analysis from the automotive Web site CarGurus suggests that youll get a much better deal on a used car if you shop close to the Christmas holiday, instead of waiting until later in the winter.Demand for cars tends to flag at the end of the year. That means prices can be attractive, according to a study of seasonal price trends compiled by CarGurus. The site based its analysis on its used-car price index, with has tracked list prices on roughly 12 million used cars since 2010.

title: Osawatomie and Opportunity
description: Jonathan Chait had an interesting response to the criticisms that both David Frum and I lodged against the Presidents Osawatomie speech. We both suggested that the president offered a plausible description of the middle classs recent woes, coupled with a weak and potentially counterproductive prescription for how to actually address them. To this, Chait basically conceded the relative thinness of the presidents opportunity agenda, and then went on to argue that it doesnt really matter because the Republicans are worse:

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy
description: This holiday season brings two spy thrillers of very different stripes: one in an explosive package (Mission: Impossible  Ghost Protocol) and one in which the tensions bubble beneath the surface (Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.) The latter has garnered strong audience interest this past weekend in its limited debut, grossing more than $310,000 in four locations. Based on John le Carrs novel, Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy looks at the inner workings of the British secret service in the early 1970s. In her review, Manohla Dargis called the film a pleasurably sly and involving puzzler  a mystery about mysteries within mysteries.

title: Video From Inside Rebellious Chinese Village
description: As my colleague Andrew Jacobs reports, the village of Wukan in the industrial heartland of Guangdong Province in China is in open rebellion against local authorities, residents say.

title: The Year in Media | Record Labels Still Carry a Big Price Tag
description: Staff members of The Timess media news department are highlighting the most significant developments this year in the industries they cover.

title: Pop-Up Book Roundup
description: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOUThe Pop-Up Edition.By Sam McBratney. Illustrated by Anita Jeram. Paper engineering by Corina Fletcher.16 pp. Candlewick Press. $19.99. (Picture book; ages 1 to 5)

title: The Politics of the Top 1 Percent
description: What are the political attitudes of the very wealthy? How, and how much, do they differ from the less wealthy? The combination of growing inequality, a weak economy, and Occupy Wall Streets ability to focus political debate on inequality makes the answers to these questions particularly relevant.

title: Independents a Problem for Gingrich, Polls Find
description: While poll after poll this month finds Newt Gingrich to be the preferred candidate among Republicans nationally, and in several early voting states, his unpopularity among all Americans in some of the same surveys underscores the deep challenges he could face in a general election.

title: Israel Leader Sets Curbs on Settlers for Violence
description: JERUSALEM  After two days of settler violence that shocked much of Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced Wednesday that some radical Israelis would be treated the same way as suspected Palestinian militants  detained for long periods without charge and tried in military courts.

title: Boukies, a Greek Spot, to Replace Heartbreak
description: Christos Valtzoglou, who already owned Pylos, a well-regarded East Village Greek restaurant with a dramatic ceiling hung with terra-cotta jugs, hired the chef Ingrid Roettele and added a Swiss-German restaurant to his stable. He called it Heartbreak  a prescient name, since it closed in October after a brief run, just two days before Michelin awarded it a star.

title: State of the Union Date Is Set
description: President Obama will deliver the State of the Union address on Jan. 24 before a joint session of Congress, an appearance that inevitably will set the tone and sound the theme of economic renewal for his re-election campaign.

title: The Police, the Press and Protests: Did Everyone Get the Memo?
description: Back in November when New York police officers pushed protesters out of Zuccotti Park, many reporters were physically prevented from covering the events, ostensibly as a way to keep them safe.

title: Gervaiss Silent Partner Talks and Gets Laughs for Himself
description: LONDON  The first thing Stephen Merchant does in his new stand-up act is seize the elephant in the room and wrestle it to the ground.

title: The Meh List
description: Not hot. Not not. Just meh.

title: SurveyMonkey Valued at $1 Billion as TPG Joins as Investor
description: SurveyMonkey is all grown up.

title: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: Just how good are the Texans? Can Tim Tebow and the Broncos beat Tom Brady and the Patriots? Will any more coaches be fired before the end of the season? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

title: Ben Brantleys Top 10 of 2011
description: Photos of Other Desert Cities, The Book of Mormon and other shows.

title: On Our Radar: A Serial Birds-Egg Thief
description: A Briton has drawn a fourth jail sentence for his persistent thefts of rare birds eggs. He was found with almost 700 wild bird eggs at his home in London, including eggs from such species as the osprey and golden eagle. Some of the eggs were stolen just before the chicks hatched, the authorities say. [The Guardian]

title: Comptroller Halts Custodians' Contract
The Attorney General and Voting Rights
description: There has been a coordinated attack this year on voting rights. More than a dozen states have enacted laws that are intended to make it more burdensome for Americans to cast a ballot, which President Lyndon Johnson called the basic right, without which all others are meaningless. New requirements  for special IDs, for examplewill reduce turnout among minorities, the uneducated, the poor, the elderly, the newly arrived, students and other groups that traditionally vote for Democratic candidates. (For an explanation of why voter ID laws have a discriminatory effect, see my previous post on the subject.)

title: Nokia Courts Smartphone Newbies in U.S. Return
description: The past few years have not been kind to Nokia in the cellphone market, especially in the United States where homegrown iPhones and Android handsets crowded out the venerable Finnish handset maker.

title: A Start-Up Incubator That Floats
description: Technology gurus have long lamented how hard it is for foreign talent to secure American visas and create start-ups here. As Congress spins its wheels with endless debate over immigration, an ambitious venture based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is trying to chart a more productive course aboard a 600-foot boat, or possibly a barge.

title: Canada and Mexico Aim for an Oscar Nomination Repeat
description: One of the oddities of the most recent competition for the best foreign-language film Oscar was that the five finalists included both Canada and Mexico. That had happened only once before, in 2006, and precedent would seem to dictate that films from Americas neighbors to the north and south are unlikely to be nominated together in two consecutive years. Nevertheless, both countries have strong entries again in 2011, with films that could scarcely be more different from each other.

title: PAC Backing Romney Shows Anti-Gingrich Ad
description: How worried are Mitt Romney supporters?

title: Plain Speaking at the End of Life
description: Dr. Stephen Workman, an internist at the Queen Elizabeth II Health Sciences Center in Halifax, Nova Scotia, takes exception to the language physicians use with patients near the end of life. In one of his recent publications, he called language the most important tool health professionals have to improve the care of dying patients.

title: 36 Hours: Salzburg, Austria
description: WITH its medieval citadel, Baroque palaces and yodel-ready Alpine vistas, Salzburg has never had trouble luring visitors. The Austrian city abounds with tourists, most searching for the sound of music  be it Mozart or the von Trapps. Yet some of its best offerings are its least historic: contemporary galleries, fair trade coffeehouses and the futuristic Hangar 7 complex. In winter, the city is at its most hospitable, as squares transform into bustling Christmas markets, and candlelit taverns fill with skiers refueling on Teutonic comfort food. Salzburg may no longer be frozen in the past, but its appeal is timeless.

title: 36 Hours: Salzburg, Austria
description: In winter, the city is at its most hospitable, as squares transform into bustling Christmas markets, and candlelit taverns fill with skiers refueling on Teutonic comfort food.

title: Fte Accompli | Giving Arthur Elgort
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: With Candidates Like This
description: David Brooks: Gail, Im on vacation this week, and in my absence the entire political world seems to have come to bipartisan agreement: Newt Gingrich would be a terrible president. I believe this. George Will believes this. Michael Savage, the ber-populist shock jock, is offering him $1 million to quit the race. Every commentator on the left believes this.

title: Nearly 1 in 5 Women in U.S. Survey Say They Have Been Sexually Assaulted
description: An exhaustive government survey of rape and domestic violence released on Wednesday affirmed that sexual violence against women remains endemic in the United States and in some instances may be far more common than previously thought.

title: That Should Be a Word
description: Bagri-cul-ture, n.

title: Army-Navy Project Ventures Far Beyond Football
description: Navy beat Army for the 10th straight year last Saturday, 27-21, but CBSs broadcast will not be the last word on the Midshipmens victory. Instead, footage from nine video cameras stationed at FedEx Field will form a major part of a new documentary, A Game of Honor (Showtime, Dec. 21, at 10 p.m.), that explores how the academies players balance football with military commitments.

title: Romney Warns of Nominating Zany Gingrich
description: 9:31 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

title: Mick Rock Survives the 70s to Shoot Again
description: COFFEE. Mick Rock, the rock n roll photographer as famous for his hedonistic lifestyle as for his iconic images of debauchery and excess, was drinking nothing more than coffee. It was 5 p.m. on a recent Tuesday, and while hotel guests drank cocktails at the lounge of the W New York Downtown, Mr. Rock, a slim and youthful man in his 60s in tinted glasses, got his fix.

title: Mitt Romney on Newt Gingrich
description: In an interview with The New York Times, Mitt Romney questioned whether Newt Gingrich would be "zany" in the White House.

title: High Court Spotlight on Right to Credit Bid
description: Despite my earlier prediction, the Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether a Chapter 11 debtor can avoid a lenders right to credit bid when doing a sale under a plan, as opposed to the more famous Section 363.

title: Obama Praises Troops as He Ends the War He Opposed
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  President Obama observed the end of the war in Iraq on Wednesday before an audience of those who fought in it, telling a crowd of returning war veterans that the nearly nine years of conflict in Iraq, a war now indelibly imprinted on the national psyche, had come to a close.

title: How Should I Feel About the French Mitt Romney Ad?
description: Readers who think I always have an opinion loaded and ready to fire may be interested to know that I was stumped this week  by a political ad, of all things. (After 24 years of covering politics for a living, its hard even to find them surprising.)

title: Obamas Speech to Troops at Fort Bragg
W.i.P.
description: A MODERN reimagination of Andy Warhols Factory? Thats the idea, anyway, behind W.i.P., an art-slathered club that opened last month in the basement beneath Greenhouse, another club around the corner. W.i.P. (for Work in Progress) is a venture between Barry Mullineaux, who runs Greenhouse, and an arts outfit called Collective Hardware.

title: Holiday Shopping at the Last Minute? No Worries Online
description: JUST because you left your holiday shopping to the last minute doesnt mean you have to pay full price. These coupon and bargain-hunting Web sites may save you time and money at the mall. They may even save you from setting foot in the mall in the first place.

title: Last Call | Katherine Hookers Pretty Pop-Up
description: Sleek, minimalist, elegant yet cozy and inviting at the same time. Tucked into a little storefront on Thompson Street in the chic art/tea/fashion triangle of New York Citys SoHo, the bespoke British designer Katherine Hookers clothing shop blends into the landscape as if its been there forever and is here to stay. But neither of those things are true. In some takeoff of Chef Ludo-meets-fashion, Hookers first ready-to-wear line and first storefront is a pop-up and will be open in New York only through Saturday.

title: Diploma Rates Far Short of Goal, Report Says
description: Forty percent of people ages 25 to 34 in the United States have college degrees, putting the nation in 12th place among developed countries. President Obama has set an ambitious goal of catapulting the country to first place by 2025, and the College Board, separately, has quantified a complementary goal: to increase the percentage of young adults with degrees from 40 percent to 55 percent by 2025.

title: Panetta Says U.S. Has Edge on Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Wednesday that the United States and its Afghan and foreign allies had been able to seize the momentum in Afghanistan and that they were winning the war.

title: China Imposes New Tariffs on U.S. Vehicles
description: GUANGZHOU, China  The Chinese government increased trade tensions with the Obama administration Wednesday evening by unexpectedly imposing antidumping and antisubsidy tariffs on imports of sport utility vehicles and midsize and large cars from the United States.

title: Speaking of People Whose Models Have Failed
description: The latest polls show Newt slipping in Iowa  but not to the benefit of Mitt Romney. Instead, it now seems possible that Ron Paul will win the caucuses.

title: Players Involved in Cincinnati-Xavier Fight Wont Face Charges
description: The players who brawled in the final seconds of the Xavier-Cincinnati mens basketball game on Dec. 10 will not face criminal charges.

title: Dear FloFab: Im Not Drinking. Why Am I Paying?
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Mick Rock, The Rock N Roll Photographer
description: Rocked an exhibit of photographs by Mick Rock can be seen at W New York Downtown until late December 2011.

title: A Penthouse Gets a Second Life in Singapore
description: Eugene Yip and Mike Tay, both designers, renovated with an eye to preserving and enhancing an apartments midcentury roots.

title: In Singapore, Peeling Back the Years
description: SINGAPORE  The rundown penthouse apartment that Mike Tay and Eugene Yip fell in love with in 2009 was in such a sorry state that more than 80 potential buyers had walked away from it. But Mr. Tay and Mr. Yip saw beyond its dark, claustrophobic atmosphere, the uneven floors and the frosted windows that obscured the view of the citys skyline. And the Singaporean couple ignored the old mattresses and assorted other junk that populated the roof terrace.

title: Charles Isherwoods Top 10 of 2011
description: Photos of Sons of the Prophet, Kin and other shows.

title: Poland Skirts Euro Zone Woes, for Now
description: WARSAW  Does Poland have the last healthy economy in Europe?

title: Seclusion, With a Byzantine Flavor
description: Surrounded by palms, with a Sea of Marmara view, an elaborate wooden house displays an Eastern exoticism.

title: House Hunting in ... Turkey
description: A SEVEN-BEDROOM WOODEN HOUSE ON AN ISLAND OFF ISTANBUL

title: Baryshnikov Arts Center Announces New Season
description: The Baryshnikov Arts Centers spring 2012 performance season, running Jan. 12 to June 17, will include several premieres by international artists from the worlds of theater, dance, music and film. The season includes the companys first co-presentation with Performance Space 122, as well as the New York premiere of a project organized by the theater artist Robert Wilson.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 15
description: Necklaces, leather restraint-like fashions and shiny party pants.

title: Looted Dishes Used in Art Project Returned to Iraq
description: Over the last several years, as cultural patrimony cases have roiled the art world, federal marshals have made surprise visits to numerous American museums and galleries to cart away artifacts that foreign governments claimed were looted.

title: Suspicious Packages Prompt Evacuation of Credit Suisse
description: Credit Suisse staff members were briefly evacuated from their Manhattan offices on Wednesday morning after the Swiss bank received two suspicious packages in the mail, days after Deutsche Bank intercepted a letter bomb addressed to its chief executive in Frankfurt.

title: In Latest Gun Inquiry, City Finds Willing Sellers Online
description: Updated 8:03 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has dispatched private investigators to gun stores and gun shows as far away as Arizona to illustrate how some dealers are willing to sell firearms to people they believe are disqualified from owning them.

title: Times of London Cancels Comedy Podcast That Mocked Murdoch
description: 8:06 a.m. | Updated

title: What Lies Ahead? Predicting the Future of Computing
description: Overview | What might the future of computing and technology look like? What innovations are on the horizon? In this lesson, students consider predictions about the future of fields including artificial intelligence, communication and computing. They analyze current predictions, consider them in the context of modern-day life and propose predictions of their own.

title: One Year's Flat Test Results Do Not Negate System's Progress
A Sigh of Relief at a School That Was Spared
Is James Murdoch Running Out of Denials?
description: In almost every Road Runner cartoon, Wile E. Coyote overshoots the edge of a cliff and finds his feet spinning in the air, frantically pawing for the terra firma that he has left behind. Those of us watching know he is about to fall, and even as he continues to flail in midair, deep inside he knows it as well.

title: Astros Trade Melancon, a Former Yankee, to Red Sox
description: When the Yankees traded relief pitcher Mark Melancon to the Houston Astros for Lance Berkman just hours before the trade deadline in 2010, they probably did not envision Melancon winding up in the Boston Red Sox bullpen.

title: Junkyard Gives Up Secret Accounts of Massacre in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  One by one, the Marines sat down, swore to tell the truth and began to give secret interviews discussing one of the most horrific episodes of Americas time in Iraq: the 2005 massacre by Marines of Iraqi civilians in the town of Haditha.

title: A Train, Canal Street, 11:22 A.M.
For Amazon, Lashes and Backlashes
description: If Amazon had a secret agenda in 2011 to fuel a backlash against itself, the retailer has scored another triumph. Its refusal to collect sales tax in California despite a new law compelling it to do so prompted some well-publicized criticism not only from politicians but the tech community. Its hiring of ambulances at its Pennsylvania warehouse to wait for workers to keel over in the summer heat conjured up a Dickensian sweatshop. The retailer apparently brought its Kindle Fire tablet to market before it had all the kinks out, disappointing some of its biggest fans.

title: In Hunt for Securities Fraud, a Timid S.E.C. Misses the Big Game
description: Does the Securities and Exchange Commission suffer from trialphobia?

title: Lines Drawn on Antipiracy Bills
description: WASHINGTON  Type download movies for free into Google, and up pops links to sites like the Pirate Bay, directing users to free copies of just about any entertainment   the latest Twilight installment, this weeks episode of Whitney, the complete recordings of the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

title: Romney Would Like to See Book of Mormon
description: So what does Mitt Romney, perhaps the best-known Mormon in the country, think of The Book of Mormon, the Broadway musical send-up of his faith, complete with profanity and sexually explicit humor?

title: The Exaggerated Impact of Bank Transfer Day
description: The numbers sounded a bit too good to be true  and it turned out that they were. The Credit Union National Association now says that about 214,000 people joined credit unions in the month or so of anti-bank fervor this fall, not the 650,000 it originally estimated. As Gov. Rick Perry of Texas might say: Oops.

title: TimesCast | Putin Ally Resigns
description: December 14, 2011 - The chairman of Russia's ruling party, a close Putin ally, resigns amid accusations of election fraud.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.14
description: A view of the day in sports, including acrobatics at the Club World Cup soccer tournament and shovels at the ski jump.

title: In Syria and Egypt, Bloggers Face Harsh Punishments
description: Updated | Thursday | 12:46 a.m. An outspoken blogger who was detained last week in Syria is now facing criminal charges, according to the human rights group she works for in Damascus, the Syrian capital.

title: 8 Questions for the MF Global Hearing
description: Terrence A. Duffy, executive chairman of the CME Group, returns to Capitol Hill on Thursday, testifying before the House Financial Services Committee. There are certain to be fireworks.

title: Portraits of Iraqi Pride
description: The photographer Andrea Bruce wondered if Iraqis felt optimism as the American troops left. The answer  for those who were staying  was complicated.

title: Older to Wed, If They Marry at All
description: The median age of first marriage is at an all-time high, according to a new report from the Pew Research Center based on United States Census Bureau data.

title: More Detail on Top Incomes
description: The Times recently published an article noting a significant decline in the incomes of the top 1 percent.

title: Prioritizing Pakistan
description: The Op-Ed columnist Bill Keller explains the United Statess need to repair its troubled relationship with Pakistan.

title: New Jersey Company Is Given Jail Contract It Lost
description: Over the summer, Essex County, N.J., abruptly canceled plans for a contract with a private company to house federal immigrant detainees after questions were raised about the sole bidder, a company with close ties to Gov. Chris Christie. But after county officials conducted a new round of bidding in October, the same company was again the only participant, and on Wednesday night, county officials unanimously approved the contract.

title: Secret Military Documents, Straight From an Iraqi Junkyard
description: BAGHDAD  Several weeks ago, we heard that a local businessman had purchased some trailers from a closing American base.

title: Searching for Apps Is Finally Getting Easier
description: At the start of this year, app-related search engines and stores were too big a mess for the mobile software industry to leave as is.

title: Former Ukrainian Presidents Murder Charge Is Dismissed
description: MOSCOW  Criminal proceedings were dismissed Wednesday against the former Ukrainian president Leonid Kuchma in the killing 11 years ago of a prominent investigative journalist critical of his administration.

title: After Russian Vote, U.S. Pledges to Raise Concerns Forcefully
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to continue speaking out forcefully about human rights violations in Russia, even after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin responded angrily to criticism of his countrys elections by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, a top State Department official said Wednesday.

title: Michael Bubl Stays on Top
description: This week on the music charts, Michael Bubls holiday album holds strong at No. 1, beating out new releases by the Black Keys and Amy Winehouse, and the party-rockers of LMFAO reclaim the top slot for the most downloaded track.

title: Kayak Defends Cutting Ties to All-American Muslim
description: Kayak, a company that has run commercials on All-American Muslim  the reality series on the TLC cable channel that has become a source of controversy in the debate over Muslims in the United States  defended its decision to stop advertising on the show in the future, even as it admitted, we handled this poorly.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Four prolific writers  Paul Theroux, Jeffrey Zaslow, Randall Silvis and Roberto Bolao  are joined by two first-timers: a comic novelist and the nonfiction chronicler of a New York religious community.

title: Fox Rebound Not Enough to Fully Eclipse CBS on Tuesday
description: Fox was barely able to retain its Tuesday night foothold with the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, tying CBS in that ratings category most prized by advertisers. Glee and New Girl both halted recent ratings slides and remained steady for Fox when compared to last week in the 18-to-49 demo and drew 7 million and 6.8 million total viewers respectively.  Those Fox shows faced off against new episodes of NCIS and NCIS: Los Angeles on CBS for the first time in three weeks.

title: Torres Brings Upbeat Personality to Depleted Mets
description: Andres Torres knows the Mets were betting he would have a bounce-back year when they acquired him from San Francisco along with Ramon Ramirez this month in exchange for Angel Pagan.

title: Judge Allows MF Global to Continue Using Cash on Hand
description: A federal judge on Wednesday approved a request by MF Global to continue using about $21.3 million of its cash on hand, allowing the bankrupt brokerage firm to continue operating under Chapter 11.

title: TimesCast | December 14, 2011
description: A preview of an interview with Mitt Romney; the chairman of Russia's ruling party resigns; and Bill Keller on why the United States must repair relations with Pakistan.

title: The Caucus Hairstylist
description: Cathy Jorgensen, who runs a salon in Des Moines, talks about getting regular visits from prominent politicians in town to compete in the Iowa caucus.

title: TimesCast | December 13, 2011
description: Jerry Sandusky waives his right to face his accusers in a preliminary hearing; and a rare glimpse at life inside Myanmar's capital.

title: Browns Say Medical Staff Missed Hit on McCoy
description: Mike Holmgren, the president of the Cleveland Browns, said Wednesday that quarterback Colt McCoy was not tested for a concussion after taking a hit to the head during a game last week, in part because the medical staff was tending to other players and did not see the play.

title: TimesCast | December 12, 2011
description: Mikhail Prokhorov, a Russian billionaire, plans to run against Vladamir Putin for president; and Occupy Wall Street protesters picket Goldman Sachs.

title: New Services at Univision and Hulu Focus on Latino Viewers
description: Viewers who dont get up early enough to watch the latest installment of the morning show Despierta Amrica on Univision will now be able to watch clips from the show on their mobile phones.

title: Tip of the Week: Sneaking a Peek at Your Desktop
description: For Windows 7 users, passing the cursor over the Show Desktop button (that thin vertical sliver on the far right side of the Taskbar) is a handy way to glance at the computers desktop, even with a screen full of open windows. But for those who accidentally brush the mouse over the button and get distracted by the disappearing documents on the screen, there is a way to disable the Show Desktop button  just right-click on the Show Desktop button and remove the checkmark next to Peek at desktop. Later, if you want to restore your peeking powers, right-click the Show Desktop button again and re-select the option.

title: The Giving Spree | Alison Mosshart
description: Who: Alison Mosshart, lead singer of the Kills.

title: Organizing Communities to Improve Schools
Channel Surfing: Fear and Desire
description: Dr. Strangelove its not.

title: A Hairstylist Grooms Hopefuls, With a Trim
description: DES MOINES

title: Prewar Sports Cars Valued at $12.4 Million to Be Auctioned at Goodwood
description: Collectors who favor prewar sports and competition cars would rarely be mistaken for poseurs. Cars of that type are rare, visceral, demanding to own and drive, and prohibitively expensive to buy. Add to these the challenge of weeding out the cars that may not be what they seem, and its easy to see a giant keep out sign for casual collectors.

title: British Cities Suggest Themed Trips
description: With the multitudes flocking to London next year for the Olympic Games, some of Britains other offerings may get overlooked. The British Heritage Cities Web site provides a reminder in the form of eight new themed itineraries to Bath, Carlisle, Chester, Oxford, Stratford and York.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Congo, Belgium and India.

title: Mayor Criticizes Judge for Releasing Murder Suspect
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday criticized the Brooklyn Criminal Court judge who allowed the man accused this week of killing a police officer to be released from custody without bail in an earlier drug case.

title: Carine Roitfelds Daughter Builds Her Own Empire
description: Unveiled at a party Tuesday night at the Kiki de Montparnasse shop, the collection of lace-embellished, lace-panel, vintage-style slips, kimonos, satin corselets and fancy underpinnings.

title: Building an Empire of Her Own
description: THE din at Le Grainne Cafe, a popular bistro in Chelsea, subsided just long enough to make out the words of a matron at a corner table. I love your boots, she told the young woman seated nearby, her glance traveling covetously from her neighbors instep to the tops of her thighs.

title: Getty Museums Acting Director is Leaving
description: David Bomford, who has been acting director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles since 2010, will be returning to his home in London where he plans to pursue research, scholarship and writing, the institution announced on Tuesday. Mr. Bomford joined the Getty in 2007 as associate director for collections and was named its acting director after Michael Brand resigned in 2010, citing differences with James N. Wood, who was then the president and chief executive of the Getty Trust, the umbrella organization that oversees the museum. Mr. Wood died later that year and was replaced by James Cuno, the former director of the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Congo, Belgium and India.

title: For Fashion Start-Ups, a Bridge to Investors
description: IN a setting reminiscent of a speed-dating bar scene, but with no promise of even a first date, much less a long-term relationship, more than 20 fledgling fashion companies pitched their talent, their drive and their ideas to an audience of potential investors at the Fashion Institute of Technology last week.

title: What You Get for ... $480,000
description: ST. PAUL, MINN.

title: Among Unknowns Who Tested Positive, Braun Stands Out
description: The few dozen names on the list dont ring a lot of bells. Humberto Cota? Kelvin Pichardo? Mark Rogers?

title: Four Pranksters, Giving as Good as They Get
description: It seems as if the punked-and-pranked genre of television ought to be dead by now, but four New York guys prove that it isnt in (Impractical) Jokers, a gleefully idiotic show that has its premiere Thursday night on TruTV.

title: Online Sharing: The How, What and When of 2011
description: Its Wednesday. That means it is the most popular day for users to share on the Web.

title: Homes for $480,000
description: A two-bedroom house in St. Paul, a two-bedroom condo in Philadelphia and a three-bedroom house in downtown Dallas.

title: You Change It, You Buy It
description: Major League Baseballs new collective bargaining agreement, which is expected to be ratified on Thursday, covers many familiar topics: revenue sharing, drug testing, video replays and so on.

title: A Classic Refocused for the Big Screen
description: Onstage in The Nutcracker Fritz, the brother of the child heroine, is never alone. You see him in the company of his sister, his parents, his friends and the mysterious visiting magician Drosselmeier. On Tuesday, however, in the live high-definition cinema broadcast of George Balanchines production for New York City Ballet, there were moments when he  vividly performed by 9-year-old Maximilian Brooking Landegger  filled the vast screen all by himself. Naughty, impulsive, vulnerable, he became more funnily irresistible than ever.

title: Putting Political Reform Right Into the Pockets of the Nations Voters
description: In Republic, Lost Lawrence Lessig  a Harvard Law School professor and a leading advocate of applying the principles of open Web access to less technical forms of creative expression, like music, writing, and the visual arts  makes an extraordinary leap of faith.

title: The Philharmonics Messiah, With Bright Voices and Little Vibrato
description: The great German tenor Peter Schreier and the New York Philharmonic do not share an extensive history, but what they have done together over the years has been noteworthy. Having made his debut as a soloist with the orchestra in 1973 in Dvoraks Stabat Mater, Mr. Schreier returned just three times in that capacity: in Brittens Serenade and Bachs St. John Passion and St. Matthew Passion. In 1998 the Philharmonic presented Mr. Schreier in recital with the pianist Andras Schiff, who was appearing with the orchestra at the time.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. We have cheap temporary blinds. Is it worth investing in better window coverings before selling?

title: Carrier IQ Denies It Is Under Investigation
description: 3:10 p.m. | Updated Adding formal comment from Carrier IO.Carrier IQ, which makes software that monitors mobile phone users, says it is not being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission, despite a report in The Washington Post that said the federal investigators were looking into the company.

title: The Caucus | Interview With Mitt Romney
description: The former Massachusetts governor sits down with The New York Times to discuss Newt Gingrichs challenges and the status of his own campaign.

title: Smoothed Inflation
description: One thing that becomes obvious when you look at inflation data is that the numbers bounce around a lot, not just from month to month but from year to year. One way to try to get past the noise is to use one or another definition of core inflation, which I think is necessary if you want to catch underlying inflation trends early. But to get a historical picture, its good enough just to use longish averages.

title: Scene City: Meryl Streep as the Iron Lady
description: Anne Hathaway, Ellen Barkin, Alan Cumming and other loyal subjects pay tribute to the Queen of Hollywood.

title: Curtsying Before a Queen
description: MARGARET THATCHER led Britain as its prime minister once upon a time, but its Meryl Streep who lords over Hollywood. And in a show of her unimpeachable reign, Ms. Streep attracted an impressive stream of loyal subjects for the Tuesday premiere of The Iron Lady, her latest Oscar vehicle, in which she stars as Ms. Thatcher.

title: How to Make Dining Stools From Egg Cartons
description: Jen Turner, an architect and designer, and Andrew Wagner, the director of Krrb.com, bundle industrial-size egg cartons from Chinatown restaurants to create six stools.

title: Homeland Inches Tensely to Its Finale
description: Showtimes Homeland, which many critics have praised as the most riveting new drama of the television season, will reach its finale on Sunday night in an episode that the president for entertainment for the network, David Nevins, said will have the fans of the show howling.

title: Methane Time Bomb in Arctic Seas  Apocalypse Not
description: Dec. 19, 1:44 p.m. | Updated below |A very important research effort has been under way during recent summers in the warming, increasingly ice-free shallows off Russias Siberian coast. There, an international array of scientists has been investigating widening areas of open water that are disgorging millions of tons of methane each year.

title: An Audience Gets Pawed, but Its All for Arts Sake
description: In certain circles The Shining, not the Stanley Kubrick film but the performance work by Yvonne Meier, is a thing of downtown dance lore. As Ishmael Houston-Jones, adviser to a new production, pointed out in a pre-performance discussion, many have heard about it but far fewer have actually seen it. And since only 11 audience members are admitted to each show, its probably going to stay that way.

title: Great Escape | Miami Heat
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: When Child Care Subsidies Disappear, Care is Hard to Find
description: How can you be a working parent without child care? Day care, preschool, after-school programs: without them, or some alternative, a parent of younger school-age children can work only from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., and a parent of even younger children cant work at all.

title: Emptying a Castle to Head to the Condo
description: It makes perfect sense that Candy Spelling, the widow of the hugely successful producer Aaron Spelling and former resident of a notoriously huge Los Angeles house, would see her life in terms of old Hollywood glamour.

title: Michael Kors Stock, Like His Frocks, Is Selling Fast
description: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

title: Windsor Custom at the Ainsworth
description: The kind of place designed for men who pay attention to the kind of details other men will notice, preferably with envy.

title: Custom Shirts, With a Shot on the Side
description: DO you think gingham is waning in popularity? Brian Anderson, a principal at a private equity firm, asked as he shuffled a stack of fabric swatches in the sitting room of Windsor Custom, a clothing shop decorated in navy blue and beige to resemble the rec room of a Hamptons cottage. He considered them, quite intensely. A two-ply cotton herringbone. A sateen cotton dobby. A basket-weave oxford. Each was a slightly variant shade of pink.

title: French Mitt Romney, Part Deux
description: Earlier today, I asked readers to help me think about a new negative political ad, in which Mitt Romney babbles about the 2002 Olympics in French while liberal statements hes made over the years flash across the screen. I found the ad  payback for the 2004 mockery of John Kerrys foreign language skills  funny. But I also criticized it for implicitly furthering the idea that a bit of culture, actually a bit of French culture, is a liability.

title: United States Women Win 2 Events in Beijing
description: At the first SportAccord World Mind Games Championship in Beijing  which include chess, go, checkers and Chinese chess as well as bridge  four countries were invited to compete in each bridge division, womens and open. The tournament comprises team, pair and individual competitions.

title: Gingrich, Lecturing on Brain Science, Faces Protesters
description: IOWA CITY  Newt Gingrich, in full professorial mode, stood at a lectern in front of a whiteboard decorated with his campaign signs on Wednesday and told an auditorium of college students that brain science research was not only fascinating, but a way to fix the budget over the next decades.

title: Yankees Said to Bid for Darvish
description: Major League Baseball announced that at least one team, which it did not name, submitted a posting bid for the Japanese star pitcher Yu Darvish by the deadline late Wednesday afternoon. It is believed that at least a few teams, most notably the Texas Rangers and the Toronto Blue Jays, submitted bids to win the right to negotiate a contract with Darvish, the 25-year-old ace of the Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters.

title: Camp Life in the Dry Valleys
description: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier fed streams.

title: On Queens Block, Losing a Link to Louis Armstrong
description: Selma Heraldo lived the entirety of her 88 years in a white, two-story house on 107th Street in Corona, Queens, and her life may have been very different had she not gained new next-door neighbors in 1943  Louis Armstrong and his wife, Lucille.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Amazon, Algorithms and Angry Birds
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors at The New York Times have been reading on the Web. For more Scuttlebot, go to the right-hand column of this page.

title: 1892, Now Its Online
description: THE ultimate pleasure of taking an online dip into the entirety of the Vogue archives  every issue since 1892 has been digitally scanned, page by page, and made available through a pricey new subscription site  is the sensation that it gives of falling into a fashion time machine and being shot out into different eras at random.

title: Lam Research to Buy Novellus Systems for $3.3 Billion
description: 8:47 p.m. | Updated

title: Sales at DwellStudio and Others
description: FTF Design Studio is reducing prices on all trays and accessories by 20 percent, through Wednesday (a small flat tray, regularly $335, is $268; the Umami tray, regularly $145, is $116); 137 Fifth Avenue (20th Street), (212) 925-0847, ftfdesignstudio.com.

title: An App With Friends in High Places
description: THERES a new addiction in Hollywood, apparently, but this one comes without the court-ordered 30-day rehab. Words With Friends, the Scrabble-like app, is not just popular, it seems, but cool among tastemakers in the entertainment industry and beyond.

title: Lawmakers Offer Bipartisan Plan to Overhaul Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  A Democratic senator, Ron Wyden of Oregon, and a Republican member of the House, Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, unveiled a bipartisan plan on Wednesday to revamp Medicare and make a fixed federal contribution to the cost of coverage for each beneficiary.

title: All I Want From Santa (See List)
description: WHEN it comes to holiday gifting, everyone says its the thought that counts. But when Jeminah Buot and her family kept getting the same gifts over and over again  like four stainless steel water bottles one year  they decided maybe the thought wasnt enough.

title: Looted Dishes Return to Iraq
description: Federal marshals took custody of a collection of Saddam Hussein's dinner plates used in an art project by Creative Time in order to return the dishes to Iraq.

title: Letters
description: Underarms Accord

title: Turning Egg Cartons Into Stools
description: MY history of trash collecting goes way back. Long before I was the director of Krrb (a kinder, friendlier, hyper-local version of Craigslist) or the editor of ReadyMade (the magazine, now defunct, that billed itself as the bible of reuse for Generations X, Y and Z), I was a skateboarding teenager in California trolling the Central Valley suburbs for building materials for ramps. Even now, living in Manhattan, I keep my eyes open for anything tossed to the curb that might be turned into something beautiful or useful.

title: A Procession to the Post Office, Carrying Envelopes Full of Hope
What Is College For?
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: Egypts Rural Voters Get Their Turn in Elections
description: GIZA, Egypt  Egyptians turned out to vote again Wednesday with a new confidence in a promised transition to civilian democracy amid signals that the ruling military council may be backing off its efforts to extend its power.

title: Beauty by the Bite
description: SUE DEVITT, an Australian makeup artist whose clients have included Sarah Jessica Parker, Jennifer Lopez and Keira Knightley, is known for her sumptuous eye shadows and seaweed-infused foundations. But in February, Ms. Devitt and Tanya Zuckerbrot, the official dietitian to the Miss Universe Organization, are scheduled to appear on QVC to introduce a new beauty product that you dont massage, smooth or brush onto your face. You eat it.

title: Beyond the Pass in Tech Gifts
description: No 7-year-old ever said, The holidays are so stressful! When youre young, the end of the year is always thrilling.

title: Shaun White on Design and Skater Culture
description: Shaun White, the professional snowboarder and skateboarder, and his brother, Jesse, have designed boards and performance clothing and gear for Burton, and what they call off-mountain clothing for Target, for more than three years. Later this month, Target will introduce his latest creative endeavor: the Shaun White home collection, a line of bedding, lighting and home accessories inspired by skating, snowboarding, travel, music and art.

title: Keeping Lamp Design Simple
description: By day, Dino Sanchez is an associate creative director at Frog Design, but the 34-year-old Brooklynite has always had an entrepreneurial side. He started a typeface company called Orange Italic shortly after graduating from Carnegie Mellon University and, more recently, began producing a few of his own lighting designs.

title: A Williamsburg Penthouse Marked With Memories
description: HOLLISTER AND PORTER HOVEY are sisters and bloggers known for their sense of style: their loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, layered with memento mori and vintage-store portraits, has attracted scores of admirers online. Still, they had never decorated anyone elses home.

title: A Top Goldman Executive to Retire
description: Milton R. Berlinski, who runs the group at Goldman Sachs that caters to private equity firms, is retiring at the end of the year, according to an internal memo.

title: Bringing Warmth to a Glass-and-Steel Condo
description: Hollister and Porter Hovey, sisters known for their new-vintage style, were hired to decorate an apartment at the Edge, in Williamsburg.

title: Oscar Hopefuls Campaign Strategies
description: The trophy race that culminates in the Oscars is moving into high gear this week, with a slew of critics groups and precursor awards, like the Screen Actors Guild and the Golden Globes, announcing their nominees. Soon enough it will be clear  or clearer  who will have to start picking out gowns and pretending not to have practiced their acceptance speeches.

title: A High-Level Collaboration on a SoHo Loft
description: HOLDING open the door to her fourth-floor loft in SoHo, the choreographer and dancer Elizabeth Streb tried not to laugh at the sounds of exertion as a visitor struggled up the last steep flight of stairs.

title: A Play That Unfolds in a Real Town House
description: For the last week and a half, Alice, the monstrous hostess played by Zoe Caldwell in the play Elective Affinities, has been welcoming theatergoers into the living room of her luxurious Fifth Avenue town house. Though the location is a secret (ticket buyers receive an e-mail with the places address), its a real living room, in a real brick-and-limestone town house built in the late 19th century. Embedding the audience in a living room was crucial to the play, said the producers, but finding one was a challenge.

title: The Last-Minute Gift Thats Sure to Please
description: It may be better to give than to receive  but theres nothing worse than ripping off colorful wrapping paper to reveal some gym socks, the oh-so-obviously regifted scented candles or a CD box set of any kind.

title: The Holiday Gaffes That Keep Giving
description: DESIGNERS get especially excited about decorating during the holiday season, and last year, Nicole Fuller decided that what she wanted, in the Manhattan apartment she shares with her husband, Clarence, and three Maine coon cats, was a Christmas tree covered entirely in white feathers  a swan tree, she called it.

title: Shopping for Childrens Beds
description: The industrial designer Jason Miller, who has a 17-month-old daughter, searched for childrens beds.

title: Childrens Beds
description: JASON MILLER, the industrial designer who is chief executive and creative director of the lighting company Roll & Hill, believes that when designers become parents, one of two things happens.

title: Wood Bowls With a Midas Touch
description: After learning a technique known as water gilding from a master gilder in Hamburg, Germany, Michou Osterwald applied it to some surprising objects: hand-carved African wood bowls.

title: A Very Modern Teddy Bear
description: Mr. Tedi is getting a big head, Annika Jermyn said, on hearing of the attention being paid to her creation, a very modern-looking teddy bear with, yes, a large head.

title: With Latest Network Agreements, the N.F.L. Outdoes Even Itself
description: With its consistently high ratings and its solid grip on the American sports psyche, the N.F.L. knows that broadcast and cable networks will spend ever-rising sums to carry its games.

title: Preservationists Home Movies: A Lifetime of Images as a Sweeping Visual Diary
description: For more than a half-century, the filmmaker, artist, poet, critic, programmer and ecstatic theologian of cinema Jonas Mekas has been viewing the world through a camera, often in the form of visual diaries. A restless image maker, he seizes moments of beauty and life as it happens in work that bridges outer and inner, the self and the other. The leap across this great divide is crucial: in contrast to the iEverything, me-centric ethos, his movies (initially shot in film, more recently digital) have been at once a way into the world and into his own self. I make home movies, therefore I live, he says in his 1969 film Walden. I live, therefore I make home movies.

title: Uptown Can Be a Downer
Euro Zone Deal Runs Into Second Thoughts
description: PARIS  The deal reached at the emergency European summit meeting in Brussels last Friday was supposed to cement a consensus for better fiscal discipline and reassure the financial markets about the European Unions resolve. By Wednesday, it was clearly not convincing investors.

title: NBA League Pass Fans Think Theyre Paying More for Less
description: Thanks to the N.B.A. lockout, the regular season is 20 percent shorter this season. As part of the new collective bargaining agreement, the players are taking a 12 percent pay cut. And fans who buy NBA League Pass, which lets them watch nearly every game on television, the Internet and their mobile phones, will pay at least 7 percent less.

title: Live Nation Buys BigChampagne, Analyzer of Consumer Data
description: In a bid to expand its ability to analyze large amounts of consumer data, Live Nation Entertainment, the music giant that includes Ticketmaster, is buying BigChampagne, a small but influential company that monitors online media consumption.

title: Japan May Declare Control of Reactors, Over Serious Doubts
description: TOKYO  Nine months after the devastating earthquake and tsunami knocked out cooling systems at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, causing a meltdown at three units, the Tokyo government is expected to declare soon that it has finally regained control of the plants overheating reactors.

title: Not Blessed With Fast Feet, Manning Escapes Heat With Quick Wits
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  By any measure, Eli Manning is not a mobile quarterback. He is slow. He is awkward. He is, as his father, Archie, said, not a runner.

title: The Future of Americas Post Offices
description: To the Editor:

title: Recycling Toxic Wastes
description: To the Editor:

title: Occupy Wall Street Protesters Report to Court
description: The line outside the summons court was longer than normal on Wednesday morning, as those accused of the usual offenses, like allowing a dog to wander off a leash or drinking a beer on a public stretch of pavement, were joined by protesters from Occupy Wall Street.

title: Leader of Nuclear Agency Hears Litany of Objections
description: WASHINGTON  In exchanges that ranged from merely testy to caustic, four members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a House committee on Wednesday that their chairman had withheld information from them, berated the agencys professional staff, reduced female employees to tears with abusive comments and created a chilled atmosphere that was hurting the agencys ability to function.

title: Politics and the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: The Arts and Recess
description: To the Editor:

title: F.S.U. in Volleyball Semifinals Thanks to Blocks
description: Never underestimate the power of denial. It has taken the Florida State womens volleyball team deeper into the playoffs than any of its Atlantic Coast Conference peers.

title: In Bahrain, Protests and Police Action
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof returns to Bahrain to witness the protests against the dictatorship there. At one point, he is briefly detained by the police.

title: Obama Drops Veto Threat Over Military Authorization Bill After Revisions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will not veto a military authorization bill that contains several disputed provisions about the treatment of terrorism prisoners, the White House announced Wednesday, signaling a likely end to a political battle over detainees and executive power.

title: Gingrichs Foreign Policy Words Summon the Cold War, but Enemy Is Iran
description: Should Newt Gingrich become president, his foreign policy vision might remind many people of the cold war. But this time the threat would be from a nuclear-armed Iran rather than the Soviet Union.

title: Georgia: District Suspends Marching Band Activities
description: An Atlanta-area school district has suspended all high school marching band activities while it investigates reports of physical violence among band members. The decision comes amid growing scrutiny of hazing in marching bands, following the death of a drum major at Florida A&M University last month during what officials have called a hazing ritual. The DeKalb County school district said Wednesday that it was investigating documented evidence of inappropriate activity by students last summer. The student who died in the Florida A&M episode, Robert Champion, was a graduate of DeKalb schools, and another band member at Florida A&M told the police this week that she was beaten so severely by fellow students that she was hospitalized. She and the three students accused of hazing her are also graduates of DeKalb schools. Meanwhile, the Florida A&M authorities looking into Mr. Champions death opened a new investigation after they uncovered possible employee fraud and misconduct, according to documents released Wednesday, The Associated Press reported.

title: MSNBC Apologizes to Romney Campaign for Klan Report
description: Thursday, Dec. 15, 6:59 p.m. | Updated For the latest developments on this story, read Brian Stelters report from Thursday.

title: Amid Finery and, Some Say, Vermin, Elite Arts Club and Its Ex-President Battle
description: It is a tale of boldface names and precious Manhattan real estate, of institutional loyalty and tenant tomfoolery.

title: Sony and Warner Are Said to Sue Web Music Service
description: Over the last decade, the big forces of the music industry have often teamed up in lawsuits against common Internet foes: first Napster, then Grokster, then LimeWire.

title: Stephen Schlossberg, Official of U.A.W. and Labor Dept., Dies at 90
description: Stephen Schlossberg, a onetime garment workers organizer who rose to become general counsel of the United Automobile Workers and a top official in the Labor Department under President Ronald Reagan, died on Dec. 10 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 90.

title: The Right Way to Put Kids to Work
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Fed Seeks to Protect Even a Small Bank
Fishing Lines, Deadly When Discarded, Pose Threat to Birds in City Parks
description: Prospect Park, which has been on the front lines of the debate about how to control New York Citys Canada goose population, has a new bird battle brewing. This time, between bird lovers and people who like to fish.

title: In a Tactical Shift, Romney Trains Sights on Gingrich
description: Mitt Romney, his presidential aspirations suddenly endangered by Newt Gingrichs rapid resurgence, is employing aggressive new arguments in an effort to disqualify Mr. Gingrich as a credible choice to Republicans, calling him zany in an interview on Wednesday and questioning his commitment to free enterprise.

title: Clippers Acquire Paul and Create a Rivalry
description: Chris Paul is on his way to Hollywood, joining the biggest collection of N.B.A. stars in a single arena, and creating a true basketball rivalry in Los Angeles for the first time.

title: Weight Loss, With Divas and Public Service
description: THIS holiday season, three of the countrys biggest diet companies are turning to three well-known divas to deliver public-minded messages about obesity and its opposite, hunger, along with the customary exhortations for people to begin shedding pounds as soon as the years festivities end.

title: Top Photographers Try Looking at Israel From New Angles
description: GAN HASHLOSHA NATIONAL PARK, Israel  The image is both idyllic and carefully staged: nearly a dozen foreign photographers, some of them celebrated on the international art scene, posing for a collective portrait on a sunny November morning against a startling green pool in this lush park in northern Israel.

title: Rock Bottom
description: Now that another highly qualified judicial nominee has been left as road kill, the question is how much lower can the confirmation process sink.

title: First Woman to Lead Army Drill Sergeant School Is Suspended
description: WASHINGTON  The first female commandant of the Armys school for drill sergeants has been suspended from her job and is under investigation, an Army spokesman said on Wednesday.

title: Elevator Accident Kills Woman in Midtown Building
description: Suzanne Hart, a 41-year-old executive at one of Manhattans most prominent advertising firms, was stepping into the elevator of an 85-year-old Midtown office building around 10 a.m. Wednesday, just as she had every workday for the past four years, while fellow workers streamed into the mosaic-tiled lobby.

title: National Review Makes Its Case Against Gingrich
description: 3:06 p.m. | Updated National Review, a leading conservative journal, issued a stinging critique of Newt Gingrich on Wednesday, saying his character flaws make him unfit to be president and asking Republicans to reject a hasty marriage to the front-running candidate.

title: Balanced Budget Amendments Fall Short in the Senate
description: The Senate on Wednesday rejected rival balanced budget amendments to the Constitution, dealing a blow to Republicans who have made it a central part of their fiscal platform.

title: Lottery Numbers
Worker-Owners of America, Unite!
description: College Park, Md.

title: New Leader for Brearley School Is Announced
description: The Brearley School, an all-girls private school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, named a new head of school on Wednesday, capping a six-month search that involved 100 candidates. The announcement was in a letter to Brearley community families.

title: Waiting for the Higgs Particle
description: WHEN rumors started crisscrossing the Internet last week that the elusive Higgs particle had been detected by researchers at the Large Hadron Collider outside Geneva, I experienced my first physics-generated chill in a decade. It happened again Tuesday morning with the official announcement suggesting that the more than 40-year search for the Higgs may finally be nearing its end.

title: Bloggingheads: Create a Job For Me!
description: Adam Serwer, left, of Mother Jones and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate job creation and the presidential election.

title: A Lifelong Adventurer Is Subdued by Illness
description: Scattered around a quiet living room in the Bronx are mementos of the life that Juanita Minors once lived.

title: At Iraq Wars End, Wounds Are Still Fresh for Falluja
description: FALLUJA, Iraq  They came on Wednesday to bury the war: clerics and sheiks, children and widows from across this scarred city. In the shadow of an overpass, they waved banners, burned an American flag, displayed photos of their dead and shouted well-worn denunciations of departing American forces.

title: George Whitman, Paris Bookseller and Cultural Beacon, Is Dead at 98
description: PARIS  George Whitman, the American-born owner of Shakespeare & Company, a fabled English-language bookstore on the Left Bank in Paris and a magnet for writers, poets and tourists for close to 60 years, died on Wednesday in his apartment above the store. He was 98.

title: Mitts Zest for Zings
description: Mitt Romney arrived in New York City on Wednesday, newly endorsed by Christine ODonnell, who we have not seen since her not-a-witch race for the U.S. Senate. She praised Romney for having been consistent since he changed his mind. I so miss Christine ODonnell.

title: Congress Takes Up a Partisan Battle, Again, Over Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Their poll numbers sinking, their constituents badly bruised by economic hardship and with millions of American workers about to get a sudden and unexpected tax increase, what are members of Congress discussing?

title: Iran Says It May Move Uranium Enrichment to Safer Places
description: Iran may relocate its uranium enrichment work to more secure locations, a senior Iranian defense official said Wednesday, an acknowledgment of increased concern that Irans suspected nuclear program could face a military attack from Israel or the United States.

title: MF Globals Risk Officer Said to Lack Authority
description: Congressional investigators are exploring whether regulators and feeble risk controls allowed MF Global to topple.

title: Holder Speaks Up for Voting Rights
description: For months, the Justice Department has largely been silent as Republican-dominated legislatures in state after state made it harder for minorities, poor people and other Democratic-leaning groups to vote. On Tuesday, however, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. spoke out forcefully and promised to use the full weight of his department to ensure that new electoral laws are not discriminatory. To live up to that vow, he will have his hands full.

title: Thursday: Way Less Traveled
description: Administrivial Notepad Alert! In this puzzle, there is a Notepad that reads: Parts of 15 answers in this puzzle are missing, in a manner for you to discover.

title: Obama Names Two to Serve on Labor Board
description: President Obama is nominating two new members to the National Labor Relations Board a week after the panel withdrew its case against Boeing over building an airplane factory in South Carolina.

title: Lysistrata Jones
description: Photos of the new Broadway musical.

title: Yes, Even Sexting Is Off Limits
