description: That blond babe we fell in love with in June is still looking hot in the cold light of December.

title: Beyond the Raters
description: Ratings agencies were one of the culprits of the financial crisis  bestowing top-notch, triple-A ratings on thousands of mortgage-backed securities that proved to be worth less than junk when the housing bubble burst. It has taken three years, but the nations banking regulators have now made a good proposal to remove the raters as the official arbiters of financial reliability and replace them with a set of objective, transparent criteria to determine the riskiness of assets in the trading portfolios of the nations 30 biggest banks.

title: Omnibus Spending Bill Held Up as Congress Dickers Over Riders and Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON  Travel to Cuba. Abortions in the nations capital. Energy efficiency standards for light bulbs. Those are a few of the issues that have ensnarled members of Congress trying to finish an omnibus spending bill that was due to be completed more than two months ago.

title: Illegal, Just Not on Capitol Hill
description: House Republican leaders have foolishly sidetracked a bipartisan ethics bill in Congress to ban members from using inside information they gain in private hearings and discussions in stock trades. Insider trading is illegal generally, but Congresss apparent exception from the ban was never a concern on Capitol Hill until a recent report on 60 Minutes questioned whether various members were profiting from back-room knowledge.

title: Somalias Insurgents Embrace Twitter as a Weapon
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Think of it as the Battle of the Tweets.

title: Clean Needles in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey State Assembly made a sensible, life-saving decision this month when it approved a bill that allows pharmacies to sell a limited number of syringes to individuals without prescriptions. The bill has passed the Senate, and Gov. Chris Christie should sign it into law. It will help New Jersey reduce the spread of H.I.V.

title: In India, a Growing Safety Problem
description: This weeks report of more than 100 people near Kolkata dying from bootleg liquor  coming on the heels of a fire in that city that killed more than 90  is the latest in a steady stream of horrific tragedies that seem to strike with brutal regularity in India. Rail accidents, stampedes at over-crowded religious festivals, bus accidents, building collapses, and a world-record number of traffic fatalities, are among the hazards regularly reported across the country.

title: Bill Would Require More Monitoring of Implants
description: Amid growing problems with artificial hips and other medical implants, bipartisan legislation was introduced in the Senate on Wednesday that would force manufacturers to track the performance of such products after they were approved for sale.

title: A City Embraces the Soul of Its Team
description: YAROSLAVL, Russia  Yuri Fedotov remembers the exact date he first watched this citys professional ice hockey team in action. It was Dec. 2, 1986  a day that began a relationship of love and faith that he said endured, and in fact helped reassure him during the political and economic upheavals in his country over the last two decades.

title: A Team Rebuilds
description: In Yaroslavl, the hockey team Lokomotiv is being carefully reconstructed.

title: Getting Detained and Gassed
description: MANAMA, Bahrain

title: Texas Counties in Voting Chaos Over Redistricting Case
description: SAN ANTONIO  Jacquelyn F. Callanen was neither a plaintiff nor a defendant in the redistricting case that the Supreme Court decided to hear last week. But her life  and her office  went from calm to chaos because of it.

title: Thursdays Matchup: Jaguars at Falcons
description: Jaguars (4-9) at Falcons (8-5)8:30 p.m. Eastern, NFL NetworkLine: Falcons by 11

title: Knicks Not Among Crawfords Choices
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  While Carmelo Anthony returned to practice Wednesday after missing a day because of a sore knee, some of the Knicks focus remained on Jamal Crawford, a player who is not even on their roster. By days end, it was clear Crawford would not be showing up for practice on Thursday  or on any other day, either.

title: Greene Provides Power for Jets Offensive Surge
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Wildcat may be perceived as a trick play, but as Jeremy Kerley intimated recently, there is no trickery involved when Shonn Greene receives the direct snap. We wouldnt use Shonn to try to hit the outside, Kerley said.

title: At a Rally for Hamas, Celebration and Vows
description: GAZA  The Hamas movement celebrated the 24th anniversary of its founding on Wednesday by reasserting that it would never recognize Israel nor abandon violence.

title: Corrections: December 15
description: NEW YORK

title: A Hired Gun Can Help During N.H.L. Shootouts
description: Rangers Coach John Tortorella seemingly does not have much to worry about these days. His young team is among the top clubs in the N.H.L., excelling on offense, defense and in goal.

title: Candidates on the Attack
description: Political attacks by Republican candidates are strategically aimed at the rivals they most want to beat.

title: Putting the Bake in Bake Sale
Israel: Bridge at Holy Site Is Reopened
description: Israeli authorities reopened a wooden bridge used by non-Muslims to enter the holy compound known as the Noble Sanctuary to Muslims and the Temple Mount to Jews. The Israelis closed the bridge on Monday because they considered it unsafe and wanted to replace it. But any act around the holy compound produces suspicion, and Palestinian and Jordanian officials fiercely objected. The Israelis said they would reinforce the bridge rather than rebuild it.

title: Russell Hoban, Frances Author, Dies at 86
description: Russell Hoban, a prolific author who created Frances, a girl who appeared in the guise of a badger in seven books for children, and Riddley Walker, the eponymous narrator of a widely praised postapocalyptic novel for adults, died on Tuesday in London. He was 86.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 15, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Center Begins Project Focused on Finding and Prosecuting Nazis
description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center has begun Operation Last Chance II, focused on finding and prosecuting remaining World War II Nazi war criminals who are still at large, the organizations chief Nazi hunter, Efraim Zuroff, said at a news conference in Berlin. The new project offers financial rewards of up to $32,900 for information leading to the prosecution and punishment of Nazi war crime suspects. The current drive to reopen hundreds of dormant investigations became possible after a legal precedent was set by the successful conviction of a former camp guard, John Demjanjuk, 91, in May.

title: Like Ivies, Berkeley Adds Aid to Draw Middle-Class Students
description: LOS ANGELES  The University of California, Berkeley, announced Wednesday that it would offer far more financial aid to middle-class students starting next fall, with families earning up to $140,000 a year expected to contribute no more than 15 percent of their annual income, in what experts described as the most significant such move by a public institution.

title: Anthony Amato, Founder of Amato Opera, Is Dead at 91
description: Anthony Amato, the founder and artistic director of the Amato Opera Theater, the scrappy, often threadbare and very rarely dull chamber opera company on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that was a mainstay of New Yorks cultural life for 61 years, died on Tuesday at his home on City Island, in the Bronx. Mr. Amato, who was also the companys stage director, music director, prompter, vocal coach, diction coach, caterer, broom pusher and emergency tenor, among other things, was 91.

title: Donations Are Sought to Aid 16 Nations
description: The United Nations asked donor countries on Wednesday for $7.7 billion to help deal with humanitarian crises in 16 countries in 2012, earmarking much of the money for tackling drought and famine in Somalia. The United Nations is hoping to bolster aid to Yemen to $447 million to tackle the effects of conflict and a food crisis.

title: What Iraqis Think of the American Withdrawal: Anbar Province
description: As American forces start to pull out of Iraq, we asked Iraqis around the country three questions:

title: Whatever Happened to  Falluja
description: FALLUJA, Iraq  Even before the war many people in Falluja did not like Saddam Hussein. They thought he made his decisions without consulting his people, that he was a dictator and they wanted to get rid of him.

title: As Doctors Use More Devices, Potential for Distraction Grows
description: Hospitals and doctors offices, hoping to curb medical error, have invested heavily to put computers, smartphones and other devices into the hands of medical staff for instant access to patient data, drug information and case studies.

title: Texas Two-Step
description: At the L.B.J. Library in Austin, Tex. on Tuesday night, Attorney General Eric Holder forcefully renewed the Department of Justices commitment to protecting the right to vote. Invoking President Johnsons remarks on signing the Voting Rights Act into law in 1965, Holder said that the right to vote is not only the cornerstone of our system of government  it is the lifeblood of our democracy.

title: Failure Rate of Schools Overstated, Study Says
description: When the Obama administration was seeking to drum up support for its education initiatives last spring, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan told Congress that the federal law known as No Child Left Behind would label 82 percent of all the nations public schools as failing this year. Skeptics questioned that projection, but Mr. Duncan insisted it was based on careful analysis.

title: Insurance Institute Names a Record Number of Top Safety Picks
description: For the second consecutive year, car buyers with safety at the top of their shopping list have a record number of choices at their dealerships. This conclusion was reached by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a nonprofit group financed by the insurance industry, which released its list of Top Safety Picks for 2012 on Thursday.

title: Charter School Approved for Affluent Brooklyn Enclave
description: The panel that oversees education policy in New York City approved the first charter school for brownstone Brooklyn on Wednesday night, backing a plan to give it space inside a building already shared by three other public schools.

title: Word of the Day | tether
description: tether \te-thr\ noun and verb

title: Robert Lawrence Balzer, Wine Writer, Dies at 99
description: Robert Lawrence Balzer, an early champion of American wines and a widely read critic of them for more than 60 years as a journalist and author, died on Dec. 1 at his home in Orange, Calif. He was 99.

title: Boris Chertok, Engineer With Russian Space Program, Dies at 99
description: Boris Chertok, a Russian rocket engineer who played a central role in designing the navigation systems for Soviet spacecraft during the race to the moon, among them the one that carried the first human into space, died Wednesday in Moscow. He was 99.

title: X Factor Watch: Knockout Performances With Little Fluff
description: Before delving into the details of Wednesday nights X Factor, by far the most enjoyable episode of the show yet, let me get something off my chest:

description: NYT Front Page for 12/15/2011

title: A Post-Retirement Vision That Helps Others See
description: At 58 years old, Dr. Govindappa Venkataswamy decided he needed to develop a post-retirement plan to keep his mind engaged.

title: Dec. 15, 1916 | Frances Decisive Attack in Battle of Verdun
description: On Dec. 15, 1916, the French launched a counterattack against German forces that would bring an end to the Battle of Verdun three days later, thus ending the longest and most costly battle of World War I.The New York Times quoted a report released by the French War Office: The attack started at 10 oclock. The enemys front broke down everywhere to a depth of about three kilometers. We have taken a great many prisoners, whose exact number has not yet been determined.  We have taken or destroyed numerous pieces of heavy and field artillery and also a considerable quantity of material.  Our success is complete. The troops have given vent to great enthusiasm. Our losses are slight.

title: Sports Illustrateds Swimsuit Edition Makes a Modest Splash
description: With barely a whisper of marketing, Sports Illustrateds iconic swimsuit edition made its debut in India two weeks ago. The 100-rupee ($2) issue is packed with sleek foreign models in a variety of swimwear.

title: In Baghdad, Panetta Leads Uneasy Moment of Closure
description: BAGHDAD  Almost nine years after the first American tanks began massing on the Iraq border, the Pentagon declared an official end to its mission here, closing a troubled conflict that helped reshape American politics and left a bitter legacy of anti-American sentiment across the Muslim world.

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 15, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Rousing Russia With a Phrase.

title: The New YouTube
description: WHO is Rebecca Black?

title: Portraits of Iraqi Pride
description: What now?

title: Where Is the Volcker Rule?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Would You Consider Deleting Your Facebook Account?
description: Roughly 200 million people in the United States  two-thirds of the countrys population  are on Facebook. Do you have a Facebook account? How attached to it are you? Do you have conflicted feelings about the site? Would you ever consider deleting your profile? Why or why not?In an article entitled The Facebook Resisters, Jenna Wortham reports that some people, even those with established Facebook presences, are dialing back their use of the social networking site or deleting their profiles completely, worried about invasions of privacy or feelings of social isolation. She writes:

title: On TV, Putin Is Dismissive of Critics Far and Near
description: MOSCOW  Vladimir V. Putin was back in the saddle during his annual televised question-and-answer session on Thursday night  glowing with health and sure of himself, reeling off catalogs of numbers and acid one-liners, just like old times.

title: Reaching the Ears of Iowa
description: In Iowa, the campaign is playing out on Simon Conways radio program on WHO, the most listened-to and widely broadcast news radio station in the state.

title: Chirac Found Guilty in Political Funding Case
description: PARIS  Former President Jacques Chirac, 79, was convicted Thursday of embezzlement and misusing of public funds to illegally finance his political party using fake jobs when he was mayor of Paris.

title: U.S., North Korea Hold Talks on Humanitarian Aid
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Officials from the United States and North Korea met in Beijing on Thursday to discuss the possible terms of resuming humanitarian aid shipments to the impoverished North.

title: Obscured Frescoes See the Light in Rome
description: When the Baroque master Pietro da Cortona was commissioned by Pope Alexander VII Chigi to fresco a 245-foot gallery at the Quirinale in Rome in 1655, he did not disappoint.

title: The Early Word: Battlefronts
description: In Todays Times:

title: In Wake of Investigation, Lius Approval Ratings Plummet
description: John C. Liu, the city comptroller, has suffered a steep drop in his approval ratings in the wake of a federal investigation into his campaign fund-raising, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released on Thursday.

title: In Iowa, British-Accented Radio Host Draws G.O.P. Hopefuls
description: DES MOINES  If youre competing in the Iowa caucuses, theres a new obligatory stop on the campaign trail this year, and its not a greasy spoon or an evangelical church.

title: Talk of Aid From Russia Buoys Markets in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Europe took a breather Thursday as a surprisingly strong Spanish bond auction and hints of Russian bailout money for the region provided at least a temporary sense of calm in the financial markets.

title: Africas Abortion Wars
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Between heavy lunches and poolside cocktails, the doctors and health experts who gathered at a fancy hotel here early this month to talk about reproductive health often brought up cultural taboos. Cultural taboos that hinder open discussion of H.I.V., cultural taboos that prevent the availability of contraceptives, cultural taboos that make abortions illegal in many African countries.

title: The Pakistanis Have a Point
description: Bill Keller examines the complicated, dysfunctional and co-dependent relationship between the United States and Pakistan in The New York Timess upcoming Sunday Magazine. He writes:

title: Frosted Cookies
description: 1. Roll the dough by hand into three logs of equal size, chill and then slice off rounds to create cookies.

title: Cookie Bars
description: 1. Spread the dough onto the bottom of a deep, well-greased 9-by-13-inch baking pan (or one lined with parchment paper).

title: Thumbprints
description: 1. Roll the dough into 1 1/2-inch-diameter balls and then press the pad of your thumb into the middle, flattening the ball and making an indentation.

title: Sandwich Cookies
description: 1. Roll the dough by hand into three logs of equal size, chill and then slice off rounds to create cookies.

title: Rolling in the Dough
description: Cookie recipes are just about infinite, because almost anything can be shaped into a circle and baked: hence gluten-free, dairy-free, sugar-free cookies. But the basic cookie contains three key ingredients: butter, flour and sugar. That combination has not been bettered, and it can be varied in so many ways that, really, its the only recipe you need.

title: When the Doctor Faces a Lawsuit
description: Within months of completing my training, I received the call that every doctor dreads.

title: Brighter Playoff Forecast for Giants and Jets
description: The playoff race simulations at NFL.-Forecast.com are merely a snapshot. But the snapshot this week provides a prettier picture for fans of the Giants and the Jets.

title: Old Mutual to Sell Its Nordic Business for $3.2 Billion
description: LONDON  British insurer Old Mutual agreed on Thursday to sell the Skandia Insurance Company, its Nordic savings and banking business, to the Swedish insurance company Skandia Liv for 2.1 billion, or $3.2 billion.

title: Bootleg Liquor Kills More Than 100
description: More than 100 people died and many more remained hospitalized in eastern India on Thursday after consuming bootleg liquor, authorities said.

title: Credit Suisses Latest Cost-Cutting Effort
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse, the second-largest Swiss bank, will combine the support operations for its investment and private banking divisions as it looks to reduce costs against the backdrop of the sovereign debt crisis.

title: Ceremony Marks End of U.S. Mission in Iraq
description: Secretary of Defense Leon E. Panetta addressed a ceremony on Thursday in Baghdad ending the U.S. military mission in Iraq.

title: Madagascars Lemurs, Sacred No More
description: A boy ventured into the forest to collect honey. He climbed a tall tree in pursuit of a hive, but before he could collect his prize, he was attacked by bees. Losing his grip, he fell from the tree, which almost certainly would have meant his untimely end. But a kind indri  a type of large lemur  caught him, and the boy was saved. Since that day, the elders say, no one should eat the indri.

title: Week 15 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Explaining Tebow
description: How are the Broncos 7-1 behind starting quarterback Tim Tebow? If I plug the Broncos offensive efficiency stats since Tebow took the reins into the game prediction model, they come out as the 19th-best team and would be expected to have just a .480 winning percentage.

title: A Pizza-Making Class Rises, Then Falls
description: On Nov. 2, Pizza a Casa, a pizza-cooking school on the Lower East Side, surpassed Central Park and the long-running musical The Lion King to become the second-highest-rated attraction in New York City on the popular travel review Web site TripAdvisor. The storefront on Grand Street improbably trailed only the Top of the Rock, outpacing even the Statue of Liberty. (TripAdvisor lists 660 attractions for New York.)

title: News From Ireland
description: Kevin ORourke:

title: Covidien to Spin Off Pharmaceutical Unit
description: Its a spinoff of a spinoff.

title: Final Debate of 2011 Poses Danger for Hopefuls
description: No bigger danger remains for the Republican presidential candidates  and especially for the leaders in the race, Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich  than Thursday nights debate.

description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MF Globals Risk Officer Said to Lack Authority | Congressional investigators are exploring whether regulators and feeble risk controls allowed MF Global to topple.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 15
description: On Thursday, a House committee plans to take up the Stop Online Piracy Act, one of a pair of bills in the Congress intended to curb online piracy, particularly of movies, music and television shows. On one side is the entertainment business, which considers the current tools inadequate to fight pirating sites, a Whac-a-Mole approach, Edward Wyatt writes. On the other side, technology companies, who argue that the bills are so broad and heavy-handed that they threaten to close Web sites and broadband service providers and stifle free speech. Each is marshaling huge resources to lobby Congress and the American public, with the entertainment business framing the issue as about protecting jobs in the United States.

title: The War Is Over; the Heartbreak Isnt
description: Marine Cpl. Robert Marcus Rodriguez of Maspeth, Queens, all of 21 years old, was the first serviceman from New York City to die in the Iraq war. That was a few days after the start of combat in March 2003. He was assuredly not the last to be killed. That sad distinction fell in August 2008 to Army Specialist Jorge Luis Feliz Nieve, 26, of Queens Village.

title: Afghan Rebuke of Qatar Sets Back Peace Talks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan withdrew its ambassador from Qatar in protest over reports that the Persian Gulf emirate has been in discussions about bringing in Taliban insurgents to jump-start peace talks, officials confirmed Thursday.

title: Thumbs Up for Success Academy's Move Into Brownstone Brooklyn
Wage Protection for Home Care Workers
description: The Obama administration proposed regulations on Thursday to give the nations nearly two million home care workers minimum wage and overtime protections. Those workers have long been exempted from coverage.

title: Daily Report: Congress Considers Bills to Prevent Piracy
description: Two Congressional bills take aim at Internet sites that offer pirated copies of movies, television shows and music, reports Edward Wyatt in Thursdays New York Times. Most such sites operate overseas, but the legislation, with bipartisan support, is directed at companies in this country  search engines like Google and Yahoo, payment sites like PayPal and ad servers  that help the sites stay in business.

title: Olympus President Says Executives May Seek to Keep Jobs Despite Scandal
description: TOKYO  Top executives at Olympus, the camera maker, may seek to keep their jobs despite a huge accounting scandal, the president said Thursday, intensifying a standoff with Michael C. Woodford, the ousted chief executive, and throwing the companys future into further disarray.

title: List of Golden Globe Nominees and Winners
Pulp Friction: The Kindle Debate
description: My article in The New York Times on Monday citing high levels of dissatisfaction with Amazons new tablet generated a torrential response, much of it from people who said they loved their Kindle Fires. The wilder commentators suggested that the whole article somehow came from Apple, which, in their view, was trying to get people to hock grandmas jewels to buy $500 iPads. None of those conspiracy theorists explained why so many original users of the Fire put mixed to negative reviews on Amazons own site.

title: The Year in Media | Where Will Borders Books and Customers Go?
description: Staff members of The Timess media news department are highlighting the most significant developments this year in the industries they cover.

title: Congress Reaches Deal to Reauthorize and Revamp Small-Business Programs
description: The House of Representatives and the Senate have resolved a three-year battle over the future of two important federal initiatives to aid small businesses: the Small Business Innovation Research program and the Small Business Technology Transfer program. On the particulars, the Senate seems to have carried the day, but the House has won long-term changes to the innovation research program that open it up to companies backed by venture capital. In their dispute, the House and Senate have served as proxies for opposing views of the programs purpose: whether it should funnel funds to small businesses otherwise neglected by the markets, or maximize the return to the economy in job and wealth creation.

title: Vain Glorious | Perfect Holiday Palettes
description: Cosmetic palettes make perfect holiday gifts, but only if youre able to part with them. Six compacts that are sure to test your will:

title: Howard Stern to Join  NBCs Americas Got Talent
description: Howard Stern has signed up to be a judge on Americas Got Talent, NBCs popular summer series, he said on Thursday morning.

title: Golden Globe Nominations Go to The Help, The Descendants, The Artist
description: LOS ANGELES  GOLDEN GLOBE voters did little to clear up a blurry awards picture in Hollywood on Thursday, giving films like The Artist, The Help and The Descendants roughly the same number of nominations and snubbing some perceived Oscar front-runners.

title: Barcelonas Costly Victory in Japan
description: While most of the soccer world was asleep early Thursday, Barcelona notched a costly victory against Al-Sadd of Qatar in the FIFA Club World Cup in Yokohama, Japan.

title: Your Life on Facebook, in Total Recall
description: Remember those karaoke videos from three years ago that somehow wound up on Facebook? They were embarrassing for the few hours they spent at the top of your Facebook profile, and then they were buried under a cascade of new updates.

title: Morgan Stanley, Like Rivals, to Make Deep Job Cuts
description: 8:32 p.m. | Updated

title: Golden Globe Nominees
description: Images of some of the films and actors nominated for the 2012 Golden Globe Awards.

title: A Fight in the N.R.C. Family
description: It was technically a hearing in the House of Representatives, but when the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform heard from all five members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Wednesday for two and a half hours, it sometimes sounded like a counseling session for a bad marriage, complete with he said, she said.

title: How to Assemble a Dragon
description: A sequence from The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, described by the films director and editors.

title: Four Minutes With The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo
description: Angus Wall has edited the last five movies directed by David Fincher  the three most-recent (The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, The Social Network and The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo) in partnership with Kirk Baxter. Earlier this year, Wall and Baxter won the Oscar for Best Achievement in Film Editing for The Social Network, and while they each work on outside projects   Wall created the arresting title sequence for HBOs Game of Thrones  they spend much of their time in adjacent rooms, cutting and splicing copious amounts of Finchers footage. Wall explains the key to editing like this: The human brain wants to put things together; it wants to create a narrative. Their job is to facilitate that desire.

title: A Better Life Under Saddam
description: In Adhamiya, Samir Nasrat said the war brought worries never felt under Saddam.

title: Indexes End 3-Day Swoon On Upbeat Economic Data
description: Stock indexes snapped a three-day decline as data on jobless claims and manufacturing signaling a strengthening economy overshadowed concern over the European debt crisis.

title: The Future of Motherlode
description: Im overwhelmed. Thanks for a warm welcome to Motherlode, and for a list of ideas for new topics that will keep me writing and you commenting for a long time (and, not to mention, help me bring in some great guest posters).

title: Leading Off: Paul Fiasco Over, N.B.A. Silliness Moves to Orlando
description: If you are mildly surprised the N.B.A. finally managed to trade Chris Paul on Wednesday, keep in mind that the N.B.A. had to trade Chris Paul. After nearly a week of unrelenting scorn for playing puppetmaster with the highest profile star on the team the league operates, Commissioner David Stern did the one thing he had to do to turn off that rather uncomfortable klieg light: get the hapless Hornets a respectable deal for Paul. The alternative was an unhappy star taking the court for an ownerless team as an every-other-night reminder that the leagues fantabulous lockout had created something resembling a banana republic.

title: Save your Elite Flyer Status While You Can
description: ITS crunch time for top-tier frequent fliers. On Jan. 1, miles that count toward elite status automatically reset to zero on most airlines. That means fliers who werent able to collect enough miles or trip segments to maintain their spot in the frequent flier pecking order  typically between 25,000 and 125,000 miles a year, or 30 and 140 segments, depending on the airline  will lose some, or all, of their beloved perks.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Surprise! The Golden Globe Nominators Like Stars
description: The Hollywood Foreign Press has spoken, and guess what? It likes the stars.

title: Disagreement Over Payroll Tax Cuts Impact on Social Security
description: WASHINGTON  For all of the partisan brawling over President Obamas call to extend a temporary payroll tax cut for 160 million Americans, one concern is bipartisan: a significant minority of Democrats and Republicans say that cutting the taxes that finance Social Security benefits will further undermine the program.

title: Thursday Reading: Distracted Doctoring Is Latest Gadget Side Effect
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Provincial Chinese Officials Seek to End Village Revolt
description: BEIJING  Officials in Guangdong Province trying to end a five-day standoff between the police and angry villagers have vowed to temporarily halt questionable property sales and to investigate claims that the local government illegally confiscated farmland for private development, the state news media reported Thursday.

title: Take the Cultural Osmosis Pop Quiz: Tintin Edition
description: If youre just joining us, the goal of each installment of the Cultural Osmosis Pop Quiz is to measure the extent to which a pervasive pop-cultural phenomenon  say, Harry Potter or Twilight or, in this case, Tintin  has permeated the consciousness of those people who make no effort to pay attention to it or even strive to avoid it.

title: Did W.P.S. Pin Federation in a Corner?
description: Was there really any alternative?

title: Syrian Army Defectors Reportedly Kill 27 Soldiers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The armed insurgency against the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has become more organized in recent weeks, with defectors launching attacks that have become bolder and in some cases more sophisticated, according to activists and residents inside the country and in exile.

title: What Were Reading
description: DNA Info: Another downtown casualty, the Milk Street Cafe plans to close up shop for good on Thursday. The owners blame the police for erecting barricades against Occupy Wall Street, and keeping them up even after the protesters left. Via Eater.  Patrick Farrell

title: Seth Rogen, Happy Non-Nominee for His Role in 50/50
description: My home phone rang, which only happens when something terrible is going on, Seth Rogen said, of learning that the film he produced and co-starred in, 50/50, was nominated for the Golden Globe for best comedy this morning. He hadnt yet talked to his fellow star, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, nominated for best actor in a comedy, when the Bagger spoke to him. My brain just doesnt think I should call people this early, he said. (His publicists brain apparently disagreed.)

title: Former N.B.A. Employee Says Sexual Harassment Concerns Were Ignored
description: A former N.B.A. security official says that he repeatedly warned his superiors that women in the office were being sexually harassed or discriminated against, but that his concerns were ignored and that he was ultimately fired for his actions on the womens behalf. He is suing the league for lost wages and damages.

title: Packing Heat and Singing Sweetly
description: 1. PISTOL ANNIES Hell on Heels (Columbia Nashville) The country singer Miranda Lamberts side project with Ashley Monroe and Angaleena Presley turned out to be loose, wise, tough, well written, well sung and more in tune with the debt-stricken American moment than her own record this year.

title: Heartache, Mortality and Success
description: 1. FEIST Metals (Cherrytree/Interscope) Leslie Feists songs of heartache, solitude and eventual solace are both handmade and subtly sophisticated on Metals. She traded pop gloss for pensive, lingeringly unresolved melodies and arrangements that crest unexpectedly from within, with her own taut electric guitar and apparitions of horns and voices summoning the tensions behind the beauty.

title: Blood Sport in a High-Rise
description: Not a lot happens, in the usual sense of movie action, in Carnage, Roman Polanskis swift and spry adaptation of Yasmina Rezas play: voices are raised; whiskey is drunk; leftover fruit cobbler is consumed and (spoiler alert!) vomited. A few slightly more dramatic events have already taken place before the action starts. There has been a playground altercation between two young boys, and a hamster has been removed from a comfortable high-rise apartment and abandoned to its fate on the streets of Brooklyn.

title: Waking Up With Eczema
description: During my latest eczema outbreak, the routine was typical. I wake up and remove from my hands the white cotton socks that prevent me from scratching overnight, then press a tissue to my closed eyes to remove the pus and blood that have accumulated in the folds of my eyelids. In the bathroom, I try not to dwell too long at the sight of myself in the mirror before patting my skin dry and slathering it with lotion. I wrap bandages over the raw and weeping patches in the crooks of my elbows  a stopgap, really, since the bandages will soak through in several hours. I take Benadryl to calm the itching, and ibuprofen to temper the swelling and pain, before heading to meetings in an antihistamine haze. I hope no one stares, but they do.

title: Just One Look | Theyskens Theory
description: Theyre calling them spants, said a fellow observer at the Theyskens Theory prefall collection appointment yesterday afternoon. Spants  like these silk wide leg pants with a built-in split train  are a perfect mix of the designer Olivier Theyskenss past successes: the long flowing silk skirts (styled with a faded tee) and the super-wide-leg trouser. Also new among the labels faithful hot shorts, biker jackets and low slung denim pants are crystal-embroidered sheer tops and tights (that slouch in the perfect, grungy way) and a glowing signature print inspired by certain light-catching prisms.

title: Statue Deepens Dispute Over Wartime Sexual Slavery
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The unsmiling teenage girl in traditional Korean dress sits in a chair, her feet bare, her hands on her lap, her eyes fixed on the Japanese Embassy across a narrow street in central Seoul. Within a day, the life-size bronze statue had become the focal point of a simmering diplomatic dispute as President Lee Myung-bak prepared to visit Tokyo this weekend.

title: Sounds That Come From in the Head and on the Street
description: 1. AMBROSE AKINMUSIRE When the Heart Emerges Glistening (Blue Note) An earnest young trumpeter with a bracingly original style  shadowy tone, sure attack, surprising turns of phrase  Mr. Akinmusire puts the focus here on the gleam of his crackerjack quintet. Its a smart dispatch from the new postbop frontier, and the rare album of that description to feel emotionally unarmored.

title: A New Madonna Album, on a New Label
description: Madonnas next album will be released on Interscope Records in March, the first in a three-album deal with the label.

title: From Retro Yuck to Foodie Rap
description: 1. DRAKE Take Care (Young Money/Cash Money/Universal Republic) Heres a new blueprint: attack from the outside, rewrite the rules, get famous and win, then tear everything up and start again from even further afield. Thats what Drakes doing on this, his second major-label album, a perversely strange and entrancing collection of piano-driven self-lacerations and anti-anthems. Its bold and arresting, and virtually impossible to copy.

title: Walkouts by Nurses Loom as Hospitals Seek to Cut Costs
description: The specter of nursing strikes is looming on both coasts, as newly empowered nurses unions confront hospitals pressed to cut costs amid changes in health care financing.

title: Chinese Ambassador Meets With Dissident Leader in Myanmar
description: The Chinese ambassador to Myanmar has met with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the countrys main political opposition movement, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesman said on Thursday in Beijing.

title: U.S. Will Not Finance New Research on Chimps
description: The National Institutes of Health on Thursday suspended all new grants for biomedical and behavioral research on chimpanzees and accepted the first uniform criteria for assessing the necessity of such research. Those guidelines require that the research be necessary for human health, and that there be no other way to accomplish it.

title: The Best Albums of 2011
description: Jon Pareles, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff, pop music critics for The Times, discuss their favorite albums of 2011.

title: 'Random Scanning' by Police at New Dorp High
Did You Think Twice About the Elevator?
description: The odds of dying in a New York City elevator are minuscule.

title: The Key Players in Benton Harbors Revival
description: The once-vibrant manufacturing center in Michigan is almost a caricature of economic disparity in America.

title: Now That the Factories Are Closed, Its Tee Time in Benton Harbor, Mich.
description: On the northern edge of Benton Harbor, just beyond the grim grid of housing projects, shuttered storefronts, boarded-up homes and junk-laden yards that dominate much of the town, sits an emerald oasis known as Harbor Shores. As the name suggests, Harbor Shores is a resort development. At its heart is a pristine Jack Nicklaus-designed golf course that meanders along a river and creek; through woods and wetlands; and, most striking, across tall, white sand dunes overlooking Lake Michigan.

title: New Gingrich Ad Cites Bold Ideas
description: Newt Gingrichs campaign is up with a new ad in Iowa that is largely positive while gently chiding his opponents for the tone of their political conversation. The script reads:

title: The Sound of One President Caving
description: For a while, the administration encouraged people to think that President Obama would take a stand against the unnecessary and very dangerous provisions that Congress jammed into the annual National Defense Authorization Act. He threatened to veto the whole bill in order to block new rules that would mandate the military custody of most terrorist suspects, and officially sanction their indefinite detention, without due process.

title: Edsel Ford II Wants the Family Punch Bowl Back
description: Edsel B. Ford II, the great-grandson of Henry Ford, left his audience at Sardis restaurant on Tuesday with little doubt about what he wanted from them.

title: Missing Muppets, Forgotten Ingenues and Other Golden Globes Oversights
description: Along with Seth Rogen, a slew of other worthy stars were left off the Golden Globes tally sheet this morning. The love may be drying up for Martha Marcy May Marlene and Like Crazy, whose breakout actresses, Elizabeth Olsen and Felicity Jones, were not mentioned. Neither was Gary Oldman, for bringing George Smiley to life (again) in Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy. Critical and arthouse favorites like the financial thriller Margin Call and Terrence Malicks Tree of Life were forgotten (though two Tree of Life stars, Brad Pitt and Jessica Chastain, were nominated for the work in other films). And pity Kirsten Dunst, who turned in a possibly career-changing performance with a difficult director in Melancholia and so far has no major Stateside statuettes to show for it.

title: CBS Is Reviving Person to Person, Made Famous by Murrow
description: In its latest back-to-the-future programming move, CBS News is reviving Person to Person, a 1950s series hosted by Edward R. Murrow that visited celebrities, politicians and other stars in their homes.

title: Guess Where This Is?
description: Before falling into decay, this gentrifying neighborhood in Asia was once home to fanciful colonial mansions. Guess where this is in the comments below.

title: New Jersey Help Line for Troops Expands to Nationwide Program
description: A peer-group counseling program that has proven successful in New Jersey is being expanded for reservists and National Guard troops nationwide, in part to help stem the continuing problem of suicides within the military, the Pentagon announced this week.

title: Berkeley to Increase Aid to Middle-Class Students
description: In Thursdays Times, Jennifer Medina reported that the University of California, Berkeley, will expand its financial aid to middle-class students next fall, seeking to combat economic stratification on campus.

title: U.S. Finds Pervasive Bias Against Latinos by Arizona Sheriff
description: PHOENIX  In a strongly worded critique of the countrys best-known sheriff, the Justice Department on Thursday accused Sheriff Joe Arpaio of engaging in unconstitutional policing by unfairly targeting Latinos for detention and arrest and retaliating against those who complain.

title: Hispanic Society Enlists Sothebys to Auction Rare Collection of Coins
description: A rare collection of almost 38,000 coins is expected to raise between $25 million and $35 million for the Hispanic Society of America, Sothebys New York announced Thursday. The collection, assembled more than 100 years ago by Archer M. Huntington, the founder of the Hispanic Society, will be offered as a single lot in sealed bid auction beginning Thursday and ending next March.

title: From the Past, but Looking Forward
description: THIS was a year for celebrating both the enduring power of traditional theater and the creative stealth bombs that can be planted within it, for putting new and explosive life into classic vessels. The Book of Mormon, the years biggest hit, is on one level as cheerful and predictable an organic musical as anything Rodgers and Hammerstein might have come up with. But its also a sustained act of gleeful subversion. And while plays like Jerusalem, The _______ With the Hat and Other Desert Cities are anything but experimental in form, each seduces its audiences into traveling into places that they hadnt expected (or thought they wanted) to visit. With one notable exception (the Belarus Free Theaters galvanizing Being Harold Pinter) the shows listed below have the pleasingly familiar surface appearance of the Broadway of decades ago. What lurks in the hearts and minds of the original productions here (the revivals are another matter, but only just) is very much of the 21st century.

title: Without Hype, Playwriting Thrives
description: FOR the second year running I quickly totted up my list of my favorite nights at the theater before noticing, to my happy surprise, that the lineup didnt include a single revival. This year, perhaps just as remarkably (if less happily), it doesnt include a single musical either. True, it was hardly a stellar year for either genre.

title: Pop Art | Peter & the Wolf
description: Its really best to see the work of Jason Hackenwerth in person to appreciate it, since describing what he does which is to assemble art out of balloons makes him sound a bit like a glorified clown. In truth, Hackenwerths latex balloon sculptures have more in common with the variegated, tentacled glass work of Dale Chihuly than with some Bozos bicycle.

title: Justice Department Findings in Investigation of the Maricopa County Sheriffs Office
description: After a two-year investigation, the Justice Department announced that the Maricopa County Sheriffs Office has engaged in a pattern of misconduct that violates the Constitution and federal law.

title: Popcast: The Best Albums of 2011
description: December brings year-end reflection and abundant lists from culture mavens, and this week The Timess pop music critics listen to and discuss their favorite albums of 2011.

title: Goldman Sachs Names Co-Head of Private Equity Banking Group
description: Goldman Sachs has named Pete Lyon co-head of the investment-banking unit that covers private equity firms. The announcement comes a day after the firm announced the retirement of Milton R. Berlinski, a 26-year Goldman veteran who had run the unit alongside Alison Mass.

title: Mosque Is Attacked After Demolitions at Settler Outpost
description: A mosque in a village outside the West Bank city of Ramallah was defaced and set on fire early Thursday, the third day of extremist Jewish violence that has prompted widespread condemnation and new law enforcement steps by the Israeli government.

title: The Hosts Risks at a Holiday Party
description: Planning a party this holiday season? The insurer MetLife reports that some two-thirds of potential hosts say they will take extra steps to protect their belongings during parties this year, including plans to lock, hide or move their valuables. (Which begs the question: Who are they inviting to their eggnog shindigs, anyway?)

title: Nepal and Others Mull Monsantos Role in Advancing Agriculture
description: Heres a quick update on efforts to expand access to higher-yielding hybrid seed in Nepal. Even though the country already has lots of different varieties beyond their own traditional supplies, a recent plan to expand access to higher-yielding seed, facilitated by the United States Agency for International Development and involving Monsanto, hit a big roadblock, as was explored here not long ago (In Nepal, Farmers Struggle as City Dwellers Fight Monsanto).

title: Poetry Pairing | Winter Syntax
description: This week our Poetry Pairing matches Billy Collinss Winter Syntax with an audio slideshow by Keith Mulvihill in which a reporter, photographer and mountaineer together navigate the snowy Tuckerman Ravine Trail along the Presidential Range in New Hampshire.

title: Dita Von Teese: What I Wore
description: Born Heather Sweet in Michigan, Dita Von Teese, 39, has been performing burlesque since 1992. Among several projects, she is working on a womens clothing collection (Dita Von Teese Muse) and a lingerie line (Von Follies), both of which are to be introduced next spring. Ms. Von Teese lives in Paris and Los Angeles.  BEE-SHYUAN CHANG WEDNESDAY, DEC. 7

title: Gingrich Admits Mistake With Romney Attack
description: Newt Gingrich said Thursday he made a mistake when he attacked Mitt Romney in recent days, pinpointing his remark on Saturday that the only reason Mr. Romney was not a career politician was that he had lost the 1994 Senate race in Massachusetts to Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Fenway and Wrigley Find Two Sides to Landmark Status
description: Baseballs two oldest and most iconic ballparks are on divergent paths when it comes to recognizing their historic status. After a decade of renovations, Bostons Fenway Park is hurtling toward federal landmark recognition  and the tax credits that come with it. Meanwhile, in Chicago, the Cubs contend that Wrigley Fields local landmark designation is a roadblock to upgrading the stadium and increasing revenue.

title: TimesCast | December 15, 2011
description: Michael S. Schmidt and Stephen Farrell report from Baghdad, as the United States declares the mission in Iraq over.

title: Malaysia Emerging as Transit Point for Ivory Smuggling
description: A wildlife protection group reports that Malaysia, where hundreds of African elephant tusks were seized this week, is becoming a transit point for illegal ivory that is being sold in markets around Asia. In the fourth case of its kind this year, Malaysian customs officials seized 15 tons of tusks and other ivory products on Monday worth an estimated $1.3 million, said Azis Yacub, the director of the customs department in the central state of Selangor.

title: Eagles Are Facing Jets and a Grim Reality
description: PHILADELPHIA  Brent Celek, the feisty tight end for the underachieving Philadelphia Eagles, asked for a moment of his teammates time in the locker room last Sunday before they played the Miami Dolphins. Celek then began to talk  or, rather, shout.

title: No Popping the Cork for These Nominees
description: As nominees and non-nominees learned of their fortunes today, we spoke with a few about the news and their plans to celebrate. Or not. Low-key might be the best adjective for these plans. Here are edited excerpts from conversations with Octavia Spencer, Rooney Mara, Albert Brooks and Kenneth Branagh:

title: The Giving Spree | Rodarte
description: Who: Rodartes Laura and Kate Mulleavy

title: Livery Cabs Idle as the Power Couple Bickers
description: Even in good times, New Yorks mayors and governors offer a troubled marriage. Big state, big city, big egos: So much works against a happy union.

title: More Rubble From the Military Detention Cave-In
description: There are a few issues I didnt get to in my previous post on the National Defense Authorization Act, which President Obama has indicated hell sign.

title: Accounting for Social Security
description: Social Security is a pay-as-you-go program financed by payroll taxes on workers and employers. When its revenues fall short of the benefits it owes in a given year, it covers payments by drawing on a $2.6 trillion fund that is accounted for separately from the federal budget and invested in government bonds.

title: Live Blog: House Panel Hearing on MF Global
description: Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of the bankrupt MF Global, will be speaking Thursday to a Congressional subcommittee about the collapse of the brokerage and the loss of roughly $1 billion in customer money. In his third trip to Capitol Hill in a week, Mr. Corzine is set to testify before the House Financial Services Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee. The hearing starts at 1 p.m.

title: Lawmakers Propose Royalties Be Paid to Artists on Resale
description: Its the dream of every art collector to buy a painting from a little-known artist for $100 and later sell it for $1 million. But how does that artist feel? Some think it unfair that artists typically do not directly benefit when a particular work escalates in value, and a bill introduced Thursday by Representative Jerrold Nadler, Democrat of New York, and Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, seeks to redress that.

title: In New Ad, Perry Takes on Romney and Gingrich
description: DES MOINES  With less than three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Rick Perry is firing his toughest volley yet at Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich, the front-runners in many national polls, with a new commercial that seeks to paint them as political insiders.

title: Wheelies: The Executive Class Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Kors I.P.O. Makes Its Debut in Style
description: 8:43 p.m. | Updated

title: List of Protesting Principals Tops 1,000
The Bake Sale Conundrum
Viggo Mortensen and Dangerous Methods Fate
description: Its a very pleasant surprise, Viggo Mortensen said of his Golden Globe nomination for best supporting actor for A Dangerous Method, directed by David Cronenberg. Emphasis on the surprise: My movie is doing extremely well in a few theaters, Mr. Mortensen continued, calling from Madrid, where he is doing the Ariel Dorfman play Purgatorio, but it hasnt seemed to be very visible or acknowledged by the awards crowd so far.

title: Maya Lin Project Approved in Newport Despite Objections
description: Over the objections of a group of vocal opponents the city council of Newport, R.I., voted Wednesday night to approve the use of a small park for a permanent installation being designed by the artist Maya Lin to evoke the citys past and to honor the heiress Doris Duke.

title: Lawmakers Agree on Spending Bill, Avoiding Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  Retreating from their harsh partisan sniping, and perhaps fearing public rebuke, Congressional leaders said Thursday that they had agreed on a large-scale spending measure to keep the government running for the next nine months.

title: Smelling a Hit, Amazon Opens Up About the Kindle
description: The masses, undismayed by reviewers, are speaking with their wallets.

title: Share Your Essential Holiday Recipes
description: What are your favorite recipes for the season? Share your best, whether theyre for a cookie swap, a Hanukkah party, a Christmas dinner, a New Years brunch or any other celebration. Use the form here to submit your photos and recipes.

title: Some Big Schools Struggle to Sell Bowl Tickets
description: The conventional wisdom in the business of bowl games is that big programs bring along lots of fans. But several schools, including Virginia Tech, Penn State, Clemson and West Virginia, are testing that wisdom.

title: A Withdrawal Ceremony in Iraq, Observed by Few Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  When Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta arrived in Baghdad on Thursday for the ceremony to mark the end of the United States militarys mission in Iraq, there was one group noticeably underrepresented: Iraqis.

title: Save the Packaging
description: My husband asked me what I wanted for Christmas. I gave him a list of practical items: a sports watch, a spa day. But later, he mentioned that he and my son had done a lot of research about a special gift for me. Curious, I checked our shared e-mail and discovered that hed bought a $2,500 telescope. This is lovely, but Im not interested in astronomy. Id rather use the money for a scheduled home improvement. How do I tell him that his gift is generous but unwanted? (And should I do it now or later?)

title: Take That, SAG Awards
description: Earlier, Albert Brooks, a Golden Globe nominee for his role in Drive, told the Baggers colleague Paula Schwartz that he did not consider the nod vindication for being overlooked by the SAG Awards yesterday. Listen, I dont do that, he said. If you start this whole thing as the barometer of your existence youre doomed to fail.

title: Q.&A.: Nokia and T-Mobile Executives Talk About Windows Phone
description: The struggling phone maker Nokia announced on Thursday that it had teamed up with T-Mobile USA to offer a new phone running Microsofts Windows Phone 7 software. Landing in stores Jan. 11, the Lumia 710 will cost $50 with a two-year contract on T-Mobile, with rates starting at $50 a month. Chris Weber, president of Nokia Americas, and Andrew Sherrard, senior vice president of marketing for T-Mobile USA, discussed the strategy behind the phone in an interview.

title: At Occupy Frankfurt, Calm Anarchy Has Staying Power
description: FRANKFURT  The Frankfurt version of the Occupy Wall Street movement has many of the trappings of the New York City original, including a tattered cluster of tents, a location close to the beating heart of financial power and a diverse group of activists trying to come up with a unifying demand.

title: U.S. Marks End to 9-Year War, Leaving an Uncertain Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  At a crowded market in the city center here, the flotsam of the war is for sale. Ripped Fuel workout supplement. Ready-to-eat meals, macaroni and cheese Mexican style. Pistol holsters. Nothing seems off limits to the merchants out for a quick dinar, not even a bottle of prescription pills from a pharmacy in Waco, Tex., probably tossed out by a departing soldier.

title: Bellevue Marks 275 Years of Taking Care
description: Bellevue Hospital Center celebrated its 275th anniversary Thursday with what one hospital official called a conservative, restrained noontime event, consonant with economic hard times, in the hospital atrium on the east side of Manhattan. Although a 275th birthday might not match up in gravitas to 200 years or 250 or 300, there is a word for it: dodranstricentennial.

title: The Year of C.E.O. Failures Explained
description: In some ways, the most interesting stories in tech for 2011 werent the products. They were the companies. Or, more specifically, their chief executives.

title: Obesity Rate Falls for New York Schoolchildren
Week 15 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: 2010 Brooklyn Elevator Injury Leads to Repairmans Indictment
description: Updated, 9:10 p.m. | One year after the elevator accident that nearly claimed her life, Debra Jordan still struggles to use her left leg and dreads whenever she must change floors.

title: WPP Gives Lincoln Its Own Boutique Ad Agency
description: As the Ford Motor Company seeks to reinvent its Lincoln luxury-car brand, WPP, the giant advertising agency holding company that works for Ford Motor, is reinventing its model for creating campaigns for Lincoln.

title: Everything Old Is New Again
description: On Thursday, I wrote about a Pew Research Center study showing that the median age at first marriage is about six years higher today than it was in 1960, for both sexes.

title: Stop U.S. Drone Flights, Iran Warns Afghanistan
description: Iran escalated its confrontation with the United States on Thursday over the captured American spy drone launched from Afghanistan, warning the Afghan government to order a halt to such surveillance flights.

title: Tweeting Your Way to a Scholarship
description: For many aspiring college students, getting a scholarship requires endless Googling, scrounging letters of recommendation and, of course, writing essays. Or, there is Twitter.

title: How Should Schools Teach About Sex? Students Have Their Say
description: For the second installment of our Reading Club, we chose the New York Times Magazine article Teaching Good Sex by Laurie Abraham, which profiled Al Vernacchio and his novel approach to teaching about human sexuality. We invited students to read the lengthy article and participate in a conversation.

title: Gingrich Momentum Slows, Polls Suggest
description: A lot of bad habits when analyzing general election polls can be good ones when it comes to primaries and caucuses. In particular, making inferences about a trend based on just a couple of polls will often lead you astray in the general election. As I wrote about on Tuesday, however, this is probably the lesser of evils when it comes to primaries. Voter preferences can change fast in primaries, and although the polls may or may not track them as accurately as we might like, in the long run you will benefit from being aggressive about trying to discern who has the momentum.

title: How Fighting Became So Ferocious
description: Although fighting has always been accepted in North American hockey and permitted under the N.H.L.s rules, the role of fighters and the process of dropping the gloves have changed dramatically. In the old days, superstars fought their own battles. Today, there are players with marginal skills and little talent who engage in staged fights that have absolutely nothing to do with the game.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.15
description: A view of the day in sports, including the sailing world championships in Perth, Australia, and the Arab Games in Doha, Qatar.

title: A Bright Spot Emerges in Postwar Colombo, Sri Lanka
description: This gentrifying district is seeing new boutique hotels and restaurants.

title: You and Your Man Shed
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Passat, Focus and Elantra Are Finalists for North American Car of the Year Award
description: The finalists for the 2012 North American Car and Truck of the Year awards were announced Thursday in Detroit, and like last year, there are plenty of hairs to split and quibbles to lodge.

title: Taking a Step Forward
description: WE should sign up for dance classes at the high school, I said to my husband.

title: Watch Out for Drones, A.C.L.U. Warns
description: The American Civil Liberties Union on Thursday warned of the prospect of routine aerial surveillance of American life and called for new regulations to govern the use of unmanned aerial systems, or drones, over American skies.

title: Theater Talkback: The Year in Miscellany
description: The approach of a new year brings reflections on the old. For writers about culture, this is a fancy way of saying its time to compile a list of the finest achievements of the year in the field you cover, preferably keeping the number to an easily digestible 10.

title: New Deal Divides Amanpours Time, and Her Audience
description: Christiane Amanpours new dual anchor jobs, with ABC and CNN, seem to come with an unusual condition: territorial exclusivity.

title: Producers Promise Revamped Flashdance Musical Is Ready for Broadway
description: Flashdance, the 1983 film that made a fashion statement out of oversized sweatshirts and leg warmers, is the latest movie undergoing a Broadway makeover. A group of veteran theater producers plans to bring a musical version of Flashdance to New York next fall, following an overhaul of the shows script and score after a critically drubbed production in London in 2010.

title: DiPietro on Injured Reserve  Again
description: The Islanders placed goalie Rick DiPietro on injured reserve with a groin injury Thursday, the second time this season and the umpteenth time in his star-crossed career that DiPietro has sustained a major injury. DiPietro is only a bit more than one-third of the way through the 15-year, $67.5 million contract he signed with the Isles in 2006, yet the list of injuries he has sustained since the signing is long and harrowing. That list appears below, along with the number of games DiPietro played in each of those seasons:

title: Citing Legal Error, S.E.C. Says It Will Appeal Rejection of Citigroup Settlement
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that it would appeal a federal court decision that harshly rejected a settlement between the commission and Citigroup over securities fraud charges related to the financial crisis.

title: Posters of Studio Ghibli
description: A look at the Japanese-language posters for the films in the Studio Ghibli retrospective.

title: Trying to Decide if The Help Is Drama or Comedy
description: Tate Taylor, the director of The Help, is currently holed up in the woods of Marthas Vineyard, in a house with no cell service, where he is working on an adaptation of the inspirational novel Peace Like a River for DreamWorks and Brad Pitts Plan B Productions.

title: Radish Carving, Anyone?
description: From England to Mexico to Jerusalem, surprising holiday customs around the world.

title: Still a Good Neighbor, State Farm Updates Its Logo
description: One of the most familiar brand logos, unchanged since 1953, is getting a new look in the new year.

title: Mammals, Coffee and Mountains
description: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

title: Holland Cotters Best of 2011
description: A look at some of the art world highlights of the year.

title: Parental Quandaries: Drinking (or Not) in the Basement, Resolved
description: The parenting quandary brought up last Friday: When Meredith, a high school junior, tells her mother, Sylvia, about rumors that two boys were drinking at a small club gathering in her basement, should the mother tell the boys parents, even though she knows there was no alcohol accessible and she saw nothing?

title: Roberta Smiths Best of 2011
description: A look at some of the art world highlights of the year.

title: Bus May Have Been a Getaway Vehicle, the Police Say
description: The authorities are investigating whether an armed robber used a public bus bound for New Jersey as his getaway vehicle after pulling a heist in Upper Manhattan on Thursday, the police said.

title: No Water Under This Bridge
description: JERUSALEM  In most well-managed cities, when a bridge is said to be putting the public at risk, it is closed without controversy until it can be made safe again. Not so in Jerusalem. In most well-managed holy sites, worshipers place a high priority on their safety and wont stand for shoddy infrastructure. Not so in Jerusalem.

title: Watch Out, America: Russell Brand is Coming to FX
description: Having risen and fallen and risen again a few times already on the British airwaves, Russell Brand now finds himself in ascendance on American television, where hell host a series of late-night specials for the FX cable network next year, FX announced on Thursday.

title: Six Christmas Traditions From Around the World
description: Christmas trees, Santa Claus and gingerbread lattes are all well and good. But with the homogenizing creep of Yuletide customs, travelers might well worry theyll go to the trouble of getting somewhere new over the holidays only to find its just like everywhere else. Not the six places here. Each has its own way of celebrating Christmas, and with the festivities unfolding in plazas, parks and other public places, travelers are free to join right in.

title: Christmas in Catalonia
description: In Barcelona there are no candy canes or Santas but, instead, a Royal Mailman and wise men on a ship.

title: Video Shows Ukrainian Opposition Leader in Prison
description: A video of the jailed Ukrainian opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko lying in a prison bed has drawn fire from her lawyer after it was shown on national television and posted on the Internet.

title: A Catalan Christmas
description: IT was the Christmas season in Barcelona, but inside the city hall, a 14th-century palace, a scene from the Arabian Nights was playing out. Palm trees and satin cushions had turned the Gothic patio into a desert tent, complete with incense and Middle Eastern music. Pages, clad in pantaloons and velvet-trimmed turbans, led each child to the Moorish throne of the Royal Mailman and the bulging satchel he would use to convey their petitions to the Three Kings. Yes, those Three Kings: the magi in the manger with the frankincense and myrrh. Here in the Mediterranean, the North Pole and the jolly guy in the fur-trimmed suit dont make much cultural sense. And you have to admit that theres a certain biblical logic to having the Kings rather than Santa bear gifts.

title: Thatcher vs. Nobbs, Round 2: Dueling Premieres
description: Are you following the battle of the blondes royale between Albert Nobbs and The Iron Lady? There was a moment when Lady Ironsides had pulled out ahead, on account of a glamorous Vogue cover, but the Bagger will have to give the latest edge to Nobbsy. Both vehicles  the Meryl Streep film in which she plays Margaret Thatcher, and the Glenn Close passion project in which she plays a male butler in Victorian Dublin  had screenings and glitzy afterparties on Tuesday night. As promised, the Bagger showed at both events. But it was the Albert Nobbs affair we returned to, and not just because Lou Reed and Patti Smith were there to watch Sinead OConnor perform barefoot. More on that later, promise!

title: Chase Adopts Simplified Checking Disclosure
description: Chase has become the first big bank to voluntarily adopt a simplified, plain-language checking account disclosure, as proposed by an arm of the nonprofit group Pew Charitable Trusts.

title: On Our Radar:  Superfund Cleanups in N.Y.
description: A court rules that New York State can require companies to return state-designated Superfund sites to the condition in which they existed before they were used for industrial purposes  not simply remove the pollution that poses risks. [Associated Press]

title: Airlines Cut, Hotels Step Up
description: To the Editor: Re Airlines Cut Back, Hotels Step In (Practical Traveler, Dec. 4), these days it doesnt seem that hotels would have to do too much or get too creative to provide better service than airlines.

title: Peace While Traveling? Not Impossible.
description: AS founder and guiding teacher of the Community Meditation Center in New York, Allan Lokos has an arsenal of tools for coping with stressful situations. When it comes to travel, he said, acceptance and awareness are key. Accept that you cant make the plane take off, he advised; and when dealing with other travelers, give yourself time to be gracious.

title: Surfing in Greece? The Waters Fine
description: BOLTS of lightning flashed in cobweb patterns overhead, the gray and storming sea sending wave after wave that crashed on the beach behind us. We paddled our borrowed surfboards furiously southward to avoid the whitewash, then, one by one, turned into the arching faces and rode them to shore.

title: Iraq: End of an Era
description: The United States declares the end of the nine-year war in Iraq, but questions remain over the country's future and stability.

title: Commonwealth, San Francisco
description: Casual sophistication and social consciousness connect at this progressive fine-dining restaurant in San Franciscos Mission district  but not in the way you might expect.

title: 24/7 Episode 1: A Victory Dance for HBO
description: After the inaugural installment of HBOs 24/7: Road to the N.H.L. Winter Classic chronicled the on- and off-ice pursuits of the Penguins and the Capitals with great fanfare, Part 2 with the Rangers and the Flyers did not disappoint.

title: The Giving Spree | Rufus and Martha Wainwright
description: Who: The brother-and-sister singer-songwriters Rufus and Martha Wainwright, who play tonight at the Town Hall in New York City.

title: In Cambodia, a Pocket of the Past
description: In Battambang, the countrys second-largest city, historic structures and artists mingle.

title: A Pocket of the Past in Battambang, Cambodia
description: UNDER an electric blue sky, with the morning sun already beating down, Som Sangva Sak stood on a narrow, two-lane bridge over the Sangker River and surveyed his hometown, Battambang, in northwestern Cambodia.

title: Movie Listings for Dec. 16-22
description: Movies

title: Its Kosher in Romes Ghetto
description: THE classics of Roman Jewish cuisine were born from poverty and persecution. For nearly 300 years, the citys Jews were confined by the pope to a narrow strip of flood-prone land called the Ghetto. Cheap, portable and deep-fried street foods were a solution to meager means and cramped housing.

description: Pop

description: THE UPSHOT

description: Photographs from Iraq, Bahrain, India and Russia.

title: There Was a War? And It Ended?
description: Aug. 14, 1945  V-J Day  marked the surrender of Japan to end World War II, and crowds flooded into Times Square to celebrate. Ticker tape flew from windows and service members in uniform ran around kissing women, for the sheer joy of it and for the cameras.

title: Inflation Predictions
description: Peter Schiff on Glenn Beck, Dec. 28, 2009:

title: Sculpture as Portrait at the Metropolitan
description: A surprising number of sculptures are included in Masterpieces of Renaissance Portraiture, which opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday. But rather than display them against gallery walls the curators will show many of them free-standing and in the round. Thats because Keith Christiansen, chairman of European paintings at the Met, who has organized the exhibition with Stefan Weppelmann, curator of Italian and Spanish paintings at the Gemldegalerie in Berlin, wants visitors to be able to examine some of these three-dimensional works from every angle.

title: A Portraitist Considered the Titian of Louisiana
description: A narrowly focused exhibition has been traveling along the East Coast for the last year, containing all the known and attributed works by the New Orleans painter Julien Hudson. A total of eight, dating from the 1830s, have been found.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Bahrain, India and France.

title: Saluting Niedermayer, on Eve of Devils Tribute
description: On the eve of the retirement of Scott Niedermayers No. 27 by the Devils, Slap Shot spoke with a teammate, opposing executive and television analyst about the defensemans artistry and competitiveness.

title: Bill Kellers Graphic Account From Pakistan
description: For Bill Kellers article on Pakistan, our goal was to illustrate several key events from the last year in the U.S.-Pakistani relations that ratcheted up tension between the two countries. Commissioning these illustrations was challenging because detailed accounts of the events were hard to find and often contradictory. For the purposes of our illustration, even the smallest details needed to be correct.

title: Wynton Marsalis to Join CBS
description: Wynton Marsalis, the virtuoso jazz trumpet player and longtime artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, is adding another job to his resume: television commentator.

title: For ATS Sedan, Cadillac Wrings Big Boost From Small Engine
description: On Wednesday, Cadillac introduced a 2-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder engine for its 2013 ATS compact luxury sedan, which is scheduled to have its debut at the Detroit auto show in January. A 2.5-liter 4-cylinder and 3.6-liter 6-cylinder will also be offered.

title: Way Off Baseline
description: Oh, my. Jonathan Chait  who reads National Review so that the rest of us dont have to  finds a former Bush budget aide claiming that Obama must be responsible for the deficit, because back in 2008 the CBO projected a surplus.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Double Play Toys
description: A retail toy business in Borough Park, Brooklyn, was founded in the kitchen of a local mother.

title: A Store Where Toys Must Be Kosher
description: IN this toy store, Batman and Spider-Man are not heroes.

title: Hungarian Bill Could Take Power From Central Bank
description: BUDAPEST  The government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban has proposed legislation that could challenge the independence of Hungarys central bank, its chief said Thursday, part of what the bills critics say is a sweeping drive to consolidate power that has undermined many of the countrys institutions.

title: Guy Ritchie Discusses a Scene From Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows
description: In Guy Ritchies latest installment of the Sherlock Holmes franchise, Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows, the director uses some of his signature techniques, while also trying out a few new technical toys to tell an action-filled tale starring the famed sleuth.

title: Have You Heard the Bad News?
description: In a funk after my morning posts on the National Defense Authorization Act, I scanned the Internet looking for a pick-me-up, but just found more reasons to feel bad.

title: Janet Robinson, Chief Executive of Times Co., to Step Down

title: Trusting Someone Over 60
description: SO, yes, there are still millions of stories in the naked city. Stories of the young, the old, the rich, the destitute, the gorgeous, the vile. Stories that crack your heart open, stretch your mind, exhaust your patience, chill you, warm you, annoy you, even bore you.

description: Dance

description: OTTAWA  Research in Motion said on Thursday that a new line of BlackBerry smartphones that it hoped would turn around its flagging fortunes will not come to market until late next year.
