title: Group Clears Path for a Third-Party Ticket
description: To those who bemoan the lack of better choices in presidential elections, third-party fantasies come easily at this stage in a campaign. End hyper-partisanship and Washington dysfunction: Vote Bloomberg-Petraeus in 2012!

title: Beyond Eeny Meeny Miny Moe: Sorting Out the G.O.P. Field
description: I woke up this morning feeling grateful not to be an Iowa Republican. If I were, Id feel obligated to participate in the caucuses on Jan. 3, a truly depressing prospect. The contenders for the G.O.P. nomination  seven of them now that Herman Cain self-immolated  have given speeches, schmoozed diners at diners, and run TV ads. Theyve also participated in thousands of debates, which like last nights season finale have amply demonstrated that no one on stage with a remote chance of winning is remotely suited to leading this country.

title: May the Best Dog Actor Win
description: The staff of The Hollywood Reporter continues with its hard-hitting, link-baiting coverage of this years animal stars.

title: Bonnie & Clyde Will Close on Dec. 30
description: Bonnie & Clyde, the composer Frank Wildhorns latest bid for Broadway success after several flops, wont end his unlucky streak. Producers announced on Friday that the show, starring Jeremy Jordan and Laura Osnes, will close on Dec. 30.

title: At a Meeting Spot for Occupiers, Signs Prohibit Signs
description: Updated, 1:45 p.m. | Soon after the Occupy Wall Street protesters built an encampment in the financial district in mid-September, organizers looking for a less conspicuous place to gather began holding certain meetings inside a public atrium at 60 Wall Street.

title: Standouts in a Solo Setting
description: IT seems that a recital should be a breeze for a singer. Unlike in opera, there are no ill-fitting costumes; there is no awkward directorial concept to pull off. Its just you, a piano and the music.

title: Administration Proposes Wage Protections for Home Care Workers
description: The Times reports on Friday that the Obama administration has proposed regulations that would provide the nations two million home care workers with minimum wage and overtime protections. Those workers have long been exempted from coverage.

title: Cunning Vixens, A Dark Concert And Much Glass
description: BEST of lists are approximate endeavors. I was sorry I couldnt attend the Mostly Mozart Festivals Don Giovanni, one of many tantalizing events I missed. But the following proved highlights of my year.

title: U.S. Transfers Its Last Prisoner in Iraq to Iraqi Custody
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration turned over the last remaining prisoner in American custody in Iraq to the Iraqi government on Friday, a move expected to unleash a political backlash inside the United States even as the American military draws closer to completing its exit.

title: TimesCast | December 16, 2011
description: The Army private accused of aiding WikiLeaks appears in military court; the literary legacy of Christopher Hitchens; and Nate Silver on the Iowa race.

title: In a Sign of Labor Recovery, More Workers Are Quitting
description: THE number of Americans quitting their jobs has begun to rise, albeit from a very low level. That is a tentative sign that labor market mobility, which plunged during the 2007-9 recession, has started to recover.

title: Impatient Protesters Convulse Syria as Russia Offers New Resolution
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Frustrated by the Syrian governments intransigence and the Arab Leagues delays in penalizing President Bashar al-Assad, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in Syria took to the streets on Friday over the violent repression of their nine-month-old uprising.

title: On Our Radar: Billions Needed for Texas Water Projects
description: A Texas agency reports that the state should spend $53 billion to cope with its water needs over the next half-century, building infrastructure like new reservoirs, dams and wells, but warns that droughts may prevent the state from keeping up with demand. It is also unclear how the state would come up with the money. [The Associated Press]

title: The life and inventions of Hedy Lamarr and a sequel to Pride and Prejudice
description: This week, composer John Adams on Richard Rhodess book, Hedys Folly, about the life and inventions of Hedy Lamarr; Liesl Schillinger discusses Death Comes to Pemberley, P.D. Jamess sequel to Pride and Prejudice; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: The Happy Hitchens: Quotations from The Life-Lover, Too
description: That Christopher Hitchens could be ferocious there is no doubt. His friend Martin Amis called him, accurately enough, one of the most terrifying rhetoricians the world has yet seen. So it makes sense that many of the encomiums to Hitchens today in newspapers and across the Web reprint many of his most indelible put-downs.

title: Land of Good Bones and Deep Pockets
description: A NEIGHBORHOOD of mansions and bakeries, museums and florists, Carnegie Hill is at once grand and intimate. As pleasantly walkable as any community in New York, its streets offer up vignettes that at times seem almost choreographed. Men sell Christmas trees from the gently sloping porte-cochre of the Convent of the Sacred Heart on East 91st Street. A high-stepping girls track team giggles through agility drills near the Engineers Gate to Central Park. Jacketed St. Davids boys and plaid-uniformed Spence girls grapple with planetoid-size burgers at Jackson Hole, as much an institution in these parts as any of the museums housed in Fifth Avenue palaces.

title: Panetta Nudges Turkey to Rebuild Ties With Israel
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta on Friday called for Turkey to rebuild ties with Israel in the interest of security, echoing a call he issued this month for the government of Israel to reach out to other nations across the Middle East.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 15s Toughest Picks
description: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Opera Flourishing At the Extremes
description: SOME organizations that travel the classical music mainstream have undertaken innovations this year. Take, for example, the demand for fresh programming that made the Spring for Music festival of visiting orchestras at Carnegie Hall such a success. But for me the most memorable performances were by groups that specialize in the repertorys extremes, early and new music. And thoughtful, often provocative opera productions figured prominently at both ends.

title: A Unit, Near Last, in the Military Withdrawal From Iraq
description: The Iraq Wars small, subdued closing ceremony certainly gave the impression that there were few Americans left in the country. It was a final coda to a quietly withdrawing column of units leaving Iraq after more than eight years of war. Andrea Bruce, a photographer working for The New York Times, documented one of the last units in the exodus on the long road home:

title: Parental Quandary: When a Friends Child Hits Yours
description: When families with children nearly exactly the same age come together, it can feel golden  as if the gods of friendship were shining on you. Youll raise your kids together, play together, take trips together and watch them become lifelong companions as you yourselves stay close. For Isabel, though, it isnt working out that way.

title: In His Own Words
description: A selection of Op-Ed articles and letters written by Christopher Hitchens.

title: Cheap, and Likely to Remain So
description: THOUGH millions of Vegas, Pintos and Gremlins were made during their production runs of nearly a decade, most are gone now, long since sent to the shredder.

title: China Revokes Probation of Missing Human Rights Lawyer
description: BEIJING  Chinas official news agency reported on Friday that Gao Zhisheng, a prominent human rights lawyer who has been missing for more than 20 months, will serve the next three years in prison because he repeatedly violated his probation.

title: On Assignment in Bagan, Myanmar
description: In March, Justin Mott photographed the temples and pagodas in and around Bagan, Myanmar, just as tourists began to visit.

title: Marcus Bachmann Outlines First Spouse Agenda
description: LE MARS, Iowa  Laura Bush, a former librarian, dedicated herself as first lady to improving reading. Michelle Obama wants to help children become healthier.

title: Dec. 18  24
description: Television

title: A Boggle of BlackBerrys
description: OTTAWA  Research in Motions chief executives, Mike Lazaridis and Jim Balsillie, frightened its investors Thursday when they said the company would not have new BlackBerry phones until late in 2012. Until then, they said, RIM would heavily promote the existing lineup.

title: Just One Look | Proenza Schouler
description: High-fashion tech-sportswear, similar to whats been so popular this prefall season, is what Proenza Schoulers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez do best. Their version features taffeta workout separates like this top, shown under a silk nylon blended bungee skirt and tweed coat. Sleeping-bag-like quilted skirts and dresses, 70s mountain boy tees and an aerial terrain view print were all inspired by the designers recent trip to the Himalayas. The faithful need not fret: PS 1 bags (in every shade of soil and sand) were aplenty, because lets be real, life cant be all hikes and bikes.

title: Angelina Jolie Gets Some Good News at the Dentists Office
description: The Golden Globe nominations on Thursday drew varied reactions from nominees and non-nominees alike. Then there was the power couple Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, who both snagged nominations. Mr. Pitt is up for best actor for Moneyball, while Ms. Jolies directing debut, In the Land of Blood and Honey, about the Bosnian war, is competing in the foreign-language category. Even without the controversies surrounding it, Ms. Jolie knows the film is a hard sell.

title: Republican Candidates Mum on Iraq
description: The end of the Iraq war has been marked with speeches and ceremonies in Washington, Baghdad, Fort Bragg, N.C., and elsewhere. But it has gone almost completely unremarked on the Republican campaign trail.

title: Beach Boys Announce Reunion Tour, Complete With Brian Wilson
description: Fifty years after they first played together, the Beach Boys announced Friday that they would release a new studio album and go on a 50-date tour in 2012, beginning with a reunion concert at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage festival in April.

title: What Are the Best Dogs for City Living?
description: For New York City residents, apartments can be small and green spaces can be few and far in between. So why would so many want to crowd a dog (or two) into their 600-square-foot studios? Elissa Gootmans article, appearing in this Sundays Real Estate section, explores the question. She writes:

title: RIMs Year of Misery
description: For Research in Motion, 2011 was a devastating year. Once a leader in the smartphone business, the company, which makes the BlackBerry, saw its market share shrivel. Then there was an embarrassing service failure and the botched introduction of a tablet.

title: Dasha Libin and Dan Anderson
description: SOME couples fight for fun. Others do it out of frustration. For Dasha Libin, a Soviet migr, and Dan Anderson, who hails from Arkansas, fighting is a passion.

title: Bears Decision-Making Questioned in Light of Hurds Arrest
description: 3:42 p.m. | Updated The Bears have announced they have waived Sam Hurd.

title: A Father From the Falklands Caught in an International Dispute
description: BUENOS AIRES

title: Testing the Waters With a Smaller Vessel
description: FOR a brand that ceased to be bold long ago, Buick is making a rather audacious request with its newest car, the 2012 Verano: would you please consider it the equal of small cars from prestigious brands like Audi and Volvo?

title: 2012 Buick Verano
description: With the Buick Verano, General Motors is betting that Americans will pay premium prices for an upscale compact.

title: Import Fighters? No, Just Punchlines
description: ADDRESSING a group of 450 civic leaders at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan on Oct. 3, 1968, the chairman of General Motors, James M. Roche, did something almost sacrilegious for an auto executive: he talked about a future product.

title: Americas Least Wanted
description: The import fighters that American automakers produced in the 1970s not only lost the battle, but helped lose the war. Heres a rogues gallery of Vegas, Gremlins and Pintos.

title: Middle Class, With Few Pre-K Options
The Dismal Education
description: THE stereotypes about economists are well known: that were selfish Grinches; that we dont read human interest stories because they dont interest us; that the only reason we dont sell our children is that we think theyll be worth more later.

title: At Least 10 Die as Police Clash With Strikers in Kazakhstan
description: MOSCOW  What appeared to be an attempt by local authorities to oust striking oil workers from a square in the former Soviet state of Kazakhstan went horribly wrong on Friday, ending in at least 10 deaths in clashes with the police.

title: Aspirations in Colorado to Be a New Motor City
description: Fort Collins, Colo.

title: What Nonprofit Groups Know About You
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I look at the common but not well-known science of prospect research. Hospitals, colleges and charitable enterprises of all sorts who want you to give them money have plenty of data available about your net worth, home and any fancy cars or boats and such.

title: Caviar Migrates Beyond the Caspian Region
description: RIOFRO, Spain  Caviar might be perceived as one of the worlds most exclusive products, but its production is expanding far and fast.

title: Bonds Avoids Prison Time for Giving Evasive Testimony
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Barry Bonds, baseballs home run champion, avoided a prison term Friday when a federal judge sentenced him to 30 days of house arrest, 2 years of probation, 250 hours of community service with youth groups and a $4,000 fine for providing evasive testimony to a federal grand jury eight years ago.

title: Taking Fund-Raising To a New Level
description: All of the nonprofit groups whose solicitations fill up your mailbox at this time of year badly want you to like them.

title: With Olympics in View, Bopanna and Qureshi Dissolve Doubles Team
description: With the 2012 London Olympics now less than a year away, Indian doubles specialist Rohan Bopanna has replaced playing for peace with playing for gold.

title: Still Governor, Perry Collects Retirement Pay
description: 3:15 p.m. | Updated  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been beating the drum about cutting the pay of Congress in half  or by 75 percent under one plan  a proposal that has become a cornerstone of his presidential campaign platform.

title: Cornells Bid for City Campus Gains and Stanford Bows Out
description: Click to read the updated version of this article that appears in the newspaper.

title: Despite Delay, the 100-Watt Bulb Is on Its Way Out
description: The law to phase out traditional incandescent light bulbs was promoted as a simple, almost painless, change when Congress first passed it. By requiring that light bulbs use at least 25 percent less electricity, starting in 2012, the nation would use less energy, manufacturers would invent more efficient types of bulbs and the planet would be spared millions of tons of carbon emissions every year.

title: Canadas Approach to Inconvenient Art
description: Franke James is a Canadian artist with deep concerns about her countrys outsize contribution to resource waste and the building accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Check her scrolling artwork titled Fat Cat Canadas Giant Litter Box for an example.

title: Invasion of the Head Snatchers
description: IT wasnt the first time the fashion industry was slammed for extreme Photoshopping. But an entirely fake body?

title: Soups on for the Holidays
description: To keep you warm this winter, Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, suggests blending up creamy homemade soup:

title: Stir It Up | Miss Lilys Variety Show
description: Miss Lilys, the raucous Houston Street hot spot for hush puppies and jerk chicken, has put authentic Caribbean food in fashions favor in recent months. Now the restaurant is opening a carefully edited record shop and radio station with a juice bar next door named Variety. Serge Becker, who designed the space to serve the citys community of artists, designers, writers and musicians inspired by Caribbean culture, sees it as a place to talk Jamaica and enjoy a juice and patty. Expect to catch underground notables like Brazils hottest rapper, Criolo, or the Chinese-Jamaican music producer Clive Chin taking to the turntables or perusing the shops selection of rare vinyl, apparel and limited-edition art. Miss Lilys fine-looking staff (pictured here in the juice bar wearing the resort collections most optimistic prints and colors) only help to make the hangout rock steady. The Moment caught up with the girls to find out how to get their look (that hair!) and whats in their makeup bag. Go to slide show >>

title: Empathy Gifts to Friends in Need
description: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about all the solicitations for money at this time of the year. But adding a level of complication this year is that so many of us know someone who is unemployed or underemployed. And do you have any responsibility to them?

title: TimesCast | Iowa Caucus Projections
description: With the Iowa caucuses just weeks away, the Five Thirty Eight blogger Nate Silver digs into the poll numbers.

title: Stores Pop Up to Make a Big Impression, if Not Big Sales
description: As the effort to encourage Americans to buy more stuff before Christmas enters the home stretch, a popular tactic in the marketing tool kit is gaining favor: the pop-up retail store.

title: Real-Life Rudy Charged With Fraud
description: Daniel Ruettinger may have turned his tale as one of the sports worlds ultimate underdogs into a highly profitable motivational speaking career and the movie Rudy.

title: As Tension Rises in France, Harsh Talk With Britain
description: PARIS  To the long list of victims emerging from Europes financial crisis, make room for a new one: the Entente Cordiale between Britain and France.

title: Only 9 Nations Will Be Needed To Ratify Europes Fiscal Treaty
description: BRUSSELS  A new treaty to impose tighter discipline among the 17 nations in the European Union that use the euro will come into force once nine countries approve it, according to a draft released Friday. That potentially reduces the threat that disapproval by one nation could scuttle the pact.

title: What About the Boys?
description: Beyond calling for Joe Paternos dismissal at the start of the Penn State horror show, I have not commented on the unfolding story, which has tainted the entire Penn State football program and the college itself. The emerging details have almost defied comment.

title: TimesCast | Christopher Hitchens
description: December 16, 2011 - The New York Times Book Review editor, Sam Tanenhaus, reflects on the literary legacy of Christopher Hitchens.

title: With Paul and Griffin, Clippers Are a Hot Ticket
description: Basketball, more than any other team sport, is a game dominated by superstars. For every ball-passing, defensive-minded team like the 1970 Knicks or the 1977 Trail Blazers, there are two or three times as many teams that have won championships on the backs of one or two stars. The Bulls teams of the 1990s, of course, spring to mind.

title: TimesCast | Bradley Manning In Court
description: At Fort Meade, the first hearing begins for Private Bradley Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking military documents, cables and videos to WikiLeaks.

title: Wheelies: The Blame-Game Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Meet the  Comedy Duo Theron & Oswalt
description: The Bagger would like to conclude our weeklong spotlight on the cast and filmmakers of Young Adult by sharing a few moments with its director and stars, Patton Oswalt and Charlize Theron.

title: Late Show Photo Exhibition
description: A writer for David Lettermans show exhibits his photos of celebrities and a wad of gum.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, West Bank, China and Ukraine.

title: Tying a Roast
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to stuff and tie a roast for the holiday table.

title: S.E.C. Fraud Case Casts Dark Cloud Over Fortress
description: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

title: The Giving Spree | Maria Cornejo
description: Who: The designer Maria Cornejo

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom midcentury in Irvington, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Redding, Conn.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Hotel des Artistes duplex, a Prospect Heights co-op and a NoHo co-op

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, West Bank, China and Ukraine.

title: Another View: MF Globals Corporate Governance Lesson
description: Michael W. Peregrine, a partner at the law firm McDermott Will & Emery, advises corporations, officers and directors on issues related to corporate governance, fiduciary duties and internal investigations.

title: Close to Fetching Coal and Making Pizza
description: The coal oven for the new location of Grimaldis Pizzeria in Brooklyn has been approved by the Buildings Department, Jennifer Gilbert, a department spokeswoman, said Friday, allowing the famous pizza shop to finally plan the grand opening.

title: Bronx School Wins $50,000 in Music Contest
Just One Look | Boy by Band of Outsiders
description: This morning, Boy by Band of Outsiders showed a preppy-pretty prefall collection at the labels Broome Street studio. There, collegiate plaids and sweet foulards on tie-neck blouses were tucked into pencil skirts and under tailored blazers and, in one instance, paired with a very Ivy League-looking velvet green suit. Here, a romantic red check peplum blouse and skirt thats fit for eating clubs, social clubs and dance clubs alike.

title: A Tenderloin Thats Well Worth the Tending
description: ROASTING a whole beef tenderloin can seem like the kind of thing that only a very accomplished  or mildly delusional  cook would undertake as the centerpiece to a holiday meal. Not only is it one of the priciest cuts, but its also one of the least forgiving.

title: Buying and Tying a Tenderloin
description: When youre spending this kind of money on a hunk of meat, it really makes sense to find a butcher you can trust, or at least strike up conversation with the meat carvers in the back of your supermarket. You want to make sure the fillet you are buying is well trimmed of any silverskin, which is a thin layer of white connective tissue that is as unpleasant as gristle to chew (and all gristle should be expunged as well). Then have your butcher tie up the roast so its easier to handle and will cook more evenly. Failing that, you can watch my latest video, above, on how to tie up a roast. Its not hard but does take more time than, say, having someone else do it for you.

title: Sand Toys
description: Glamis Dunes, Calif., is considered the sand toy capital of the world. Photographer Peter Bohler spent Thanksgiving weekend there with thousands of dune riders.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Brooklyn Night Bazaar returns with more than 100 vendors and other merchants in a 40,000-square-foot warehouse space at 149 Kent Avenue (North Fifth Street) in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, from 5 p.m. to midnight Friday and Saturday. Music and drinks from local breweries and wineries will be featured. There is no entrance fee to the market space, but tickets are $10 to $20 for certain musical performances.

title: Latest Challenge for Knicks: Their Bench
description: The Knicks upgraded their starting lineup this off-season by swapping out Chauncey Billups for Tyson Chandler  but this has made their bench less reliable. Last year Toney Douglas, Shawne Williams, Bill Walker, and Jared Jeffries were a productive group of reserves for New York. This year Douglas moves into the starting rotation, and Williams moves across the river to wear a New Jersey Nets uniform.

title: Big Dogs Are Set: Winn-Dixie Musical Casts Its Canine Star and His Trainer
description: William Berloni, the animal trainer who won a special Tony in June but has had trouble finding Broadway work because of the expense of using live animals, is aiming to return in a big way.

title: Helping America Build a Better Negroni
description: This week I received a letter  yes, an actual letter, which appeared to have been composed on an actual typewriter  from a gentleman in Pennsylvania named Gene Horn. Mr. Horn had a question about the Negroni, for which, conveniently, Robert Simonson offered a recipe in a recent Diners Journal post about holiday cocktails.

title: Under Attack by Soldiers, Egyptian Protesters Report From Inside the Fray
description: Updated | 7:55 p.m. As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, at least two people were killed and more than 200 were injured on Friday as military police beat up demonstrators challenging military rule and angry protesters hurled improvised explosives at the empty Parliament building.

title: In Obama Speech on Israel, Little Mention of Palestinians
description: Less than a year before the presidential election, a pattern is emerging. The Republicans will outdo themselves to say the most provocative things they can to demonstrate they love Israel more than anyone else. And President Obama will counter by saying as little as he can about the Palestinians.

title: In Debt Crisis, Gulf Is Yawning Between Italy and Its Politicians
description: ROME  With its elegant marble floors, ornately carved wooden ceiling and flattering lighting, the central meeting point of Italys Lower House is arguably one of the most beautiful political arenas in the world.

title: WaMu, the Cost of Law school Accreditation and a Different Economy
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Gretchen Morgenson on WaMu, David Gillen and David Segal on the cost of law school accreditation, and Christina Romer on making this time different for the economy.

title: Artifacts | Robert Heineckens Copywork
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Do Working Mothers Really Prefer Part-Time Jobs?
description: The National Marriage Project released an optimistic report this week on marital satisfaction and parenthood. Because When Baby Makes Three was edited by the director of the project, which aims to promote marriage by identifying strategies to increase marital quality and stability, and by the Director of the Center for Marriage and Families at the Institute for American Values, which seeks to increase the proportion of children growing up with their two married parents, this is not a report that focuses on numbers showing that marital happiness decreases among parents. Its a report that looks at why thats not true for a substantial minority of husbands and wives.

title: What Romney Knew About Medicaid
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  As Mitt Romney finished up an early morning town-hall-style meeting in Iowa, finishing up an answer on entitlement programs like Medicare and Medicaid, he offered a casual confession: I have to admit, I didnt know all the differences between these things before I got into government, and then got into it and understood that Medicaid is the health care program for the poor, by and large.

title: Millennium Hotel Loses Racial Harassment Suit
description: On its Web site, the Millennium Broadway Hotel says everyone receives star treatment. But one longtime employee said he was treated just the opposite, claiming that he was the victim of a long campaign of racial harassment that the hotel did nothing to stop.

title: Flags for Civilians
description: A bit of legislation recently landed on President Obamas desk that passed both the House and the Senate without any dissenting votes whatsoever: The Civil Service Recognition Act.

title: Youthful Energy, Onstage and Outside
description: In New Dances: Edition 2011, Juilliard Dance students appear in order of class: the youngest, 2015, to the oldest, 2012. Were it not for that arrangement, it would have been tricky to tell who was the more advanced when their program opened on Thursday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater. The dancers were all of a high caliber, and the works, all premieres by four guest choreographers, didnt necessarily display ascending skill.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 16
description: Subjects include the return of a Christmas tradition, the killing of a police officer and the death of a woman in an elevator accident.

title: Fishmongers Stew
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Stew, Fresh From the Fisherman
description: A JOLLY fishmonger is an inspiration. Alex Villani, well known to Greenmarket shoppers in Manhattan and Brooklyn, is just that: smiling, laughing, joking and incredibly hard-working.

title: Key to a Great Stew: a Great Fisherman
description: It doesnt take much in the way of ingredients to make a good fish stew, but it does need good fresh fish. Enter local fishmonger Alex Villani of Blue Moon Fish. Well known in Manhattan and Brooklyn Greenmarkets, his fish and shellfish have a loyal following. In an admirably energetic and unusual arrangement, the man catches the fish out by Mattituck on Long Island, drives it to market, and, with the help of his wife, Stephanie, sells it at his stall, all the while smiling about it.

title: On Looting, UK Feminista and Where Feminism Went Wrong
description: Jenny Turner in The London Review of Books: Here, in a nutshell, is the problem with feminism. Young women of good character losing their heads and wishing they hadnt. You feel so sorry for them, but cant you sense what they tasted in the air as they were doing it: freedom, fury, the power  for once  of being young and strong and agile and a homegirl, the flat-out joy of getting your hands on some free stuff.Read on.

title: Congress to Examine S.E.C. Settlement Policy
description: 8:27 p.m. | Updated

title: In the Tradition of a Matriarch, This Family Keeps Crooning and Caroling
description: A Not So Silent Night, the concert at Town Hall on Thursday, was a typical Christmastime family gathering: motley, convivial, multigenerational, jokey, affectionate, conscious of passing years and tinged with both skepticism and faith. There wasnt any bickering, though. The family onstage happens to be packed with singers and songwriters  troupers all  and this year the next generation was resuming a tradition.

title: Fewer Students Repeat a Grade This Year
Military Police Clash With Protesters in Cairo
description: The center of Egypts capital erupted in violence again on Friday as military police beat up demonstrators challenging military rule.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 18
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: For Richard Dawkins, Traditional Christmas Carols Trump Atheism
description: Richard Dawkins may want to take God out of public life, but dont try to take the Christ out of his Christmas carols.

title: Surprising Histories, With Drinks
description: FROM Cairo to Manhattan to Moscow, its been a rabble-rousing year. Given the tumult, holiday readers may rush to wrap themselves in a few nostalgia-drenched books that offer refuge from the headlines.

title: Chaucer and Beowulf March (or Make That Dance) to a New Turntable Beat
description: In the arts, as in so many things, time elevates.

title: Revealing the Habits of Copyright Advocates
description: As Congress moves forward on two bills aimed at curbing online piracy, a Web site has given opponents a way to attack those lobbying for the measures by exposing their illegal downloads.

title: Bill Cunningham | Reds
description: SantaCon, the annual street happening in which nearly 5,000 costumed participants join in a day of good cheer, eating and drinking, was last Saturday.

title: Tough Women, Candid Candidates
description: BEST is the worst of categories, because there are so many different standards for television  Breaking Bad may offer the most searing performances, but plenty of seemingly high-minded people get a kick out of Hoarders or Chelsea Lately. There was a lot of good television in 2011, but it was also a year that stood out for deliciously bad entertainment as well.

title: Do Iowa Polls Predict New Hampshire Results?
description: Jonathan Bernstein asks a great question pursuant to the release of our state-by-state forecasts today. If we want to know what will happen in New Hampshire on Jan. 10, should we be looking at the Iowa polls as well as those from the Granite State?

title: Avoiding the Holidays? Take the Ferry
description: The Staten Island Ferrys terminals are bereft of holiday dcor this year. Commuters may grouse, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday that the citys Transportation Department did the right thing by skipping the Christmas trees, menorahs and holiday lights that had festooned the terminals in previous years.

title: Chic in Review | Lanvin, the Next Generation
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Jazz Has a Lot of Pieces, but Do They All Fit?
description: The Utah Jazz didnt exactly crash and burn following the departure of Deron Williams last season, but that in itself presents a bit of a problem. Rather than truly bottom out in their rebuilding efforts  or make a lateral move for a parallel star  the Jazz have nested in the leagues uncomfortable middle ground: Utah is bad enough to be an irrelevant element of the Western Conference playoff picture, but too good to expect a top draft pick.

title: For Real Sweat Equity
description: AS anyone in client services knows, schmoozing can take a physical toll. All those drinks, dinners and parties mean little time to hit the gym. So why not mix work with working out?

title: Some Early Applicants Will Wait a Little Longer
description: This is early decision notification week, and, on Thursday in particular, many a computer mouse hovered over the refresh button as students anticipated an admittance, deferral or denial.

title: The Last Republican Debate Before the Iowa Caucuses
description: The Last Republican Debate Before the Iowa Caucuses

title: Remember Me From Yesterday?
description: IS the high school reunion past its prime?

title: Book Review Podcast: A Brainy Beauty and World War II
description: In this Sundays Book Review, the composer John Adams reviews Richard Rhodess Hedys Folly, about the wartime inventions of the movie star Hedy Lamarr. Mr. Adams writes:

title: Its Her Final Show, but Behar Keeps Thinking About Tomorrow
description: Whats Joy Behar going to do in the afternoons now?

title: Toggling Between Life and a Dream
description: PEOPLE tell me all the time that I have a dream job.

title: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
description: Stores were packed with shoppers last weekend, Christmas trees lined the sidewalks awaiting homes and thousands of inebriated Santas staggered across Manhattan on an annual bar crawl.

title: Auction Shows Elizabeth Taylors Star Still Shines
description: The New York exhibition alone was seen by more than 25,000 visitors, who came to ogle the jewels and the ancillary items.

title: Once a Star, Always a Star
description: MINE! screamed the violet tags attached to towering piles of Louis Vuitton luggage on display at Christies, where the collection of jewelry and clothing acquired by Elizabeth Taylor over a storied and tempestuous life went up for auction last week, knocking down records right and left.

title: A John Lennon in the World of Comics
description: The talking heads who turn up in Method to the Madness of Jerry Lewis, a documentary having its premiere on Saturday on Encore, really, really want us to know that Mr. Lewis is a towering figure in comedy and worthy of the respect accorded to showbiz greats.

title: Drama, Fictional and Real, and Well-Earned Laughs
description: FROM the modest slice of the television pie that I found time to watch this past year here are 10 of my favorite shows, in alphabetical order. Not included: Friday Night Lights, the best show of 2010 and previous years. Six episodes in January and early February werent enough to qualify (and the NBC reruns dont count).

title: Lure of the Obscure: Shows Very Good or Very Bad
description: PERHAPS, as the end of the year approaches, you have an empty feeling inside. You have watched 14 hours of television a day, the government-recommended minimum, yet you feel as if youve missed something. You know who won all the reality competitions and how the various characters on Modern Family are related, but you havent been wowed or surprised or grossed out sufficiently to compensate for your investment of time, not to mention that flat screen you bought with your tax refund.

title: Belated Acclaim for an Artist With a Restless Sensibility
description: Greenport, N.Y.

title: A Look Back at Extended Unemployment Benefits
description: Tangled in the current Washington debate over extending the payroll tax is another thorny, but less prominent, policy issue: whether to also renew extended unemployment benefits.

title: Letters
description: Anchors and Motherhood

title: Stoppards Pirandello Lands A Bigger Stage for Its One-Night American Premiere
description: The American premiere of Tom Stoppards adaptation of Luigi Pirandellos Henry IV may be running for one night only, but now more people will be able to see it.

title: Sounding a Little Like Christmas
description: The Christmas repertory list for New York performing groups has long had Handels Messiah at the top and, for the more secular-minded, Bachs Brandenburg Concertos presented nearly as plentifully. The Orchestra of St. Lukes touched on this second tradition on Thursday evening, when 11 players opened its concert at Carnegie Hall with a zesty account of the Brandenburg Concerto No. 3.

title: A YouTube Takedown Raises Questions Over Media Influence
description: Under what circumstances can a big media company demand that YouTube remove a video?

title: When Japanese-Americans Were Interned in Camps
description: To the Editor:

title: The Life Report: Frank H. Wheeler
description: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives. This one takes the form of a letter from a father to his two sons.

title: Belle Is Fulfilled, and Dickens Restored
description: It is possible to see A Christmas Carol on film or onstage a dozen times, maybe more, and yet never see one particular scene from Dickenss original 1843 novella. It stars Belle, the young Ebenezer Scrooges fiance, who broke off their engagement because Ebenezer had become so obsessed with money. She is seen talking about him casually but sympathetically with her handsome husband, in a tableau of contented domesticity with their beautiful daughter and their prettily decorated Christmas tree.

title: Reviewing the Buick Verano
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reviews the Buick Verano, a premium compact sedan that shares its architecture with its strong-selling, and more frugally priced, corporate relation under General Motors, the Chevrolet Cruze.

title: Group Therapy: Tell Us Your Pinto, Vega and Gremlin Stories
description: Though an era of stylish, high-quality compact cars is upon the land, with American manufacturers like Chevrolet, Ford and  shortly  Chrysler producing attractive vehicles worthy of being cross-shopped against their Asian counterparts, it was not always so.

title: Lord, What Is Man, and Other Philosophical Tidbits for the Ages
description: Eloquent in its middle, the Welsh countertenor Iestyn Daviess voice soars at the top of its range. Dapper and self-possessed, Mr. Davies, who made his New York recital debut at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday evening, is a singer of serenity and understatement. Even his virtuosity seems somehow modest.

title: A Region in the Caucasus
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Equity Buyouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing a Theater to a Beleaguered City
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.

title: U.S. Activist Jailed in Peru Can Go Home For Holidays
description: LIMA, Peru  A court here is allowing Lori Berenson, the paroled American who spent more than 15 years in Peruvian prisons on a terrorism conviction, to travel to the United States for the first time.

title: Reflections on Iraq as U.S. Troops Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Rejuvenating Opera With an Act of Dissent
description: NEW YORK is unquestionably an international capital of the arts, but it can also be a frustrating backwater when it comes to contemporary opera. Yes, in February the Metropolitan Opera mounted John Adamss Nixon in China: a groundbreaking work at its premiere 24 years ago, since embraced as canon most everywhere but here. In November the Met revived a brilliant staging of Philip Glasss Satyagraha, a 1979 opera that proved its worth elsewhere first.

title: Hummingbird Makes a Year-End Visit
description: Visitors to the American Museum of Natural History are familiar with its dioramas of stuffed fauna from around the world. On the third floor is a hall dedicated to birds of New York City, including the extinct carrier pigeon.

title: Christopher Hitchens, Consummate Writer, Brilliant Friend
description: London

title: Talking With Ellen Johnson Sirleaf
description: A conversation between Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, president of Liberia and 2011 Nobel Peace Prize laureate, and Alison Smale, executive editor of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Exchanging Vows Under a Canopy, No Matter the Faith
description: WHEN Natalie Rodic Marsan, 35, a Texas native who now lives in Brooklyn, was planning her June 12, 2010, wedding on an island off Croatia, she imagined it taking place on the beach under a canopy like a huppah, the wedding covering that is a fixture at Jewish weddings.

title: Listening to the British Rioters
description: As we come to the end of a remarkable year of protests and riots across the globe, it is not hard to feel that too little time has been devoted to digesting the meaning of whats happened, perhaps in part because technology now makes it so easy to get caught up in following the rush of events as they unspool online.

title: Christopher Hitchens, Book Critic
description: Even as Christopher Hitchens weakened from cancer over the past year and a half, the work he contributed to The New York Times Book Review was as strong as ever, if not stronger. The last piece he wrote for us assessed the playwright David Mamets account of shifting politically to the right. Mr. Hitchens made it clear that his pugnacity would be with him until the last: This is an extraordinarily irritating book, he began, later saying of one of Mr. Mamets opinions that it has a long way to go before it can even be called simplistic.

title: In Beijing, Americans Win 2 Individual Events
description: The first SportAccord World Mind Games, which ended on Friday in Beijing, brought together competitors in five disciplines: bridge, checkers, chess, Chinese chess and go.

title: Revolt Begins Like Others, but Its End Is Less Certain
description: WUKAN, China  Each day begins with a morning rally in the banner-bedecked square, where village leaders address a packed crowd about their seizure of the village and plans for its future. Fridays session was followed by a daylong mock funeral for a fallen comrade, whose body lies somewhere outside the village in government custody.

title: Willy Parkers, Not Just for the Locals
description: IF you havent eaten at Willy Parkers American Bar and Grill in the last four months, you havent eaten at Willy Parkers. A new chef came on board in August, bringing with him an upgraded menu.

title: In Spin Room After Debate, Glimpses Into Campaigns Weak Spots
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  Mitt Romneys criticisms became contrasts. Newt Gingrichs consulting firm morphed into a small business. And Ron Pauls isolationist worldview evolved into a strong national defense.

title: Robust Despite the Rains
description: Despite the major problems that recurring rains caused for Long Island vintners during this years growing season, two leading producers are quickly releasing successful 2011 whites.

title: Penn States McQueary Tells Court What He Saw
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  A Penn State assistant football coach testified Friday that in 2002 he saw Jerry Sandusky sexually assaulting a young boy and that he reported it, in graphic detail, to Coach Joe Paterno and two senior Penn State University officials.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Former Chiefs of Freddie and Fannie of Deception
description: 9:30 p.m. | Updated

title: Its a Genuine Rembrandt, but Not a Painting
description: Rembrandt used drawing in the 17th century the way 21st-century artists use photography: to record people, places and things, and as source material or preparatory studies for his works. There is no consensus on how many drawings he produced, but some estimates place the number in the thousands. A selection from his prodigious output is on view in Drawings by Rembrandt, His Students and Circle From the Maida and George Abrams Collection, which features more than 50 drawings by nearly two dozen artists.

title: Inside the Spin Room
description: The spin room has taken on an outsized importance in a political season defined by gaffes (a brain freeze), flubbed jokes (a $10,000 bet) and factually challenged assertions (suggesting a vaccine causes mental retardation).

title: Week in Pictures for Dec. 16
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the return of a Christmas tradition, the killing of a police officer and the death of a woman in an elevator accident.

title: Appealing to Nostalgia for the Old Country
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Stanford Ends Effort to Build New York Arm
description: Stanford University abruptly dropped out of the intense international competition to build an innovative science graduate school in New York City, releasing its decision on Friday afternoon. A short time later, its main rival in the contest, Cornell, announced a $350 million gift  the largest in its history  to underwrite its bid.

title: Crippling the Right to Organize
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Hearings Shed Light on Pollock Dispute
description: Years before federal authorities opened their forgery inquiry into a cache of Modernist paintings handled by high-end art dealers, the Knoedler Gallery agreed to refund $2 million to a client who had questioned the authenticity of one of the works, according to court testimony this week.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $6,100,000
description: A four-bedroom four-bath apartment on Riverside Boulevard on the Upper West Side was the biggest sale of the week, at $6.1 million, according to city records.

title: Gifts Destined for the Table, Not the Trash
description: FRUITCAKES and plum pudding are holiday traditions right up there with inflatable reindeer and aerosol snow. These boozy variations on a theme of candied fruits, nuts, spices and extracts are generally garish and heavy-handed, a perennial favorite for re-gifting.

title: High-Profile Romney Endorsement Is Dismissed by Gingrich Camp
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Mitt Romney chartered a plane from Iowa and headed south to collect one of his partys most coveted endorsements on Friday, while Newt Gingrich returned home to Virginia  on a commercial Delta flight, with one connection  to watch his wife play the French horn at a Christmas concert.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Unusual Year-End Lists and a Spider Bot
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors picked out on the Web on Friday. For the full list, look over to the right-hand column.

title: Indian Point: The Next Fukushima?
description: Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Amazon Says Long Term And Means It
description: In 1997, the year Amazon.com went public, its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, issued a manifesto: Its all about the long term, he said. He warned shareholders we may make decisions and weigh tradeoffs differently than some companies and urged them to make sure that a long-term approach is consistent with your investment policy. Amazons management and employees are working to build something important, something that matters to our customers, something that we can tell our grandchildren about, he added.

title: Beyond Durban
description: Startling new evidence that global carbon dioxide emissions are rising faster than ever did little to increase the urgency of the climate talks in Durban, South Africa, which concluded earlier this week. Once again, the worlds negotiators kicked the can down the road.

title: German Baking, From Almond Paste to Zimtsterne
description: SCOTT RIVERAS sales pitch was in high gear on a chilly Saturday morning at the New Haven farmers market. If you like whole grain and rye I recommend trying our vollkorn brot, he told more than a few customers while slicing bite-sized pieces of a dozen or so German breads, pretzels and cakes from Whole G bakery, whose name stands for whole German and whole grain.

title: Nonprofit Companies Enjoying, Well, Profits
description: By Sunday, when the critically acclaimed Broadway drama Venus in Fur closes at Manhattan Theater Clubs Samuel J. Friedman Theater after a two-month run, many of the clubs 15,000 subscribers will have seen the play. Normally, that would be that: Unlike commercial producers, who aim to enrich themselves with long-running hits, Manhattan Theater Club is a nonprofit that seeks to open (and close) several shows each year for subscribers and others.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Election Apps
description: The presidential campaign season will soon be in full swing. Sarah Wheaton, who updates the New York Times apps Top News section, and Jonathan Ellis, who oversaw the new Election 2012 app development, stop by to talk about the election coverage and apps.

title: An Agreement on Spending
description: They are reviled by the right and were even kicked out of their lavish old offices on the House side by Republican leaders. But Congressional appropriators  known for handling the most basic task of the legislative branch in a centrist manner  did their jobs this week. The spending bill they wrote for the remainder of the 2012 fiscal year came together with a minimum of ideology and passed the House over the opposition of hard-liners. The Senate is expected to give its approval this weekend, averting a shutdown.

title: At 93, Still the Staff Artist
description: IRWIN HASEN, 93, says the happiest moment in his life came early one morning in September 1955, when he had just begun drawing the comic strip Dondi.

title: The Case Against Sheriff Arpaio
description: After a three-year investigation, the Justice Department has accused Joe Arpaio, the sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., and longtime darling of the anti-immigrant crowd, of unconstitutional policing and creating a pervasive culture of bias against Latinos.

title: G.O.P. Debate Wins High Ratings (Again)
description: The Republican presidential debate on Fox News Thursday night continued the trend of winning huge ratings for the candidate face-offs this year.

title: Podcast: WaMus Settlement, the Cost of Law School and the Pain of the Financial Crisis
description: The demise of Washington Mutual in 2008 was the biggest bank collapse in United States history.

title: Few Hard Rules for Backup Officers
description: It is late, and the streets are dark. A violent crime is erupting. Confusion reigns. And, invariably, patrol officers on duty in New York City will need one thing: backup.

title: Online, Then Out for a Long Walk
description: For Dennis Crowley, 35, a founder of the social networking service Foursquare, Sundays are a time to explore the city the way his company encourages users to do, seeking out new experiences and revisiting old favorites. Expeditions begin and eventually end in his Alphabet City apartment, where he lives with his girlfriend, Chelsa Skees, 30, who is a partner in a retail startup in Chelsea, and her cat, Peanut Butter, known to his more than 100 Twitter followers as @Pnizzle.

title: An Early Holiday Hangover
description: Right now youre probably asking yourself: Whats up with reproductive rights this holiday season?

title: English, Once a Barrier, Opens a Door
description: For Hui Lin, 17, English has been something of a lifeline. Five years ago, she could barely speak the language, struggling to count to 10 even after finishing seventh grade at a school in Chinatown in Manhattan.

title: The First to 700 Wins
description: Campus Magnets Charles Granby became the first coach in the P.S.A.L. to reach the milestone.

title: Buyers of Stolen Gadgets Are Arrested
description: The police arrested 141 people across New York City this week on charges that they bought stolen iPhones and iPads from undercover police officers.

title: Lottery Numbers
Holiday Tradition in Gramercy Park
description: Q. Is Gramercy Park ever open to the public?

title: Inconvenient Income Inequality
description: Is income inequality becoming the new global warming? In other words, is this another case where the facts of an existential threat lose traction among a weary American public as deniers attempt to reduce them to partisan opinions?

title: Creative Visions, Writ Large
description: The artist Kristin Jones is planning her first major public art project in New York City in a dozen years.

title: Millions From Diamonds Go to Mugabe, Observers Say
description: JOHANNESBURG  Tens of millions of dollars in diamond profits  perhaps more  are being secretly extracted from state-owned mines in eastern Zimbabwe, bypassing the nations treasury and raising fears that President Robert Mugabe is amassing wealth to help extend his 31-year reign, according to monitoring groups, diplomats, lawmakers and analysts.

title: With Victory No. 700 Comes a P.S.A.L. First
description: Campus Magnet Coach Charles Granby rose slowly from the visitors bench and peeked at the game clock Thursday night at Forest Hills High School. Time was running out on another opponent, and a small contingent of family and friends seated behind him began to roar.

title: Health Care Law Will Let States Tailor Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  In a major surprise on the politically charged new health care law, the Obama administration said Friday that it would not define a single uniform set of essential health benefits that must be provided by insurers for tens of millions of Americans. Instead, it will allow each state to specify the benefits within broad categories.

title: Like Christo, Thinking Big
description: THE artist Kristin Jones, 55, wrapped in a double layer of green velvet capes with her blond Rapunzel braid askew over one shoulder, stood in the northwest corner of Washington Square Park gazing rapturously at a 330-year-old tree known as the Hangmans Elm. She placed a protective hand on its mighty trunk.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Greeks pondered leaving the euro and returning to the drachma, Facebook resisters gave their side, investigators dug deeper into the collapse of MF Global and Russia joined the World Trade Organization.

title: Occupy Group Faults Church, a Onetime Ally
description: For months, they were the best of neighbors: the slapdash champions of economic equality, putting down stakes in an outdoor plaza, and the venerable Episcopal parish next door, whose munificence helped sustain the growing protest.

title: College Football Analyst Is Weighing Senate Run
description: Craig James, the often-contentious ESPN football analyst, is contemplating a run for the United States Senate seat in Texas being vacated by Kay Bailey Hutchison.

title: With Vows Exchanged, Break Out the Slides
description: Recently at PowerHouse Arena in Dumbo, a loft-like store for arty bibliophiles, David Friedlander, a handsome guy whose career has a 21st-century way of resisting easy description, married Jacqueline Schmidt, an ethereal redhead  a dancer once, a graphic artist now  who seems to run on earnest optimism.

title: For the Fallen, an Esoteric, Simple Symbol of Grief
description: The locker that nobody wants to open is on the seventh floor of a massive police building on East 20th Street. Turn left out of the elevator, then walk down a hall and through a cluttered computer training classroom, to a door in the rear marked Ceremonial Unit. Another left into a little dead-end hall, and there it is, the last locker on the left, marked No. 2064. Its as if someone wanted to make it hard to find.

title: For the Jets, a Familiar Face in a Familiar Place
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  An unworn green practice jersey hung inside Jim Leonhards locker Friday afternoon. The black stool that normally sits in front of his locker had been stowed away. There was no green equipment bag for Leonhard to jam his gear into before Sundays game against the Eagles in Philadelphia.

title: A Strenuous Strut Down the Catwalk
description: One by one, in gowns or tuxedos, guests at a fund-raiser on Monday night carried giant canisters of water around a catwalk in the middle of the cavernous 69th Regiment Armory on Lexington. Some women kicked off stilettos for the trek; others bore the burden in heels.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Saturday: Lowest Number on a Clock
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Nope, this one just wasnt in my wheelhouse either. I know. Ive been whining for days, and I can only hope that the big Sunday grid is a little kinder to me. It would be a nice way to wrap up the weekend, after the past two days of J.B.F.s (Just Barely Finished).

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: This Sunday: How Nice Can Benton Harbor Ever Be?
description: Detroit gets all the scary headlines, but there is a more desperate city in the state of Michigan, and it is called Benton Harbor. For the magazines cover story this week, Jonathan Mahler went there to investigate the citys plan to revive itself with a publicly subsidized golf course and luxury-housing development in the very place where factories once provided thousands of blue-collar workers with a way of life. Slowly, since the 1960s, Benton Harbor has lost all its factories and half its population; those who remain subsist on a per capita income of $10,000. The citys finances are so wrecked that the state government sent in an emergency manager who answers to no one locally. Putting a golf course in the midst of all this is, as Jon observes, almost a caricature of economic disparity.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Investors Scrutinizing JPMorgans Mortgages
description: Bank of America, the firm perhaps hardest hit by mortgage-related lawsuit woes, might have some company in the courthouse soon.

title: Nets May Be Just Player Away From Reviving Knicks Rivalry
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Chris Paul landed in Los Angeles, pulled on a red Clippers jersey and, in an instant, a rivalry was born where none had existed. This is how quickly reality can change in todays N.B.A.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Cuomo Brings Peaceful End to Yogurt War Between Cities
description: He persuaded a skeptical Legislature to legalize same-sex marriage. He rewrote the states tax code in three days. And now, for the crowning achievement of his first year in office, he has brokered peace in the yogurt wars.

title: Yemeni Uprising Opens a Door to Besieged Rebels in the North
description: SAADA, Yemen  In the streets of this citys medieval quarter, the toll of Yemens hidden wars became clear.

title: Volunteers Come Out, Again, for Ron Paul in Iowa
description: Supporters from the Texas congressmans 2008 presidential campaign are now a more motivated and efficient force, and that has given him an advantage in Iowa.

title: An Epic Drawn From the Tears of Nanjing
Devils Win on Niedermayers Night
description: NEWARK  On the night the Devils honored Scott Niedermayer by retiring his No. 27, it was easy to understand why the current team is probably a few years away from becoming a Stanley Cup contender. Defensemen the caliber of Niedermayer do not come along often, and the Devils do not have anyone like him. Few teams do.

title: Pauls Ground Game, in Place Since 08, Gives Him an Edge
description: ANKENY, Iowa  It was four years ago that Ross Witt, a soft-spoken electrical engineer at John Deere, overcame his natural discomfort with knocking on hundreds of his neighbors doors during dinnertime as a precinct coordinator for Ron Pauls campaign.

title: Hunting for Clues to Global Warming
description: Scientists in Alaska are trying to determine whether potential thawing of permafrost in the Northern Hemisphere will release huge amounts of carbon, intensifying global warming.

title: Giants Kiwanuka Still Adjusting in Another Transition to Linebacker
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants selection of Mathias Kiwanuka in the first round of the 2006 draft illustrated the teams commitment to stockpiling talent on the defensive line, which already had Michael Strahan, Osi Umenyiora and Justin Tuck. The former general manager Ernie Accorsi often said that a team could never have enough pass rushers.

title: Lives Restored
description: A series profiling people who are functioning normally despite severe mental illness and have chosen to speak out about their struggles.

title: Frozen Carbon
description: Permafrost underlies nearly a quarter of the Northern Hemisphere and stores a huge amount of carbon.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.16
description: A view of the day in sports, including the womens World Handball Championships and the Division III football national championship.

title: Access to Details on Wealthy Donors Fueled Theft Ring
description: She worked as an ordinary clerk in the back offices of UJA-Federation of New York in Manhattan, but her position gave her ready access to the credit card and checking account details of enormously wealthy donors, including the billionaire Ira Rennert and a half-dozen generous philanthropies, like the Starr Foundation.

title: As Permafrost Thaws, Scientists Study the Risks
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  A bubble rose through a hole in the surface of a frozen lake. It popped, followed by another, and another, as if a pot were somehow boiling in the icy depths.

title: MSG and Time Warner Face Off
description: MSG Media accused Time Warner Cable on Friday of threatening to remove its networks, MSG and MSG Plus, from its systems in the New York and Buffalo markets on Dec. 31 in a contractual dispute that could deprive viewers of Knicks, Rangers, Islanders, Devils and Sabres games.

title: U.C.L.A. and Illinois in Womens Volleyball Final
description: SAN ANTONIO  Thursday nights national semifinal matches of the N.C.A.A. womens volleyball Final Four could not have played out more differently. U.C.L.A. swept the first match of the night, 3-0, against Florida State. In the second game, Illinois and Southern California pushed their match to five sets. Illinois won the fifth set on a match point that included about 50 touches before the Illini notched the 15th and decisive point. After the exhausting conclusion of the match, the Illini did not celebrate their programs first championship game appearance; the players lined up, shook hands with their Southern California counterparts and began preparing for their matchup against U.C.L.A.

title: Corrections: December 17
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Gingrich Represents New Political Era for Catholics
description: Newt Gingrich sat beneath the soaring dome in the largest Roman Catholic church in North America, the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington, and listened as a choir that included his wife sang at an evening vespers service for Pope Benedict XVI and 300 American bishops.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: A 24-year-old shopkeeper died Wednesday, two weeks after being severely beaten up by protesters who demanded a shutdown in the Nowhatta area of Srinagar. Tariq Ahmed Bhat had refused closing down his shop. (Kashmir Live)Rajasthan: The Rajasthan police commissioner and the Jaipur Municipal Corporation have decided to relocate the citys beggars in order to create a good impression and encourage non-resident Indians to invest in the state. The decision was made in advance of the upcoming Pravasi Bharatiya Diwas, from Jan. 7-9 (Daily Bhaskar).

title: Mitigation Package for Colton Harris-Moore
description: The lawyers for Colton Harris-Moore, known as the Barefoot Bandit, filed papers detailing poverty and abuse during his childhood in hopes that the judge would hand down a lenient sentence.

title: Barefoot Bandit Gets Prison for Stealing From Neighbors
description: COUPEVILLE, Wash.  Colton Harris-Moore, the Barefoot Bandit, stood bolt upright in orange jail garb before Judge Vicki I. Churchill in the small courtroom here on Friday and was sentenced to seven years and three months in prison. His hands were folded in front of him because they were shackled, and he struggled to hold back tears as he pleaded guilty to 33 state charges including burglary and identity theft.

title: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
description: In the upcoming Don 2, Priyanka Chopra plays Roma, a cop in hot pursuit of the mastermind criminal Don (played by Shah Rukh Khan) but also perhaps a little bit in love with him. His special name for her is junglee bili, or wild cat. Priyanka tells us what makes the action-thriller franchise special.

title: Congress Passes Bill Bolstering Pipeline Safety Rules
description: A bill doubling the maximum fines that pipeline operators face for violations easily cleared the House and Senate this week, along with other provisions intended to strengthen rules on oil and gas pipeline safety that critics have faulted as weak.

title: Analysts Say Economic Recovery Might Suffer if Tax Break Is Allowed to Expire
description: WASHINGTON  Economists are warning that the looming expiration of a temporary payroll tax cut  and the possibility that Congress will not extend it  would cause families to spend less and could sap strength from a fragile recovery.

title: Patrick V. Murphy, Police Leader Who Reformed New York Force, Dies at 91
description: Patrick V. Murphy, the son of a New York City policeman who rose to lead the Police Department in the early 1970s, steering it through one of its rockiest periods as he instituted reforms to root out corruption in the ranks, died Friday at a North Carolina hospital. He was 91 and lived in Wilmington, N.C.

title: Billie Jo Spears, Country Singer, Dies at 73
description: Billie Jo Spears, a singer of country songs with strong women as their protagonists, died on Wednesday at her home in Vidor, Tex. She was 73.

title: Drum Majors Death Ruled Hazing Homicide
description: The death of a Florida A&M University drum major last month was a homicide caused by hazing, a Florida medical examiner said Friday.

title: Texas: Judges Push Back Primary Election Date
description: A federal three-judge panel in San Antonio on Friday pushed back the states primary elections from the scheduled date of March 6 to April 3, resolving one of the most pressing issues in a redistricting dispute that has thrown much of Texas politics into disarray. One option under consideration had been splitting the primary into two separate elections, a move that many Democrats and Republicans opposed, saying it would hurt voter turnout, cost counties hundreds of thousands of dollars and create logistical problems for elections officials. The parties issued a joint statement on Friday saying they were pleased with the new election schedule. The judges decision ordering a single unified primary came after an agreement on the election schedule had been reached by the state Democratic and Republican Parties.

title: California: Judge Rejects Lethal Injection Protocol
description: A judge tossed out Californias newly adopted lethal injection protocol on Friday, throwing the states execution system into further upheaval. Judge Faye DOpal of Marin County Superior Court in San Rafael ruled that the state had failed to justify the decision to put in place a three-drug lethal injection method, which some experts had said carries a risk of excruciating pain, instead of a one-drug method, which one of the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitations own experts had recommended. No executions have been conducted in California since 2006, when a federal judge effectively halted lethal injections, citing various deficiencies in the states methods. Since then, the state has revamped its execution system, including the construction of a new death chamber specifically for lethal injections. The corrections department declined to comment on the ruling.

title: Friending the New York Scene
description: SINCE moving to Manhattan three years ago, Sean Parker, a founder of Napster and former president of Facebook, has considerably enlivened New Yorks social scene.

title: Panetta Is First U.S. Defense Secretary to Visit Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Presidents from Thomas Jefferson to Barack Obama have waged war on these shores. Given such volatile relations, it is little wonder that no American defense secretary had ever set foot here.

title: At Rikers Island, a Lens Is a Mirror
description: About a year ago Clara Vannucci hopped on a yellow school bus as it went around the city picking up children, mothers, sisters and brothers. The destination was at the end of a long bridge in Queens  a holiday party for women jailed at Rikers Island.

title: The Weekend Word: Deal
description: Todays Times

title: Leader Denies Use of Violence as Cairo Crackdown Persists
description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers escalated a bloody crackdown on street protesters on Saturday, chasing down and beating unarmed civilians, even while the prime minister was denying in a televised news conference that security forces were using any force.

title: Are You Happy to Pay an N.F.L. Tax?
description: Brian Stelter and Amy Chozick of The Times on what the latest N.F.L. TV deals mean for you:

title: Floods in Southern Philippines Leave Hundreds Dead
description: MANILA  Flash floods in the southern Philippines on Saturday sent water gushing into homes, killing more than 500 people and surprising families who fled to rooftops clutching children, officials said.

title: A Spirited Contest for Worst Christmas Movie Ever
description: LOS ANGELES Whats the worst Christmas movie of all time?

title: Ron Wyden, Useful Idiot
description: I was too busy and too overstretched to weigh in on this earlier, but Sen. Ron Wyden did indeed do a bad, bad thing in his joint proposal with Paul Ryan. Ezra Klein explains why; and the devil isnt in the details.

title: They Have Made A Desert, Ireland Edition
description: And called it a successful example of austerity, of course:

title: Pierre-Pauls Football Education, Far From the Big Time
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Teammates and coaches spent several days last week attempting to pithily describe how impressive the rise of Jason Pierre-Paul has been, but the most telling aspect of his ascension may well be this: Only three years ago, he was playing for a college program that shared practice space with a rodeo team.

title: Chronic Confusion
description: A quick note  Ive seen several news reports in the past few days asserting that the structural problems of southern Europe have caused chronic trade deficits.

title: The Caucus Click: Ron Paul on Leno
Readers Share Their #MyWipeOut Stories
description: As part of last weeks ski issue we asked readers to share their #MyWipeOut stories on Twitter. Here are a selection of their epics spills, face plants and lost skis .

title: For Senate Tax Cut Stopgap, Odds in House Are Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON  Capping a year of last-minute, half-loaf legislation, the Senate voted overwhelmingly on Saturday to extend a payroll tax cut for only two months, with the chambers leaders and the White House proclaiming victory, even as they punted into the new year the issue of how to further extend the tax cut and unemployment benefits.

title: Astros Luhnow Took Short Walk to New Job
description: It was like a trade in which the player leaves one clubhouse, crosses a stadium hallway, enters the other teams clubhouse and starts a new life. That is what happened to Jeff Luhnow on the last night of the winter meetings this month at the Hilton Anatole in Dallas.

title: Walking Out of a Cornfield and Into Free Agency
description: Think of it as Fantasy Free Agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Film Tells Story of Torress Struggles With A.D.H.D.
description: Discerning a fastball from a changeup is difficult enough; imagine doing it with untethered focus, attention meandering.

title: For Maryland, Distant Memories of a Track and Field Power
description: An early-spring sun soaked University of Maryland mens track and field athletes with rays of inspiration as they walked single file into the stadium at the University of North Carolina. Some two dozen runners, jumpers and throwers strode with proud purpose, hoisting Maryland flags and moving to the pounding beat of a Parliament-Funkadelic song, blaring from a boom box, with the lyrics, If you hear any noise, its just me and the boys.

title: Austrian to Join Klinsmanns U.S. Staff
description: Andreas Herzog has wound up his work with Austrias under-21 national team and said Saturday that he is headed back to the United States to become part of Jurgen Klinsmanns coaching staff with the national team.

title: Philippines Flooding
description: Pounding rain from a tropical storm swelled rivers and sent walls of water rushing through the southern Philippines while people were asleep, killing more than 500.

title: Finding Wildlife Safaris on This Continent
description: Africa and safari vacations may go hand-in-hand, but its possible to go on a wildlife excursion without leaving the United States.

title: Behind the Scenes, Haymon Is Shaking Up the Fight Game
description: As Floyd Mayweather Jr. basked in his latest victory, the man behind the curtain actually stood behind a curtain, a clich sprung to life. Few in the postfight news conference recognized this man, a reclusive, eccentric so-called adviser who rarely ventures into public.

title: Real Madrid Routs Sevilla, Keeping League Lead
description: MADRID  Cristiano Ronaldo and Real Madrid had been feeling the weight of world soccer after a loss to Barcelona last week in their rivalry game.

title: 30 Seconds With Chris Mullin
description: Chris Mullin made plenty of basketball news this year despite the N.B.A. lockout.

title: Promise of Potential Helped N.B.A. Sell Second Chris Paul Deal
description: In the N.B.A., the only thing more enticing than talent is ambiguity. Acquire an established veteran, and fans nod appreciatively. Acquire a potential lottery pick, and people swoon.

title: The Caucus Click: Morning Walk
Laszlo Cseh Uses Silver as a Steppingstone
description: ATLANTA  The wake-up call on Laszlo Csehs phone will not let him snooze. When he is tired from travel, fatigued from training, or drained from his Sisyphean pursuit of Michael Phelps, he cues a video of the 200-meter butterfly final at the 2008 Olympics, which he downloaded upon returning home from Beijing.

title: The Dynamics of Plan B, as in Backup Quarterback
description: When David Carr became an N.F.L. quarterback in 2002, he had an unconventional wish for a first pick in the draft.

title: What Iraqis Think of the American Withdrawal: Kirkuk
description: As American forces pulled out of Iraq, we asked Iraqis around the country three questions:

title: Variety: An Acrostic of Great Growth
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Mmmm  do you smell that? Fresh pine. This acrostic made me feel like I had taken a walk in the wintry woods.

title: Large Bloc of Lawmakers Boycotts Iraqi Parliament
description: BAGHDAD  One of the largest and most powerful political groups in Iraq began a boycott of Parliament on Saturday, signaling fresh waves of political dysfunction that threaten to unravel Iraqs year-old governing coalition just days after the formal end to the American military mission here.

title: South Carolina Power Broker Welcomes Romney to State
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Representative Tim Scott of South Carolina welcomed Mitt Romney Saturday morning, moderating a town-hall style meeting for Mr. Romney, a Republican presidential hopeful, that featured largely safe questions on crucial party issues like right-to-work states, federal spending and Social Security.

title: Bachmann Hits the Road in Iowa
description: SPENCER, Iowa  Someday, maybe, if Michele Bachmann becomes the Republican nominee for president, campaign stops will be huge rallies with thousands of supporters whipped up into an election-year frenzy.

title: Press 1, for Some Straight Talk From Mr. Gingrich
description: Newt Gingrich, operating on a shoe-string budget, campaigned by conference call on Saturday with Iowa voters.

title: Romneys Truthiness
description: Kevin Drum erupts in justified outrage over Romneys statement that

title: MILESTONES
description: While the news might dwell on what weve lost, we occasionally still witness the most remarkable music: marriages, journeys, longings, births and returns.

title: OCCUPY
description: The bankers stood back, the corporations hushed a moment, and the cops took out their pepper spray.

title: THE WORLD
description: The surprise of the world is that it can still surprise us.

title: NATURE
description: We look for calm, but there is always an inevitability of storm.

title: THE NATION
description: We were all, in some way, looking for a brand-new roof.

title: ARAB SPRING
