description: The light from the Arab Spring rose from the ground up.

title: A Road Trip, Mexican Style, to Watch the Cowboys
description: MONTERREY, Mexico The convenience store was the last stop until the border on the road leading out of this industrial Mexican city, and Raul Vargas, a tour guide, made his instructions clear: the 24 die-hard Cowboys fans on his charter bus should get their snacks and beer now, because this bus would not stop again until it reached the United States Customs checkpoint in Laredo.

title: Military Clashes with Protesters for Second Day
description: Hundreds of Egyptian soldiers swept into Cairos Tahrir Square in the second day of a violent crackdown on anti-military protesters that has left 10 dead and hundreds injured.

title: Organized Chaos on the Jets Sidelines
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When Mike Westhoffs mind boosts into overdrive, so do his legs. He assesses a few plays in advance of what might happen on fourth down, then darts from one end of the Jets sideline to the other preparing his special-teamers. Ever the perfectionist, Westhoff is not satisfied until he has looked each of them in the eye.

title: Giants Boley Is Accused of Child Abuse in Custody Case
description: Giants linebacker Michael Boley is being investigated on accusations that he physically abused his 5-year-old son, according to his lawyer.

title: Gingrich Looks to Make Activist Judges an Issue
description: So far the threat of activist liberal judges has not been a rallying cry of the Republican campaign, but Newt Gingrich would like to change that.

title: For Law Schools, a Price to Play the A.B.A.s Way
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.

title: Why Is the N.Y.P.D. After Me?
description: WHEN I was 14, my mother told me not to panic if a police officer stopped me. And she cautioned me to carry ID and never run away from the police or I could be shot. In the nine years since my mother gave me this advice, I have had numerous occasions to consider her wisdom.

title: The Pungent Aroma of Paranoia
description: WASHINGTON

title: Help Wanted
description: THE historian Walter Russell Mead recently noted that after the 1990s revolution that collapsed the Soviet Union, Russians had a saying that seems particularly apt today: Its easier to turn an aquarium into fish soup than to turn fish soup into an aquarium. Indeed, from Europe to the Middle East, and maybe soon even to Russia and Asia, a lot of aquariums are being turned into fish soup all at once. But turning them back into stable societies and communities will be one of the great challenges of our time.

title: Vine Talk Participants Complain of Not Being Paid
description: On the syndicated public television show Vine Talk, the actor Stanley Tucci leads a changing cast of chefs and celebrities in a convivial round of wine tasting. But off-camera, many of the shows participants are battling over money still owed to them.

title: Repressing Democracy, With American Arms
description: SITRA, Bahrain

title: Self-Adoration Reaches Newt Heights
description: MARVELING over a presidential candidates arrogance is like noting that a hockey player wears skates. It states not just the obvious but the necessary. You cant zip across the ice in Crocs, and you cant thrash your way to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue if your confidence doesnt bleed into something gaudier. Arrogance is the grist, and arrogance is the given.

title: Working With Medicare
description: There are many ways to rein in Medicare spending without scrapping the system and starting over.

title: Ask David Segal About Law School
description: On the cover of this weeks Sunday Business section, The Timess David Segal writes about how standards set by the American Bar Association can affect law schools. The associations rules make it difficult for law schools to offer legal education without charging hefty tuition.

title: Jets at Eagles: Matchup to Watch
description: Jets (8-5) at Eagles (5-8), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, CBSMatchup to Watch: Brodney Pool and Eric Smith vs. Philadelphias offense

title: The Believers Atheist
description: OF the many remarkable things about Christopher Hitchens, who died on Thursday after one of the most prolific and provocative careers in modern Anglo-American letters, perhaps the most remarkable was how much religious believers liked him.

title: War Really Is Going Out of Style
description: THE departure of the last American troops from Iraq brings relief to a nation that has endured its most painful war since Vietnam. But the event is momentous for another reason. The invasion of Iraq was the most recent example of an all-out war between two national armies. And it could very well be the last one.

title: The Internet Gets Physical
description: THE Internet likes you, really likes you. It offers you so much, just a mouse click or finger tap away. Go Christmas shopping, find restaurants, locate partying friends, tell the world what youre up to. Some of the finest minds in computer science, working at start-ups and big companies, are obsessed with tracking your online habits to offer targeted ads and coupons, just for you.

title: Are We Not Man Enough?
description: ON Friday, a federal judge in San Francisco sentenced Barry Bonds, Major League Baseballs career home run leader, to two years of probation and community service. Mr. Bondss success in baseball, and his conviction for obstruction of justice earlier this year, both stemmed in part from his use of a testosterone-based balm famously known as the cream.

title: The Grim Good Cheer of the Irish
description: Dublin

title: Life Goes On, and On ...
description: A FRIEND calls from her car: Im on my way to Cape Cod to scatter my mothers ashes in the bay, her favorite place. Another, encountered on the street, mournfully reports that hes just planted his mother. A third e-mails news of her mothers death with a haunting phrase: the sledgehammer of fatality. It feels strange. Why are so many of our mothers dying all at once?

title: To Stay Great, Never Forget Your Basics
description: This interview with  Geoffrey Canada, president and C.E.O. of the nonprofit  Harlem Childrens Zone, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Panning Salon
description: The record $52.4 billion spree shoppers went on from Black Friday through Cyber Monday was really just for show. Beneath the holiday spending, consumers are grouchy. You can sense their mood just by scanning the posts at consumer-review sites like Trip Advisor and Yelp.

title: Environmentalists Get Down to Earth
description: AT a fall retreat, board members of the Natural Resources Defense Council, the environmental advocacy group, listened as a political consultant gave a critique of the green movement.

title: Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me
description: This week ends our collaboration with NPR on the Wait Wait quiz. New features will appear in this space beginning in mid-January.

title: Name Withheld, but Not His Identity
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES generally does not publish the names of sex crime victims. But a Nov. 22 article about one boy in the Jerry Sandusky case at Penn State contained biographical details that effectively identified him for anyone who knows how to search the Web, according to critics and the boys lawyer.

title: Arrests as Occupy Protest Turns to Church
description: From his spot at the center of Duarte Square in Lower Manhattan, Matt Sky watched on Saturday as hundreds of protesters streamed into the public areas of the triangle-shaped space at the center of an ideological tug of war between onetime allies turned adversaries: Occupy Wall Street and Trinity Church.

title: Inside the Euro Zone, Bracing for Austerity
description: Camogli, Italy

title: Alabamas Second Thoughts
description: Alabamas stance on its extremist immigration law is shifting from defiance to damage control. Gov. Robert Bentley admitted this month that the law needed fixing and promised that he and legislative leaders would do that in next years session. His retreat followed a letter from the states attorney general, Luther Strange, to legislative leaders suggesting that they throw out whole sections of the law to make it easier to defend in court.

title: Sunday Dialogue: When Marijuana Is Used as Medicine
description: Is marijuana safe and effective for medical purposes? Readers debate the science and politics.

title: Drawing on a Long Life, for a Short Guy
description: Irwin Hasen, 93, says, "I was drawing myself," for the more than three decades he created Dondi, the lovable war orphan that graced newspaper comics and pleased generations.

title: The Civilian Toll in Libya
description: NATO airstrikes killed dozens of civilians at sites in Libya examined by The New York Times, but NATO has largely refused to acknowledge or investigate the casualties.

title: A Financial Crisis Neednt Be a Noose
description: RECESSIONS after financial crises are long and severe, and the subsequent recoveries are protracted. That is the bold conclusion of This Time Is Different, the book by Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff, and it has become conventional wisdom.

title: Errant NATO Airstrikes in Libya: 13 Cases
description: Evidence from 13 cases in which NATO airstrikes in Libya killed civilians or did not hit their intended targets.

title: Vulcan Prepares Fight Against Martin Marietta Bid
description: Vulcan Materials is not going to sell itself to its rival, Martin Marietta Materials. without a fight.

title: NATO Airstrikes in Libya
description: New York Times reporter C.J. Chivers reports from Libya on the collateral damage and casualties caused by NATO airstrikes during its seven month campaign.

title: In Strikes on Libya by NATO, an Unspoken Civilian Toll
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  NATOs seven-month air campaign in Libya, hailed by the alliance and many Libyans for blunting a lethal crackdown by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and helping to push him from power, came with an unrecognized toll: scores of civilian casualties the alliance has long refused to acknowledge or investigate.

title: American Who Was Jailed in Peru Is Blocked at Airport
description: LIMA, Peru  Lori Berenson, the New Yorker paroled last year after serving more than 15 years in prison here on a terrorism conviction, was blocked from leaving the country for what was to have been her first visit home since her arrest, she said Saturday.

title: Slapped Wrists at WaMu
description: WHEN Washington Mutual collapsed in 2008, it was the largest bank failure in American history. So the $64.7 million settlement struck last week by federal banking regulators and three former WaMu executives seems like small potatoes indeed.

title: Holden Withington, Last Living B-52 Designer, Dies at 94
description: On a Friday in 1948, six aeronautical designers from the Boeing Company holed up in a hotel suite in Dayton, Ohio. They stayed put until Monday morning, except for the one who left to visit a hobby shop and returned with balsa wood, glue, carving tools and silver paint.

title: Making the Case for, and Against, Chess as an Olympic Sport
description: Could chess be an Olympic sport?

title: Concussion Roster Quickly Expands Again
description: In mid-November, Brendan Shanahan, the N.H.L. vice president for player safety, reported that concussions were down almost 50 percent from the same period in 2010, a significant improvement he attributed to increased player awareness about the kinds of hits that cause head trauma and the enforcement of new rules against such hits.

title: Medvedev Urges Reform of Russias Political System
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Saturday that the countrys political system had exhausted itself and must be changed, and that the Russian authorities should accept that street protests reflected the mood of our people.

title: Rules to Stop Pupil and Teacher From Getting Too Social Online
description: Faced with scandals and complaints involving teachers who misuse social media, school districts across the country are imposing strict new guidelines that ban private conversations between teachers and their students on cellphones and online platforms like Facebook and Twitter.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, December 18
description: Mitt Romney makes his first Sunday show appearance this week, capping off a week in which he has conducted nearly as many interviews as he had since declaring his candidacy. He will stop by Fox News Sunday to talk about President Obama, the economy and the battle for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Rebooting Philanthropy in Silicon Valley
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: Increasingly, Smoking Indoors Is Forbidden at Public Housing
description: AUBURN, Me.  Glenys Cushman was grabbing a quick cigarette here the other day outside her federally subsidized apartment. The rules say no smoking inside or within 25 feet of the entrance, and though she hates having to go outside, she has come to accept it.

title: Henry Lafont, Pilot, Dies at 91; Fought in Battle of Britain
description: Henry Lafont, a French pilot who took part in a harrowing aerial escape from North Africa to fight for the honor of France after its capitulation to Hitler and who became the last surviving French veteran of the Battle of Britain, died on Dec. 2 in Trmuson, in the Brittany region of France. He was 91.

title: Making Science Leap From the Page
description: WHEN a college textbook, Principles of Biology, comes out from the Nature Publishing Group in January, one place it wont be is on the shelves of school bookstores.

title: Kazakhstan Orders Curfew for Oil Town
description: MOSCOW  The president of Kazakhstan declared a state of emergency on Saturday in a town in the western oil-producing region of the country, where striking workers and the police fought the day before, leaving at least 11 people dead.

title: Letters: Symbols vs. Causes
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Protests and Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paula E. Hyman, Who Sought Rights for Women in Judaism, Dies at 65
description: Paula E. Hyman, a social historian who pioneered the study of women in Jewish life and became an influential advocate for womens equality in Jewish religious practice, including their ordination as rabbis, died on Thursday at her home in New Haven. She was 65.

title: Iraq, a War Obama Didnt Want, Shaped His Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has made good on his campaign pledge to end the Iraq war, portraying the departure of the last troops as a chance to turn to nation-building at home.

title: Reframing the Debate Over Using Phones Behind the Wheel
description: For years, policy makers trying to curb distracted driving have compared the problem to drunken driving. The analogy seemed fitting, with drivers weaving down roads and rationalizing behavior that they knew could be deadly.

title: Prepping for Your Annual Review
description: Q. Its time for your yearly performance review. You arent expecting any big surprises, but you still feel a little nervous. How should you prepare for this meeting?

title: Reader Comments on Bahrain
description: My Sunday column is about Bahrain, our ally in the Gulf, and the Obama administrations proposed $53 million arms sale to the regime. As you may know from my last column, I was detained in Bahrain by riot police who also broke the camera and roughed up the video journalist with me. But, truth be told, I also have a good deal of admiration for Bahrain and what the royal family has accomplished here  the soaring living standards, the investment in education, the empowerment of women, the solid middle class. Its just that when you educate people and create a cosmopolitan nation, you cant continue to deny them democracy. People want more from life than fine watches and nice houses.

title: Gunmen Attack Helicopter Carrying Mine Workers in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Gunmen fired at a helicopter carrying workers for the mining giant Freeport-McMoRan shortly after it took off Saturday from a town near the companys huge gold and copper mine in eastern Indonesia, a police spokesman, Colonel Wachyono, said.

title: Journey of a Bookworm
description: MY dad was a Marine officer who fought in the Battle of Inchon in the Korean War. He was badly injured and awarded three Purple Hearts and the Bronze Star. I grew up hearing stories about the war and how he continued to fight while hurt. He served as an example of picking yourself up after being knocked down.

title: Secretary Expects Cuts in Marines and the Navy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  On a trip to Afghanistan to visit Navy and Marine forces, the secretary of the Navy, Ray Mabus, said Saturday that he expected both branches to reduce their numbers after the Iraq and Afghan wars, and to return to their seafaring roots  although both will have some new areas of focus.

title: Video Shows Egyptian Soldiers Beating and Shooting at Protesters
description: As our colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, Egyptian soldiers chased down and beat unarmed civilians on Saturday, even while the prime minister appointed by the military was denying in a televised news conference that security forces were using any force.

title: Perry Criticizes Competitors Over Earmarks
description: SPENCER, Iowa  Rick Perry accused two rivals of being excessive users of earmarks in the federal budget, describing them as part of the insider culture that he would reject as president.

title: In the Forecasting Fog, Its Wise to Slow Down
description: THE American economy certainly isnt at peak strength. With unemployment at a painfully high 8.6 percent, it cant be. But unless the economy receives another shocking blow, it isnt in imminent danger of relapsing into recession.

title: New England Asks: Who Has Fairest Lobster Trap Tree of All?
description: The tiny towns of Beals and Jonesport, Me., have completed their second annual holiday display: a conical tower of 1,364 lobster traps, 60 feet tall, built to withstand the powerful winds that come off the water. It is the towns Christmas tree, made of wire traps plucked from the sea by lobstermen who lend them to the cause.

title: The Death of a Boy in Bahrain
description: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof visits the family of a 14-year-old boy in Bahrain whose death may offer a lesson in American foreign policy.

title: Sunday: Again?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  What do you gain from doing crossword puzzles? Some people feel that puzzles makes their brain sharper, some people do them to increase their vocabulary. Others do crosswords because their commute to work would be deadly boring without them. And, of course, theres the community: a whole tribe of constructors, editors, bloggers, solvers and commenters who regularly gather both virtually and in real life to challenge and entertain one another.

title: Oligarchs or Not, Russians Still Flock to Furs
description: Born out of harsh winters and long tradition, wearing furs remains popular in Russia, where organizations like People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals have been unable to make many inroads.

title: Gingrich Survives Glare to Exploit the Spotlight
description: Early in October, Newt Gingrich was completing a busy three-day swing through South Carolina. He had met with Tea Party members and others, and despite bad poll numbers  fallout from a disastrous summer after his top aides quit en masse  he was beginning to sense a change in his fortunes.

title: Video of Occupy Wall Street Manhattan March
description: Following an action against Trinity Wall Street, an Episcopal church that members of the Occupy Wall Street movement once considered an ally early Saturday, protesters took to the street. Below is a video of the marching protesters as they move northward up Seventh Avenue, broadcast by a user called The Other 99.

title: As Wars End, Young Veterans Return to Scant Jobs
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  In Afghanistan, Cpl. Clayton Rhoden earned about $2,500 a month jumping into helicopters to chase down improvised explosive devices or check out suspected bomb factories.

title: Economic Health in Iowa Conflicts With a G.O.P. Theme
description: PELLA, Iowa  Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich, Rick Perry and nearly every other Republican presidential candidate has visited the same sprawling factory complex here in recent months. They came to talk about business and manufacturing and, of course, to hit hard on the dominant theme of the campaign trail: unemployment and the struggling economy.

title: Test Drive for Two Teams Still Tinkering
description: NEWARK  The doors swung open, the seats filled up (mostly) and two dozen tall men trotted onto the Prudential Center court Saturday afternoon. Balls were dribbled, dunks were thrown down, and T-shirts were tossed  the first tangible proof of the N.B.A.s belated return.

title: A New Favorite in the Republican Field
description: Newt Gingrich is the latest candidate to surge in the national polls, and he is leading in influential states just weeks before their votes are cast.

title: A Partisan Lightning Rod Is Undeterred
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  For nearly three years, Republicans have attacked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on national security and civil rights issues. For months, they have criticized him over a gun-trafficking investigation gone awry, with dozens of leaders calling for his resignation. Last week, more than 75 members of Congress co-sponsored a House resolution expressing no confidence in his leadership.

title: State Jobless Rates, in Order of Primary Dates
description: State jobless rates, in order of primary dates.

title: Redskins at Giants: Matchup to Watch
description: Redskins (4-9) at Giants (7-6), 1 p.m. Eastern, FoxMatchup to Watch: Giants linebackers vs. running back Roy HeluThe Giants held Tim Hightower, the starting running back at the time, to 72 yards rushing in the season-opening loss to Washington, but Helu has excellent speed to the outside and will require some discipline from the Giants linebackers. Overpursuing will be punished, and the Giants must contain Helu if they hope to keep him from continuing his streak of three games with 100 or more yards.

title: Des Moines Register Endorses Romney
description: DES MOINES  The Des Moines Register endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Saturday night, saying his sobriety, wisdom and judgment fit the times and outweigh what they called his tendency to pick his way through the political minefields.

title: Tax Bill Can Stall Oil Pipeline, Officials Say
description: Payroll tax cut legislation that would force President Obama to speed up a decision on the controversial Keystone XL pipeline would likely keep the project from moving forward because it would cut short the necessary environmental review, Obama administration and State Department officials said on Saturday.

title: Seeking the Help of Saints to Care for Her Grandchildren
description: If I became super-rich, Id give my grandma a million dollars so she could buy herself anything that she wants, Edward Cruz, 10, said.

title: Raising a 3-Year-Old Who Had a Rough Start
description: Even at 17, Kathy Mallon had a strong will. Mopping floors at a convent in her native Ireland, she decided she had had enough. Defying her parents wishes, she said, I climbed the gate to get out of there.

title: Serving the Role of a Loving Mother to Her Little Monster
description: Mary Rodriguez, a diabetic widow, greeted a visitor recently without an umbrella in the rain outside the maze of brick buildings in the Brooklyn housing project where she lived. Her legs were swollen, and her flip-flops were drenched. She wobbled back in while mentioning she owned a walker.

title: Republican Candidates Cram In Events With Voters Before Break for the Holidays
description: ALGONA, Iowa  The Republican candidates for president logged hundreds of highway miles on Saturday as they stepped up contact with voters before a forced interruption for the holidays next week.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 17
description: A view of the day in sports, including the I.S.A.F. Sailing World Championships in Perth, Australia, and the Bobsleigh World Cup in Winterberg, Germany.

title: Griffin Is Latest Bang in Texas Quarterback Boom
description: In the span of two months, Baylor University quarterback Robert Griffin III  or RG3  has done the unthinkable. He has beaten Texas and Oklahoma; he has led the perennially miserable Baylor Bears to their best season since 1986; he has won the Heisman (the first time ever for the school); and, befitting his status as a media darling, he has cracked a Kim Kardashian joke on The Late Show With David Letterman.

title: New Codes Aim to Cut Energy Use
description: The international symbol for Texas energy-guzzling habit is a monster pickup truck  pulling another pickup truck. But homes and other buildings are also big offenders, accounting for roughly 40 percent of the states overall energy use.

title: So the Primaries Will Be in April Now, but Everythings Still a Mess
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Tugboats
description: About 30 tugboats work San Francisco Bay, helping cargo ships and tankers navigate challenges of wind, tides, currents, fog and even parallel parking. A tugboats job isnt only to tug large vessels: the tugs also help steer and brake the bigger boats.  LOUISE RAFKIN

title: In Pacifica, the Angry Golfers vs. the Supervisors and a Back-to-Nature Plan
description: The game is not yet over at the Sharp Park Golf Course in Pacifica. A powerful group of advocates  some of them as old as this historic 79-year-old course overlooking the Pacific  is vowing to keep the links open, despite the San Francisco supervisors vote this week to begin a process to transform this 417 acres of oceanfront land into National Park land.

title: Paying Respects to a Fallen Officer
description: The line in front of Claude R. Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home in West Babylon, N.Y., formed about 1 p.m. and did not begin thinning until late afternoon, when the sun began to set and the dry air turned markedly colder.

title: Delays for Paramedics Draw Criticism in Oakland
description: Gunshots cracked the air on a sunny morning as two men led a group of high school teachers on a tour of a violent area of West Oakland. As the teachers fled to safety, the local guides hurried to the chaotic scene on the nearby corner of 13th and Peralta Streets.

title: The Luxury Market Is Robust Despite Troubles in Lower Income Brackets
description: Pierre Buljan guided his black Mercedes S.U.V. around the winding roads of the Hillsborough hills and into Atherton, where the mansions of Silicon Valley technology barons hide behind thick stone walls, wrought-iron gates and tall, manicured hedges.

title: Prosecution Deferred Offers Options
description: Jose Lopez walked out of a Cook County courtroom Wednesday with a huge weight lifted from his shoulders.

title: City Inaugurates Costly Plan to Replace Aged Water Mains
description: On a computer-generated wall map, Thomas H. Powers outlined the first steps in what promises to be the biggest investment in Chicagos labyrinthine water and sewer system since Mayor Richard J. Daley built the enormous Jardine water treatment plant on the lakefront almost 50 years ago.

title: Bulls Aside, Outlook Is Grim for Local Teams
description: So the Bulls are back at work, not noticeably affected by the N.B.A. lockout and deliberately sitting out the game of free-agent musical chairs that might result in some major stars realigning.

description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

Corrections: December 18

title: Lauren Keyfetz, Jason Borschow
description: Lauren Brooke Keyfetz, a daughter of Eva and Barry Keyfetz of Aventura, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Jason Ross Borschow, a son of Galina and Jonathan Borschow of San Juan, P.R. Rabbi Ed Farber performed the ceremony at the Aventura Turnberry Synagogue.

title: Elizabeth Chalmers and Marco Castaneda
description: Elizabeth Prewitt Chalmers, the daughter of Elizabeth H. Prewitt and Walton M. Chalmers, both of Washington, is to be married Sunday to Marco Esteban Castaneda, a son of Irene M. Castaneda and Adan I. Castaneda of Pflugerville, Tex. Clifford A. Brown, judge of the 147th Judicial District Court in Travis County, Tex., is to officiate at the Palm Door, an event space in Austin, Tex.

title: Charlotte Grassi and Brooks Aukamp
description: Charlotte McClelland Grassi, a daughter of Eleuthera S. Grassi and Temple Grassi of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday to Brooks Moore Aukamp, the son of Lee Ann Aukamp and William M. Aukamp of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. William Hague, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: Erin Carney and Sean Berry
description: Erin Kathleen Carney and Sean Peter Davison Berry were married Saturday at St. Marks Episcopal Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Sean E. Mullen, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

description: Dr. Starr Britni Koslow and Michael Jacob Mautner were married Saturday evening at the Westin Diplomat Country Club in Hallandale Beach, Fla. Rabbi Robert P. Frazin officiated.

title: Marie Ternes, Micah Kellner
description: Marie Margaret Ternes and Assemblyman Micah Zachary Kellner were married Saturday at a private apartment in New York. The brides father, Alan Ternes, a Vermont justice of the peace who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Nicole Zila, Andrew Spicehandler
description: Nicole Heather Zila and Andrew Mitchell Spicehandler were married Saturday evening in Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Mark R. Newton officiated, with the assistance of the Rev. George Bergin, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Elm Court Estate.

description: Rissa Erin Bordenick and Joshua Laurence Perkiel are to be married Sunday in Key West, Fla. Rabbi Shimon S. Dudai is to officiate at the Casa Marina hotel.

title: Michelle Bossy and Douglas Coon
description: Michelle Ann Bossy and Douglas William Coon are to be married Sunday evening at the Pratt Mansions in New York. Katharine D. Simon, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

description: Rebecca Yoheved Starr, a daughter of Dorothy Ackerman Starr and Dr. Jerome I. Starr of Worcester, Mass., was married there Saturday evening to Adam Shalom Kazan, the son of Marian Axelrod Kazan and Rabbi Fredric Kazan of Merion Station, Pa. Rabbi Steven A. Schwarzman performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Israel, with the bridegrooms father participating.

title: Rebecca Levine, Joseph Beckman

description: WUKAN, China  Leaders of a protest movement that has taken control of this coastal village of 13,000 demanded on Saturday that the authorities return the body of a supporter who died in mysterious circumstances, saying it could hold evidence that he was tortured.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
Opera Singer Is Stable After a Fall at the Met
description: The mezzo-soprano Wendy White fell from a platform eight feet above the stage during a performance of Gounods Faust at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night and was taken to the hospital. The Met said she did not appear to be seriously injured and was in stable condition but was undergoing tests.

title: Last Convoy of American Troops Leaves Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  The last convoy of American troops drove into Kuwait on Sunday morning, punctuating the end of the nearly nine-year war in Iraq.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Were entering that time of year when magazines bring out two classic features  the year-end wrap-up and next years forecast  specials designed as much for their list-like easy readability and prophetic powers as they are for allowing editors to take time off between Christmas and the New Year.

title: Last Convoy of American Troops Leaves Iraq, Marking an End to the War
description: In The Times, Tim Arango and Michael Schmidt in Baghdad report on a caravan of United States military vehicles which passed from Iraq into Kuwait in what they describe as the final moment of a drawn-out withdrawal that included weeks of ceremonies in Baghdad and around Iraq. They write:

title: Tim Tebow, and Keeping Religion Out of Football
description: The Tim Tebow success story, puzzling to some and entertaining to most, seems to have one obvious drawback: the injection of religion.

title: Vaclav Havel, Former Czech President, Dies at 75
description: Vaclav Havel, the Czech writer and dissident whose eloquent dissections of Communist rule helped to destroy it in revolutions that brought down the Berlin Wall and swept Mr. Havel himself into power, died on Sunday. He was 75.

title: Oil Rig Sinks Off Russia; 49 Missing
description: MOSCOW  An oil drilling rig that was being towed in a storm sank Sunday off the coast of Sakhalin Island, Russia, with 67 people on board, most of whom are still missing.

title: Frantic Dash From Flood in the Middle of the Night
description: MANILA  Just after 1 a.m. Saturday, Mary Ann Melancio became concerned about a co-worker. He had sent Ms. Melancio a text message saying that he was trapped by floodwaters in his home with his wife and 10-year-old daughter.

title: Inflation Conspiracy Theories
description: One response of inflation-fearers to the absence of the inflationary outburst theyve been waiting for is to reject the numbers, and claim that the BLS is hiding a much higher rate of inflation than the official numbers say. You see that a fair bit in comments, and some credulous mainstream figures (i.e. Niall Ferguson) have also bought into this story. How do we know that its wrong?

title: Could Silicon Valley Rethink Philanthropy?
description: Laura Arrillaga-Andreessen is on a mission.

title: Cornered by Attacker in Elevator, Fire Victim, 73, Had No Way Out
description: By the time Deloris Gillespie saw him, waiting on the other side of an elevator door, it was too late to escape.

title: Rissa & Joshua
description: In this homemade video, Rissa Bordenick and Joshua Perkiel recall the moment they fell in love with each other.

title: Mitt Romney Makes a Rare Sunday Television Show Appearance
description: In an interview with Chris Wallace on Fox News Sunday, in his first Sunday morning television show appearance in nearly two years, Mitt Romney sat down for a wide-ranging conversation that included how he would take on President Obama  and how Mr. Obama would try to portray him  in a general election and how he dealt with his wifes diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

title: A Racial Attack That, Years Later, Is Still Being Felt
description: Twenty-five years later, this is the legacy of a racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens:

title: Extension of Tax Cut Stalls in House as G.O.P. Objects
description: WASHINGTON  The House Republican leader on Sunday flatly rejected a short-term, bipartisan Senate measure to extend a payroll tax break and unemployment insurance, setting the stage for a bitter year-end Congressional collision and the potential loss of benefits for millions of Americans.

title: U.C.L.A. Beats Illinois for Volleyball Title
description: SAN ANTONIO  U.C.L.A.captured the N.C.A.A. womens volleyball tournament championship Saturday night, beating Illinois in four sets for the fourth national title in program history and the Bruins first since 1991.

title: Vaclav Havel, Dead at 75
description: Vaclav Havel, the dissident playwright who wove theater into politics to peacefully bring down communism in Czechoslovakia, has died.

title: Sherlock Holmes and Chipmunks Are Sluggish Leaders at Box Office
description: Bells are ringing in Hollywood, but theyre not the Christmas kind. Two big sequels, Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows and Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked, delivered shaky results over the weekend, alarming studios about a continued downturn at the North American box office. A Game of Shadows (Warner Brothers) was No. 1 with about $40 million in ticket sales. Analysts had expected that film, which cost $125 million to make, to take in over $50 million; the first installment in this franchise opened with $62 million in 2009. Chipwrecked (20th Century Fox) was second, taking in about $23.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. That result was 52 percent below the opening weekend total for the last Chipmunks movie in 2009. Chip-Wrecked cost an estimated $80 million to make. A variety of factors could have dented interest: sequel fatigue, family film overload, higher ticket prices, a lack of overall momentum at the box office. Elsewhere, Tom Cruises Mission: Impossible  Ghost Protocol (Paramount) was a powerful third, taking in about $13 million in limited release on 425 Imax screens. That result set an Imax record and positioned Ghost Protocol as a potential blockbuster and career rebound for Mr. Cruise as it expands nationwide on Wednesday. New Years Eve (Warner) was fourth with about $7.4 million in ticket sales, lifting its two-week total to $24.8 million. The Sitter (Fox) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4.4 million for a two-week total of $17.7 million.

title: Twice-Told Irish Tales
description: One thing I meant to mention when discussing Ireland is something Kevin ORourke pointed out: this is the second time in two years that Ireland has been declared a success story for austerity based on a slight uptick, soon reversed.

title: Useful Idiots, Defined
description: It was clear from many of the comments on my Ron Wyden post that many people didnt know that I was using a technical term with a precise meaning. From Wikipedia (and yes, it has this right):

title: Israel Frees Palestinians in 2nd Stage of Exchange
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Israel released about 550 Palestinian prisoners on Sunday night in the second half of a swap that freed one of its soldiers, Gilad Shalit, who had been held by Hamas in Gaza for more than five years.

title: Violence Spreads to a Second Town in Kazakhstan
description: MOSCOW  Violence between striking workers and the authorities in western Kazakhstan spread over the weekend, bringing the death toll to 14, the countrys general prosecutor announced on Sunday.

title: Dont Scowl, Beethoven, Youre Loved
description: If we are to believe the Beethoven mythology, which is based mostly on his letters and reports from his inner circle, Beethoven had an unshakeable sense of his own importance. Unlike Mozart and Haydn he refused to defer to nobility, asserting that a composer is of greater value, in the cosmic scheme of things, than a prince. And though he had patrons among the aristocracy, he revered Napoleon, their nemesis, and dedicated his Third Symphony, the Eroica (Heroic) to him, only to remove the dedication when Napoleon crowned himself emperor.

title: A New York Stop for Cate Blanchett, Hugo Weaving and Uncle Vanya
description: New Yorkers will have a chance to see the Sydney Theater Companys celebrated production of Uncle Vanya with Cate Blanchett and Hugo Weaving next summer. The production, which received rave reviews when it appeared last August at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, will be presented at City Center from July 19 through July 28 as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, a festival spokeswoman, Eileen McMahon, said. Ms. Blanchett plays Yelena, and Mr. Weaving plays Astrov in the farcical-yet-heartbreaking production, which was staged by the Hungarian director Tamas Ascher. Ms. Blanchetts husband, Andrew Upton, provided the actors a new English translation of Chekovs in 1897 play in Russian.

title: Gingrich Continues His Crusade Against Activist Judges
description: Newt Gingrich continued his crusade against activist judges Sunday, saying he would consider sending the Capitol Police or a United States Marshal to subpoena any federal judge who issued an opinion he thought was out of sync with American values. He would then encourage Congress to impeach the judge.

title: Remembering the Words of Vaclav Havel
description: Among the tributes coming in after the death of Vaclav Havel, the playwright who helped found the Czech Republic and was its president for a decade, are several from the theater world. There is less morality in politics with his death, Natalia Koliada, a co-founder of the Belarus Free Theater, which had a supporter in Mr. Havel, wrote on her Twitter feed. (The companys play Being Harold Pinter made Ben Brantleys list of the best shows of 2011.) The Public Theater, which produced the American premieres of several of Mr. Havels plays, wrote on Twitter: We are saddened by the death of Vaclav Havel.

title: Egypt News Media Clash Over Cause of Violence
description: CAIRO  On the third day of clashes between security forces and protesters in the center of the capital, a new battle broke out Sunday between Egypts state-run and independent media over whom to blame for the violence.

title: How Defense Won the Mind Games in Beijing
description: Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y., and Beth Palmer of Chevy Chase, Md., won the womens teams and womens pairs at the SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last week. They were particularly proud of their defense in the diagramed deal.

title: Playoffs? Yes, Giants Still Control Their Playoff Chances
description: The Giants still control their playoff chances. If they beat the Jets on Saturday and the Cowboys in the regular-season finale, they will advance to the postseason.

title: Fallen Opera Singer Said to Be Recovering
description: Wendy White, the mezzo-soprano injured when she fell during a performance at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, has been released from a hospital and is recuperating at home, a spokesman for the opera, Peter Clark, said Sunday. Ms. White sustained bruises in a fall from a platform eight feet above the stage, he said. It remains unclear when she will be well enough to perform again. The accident happened during Act III of a performance of Gounods Faust. Ms. White, in the role of Marthe, was walking onto a platform from a staircase behind Ren Pape, who was playing Mphistophls, when a hinge securing a piece of plywood under her broke. After a half-hour break the show went on with an understudy. Ms. White is a Met stalwart who has made more than 500 appearances with the company since her 1989 debut as Flora in La Traviata.

title: Gruesome and Gory, a Chaotic Fairy Tale Gone Terribly Awry
description: Dont let the presence of toy instruments in H. K. Grubers Frankenstein!! fool you. Mr. Gruber calls the work a pan-demonium for chansonnier and orchestra after childrens rhymes by H. C. Artmann, but lurid and bloody, these are fairy tales for adults, closer to Grimm than to Disney.

title: Silent Screams and Fierce Walks, as Music Sets the Scene for Dance
description: Its a rarity to come across live music in a contemporary dance setting, but when it happens, the result is usually something more than pleasant. Whether its made to fit the dance or not, the presence of musicians invariably deepens the texture of choreography, lending a richer hue. Then there are those instances when the relationship adds up to little more than a couple sharing a room but sleeping in separate beds.

title: South Korea Urges Japan to Compensate Former Sex Slaves
description: TOKYO  President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea used what was supposed to be a routine visit to Japan on Sunday to press for compensation for Korean women who were forced to work as prostitutes by the Japanese military during World War II. He called the issue a burden on relations between the two nations.

title: Lightsaber Rattling in the Online Galaxy
description: Over the last third of a century no new fiction has engaged the popular imagination and become as thoroughly essential an element of mass culture as Star Wars. There cant be many people anywhere who wouldnt at least recognize a lightsaber or Darth Vader.

title: Forced Drama, Product Placement and Star Power
description: It has been a bloated, overwrought embarrassment. It has been full of laughably excessive production numbers and clumsily manufactured drama. It may have set records for clichd sound bites, insipid banter and shameless product placement.

title: Just Wait Until You See Whats on the Menu
description: From my seat on the aisle in the orchestra section at the Metropolitan Opera House I saw only one family get up and leave during the third act of Engelbert Humperdincks Hansel and Gretel at its season premiere on Friday night. That seemed noteworthy because onstage, in a kitchen filled with lost children baked into gingerbread, a frumpy, gluttonous witch was compelling a little girl to help fatten her brother for the oven, between unsubtle hints that the girl was destined for the same fate.

title: For a Big Birthday, Leading Three Groups a Night
description: Wadada Leo Smith was a force in motion during the early stretch of his concert at Roulette in Brooklyn on Friday night. Stalking the stage, busily directing the output of his Golden Sextet, he gave off an air of restless intent. The exceptions mostly came when he played his trumpet, projecting in a hard, lustrous tone. In those moments he rooted himself: shoulders squared, the bell of his horn pointing either straight ahead or toward the floor. At every juncture he seemed to mean business.

title: Scrutiny for a Maestro and a Mezzo
description: Through no doing of the Ensemble ACJW, its concert on Friday night at Zankel Hall took on a newsier aspect than might have been anticipated. Just a couple of weeks earlier the evenings conductor, the young Spanish maestro Pablo Heras-Casado, still relatively unknown in New York, had been named principal conductor of the Orchestra of St. Lukes, a major fixture in the citys musical ecosystem.

title: Relentless Waves of Sound, Reined by Drops of Thundering Bass
description: Late in its two-plus-hour set at Madison Square Garden on Friday night Swedish House Mafia was playing its second Coldplay remix in a row, Every Teardrop Is a Waterfall following Fix You, and most of the people in the sold-out arena were bopping, as theyd been all night. The seat next to me had been occupied by at least four different people, all of whom had danced in and then danced onward.

title: Confection Suite: Homage to the Queen of Salsa
description: At the Apollo Theater on Saturday afternoon Goya Foods provided samples, as if the lobby were a supermarket. There was free coffee and wafers with dulce de leche filling. One reliable purveyor of Latino products, promoting its brand, was sponsoring another: Ballet Hispanico.

title: New York Public Library Is in Talks to Sell Space
description: The New York Public Library is negotiating to sell five floors at 188 Madison Avenue, the former B. Altman department store at 34th Street. The building is also home to the Science, Industry and Business Library, which is to remain there. The library would not disclose the potential price or buyer, pending a conclusion of the deal, which is expected early in the new year. Proceeds are expected to go toward a plan to transform the librarys main Fifth Avenue site into a combined research and circulating library. The space in the B. Altman building includes two floors that the library has leased out since it bought about 15 percent of the building in 1993. The other floors are used for administration; staff members there will move elsewhere. The B. Altman building also houses the City University of New York Graduate Center and the Oxford University Press.

title: Etta James Is Terminally Ill
description: Etta James, the seminal R&B singer, is terminally ill, according to her doctor, Elaine James  (who is not related to Etta James). Dr. James told The Press-Enterprise in Riverside, Calif., that family members were told two weeks ago that Ms. Jamess chronic leukemia could not be cured. I am Southern and Christian and would just ask for the prayers of her fans and friends, Dr. James said. They know shes been sick, but not how sick. Etta James, 73, has been among the most celebrated American blues singers for decades, recording enduring hits like At Last, Tell Mama and Id Rather Go Blind. She was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993. Her career was also influenced by drug addiction, troubled love relationships and health and legal problems. In 2010 she was hospitalized for a staph infection, and it became public that she was suffering from Alzheimers disease, and that she had been treated for dependence on painkillers. Dr. James has cared for Etta James, above, at her home in Riverside since March 2010, and she made the statements last week outside a hearing over control of Ms. Jamess $1 million estate. Donato James, her son, has been fighting in court with her husband, Artis Mills, over who will be named the estates conservator.

title: Jacobs Pillow Announces Its Summer Slate
description: Jacobs Pillow will put on a weeklong homage to the choreography of its founder, Ted Shawn, as part of an unusual and ambitious lineup for its 80th summer dance festival in Becket, Mass. The rotating cast for the series of performances in honor of Shawn starting on July 11 will include about 20 prominent male dancers, among them Arthur Mitchell of the Dance Theater of Harlem, the tap-dance specialist Jason Samuels Smith and the former New York City Ballet principal Jock Soto. The schedule for the festival, to run from June 16 to Aug. 26, was released on Sunday. Among the other highlights of this years festival are a rare United States performance by the Hong Kong Ballet of Kinsun Chans Black on Black; a world premiere by the Swedish choreographer and dancer Pontus Lidberg, performed by Morphoses; and a collaboration between Jonah Bokaer and David Hallberg. This year Ella Baff, the executive and artistic director of Jacobs Pillow, decided to break with that institutions tradition of offering mostly new works. She programmed repeat performances of three popular dances from past festivals: Tero Saarinens Shaker-inspired Borrowed Light from 2006, Crystal Pites Dark Matters from last summer and Doug Elkinss Frulein Maria from 2009. I hope to encourage the public to consider more contemporary dance works as classics, to be revisited in the same way that we enjoy and deepen our appreciation for classic works of music, theater and the visual arts, Ms. Baff said in a statement. (Below, Shawn as the biblical Jacob on Pillow Rock.)

title: Good Minus God
description: I was heartened to learn recently that atheists are no longer the most reviled group in the United States: according to the political scientists Robert Putnam and David Campbell, weve been overtaken by the Tea Party. But even as I was high-fiving my fellow apostates (Were number two! Were number two!), I was wondering anew: why do so many people dislike atheists?

title: Monday: Where Folks Get Into Hot Water
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Todays constructor, Richard Chisholm, has not been seen around these parts for almost a year, but hes actually a fairly prolific puzzle maker. Mr. Chisholm has had crosswords published in The New York Times on all days of the week except for those most difficult days, Friday and Saturday. Come on, Mr. Chisholm; hit for the cycle already. Not that that makes a good constructor; hitting for the cycle is not really any more important than producing a puzzle that happens to be a pangram. It would just be fun to add another constructor to the list of those who have already done so.

title: Back to Earth: Giants Go Flat, Imperiling Playoff Bid
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A year ago, Justin Tuck roused the Giants from a first-half slumber against the Jacksonville Jaguars with a stirring halftime speech. Tuck, the teams defensive captain, came into the locker room, ranted about how the Jaguars were disrespecting the Giants in their own home and challenged everyone to rise up. It was fiery and ferocious, teammates said, and the Giants responded, rallying from an 11-point deficit to win by 4.

title: The Queen of Cable TV
description: Early in Bonnie Hammers first stint running a cable network, she knew something was wrong. The SciFi channel was emerging as a destination for fans of the genre, largely on her strategy of reviving the mini-series.
