title: Apple App Makers on Edge for Holidays
description: On Christmas morning, millions of people will unwrap new iPads, iPhones and iPod Touches  and immediately start downloading games and other applications for them. It is the biggest day of the year for app sales, which can mean big money for developers.

title: Dont Tax the Rich. Tax Inequality Itself.
description: THE progressive reformer and eminent jurist Louis D. Brandeis once said, We may have democracy, or we may have wealth concentrated in the hands of a few, but we cannot have both. Brandeis lived at a time when enormous disparities between the rich and the poor led to violent labor unrest and ultimately to a reform movement.

title: Asuka
description: Ballet Hispanico gave the premiere of a work based on the singer Celia Cruz.

title: Reliving the Best (and Worst) Ads of 2011
description: MANY of the best advertisements of 2011 had something in common: celebrities, whether in front of the camera or behind it.

title: At an Iowa Church, Perry Takes On the Role of Faith in Government
description: CHARLES CITY, Iowa  First Wesleyan Church is about as far away as you can imagine from the brightly-lit debate halls and smart-alecky pundits who have bedeviled Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on his long slide from Republican presidential frontrunner.

title: Des Moines Register Endorsement Has a Mixed Predictive Track Record
description: A couple of weeks ago we looked at the track record of candidates endorsed by The Union Leader of New Hampshire, and found that they had historically performed quite strongly. Their actual vote share in the New Hampshire primary exceeded their standing in the polls at the time the endorsement was made by about 11 points on average.

title: A Sequence That Summed Up the Giants
description: A capsule look at the Giants 23-10 loss to the Redskins on Sunday:

title: Giants Replay: Week 15
description: The Redskins hurt the Giants and their playoff hopes with a dominating 23-10 victory.

title: Cesria vora, Singer From Cape Verde, Dies at 70
description: Cesria vora, who brought the music of the tiny Cape Verde islands off Senegal to a worldwide audience, died on Saturday in Mindelo, on So Vicente, her native island in Cape Verde. She was 70.

title: Gardens Roar Sounds Genuine as Retooled Knicks Work Out
description: The lights dimmed just before noon Sunday at the newly remodeled Madison Square Garden, and 10,500 Knicks fans, eager to see their newly remodeled team after the long N.B.A. lockout, began to roar.

title: Bumbling Jets Cannot Contend With the Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA  Mark Sanchez lay face down on the grass early in the second quarter Sunday, his body twisted in a position as uncomfortable as the Jets day at Lincoln Financial Field. He had just fumbled deep in Jets territory, facilitating a 28-point first-half outburst by the Philadelphia Eagles, and for a few seconds he remained on his stomach, as if reluctant to watch any more of what deteriorated into a grisly and comprehensive defeat.

title: Mitt Romneys Lucrative Continuing Relationship
description: Mitt Romney stepped down as the head of Bain Capital in 1999, but he received a share of the profits in 22 new funds created by the firm during the next 10 years. In that time, the companys assets under management grew 20-fold.

title: A New Childrens Book Parodies a Beloved Classic
description: Was 2011 the year of the irreverent picture book?

title: Avoiding the Trap of Big-Time, Big-Money Sports
description: At the conclusion of a program to celebrate his return to Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan last week, the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr. spoke about an initiative to heal the spirit of America. Specifically, Forbes, who was the senior minister at Riverside Church for 18 years, called for a great awakening.

title: Bonnie Prudden, 97, Dies; Promoted Fitness for TV Generation
description: Bonnie Prudden, whose alarm over the flabbiness of American children propelled her to become one of the most visible postwar champions of physical fitness, died on Dec. 11 at her home in Tucson. She was 97.

title: Digital Data on Patients Raises Risk of Breaches
description: One afternoon last spring, Micky Tripathi received a panicked call from an employee. Someone had broken into his car and stolen his briefcase and company laptop along with it.

title: Messi Not Ready to Pass the Torch
description: It is tempting to describe this years FIFA Club World Cup final as men against boys  so completely and easily did Barcelona outplay the Brazilian team Santos on Sunday night in Yokohama, Japan.

title: Military Clashes with Protesters for Third Day
description: Egypts ruling military and the protesters who demand they immediately step down battled for a third day in the streets on Sunday.

title: A Comic Distributes Himself
description: Louis C. K. is something of a pirate in the entertainment world, a man who has ignored propriety on his way to building a huge comic franchise. So its odd to see him put one of his shows for sale on the Web and politely ask fans not to rip him off.

title: Bob Brookmeyer, Jazz Musician and Educator, Dies at 81
description: Bob Brookmeyer, who left a distinctive mark on jazz as a musician, composer, arranger and educator whose students included many of todays leading jazz arrangers and bandleaders, died on Thursday in New London, N.H., four days before his 82nd birthday.

title: Iraq After the U.S. Military Withdrawal
description: A look at Baghdad, Iraqi governance and regional disputes after the U.S. military withdrawal.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Aided by Amnesty Clause, Knicks Are to Sign Davis
description: Baron Davis is set to join the Knicks, continuing their rapid makeover. Davis, 32, was cut last week by the Cleveland Cavaliers, who used the N.B.A.s amnesty clause to remove the final two years and $28.7 million of his contract from the salary cap. His Knicks contract will be for one year and $2.5 million, according to Sports Illustrated.

title: New Digital Leader at Rodale
description: While holiday shoppers are busy buying iPads, Kindles and other e-readers, the magazine publisher Rodale is snapping up one of the executives behind Nook, Barnes & Nobles line of e-readers.

title: More Low-Key Than His Predecessor, NBC Sports Chief Still Aims High
description: For Mark Lazarus, the chairman of the NBC Sports Group, quail hunting offers a consuming escape  walking through fields with his sons, friends or colleagues, along with the pointers that flush the birds into the sky. The action reminds him of a vigorous round of golf rather than sitting in a blind calling for ducks.

title: 10 Years of Assessing Students With Scientific Exactitude
description: In the last decade, we have emerged from the Education Stone Age. No longer must we rely on primitive tools like teachers and principals to assess childrens academic progress. Thanks to the best education minds in Washington, Albany and Lower Manhattan, we now have finely calibrated state tests aligned with the highest academic standards. What follows is a look back at New Yorks long march to a new age of accountability.

title: Instability a New Fear for Investors in Russia
description: MOSCOW  The street protests in Moscow that have raised the prospect of deep political reforms have had the opposite effect on the countrys stock exchange: it has plummeted faster than any other major equity market in the world over the last two weeks.

title: Fast-Food Outlet Stirs Concerns in a Mecca of Healthy Living
description: LOMA LINDA, Calif.  In this small city, home to a large Seventh-day Adventist community, the average lifespan goes well past 80, and it has one of the highest rates of longevity in the world according to some estimates.

title: Penalty Flags for Jets; White Flag on Season?
description: A capsule look at the Jets 45-19 loss to the Eagles on Sunday:

title: After a Brothers Death, Moving Into the Empty Space
description: NORTHFIELD, N.J.  This was to be the year that the Brenner brothers, Casey and Ryan, would receive their varsity football letters together. But on the night of the Mainland Regional High School team banquet, Ryan dressed alone for the event in his older brothers bedroom, where he moved after Casey died in a car accident last summer.

title: Found and Lost
description: One year has passed since the police went looking for a missing woman, Shannan Gilbert, in the marshy thickets of a barrier island off Long Islands South Shore. They didnt find her, but they stumbled on something baffling and horrifying: evidence of an unnoticed, uncaught serial killer.

title: Iranian TV Airs Video It Claims Is of U.S. Spy
description: Iranian state television broadcast video images on Sunday of a man who it said was a captured American spy sent to infiltrate Irans intelligence services.

title: Help for Homeless Veterans
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development have announced modest but real progress in the effort to house homeless veterans. A count of people living in shelters and on the street in 400 communities on one night in January found 12 percent fewer veterans than at the same time last year  67,495, compared with 76,329 in 2010. The percentage of homeless veterans living in shelters and transitional housing was also slightly better, up by 2 percent.

title: The Trouble With That Revolving Door
description: Last week, an inside-the-Beltway newsletter, First Street, published a unique top-ten list. It reveals which former members of Congress are among the most important Washington lobbyists.

title: States of Conflict: A Final Update
description: A VERSION of this chart has been appearing in the Op-Ed pages every few months for eight years. The first was published eight months after the invasion of Iraq, and data from the conflicts in Afghanistan and Pakistan were added in more recent years. Gains have been made in these three countries, but violence persists and peace is by no means assured. Nonetheless, with the end of the war in Iraq officially announced last week, this will be the last of the series.

title: Are Presidential Pardons Fair?
A Melding of the Artists Politics and the Politicians Art
description: With Vaclav Havel, the Czech author and playwright, it is impossible to separate the artists politics from the politicians art. He was both a witness and a communicant, repeatedly exploring, in the words of the title of one of his essays, the power of the powerless.

title: Channels Swift Rise Attracts Ads and Envy
description: Last year, the History channel had a growth spurt, gaining hundreds of thousands of viewers while most of its competitors struggled to grow at all. This year, even more remarkably, the channel did it again.

title: Tebow and Broncos Have No Comeback for Patriots
description: DENVER  At a busy shopping strip Saturday afternoon, there was a man dressed as a robot meant to entertain and lure frantic Christmas shoppers. At one point, as a few men strolled by, the robot yelled, Now, Ill Tebow for you! and he dropped to one knee and lowered his head in an imitation of the now well-known pose of the quarterback who has captivated the N.F.L. this season. The men  a few of them wearing Patriots jerseys  laughed and kept moving. They, after all, have seen pretenders before.

title: Overhaul Brings in Baron Davis
description: Baron Davis is set to join the Knicks, continuing a rapid makeover made possible by the N.B.A.s new amnesty provision.

title: As Gingrichs Star Rises, So Do His Partys Concerns
description: WASHINGTON  From the House that Newt Gingrich once ran through the Washington establishment to state capitals across the nation, some Republicans are going public with their concerns that Mr. Gingrich would be a weak general election candidate and a drag on the partys fortunes if he won the presidential nomination.

title: Making a List, and Taking It to the Pawnshop
description: Children in San Mateo, Calif., whispered their wish lists to Santa Claus this weekend at Best Collateral, a pawnshop in a strip mall about 20 miles south of San Francisco.

title: Gingrich and Romney Tack Right, but Leave a Path Back to the Middle
description: WASHINGTON  Through the long march of 2011 debates ending last week, Republican presidential candidates have leaned right  so far right, Democrats hope, that the ultimate nominee will fall next November.

title: Lessons of the Deepwater Horizon
description: The latest investigative report on the Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, released Wednesday, is an important reminder of industrys past carelessness and a summons to vigilance in the future. It could not have been more timely, coming just as the Interior Department was concluding its first auction of new drilling leases in the gulf since the spill.

title: Shes Warm, Easy to Talk to, and a Source of Terror for Private-School Parents
description: Elisabeth Krents loves eating hot fudge sundaes, reading Wilkie Collins novels and trying, often unsuccessfully, to grow tomatoes.

title: Rules Stretched as Green Cards Go to Investors
description: Affluent foreigners are rushing to take advantage of a federal immigration program that offers them the chance to obtain a green cardin return for investing in construction projects in the United States. With credit tight, the program has unexpectedly turned into a mainstay for the financing of these projects in New York, California, Texas and other states.

title: Will China Break?
description: Consider the following picture: Recent growth has relied on a huge construction boom fueled by surging real estate prices, and exhibiting all the classic signs of a bubble. There was rapid growth in credit  with much of that growth taking place not through traditional banking but rather through unregulated shadow banking neither subject to government supervision nor backed by government guarantees. Now the bubble is bursting  and there are real reasons to fear financial and economic crisis.

title: A Stranger at the Door
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: De Blasio Backs Wage Bill in a Challenge to Quinn
description: With the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, courting business leaders as she prepares to run for mayor, Bill de Blasio, the public advocate and one of her chief rivals, has thrown his support behind a much-disputed bill that would increase wages for workers in city-subsidized development projects  a move that could force Ms. Quinn to take a position on the issue.

title: A Fraction of a Tax Cut
description: If you looked quickly at what the Senate did on Saturday, it seemed as if it agreed to President Obamas proposal for short-term middle-class relief by extending the payroll tax cut and unemployment insurance. In fact, thats not quite what happened.

title: Struggling to Catch Up, a Giants Rookie Defensive Back Is Finally Benched
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  This has not been the sort of rookie season that Prince Amukamara envisioned when the Giants selected him in the first round of the draft in April.

title: Disruptions: Wearing Your Computer on Your Sleeve
description: Technology often has a way of fixing the problems it creates. Heres one that needs solving.

title: Lottery Numbers
G.O.P. Contests Near, and the Pace Picks Up
description: With voting to begin in Iowa nine days after Christmas, the Republican presidential contest has become intense and frenetic. The week ahead will feature a dizzying amount of travel, wall-to-wall campaign advertising in the early-voting states and stump speeches delivered with new intensity.

title: Along a Block in Brooklyn, Wary Residents Ponder the Murder of an Officer
description: For much of the past week, police officers have searched a block of Pine Street in Brooklyn for the bullet that killed Officer Peter J. Figoski. They have even examined tree branches and the upper reaches of nearby two-family homes, from a cherry picker. Yet the slug seems to have disappeared.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include housing starts for November (Tuesday); sales of existing homes for November (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, third-quarter gross domestic product (final), the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for November, and leading economic indicators for November (Thursday); durable goods for November, personal income and spending for November, and sales of new homes for November (Friday).

title: Kim Jong-il, Dictator Who Turned North Korea Into a Nuclear State, Dies
description: Called the Dear Leader by his people, Kim Jong-il presided with an iron hand over a country he kept on the edge of starvation and collapse, fostering perhaps the last personality cult in the Communist world even as he banished citizens deemed disloyal to gulags or sent assassins after defectors.

title: In a Study, Judges Express a Bleak View of Lawyers Representing Immigrants
description: They are often poorly prepared or make incoherent arguments in court. Some fail to present key evidence or witnesses. Others simply do not show up.

title: Private Investment Rounds Weaken I.P.O.s
description: Facebooks initial public offering will grab plenty of headlines in 2012. But as Zyngas tepid debut last week shows, multiple private investment rounds and the ability to trade shares before going public mean slim pickings when public market investors finally get their chance to own Silicon Valleys emerging heavyweights. That is one reason the average I.P.O. this year has wound up trading about 10 percent below its offer price.

title: Letter on Living Wage in New York City
description: Bill de Blasio, Public Advocate for New York City, writes in support of passing a Living Wage bill for the citys economic development projects.

title: For Election Year, MTV Drops Choose or Lose Slogan
description: After nearly 20 years of Choose or Lose, MTV is changing the name of its election season campaign.

title: Buyout Profits Keep Flowing to Romney
description: Almost 13 years ago, Mitt Romney left Bain Capital, the successful private equity firm he had helped start, and moved to Utah to rescue the Salt Lake City Olympic Games and begin a second career in public life.

title: Jets Replay: Week 15
description: A look at the Jets 45-19 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Even at 6-8, Philadelphia Keeps Alive Its Hope of Winning the N.F.C. East
description: PHILADELPHIA  Judging from the empty seats at Lincoln Financial Field, there is a vacancy of hope among many Eagles fans near the end of this maddening season.

title: Pakistani Crisis Prompts Leader to Race Home
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A tense showdown between Pakistans powerful army and its besieged civilian government brought President Asif Ali Zardari hurrying back from Dubai early on Monday, after weeks of growing concerns by his supporters that the military has been moving to strengthen its role in the countrys governance.

title: Air Force Drone Operators Report High Levels of Stress
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly half the operators of drone aircraft have high levels of job-related stress, mostly linked to long and erratic work hours because of a tremendous increase in the use of the aircraft, the Air Force said in a new study.

title: Private Torment Trumps Terrorism
description: No government mole was unmasked, and the C.I.A. officer Carrie Mathison (Claire Danes) was not vindicated. The finale of Homeland wasnt entirely satisfying, but it did end with a jolt. Sgt. Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis) failed to blow himself up; it was Carrie who ended up on a hospital bed, twitching under a round of electroshock treatment.

title: Corrections: December 19
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: NYT Front Page for 12/19/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/19/2011

title: Sports Replay: Dec. 18
description: The day in sports, featuring pro football, including two firsts, pro basketball and womens handball in Brazil.

title: Word of the Day | frantic
description: frantic \fran-tik\ adjective

title: After Yearlong Competition, Mayor Is Said to Pick Cornell for Science School
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to announce on Monday that he has chosen Cornell University to create a new science graduate school on Roosevelt Island, capping an intense yearlong competition in his ambitious bid to spur a boom in New York Citys high-tech sector.

title: Exonerated of Murder, Texan Seeks Inquiry on Prosecutor
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A Texas man wrongfully convicted in 1987 of murdering his wife is scheduled to be officially exonerated on Monday.

title: Many in U.S. Are Arrested by Age 23, Study Finds
description: By age 23, almost a third of Americans have been arrested for a crime, according to a new study that researchers say is a measure of growing exposure to the criminal justice system in everyday life.

title: M.I.T. Expands Its Free Online Courses
description: While students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology pay thousands of dollars for courses, the university will announce a new program on Monday allowing anyone anywhere to take M.I.T. courses online free of charge  and for the first time earn official certificates for demonstrating mastery of the subjects taught.

title: Little to Show for Strong Work Ethic and a Degree
description: Abdulla Chowdhury was telling the story of how he took his young daughter shopping recently for a winter coat, and the memory was enough to make him bury his head in his hands. In his wallet had been a $20 bill. On the coat rack, many options sure to please his daughter. But the cheapest coat cost $50. So the money stayed in his pocket and the coat remained on the rack. The moment crystallized one of Mr. Chowdhurys worst fears: his inability to provide for his two children the way his parents had provided for him.

title: Monday Matchup: Steelers at 49ers
description: Steelers at 49ers, 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: 49ers by 3

title: Kim Jong-il, North Korean Dictator, Dies
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Jong-il, the North Korean leader who realized his familys dream of turning his starving, isolated country into a nuclear-weapons power even as it sank further into despotism, died on Saturday of a heart attack while traveling on his train, according to an announcement Monday by the countrys state-run media.

title: On North Korean State Television, News of the Leaders Death and Floods of Tears
description: Updated | 12:55 p.m. As our colleagues Choe Sang-hun and David Sanger report, Kim Jong-il, the mysterious and mercurial dictator of North Korea, has died. The news rippled across the globe Sunday night after the countrys official news media proclaimed the leader dead by way of a black-clad television announcer who appeared to be holding back tears.

title: Coming to Amritsar, the Pod Car
description: Bangalore, Kolkata and Delhi may have the Metro, but Amritsar will soon have the Pod.

title: Kims Death Inspires Worries and Anxiety
description: LONDON  The death of Kim Jong-il provoked uncertainty, anxiety and calls for a peaceful succession on Monday as governments within the region and beyond awaited some signal from North Korea about its nuclear intentions and the prospects, if any, for a new relationship with the world beyond its borders.

title: North Koreas Elusive Leader
description: Called the Dear Leader by his people, Kim Jong-il, the son of North Koreas founder, remained an unknowable figure.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 19, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Dec. 19, 1997 | The Film Titanic Premieres
description: On Dec. 19, 1997, James Camerons $200 million epic Titanic opened in American theaters. The film went on to gross more than $1.8 billion worldwide, a record that stood until 2010, when Mr. Camerons Avatar surpassed it.

title: Test Yourself | Dec. 19, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Philbin Packs Up His Desk, but Not His Stories.

title: Banking Worries Send Stocks Lower in U.S.
description: Financial stocks fell by more than 2 percent in the United States on Monday and shares were mixed in Europe after remarks by European Central Bank officials and the prospect of increasing capital requirements suggested further challenges ahead for banks.

title: Trimming the Traps
description: HOW many lobster traps make up the Christmas tree display shared by the Maine towns of Beals and Jonesport?HOW tall is the tree?

title: An Urbanizing India Faces Natural Disaster Risk
description: The number of people exposed to natural disasters is expected to more than double to 1.5 billion by 2050, with 200 million of them in India, because of rapid urbanization and the extreme weather stemming from climate change, according to the World Bank.

title: Orton May Have Chance at Revenge in Finale in Denver
description: Kansas Citys playoff chances were slimmer than slim* heading into Sundays game against Green Bay. The Chiefs stunning victory kept them alive, but it also brought to light a possible dramatic development for Week 17.

title: Bearing Witness in Iraq
description: Baghdad, Iraq

title: What Will You Remember Most From 2011?
description: What national, international, cultural and personal events in 2011 stand out for you most? Why? To refresh your memory, you might first take our 2011 news quiz, and watch the Year in Rap video weve posted above it. Which of these events seems most important? Why?

title: Saudi Prince Invests $300 Million in Twitter
description: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has taken a $300 million stake in the social media start-up Twitter, adding an emerging brand name to an international investment portfolio that largely includes established giants like Apple, Citigroup and Walt Disney.

title: The Early Word: Rejected
description: In Todays Times:

title: As Violence Continues, Egyptian General Blames Protesters
description: CAIRO  After four days of street fighting with protesters that has left 13 people dead, Egypts military rulers faced calls on Monday from the United States, the United Nations and a newly united front of Islamist and liberal political leaders to stop the violence.

title: Dining During a Roman Holiday
description: Contrary to popular belief, visitors to Rome during the winter holidays are not doomed to eat in tourist traps or at McDonalds. Many worthy restaurants throughout the city will be open during Christmas and New Years, albeit on abbreviated schedules. To handle the busy holiday season, many restaurants offer large, prix fixe tasting menus and, with a bit of planning, one can eat very well, for a price.

title: Feminisms Uneven Success
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Week 15 Quick Hits: Patriots Have Their Way
description: A quick look at every game from Week 15:

title: Candidates Pick Up the Pace as Iowa Vote Approaches
description: The pace of the contest for the Republican presidential nomination is picking up, with voting to begin in Iowa on Jan. 3. An article in Mondays Times reports on how the candidates plan to spend the coming days.

title: Back at Work, and Catching Up on Online Shopping
description: For online retailers, Monday could be another bonanza, as last-minute shoppers place their orders in time to get free shipping by Christmas.

title: Q&A: Converting Music File Formats
description: Q.

title: Tom Coughlins Remarks After Loss to Redskins
description: The full transcript is at Giants.com:

title: Why Playoff Tiebreaker Favors  Jets Over Bengals
description: As most Jets fans know by now, the Jets will almost certainly make the playoffs if they win their last two games and finish 10-6. Cincinnati is the only other playoff contender that could finish 10-6, but the Jets would most likely win the fourth tiebreaker, strength of victory. Those odds only increased when San Diego defeated Baltimore on Sunday night. Here is how it would break down.

title: This Week in Small Business: Making Lists
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: For Green Groups, a Shift in Tactics
description: In The Timess Sunday Review section, I wrote about the generational leadership change that big environmental groups are undergoing and how it is affecting their strategies. Several leaders and observers I interviewed noted that in an Occupy Wall Street era, some people have little patience for the notion of courting corporations and policy makers to seek their cooperation. They want to apply direct pressure.

title: Rex Ryan on Giants Game: Its Going to Be Ridiculous
description: A few excerpts from Rex Ryans talk with reporters after the loss to the Eagles on Sunday. The full transcript is at Jets.com:

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 19
description: Bonnie Hammers attention to detail and programming instincts at NBCUniversal networks like USA has made her possibly the most important executive in cable television, Bill Carter writes, and a critical piece of Comcasts takeover of the company last year. In her career, she identified Bob Vila as a host, taught Vince McMahon how to build story arcs into wrestling and made USA a powerhouse with shows like Royal Pains and Burn Notice. Yet the job she really wanted  turning out NBCs dismal primetime  somehow has escaped her. Mr. Carter writes:

title: Paul Moves Into Lead in Iowa Forecast
description: Our Iowa forecasts, which are designed to be quite aggressive, have had a big reaction to the new Public Policy Polling survey published late Sunday evening. The poll showed Newt Gingrichs support slipping badly in Iowa and Ron Paul moving into the lead.

title: Ad Spending Slowed to a Crawl in the 3rd Quarter, Report Finds
description: Like traffic on the way to the beach on a summer Friday afternoon, advertising spending in the third quarter barely moved, according to a report to be released on Monday morning.

title: Daily Report: An Apps Holiday
description: People who leave their Christmas shopping for the final hours are not the only ones feeling anxious these days. Developers of apps for Apple products are also stressed out, Jenna Wortham reports in Mondays New York Times.

title: Last-Minute Tinkering, Then Into the Oscar Race
description: The clock has been ticking on Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close, Stephen Daldrys adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foers novel. The film was a late entrant in the Oscar race, and subject to high speculation because of it, though a review embargo was in effect until yesterday. (David Denby didnt jump the gun on the Daldry.)

title: Opinion Report: The Deepwater Horizon
description: From the editorial page

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Saudi Prince Invests $300 Million in Twitter | Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia announced a $300 million investment in the social media site Twitter as he continued to expand his holdings in the United States.

title: Young Heir Faces Uncertain Transition in North Korea
description: TOKYO  With the abrupt death of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, the fate of his isolated, nuclear-armed regime has dropped into the hands of his youngest son, Kim Jong-un, who is such an unknown that the world did not even know for sure what he looked like until last year.

title: Despite Defeat, Tebow Is Playing Better
description: When he was winning in dramatic fashion, Tim Tebow was often criticized for his poor statistical performances.In defeat on Sunday, he played one of his better games, statistically and otherwise, with 2 touchdowns and 93 yards on the ground, and 194 passing yards.

title: Communication Tools That Can Lead to Trouble
China Exerts Influence Nurtured Over Decades
description: BEIJING  China, North Koreas foremost ally, appears to be moving quickly to try to ensure stability in a crippled and isolated nation now facing a leadership transition fraught with dangers.

title: Bi-Lo to Pay $9.50 a Share for Winn-Dixie
description: Bi-Lo agreed on Monday to buy Winn-Dixie Stores for about $560 million, uniting two of the Souths better-known regional supermarket operators.

title: Ravenous | In Praise of Parsley
description: Im partial to parsley, flat leaf and curly.

title: Hand-Washers Beware: Your iPod Nano Could Get Hurt
description: I love the thought of using the tiny iPod Nano as a wristwatch. It comes with 16 gorgeous animated watch faces, and in my recent column, I noted that you can even buy a variety of watchbands for it.

title: Monday Reading: Save Your Elite Flier Status While You Can
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Irish Competitiveness (Wonkish)
description: More abut Ireland: one of the reasons it has been touted as a great success story for austerity is the fact that unit labor costs have fallen sharply, suggesting that Ireland is well along in the process of internal devaluation.

title: The Plight of Chinas Favored Sons
description: ZHUHAI, China  In the rural Chinese town where Li Yiming grew up, the gossip mill starts to turn if a man is still single at 25. As he nears this milestone, the 23-year-old Li, an assembly-line worker in the coastal city of Zhuhai, is despondent. He knows hell never earn enough at any factory to win the approval of his girlfriends parents.

title: The Coming War for the Social Workplace
description: The hard-nosed competition for billions in corporate software spending is heading for an improbable showdown: Will the boss like that product prototyping cost projection?

title: Complaint Box | Sidewalk Gum
description: I had seen the blobs before  but it wasnt until I lost my hearing aid that I had an in-your-face encounter with them. While searching for the device, I retraced my steps  same elevator, same route, focusing like a mine sweeper, gazing left to right, right to left  but my view was blocked by chewed-up pieces of gum in varying stages of decay, from light-colored, freshly spat out, to deeply embedded, flat and black.

title: Keynesophobia
description: Dean Baker is once again justifiably mad at Robert Samuelson. It is indeed frustrating that after three years in which Keynesian predictions have been spectacularly correct, pundits insist on reading the evidence as a rejection of Keynes.

title: Putting Many Fingers on the Trigger
description: The body of Police Officer Peter J. Figoski will be returned to the earth on Monday after the last bagpipe and muffled drum have sounded, a farewell guided by decades of tradition. There is another, less ennobling convention, and it has been observed with zeal ever since a wretch fired a shot that took Officer Figoskis life a week ago.

title: Maya Angelou Says Shes Disappointed With Rapper After Collaboration
description: 4:18 p.m. | Updated

title: With London Listing, Polymetal Chief Looks to Expand
description: LONDON  As the Russian gold producer Polymetal joins a major British stock index, its chief executive is seeking to attract international investors and expand its operations, mainly in the former Soviet Union.

title: With Twitter, Walid Adds a New Brand to His Portfolio
description: By buying a $300 million stake in Twitter, is Prince Walid bin Talal anointing the social media network as another established brand name?

title: Bloomberg TV Hires Former CNBC Anchor
description: 10:40 a.m. | Updated | For the third time this month, a former CNBC anchor has found a new job at a CNBC rival.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Los Angeles Times: The tantalizing prospect of a domestic mango crop inches closer, according to the fruit detective David Karp.Julia Moskin

title: Defying Police Crackdown, Kazakh Protests Continue
description: MOSCOW  Hundreds of people took to the streets in western Kazakhstan on Monday in defiance of a bloody police crackdown on striking oil workers that has caused dozens of casualties in the Central Asian nation.

title: Hungarys Constitutional Revolution
description: Last week I devoted a column to the unsettling political developments in Hungary. To expand on all this, Ive asked my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, who has been working extensively on the situation, to contribute a post. Its below the fold.

title: Cash Mobs Promote Spending (and Socializing) Locally
description: Updated at 11:04 a.m. / To reflect that another cash mob was held last week in Cleveland.

title: Charting Drake and Chop Care
description: On the mixtape Chop Care, the Houston DJ and record executive OG Ron C has chopped and screwed Drakes hit rap album Take Care. That is, hes slowed it way down, cut it up and stretched it out, like something youd want to hear full of cold medicine in your bed. The artist Andrew Kuo prefers it to the original, and here he breaks it down.

title: Assessing Giants Cornerback Prince Amukamara
description: Toward the end of Coach Tom Coughlins news conference Sunday, a reporter asked for his assessment of the rookie cornerback Prince Amukamara. Coughlin hesitated. Then he said, It seemed like they threw the ball in that direction and we were not having a lot of success.

description: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier fed streams.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Health Care Case in Late March
description: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would devote three days in late March to hearing arguments in challenges to the 2010 health care overhaul law. A decision in the case is expected by the end of June.

title: The Queen of the Bistro Playlist
description: If youre like me, you mourned the passing of Cesria vora over the weekend. And if you happened to spin a few of her albums on Saturday and Sunday afternoon, maybe while roasting dinner, its not impossible that her songs summoned up the memory of a few excellent meals.

title: Tacos for the Holidays
description: The holiday season can be like an ongoing house party. Children are home from school, their friends are coming by, relatives are in from out of town, and one meal follows the next. One way to meet the challenge of feeding everybody is to pick up a supply of corn tortillas (all the better if more locally made) and make a big pot of beans and some other dishes that are at home in a taco. Buy a few jars of salsa, or make your own, and your house will be taco party central during the busy holiday week.

Some of the reaction online to the article suggested that Mr. Parker was reminiscent of Steve Jobs, a founder of Apple, who died in October at 56. I believe it is too soon to make that comparison. The next five years are crucial for Mr. Parker, who has yet to prove he is an influential force in Silicon Valley.

description: Who: the businesswoman Wendi Murdoch

description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog. His new book, The Behavior Gap, will be out in January.

description: LONDON  The British government plans stricter banking regulations that would force banks to separate their investment banking operations from those businesses that take deposits.

The animating force in Stieg Larssons Millennium trilogy  incarnated on screen first by Noomi Rapace and now, in David Finchers adaptation of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, by Rooney Mara  Lisbeth is an outlaw feminist fantasy-heroine, and also an avatar of digital antiauthoritarianism.

description: Robert Samuelson today:

At most airports, such a traveler has few options: wandering through the nearby shops and restaurants, waiting in a chair near the gate or, for a fee, waiting in an airline lounge.

description: BAGHDAD  A day after the United States withdrew its last combat troops, Iraq faced a dangerous political crisis Monday as the Shiite-dominated government ordered the arrest of the Sunni vice president, accusing him of running a death squad that assassinated police officers and government officials.

description: OTTAWA  European Goldfields agreed on Sunday to an all-stock takeover by Eldorado Gold valued at 2.5 billion Canadian dollars, but some analysts believe that other bids may now emerge.

No Bail for Man Accused of Burning Woman Alive
description: Jerome Isaac entered the courtroom in handcuffs and a white Tyvek suit, bearing what appeared to be the aftereffects of a horrific crime. Red, glistening blotches dotted his cheek and neck; his lip and left eye were badly swollen.

description: Kim Jong-un succeeds his father; the view from China, North Koreas foremost ally; and Nicholas D. Kristof on Kim Jong-ils impact on his people.

title: Start the Pajama Party
description: HERES a bit of good news for 11th-hour shoppers: Creatures of Comfort, the year-old NoLIta boutique by way of Los Angeles, has added silk pajamas to its private label for the holidays. I remember looking for these pajamas and not finding them except when I visited Asia, said Jade Lai, the owner. So last year I made my holiday wish list for things to stock this season, and silk pajamas were on the top of the list. The luxurious unisex pajamas come in eight different color combinations, including navy blue with red piping, as well as black, white, lavender and emerald green, all with contrasting piping. Silky PJs from Creatures of Comfort? Sounds right.

title: Elevation of the Chimp May Reshape Research
description: When Dr. Francis S. Collins, the head of the National Institutes of Health, announced Thursday that the government would halt all new grants for research on chimpanzees, it was, in one sense, a familiar Washington moment.

title: In the Images of War, Reflections and Lessons Learned
description: From the early days of the Iraq war, images from photojournalists on the ground provided a glimpse of the the triumphs and shortcomings of a conflict that polarized the American people. As photographers pack up their equipment to return home, one reflects in a post today on the Lens blog on the memories and lessons created while in Iraq.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.19
description: The day in sports included the Arab Games, which continued in Doha, Qatar, as well as World Cup skiing in Alta Badia, Italy.

title: Prague and Pyongyang
description: The deaths of Vaclav Havel and Kim Jong Il within a 24-hour span are more than a reminder of the extremes of heroism and iniquity that coexist in human affairs. Theyre a reminder of how much successful political heroism depends, in the end, on the ability to prick the conscience of iniquity, and to remind even the worst regimes and most compromised authorities that there are moral absolutes which they transgress at their peril. The great success of the Velvet Revolution, like the successes of Gandhi and Mandela and Martin Luther King and so many other icons of peaceful revolution, was achieved by public argument as well as by public protest, and by the fact that the bureaucrats and apparatchiks and generals the revolutionaries were confronting werent willing to take the most absolute and unthinkable steps to retain their privileges and defend their power. (In David Chappells A Stone of Hope, a history of religion and the civil rights movement, theres a fascinating account of how this worked in the white South  the way that the Christian appeals of King and Ralph Abernathy and Co. persuaded many white Christians that they had a moral obligation to stand by and let the revolution happen, rather than defend Jim Crow to the end.) When civil disobedience works, it does so by reminding the inhumane of their inhumanity, and by finding the vulnerabilities in what seem like permanently hardened hearts. In this sense, theres a circular quality to any successful peaceful revolt: No De Klerk without Mandela but also no Mandela (as we know Mandela) without De Klerk; no Gorbachev without Sakharov and Walesa and Havel, but no Havel and Walesa (as we know them) without Gorbachev.

description: We just published an important article from Jack Healy in Baghdad:

description: Arkansas State Universitys new head football coach figures to earn at least four times as much money as his predecessor.

The survey results among registered Republicans in national polls over the last month show persistent signs of an electorate in search of a nominee.

description: Warren Hellman, a Wall Street investor who was president of Lehman Brothers and whose passion for bluegrass inspired him to create a San Francisco music festival that draws hundreds of thousands of people a year, died on Sunday in San Francisco. He was 77.

description: Babies born only three weeks prematurely face an increased risk of behavioral and emotional problems as preschoolers, a new analysis has found.

description: Statins, among the most commonly prescribed drugs for the prevention of cardiovascular disease, also appear to reduce the risk for death in patients hospitalized with the flu.

description: MIAMI  Rebuffing the governor, Florida A&Ms board of trustees on Monday decided not to suspend the universitys president and asserted that it would stand firm against outside influences, no matter how well intended.

description: Change is the N.B.A.s only true constant. With that in mind, here is a look at the teams poised for substantial changes in their offensive performance:

title: Supportive Steps After a Sexual Assault
description: Do you know what to do if you or someone close to you becomes the victim of a sexual assault? A national survey released last week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention indicated that sexual assaults are far more common than previously believed, with nearly one woman in five reporting that she had been the victim of rape or attempted rape.

title: The Year in Media | My Channel, Myself
description: Staff members of The Timess media news department are highlighting the most significant developments this year in the industries they cover.

title: A Matter of Time
Black Hole Forecast: A Cold Gas Cloud
description: For the past 20 years, astrophysicists have been watching stars and other space matter swirling aroundSagittariusA* (pronounced A-star),the black holeat the center of the Milky Way. Butthey have never seen anything sucked into it (or any other black hole, for that matter).

title: Should Students and Teachers Be Facebook Friends?
description: Should schools regulate or ban communications between teachers and students by cellphone, Facebook or e-mail? Jennifer Preston, a Times reporter, found districts in New York State and across the country scrambling to create a social media policy in the wake of a few inappropriate relationships that included electronic communications. A district in Georgia has banned private electronic communication entirely; Missouri is revamping such a rule after teachers persuaded a judge that the proposed law was unconstitutional.

title: New Girl on Fox Gets a Lift From DVR Use
description: Fox received a bit of good news from the latest DVR rankings report, which includes the initial live broadcast viewership figures and DVR-playback numbers for the next seven days. For the week of Nov. 28 to Dec. 5, the freshman comedy New Girl on Fox not only posted the largest gain in total viewers, 3.1 million, but it also had the largest ratings increase in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic considered important to advertisers. (The show reached 10.7 million viewers, up from 7.6 million.)

title: Honor of a Lifetime, Arriving Too Late
description: When Alfred B. Nobel created the prizes that bear his name, he decreed that they be given for work done in the preceding year. A seemingly simple provision, intuitively sensible to anyone who follows the Oscars, the Emmys or the Pulitzers.

title: Muppet Show Continues: Museum Extends Jim Henson Exhibition
description: Not unlike the ending of a certain hit movie that found the Muppets mobbed by fans they didnt realize they had, the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, has learned that a lot of people really like Jim Hensons creations  enough that it is extending the retrospective on that artist and puppeteer by almost two months. On Monday, the museum said that Jim Hensons Fantastic World, the traveling Smithsonian exhibition on the life and work of the Muppets creator, will now run through March 4; it was originally scheduled to close on Jan. 16.

title: Closer Look at S.E.C.s Mortgage Fraud Charges
description: The civil securities fraud charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against six former executives of the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac signal an aggressive turn in the pursuit of cases tied to the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Regimens: A Much Quicker Way to Treat Latent TB
description: The standard treatment for latent tuberculosis infection  that is, infection without symptoms  is nine months of daily doses of isoniazid, an antibiotic. The treatment is effective, but only about 60 percent of patients carry it out completely.

title: Genes Play Major Role in Primate Social Behavior, Study Finds
description: Social behavior among primates  including humans  has a substantial genetic basis, a team of scientists has concluded from a new survey of social structure across the primate family tree.

title: Uranium Mining in Virginia
description: A report of the National Research Council on the scientific, technical, environmental, human health and safety, and regulatory aspects of uranium mining and processing in Virginia.

title: Uranium Mining Debate in Virginia Takes a Step
description: WASHINGTON  The National Academy of Sciences delivered a long-awaited report on uranium mining to the Virginia legislature on Monday, warning that the state faced steep hurdles if it is to safely mine and process the nuclear reactor fuel.

title: Leishmaniasis: Extend Friendly American Hand to Iran? Doctor Says a Vaccine Is a Place to Start
description: A leading tropical medicine researcher has proposed that the United States extend a friendly hand to Iran  not over nuclear weapons or oil or Israel or Iraq, but over vaccines.

title: Maos Rockets and Modern War, Part III
description: Among the perennial tools of battlefield underdogs, the 107-millimeter rocket has a secure place. Like the assault rifle, the rocket-propelled grenade and the makeshift bomb, this class of weapon, first fielded by China and known as a Type 63, has been a consistent presence in recent wars, used by Palestinians against Israel, by Pakistani and Afghan fighters against Western and Afghan-government troops, by Iraqi insurgents and by both sides of the bitter contest this year for Libya. And that is only a partial list.

title: Saab Bankruptcy: Long Before the Fall, Innovations Aplenty
description: Barring an unforeseen rescue, Saabs long, strange trip through Swedish courts and Chinese office towers appears to be over.

title: Colleagues Recall Victim of Elevator Accident
description: At the beginning of the year, Suzanne Hart was assigned to oversee the redesign of her employers internal Web site, coordinating designers and technology specialists and countless others. The project could easily have taken seven or eight months.

title: Rangers Lose Two Defensemen as Staal Gets Closer to Return
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  There was bad news and good news for the Rangers injury-riddled defensive corps Monday.

title: Face Time | Tracee Ellis Ross
description: The final episode of the family sitcom Reed Between the Lines will air at 10 p.m. Tuesday on BET. I had a moment to chat with one of its stars and producers, Tracee Ellis Ross, a k a Dr. Carla Reed. I was excited to get the lowdown on her favorite beauty products, since Ive always been impressed by her skin, hair, flair for fashion and fearlessness in so many things  including lip color.

title: Exploring the Links Between Acetaminophen and Asthma
description: Is acetaminophen behind a sharp rise in asthma around the world over the past three decades?

title: They Sure Have Earned Their Vacation, Havent They?
description: There have been so many games of chicken on Capitol Hill in 2011 that it seems appropriate to end the year with the most irresponsible one yet. And even though the outcome will affect virtually everyone who gets a paycheck, no one seems to know whether it will end with a crash or a deal.

title: When Lobotomy Was Seen as Advanced
description: Most of us recall lobotomies as they were depicted in the movie One Flew over the Cuckoos Nest horrifying operations inappropriately used to control mentally ill patients. But in the 1950s, surgeons also used them to treat severe pain from cancer and other diseases.

title: How Hungry Mosquitoes Cool Themselves
description: Most blood-sucking insects urinate while they feed so they can avoid filling up on fluid and get more nutrients out of their meal.

title: New Musicals Struggle at Broadway Box Office
description: Several newly opened Broadway musicals struggled to sell tickets last week, according to box office data released on Monday, as holiday tourists and others appeared to favor long-running hits like The Lion King and star-driven productions like Hugh Jackmans one-man concert.

title: Phillies Keep Rollins, but What About Cole Hamels?
description: Jimmy Rollins made his major league debut with the Philadelphia Phillies in 2000. That season, the Phillies lost 97 games, finished last in the National League East and traded their best pitcher,Curt Schilling. Two years later, on their way to another losing season, they traded their best offensive player, Scott Rolen.

title: Romneys Gordon Gekko Moment
description: Our colleagues have an article in todays New York Times on Mitt Romney and his lucrative retirement agreement from Bain Capital, the private equity fund that he helped start. Mr. Romney received a share of the firms profits on all of its funds raised through February 2009, earning him millions of dollars that have helped fuel his political career.

title: A Walk Through Water Before Reaching Land
description: Roughly 400 million years ago, an ancient lobe-finned fish left its watery habitat to become the first four-limbed terrestrial creature. Its descendants  which are called tetrapods and include tree frogs, blue jays and human beings  typically get around by stepping, flying or jumping.

title: The Tree of Life Gets a Makeover
description: Darwin called it the abominable mystery: the reason for a sudden explosion of diverse flowering plants in the fossil record. Biologists have pondered the issue for years but were hampered by the absence of full studies of some plants and a lack of sophisticated tools for analyzing large genetic data sets. But now, thanks to a method called functional phylogenomics, scientists have resolved some of the enigmatic relationships of plant families, potentially opening the way for advances in agriculture.

title: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from North Korea, New York, Egypt and Philippines.

title: Lions Come Back and Aim for a Wild Card
description: The Detroit Lions are getting quite the reputation for being kings of the comeback. Their 28-27 victory Sunday over the Raiders, in Oakland, was their fourth come-from-behind win of the season.

title: Cornell Alumnus Is Behind $350 Million Gift to Build Science School in City
description: The donor whose $350 million gift will be critical in building Cornell Universitys new high-tech graduate school on Roosevelt Island is Atlantic Philanthropies, whose founder, Charles F. Feeney, is a Cornell alumnus who made billions of dollars through the Duty Free Shoppers Group.

title: A Schnabel Art Show Monologue
description: ANACOLUTHON comes from the Greek words for not and following. It applies to both stream-of-consciousness writing and conversations with Lola Montes Schnabel, the outgoing young artist who was having her first solo show in New York last Friday.

title: Mediator Sits Down With City Opera and Union Leaders
description: Union leaders and management at New York City Opera met with a federal mediator on Monday morning in an effort to resolve a labor dispute that threatens the companys season. One of the unions said the mediator, Allison Beck, the deputy director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, first met with both sides together and then separately. The union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, said in a statement that it agreed to return to negotiations on Jan. 3, just days before rehearsals are supposed to begin. The guild represents chorus members, stage managers and assistant directors. The orchestras union is also negotiating with the companys management, which declined to comment on Monday, citing a news blackout requested by the mediator.

title: A Melting Pot at the Intersection of Empires for Five Centuries
description: In its time and place, the ancient city of Dura-Europos had much in common with todays most cosmopolitan urban landscapes. Religious, linguistic and cultural diversity characterized much of the citys life for more than 500 years, starting at the outset of the third century B.C. in what is now Syria.

title: GPS Watch Can Be an Unreliable Running Partner
description: I used to run with a GPS watch, and at the time it seemed like a technological marvel.

title: A New International Theater Festival for New York
description: Thanks to festivals like Under the Radar and Coil, January is a busy month for devotees of international theater in New York. But things promise to be even more active than usual next month, when a new event called the Times Square International Theater Festival makes its debut.

title: 'I'm in the Right Place,' Common Tells Eagle Academy Boys
The Problem With GPS Watches for Runners
description: In her latest Personal Best column, Gina Kolata explores an all too common problem for runners who use GPS watches to track their distance and pace. Many of the watches are simply not very accurate, recording incorrect times and distances, which can be a nuisance for runners who are training for races.

title: AT&T Ends $39 Billion Bid for T-Mobile
description: AT&T on Monday ended its effort to buy T-Mobile USA, acknowledging that it could not overcome stiff opposition by the Obama administration to form the nations biggest cellphone service provider.

title: Feoktistovs Journal: A Russian Back on American Ice
description: My name is Nikita Feoktistov. Im a 21-year-old forward on the Russian Red Stars, an all-star team from Russias junior league, the Minor Hockey League, that feeds the majors, the Kontinental Hockey League. The Red Stars are on a tour of the United States to play six N.C.A.A. schools including Notre Dame and two top amateur teams.

title: Behind I.B.M.s Big Predictions
description: I.B.M. just issued its annual list of five predictions of developments in technology that it thinks will come true in the next five years. Like lots of predictive lists, particularly those that come around New Years, this is something of a pseudo-event that serves as an advertisement for the predictors own product or service. I.B.M.s is no different in that regard, but it is worth looking at, both for the pedigree of who is doing the predicting, and what I.B.M.s choices say about itself.

title: Roiling Through an Undertow
description: The tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby has a burly but beseeching tone, and in his own bands he often pushes toward an amiable ruckus. Novela, the nine-piece band he presented at the Jazz Gallery on Sunday night, takes this predilection to its logical extreme. Drawing from Novela (Clean Feed), an album released in September, the group played a sprawling set of faintly episodic, heavily textured music, pausing only a couple of times to re-establish a center of gravity. The distinctive color of Mr. Malabys voice, on soprano as well as tenor, was often lost on a crowded canvas. He seemed totally fine with that.

title: Special Delivery, With Teeth Marks
description: Updated, 5:58 p.m. | Senders of holiday goodies, beware: at one Manhattan post office, four-legged, scaly-tailed postal inspectors may intercept your package and render it unfit for delivery, or worse.

title: Facial Fixers for Men
description: ITS not as if men are allotted a whole lot of bathroom counter space to begin with. So if we are going to fight for those few extra inches, you had better believe its going to be for something that pulls its weight. Here are some products that are worth making room for.

title: Numberplay Delayed This Week
description: Numberplay by Pradeep Mutalik will not appear today, but will be posted later in the week. Keep your eyes skinned!

title: Gingrich Promises a 44-Stop Bus Tour to Fight Negative Ads
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa  Returning to Iowa where the latest polls show his campaign suddenly slipping, Newt Gingrich lamented what he called a barrage of negative ads aimed at him and promised a 44-stop jobs and prosperity tour before the voting on Jan. 3 to fight back.

title: The Light in the Ocean and the Quest for the Higgs
description: The light in the ocean and the quest for the Higgs boson.

title: Following the Tune of Religion in Britain
description: The British early-music choir Stile Antico has spent the last couple of weeks touring with Puer natus est, a program devoted to Tudor and Jacobean Advent and Christmas music that it has also released on a Harmonia Mundi CD. The 13 singers brought these works to the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church on Sunday afternoon, where they ended their tour with an appealingly warm, fresh performance.

title: For a Reporter, Lingering Questions About North Korea
description: The dress code seemed a mile long.

title: Lyrical Renegades and Free-Range Sages
description: In poetry  as in calling ballgames  its voice that makes the speaker memorable. Sure, it helps for a poet to be a master of meter, a lord of the poetic line. But thats not why, say, we still read Walt Whitman or Emily Dickinson. We read him for his warm and vast-as-America hymning, and her for crabbed and cryptic messages left in a poetic bottle. Each poet here, too, writes in a vital and original voice, from a Vietnamese-American tale spinner to an alter-ego cockroach crashing headlong onto the keyboard.

title: Nature Triumphant
description: The world grows more crowded  Earth: Pop. 7 billion  but inside Massimo Vitalis latest large-format photographs, worlds unto themselves, really, the people are becoming fewer (and smaller). The depopulation is on display in two current exhibitions, one at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery in New York and the other at Brancolini Grimaldi in London.

title: At Planet Green, Tilting From Ecology to Gastronomy
description: Secular, issue-oriented, do-gooder television: its a small niche to begin with. And on the evidence of two new shows from Planet Green  the channel started in 2008 by Discovery Communications with a focus on ecology and sustainable living  its getting smaller all the time.

title: Six Great Gifts For Photographers
description: Still stuck for a gift to give your household shutterbug? Here are some of my favorite photo products from this yearas well as some perennial favoritesat a variety of prices.

title: Pairings: Mortadella Mousse
description: With blanc de blancs Champagnes, inspiration comes easily. Pop open a tin of caviar, but also consider fat-rich cured meats and cheeses, like an irresistibly delicate, almost buttery mortadella mousse swirled on toast. I pured diced mortadella, smoothed it with mascarpone and sharpened it with grated Parmesan. Then I recalled a mortadella spread at Osteria Morini, a SoHo restaurant that specializes in the food of Emilia-Romagna, the home of mortadella. Michael White, the chef and an owner, uses ricotta and heavy cream in his spuma di mortadella. Same idea, but I put my money on my mascarpone. I did add his fragrant touch, a pinch of nutmeg. Canaps can be served as is or, with a dusting of extra Parmesan, lightly browned under the broiler.

title: A Toast to Versatility
description: NO doubt this column appears on first glance to be one of those dutiful end-of-the-year pieces on sparkling wines. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: A Landlords Uphill Fight to Ease Rent Restrictions
description: James D. Harmon Jr. learned the value of a house as a child, shoveling coal into the furnace of one of two Upper West Side buildings owned by his grandfather, a French immigrant who worked as a waiter. Jimmy, you take care of your building and your building will take care of you, his grandfather told him.

title: Toward a North Korea Reading List
description: 5:37 p.m. |Update

title: New Albums From Young Jeezy, Nero, and Bryan and the Haggards
description: YOUNG JEEZY

title: AT&T Deals Wall Street Losers
description: Start recalculating the league tables.

title: Scene City: Another Artist Named Schnabel
description: Art insiders and celebrities gather for Lola Montes Schnabels show.

title: Sounds in Keeping With New Galleries
description: Each program presented by the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert has at its heart a thematic agenda: some small notion that links the pieces. The idea can be vague, like simplicity or craftsmanship, and its usually understated; the performances are comfortably chatty, but you never feel lectured to. But that daub of glue always helps to make the programs by this personable, proficient ensemble hold together, and stick with you.

title: Q&A: Wide World Seen From Train Windows
description: AN architectural historian with a penchant for railroad stations, David Naylor has been traveling by train since the 1970s. He described the view from a train as a sort of movie, a documentary on the history of a region. I would say that compared to the fragmented views out of car windows and the miniaturized views out of planes, the meditative view out of a train window is even better than television, he said.

title: Rutledge Named Chief of Charter Communications
description: Charter Communications, one of the nations biggest cable providers, on Monday named Thomas M. Rutledge its new chief executive, days after he resigned from his post at Cablevision.

title: Whats Next for T-Mobile?
description: 4:00 p.m. | Updated  Adding additional comment from AT&T about spectrum.AT&T on Monday withdrew its $39 billion bid to acquire T-Mobile after facing resistance from governmental agencies that had raised antitrust concerns.

title: Jobs Created by a Pipeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Close Enough for an Oscar Nod?
description: LOS ANGELES  Imagine a mother, Everywoman  in this case, Sandra Bullock  whose young son fervently wishes that she, and not his father, had died in the World Trade Center attacks.

title: U.S. Backs Apple in Patent Ruling That Hits Google
description: A federal agency ruled on Monday that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Googles Android phones function.

title: Natural Light
description: Examples of bioluminescent sea creatures.

title: Homeland Finale Breaks Showtime Record
description: The finale of Showtimes hugely talked about new drama Homeland, a favorite of critics and even President Obama, attracted the biggest audience for the series so far and the biggest for any first-year show in Showtimes history.

title: U.S. Considers Combating Somali Militants Twitter Use
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The United States government is increasingly concerned about the Twitter account of the Shabab militant group of Somalia, with American officials saying Monday that they were looking closely at the militants use of Twitter and the possible measures to take in response.

description: To the Editor:

title: Climate Panel Needs to Follow its Own Advice
description: I believe its time for Rajendra K. Pachauri to take a new approach to discussing climate change or leave the chairmanship of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change after nearly a decade in that position. There is an unavoidable and counterproductive blurriness to the line between his personal advocacy for climate action  which is his right as an individual  and his stature as the leader of the panel, which was established in 1988 as a policy relevant but policy neutral organization.

title: Council Mandates City Alerts on PCB Dangers
Early-Morning Investors
description: To the Editor:

title: An Emergency, Dimly Remembered
description: ITHINK a lot of flying is not enjoyable, but I still think its fascinating. I was in Africa earlier this year, flying around in a small plane, close to the ground, and it gave me a very visceral sense of the fact that I was in a piece of metal, hurling through the air. I liked it. It certainly was more interesting than being boxed up in a huge commercial jet.

description: IN television there may be no free lunch, but for some advertisers, the current rating system continues to supply a healthy serving of free viewers.

title: The Hereditary Principle
description: Its one of those things people take for granted, but its actually quite remarkable that a Peoples Republic, which supposedly has rejected bourgeois norms and all that, has become  a hereditary monarchy.

Chinas Newest Province?
description: Washington

title: Kims Heir Likely to Focus on Stability
description: TOKYO  The death of Kim Jong-il, the hermetic North Korea leader, threw the rest of Asia into deep anxiety Monday and reverberated across the Pacific. Friends and enemies of the nuclear-armed country fretted over whether it was now facing an unpredictable power struggle  even as the official North Korean press proclaimed that Mr. Kims cherubic-faced youngest son was his successor.

title: Reactions to AT&Ts Decision to Cancel Its T-Mobile Deal
description: After nine months of AT&T fiercely defending its $39 billion bid for T-Mobile USA in public and in court, the company finally agreed on Monday to end its takeover effort.

title: Cuts for the Already Retired
description: Retired police and firefighters from Central Falls, R.I., have agreed to sharp pension cuts, a step thought to be unprecedented in municipal bankruptcy and one that could prompt similar attempts by other distressed governments.

title: Sprinter Leaves Humiliation Behind
description: NORFOLK, Va.  Having done the heavy lifting to restore his career and his reputation, LaShawn Merritt, the reigning Olympic sprint champion at 400 meters, came to the gym to burnish his abdominal muscles.

title: In Kims Undetected Death, Sign of Nations Opacity
description: WASHINGTON  Kim Jong-il, the enigmatic North Korean leader, died on a train at 8:30 a.m. Saturday in his country. Forty-eight hours later, officials in South Korea still did not know anything about it  to say nothing of Washington, where the State Department acknowledged press reporting of Mr. Kims death well after North Korean state media had already announced it.

title: State Tests Extended to About Three Hours
description: New York State math and language arts tests for elementary and middle school students will each be lengthened to about three hours beginning this April.

title: Among Legal Ranks, Shrugs for Gingrichs Tough Talk
description: WASHINGTON  The American legal establishment is not sure what to make of Newt Gingrichs mounting attacks on the independence of the federal judiciary. Reactions vary from amusement to alarm. What is hard to find is approval.

title: Mitt Romney Blankets the Small Screen
description: Mitt Romney is coming to a television screen near you.

title: A Childrens Story Series: Will a Game Help Books?
description: Scholastic, the American publisher of the Harry Potter novels, is set to introduce another major successor to that blockbuster franchise by J. K. Rowling.

title: Its Time to Rethink Temporary
description: We tend to view architecture as permanent, as aspiring to the status of monuments. And that kind of architecture has its place. But so does architecture of a different sort.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Robot Drug Agents and Mourning
description: Heres what the reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web. For the full list, look over to the right-hand column.

title: Skidding Bank Shares Worry Investors
description: Talk about a bad anniversary present.

title: Two Ways for Banks to Win With I.P.O.s
description: There was a lot of back slapping at Morgan Stanley when Zynga had its market debut on Friday. But it should hold the self-congratulatory applause.

title: Dual Diagnosis
description: Antonio Lambert, diagnosed with a mood disorder and addiction, manages through faith, medication and companionship - leaning the same "peer specialist" skills he teaches.

title: An Inconvenient Truth
description: There is so much about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac that we should be angry about.

title: Reality of Having to Win Closes In
description: Two weeks ago, after the Giants lost a close game to the then-undefeated Green Bay Packers, several players talked about how their playoffs had just begun. Every game from that point forward was must-win, the players said. These were elimination games. And even though it was only December, the preparation had to feel as if it were January.

title: Relive Rout? Ryan Stokes Rivalry Instead
description: Over the telephone Monday, Rex Ryan sounded as if it had been he who was sacked four times against Philadelphia.

title: Amgen Plans to Team Up With Watson on Generics
description: LOS ANGELES  Amgen, the biotechnology company, is planning to develop generic versions of some best-selling drugs.

title: For Medicare, We Must Cut Costs, Not Shift Them
description: Suddenly, everybody is talking about turning Medicare into a voucher program. Its not a new idea. Its been two decades since wonks first started talking seriously about premium support and the idea of replacing Medicare with a competitive marketplace in which older people could shop for health insurance. But the idea got new life last week when Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, a Democrat with a long record on health care, joined Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Budget Committee, in suggesting that such a scheme was the best way to cut health care spending while providing for the medical needs of the elderly. The plan resembles a proposal that Alice Rivlin, who was budget director under President Clinton, and Pete Domenici, a longtime Republican senator, have also recently been promoting.

title: In Murky Republican Contest, the Clearest Target Is Gingrich
description: A furious and sustained barrage of criticism aimed at Newt Gingrich appears to be reshaping the volatile Republican nomination contest once again with just two weeks left before voters begin weighing in.

title: German President Pressured Over Loan From Friend
description: BERLIN  By nightfall on Monday some 45 reporters had paid a visit to the law firm of Redeker Sellner Dahs here to examine copies of private financial documents belonging to President Christian Wulff, a paper trail made public by his legal team in a bid to save his reputation and his job.

title: A Farewell to Havel in Prague
description: Updated | Tuesday | 1:13 p.m. Quietly and lovingly, Czechs bid goodbye to their former president, Vclav Havel, the dissident playwright who stood firm against Communism and led his people to freedom in 1989.

title: For Wall St.s Big Players, the Holiday Party Is Still Over
description: Three years after the financial crisis, the Grinch still hovers over Wall Street.

title: Frozen in Time
description: If you could fly into Nicosia International Airport, youd arrive in a different era. The architecture, furniture and advertising all scream early Seventies. The Cyprus Airways jet plane out on the tarmac is an ancient Hawker Siddeley Trident, a British model that most carriers retired in the mid-1980s. But there are no other planes, nor any passengers.

title: Birthday of a Nation
description: On Dec. 24, 1861, the Charleston, S.C. Courier gave an impassioned account of the first anniversary of secession, as it was celebrated in the true birthplace of the Confederacy. The Confederate and State Flags floated over the Custom House, the Old Exchange  which connects Charleston of this day with the Charleston of Colonial history, and with the names and services of LAURENS, GADSDEN, PINCKNEY, and their compeers of 1776.

title: Gingrich Hires a Political Director and Announces an Endorsement
description: While his presidential campaign is suddenly facing greater challenges, Newt Gingrich has turned to a political professional, Martin Baker, who is coming on board as political director.

title: Helping a Son Cope With Diabetes, While Juggling Her Own Challenges
description: Playtime and parties can be dangerous pastimes for Joshua Cancino-Betanzos.

title: Lottery Numbers
Knicks Are Confident Davis Will Be Worth the Wait
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The complete data for the Baron Davis risk-reward graph will not be available for four weeks, maybe six, possibly eight. There are too many variables to count for the moment.

title: Eager to Emerge From Its Slumber, but Seeing a Threat to an Idyllic Life
description: For generations, its residents say, Roosevelt Island has been New York Citys depository. The island accepted inmates, quarantined smallpox patients and even lent its earth to support the Queensboro Bridge.

title: In Gilded City, Living Wage Proposal Still Stirs Fears
description: Lets slip into our Louis Vuitton shoes and take a gilded stroll through Manhattan.

title: Death of a Dictator
description: The United States and its partners have long struggled to understand North Korea, where a cruel system of fear, repression and paranoia keeps the country largely impenetrable to outsiders. They will have to work harder than ever to pierce the curtain  and manage stability on the Korean Peninsula  after the abrupt death of Kim Jong-il, the North Korean dictator, and the ascension of his youngest son, Kim Jong-un.

title: Dan Frazer, Fretful Supervisor on Kojak, Dies at 90
description: Dan Frazer, a character actor whose Hells Kitchen upbringing prepared him for a long run of roles as a blue-collar type or a cop, most notably as the beleaguered supervising officer Capt. Frank McNeil on Kojak, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Firefighter, Burning, Escapes From Window
description: A firefighter whose head and back became covered in flames as he battled a blaze at a Brooklyn brownstone escaped from a third-floor window Monday morning as fire roared all around him, the authorities said.

title: Tuesday: Like an Acrobats Limbs
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Today is Tuesday, which means we have an entertaining crossword puzzle to talk about, but before we discuss that I wanted to ask those of you who are reading this whether or not you like to do the Second Sunday or Variety puzzles.
