description: Instead of the inflatable rat that has become ho-hum at union protests in New York, a giant three-headed dog with fangs was the effigy on display as about 250 unionized nurses rallied outside the Midtown headquarters of the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management.

title: Sea Scallops With Cider Glaze and Cauliflower Two Ways
description: Adapted from Floyd Cardoz, North End Grill, Manhattan

title: An Indian Star Switches Cuisines
description: FOR the men in hard hats wielding drills, yelling into their phones or at one another, the hubbub was business as usual. But for the man with the wordless expression of joy and anticipation  the kind of face you see on Christmas morning or at a sonogram reading  this was something different.

title: Dining Calendar: Feasting on Fish
description: The traditional Italian Christmas Eve dinner, the Feast of the Seven Fishes, is not exactly Mothers Day, but it gets close, with special fish dinners all over town and not just at Italian restaurants. Here are some choices on and around Dec. 24 (prices do not include beverages, tax or tip).

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Harlem Shambles, a Butcher Shop, Opens Uptown
description: Wonder why a new uptown butcher is called Harlem Shambles? The noun shamble comes from an old word for butcher shop. Timothy Forrester, who owns this bright, spacious store with his brother, Mark, brings in carcasses from local farms and does all the butchering on the premises. Everything is grass-fed and antibiotic- and hormone-free. Dry-aging is evident in the look of the deeply crimson beef; a boneless strip steak was tender, with beefy flavor.

title: A Roast Goose Ready to Serve at Christmas
description: If Christmas brings to mind Charles Dickens and ye merry gentlemen, then dinner must be roast goose. You can let Christopher Parks, the executive chef at Guilty Goose, a brasserie-style restaurant, take care of the succulent, beautifully burnished free-range bird, with gravy and an earthy, winy dressing of brioche, goose sausage, bacon, raisins, apples and a whiff of sherry. Roasted brussels sprouts, squash pure, corn bread and, for dessert, apple crumble tart, are included in the dinner to go. Everything is easily reheated, unless, like the late Elizabeth David, you prefer your roast goose cold. Roast goose is also an Eastern European dish for Hanukkah.

title: Jenis Ice Cream in Holiday Flavors
description: Jenis Splendid Ice Creams, a company whose particularly alluring products are worth ordering from Columbus, Ohio, has introduced new flavors, most with seasonal spicing and a touch of spirit, to embellish a holiday party. Boozy eggnog, goat cheese with Cognac figs, smoked tea and plum pudding, vanilla cedarwood and black currant lambic sorbet are some of the winners among 11 options. Dark chocolate peppermint is not so unusual, but Jenis is intense. Some flavors were less appealing: the marshmallow bits in the sweet potato ice cream were a tad rubbery, and the cake crumbs in the Black Forest made the texture grainy.

title: In North Korea, an Outpouring of Grief
description: Pictures of mourning from North Korea show a blend of compulsory emotion, cultural expressions of loss and sincere, spontaneous outbursts of grief.

title: North Koreas Tears: A Blend of Cult, Culture and Coercion
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Among countless mourners at a public square in North Korea,  the kneeling middle-aged man in an off-white windbreaker stands out. The state broadcasters camera zooms in as he wails, rocking back and forth with clenched fists, his grief punctuated by the white puffs of his breath visible in the cold of the capital, Pyongyang.

title: Abandoned Homes of the Antebellum South
description: How Mississippis abandoned antebellum mansions give insight into the Civil War.

title: Kayak iPad App Now Reserves Cars and Plans Trips
description: Kayak, the plane-booking service, released an upgrade on Tuesday for its iPad app, adding car reservation and trip-planning tools while introducing a brand-new design.

title: Living With Multiple Sclerosis, and Separated From the World by a Stairway
description: Twenty-one steps keep Diane Kessler a virtual prisoner in her home.

title: League to Add Independent Trainer at Each Game to Check for Concussions
description: The N.F.L., reacting to the Cleveland Browns treatment of quarterback Colt McCoy after he was hit on the head during a game Dec. 8, will pay for a certified trainer who is not affiliated with either team to be at each game to assist in spotting and checking for concussions.

title: Explaining Obamas Approval Rating Bounce
description: President Obama has seen improved approval ratings in the past few weeks. His approval rating in the average of six polls tracked by Real Clear Politics now stands at 46.5 percent. Thats the highest the figure has been since July, and is up from a low of about 42 percent in early October.

title: An Uneasy Search for Truth as Ghosts From Military Rule Start to Stir
description: BRASLIA  After years of wrangling with the nations military hierarchy, the authorities here have created a truth commission to examine the abuses of Brazils long dictatorship, a move hailed as a sign that Brazil could be ready for a more active role against rights abuses, not just at home but globally as well.

title: In Canada, a Car Built in China
description: DETROIT  Chinese-made cars have quietly arrived in North America for the first time, but without the bamboo dashboards and quirky names that have adorned them at recent auto shows.

title: Ohio: 12 in Amish Sect Charged With Hate Crimes
description: A federal grand jury in Cleveland indicted 10 men and two women from a renegade Amish sect on hate crime and assault charges in an attack on Amish rivals in which their beards and hair were shorn off, a form of religious humiliation. The sect leader, Samuel Mullet Sr., and six others were arrested in November and remain jailed. On Tuesday, those men and five other people were formally charged. According to the indictment, Mr. Mullet beat some of the rivals and forced their wives to have sex with him. The rivals had fled from Mr. Mullets community in Bergholz, Ohio, or had criticized the sect.

title: Jurors Need to Know That They Can Say No
description: Washington

title: Mitt Romney's 'Closing Argument'
description: From a Speech in Bedford, New Hampshire

title: A Piecemeal Approach to Health Law in States
description: The Obama administrations surprise announcement Friday that it planned to give states broad leeway to pick the benefits offered under the federal health care law offers yet another example of a gradualist approach to carrying out its signal domestic policy achievement.

title: In New Guidelines, Officials Affirm That States Family Courts Are Open to Public
description: New Yorks top court officials issued new guidelines this week declaring that Family Courts across the state are open to the public, restating a rule issued 14 years ago but sometimes not followed by the courts themselves.

title: Darvish Could Provide the Strike the Rangers Need
description: Picture this scene, which could play out in two months at a spring training complex in Surprise, Ariz. Japans best pitcher, Yu Darvish, climbs a mound for his first bullpen session with the Texas Rangers. Among those watching are Nolan Ryan, the man with the most strikeouts in baseball history, and Greg Maddux, the man with the most major league victories of anybody alive.

title: A Fight to Make Banks More Prudent
description: FRANKFURT  For Philipp M. Hildebrand, it was a reminder of what happens when you get between bankers and their bonuses.

title: Rick Perry on His 'Outsider' Status
description: Rick Perry casts Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney as insiders at a campaign stop in Iowa.

title: Egypts Military Masters
description: Five days of violent clashes between Egyptian soldiers and protesters have produced appalling images of cruelty and abuse  including a video showing soldiers stripping the abaya off a woman on the ground to reveal her blue bra as one raises a boot to stomp on her.

title: Mets Drop Minor League Team
description: The financially troubled Mets announced Tuesday that they were eliminating their minor league team in the Class A Gulf Coast League. That move could save them between $750,000 and $800,000, according to executives with other franchises who are familiar with the cost of running those teams.

title: Gifts for Non-Cooks
description: Americans spend less time cooking than anyone, and the amount we cook  some people count microwaving a pizza  has been on a long, slow decline. The reasons for this decline are varied and complex, but an increase in the average of both hours worked and television watched, coupled with the marketing of convenience foods, have turned cooking from a sometimes-pleasurable necessity into, for many people, an ominous-seeming choice.

title: For Illegal Immigrant, Line Is Drawn at Transplant
description: Without treatment to replace his failing kidneys, doctors knew, the man in Bellevue hospital would die. He was a waiter in his early 30s, a husband and father of two, so well liked at the Manhattan restaurant where he had worked for a decade that everyone from the customers to the dishwasher was donating money to help his family.

title: Video of Egyptian Womens March in Cairo
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, Thousands of women marched through downtown Cairo on Tuesday evening to call for the end of military rule in an extraordinary expression of anger over images of soldiers beating, stripping and kicking a female demonstrator on the pavement of Tahrir Square.

title: Fish Seller Settles Harassment Suit Brought by Black Workers
description: The fishmonger M. Slavin and Sons, the company with the familiar Eat Fish Live Longer delivery trucks, has agreed to pay $900,000 to 31 black workers to settle a discrimination suit brought by the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Kim Jong-il, the Sportsman
description: In the political world, Kim Jong-il of North Korea was a despot and nuclear antagonist. In the sporting world, he might have been the only guy ever to wear platform shoes, a bouffant hairdo and Dear Leader embroidered on his bowling shirt.

title: Last Witness for Military Takes Stand in Leak Case
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The governments arguments in the case against Pfc. Bradley Manning came to a dramatic conclusion Tuesday when the computer hacker who turned him in to the authorities took the stand to explain his role in the investigation, revealing at one point that he was simultaneously trading computer messages with Private Manning while sharing information from those chats with the authorities.

title: Why Solutions Journalism Matters, Too
description: This is a follow-up to last Fridays column revisiting social change organizations that grew in 2011.

title: 3 Million Could Lose Jobless Pay in Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  More than three million people stand to lose unemployment insurance benefits in the near future because of an impasse in Congress over how to extend the aid and how to offset the cost.

title: The Jets Players Are Asking Themselves: Is This a Rivalry Game?
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  It happens every summer, a preseason matchup between the Jets and the Giants that allows one set of fans to brag about a victory that does not count. The elation might last an hour or two, replaced by visions of winning the games that matter against the teams that matter: Philadelphia and Dallas for the Giants, New England and Miami for the Jets.

title: Remembering 08 Fizzle, Romney Puts Added Emphasis on New Hampshire
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  Over the next week, as most of the Republican presidential candidates barnstorm Iowa, Mitt Romney will rumble across New Hampshire on his most elaborate campaign swing of the election: a three-day, nine-town bus tour that his campaign has nicknamed Earn It.

title: Philadelphia Sportswriter Accused of Child Molestation
description: PHILADELPHIA  A prominent Philadelphia sportswriter abruptly retired Tuesday as three women and one man accused him of sexually molesting them when they were children in the 1970s, according to an investigation by The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: How Do You Prove Youre an Indian?
description: Los Angeles

title: Amazon Makes the Fire Less Balky
description: The Kindle Fire, Amazons color touchscreen tablet, is flying off the virtual shelves, the company says. Its price tag is $200  and thats all many consumers think they need to know.

title: E-Mail Clues in Tracking MF Global Client Funds
description: Federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global have uncovered e-mails that detail the transfers of money in the firms last days, including transfers that contained customer money, according to people close to the investigation.

title: For Gingrich in Power, Pragmatism, Not Purity
Microsoft Follows Apple With Victory Against Android
description: Another day, another legal win by a member of the anti-Android axis.

title: New York Mets Summary Term Sheet
description: An early version of the offer the owners of the Mets made to potential investors. Team officials would not say if any of the terms of the offering had changed over time.

title: Georgia Judge Accused of Misconduct Will Resign
description: ATLANTA  In her courtroom in Brunswick, Ga., Judge Amanda F. Williams told lawyers to sit down and shut up. She once jailed a defendant for using the words baby momma. And she detained offenders indefinitely without access to lawyers, state judicial investigators say.

title: $20 Million Can Buy Quality Time With Mr. Met
description: It is, understandably, not the easiest sell: $20 million to own a small, noncontrolling interest in a baseball team renowned of late for losing  on the field and at the gate.

title: Where Communists See an Opening, Many Russians See a Closed Door
description: MOSCOW  If there was ever a moment for a Communist comeback, it would seem to be now.

title: The End, for Now
description: With the withdrawal of the last U.S. troops from Iraq, were finally going to get the answer to the core question about that country: Was Iraq the way Iraq was because Saddam was the way Saddam was, or was Saddam the way Saddam was because Iraq is the way Iraq is  a collection of sects and tribes unable to live together except under an iron fist. Now were going to get the answer because both the internal iron fist that held Iraq together (Saddam Hussein) and the external iron fist (the U.S. armed forces) have been removed. Now we will see whether Iraqis can govern themselves in a decent manner that will enable their society to progress  or end up with a new iron fist. You have to hope for the best because so much is riding on it, but the early signs are worrying.

title: Recalling 1988, When Jets Dashed Giants Hopes
description: There are precious few pivotal moments in Giants-Jets history, mostly because a majority of the meetings between the teams  particularly in recent years  have been casual preseason games, listless affairs that had about as much substance as a lecture on the last day of school.

title: Putting Paychecks at Risk
description: If the House had actually voted on Tuesday on the two-month extension of the payroll tax cut in the Senates bill, there is a chance that it would have passed. There is a chance a truly ugly legislative wreck could have been avoided and that the take-home pay of 160 million workers would not be reduced in less than two weeks.

title: TimesCast | Gingrich Productions
description: After his stint as House Speaker, Newt Gingrich and his wife started a venture that produces documentaries and childrens books.

title: TimesCast: Gingrich Productions
description: After his stint as House Speaker, Newt Gingrich and his wife started a venture that produces documentaries and childrens books.

title: Who Controls Montanas Rivers?
description: The Great Falls Reach of the Upper Missouri River in Montana cannot be navigated by boat. In that 17-mile stretch, as Lewis and Clark documented in 1805, the river cascades down nine waterfalls. The explorers journals are evidence in a Supreme Court case that turns on whether the Missouri and two other rivers were navigable in 1889 when Montana became the 41st state.

title: F.C.C. Judge Rules for Tennis Channel in Dispute With Comcast
description: For years, the Tennis Channel has hungered to be watched as broadly nationwide as other sports channels.

title: As Further Sanctions Loom, Plunge in Currencys Value Unsettles Iran
description: Irans currency, the rial, tumbled in value to its lowest level ever against the dollar on Tuesday in panic selling caused in part by the countrys increased economic isolation from international sanctions, an unbridled inflation problem and worries that government officials there are ideologically incapable of devising a workable solution.

title: Deal Struck to Broaden Taxi Service in the City
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo struck a deal with the Bloomberg administration on Tuesday that would expand taxi service in New York by allowing livery cabs to be hailed on the street in parts of the city traditionally underserved by yellow cabs.

title: Iraqs Sunni Vice President Denies Ordering Killings
description: Tuesdays TimesCast video looks at developments in the deepening political crisis in Iraq. Stephen Farrell reports that the countrys Sunni vice president, Tariq al-Hashimi, strongly rebutted accusations by the Shiite-led central government that he had ordered the assassinations of government officials. Mr. Hashimi then accused the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of using security forces to persecute political opponents.

title: Few Options for Lagging T-Mobile
description: T-Mobile USA, the weaker partner in the now-collapsed proposed merger with AT&T, has few good options to thrive in the competitive wireless market in the United States.

title: Aides Qualify Panettas Comments on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  An assertion by Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta that Iran could have a nuclear weapon as soon as next year was based on a highly aggressive timeline and a series of actions that Iran has not yet taken, senior Pentagon officials said Tuesday.

title: U.S. Citizen Is Convicted in Plot to Support Al Qaeda
description: BOSTON  An American citizen from an upscale suburb here was convicted on Tuesday of conspiring to support Al Qaeda and of other terrorism charges.

title: Better Care for the Disabled
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has vowed to reform the wasteful and sometimes dangerous system that is supposed to care for more than 125,000 developmentally disabled adults in about 6,000 homes across New York State.

title: Wednesday: Tome or Not Tome?
description: Administrivial Update! Happy 98th Birthday to the American-style crossword! Journalist Arthur Wynne, who is usually credited with inventing a prototype of the pastime that would spawn millions of addicts, published the first crossed-words game on December 21, 1913 in a Sunday newspaper called the New York World. Read more about the beginnings of your favorite pastime here, and dont forget to celebrate with a PETIT FOUR made from OLEO.

title: Jets Turn Down the Volume With Season on the Line
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Bart Scott has piped down, at least publicly, in the 11 months since he became famous for blurting, Cant wait! into a microphone after the Jets beat the New England Patriots to earn a spot in the A.F.C. championship game against Pittsburgh.

title: Separation of Newt and State
description: WASHINGTON

title: Carnival Cruise Campaign Focuses on the First-Timers
description: ANEW television commercial for Carnival Cruise Lines opens with a couple looking over the railing of a cruise ship.

title: Last Rehearsal for Knicks, With the Cast in Flux
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The second game of the N.B.A. preseason is normally a platform for experimentation and tryouts, not final tuneups. But what is the agenda when the second preseason game is also the last?

title: Gingrich and Clinton Trade Careful Praise in Fox News Interview
description: A virtual lovefest broke out on Fox News Tuesday night as former President Bill Clinton and former House Speaker Newt Gingrich offered respectful praise for each other, neither rising to the bait tossed out by the host, Bill OReilly.

title: Putting a Positive Spin on Too-Big-to-Fail
Ralph MacDonald, Pop Percussionist, Dies at 67
description: Ralph MacDonald, a Grammy Award-winning percussionist and composer whose understated Afro-Caribbean rhythms were known as the ghost behind the hit records of a multitude of 1970s and 80s pop stars and who was a co-writer on the hit songs Where Is the Love? and Just the Two of Us, died on Sunday in Stamford, Conn. He was 67.

title: Rangers Cross the Hudson and Take Home a Win
description: NEWARK  After a long layoff, the Battle of the Hudson was finally rejoined Tuesday night, and a Russian sniper made the difference.

title: Ranbaxy Settles Violation Dispute
description: Ranbaxy Laboratories of India agreed to a settlement with the United States Food and Drug Administration and will make a $500 million provision in relation to a Justice Department investigation to resolve a dispute about plant violations.

title: Taciturn Arrestee Has Case Closed
description: A disorderly conduct summons issued to a Hoboken, N.J., translator by a Port Authority police officer after he refused to say which country he was from was dismissed on Tuesday by a Municipal Court judge.

title: A Language of Corruption, Spelled in Sobs and Shame
description: In the end, it was not clear if this man was crying for what he had done, or for himself.

title: Black Men for Black Women?
Judge to Police: Relax About the Weed Man
description: He calls himself the Weed Man, and he has become a familiar presence in Times Square, standing near Planet Hollywood and holding aloft a placard that stands out even in this part of the city.

title: Norman Krim, Who Championed the Transistor, Dies at 98
description: Norman Krim, an electronics visionary who played a pivotal role in the industrys transition from the bulky electron vacuum tube, which once lined the innards of radios and televisions, to the tiny, far more powerful transistor, died on Dec. 14 in a retirement home in Newton, Mass. He was 98.

title: Somalia: Soldiers From Djibouti Arrive
description: A long-awaited contingent of soldiers from Djibouti arrived in Mogadishu, Somalias capital, on Tuesday to join the African Union peacekeeping force. After a few hours of confusion about where the Djiboutians would be based, about 200 soldiers wearing helmets and flak jackets marched off the plane and headed to a camp along the ocean. Djibouti had promised for years to send peacekeepers to Somalia. It is the third country to contribute combat units, along with Uganda and Burundi. Djiboutian officials say they expect to send several hundred more troops in the coming months. The total African Union force is now about 10,000 soldiers.

title: Romney Reworks Stump Speech, but Keeps Focus on Obama
description: BEDFORD, N.H.  Mitt Romney drew some of the sharpest and harshest distinctions yet between himself and President Obama on Tuesday night, painting the upcoming election as a choice between two destinies  his vision of a capitalist society based on merit and enterprise, versus what he called the presidents embrace of entitlement programs and an intent to use the invisible boot of government to bring us all down.

title: Lottery Numbers
Iraqi Photographers Captured the Costs of War
description: Many of the most dramatic images of the Iraq war were made by Iraqi photographers who risked life and limb. They set out to document what many hoped would be its rebirth, and kept shooting what they realized was its dissolution.

title: Orson Welless Oscar Has a New Owner
description: LOS ANGELES The Orson Welles Oscar went to the highestand unidentified  bidder for $861,542, the Nate D. Sanders auction house said Tuesday evening. Welles received the Oscar in 1942 for his work on the script for Citizen Kane. It was thought to be lost and later replaced. But eventually the original turned up in the hands of a cinematographer who said he had received it from Welles as a gift, and, after a court fight, it was turned over to Welless daughter Beatrice. When the original first went on the block, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences went to court to try to stop the sale, but lost. Sothebys later tried to sell it, but ended that effort when an undisclosed reserve price was not met. And, now, finally the Oscar has been sold in an auction that, according to Sanders, included an underbid from the magician David Copperfield. Im proud to have represented this fantastic award to the cinema collecting community, Nate D. Sanders, the auction house owner, said in a statement that was circulated late Tuesday.

title: More Georgia Schools Accused of Cheating
description: Investigators who this year found rampant cheating among Atlanta public school teachers and principals released another report on Tuesday detailing widespread wrongdoing in another Georgia county.

title: Gene Summers, Modernist Architect, Dies at 83
description: Gene Summers, an architect who helped execute Ludwig Mies van der Rohes designs for the Seagram Building in Manhattan and other Modernist landmarks, then went on to design the McCormick Place convention center in Chicago, died on Dec. 12 in Sebastopol, Calif. He was 83.

title: Romneys Three Paths to Victory
description: Two months ago, I wrote a column describing why Mitt Romney is the Republican Partys inevitable nominee. Now that actual voters are about to finally have their say, its worth revisiting the subject, and looking at exactly how Romney is going to win his partys nomination.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 20.
description: The day in sports included the Arab Games in Doha, Qatar, as well as soccer in Germany and England.

title: Dyed in Blue: Giants Are N.F.L. Royalty
description: Ed Valentine is the editor of Big Blue View, a Giants blog. He and Brian Bassett of The Jets blog will write in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

title: Bleeding Green: Jets Barge In on Tradition
description: Brian Bassett is the founder of SNYs The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at  @Brian_Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

title: For Older Runners, Good News and Bad
description: Sometimes its good news when a studys hypothesis is not proved. That was the case, certainly, with a new study of older runners, in which researchers assumed that athletes over 60 would be noticeably less efficient than their younger counterparts.

title: Word of the Day | partiality
description: partiality \pr-she-a-l-te, pr-sha-l-te\ noun

title: What Remains
description: Perhaps the most famous house of 1861 was, by July of that year, no longer standing. The home, called Spring Hill, belonged to Judith Henry, an invalid widow, and stood on a hill overlooking Bull Run. In the battle that engulfed the fields around Spring Hill on July 21, Henry was killed and her home destroyed, save for a few remnant beams and a section of chimney.

title: Qaddafi Son Being Held by Rebels, Rights Group Says
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the son and presumed heir of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, is alive and well and being held by a rebel militia outside the Libyan capital, according to an American human rights organization that was granted rare access to him. But the group said that Mr. Qaddafi had been denied access to legal counsel as he awaited trial on charges of crimes against humanity.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/21/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/21/2011

title: Corrections: December 21
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Tintin, Boy Reporter
description: Charles McGrath looks at Hergs graphic novels.

title: Hong Kong Culls Thousands of Birds After Virus Found in Chicken
description: HONG KONG  Health workers here began slaughtering more than 17,000 chickens on Wednesday after a carcass infected with bird flu was found at a poultry market, government officials said. It was the first large-scale culling in three years.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 21, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Dec. 21, 1988 | Pan Am Flight 103 Crashes Over Lockerbie, Scotland
description: On Dec. 21, 1988, a terrorist bomb exploded aboard Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing all 259 people on board and 11 people on the ground.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 21, 2011
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article Xbox Live Challenges Cable Box.

title: North Korea Portrays Son as Firmly in Charge
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The leadership of North Korea moved swiftly on Wednesday to portray Kim Jong-un, thrust into the international spotlight after the death of his father, as the countrys unchallenged ruler.

title: Fighting Pollution With the Language of Light
description: Go to related article

title: Iraqi Photographers Captured the Costs of War
description: An interactive presentation including the photographs and voices of five Iraqi photographers accompanies this post. We urge you to view it.

title: Can You Be Good Without God?
description: A writer for a Times blog about philosophy argues that being an atheist does not mean anything goes  in fact, quite the opposite. What do you think? Can morality be independent of God? Can people who dont believe in God still be as good as those who do? What governs your own decisions about whether and how to act ethically?

title: Tokio Marine to Buy Delphi Financial for $2.7 Billion
description: LONDON  Tokio Marine Holdings, Japans second-largest casualty insurer, agreed on Wednesday to buy the American insurer Delphi Financial Group for $2.7 billion in the latest move by the Asian insurance company to diversify outside its home market.

title: Tip of the Week: Getting More Info From Your Mac
description: Want more information about the items scattered around the Mac OS X desktop, like the number of items inside a folder or the resolution of an image? Just click the desktop background and go to the View menu in the Macs Finder. Choose Show View Options from the menu and turn on the checkbox next to Show item info. The desktop icons now display that additional data. If you decide that the Mac might be showing you too much information, just repeat the steps and remove the check from the box next to Show item info.

title: Carbon Emission Fees for Flights Upheld
description: PARIS  The European Unions highest court on Wednesday endorsed the blocs plan to begin charging the worlds biggest airlines for their greenhouse gas emissions starting Jan. 1. The move sets the stage for a potentially costly trade war with the United States, China and other countries.

title: European Bank in Strong Move to Loosen Credit
description: After long resisting the kind of financial force Washington used at the height of the financial crisis in 2008, European central bankers on Wednesday pumped nearly $640 billion into the Continents banking system. The move raised hopes that the money could alleviate the regions credit squeeze.

title: Rex Ryan, the Say Anything Coach
description: As if there could be any doubt, Rex Ryan is the focal point of Giants-Jets week. He seems to be part coach, part boxing promoter, part team psychologist.

title: Paring a College List from 19 to 13, With Room for Yale and Deep Springs
description: Ive always heard that senior year is easy: a year of coasting, relaxation and (arguably) well-deserved laziness. Starting my final year at Marist School, a Catholic college prep school in Atlanta, I almost looked forward to slipping into senioritis. Yet 4 months, 1 round of final exams and 13 college applications later, its fair to say senior year is no pleasure cruise. On top of a challenging course load and a busy extracurricular schedule, I face some huge decisions about next year.

title: Unemployment Compensation Over Time
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Former Astor Mansion in London Is Open to the Public
description: A London mansion that was built for the American William Waldorf Astor in 1895 opened to the general public this fall for the first time in its history. The main floors of Two Temple Place have been transformed into a space dedicated to displaying publicly owned British art.

title: A Daughter of a Single Mother Looks to College as a Pathway to Help Other Children
description: My name is Autumn Chubbs; I attend Long Beach Polytechnic High School, a public school in California, and I live in a single parent household with my mother,who makes sure that I am on top of all my schoolwork and college deadlines.

title: The Early Word: Unmoved
description: Todays Times

title: Japan Says Decommissioning Damaged Reactors Could Take 40 Years
description: TOKYO  Decommissioning the wrecked reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant will take 40 years and require the use of robots to remove melted fuel that appears to be stuck to the bottom of the reactors containment vessels, the Japanese government said on Wednesday.

title: Demonstrators Who Took Over Chinese Village Halt Protest
description: WUKAN, China  Villagers who had carried out a prominent protest against what they called land seizures by officials and business people agreed on Wednesday to halt their demonstrations after more than 10 days of keeping Communist Party authorities out of their village. The protests ended after a leader of the villagers met on Wednesday morning with senior officials from coastal Guangdong Province in southern China.

title: 10 Things Job Applicants Should Know
description: While there clearly are not enough jobs to go around, some people are getting hired. Every day, every hour, thousands of people are selected from thousands more who are ready, willing and able to work. The question is, why is it that some people get hired and some dont?

title: Amp to Unveil Electrified Jeep Grand Cherokee at Detroit Auto Show
description: Amp Electric Vehicles, the Ohio-based company that made an initial splash with a plug-in conversion of the Chevrolet Equinox crossover in 2010, is branching out with an electric version of an upscale American S.U.V., the Jeep Grand Cherokee.

title: No Encore for the YouTube Stars Kapp and Mosca
description: Following up on the 48-year-old grudge that sparked a fight and spawned a popular YouTube video:

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Taste for Salt Is Shaped Early in Life
description: There is no question that Americans have an unhealthy appetite for salt, but one big reason may be overexposure to salty foods in infancy.

title: Whats Behind Delhis Fogged In Flights?
description: For many residents of Delhi, winter means chilly nights, open-air concerts, strolls in the park and maybe a bout of flu.

title: Algonquins Roaming Diva Cat, Matilda, Has Closer Quarters
description: What fresh hell is this? They have surrounded the lobby of the Algonquin Hotel with an invisible electric fence.

title: Authorities Seize Documents in Raid on Olympus in Tokyo
description: TOKYO  More than two months after Olympuss former president blew the whistle on a huge accounting fraud, Japanese authorities raided the companys headquarters here Wednesday, emerging several hours later with boxes of documents.

title: Submersibles, Camera, Action!
description: The journey from my home in Hawaii to San Jos, Costa Rica, was fraught with the usual assortment of international travel woes  a delayed flight, a missing piece of luggage containing expensive diving equipment and a bit of a mix-up involving my ride from the airport.

title: Daily Report: Few Options for T-Mobile
description: Now that its proposed merger with AT&T is a matter of history, T-Mobile has few good options to thrive in the competitive wireless market in the United States, report Jenna Wortham and Brian X. Chen in Wednesdays New York Times.

title: Their War at Home
description: Nearly nine years of war in Iraq have produced a growing cadre of world-class, homegrown Iraqi news photographers. These are the stories of five of those photojournalists, with a sampling of their images.

title: A Searing Family Drama Reveals a Human Side of Iran
description: Traveling around North America and Europe this year for festival showings of their new movie, A Separation, the Iranian director Asghar Farhadi and his cast have discerned a pattern. Audiences arrive skeptical, anticipating something exotic and unfamiliar, and leave pleasantly surprised that they understand and can identify with the films characters.

title: Week 15 Film Review: How Eagles Outcoached Jets
description: A closer look at Week 15, with the benefit of film review:

title: HSBC to Sell Japanese Private Banking Unit to Credit Suisse
description: LONDON  HSBC, looking to shore up its books, agreed on Wednesday to sell its Japanese private banking unit to Credit Suisse.

title: Nobody Could Have Predicted
description: For the most part Ive been staying out of the Why was the stimulus so inadequate? debate, since it mostly revolves around an unanswerable question: could Obama have gotten more if he had tried and/or made a stronger case?

title: Republican Unity Cracks as Election Nears
description: The criticism of the House Republicans this week has been fierce.

title: Roadside Bomb Kills Five NATO Soldiers in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO said a roadside bomb killed five of its service members in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, and Afghan officials and the Taliban identified the dead as Polish soldiers.

title: The IMF on Ireland
description: The latest report is out, and its not too enthusiastic, even though it was prepared before the latest set of bad numbers. Its worth noting that the IMF is aware that the huge apparent improvement in relative unit labor costs is to a significant degree a statistical illusion:

title: Morning Take-Out
description: E-Mail Clues in Tracking MF Global Client Funds | Federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global have uncovered e-mails that detail transfers of money in the firms last days, including transfers that contained customer money, according to people close to the investigation.

title: How Bridesmaids Could Get a Best-Picture Nomination
description: The critics have spoken, and so have the awards watchers, and both would like to nominate Bridesmaids as a movie of the year. The Kristen Wiig-Annie Mumolo comedy made it to many top 10 lists, including those of the Baggers colleagues A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, and the American Film Institute. It earned important Golden Globe and Screen Actors Guild nominations as well, and now the experts over at Gold Derby are predicting that it has a shot at the best picture Academy Award. (It edged out Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy, which dropped off the list from a month ago.)

title: Opinion Report: Avoiding Blame
description: From the editorial page

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 21
description: The National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity has asked two journals, Science and Nature, to keep out details of certain research from articles they plan to publish about the spread of a deadly flu virus. The virus normally doesnt travel from person to person, but scientists managed to make a highly transmissible form (at least in ferrets, which provide a good model of what viruses will do in people). The government board fears the information could be used by terrorists to create deadly viruses and touch off epidemics.

title: The Holy Land of the Holy Graves
description: MODIIN, Israel  Monday afternoon, a day before the start of Hanukkah, Im on the road from Jerusalem to Tel Aviv. I turn right where the brown signs point to the Maccabean Graves. I take the short unpaved road to where the Maccabees  those rebellious Jewish devotees who defeated the forces of the Greek-Macedonian Seleucid Empire around 100 B.C.  almost certainly were not buried.

title: Attack Over a Basketball Game at Erasmus
Fortress Chief Takes Leave to Handle S.E.C. Lawsuit
description: Daniel H. Mudd, who faces accusations that he misled investors while he was the top executive of Fannie Mae, is taking a leave of absence from his role as chief executive of Fortress Investment Group.

title: The Giving Spree | Gary Shteyngart
description: Who: Gary Shteyngart, the author most recently of Super Sad True Love Story.

title: Army Charges 8 in Wake of Death of a Fellow G.I.
description: One night in October, an Army private named Danny Chen apparently angered his fellow soldiers by forgetting to turn off the water heater after taking a shower at his outpost in Afghanistan, his family said.

title: Wednesday Reading: Three Million Could Lose Jobless Benefits
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Anti-Gingrich Ground Game
description: While Newt Gingrichs rivals for the Republican presidential nomination have stepped up their attacks on the former House speaker via the airwaves, they are also sharpening their criticism of Mr. Gingrich in fliers and other materials being distributed in Iowa.

title: How Mitt Will Win
description: In this weeks Campaign Stops column, I double down on my earlier guarantee of a Romney victory, and sketch out his three potential paths to the nomination. Heres the first, and smoothest:

title: Prime Minister Puts Power-Sharing at Risk in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq threatened on Wednesday to abandon an American-backed power-sharing government created a year ago, throwing a fragile democracy into further turmoil just after the departure of American troops and potentially tarnishing what has been cast as a major foreign policy achievement for President Obama.

title: Here Come the Tour Buses, Minus the Loudspeakers, and Maybe Human Guides
description: By the citys count, affirmed with a touch of official hokum in Times Square on Tuesday, a record number of tourists, 50.2 million, will have visited New York City by the time 2011 gasps its last in 10 days.

title: 8 Charged in Death of Fellow American Soldier
description: Eight American soldiers were charged with manslaughter and other crimes in connection with the death of Pvt. Danny Chen, a soldier from New York whose body was found in October lying in a guard tower in southern Afghanistan, the American military said in a statement on Wednesday. Read the full article .

title: Leading Off: N.C.A.A. Roulette Stops on Ohio State
description: When Ohio State was finally delivered its N.C.A.A. penalties on Tuesday, there was a bit of a Casablanca moment in there, just about the time Athletic Director Gene Smith delivered his latest in a long string of roll-your-eyes moments and said he was shocked the powers-that-be would hand down stiffer penalties than the Buckeyes had suggested for themselves. Yes, never mind that Smith was well aware his former football coach Jim Tressel had done everything but put the N.C.A.A. rule book through a shredder and he and E. Gordon Gee had reacted so lamely it veered toward a Three Stooges routine. Nonetheless, he was shocked, Captain Renault-like, that the N.C.A.A. had found something untoward going on in Columbus.

title: Out of Harvard, and Into Finance
description: Given the efforts at some of the top schools to guide their students away from Wall Street and into public service, Ive been wondering whether the career choices of the nations young elites have changed much in the last few years.

title: Ristretto | Holiday
description: The best present for a coffee lover is coffee. It doesnt need to be expensive to be great, and if its a subscription for regular shipments of hard-to-find coffee from a cult roaster, it makes giving the gift all the more gratifying.

title: Hey, Girl. Happy Holidays. To You. To Us.
description: Lets face it, certain cultural forces are unstoppable. Harvey Weinsteins quest to win Oscars. The disarming power of kittens in movie trailers. And Ryan Gosling. The coolest person of the year  as anointed by that frequent arbiter of raditude, Time Magazine  has also been among the stickiest, memewise. (Do we need to explain? Mr. Gosling provides the dreamy stare; bloggers provide the come-ons.)

title: On Our Radar: China Demands Emission Cuts
description: Amid protests over pollution, China says it has ordered local governments to reduce emissions of major pollutants by as much as 10 percent by 2015. Skeptics point out that the governments monitoring of pollutants is lax and in some cases highly inaccurate. [The Telegraph]

title: What Were Reading
description: Afar: A pumpkin baked in a blazing fire. Sweetbreads and blood sausage. Frosty caipirinhas. Heres what pastry chef Caitlin Freeman found on a trip to Uruguay.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Correcting Data Error, Realtor Group Revises Existing-Home Sales Downward
description: The organization that once said the housing boom would never bust said on Wednesday that the market collapse was even worse than it originally reported.

title: Death Penalty Death Watch: California
description: Ive already made my position on capital punishment clear, on the editorial page and on this blog. The death penalty is immoral: the state shouldnt play at executioner. Its imposed in a racially biased manner, defendants have insufficient access to reliable counsel, and its also impractical: Its expensive, with convicts sitting on death row for decades, and the means of execution are often cruel.

title: Apps to Keep Children Happy
description: WITH Christmas upon us and New Years just around the bend, many families are contending with long road trips and crowded flights. All those hours in the car and at the airport are bound to bring out tantrums in toddlers, squabbles among siblings and the familiar Im bored from tweens.

title: What Are the Best Apps to Keep Kids Entertained While Traveling?
description: This week in the Practical Traveler column Michelle Higgins offers a selection of fun kids apps to keep children entertained while traveling, as well as some unplugged ideas. When you are on the road, what apps have you used to keep your kids busy? How about some unplugged ideas? Share your responses in the comments below.

title: RIM Shares Jump on Takeover Whispers
description: Speculation about suitors circling Research in Motion breathed new life into its shares on Wednesday.

title: China Says Christian Bale Should Be Embarrassed After Assault
description: While American audiences struggle to understand the dialogue in the trailer for Christian Bales next Batman movie, the Chinese government has expressed itself loud and clear to that Dark Knight star, saying that Mr. Bale was trying to create news when he tried to visit a detained lawyer in China last week.

title: New York or D.C: Whose Cheap Food Rules?
description: Few rivalries between cities start with one side pleading its inferiority. But the arena here is restaurants, not sports, and so The Washington Post set up a smackdown between D.C. and New York  and which has the better cheap food  by stipulating its challenger status.

title: New in the Campaign Finance API: Independent Expenditures
description: The Campaign Finance API started as a service for data about presidential candidates. But as the campaign for next years presidential election has unfolded, its clearer than ever that the men and women jockeying for the Republican nomination are only a part of the action. Independent efforts, from so-called Super PACs to advertising campaigns funded by wealthy individuals and interest groups, play an important role in federal elections, as our reporters have written.

title: Romneys Big Lie
description: Suppose that President Obama were to make the following statement:

title: The Hair Remains the Same
description: Before getting the Spielberg treatment, Herges Tintin went through other visual iterations.

title: The 12 Games of Christmas: Americans Abroad on TV
description: The last few weeks of December bring a bleak emptiness to much of the soccer world, with leagues in France, Spain, Italy, Germany, the Netherlands and other countries retreating into hibernation for extended stretches.

title: Golly Gee
description: I have to post this every once in a while: a lot of comments are being rejected because they contain obscenities that violate Times rules. And the sad thing, based on a random sample, is that many of the comments would have been useful contributions to the discussion except for one or two words.

title: Al Jazeera English Among Winners of DuPont Broadcast Awards
description: Three regular recipients of broadcast journalism awards, CBS, NBC and HBO, and two relatively new recipients, Al Jazeera English and The New York Times, were among those named winners of the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards on Wednesday.

title: Zhang Yimou and the Challenges of Filming in China
description: As someone whose life was upended by the Cultural Revolution, the Chinese director Zhang Yimou, 60, has every reason to be wary of politics. But his new film, The Flowers of War, which opens Wednesday, is Chinas submission for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film and has already picked up a Golden Globe nomination. (Its the subject of an article in the Arts & Leisure section here.) It deals with one of the most horrific episodes in modern Chinese history: the Nanjing Massacre of December 1937, in which Japanese troops overran Chinas capital, killing more than 200,000 people and raping as many as 80,000 women.

title: Cities Face Tough Choices as U.S. Slashes Block Grants Program
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  It is no secret that these are hard times for cities, with tax collections down, state aid dwindling, unemployment high and foreclosures pitting many blocks. So, as he sat in his office here, Mayor Ed Pawlowski of Allentown echoed the question mayors around the country are asking: Why has Washington cut one of the main federal programs for cities by a quarter in the last couple of years?

title: Surge in Syrian Killings Is Reported Before Visit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian rights activists and opposition groups said on Wednesday that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad had killed at least 160 defecting soldiers, civilians and antigovernment activists over the last three days in northwestern Syria. If confirmed, the killings would constitute one of the worst spasms of violence in the nine-month-old uprising.

title: Great Escape | Eastern Exposure
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Year in Media | Social Media and Egypts Revolution
description: The value of social media as a tool to help bring political change was displayed in dramatic fashion on Jan. 25. After the people of Tunisia in January had utilized Facebook and YouTube to help topple the regime of President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, opposition groups in Egypt were inspired. They, too, turned to Facebook, Twitter and YouTube to help organize protests for Jan. 25, known as National Police Day  the beginning of the uprising in Egypt that brought down the government of Hosni Mubarak.

title: The Most Popular Health Topics of 2011
description: High-protein diets and superhero workouts  those were two of the most sought-after topics on the Internet in 2011.

title: Gingrich Condemns Senate on Payroll Tax Vote
description: DES MOINES  Newt Gingrich put a pox on all parties in Washington on Wednesday for failing to pass a payroll tax extension, but he especially condemned the Senate, where Republicans joined Democrats to vote for a two-month extension of the tax break, which affects 160 million Americans.

title: Why Some Business Owners Think Now Is the Time to Sell
description: Looking back, Cyndi Finkle wishes she had sold her craft services company, Sunday Night Dinner, early in 2008 when the economy was booming. With a track record of 30 to 50 percent annual growth for each of the previous five years, it could have been a compelling transaction.

title: Duo Wanted in String of House Burglaries in Queens
description: A man and a woman working as a burglary team are wanted in connection with 12 home break-ins in Astoria, Queens, most of them within the last month, the police said.

title: Are You Thinking of Selling Your Business in 2012?
description: Is it 2012 yet? From where I sit, the Great Recession has felt like the movie Groundhog Day, in which Bill Murray relives the same miserable day over and over again. For those of us waiting for the business-for-sale marketplace to turn the corner, 2012 brings a number of reasons for hope, many of which are addressed in a just-published New York Times article. While the decision to sell your business should be entered into with careful thought and planning, here are five reasons you may want to get a deal done by the end of 2012.

title: Young Star Makes a Fancy First Impression
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Charisma, hes got. The Spanish basketball star Ricky Rubio, with his longish dark hair and fashionable facial stubble, flashed plenty of that in his first two appearances with the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Unfit Salmon and Plain Old Darwinian Selection
description: Captive-born salmon waste no time making themselves at home. In crowded aquaculture tanks, they outperform wild counterparts in survival and reproduction  great news if youre a salmon farmer. But these changes come at a cost. The more capable a salmon is of thriving in captivity, the less capable it is of succeeding in the wild.

title: What Iraqis Think of the American Withdrawal: Babil Province
description: As American forces pulled out of Iraq, we asked Iraqis around the country three questions:

title: The Choice Q. and A. on Facebook: A Recap, and an Invitation
description: On Tuesday, The Choice blog hosted its first live Facebook discussion about college admissions. Our guest expert was Marie Bigham, director of college counseling at the Greenhill School in Addison, Tex. She answered a series of thoughtful questions from readers on subjects like the role of recommendations in the application process, the rising cost of college and how colleges analyze transcripts.

title: Looking Back at 2011: Retrospectives and Ideas for Teaching With Them
description: Updated | Jan. 1, 2012

title: An Official Release for Captain Beefhearts Bat Chain Puller
description: More than 36 years after it was recorded, Zappa Records is finally releasing Captain Beefhearts album Bat Chain Puller, Billboard  and The Wire report.

title: F.C.C. Rules for the Tennis Channel
description: On Tuesday, a Federal Communications Commission administrative law judge ordered Comcast to carry the Tennis Channel exactly as it does Versus and the Golf Channel. The ruling is particularly important because Comcast is the largest owner of cable systems in the United States. Richard Sandomir has the story here.

title: Large Hepworth Sculpture Stolen From  Park in London
description: Thieves entered Dulwich Park in south London on Monday night and stole a large bronze sculpture by one of Britains much-loved artists. The sculpture, Two Forms (Divided Circle), by Barbara Hepworth, had been a familiar sight since it was installed in the park more than 40 years ago.

title: Security in Flu Study Was Paramount, Scientist Says
description: The National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity, concerned about bioterrorism and a worldwide pandemic, has for the first time ever urged scientific journals to keep details out of reports that they intend to publish on a highly transmissible form of the bird flu called A(H5N1), which has a high death rate in people. Working with ferrets, researchers on the virus at two medical centers  Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, in the Netherlands, and the University of Wisconsin-Madison  are investigating genetic changes that may make the virus more easily transmittable to people. Doreen Carvajal spoke with Ron A. M. Fouchier, the lead researcher at the Erasmus Center. An edited and condensed version of the conversation follows.

title: Layaway Angels Pay Off Family Accounts
description: Anonymous donors have been going into big-box stores  Kmart in particular  and paying off layaway accounts. NPR and The Associated Presspicked up the story five days ago, and in it a reporter described a young father stepping up to the layaway counter with three kids behind him to pay something on his account when a mysterious woman approached.

title: How Do You Glaze a Ham?
description: Bourbon, molasses and pecans.

title: The Movement Toward a Buy Nothing Christmas
description: As I was reading How the Grinch Stole Christmas!with my kids, I couldnt help but marvel that the book (and the animated television special) endures as a holiday favorite, even as its core anticonsumerism message goes completely ignored.

title: Thursday Matchup: Texans at Colts
description: Texans at ColtsThursday, 8:20Line: Texans by 5 . It only took one loss to for the euphoria of the Texans first-ever division title to fade into pessimism about their playoff chances. The Texans are relying on third-string quarterback T.J. Yates to remain viable, top receiver Andre Johnsons recovery from a pulled hamstring has been slow (he has been ruled out for Sunday), top pass rusher Mario Williams (torn pectoral muscle) is long gone, defensive coordinator Wade Philips is recovering from surgery, and Arian Foster has fumbled three times in four games as the strain of carrying the offense has taken its toll.

title: A Challenge to #Takethetest
Christmas Makes Michael Bubls Year
description: Coming soon as stuffing to a million or two stockings: Michael Bubl.

title: An iPhone Cover Fit for the Griswolds
description: If you are into Clark W Griswold-level holiday decorating (you know who you are  your dog is wearing antlers right now), then Speck, makers of protective cases for electronic devices, has a little holiday cheer for your iPhone.

title: Dance Theater of Harlem to Start Auditions for Revived Troupe
description: Dance companies are supposed to be shrinking, not starting up in these recessionary times. Not so at the Dance Theater of Harlem, which closed its company in 2004. Theater officials on Wednesday announced the start of auditions to create a new stripped down troupe of 18 dancers, which will begin rehearsing in August and touring in October and aims to return to a New York stage by April 2013.

title: Countrywide Will Settle a Bias Suit
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Wednesday announced the largest residential fair-lending settlement in history, saying that Bank of America had agreed to pay $335 million to settle allegations that its Countrywide Financial unit discriminated against black and Hispanic borrowers during the housing boom.

title: Freed From Jail, Russian Blogger Drives Anti-Kremlin Movement
description: MOSCOW  Free after a 15-day prison term, the opposition blogger Aleksei Navalny moved quickly on Wednesday to use his growing celebrity to promote a huge antigovernment protest, exhorting people across the country to turn out on Saturday and register their anger against United Russia, the party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Consumer Electronics Show Loses Its Anchor, Microsoft
description: 2:55 p.m. | Updated to reflect comment from the Consumer Electronics Association.

title: Apps to Put Words in Santas Mouth
description: You might expect folks who make iPhone Santa apps to be filled with the holiday spirit, but after testing some of their wares, Ive concluded they might be some of the Scroogiest people around. I tried some apps similar to one I liked last year, Talking Santa, which let me record a message and make it appear to come from an animated Santa. I thought it would be a fun way for parents to send a message from Santa to their children.

title: The Algonquin Curtails Its Famous Cat
description: Herding cats, as we all know, isnt easy. So the Algonquin hotel has installed an electronic fence to keep its resident cat, Matilda, in the lobby and out of areas where food and drink are served.

title: G.M. Claims Remedy for Squealing Brakes
description: At one time or another, most motorists register the fingers-on-chalkboard sound of squealing brakes coming from their cars. So unnerving is the sound that it can cause drivers to erroneously assume that their brakes may be on the verge of failure. On Wednesday, General Motors announced that it was working on a brake assembly that might prevent the cacophony.

title: Vain Glorious | Hold a Candle
description: Much like your wardrobe, home fragrance is about mastering a mix of the classic and the seasonal. Keep your beloved Feu de Bois candle from burning out by taking a match to one of these festive, holiday-inspired offerings instead:

title: The Year in Review  And Next Year in Preview
description: Gail Collins: David, this will be our last conversation of 2011. When we talk next in two weeks, the Iowa caucuses will be over. Who do you think will win? The way things are going, I have to conclude its going to be Steve Jobs. True, hes no longer alive, but these days everybody seems to like him a lot. Which you certainly cannot say of any of the Republican presidential candidates.

title: Serb Charged With Arms Smuggling in Kosovo Conflict
description: PARIS  An ethnic Serb accused of being the shadowy smuggler behind recent border clashes in northern Kosovo was arrested in central Serbia late Tuesday, a day after Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany warned Serbia that it must reach a peace agreement with Kosovo to join the European Union.

title: Bold, Colorful Mens Socks
description: Distinctive socks are a clever and easy way for men to add a little oomph to their look without going overboard.

title: Lens: Iraqi Photographers Captured the Costs of War
description: Foreigners may have started the war in Iraq, but it was not only foreigners who covered its deadly battles, car bombs, civilian casualties and sectarian violence. Over on the Lens blog, Anne Barnard tells the story of Iraqi photographers who were tried, tempered and tested in the nine years since the American invasion  and who came out the other side professional photojournalists.

title: A Simple Yes or No? Its Not That Easy
description: SOME marriage proposals make for great theater, but in the case of Dina Kirschenbaum and Mark Thomas, a theater made for a great proposal, one of the best submitted in 2011.

title: Coffee Gulch
description: This fall, a handful of new coffee spots opened in NoHo, turning Lafayette Street into Latte Row. Now Gasoline Alley (331 Lafayette Street, at Houston Street), La Colombe Torrefaction (400 East Lafayette Street, at East Fourth Street) and Au Breve (51 Cooper Square, at East Sixth Street) join local standbys Think Coffee (1 Bleecker Street, at the Bowery) and the always fashionable Smile (26 Bond Street, at Lafayette Street).

title: App Smart Extra: Other Peoples Apps, Now Visible to You
description: Last weeks App Smart column highlighted Web sites that help you find  and in some cases, purchase  new apps. One new Apple-related service, Crosswalk, actually lets you peek at whats on another persons device.

title: Book That Became Hit French Film to Be Released in U.S.
description: The memoir that inspired the hit film Intouchables in France will be published in the United States next year, its publisher said. Atria Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, secured the rights to release the book, Le second souffle (the English title is Second Wind).

title: Year-End Surprises in Deal Law
description: 11:29 a.m. | Updated

title: A Christmas Scandal: A Glimpse of Stocking
description: HERE is a holiday enigma, wrapped in a big Christmasy bow.

title: The Imagery of War Horse
description: A look at moments from the film.

title: Gingrich Web Site for Sale
description: What happens when a presidential campaign neglects to snatch up the Web site in the candidates name?

title: Railroad Stations of Yore
description: From Delaware to Buffalo to Chicago, a historical photographic essay on railroad stations from around the country.

title: TimesCast | December 21, 2011
description: Edward Wong reports from Wukan, China | The consequences of not extending the payroll tax break and jobless benefits | Steven Spielberg's "The Adventures of Tintin"

title: Meyer Says Ohio State Undeterred by Sanctions
description: The Ohio State Coach Urban Meyer said that hes at peace with the news of Ohio States N.C.A.A. sanctions, which include a postseason ban in 2012, and is prepared to move on.

title: Protesters Interrupt Gingrich Speech
description: After condemning the Senate for leaving town during the debate over the payroll tax, Newt Gingrich was interrupted by protesters in New Hampshire.

title: Obama Gets a Lift From Tax Battle With Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  After a long stretch of high unemployment, legislative turmoil and, in turn, slipping public approval, President Obama seemed to regain his political footing this week with the help of House Republicans, whose handling of a standoff over payroll taxes had even leading conservatives accusing them of bungling the politically charged issue.

title: Google Expands YouTubes Suite of Services for Schools
description: Say the word YouTube to most teachers and youll get the type of cringe reserved for a ringing cellphone. Google, which owns YouTube, would like change that with a new network setting designed to give schools more control over what their students see when they visit the video site from a classroom or library PC.

title: Two Roll-Your-Own-Cigarette Stores to Close
description: Two stores, on Staten Island and in Chinatown, have agreed to stop selling roll-your-own cigarettes after New York City accused them of being fronts for evading cigarette taxes.

title: Below the Line: Green Valleys, Golden Sunsets and War Horse
description: War Horse, Steven Spielbergs film adaptation of Michael Morpurgo's childrens novel (and a subsequent play based on it), will open in theaters Christmas Day. But it has the look of a movie that could have just as easily played on movie screens 50 years ago. The wide open spaces, the glowing skies, the rolling hills have the feel of John Ford films, which inspired Mr. Spielberg and his longtime cinematographer, Janusz Kaminski.

title: South Street Seaport Museum to Reopen in January
description: The South Street Seaport Museum will reopen on Jan. 26, the institution announced on Wednesday. The museum, which has been plagued by financial problems, was provisionally taken over by the Museum of the City of New York in September, with help from a $2 million grant from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.

title: E.P.A. Issues Limits on Mercury Emissions
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency unveiled new standards on Wednesday sharply limiting emissions of mercury and other toxic pollutants from the nations coal and oil-burning power plants.

title: Romney Teases Reporters Over Lunch
description: NEWPORT, N.H.  The plane the Romney campaign charters for reporters is nicknamed Hair Force One, and on Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Romney offered up his own moniker for the press bus: This is the John Kerry bus, Mr. Romney quipped, when a group of finicky reporters didnt immediately jump for the submarine sandwiches he tried to pass out for lunch.

title: Proposal Planners: If Youre Ready to Pop the Question
description: THE marriage game has no shortage of matchmakers, wedding planners, fashion stylists, floral designers and other referees.

title: Imperfect Little Girls
description: Perfect little girls sound so good in theory: Always saying please and thank you. Always eager to please. Always pleasing with their A-pluses. But in practice, they are full of peril. They wont leave the house until their shoelaces are tied just so  even if it takes 14 painstaking attempts. They cannot abide an error. Worst of all, according to parents most dire nightmares, they risk growing up to become anxious, anorexic or otherwise emotionally damaged adults.

title: Taking the Pulse of New Hampshire Voters
description: With the first Republican nominating contests just weeks away, we are looking to take the pulse of New Hampshire voters heading into the holiday break. Do you live in New Hampshire? If you plan to vote in the primary, have you chosen a candidate? What issue is most important to you? What does the race look like from where you stand? And how does it compare to primaries past?

title: Whitney Announces Biennial Artists
description: In recent years, some of the Whitney Museum of American Arts Biennials have featured over-the-top spectacle, while others have been lower key. On Wednesday, the museum announced an eclectic lineup for the 76th edition of its survey of contemporary American art, which opens March 1. The list includes Dennis Cooper, who plans to install a speaking robot; Andrea Fraser, who once posed as a museum tour guide as part of a performance piece; Kate Levant, who will have a hanging-fabric sculpture on display; and Nick Mauss, who is installing a velvet room. Also represented will be the experimental theatrical director and playwright Richard Maxwell; the filmmakers Vincent Gallo, Werner Herzog and Frederick Wiseman; the dancer and choreographer Michael Clark; and the rock band Red Krayola.

title: What to Do, and Not Do, About North Korea
description: Washington

title: Baldwin Says Hes Lost Interest in Mayors Job
description: A Mayor Baldwin is not to be.

title: Social-Minded Hip-Hop Is Making a Comeback
description: In May, when a rapper was invited to perform at the White House as part of an evening devoted to poetry, it was met with predictable conservative outrage. That the kerfuffle was over Common, the most neutered of all rappers, only underscored the bad faith beneath the squawking. Still, the episode was a reminder that rap  the idea alone  can still rattle nerves well into its middle age.

title: Mitt Romney on the Payroll Tax Debate
description: Mitt Romney answers questions on the Obama administration's handling of the payroll tax debate.

title: A Holiday Debate: Clean Air vs. Full Wallets
description: Updated, 3:24 p.m. | Its hard to spoil the Christmas or Hanukkah spirit at the popular holiday bazaars that sprout every year in places like Union Square or the Columbus Circle corner of Central Park, selling all manner of tchotchkes, knick-knacks and bric-a-brac for impulsive gift hunters.

title: New Directions for the Intergovernmental Climate Panel
description: Dec. 23, 11:14 p.m. | Updated below |Thereve been a variety of reactions to my post criticizing Rajendra K. Pachauri, the longtime chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

title: Pictures of the Day: Czech Republic and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Czech Republic, North Korea, Russia and India.

title: On Defense, Heat and Thunder Get Better
description: Change is the N.B.A.s only true constant. With that in mind, here is a look at the teams poised for substantial changes in their defensive performance:

title: City Rejects Pleas to Expedite New School in Murray Hill
Quiz Show Helps NBC in Ratings
description: While other broadcast networks were in full repeat mode on Tuesday night, NBC grabbed a rare prime-time ratings victory in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic with the second episode of Whos Still Standing?, a new quiz show in which contestants are dropped down a hole if they give the wrong answer. About 5.8 million total viewers tuned in, and the show was up 20 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old viewership category compared with Mondays premiere. NBCs demographic numbers were also helped by Saturday Night Live Presents: A Very Gilly Christmas, which tied for the highest-rated program of the night in adults 18-to-49 and drew an average of 5.8 million total viewers over a two-hour period.

title: CoverGirl Withdraws Enhanced Taylor Swift Ad
description: Theres a certain Taylor Swift ad for CoverGirl mascara that you wont be seeing in American magazines any time soon.

title: Mercedes-Benz Introduces Gas and Diesel E-Class Hybrids
description: On Wednesday, Mercedes-Benz announced two new hybrid E-Class sedans. The E300 BlueTec Hybrid is equipped with a diesel-electric powertrain, the automakers first to be commercialized, while the E400 Hybrid has a more conventional gas-electric hybrid system.

title: Director of MacArthur Genius Program to Retire
description: 3:06 p.m. | Updated Daniel J. Socolow, the director since 1997 of the MacArthur Foundation fellowship program known as the genius awards, will retire sometime in the next several months, foundation officials are expected to announce Thursday.

title: Eurofile | Le Havre in a New Light
description: Strolling along the Rue de Paris in Le Havre at dusk on an early winter day, I was mystified by the faint rosy glow of the concrete buildings around me. It couldnt be the sun, since the sky was shrouded with low pewter clouds scuttling in off of the English Channel. Maybe the briny sea air was causing some kind of chemical reaction with the lime in the cement? Id have to ask my friend Arnaud when I met him a few minutes later for dinner. One way or another, this gentle color blunted the brute angles of these perplexing post-war buildings. One minute, I found them harshly beautiful; the next, cold and alien.

title: Romney Refuses to Criticize Boehner Over Payroll Tax Vote
description: KEENE, N.H.  At a morning campaign stop at a restaurant here, Mitt Romney said that while he supported an extension of the payroll tax cut, he was not willing to get into the Congressional sausage-making process and refused to criticize the speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, for siding with Republican members in blocking the Senates proposed two-month extension of the tax break.

title: Yahoo to Consider Sale of Asian Assets
description: 8:18 p.m. | Updated

description: All puffed up with coats; partying in pajamas; and sparkly bags.

title: Walgreen Facing Big Loss in Fight With Express Scripts
description: CHICAGO  The historically steady growth of the Walgreen Companys business of filling prescriptions is likely to drop off sharply next year, as the pharmacy giant faces the imminent loss of millions of customers who use the pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts.

title: In Ad, Ann Romney Stresses Character
description: Ann Romney, who has taken on an increasingly visible role in her husbands campaign over the last two weeks, will appear before Iowans in a new television commercial in which she urges them to contemplate what kind of character a president should have.
