description: On the 22nd floor of a new condo tower in an affluent Rio neighborhood, a three-bedroom has a large glassed-in veranda that mimics the contours of the building.

title: House Hunting in ... Rio de Janeiro
description: A THREE-BEDROOM HIGH-RISE APARTMENT WITH OCEAN VIEWS IN RIO DE JANEIRO

title: TimesCast | Political Standoff
description: Congress' inability to pass legislation to extend the payroll tax break and jobless benefits will have significant financial consequences for most Americans.

title: Ludlow Manor
description: HAVING savaged much of the Lower East Side, the weekend warriors who pack the areas forgettable new clubs are surging southward. Their stronghold beneath Delancey Street might be Ludlow Manor, an entertainment triplex opened last month by Georgie Seville and Luc Carl, who appear to be cashing in their chips with this glammed-up behemoth.

title: The Armorys Ambitions Expand to Match Its Hall
description: Rapist Santas in the brutalist opera Die Soldaten. The Royal Shakespeare Company performing in a life-size reproduction of its theater. A five-story crane continuously plucking at 30 tons of salvaged clothing. A three-dimensional re-creation of Leonardos Last Supper.

title: The Park Avenue Armory: A Home for Art and Performance
description: No longer merely the fusty home of antiques shows, the Armory over the past five years has unveiled art installations, staged dramas, presented operas and concerts and served as an outpost of the Whitney Biennial.

title: On Flu Strains, Folkies and Faith in Science
description: Im a huge fan of science, as is obvious given that Ive spent my life studying it and writing about it. I think that more science and science literacy, and fostering a culture of innovation and inquiry, will boost odds of a relatively smooth ride for humanity as our appetite for resources crests.

title: A Seasonal Cocktail: The Bitter Darling
description: I was recently asked to create a specialty cocktail for a big holiday bash. I knew I wanted it to be something special and seasonal, but the constraints posed by the party (it was held at the Center for Fiction, a lovely place, but one not equipped with a full bar or full kitchen) demanded that I keep it simple. Not a worry, as Im inclined to keep it simple where cocktails are concerned.The classic rye Manhattan was my starting point. What if I replaced the sweet vermouth with ginger syrup? That worked fine, but something was missing. I was testing the drink in a friends kitchen in New Hampshire over Thanksgiving weekend. A bowlful of clementines (one of my favorite winter treats) sat on the counter. Freshly squeezed clementine juice  and a generous dousing of Angostura bitters  brought the whole thing together.Its easy to make ginger syrup: I prepare a basic sugar-and-water simple syrup, in which I steep peeled, fresh ginger long enough that its strong, spicy bite really comes through. But you can skip this step altogether and buy the excellent ready-made ginger syrup from Brooklyns Morris Kitchen.As a nod to the bitters and the clementine, I christened the drink the Bitter Darling. It was a hit. And even though I invented it especially for one party, Im sure itll be a mainstay of my winter-cocktail repertory.

title: Theater Talkback: Honorable Mention for the Dishonorably Unmentioned
description: Early in my career as a critic at The New York Times, I began receiving nuisance calls from a ghost. This was before I had caller ID (or an unlisted number), and for a week or so I would pick up my phone only to hear an angry actress berating me for not singling out her performance in my review of an Off Broadway show in which she appeared as a specter.

title: The Giving Spree | Brooklyn Decker
description: Who: the actress Brooklyn Decker

title: A Bundle of Potential in a Ball
description: You may remember that, in the movie Field of Dreams, a mysterious voice in Kevin Costners head kept intoning: If you build it, they will come. It took some time for him to realize that somewhat unspecific piece of guidance really meant: If you build a baseball diamond in a cornfield, dead players will come back to life.

title: More Advice for Pre-Retirees Coming to 401(k)s
description: If youre nearing retirement, youre probably aware of the anxiety-inducing task that lies ahead: figuring out how to replace your paycheck with a steady stream of income generated by your investments.

title: Ovechkin and Capitals Look for Turnaround
description: Maybe the Washington Capitals are figuring out how to turn the corner. And a good start certainly would be to get superstar Alex Ovechkin going again.

title: Food Gifts That Matter
description: My column today offers suggestions for gifts for non-cooks. Obviously, cooking is not the only issue out there, and direct contact with friends is not the only way to change things in the food world: there is cash. There are countless worthy causes and just as many charitable institutions. If finding the cash to spare is difficult so, too, may be choosing where it will be put to best use. But if youre thinking about making a donation this year to brighten the national or global food landscape, heres a list of organizations where your gifts will be well spent. (No doubt there are equally worthy omissions; please add them in the comments section.)

title: Helped by an Obama Stimulus
description: CHICAGO

title: Black Firefighters Are Permitted Door-to-Door Outreach
description: The federal court monitor charged with diversifying the citys Fire Department is allowing black firefighters to go door to door to persuade black applicants to join the department, over objections from city lawyers.

title: Yale Coach Resigns After Rhodes Scholarship Claim
description: For a couple of weeks in November, the story captivated even the casual college football follower, perhaps because it did not concern allegations of child sexual abuse or recruiting violations.

title: Best iPhone Apps of 2011
description: For iPhone owners, 2011 brought a flood of new apps, but in many cases they struggled to outshine last years best. So rather than present a top 10 list that includes names from 2010, Im including only apps that had their debuts this year. If you really want to turbocharge your device, combine these with last years picks. (Note that this list doesnt include games, which will be the subject of a separate post on the Gadgetwise blog.) Like last years list, this one includes many free picks.

title: Ferrari 250 GT Spider and Mercedes-Benz Gullwing Among Highlights at Gooding Sale in Scottsdale
description: Just as movie studios often release their most tantalizing Oscar bait in the waning days before the nomination deadline, auction companies withhold some of their choicest consignments until close to the gavel date.

title: The Ebert and Roeper of Sci-Fi Arch Metal Bands
description: From the same site that gave you an old-school rappers take on Black Swan (favorite movie of the year, in a year where he didnt see any other movies) comes Rocker Reviews. The Baggers pals at NextMovie have asked the members of GWAR, the costumed, sci-fi arch metal band, for their take on one of this years Oscar hopefuls, War Horse. You might think that a group that favors rampant violence and imposing visuals might identify with the movie, but theyre split, Ebert and Roeper style:

title: Jack Klugman, After Half a Century, Returning to Twelve Angry Men
description: Thirteen years before he became famous as one of televisions great slobs, Oscar Madison on The Odd Couple, Jack Klugman had his breakout role in the 1957 film  12 Angry Men as Juror 5. He played a hardened young man who brought street smarts to the jury deliberations in a murder trial in a cast that also included Henry Fonda (as the main character Juror 8), Lee J. Cobb, and Martin Balsam. Mr. Klugman is now the only surviving actor who was on the jury  a detail much on his mind Wednesday as he spoke about his latest career move. George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., announced that Mr. Klugman  who is 89  will play Juror 9 in a production of the stage adaption Twelve Angry Men there March 13-April 8, 2012.

title: Striving for Gift Parity for Siblings
description: Hows the pressing issue of gift parity going at your house? A friend just asked me how worried I am about keeping things equal under the tree. Shes caught herself buying filler gifts just to keep things close to equal, and she doesnt like it.

title: Olivier Blanchard Isnt Very Serious
description: And when you bear in mind that the Very Serious People have been wrong about everything, thats a very good thing. Whats even better is that as the chief economist at the IMF, hes helping make at least one international institution less austerity-mad than the others.

title: Pictures of the Day: Czech Republic and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Czech Republic, the Philippines, North Korea and Russia.

title: Piers Morgan Dodges Bullets From a Great Distance
description: In an article on Wednesday, The Guardian suggested that CNN now has a damaged asset in Piers Morgan, the host of one of its most important hours. Mr. Morgan was struck by his own hand, and history, in his testimony on Tuesday before the Leveson inquiry on press ethics.

title: Who Is the Fourth Best President? Who Cares?
description: Opinion mongers on the right have been joyfully mocking President Obama for declaring that he was the fourth best president in history during a 60 Minutes interview.

title: Battle Scars Napoleonic and Domestic
description: For writers and readers of historical fiction the Napoleonic wars have been a godsend, inspiring not just the odd novel but battalions and flotillas of books. There is Bernard Cornwells multivolume series about Richard Sharpe, the British soldier who works his way up the ranks, for example, and enough naval novels set during this period to fill a harbor: C. S. Foresters Horatio Hornblower books and Patrick OBrians 20-volume Aubrey-Maturin saga, for starters.

title: A Misreading Benefits a Defender
description: Individual tournaments, in which each player has a new partner every one or two deals, have been out of favor for many years. But there were two individual competitions at the SportAccord World Mind Games last week in Beijing.

title: Sports, It Seems, Explains Recent Skirmishes in Cable Industry
description: The battle between sports programming and cable providers continues to heat up. Are consumers on the losing team?

description: Students at University of Utah and Carnegie Mellon University show us their visions for the Performing Arts Center at Ground Zero.

title: A Game Show of Sorts, the Really Loud and Potentially Uncomfortable Sort
description: Volume is a thing you take for granted on television: most shows operate at the same reasonable level, a constant across dramas and comedies and news and so on. Changing the channel doesnt shock the eardrum.

title: Varieties of Messiah: Smooth and Mild or Piercing With Male Altos
description: To gaze over the classical-music landscape in the final weeks of December is to take in what can seem like an endless, unvarying forest of Handels 1742 oratorio Messiah. But if you look a little closer, it is a forest made up of many different kinds of trees.

title: Better Ways to Wire Your Ears for Music
description: Dollar for dollar, headphones are the best way to listen to music. They pack more sonic wallop than even the most face-meltingly amazing loudspeaker system, and they do it for a lot less money. Think about it: a truly magnificent home-speaker system can cost well into the tens of thousands of dollars. A screaming set of headphones? A few hundred bucks, tops  and those in the Really Quite Good category can cost less than $100.

title: Finding Success in a Lifelong Passion for Fighting Monopolies
description: Albert A. Foer, the president of the American Antitrust Institute, was enjoying a restful Sunday last March when news broke that AT&T was seeking to buy T-Mobile USA.

description: Carine Roitfeld, the most famous-though-underemployed fashion editor in France, has been busy since she left French Vogue.

title: Guitar and Sax, Each in Exploration
description: Ben Greenberg plays guitar in the Brooklyn band Zs, but he is also the monocrat of Hubble, a project of one. He performed a short set at Zebulon in Brooklyns Williamsburg neighborhood on Tuesday; so did Diamond Terrifier, alias the saxophonist Sam Hillmer, also from Zs. Individually, theyre working on related forms of minimalism, an old idea, but theyre post-genre people, interested in the dirty magic of warping and transforming sounds and languages you might already know.

title: The 9 Lives of Carine Roitfeld
description: ARRIVING at a couture show last July, Carine Roitfeld, the most famous-though-underemployed fashion editor in France, was asked for her autograph. Ms. Roitfeld signed her name on an outdated photograph and asked the young man who had handed her the picture what he intended to do with it.

description: Conventional wisdom holds that the performing arts center planned for ground zero is something of a pipe dream  an ambitious project that will never be built because of logistical challenges, financial inertia and simmering political tensions.

title: In the Netherlands, Goalkeeper Gone Wild
description: 11:52 a.m. | Updated  A court in Amsterdam on Thursday sentenced the man who ran onto the field and attacked the AZ goalkeeper Esteban Alvarado to six months in jail, The Associated Press reported. Because of privacy laws in the Netherlands, the attacker was identified only as Wesley van W. (kind of catchy, dont you think?). Prosecutors had been seeking a 10-month jail term. Under terms of the deal van W., 19, will also be required to report to the police during all Ajax, AZ and Dutch national team games for two years. The match, which was suspended when AZ players were instructed to leave the field, will be replayed in full next month.

Maybe it dawned on the candidates that Americans are getting pretty tired of hearing from them directly. Or maybe, like all presidential aspirants, they have boundary issues.

title: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast
description: The Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta talks New York area hockey with Scott Burnside of ESPN.com and Dave Starman of CBS Sports in the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast.

title: Mistletoe Gets the Kiss-Off

title: Hobbled Tight Ends Put the Giants in a Bind Against the Jets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants have faced plenty of obstacles in their quest to reach the playoffs. They have lost games they probably should have won. They have been unable to stop talented receivers. They have showed signs of locker-room strife.

title: Faucet Handles in French
description: Although bathroom faucets traditionally identify hot and cold with markings on the handle caps, Olivier Gossart, a Parisian designer, is trying something different. His new So faucet for the French company THG suspends the words chaud and froid inside glass cubes. My idea was to have something like water, a transparent material that is very delicate, he said.

title: Nature Rendered in Glass Bowls
description: Over the years Ive seen a lot of these leaflike serving vessels in other materials, said William Couig, a glassblower in Brooklyn. I thought it would be interesting to make a line of traditionally functional objects but give it a contemporary aesthetic.

title: Sales at Room & Board, ABC Carpet & Home and Others
description: Room & Board will take up to 50 percent off sofas, tables, storage units, rugs and discontinued floor samples starting Monday (the Harter 60-inch media console in walnut, originally $2,499, will be about $1,900; the Newbury desk in maple, normally $1,299, will be about $980); 105 Wooster Street (Prince Street), (212) 334-4343.

description: AFTER nightfall on Tuesday, the Darvick family of Birmingham, Mich., began their Hanukkah rituals, just as they had done for years.

title: Serving Platters
description: TJ GIRARD believes that most traditional serving vessels could use some spicing up. Parties are supposed to be fun, exciting and entertaining, she said. Why cant the presentation of food be part of that?

title: Legos for Grown-Ups, From a Child at Heart
description: Legos will undoubtedly find their way under many a tree this holiday season. But while people usually associate the Danish toy with childhood, there is a booming community of adult fans of Lego, too. Like children, they replicas of all sorts of things with the colorful pieces: entire cities, cars, Star Trek" characters and, in the case of David Cole, animals taxidermy style.

title: Schrager Streamlines a Chicago Hotel
description: For Ian Schrager, sticking to the basics was his goal in designing Public Chicago, a hotel that opened this fall in what had been the Ambassador East, built in 1926. Working with designers headed by Anda Andrei, Mr. Schrager, a partner in the hotel, created a look that is very, very neutral, very low-key, no flash, no design on steroids, he said.

title: Skis Convert Chairs Into Rockers
description: Chair skis are a nifty invention that turn regular dining or side chairs into rocking chairs. Simply place the legs of the chair into the groove of the beechwood skis, which are about 1 1/8 inches wide by 21 inches long and fit most standard nonupholstered chairs. Flexible rubber stoppers at each end hold the legs in place.

title: The Mess Im In
description: AS a malformed Grey Gardens sort of bachelor, I have only one fork, but, unfortunately, this one fork has gone missing in the strange coral reef that passes for my apartment. And I describe my apartment as a coral reef, as opposed to the ever-thickening nest of a hoarder, because I dont suffer from hoarding, per se. I am at the mercy of another phenomenon  a kind of metaphysical cousin to hoarding  known as kipple.

title: Without Regis, Kelly Keeps Up Ratings in Morning
description: For the moment, at least, the departure of Regis Philbin from his longtime perch in the morning has not sent his former shows ratings into a tailspin.

title: Chicago Sun-Times Has a New Owner
description: 10:53 p.m. | Updated  A new company called Wrapports, which has a strong focus on digital media, has agreed to buy The Chicago Sun-Times and more than 40 other media properties from Sun-Times Media Holdings, the new company said on Wednesday.

description: When a college football team is successful, students put down their books and pick up some beers.

title: Motion Picture Academy Says It Is Flush With Money
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Things are looking up at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences  but they almost always are, if youre judging by those financial statements in the back of the academys annual report.

title: What if We Occupied Language?
description: When I flew out from the San Francisco airport last October, we crossed above the ports that Occupy Oakland helped shut down, and arrived in Germany to be met by traffic caused by Occupy Berlin protestors. But the movement has not only transformed public space, it has transformed the public discourse as well.

title: Peace Corps to Scale Back in Central America
description: MEXICO CITY  The increasing drug and organized-crime violence in Central America has led the Peace Corps to pull out of Honduras and stop sending new volunteers to Guatemala and El Salvador, the organization announced Wednesday.

title: M.T.A. Sets 2012 Budget With No Cuts
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday approved a $12.6 billion budget for 2012 that called for no new service cuts or fare increases, even though the plan leaves a $68 million deficit.

title: Film Held No Sway in Arms Dealers Trial, Juror Tells Court
description: Heather Hobson did not like Lord of War, characterizing the film as that terrible Nicolas Cage movie in an interview with The New York Times.

title: From Bad to Bold: Holmes Points Out Giants Shortcomings
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets wide receiver Santonio Holmes has moved on boldly, apparently no less contrite, less than a week after having one of the most forgettable and regrettable games in his six-year N.F.L. career.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Dead Benjamins and Spy Apps
description: Heres what the reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web. For the full list, look over to the right-hand column.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls Finesse Fight on Payroll Tax
description: DES MOINES  The wounds may have healed from his ferocious budget battles with the last Democratic president, but Newt Gingrichs memory is vivid. And he believes one lesson still holds true about the fights between Congress and the White House: presidents generally win.

title: G.O.P. Is Hopeful as Race to Replace State Senator Takes Shape
description: A day after former State Senator Carl Kruger tearfully pleaded guilty to corruption charges, the campaigning to replace him began on Wednesday, with Republicans hoping for a rare victory in New York City and Democrats eager to hold the seat.

title: Winter
description: When my trust hung from the thin thread of justice

title: Racism Charges Put a Sport on Edge
description: John Terry, captain of Englands national soccer team and the powerful club Chelsea, faces a criminal charge over accusations that he made a racial slur during an October match, apparently becoming the first player to be prosecuted for remarks said on the field.

title: Prisons and Redistricting
description: A New York State court rightly upheld a state law requiring that prison inmates be counted in their home communities rather than where they are incarcerated. The law, passed in 2010, put an end to prison-based gerrymandering, which counted nonvoting prison inmates as residents to increase the population of some legislative districts. That practice artificially inflated the political power of voting residents in prison districts and diluted the voting strength of voters elsewhere.

title: Getting By, Until the Day She Couldnt Move
description: Connie Nelson is in love with the view from her 18th-floor balcony: The glittering towers and spires of Lower Manhattan have beckoned her each day for 20 years.

title: Abuse Allegations Leave the Hall of Fame in a Difficult Position
description: Baseball and those who cover it have increasingly had to navigate the space where the celebration of sports and the acknowledgement of its troubles intersect.

title: Californias Lethal Injections
description: In 2006, a federal district court ordered California to stop executing people because the states three-drug protocol for lethal injection lacked reliability. Six of the 11 men executed by lethal injection in the state since 1978 may have suffered cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Constitution because the injection inflicted excessive pain, Judge Jeremy Fogel found. He said the state could cure the constitutional problem by being transparent in devising a new protocol and using a one-drug, anesthetic-only method (as Ohio and Washington do).

title: The Problem of the Traveling Politician
description: Politicians have always been heavy travelers, but recent news out of Iowa takes the notion of hitting the campaign trail to new extremes.

title: John Chamberlain, Who Wrested Rough Magic From Scrap Metal, Dies at 84
description: John Chamberlain, who almost singlehandedly gave automotive metal a place in the history of sculpture, smashing and twisting together a poetic fusion of Abstract Expressionism and Pop from fenders, fins, bumpers and hoods, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Former Teammates, 2 Big Men Went Different Ways
description: When Tyson Chandler was a rookie in Chicago, tall and skinny and months out of high school, he and his aspiring front-line co-star, Eddy Curry, would be summoned to the office of Jerry Krause, the Bulls longtime general manager, for a twice-weekly chat.

title: Tsunami Reveals Durability of Nissans Leaf
description: DETROIT  Nissan inadvertently gained some valuable insight into the durability of its electric car, the Leaf, when about two dozen of them were destroyed in the tsunami that ravaged Japan in March.

title: Iraqs Latest Battle
description: No one expected the dangers and tensions in Iraqi politics to vanish after the last American troop departed. But at least Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a member of the Shiite majority, might have made an effort to step up to the challenges of creating a future for Iraq based on democratic principles. Instead, he is showing a greater interest in reprisals against the Sunni minority than in encouraging inclusion.

title: Toward Healthier Air
description: Resisting strenuous last-minute lobbying by some of the nations biggest utilities, the Obama administration announced on Wednesday a final rule requiring power plants to reduce emissions of mercury and other toxic pollutants by roughly 90 percent within the next five years.

title: A New Location in the New Year for Breakingviews
After Plea, Mayweather Receives 90 Days in Jail
description: The unbeaten welterweight boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. pleaded guilty Wednesday in Las Vegas to reduced charges of domestic violence and harassment.

title: Labor Board Adopts Rules to Speed Unionization Votes
description: The National Labor Relations Board announced on Wednesday that it had adopted new rules that would speed up unionization elections, its last major policy decision before it drops to two members and can no longer make new decisions. It approved the rules in a 2-to-1 vote.

title: In New Campaign, Esurance Equates Trust With Efficiency
description: IN an advertising world where lizards and bubbly sales representatives extol the virtues of automobile insurance, one company has decided on a more pared down approach.

title: Bloggingheads: A Christ-Free Christmas
description: Amy Sullivan, left, of Time and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of GetReligion.org discuss the religious vs. secular meanings of Christmas.

title: Christmas, Over Our Dead Bodies
description: The sign outside the Cathedral School on the Upper West Side read School for Children of All Faiths, but it was also, at least for me and my brother, a school for children of no faith whatsoever. I think our parents, a non-practicing Jew and an agnostic Lutheran, chose it because they liked that we would have to wear uniforms, which would make their mornings less of a trial, and because the idea of entrusting our religious education to professionals might mean that we actually got one.

title: For Democrats in Hawaii, Unease in an Oasis
description: HONOLULU  Hawaii should be a happy outpost for the Democratic Party. It has a Democratic governor. Democrats overwhelmingly control the Legislature. It has Barack Obama in the White House and all the prestige that brings, most recently an Asia-Pacific economic summit meeting with the president as its host, packing this citys streets, restaurants and hotels with international leaders.

title: Housebound for the Holidays
description: Right now, you are probably asking yourself: What exactly is going on with Congress? Whats all this yelling about a tax increase? Also, are they shutting down the government again? Because I was really planning to spend my Christmas camping out in a national park.

title: A New Kim. A New Chance?
description: On my first trip to North Korea in 1989, I made a nuisance of myself by randomly barging into private homes. I wanted to see how ordinary North Koreans actually live, and people were startled but hospitable.

title: Signs Point to Economys Rise, but Experts See a False Dawn
description: WASHINGTON  As the fourth quarter draws to a close, a spate of unexpectedly good economic data suggests that it will have some of the fastest and strongest economic growth since the recovery started in 2009, causing a surge in the stock market and cheering economists, investors and policy makers.

title: For Georgia Tech, Home Has a Distant Feel
description: ATLANTA  Georgia Techs Jason Morris was driving on Interstate 85 on the outskirts of this city before the basketball season started when he passed the Gwinnett Center.

title: Officials Seize Counterfeit Holiday Goods and Make Numerous Arrests
description: While counterfeiters are well known for cashing in during the holidays on high-price items like fake Chanel bags, this year they have put more energy into the lower end  expanding into Christmas lights, plastic Angry Birds toys and National Football League jerseys.

title: Old Leaders Who May Wield Power In North Koreas New Government
description: Influential officials in the latter part of Kim Jong-ils rule.

title: Rags to Riches
description: The Times accompanies Indian entrepreneur Ashok Khade as he revisits his native village, where he was of the lowest caste.

title: Scaling Caste Walls With Capitalisms Ladders in India
description: PED, India  On his barefoot trudge to school decades ago, a young Ashok Khade passed inescapable reminders of what he was: the well from which he was not allowed to drink; the temple where he was not permitted to worship. At school, he took his place on the floor in a part of the classroom built a step lower than the rest. Untouchables like him, considered to be spiritually and physically unclean, could not be permitted to pollute their upper-caste neighbors and classmates.

title: Jacob Goldman, Founder of Xerox Lab, Dies at 90
description: Jacob E. Goldman, a physicist who as Xeroxs chief scientist founded the companys vaunted Palo Alto Research Center, which invented the modern personal computer, died on Tuesday in Westport, Conn. He was 90.

title: Thursday: Year of the Battle of Pollentia
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  See that title up there? Yeah, I couldnt answer it, either. I think I can say without reservation that this is my least favorite type of clue. Not only is it a Roman numeral (CDII, in case you were wondering), which are never great entries in my humble opinion, but its a Roman numeral indicating a battle that I think is somewhat obscure unless you happen to be a Visigoth. On the other hand, it apparently has its own Facebook page, so who am I to argue?

title: Gingrich Throws Down a Debate Challenge to Romney
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Newt Gingrich threw down a debate me in Iowa challenge to his chief Republican rival, Mitt Romney, on Wednesday night, hours after Mr. Romney said in a television interview that Mr. Gingrich should stop complaining about negative advertising.Ive challenged Governor Romney to meet me for 90 minutes in Iowa next week, anywhere, anytime, timekeeper, no moderator, Mr. Gingrich told supporters during a quick pep talk at a Marriott Hotel here.He went on: And well bring all of his negative ads and show them for free and he can explain them, and well find out tomorrow whether he likes the heat and wants to come in the kitchen, or whether he is just another normal national politician with clever consultants and a lot of money and no willingness to stand up and tell the truth.

title: Projects Hit Hard by Slashed Grants
description: Mayors around the country are asking, Why has Washington cut one of the main federal programs for cities by a quarter in the last couple of years?

title: Lottery Numbers
In Cab Industry, Shrugs and Concerns Over New Livery Law
description: On a rainy Wednesday in Brooklyn, one might have expected some enthusiasm for a new law that next year will allow livery cabs to be hailed on the street in northern Manhattan and the four other boroughs. Instead, some who work with livery cabs were skeptical about the effect the law might have, while those in the yellow cab business worried about its potential impact.

title: Young Ranger Rebounds With Help From Richards
description: As usual, Michael Del Zotto had dinner at a Manhattan restaurant Wednesday night with Brad Richards. The meal, on the eve of the Rangers game against the Islanders at Madison Square Garden, has become a ritual for the teammates. They also live in the same downtown apartment building. For Del Zotto, a third-year defenseman, Richardss guidance is a primary reason he is flourishing after a season so disastrous, he could not even dismiss it as a sophomore slump.

title: After Fatal Standoff, Agency Rues Not Doing More
description: SAN ANTONIO  One September morning last year, a sheriffs deputy in Kleberg County on the South Texas coast interviewed a woman who had been living on a beach with her two children.

title: Before a Brutal Death, a Reputation for Generosity and Eccentricity
description: She has come to be known for the brutal way in which she was killed: set ablaze inside an elevator, burned alive just feet from her apartment door.

title: Health Fears Over Suspect French Breast Implants Spread Abroad
description: PARIS  Health officials in at least a half-dozen countries are grappling with the intense anxiety of tens of thousands of women who received breast implants that were made in France with substandard silicone  and that have been rupturing at unusually high rates.

title: In Final Preseason Game, Frontcourt Gives Knicks a Reason for Optimism
description: The games will matter soon  sooner than anyone would prefer  and the Knicks will accept that cold reality with a mix of trepidation and self-assurance. They are too new to be entirely comfortable, but talented enough to feel secure.

title: Economy Contributes to Slowest Population Growth Rate Since 40s
description: WASHINGTON  The population of the United States grew this year at its slowest rate since the 1940s, the Census Bureau reported on Wednesday, as the gloomy economy continued to depress births and immigration fell to its lowest level since 1991.

title: What Does $40 Mean to You?
description: After House Republicans rejected a Senate compromise to extend a payroll tax cut, the White House took the fight to Twitter with the hashtag #40dollars.

title: A Big Difference in Home Sales
description: The National Association of Realtors announced that it had understated the decline in the housing market.

title: Indias Boom Brings Fortunes to Some Dalits
description: India is home to a tiny but growing class of millionaires from the Dalit population, Lydia Polgreen writes in a long feature article in The New York Times today.

title: In Islamic Law, Gingrich Sees a Mortal Threat to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Long before he announced his presidential run this year, Newt Gingrich had become the most prominent American politician to embrace an alarming premise: that Shariah, or Islamic law, poses a threat to the United States as grave as or graver than terrorism.

title: Corrections: December 22
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Gingrich Says Hes Ready to Take the Heat
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  A look of utter disbelief crossed Newt Gingrichs face Wednesday when a reporter told him that Mitt Romney had suggested earlier that Mr. Gingrich could not stand the heat of a presidential campaign.

title: Foes of Hungarys Government Fear Demolition of Democracy
description: BUDAPEST  In less than two years as a member of the Hungarian Parliament, Timea Szabo says she has looked on helplessly as the ruling Fidesz Party has used its two-thirds majority to tighten its grip on the news media and the courts, redraw parliamentary districts in its favor and pack the constitutional court with supporters. On Jan. 1, a new majoritarian Constitution written and ratified by Fidesz takes hold.

title: Sports Replay: Dec. 21
description: The day in sports, including World Cup skiing in Austria and the Arab Games in Qatar.

title: Where Crches Once Stood, Atheists Now Hold Forth
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The elaborate Nativity scenes rose in a city park along the oceanfront here every December for nearly six decades. More than a dozen life-size dioramas depicted the Annunciation, Mary and Joseph being turned away at the inn and, of course, the manger.

title: Henry E. Catto Jr., Who Served 4 Presidents, Dies at 81
description: Henry E. Catto Jr., who was tapped by four Republican presidents for high-profile jobs including director of the United States Information Agency, chief Pentagon spokesman and ambassador to Britain and El Salvador, died on Sunday at his home in San Antonio. He was 81.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/22/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/22/2011

title: Fixing Up Embassy, Congo Republic Raises Hackles in Capital
description: WASHINGTON  The Republic of Congo is no stranger to strife. Civil wars have battered the central African nation since its independence, neighboring Angola sent troops over the border in 1997, and a militia known as ninjas waged a guerrilla campaign for years.

title: Border Fence Blocks Bears in Migration, Study Finds
description: GILA BEND, Ariz.  The much-ballyhooed border fence has not just made it more difficult for illegal immigrants to slip across from Mexico into the United States. It has also become an obstacle, researchers say, for migrating bears.

title: A Review Is Ordered of Finances in Detroit
description: Michigan officials ordered a formal review of the City of Detroits finances on Wednesday after a preliminary examination by the state found probable financial stress.

title: Burnt Body Identified as That of Missing Brooklyn Coffee Shop Owner
description: When the proprietor of a Brooklyn coffee shop was reported missing nearly two months ago, his neighbors fanned out to look for him. Storefronts and subway stations were plastered with signs. A Facebook group popped up looking for clues, and local blogs and newspapers followed the case.

title: X Factor Watch: Its Still a Toss-Up
description: Its all over now but the star-studded finale.

title: Venezuela: Another Plea to Free a Judge
description: The American linguist Noam Chomsky, a prominent source of intellectual inspiration for President Hugo Chvez, made a new appeal on Wednesday for the release of Mara Lourdes Afiuni, a judge arrested two years ago by the secret intelligence police. The detention of Judge Afiuni, who was given two additional years of house arrest in December, has raised concern over the erosion of judicial independence in Venezuela. In July, Mr. Chomsky requested clemency for Judge Afiuni, who was arrested after she released a Venezuelan businessman from detention. The new appeal, made in a public letter to Mr. Chvez, detailed the death threats and other abuses suffered by Judge Afiuni during more than a year in a womens prison, and her inability now to leave her home. After more than two years in custody, there are no guarantees of a fair trial, Mr. Chomsky wrote. I am convinced that Judge Afiuni has suffered enough.

title: Israel Accuses 4 Countries of Meddling in Its Affairs
description: JERUSALEM  In a highly unusual response to criticism from European nations on the Security Council, the Israeli Foreign Ministry bluntly accused the countries of interfering with Israels domestic affairs and warned that they risked making themselves irrelevant.

title: Cairo Clashes Seem to End
description: CAIRO  The death toll from the weekends clashes between the military police and protesters demanding the end of military rule rose to 15 on Wednesday, but the five days of street fighting appeared for the moment to come to an end.

title: Bleeding Green: Giants Fans Owe Coach a Break
description: Brian Bassett is the founder of SNYs The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at @Brian_Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

title: A Medical School More Like Hogwarts
description: Its been clear for several years now that while aspiring doctors may start medical school as happy and as healthy as their non-doctoring peers, four years later they arent.

title: YuleBlog: Goals M.L.S. Gift Guide
description: Children may be the gift that keep on taking, but when it comes to the season of giving, there is nothing quite like a dreaded trip to the mall  though these days the Internet has evolved into an electronic mall beyond compare.

title: California: Nurses Plan One-Day Strike Over Contracts
description: Thousands of nurses plan to hold a one-day strike on Thursday over contract disputes between the California nurses union and two health care organizations. About 4,000 nurses employed by Sutter Health, based in the San Francisco area, will walk off the job at eight hospitals unless a deal is reached. Around 2,000 nurses from a Long Beach hospital system also plan to strike. More than 23,000 California nurses staged a one-day strike in September. The nurses were locked out at Sutter hospitals after the strike, and one patient died when a replacement nurse administered an incorrect dosage of medicine. Sutter plans to bring in replacement nurses on Thursday and Friday. A Sutter spokeswoman said care would not be compromised.

title: Dyed in Blue: Giants Fans Weigh In on Ryan
description: Ed Valentine is the editor of Big Blue View, a Giants blog. He and Brian Bassett of The Jets blog will write in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

title: Word of the Day | cubicle
description: cubicle \ky-bi-kl\ noun

title: Massachusetts: Harvard Yard Reopening After Protest
description: Harvard University said it would reopen Harvard Yard to the public on Thursday, six weeks after Occupy protesters set up tents there. Citing security, the university closed the yard to everyone but students and employees after an encampment went up there in early November. The protesters removed most of their tents this week.

title: Ad Watch: Attacking Rivals, in Black and White
description: Make Us Great Again, the deep-pocketed independent political action group supporting Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, is on the air in South Carolina and Iowa with an ad highly critical of Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich.

title: Bears, Dolphins and the Animal Stories We Tell
description: Ever since Peter Singers Animal Liberation laid the groundwork for modern animal advocacy more than 35 years ago, it has been a central tenet of the movement that we go ethically astray when we let emotional proximity to humans and a handful of nonhuman species trump the obvious interests of other animals. Although animal rights proponents havent always embraced Singers brand of utilitarianism, they have generally followed his rejection of emotionalism, reserving particular scorn for the sentimentality that allows people to lavish money and attention on pets while happily eating cows and pigs  mammals every bit as intelligent and capable of suffering as dogs and cats  which lead tortured existences before arriving on our plates.

title: Blasts Rock Baghdad as Political Crisis in Iraq Deepens
description: BAGHDAD  A series of explosions ripped through Iraqs capital on Thursday, an ominous turn for a country reeling from a deepening political and sectarian crisis that erupted after the departure of the United States military. It was Baghdads deadliest day in more than a year.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 22, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: U.S. Report Faults Two Sides in Deadly Pakistan Strike
description: WASHINGTON  A United States military investigation has concluded that checks and balances devised to prevent cross-border mishaps with Pakistan failed to avert a deadly NATO airstrike last month in part because American officials did not trust Pakistan enough to give it detailed information about American troop locations in Afghanistan.

title: Dec. 22, 1864 | Gen. Sherman Offers Savannah as a Christmas Gift to President Lincoln
description: On Dec. 22, 1864, as the Civil War entered its final months, Union Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman sent a message to President Lincoln notifying him that he had captured the city of Savannah, Ga., thereby completing his 300-mile March to the Sea that had begun in Atlanta on Nov. 16.

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 22, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Not Without My Pet.

title: A Conversation With: Sachin Pilot
description: In recent months the Indian government held meetings with Internet intermediaries like Facebook and Google, and asked them to prescreen user content and remove things that might be incendiary or objectionable, inspiring an outpouring of complaint and a rebuff from these companies. On Dec. 15, the government appeared to step down from that position, telling these companies in a meeting that there would be no censorship of Internet content.

title: Beyond Santa: Holiday Traditions Around the World
description: WHERE, on weekends leading up to Christmas, do two caves offer caroling sing-alongs?

title: No One Is Above the Law
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Black and White, and Black All Over
Whats Your Favorite Holiday Food Memory?
description: Nine writers for the Dining section and many Times readers shared their favorite holiday recipes and remembrances. When you think back on holidays meals past, what stands out most? Does your family have traditional dishes that you look forward to each year? Or does one particular meal stand out in your memory?

title: The Early Word: Benefits
description: In Todays TimesPresident Obama has benefited politically from the fight between House and Senate Republicans over how to work with Democrats and the White House to extend a payroll tax cut and jobless benefits, Jackie Calmes writes. But, she reports, whether the clash ultimately turns out to be a plus for Mr. Obama hinges on the economys performance.

title: The Kid Who Likes English Class Wonders What to Do About College
description: My best friend asked me last week, Where are you even applying? and I avoided her question. Mostly because I just dont want to talk about college. These applications have been hanging over my head for months and Im still not finished, still not done mulling over them. Even with my best friend I dont want to talk about it. It makes me anxious to think about what I still have left to do before the Jan. 1 deadline.

title: Autodromo: Watches From Brooklyn, Keeping Time in Italian
description: Two years ago, Bradley Price was driving his red 1983 Alfa Romeo GTV6 2.5 when inspiration struck.

title: Shop Delivers Deals and Donations in Prague
description: Beer can already be found for less than a euro a half-liter in Prague, and many of the citys attractions are free, but now its even easier to find a good deal here: the city has become home to a true thrift shop, where you can root out buried bargains as well as find a home for items cluttering your closet or suitcase.

title: Aspiring to Be First in the Family to Attend College, and Pay for It, Too
description: I sit at my desk with my right hand anxiously tapping in rhythm to my iTunes, my left hand twirling the baby hairs that stick out of my ponytail, and my leg shaking of restless leg syndrome.

title: The False Promise of Biometrics
description: NEW DELHI  Earlier this month, just two days after my grandfather and I received a summons to register for Indias national unique identification (UID) program, a sweeping initiative launched with much fanfare, a parliamentary committee ordered a review of the project, effectively freezing it.

title: Q&A: Clocking Your Broadband Speed
description: Q.

title: British Airways Parent Wins Lufthansas BMI
description: PARIS  British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia beat out Virgin Atlantic on Thursday in the bidding for British Midland International, the unprofitable airline being sold by Lufthansa of Germany.

title: How People Shopped Online This Holiday Season
description: Little time remains for online shoppers to have gifts delivered in time for Christmas, and sales numbers for online shopping this season are arriving. The trends are clear: shoppers spent much more money online this year than last year, and they did a lot of their shopping on tablets like the iPad.

title: At Presidencys 11th Hour, Medvedev Proposes Systemic Change
description: MOSCOW  It finally happened: President Dmitri A. Medvedev, the man who was supposed to embody the aspirations of young middle-class Russians, has outlined a concrete and substantive agenda for political change. In his last state of the nation speech before leaving office, Mr. Medvedev recommended returning to the direct election of governors, removing officials wives and children from the leadership of lucrative corporations, and creating a public television station protected from the Kremlins manipulation, among other changes.

title: Week 16 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Giants vs. Jets
description: It wasnt too difficult to pick a game to highlight for New York Times readers this week. The Giants take on the Jets, with both teams in the thick of their playoff races. The path for the Giants goes through the N.F.C. East division championship, while the path for the Jets can lead only to the A.F.C.s sixth-seed wild-card berth.

title: A Dressmaker Tries to Deliver the Right Dress at the Right Price
description: As she works to get a handle on pricing,Susan Parker, a member of our business group, weighs the competing interests of art and commerce. On the one hand, Ms. Parker, who owns the dressmaker Bari Jay, is thrilled with her creative designer and credits her with much of the companys turnaround. The designer, Kristine Eikenbary, takes her inspiration from higher-end fashion. Her designs are gorgeous, said Ms. Parker.

title: Christmas Tree Care, With an Audience
description: This is the time of year when you hear all the stuff that you are supposed to do to maintain your Christmas tree after you win the nine-rounder to force it into place without poking a hole in the ceiling or electrocuting yourself when you string up the lights.

title: Innocence Is Trampled, but a Bond Endures
description: There is no combat in the early scenes of War Horse, Steven Spielbergs sweeping adaptation of the popular stage spectacle, but the film opens with a cinematic assault as audacious and unsparing as the Normandy landing in Saving Private Ryan. With widescreen, pastoral vistas dappled in golden sunlight and washed in music (by John Williams) that is somehow both grand and folksy, Mr. Spielberg lays siege to your cynicism, bombarding you with strong and simple appeals to feeling.

title: Hard to Grasp, but Harder to Say Farewell
description: Not long before his 80th birthday in 1999 the choreographer Merce Cunningham went back to his hometown, Centralia, Wash., and spent some time with his brother Jack, a lawyer. After they talked about old acquaintances, Jack suddenly asked, Merce, when are you going to make something the public likes?

title: Coordinated Explosions Kill Dozens in Baghdad
description: A series of explosions shook Baghdad early Thursday, killing at least 63 people.

title: Rushing to Get Your Expenses Done? Join the Club
description: On Tuesday, I was sitting down to file for some work-related expenses after receiving yet another e-mail reminder of the inferno that awaits employees who are delinquent on such things. Moments later, a different e-mail landed in my inbox  this one from Concur, a company that runs an online expense management system for businesses  telling me that Tuesday, Dec. 20, was expected to be the busiest day of the year for filing for expenses.

title: Trucking Trout to Their Native Streams
description: In an innovative conservation effort, biologists on the Clark Fork River are using genetic testing to help get bull trout back to their natal streams to spawn.

title: Societe Generales Investment Banking Chief Steps Down
description: LONDON  Michel Preti, head of Socit Gnrales corporate and investment banking division, is leaving the French bank to pursue other opportunities.

title: Online Sales of Louis C. K. Special Cross $1 Million Mark
description: Though the comedian Louis C. K. may not seem like the kind of guy who derives much joy from the holiday season  let alone anything else  Santa Claus has brought him an early Christmas gift. In an interview on Wednesdays broadcast of Late Night With Jimmy Fallon, Louis C. K. said he had grossed more than $1 million from his online comedy special, Louis C. K.: Live at the Beacon Theater, after 10 days on sale, and would be donating part of that money to charity.

title: Akamai to Buy a Cloud Services Provider
description: Though the year is drawing to a close, there is no end in sight for cloud fever.

title: A Pocket Guide to the Lokpal Bill
description: Late Thursday afternoon, the Indian government introduced the Lokpal Bill in the lower house of Parliament, which would create an all-powerful nine-member anti-corruption ombudsman agency. The law will be debated next week.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Finding Success in a Lifelong Passion for Fighting Monopolies | Albert A. Foer, president of the American Antitrust Institute, was enjoying a restful Sunday in March when news broke that AT&T was seeking to buy T-Mobile USA.

title: Christmas May Offer Respite for Gingrich
description: 10:40 p.m. | Updated  The full report of this article is available here.

title: Opinion Report: Power Plant Emissions
description: From the editorial page

title: Daily Report: New Uses for Skype
description: In Thursdays New York Times, Julie Scelfo writes about how Skype, an eight-year-old technology, is being used in new ways in growing numbers of American homes. The Darvick family of Birmingham, Mich., for example, celebrates what they call Skypanukkah, to observe the Jewish holiday; with family members spread out in three different cities, they light the Hanukkah candles together through video chat.

title: State Is Investigating Pearson Foundation Trips
The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 22
description: Its been a busy year for Carine Roitfeld, who was replaced last December as the powerful editor of French Vogue by a former friend, Emmanuelle Alt. There have been wild parties she has hosted, fashion magazines and ads she has collaborated on, and talk of starting a new magazine. Ms. Roitfeld, Eric Wilson writes, has taken every opportunity to demonstrate the value of her brand, post-Vogue, and concludes: Rarely has the stock price of a fashion figure shown such resilience, after taking a severe blow to the side, since Lady Duff-Gordon survived the sinking of the Titanic.

title: DealBook: Yahoo to Consider Sale of Asian Assets
description: The board of Yahoo is considering a sale of the bulk of the companys valuable holdings in the Alibaba Group of China and Yahoos Japanese affiliate, report Evelyn M. Rusli and Michael J. de la Merced on DealBook. They write that Yahoo would sell the properties back to their majority owners in a complicated transaction that values the stakes at about $17 billion. Read the entire post.

title: The Meaning of Mercury
description: David Roberts reports on the EPAs decision, finally, to regulate mercury from coal plants:

title: Seeing Things | An Eye for Spectacle
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Thursday Reading: Texas Drought Shrivels Mistletoe Supply
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Vulcan Formally Rejects Martin Mariettas Hostile Bid
description: 12:49 p.m. | Updated

title: Brussels Hotel Offers Tintin Tie-In
description: A high-end hotel in Brussels, Tintins stomping ground, is offering two new packages and four themed rooms to celebrate the popular comic book hero. The promotion  from the Hotel Amigo  is timed to correspond with the release of the film The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn, which opened on Wednesday in the United States.

title: Winter Wonders | Cold Front
description: Reality check: its December. And chilling weather has (finally) forced women to break out the big ones  the fur and shearling coats. Here, the pop singer Kylie Minogue wears a quilted puffer with a cozy collar and a pair of black leather boots; the actress Rooney Mara picks up lunch in a cloud-like cocoon with a full bell silhouette; and the designer Ashley Olsen keeps it classic in a full-sleeved fur with an elegant rust-colored scarf and dark navy handbag.

title: What Were Reading
description: Al Jazeera: How the Egyptian revolution was fueled by food inequity: The Mubarak regime built factory farms to grow strawberries and salad for European markets, while staples like lentils and rice became too costly for Egyptians.  Julia Moskin

title: Sunday in the Magazine
description: Ira Glass from the public radio show This American Life talks to Hugo Lindgren, the editor of the magazine, about guest-editing part of The Lives They Lived issue.

title: The Music They Made
description: A sound collage featuring a sampling of the musicians who died in 2011.

title: Anticorruption Bill Provokes an Outcry in India
description: NEW DELHI  Indias government introduced long-awaited legislation on Thursday to create an independent, anticorruption agency, provoking a loud outcry from opposition parties and some civil society activists who attacked the measure from all directions.

title: House Republican Floats 3-Month Payroll Tax Extension
description: 10:29 a.m. | Updated A House Republican charged with trying to help resolve the payroll tax holiday mess suggested Thursday that Republicans might accept a three-month, rather than two-month, extension of the tax cut and unemployment benefits.

title: Honegger CD Featuring London Philharmonic
description: Christopher Maltman, baritone; New London Childrens Choir; London Philharmonic Orchestra and Choir, conducted by Vladimir Jurowski (LPO 0058; CD).

title: Danielle de Nieses Beauty of the Baroque
description: Danielle de Niese, soprano; Andreas Scholl, countertenor; English Concert, conducted by Harry Bicket (Decca B0015869-02; CD).

title: The Concussion Issue, From a Players Point of View
description: Chris Pronger, Sidney Crosby, Claude Giroux, Milan Michalek and now Jeff Skinner. The list of superstars having the dreaded label of being out indefinitely with a concussion continues to grow. By far, this has been the lead story in the N.H.L. over the last year. It began when Sidney Crosby was found to have a concussion in January. It took a backseat for a short while as Crosby returned to play in late November, but before anyone got comfortable, a slew of great players, including Crosby, have been sent to the press box to watch games, out indefinitely with concussions after all taking blows to the head.

title: Buzz Over Whos Not in North Korea Picture(s)
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Researchers scrutinizing North Koreas official images and lists of mourners paying respects to Kim Jong-il have noticed two conspicuous absences: the elder brothers of Kim Jong-un, the appointed heir.

title: Sebastian Currier: Piano Sonata, Other Works
description: Laura Melton, pianist (Naxos 8.559638; CD).

title: New and Unpopular
description: Congress is closing out 2011 with an 11 percent approval rating, and a 17 percent yearly average. Those are both record lowsGallup conducted its first Congressional job approval survey in 1974, and never before have Americans been so united in their dissatisfaction.

title: High Notes and Low Points for Classical Music
description: THIS holiday season brings a set of gifts for the world of classical music, in the form of the highly uncoveted and arbitrarily granted Special Awards for 2011. It was a year of financial hardship for the arts (what year isnt?), especially for many opera houses, symphony orchestras, festivals and chamber music organizations, but high points also abounded. The following 10 prizes are bestowed in no particular order.

title: The Mets Gleeful Baroque Mash-Up
description: THE Oxford English Dictionary defines a pastiche as a medley of various ingredients; a hotchpotch, farrago, jumble. The word is derived from the 13th-century Latin pasticium, a savory Mediterranean pie filled with whatever is left over in the kitchen. A modern analogue, pastitsio, can be found at every Greek diner in the land.

title: Let Them Eat Kulfi: France Escapes to Fantasy India
description: The French have found a way to cope with the unrelenting bad economic news in Europe: escape to India. Not the real India but a fantasy land far removed from the realities of sinking currencies and credit-rating downgrades.

title: A Flat Year Overall for Crime in New York
description: The picture of crime in New York City in 2011 is shaping up as virtually a mirror image of the year before, according to police statistics.

title: Regulator Fines Barclays Capital Over Subprime Mortgages
description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said on Thursday that it had fined Barclays Capital $3 million for misrepresenting information about subprime mortgage securities the bank had sold from 2007 to 2010.

title: Class Parent: Giving Back to Teacher
A Voters Advice to Romney: Changing Your Mind Is a Good Trait
description: BETHLEHEM, N.H.  Mitt Romney came to the Elks Lodge here Thursday morning for coffee and conversation, but he left with a piece of unsolicited advice from a voter on how to spin his perceived flip-flops.

title: On Our Radar: Indias Growing Nuclear Sector
description: The rapid expansion of Indias nuclear energy sector, which is expected to triple in size by the end of the decade, is stirring anxiety about insufficient regulatory safeguards, construction in quake zones and the displacement of farmers and other landowners. [The Sydney Morning Herald]

title: 36 Hours: Cambridge, Mass.
description: Even with the winter chill settling in, Cambridge, a city of bookstores, art houses and eclectic bars, is an ideal place to visit despite the cold.

title: Dear FloFab: When Your Guest Wants to Preview the Menu
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Steve Jobs to Receive a Grammy
description: Steven P. Jobs was not a musician, and opinions are mixed about whether the invention of iTunes will be good for the recording industry in the long run, but his mark on how music is distributed appears indelible, and so the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has decided to give him a Grammy award in February.

title: The Get | Visnja Brdar Power Ring
description: The diamond pattern on this hand-carved rock crystal and white gold Power ring ($14,000) may look like a snowflake, but it actually represents the sun. The energy of the sun is the most powerful force on earth, says the New York-based jeweler Visnja Brdar. I wanted to create a piece that reflected that energy. When I wear it, I radiate and feel that anything is possible. Known for graphic simplicity and fastidious pav work, all of Brdars pieces have uplifting themes like Love, Courage, Freedom and Faith. She may as well have called this one Perseverance, since it took two years to make. I finally found a way for the crystal to appear as if it is floating on the finger. It is perfect.

title: Croatias Monumental Provocateur
description: ASK the Croatian artist Sanja Ivekovic about her work, and she is likely to minimize her role in it. It is not a genius that is making art but the collaboration of many people, she declared this month, speaking in heavily accented English, as she strode into the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art. We should be grateful not to God for giving us our talent but to the people who support us.

title: 36 Hours: Cambridge, Mass.
description: WHEN the leaves have fallen and the winter chill has set in, many small cities slip into a prolonged hibernation. But Cambridge barely misses a beat. During the holidays, tree branches are strung with tiny white lights, and local theater productions celebrate the season. A city of bookstores and coffeehouses, art-house cinemas and eclectic neighborhood bars, the Peoples Republic of Cambridge has traded its Puritan past for a dynamic, cosmopolitan present. Spread out along the tree-lined shore of the Charles River, the city is a dense collection of grand Federal and Greek Revival mansions and modest century-old bungalows, modern office towers and brick dormitories. Nicknamed Bostons Left Bank for its bohemian image, Cambridge is easy to caricature, but hard to dislike.

title: Hungary in the News
description: The news section, that is. Good article, confirming Kim Lane Scheppeles points and adding some color to the story.

title: Welcome Back, Clippers
description: While its hard to admit that the N.B.A. got anything right in its hubris-fueled lockout, we can take consolation in the fact that what turned out well was entirely unintentional. Even better: it will cost the owners money. Yes, what we got out of that petulant billionaires spat was a shorter N.B.A. season and one thats starting at a festive time  although playing so many games on Christmas Day is most decidedly festive overkill, and all of those people selling hot dogs and directing parking lot traffic really should have the day off.

title: 36 Seconds in Cambridge, Mass.
description: Cambridge is a city of bookstores, art-house cinemas and eclectic neighborhood bars.

title: Jesus Christ Superstar Announces Its Broadway Cast
description: Technically, Jesus Christ Superstar offers a stylized retelling of the story of Easter, up to the Crucifixion, and the Passover seder that was the Last Supper. But the producers of the coming Broadway revival of that Andrew Lloyd Webber/Tim Rice musical are using the Christmas season to announce the cast, which will keep intact the lineup from its La Jolla Playhouse incarnation in San Diego and retain most of the performers who originated the production at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario, Canada.

title: This week Ben Ratliff, Jon Pareles and Nate Chinen discuss some of the most memorable songs of 2011.
description: This week Ben Ratliff, Jon Pareles and Nate Chinen discuss some of the most memorable songs of 2011.

title: Take Christopher Plummers Advice
description: The Bagger spent some time with Christopher Plummer recently, over a couple of glasses of Far Niente, a California chardonnay he knew well. Of course Mr. Plummer, with a six-decade stage and film, career, has some words of advice for younger performers, should they ask.

title: The Music They Made
description: A musical collage of the musicians and songwriters who died during 2011.

title: Principals Protest Tally: 1,088
Apps and Games for Traveling Kids
description: The Practical Traveler of The Timess Travel section, Michelle Higgins, knows what it is to be a practical traveling parent. Shes provided a list of apps for iPads, iTouches and iPhones, along with a few offline games and tricks, that should help keep kids busy in cars and on planes during holiday trips. Some of her favorites are also mine (like any form of travel desk, Zingo to Go and Scribblenauts) and some I plan to check out (I have a daughter who will love My Playhome, and Im certain Highlights Hidden Pictures would be a hit).

title: At the Laundry, Rooting for a Clean Game
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On Saturday afternoon at MetLife Stadium, there will be a large (and loud) contingent of Jets fans wearing green. The Giants fans, clad in blue, will surely be heard, too.

title: Photographing the Unseeable
description: This week, nytimes.com published the final installment of the Lives Restored series, which profiled people who are functioning normally despite severe mental illness. Written by Benedict Carey and photographed by Damon Winter, the series also includes five videos that were produced by Nick Harbaugh, Nancy Donaldson and Soo-Jeong Kang and shot by Mr. Winter.

title: Poetry Pairing | In the Jewish Synagogue at Newport
description: Todays Poetry Pairing matches the Emma Lazarus poem In the Jewish Synagogue at Newport with a 2009 article, A Synagogue Despairs of a Sweeter New Year.

title: Drinking Over a Shows Demise, First Round on the House
description: They gathered in a darkened bar in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, long faces concealed by longer beards, to say goodbye to the show that called their borough home.

title: Spanish Man Arrested in Leak of Madonna Single
description: Spanish police have arrested a 31-year-old man and charged him with stealing a demo version of one of Madonnas songs and illegally posting it on the Internet, Reuters reported. The police identified the man only by his initials: J.M.R. He was arrested in Zaragoza, charged and released, pending a trial. Investigators described him as an avid Madonna fan.

title: Cleverest List of Theatrical Moments
description: ASKED to recall unforgettable moments from the year in theater, one writer after another for The New York Times suggested scenes from Jez Butterworths Jerusalem, which won Mark Rylance a Tony Award for best actor last spring. Stipulated: Jerusalem was full of memorable moments. Stipulated: The Timess critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood already named it among their Top 10 shows of the year. Further stipulated: No Jerusalem here. But much else to remember, some of it surfacing in the smallest and most offbeat of places.

title: House G.O.P. Leaders Agree to Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON  Bowing under intense pressure from members of their own party, House Republican leaders agreed Thursday to accept a temporary extension of the payroll tax cut, beating a hasty retreat from a showdown that Republicans increasingly saw as a threat to their election opportunities next year.

title: Case Study | On Beheading Bubbly
description: Though we like to think of ourselves as a humble people who disdain ostentatious display, there are those occasions that encourage, nay, demand the chest-thumping, post-touchdown hubris inherent in our species. One of these is the presentation of a frosty bottle of Champagne. Its like a convoluted Myers-Briggs test for personalities. Many people open such a gift, even on New Years Eve, with the gravity of a monk, showing the respect and discretion due a vinous masterwork. But there are those more excitable oenophiles, whose personal standard  What Would Pirates Do?  dictates freeing the bubbly soul by lopping off the bottles neck with a saber.

title: Arab League Delegates Arrive in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As violence continued around Syria, delegates from the Arab League traveled to Damascus on Thursday to start monitoring the governments promise to end its violent suppression of the nine-month-old uprising. The visit is intended to set the ground rules for a mission that is supposed to bring hundreds of observers to Syria in the coming weeks.

title: Two New Client Libraries: Times Wire and Campaign Cash
description: Now that we have 13 APIs to use, its time for some client libraries, too. Our APIs get a lot of use internally and on NYTimes.com, often in small parts of a larger project or to power a single interactive. In most of these cases weve resorted to pulling data directly from endpoints rather than writing clients to help manage the task. But were excited to release Ruby libraries that make it easier to interact with two of our APIs.

title: Coughlin, Ryan, Tebow: Answers for Readers
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers questions:

title: The Caucus Click: Competing Messages in N.H.
Twas the Week After Layoffs
description: What a great year its been on Wall Street! Zooming bank profits, rock-solid job security, widespread appreciation on Main Street for financiers and a European economic outlook as bright as Rudolphs nose.

title: The Choice Q. and A. on Facebook: An Invitation to Juniors, and a Recap
description: Thursday night on The Choice blogs Facebook page  facebook.com/nytimesthechoice  well host our final, hourlong admissions Q. and A. of the week (and the year). And wed like the main (but by no means only) theme to be this one: What college admissions homework might high-school juniors (and their parents) assign themselves over the holiday break, and what should their priorities be right after New Years?

title: Concord Monitor Endorses Huntsman
description: Even as Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich grab the headlines with a nasty slug-fest, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is quietly working New Hampshire in the hope of pulling a come-from-nowhere upset in the nations first primary.

title: The Subtle ECB
description: A number of people have asked me for my reaction to Floyd Norriss piece today on Europe. Its a good summary of the argument many people are making about why the European situation looks less dire right now than it seemed a few weeks ago.

title: Stephen Daldry, Directors Director
description: Not all of the awards buzz has faded for Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close, Stephen Daldrys 9/11 Oscar bait. Mr. Daldry, whose three previous features (The Hours, The Reader and Billy Elliot) were all Oscar nominees or winners, will receive the director of the year award from the Palm Springs International Film Festival, it announced today. In a statement, Harold Matzner, the festival chairman, said that Mr. Daldry would be honored for this haunting film and for all of his achievements as a directors director.

title: Popcast: The Best Songs of 2011
Students Say No to Healthful School Fare
description: The Los Angeles Unified School District broke new ground earlier this year when it started phasing out junk food and offering students healthful new fare. The decision by L.A. Unified, one of the largest districts in the nation, to swap out corn dogs and chocolate milk for quinoa salads and vegetarian curries was seen as a move that might inspire other districts across the country to do the same.

title: Hearing in Soldiers WikiLeaks Case Ends
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The military hearing against Pfc. Bradley Manning closed on Thursday, with lawyers and onlookers alternately portraying the young soldier as a traitor who acted with premeditation and as an emotionally troubled whistle-blower.

title: Taking the Plight of Homeless Veterans as His Own
description: I went for a run after eating Thanksgiving dinner this year, and by the time I got home, I couldnt stop thinking about how incredibly thankful I was to have a roof over my head and a warm bed to sleep in. My hands stung, and my feet were numb from the bitter cold. I started to think about how blessed I was to be sheltered from our brutal Minnesota winters.

title: Rhapsody, Veteran Streamer of Music, Reaches a Million Subscribers
description: Digital services like Spotify that stream millions of songs by subscription have made some of the music industrys biggest news this year. Facebook and taste makers like Rolling Stone have embraced these services as the future of music listening, while artists and record companies have fretted about whether they hurt download sales.

title: Apps for Wine Lovers on Your Gift List
description: Technology and the Internet have not yet infiltrated the dining room or the wine cellar the way they have the living room. But Gary Vaynerchuk, the online wine reviewer, recommends a few online gifts for wine lovers this season.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: This year seemed to have more than its fair share of iconic deaths, but this is not a greatest-hits issue. Instead, we gravitated to those with an untold tale. Ira Glass of This American Life edits a special section devoted to ordinary people.

title: Wheelies: The Two-Plus-Two Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Housekeepers Beat Teachers When It Comes to Holiday Tips
description: When it comes to holiday tipping and gifts, workers who scrub our floors tend to get more than people who educate our children, according to a survey from Consumer Reports.

title: Wines of The Times: Ros Champagne
description: The panel found as many different styles as there were shades of pink, but less complexity than in ordinary Champagnes, leaving them to question what made the ross so popular.

title: Controversy in Champagne Country
description: As the French government makes plans to expand Champagne country, farmers and landowners await the decision of whether their land qualifies  and increases in value 200 times over.

title: Approval of Reactor Design Clears Path for New Plants
description: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission unanimously approved a radical new reactor design on Thursday, clearing away a major obstacle for two utilities to begin construction on projects in South Carolina and Georgia.

title: Beilein Family Reunion Gets Competitive
description: Its a family reunion tonight at Crisler Arena, with Michigan Coach John Beilein facing off against his son, Patrick, who is in his first year as the director of operations at Bradley. Its a nonconference game between the Wolverines and Bradley, the first in a home-and-home set over the next two seasons.

title: Iran Navy to Hold War Games Near Crucial Sea Lanes
description: Iran put neighbors on notice Thursday that it was about to conduct vast naval exercises in the Arabian Sea, including war games near the Strait of Hormuz, a vital shipping lane for international oil traffic.

description: Nick Wingfield of The Times discusses Apples recent legal victory over HTC and Pedro Rafael Rosado samples new headphones and an Android speaker dock.
