title: Little Ratings Momentum as X-Factor Heads Into Finale
description: Although the first season of The X Factor was never the 20-million-viewer juggernaut that Simon Cowell, its creator-producer-judge, had promised, the singing competition has still been a success for Fox, with an average of 10.9 million viewers tuning in live for each episode. (Factoring in the audiences that watched the show on DVR in the following seven days, that number grows to 12.4 million.) But network executives are probably a little concerned with the lack of ratings momentum heading into the finale, which was evident on Wednesday night, when the final performance show was essentially flat when compared to last week, despite almost no original competition from the other networks. The 90-minute episode averaged 11.1 million total viewers, up slightly from 10.7 million last Wednesday, but down just as slightly in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment.

title: Fatigue Syndrome Study Is Retracted by Journal
description: The journal Science on Thursday fully retracted a controversial study that had linked a mouse leukemia retrovirus to chronic fatigue syndrome, a disabling illness affecting an estimated one million people in the United States.

title: Theater Listings: Dec. 23  29
description: Theater

title: The Giving Spree | Irene Neuwirth
description: Who: The jewelry designer Irene Neuwirth

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Dec. 23-29
description: DiMenna Childrens History Museum

title: Spare Times for Dec. 23-29
description: Around Town

title: Barkley to Stay at U.S.C.
description: Quarterback Matt Barkley announced Thursday that he would return to play his senior year at Southern California, a decision that revives one of college footballs most distinguished brands.

title: For the Lakers, Offense Will Be a Hurdle
description: Phil Jackson more than earned the right to dictate the terms of his own retirement, but his decision to step down as the head coach of the Los Angeles Lakers following last seasons playoff collapse could hardly have come at a worse time.

title: Dance Listings for Dec. 23-29
description: Dance

title: Neighborhood Joint | JoMart Chocolates
description: A confectionery in Madison, Brooklyn, has held onto its employees and its customers for decades.

title: A Family Tree Just Covered in Chocolate
description: WITH peanut butter fudge truffles, raspberry caramels and peppermint bark vying for her attention, Lorna Fontana, 12, had a difficult decision to make as she pressed her face to the glass counter at JoMart Chocolates like a kid, well, in a candy store.

title: The Magi at 40,000 Feet
description: ON Christmas morning I stood waiting to board an 8 a.m. flight to San Diego with Matheson and Cameron, my 14- and 12-year-old sons, in Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Dec. 23-29
description: Art

title: In Iowa, Conservative Republicans Have Overachieved Polls
description: In the Iowa caucus, expectations have historically mattered almost as much as actual results. Candidates like Pat Buchanan and Gary Hart who do better than the polls indicated have often received a big lift going into other states, even if they did not win Iowa.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Russia, Hungary and Iowa.

title: In Internal Canadian Documents, a Warning  on Oil Sands
description: Internal government documents show that Canadas scientific and environmental bureaucracy does not share the Conservative governments view that oil sands projects in Alberta have relatively little negative impact on the environment.

title: Victoria Gitman: On Display
description: David Nolan

title: STO: My Slow Called Life and Brian Novatny: Picture FIshing
description: Mulherin & Pollard

title: Paul Sharits
description: Greene Naftali

title: Grisaille
description: Luxembourg & Dayan

title: On Tour With Whiskey
description: From Virginia to San Francisco, a photographic tour of some of Americas whiskey distilleries.

title: Proud Penny Pinchers Guide for Surviving the Tough Times
description: This time of year ones thoughts turn toward family, friends, the best rum to decant into eggnog and  if you are like me, three years out of five  the vertiginous mountain of debt on your credit cards, and the financial reckoning that is breathing into your nostrils, a bit like a wolf.

title: Rye Is Back, With Flavors of Americana
description: IN gold-rush-era San Francisco, bars lined every block of the Barbary Coast, the area where pioneer mixologists  back when they were called bartenders  honed their craft. Rye whiskey was their staple. A hundred years later, a visitor would have been lucky to find one or two rye labels on the shelves of bars in major American cities; bourbon had taken over as the American whiskey.

title: Coming to a Bookstore Near You!
description: A video for the upcoming cookbook La Tartine Gourmande, based on the blog of the same name, made us wonder whether cookbook trailers picture a movie trailer, but with charming kitchens and light jazz swapped in for post-apocalyptic underworlds and techno  are slowly becoming as widespread as trailers in other corners of the publishing world.

title: Outspoken Afghan Rights Official Ousted
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  There have been few causes that Ahmad Nader Nadery, the prominent Afghan human rights activist, shied away from over the past decade: he spoke out on the killings of civilians by NATO and Taliban forces, on election fraud by President Hamid Karzais supporters, even on land grabs by rich and well-connected Afghans whose houses now dominate central Kabuls broken streets.

title: Is Americans Religious Freedom Under Threat?
Gingrich Wraps Up Virginia Swing
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Former House speaker Newt Gingrich used a stop here Thursday to criticize President Obama and Senate Democrats, and draw contrasts between himself and his rivals for the Republican nomination.

title: Dayne Crist to Kansas
description: The former Notre Dame quarterback Dayne Crist announced on Twitter Thursday that he would be playing his final college season for Charlie Weis at Kansas, an unlikely reunion of two men attempting to resuscitate their once high-profile careers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Russia, Hungary and Iowa.

title: A Very Hairy Christmas
description: Our favorite holiday card this year! It shows Hunter Musi, the son of the photographers Vincent J. Musi and Callie Shell.

title: Comments About the Lives They Lived Issue Here, Please
description: We tried a few new things with this years Lives They Lived issue. For starters, we invited Ira Glass and his producers at This American Life, the wonderful radio show we all love, to guest-edit a special section. We invited readers to submit their own photographs and stories of loved ones, which succeeded beyond our highest expectations. We compiled a series of famous last tweets. Finally, we did a bit of the old thing, and commissioned some of our favorite writers, including John Jeremiah Sullivan, Maureen Dowd, Dwight Garner and Michael Paterniti, to write short essays.

title: Mandatory Office Party and Night of Dirty Songs
description: The average holiday office party can be divided into two parts: awkward conversation with co-workers before the booze kicks in, and even more awkward conversation with co-workers after it does. Thats why the Miser tends to bow out early and head to parties where letting loose is less likely to damage professional reputations.

title: Messrs. Lonely-Hearts, in an Unhip Gay Bar
description: A good man is hard to find, especially in this city. But is it harder or easier to find one than to find a good bar? And is it ever even possible to find such a man in such a bar?

title: The Caucus Click: Bachmann Goes From Bus to Bike
TimesCast | Bombings in Baghdad
description: Amid growing sectarian tensions, a series of coordinated bombings across Baghdad kill at least 63.

title: Gotta Dance? Swing on Over
description: THERE are swinging parties in Manhattan nearly every night. The trick is in knowing where to find them.

title: The Book of Books: What Literature Owes the Bible
description: The Bible is the model for and subject of more art and thought than those of us who live within its influence, consciously or unconsciously, will ever know.

title: TimesCast | Italy's Deep Spending Cuts
description: As Italy's new government passes strict austerity cuts, holiday shoppers and merchants in Rome react.

title: A Modern-Day Ark, With Children, Animals and Even Romance
description: Cameron Crowe may be the last of the Hollywood romantics. Hes best known for his stories about love and longing, for films that immortalize the moment when characters bare their hearts, as when John Cusack serenades a girl with a boom box in Say Anything and Rene Zellweger tells Tom Cruise he had her at hello in Jerry Maguire. These are images of such excruciating sincerity that they invite, almost demand cynicism. Yet its their openness that makes them work. And while his films depend on the familiar image of the couple in love, these are relationships that exist within a larger tribe, a band, a family and now, with We Bought a Zoo, a menagerie.

title: Shes Gorgeous, but a Nasty Hostess
description: A ways into Johannes Wielands new you, the performer Eva Mohn turns to the audience and asks bitingly, Are you all waiting for that dancing part? Well, she says, Its not going to happen, then adds, Sorry. In fact, there is dancing to come, some of it excellent, but the self-reflexive comment, the defensive and contemptuous lie, is more characteristic of this 2008 work, which made a repeat appearance at the Merce Cunningham Studio on Wednesday.

title: At George Washington, a New Team Steps Into the Starting Blocks
Seasons Greetings
description: Brent Clarks Photos of Christmas

title: Tonight Is Tango Night
description: Marc Hussner and Kristina McFadden, dance instructors from Philadelphia, perform at tango night at the You Should Be Dancing studio in Manhattan.

title: Giving Santa a Bad Name
description: WHAT could provoke a boy to cry hysterically and scream that he hates his parents? In one case, it was getting a Hello Kitty sweater for Christmas.

title: Preserving Artifacts of Anti-Semitism
description: Anti-Semitic propaganda used to be mass-produced and available in the guise of home accessories. Manufacturers in Europe and the United States caricatured Jews as shabby, greedy and menacing, and put these depictions on cigar boxes, candlesticks, trays, tiles, walking sticks, puppets and board games.

title: Better Heard Than Seen? A Cheeky Quiz Show Tests a Hotter Medium
description: The NPR program Wait Wait ... Dont Tell Me! has always seemed like the news satire show that wished this were still 1952. It is content with a somewhat sleepy pace, and it delves no deeper than improvised quips can go.

title: Artists Equipped With a Social Conscience
description: One of many artistic casualties of the McCarthy-era blacklists was the Photo League, a New York school and salon for amateur and professional photographers. Progressive in its politics and uncompromising in its aesthetics, the league was the place to be if you had a hand-held 35-millimeter camera and a left-leaning social conscience  and particularly if you believed, to borrow a bit of contemporary parlance, that photography was fine art for the 99 percent.

title: To Share and to Sip
description: Some of my cousins and I, who have more disposable income, enjoy fine wines. I take a treat bottle to holiday meals and several nice budget bottles. This holiday, I brought a $200 bottle, which a wine-enthusiast cousin praised. My brother, who knows nothing of wine, proceeded to drink half of it and exclaim, Tastes just like the $3 bottle to me. Is there a polite way to ask nonoenophiles to drink the less expensive wine and let the wine lovers enjoy the special bottles?

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Thoughts on the I.P.O. Market and Steve Jobs on Gaming
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web.

title: A Native Cultures Reach, Both Visual and Emotional
description: Kindred Spirits: Native American Influences on 20th Century Art at the Peter Blum Gallery in SoHo closes out the New York gallery year with a great group show. This superb yet fraught exhibition creates a vortex of history, visual culture, language and ideas that is both heartbreaking and exhilarating. It seems almost impossible to straighten out, but that may be what makes it so valuable.

title: Remembering Pina Bausch
description: Images from the life and career of the choreographer Pina Bausch.

title: 3-D Tribute to Artistic Impulse
description: One of the interesting and unexpected film stories of 2011 is about 3-D, which simultaneously lost commercial potency and gained artistic credibility. Those who dismiss the format as the industrial gimmick (and excuse for price gouging) that it frequently is may need to reconsider now that a handful of certified auteurs have given it a try. Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese, grand old men of baby-boomer Hollywood, have made 3-D childrens tales (The Adventures of Tintin and Hugo), which is certainly noteworthy. More remarkable, perhaps even astonishing, is that Werner Herzog and Wim Wenders, stalwarts and survivors of the iconoclastic New German Cinema of the 1970s, have used 3-D in new documentaries.

title: Getting Personal
description: A lovely, bust-length portrait painted by Francesco Francia in 1510 pictures a winsome, long-haired boy of 10 named Federigo Gonzaga. Dressed in a black gown over a white chemise and sporting a jauntily tilted cap and a bejeweled gold necklace, he holds the pommel of a sword and gazes dreamily off to his left. Under blue sky and fair-weather clouds, a pastoral sward extends behind him to a city in the far blue haze.

title: Stage Shows With Back Stories
description: RARELY does a Broadway show become one of the biggest cultural news stories of the year. But Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark had more offstage intrigue than any production in recent memory  as well as a record-setting budget of $75 million, six delays to its opening night and the gold-plated creative team of U2s Bono and the Edge and the director Julie Taymor. So its no surprise that from beginning to end Spidey dominated the year in theater news. But his wasnt the only story (just about a third of them, in this modest account):

title: Marching to Their Own Drummers
description: ENCASED in pouches with a small speaker attached to the outside, iPhones dangled from belts and wrists. They emitted dings and chatters as some 60 people began strolling along the High Line on Wednesday night.

title: Campaign Finance Law Survives Another Court Challenge
description: A New York City law that limits campaign contributions from individuals and entities that have business dealings with the city survived another legal challenge on Wednesday, when a federal appeals panel ruled that the law did not violate the free-speech and equal-protection provisions of the United States Constitution.

title: How to Trim Spending on Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: New York, Home to the Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking a Million Trees, With at Least That Many Stories
description: Outdoor performances can be the worst. For this one, a jackhammer almost drowned out Jerry Stillers opening lines:

title: Electromagnetic Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Kids and Teachers, Online
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Fractured Society, Ethnic War Kindles Both Hatred and Desire
description: In the Land of Blood and Honey tells the story of two acquaintances who become enemies, lovers and each others mirror during the Bosnian war. The movie opens in 1992 right before the fighting started and soon after Ajla (Zana Marjanovic), an artist and a Muslim, goes on a date with Danijel (Goran Kostic), a cop and a Bosnian Serb. Recently acquainted, the two meet up at a club, where they fall into each others arms, dance and flirt, nestled in an exuberant, raucous humanity, a communion that abruptly ends when a bomb detonates inside the club. The old world falls away and in its place there is dust, blood and Ajla and Danijel staggering toward their newly divided worlds.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Yes, Perry Has Lured Business to Texas. But How Many Jobs Created Is in Dispute.
description: As Gov. Rick Perry pushes his job creation initiatives on the presidential campaign trail, he often touts the Texas Enterprise Fund, an economic development program that the governors office says is bringing 59,000 jobs and $14.7 billion in capital investment to Texas.

title: Swinging Parties
description: A look at Manhattans swing-dance demimonde.

title: Send In the Food Trucks
description: AN urban farm off the East River. Artisanal food and crafts sold out of recycled shipping containers at the Dekalb Market. Smorgasburg and the Brooklyn Flea on the Williamsburg waterfront.

title: The Renaissance Portrait
description: Images from the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: A Hero With a Snout and a Tender Heart
description: Set during the political volatility of between-the-wars Italy, Hayao Miyazakis animated 1992 adventure Porco Rosso introduces an unlikely hero: a portly, chauvinistic seaplane pilot with the head of a pig and the heart of Rhett Butler.

title: Dispensing With the Penthouse
description: THE sluggish economy took its toll on Absolutely Wild Event Design, a party planning and flower business run by Peter Cunningham and Paolo Mizrahi. The two men, partners in business and in life, began to have second thoughts about their steep rent  $6,100 a month.

title: Egyptian Military Adviser Calls Attack on Woman Justified
description: An adviser to Egypts military rulers said in a newspaper interview published on Thursday that a brutal attack on a female protester by Egyptian soldiers on Saturday was justified because the woman had insulted the army.

title: When a Monster Plied the West Side
description: THOUSANDS of kids are going to find model train sets under the tree on Christmas morning  freight trains, circus trains, Wild West trains, military trains, express trains, commuter trains. ... But one train setup you wont see is a replica of the street-level freight line that plied the West Side from 1846 to 1941. The line killed and mutilated hundreds of people, and its path well earned the name Death Avenue.

title: Getting Back in the Black
description: THOUGH the threat of foreclosure has eased a little in the last 18 months, more than 2.6 million households are at least 60 days delinquent on their mortgage payments, according to Hope Now, a nonprofit coalition of lenders and agencies.

title: Bollywood Baddie Is Ready to Take On Europe
description: If Mission: Impossible and Oceans Eleven had a bombastic, funny and slick cousin, it might be Don 2.

title: Q & A
description: When the Trees Block the View

title: A Cat Knows a Thing or Two About Scoops
description: Its a Christmas present for cat lovers. Miss Minoes, the tweaked title of a 2001 Dutch film by Vincent Bal, is being given an American theatrical run (dubbed into English), and its a pleasantly quirky, family-friendly fable with lots of meowing.

title: Offstage Improvements for Goodspeed
description: EAST HADDAM VILLAGE

title: Philanthropy by the Rest of Us
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: Newt Gingrich, the Happy Warrior
description: Newt Gingrich, the Happy Warrior

title: A Pair of Buds Both Eco- and Ear-Friendly
description: Thinksounds ms01 headphones dont make much of an impact  but thats not necessarily a bad thing.

title: Gay and Vilified in Uganda
description: Kampala, Uganda

title: Monks of Burma
description: Portraits of Burmese Monk Life

title: Sometimes Just a Salary Is Not Enough to Live On
description: Gov. Rick Perry has opened a whole new realm of campaign finance.

title: 2011: A Year in Pictures
description: The Times has gathered what it believes are the best photos of the year.

title: The Battle for Los Angeles Rejoined
description: LOS ANGELES  If the last shall be first and the first shall be last, that day seems to be coming for this citys two N.B.A. teams. Of course, the passage is biblical where the time frame is eternal  which was how long it seemed it would take the lowly Clippers to match the Lakers, local lords of all they surveyed.

title: After Charging 8, Army Is Scrutinized on Hazing
description: Under Army rules, a superior is allowed to subject a soldier to certain kinds of corrective measures, including verbal reprimands and a reasonable number of repetitions of authorized physical exercises.

title: Electric Grid in Texas Faces Multiple Challenges
description: Will the lights stay on in 2012? Texas electricity experts cannot say for certain.

title: Retailers Are Slashing Prices Ahead of Holiday
description: Half off at the entire store at Ann Taylor. Sixty percent at Gap. Forty percent off almost everything at Abercrombie & Fitch.

title: The Post-Truth Campaign
description: Suppose that President Obama were to say the following: Mitt Romney believes that corporations are people, and he believes that only corporations and the wealthy should have any rights. He wants to reduce middle-class Americans to serfs, forced to accept whatever wages corporations choose to pay, no matter how low.

title: Michigan City Turns Down Millions of Dollars, Saying Federal Money Is Not Free
description: Cats lie down with dogs.

title: Social Fixer Makes Facebook More Fun and Functional
description: If you spend a lot of time on Facebook, you probably have a small list of petty gripes about the sites user interface. Why does Facebook show me posts Ive already read? Can I break up my giant News Feed into smaller sections? And please, please, can someone make that scrolling ticker in the upper right corner stop moving before it drives me insane?

title: For Transgender Detainees, a Jail Policy Offers Some Security
description: For as long as she can remember, Maribel said, she has felt that she was different. She was born a boy in Mexico, and came to the United States at 16. Two years later, she started taking hormone pills and later underwent some operations to become physically the woman she always believed herself to be.

title: Exxon Spars With Iraq Over Lack of Payment
description: The turmoil in Iraq after the United States troop withdrawal is extending to its vital petroleum industry.

title: For Burress and Gilbride, Jets-Giants Is a Reunion
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Plaxico Burress left prison in June after serving 20 months on a gun charge, the Giants began an awkward courtship in an attempt to bring him back. Kevin Gilbride, the offensive coordinator, was one of Burresss biggest supporters.

title: The Sidney Awards, Part II
description: Book tours are lonely, yet after spending four months promoting his novel Freedom, Jonathan Franzen went to an island 500 miles off the coast of Chile to be alone. He got at least one thing out of it, a profound essay in The New Yorker called Farther Away, the winner of another of this years Sidney Awards.

title: How to Control Libya Missiles? Buy Them Up
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The United States is discussing with the Libyan interim government the creation of a program to purchase shoulder-fired, heat-seeking missiles from militia members and others who gathered them up during the war, American government officials said.

title: Colleges Fail to Complete Required Safety Plans
description: More than three years after the fatal shootings at Northern Illinois University prompted a state law requiring colleges and universities to put safety plans in effect, few of Cook Countys 63 higher-education institutions have filed them and many may not have made them public.

title: Fighting to Hold On to a Gift From Santa
description: This story begins with a letter from a 13-year-old girl composed so long ago that its opening lines speak of a technology almost never heard of today.

title: The House Backs Down
description: For a full year, House Republicans have replaced governing with confrontations that they allow to reach the brink of crisis, only then making extreme demands in exchange for a resolution. On Thursday, that strategy crumbled. Battered by public opinion and undermined by more reasonable Senate Republicans, the Houses leaders backed down and signed off on a deal to continue the payroll tax cut and unemployment insurance for two months.

title: Rules Eased on Gun Sales to Noncitizens
description: WASHINGTON  The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives is relaxing restrictions on the sale of guns to noncitizens because Justice Department lawyers have concluded that the rules had no legal basis, officials said on Thursday.

title: Do We Hate the Rich or Dont We?
description: Heres an example of how the results of polls taken at the same time can be given exactly opposite interpretations.

title: Soldiers Choice
description: So this is Christmas, season of peace, time to reflect on the people coming home from a war that most Americans say was not worth it, and those still fighting in another war that raises new doubts by the day.

title: Get Tougher on Assad
description: At the end of a tumultuous year in which strongmen across the Middle East were toppled, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria is still standing, still killing his people. And leaders in Russia, China and Arab states still havent done enough to pressure him to stop. The United Nations says more than 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in the brutal government crackdown in nine months of protests.

title: A Soldiers Death
description: Private Danny Chen was alone when he died. The Army says he shot himself in a guard tower in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan. But, in an extraordinary case alleging criminal culpability in a suicide, it has charged eight soldiers in connection with his death, saying they bullied Private Chen into killing himself. Seven enlisted men face counts that include involuntary manslaughter, negligent homicide and assault. One officer, a first lieutenant, is charged with dereliction of duty.

title: Dismay, Then Disbelief at Arrest of N.F.L. Player
description: SAN ANTONIO  The Sam Hurd they thought they knew grew up here, in the shadow of the Alamodome. His family still lives in the house on Indiana Avenue, the one with chipped white paint, cracked windows upstairs and a speedboat marooned in the backyard.

title: A Tip of the Hat to the Master Mapmakers, and They Kept It Legal
description: Black, white and Latino factions in the Chicago City Council are feuding over boundaries for a new ward map necessitated by population changes. It could force an expensive election referendum.

title: Iraq Needs New Premier, Top Sunni Politician Says
description: WASHINGTON  As Iraqi and American officials struggled to contain the political crisis in Iraq, Iraqs Sunni vice president said on Thursday that the prospects for creating a genuine power-sharing arrangement with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki were so dim that Iraqi political factions should search for another Shiite politician to serve as prime minister.

title: Black Women Enlisting at Higher Rates in U.S. Military
description: Black women are enlisting in the military at far higher rates than are white or Hispanic women, and they now represent nearly a third of all the women in the armed forces, a new study by the Pew Research Center has found.

title: Timely Aid for Europes Banks
description: This week, the European Central Bank, under the energized leadership of Mario Draghi, took the desperately needed step of injecting hundreds of billions of euros into the Continents tottering banking system.

title: Blindsided by Financial Crisis, and Trying to Rebuild
description: To Tahesha Calder, her bond with her young son was slipping away. It seemed as if whenever she had a chance to see him, he was asleep.

title: F.C.C. Seeks to Ease Media Ownership Rule
description: The Federal Communications Commission is preparing to relax a longstanding rule that limits the ability of companies to own both a newspaper and a television or radio station in the same local market.

title: Onward Christian Soldiers
description: Alongside the great armies mobilizing for war across the North in the fall of 1861, another organization, which would likewise have a great impact on the lives of American soldiers, got started in New York City. At a meeting of the citys Y.M.C.A. chapter, 36 delegates passed a resolution establishing the United States Christian Commission.

title: Haiti: President Retires Raunchy Singing Act
description: President Michel Martelly will not perform again as his alter ego, Sweet Micky, after all, an adviser said Thursday. Mr. Martelly, who before his election in April had a long career as a singer known for dressing in drag and disrobing on stage, had said in September he would retake the stage on Dec. 23 to raise $10 million for education. But an adviser said the concert had been postponed indefinitely due to the holiday season and the complexity of organizing such an event.

title: Local College Hoops Fans Must Look Around
description: Journalistic objectivity is put to the test whenever Marquette University plays basketball. I went to school in that gritty, lively patch of Milwaukee just south of the late, great Avalanche Bar, and it was a life-altering experience.

title: Communities in Two States Are Puzzled Over a Killing
description: His body was found on the edge of a 70-acre apple orchard, slowly burning amid the brush, twigs and trash just off the shoulder of a rural road in Pennsylvania.

title: Facebook Gives Users a Primer on Ads
description: Millions of users who visited their Facebook pages on Wednesday may have noticed a light blue banner that read: About Ads: Ever wonder how Facebook makes money? Get the Details. Clicking on a link in the text took visitors to a page that explained why Facebook users see the ads they see.

title: The Year in (New York) Pictures
description: Compelling photographs from New York and the region including Occupy Wall Street, the 10th Anniversary of September 11th terrorist attack, and Hurricane Irene.

title: Preparations Different for a Home-and-Home Contest
description: Before every Giants and Jets home game, the visitors locker rooms at MetLife Stadium are prepped for that weekends influx of out-of-town behemoths. Plates of food are ordered. Laundry accommodations are made. A staff of attendants is dispatched to help deal with everything from corralling the endless wads of athletic tape to mopping up sweat stains.

title: Using Googles Data to Reach Consumers
description: THE viruses that Google researchers usually focus on are those that strike computers, but in recent years, they have studied those that infect people, too.

title: New Law School Sues Bar Association
description: A law school in Tennessee that was denied accreditation by the American Bar Association sued the organization on Thursday, accusing it of antitrust violations and of depriving the school of due process.

title: Comparing the Liu Inquiry to a Soldiers Hazing
description: Chinese-American leaders came to the defense of the embattled city comptroller, John C. Liu, on Thursday, comparing the federal inquiry into his campaign fund-raising to what has been called a hazing campaign before the death of Pvt. Danny Chen.

title: China: Confrontation Over Coal Plant Enters 3rd Day
description: Police officers and protesters concerned about environmental pollution from a planned coal-fired power plant confronted each other for a third day in Haimen, Guangdong Province. The protests began Tuesday when thousands of people blocked an expressway to demand the local government cancel plans to build the plant. The police fired tear gas to try to disperse the crowd, according to a local resident reached by telephone. Chinese news organizations reported that officials said they would suspend the project. But on Thursday, police officers armed with tear gas guns sealed off the highway as a group of protesters faced them. Some news agencies reported that there were some arrests. Haimen is 90 miles from Wukan, a fishing village that evicted Communist Party officials and the police over a land dispute. Leaders there announced Wednesday they were halting their protest.

title: When Tears Flow in Court, Its Pass a Tissue and Just Wait for the Agony to End
description: Courthouse regulars know the signs: the trembling fingers, the sniffle, the telltale blow of the nose.

title: Many Ski Areas Lack an Essential Ingredient
description: WEST DOVER, Vt.  There were far too many skis on hand this week at High Altitude, a rental shop on the road to Mount Snow here, and Andrew Glover, the manager, was far too lonely.

title: Nationals Get Starter; Cardinals Land Beltran
description: Two significant moves reignited baseballs hot stove after it had seemingly cooled in advance of the holiday weekend.

title: Stores Remove Formula After Boy Dies
description: Two major retail chains, including Walmart, have removed certain packages of Enfamil, a popular brand of infant formula, from thousands of stores after a Missouri infant who consumed the product died from a rare bacterial infection.

title: Friday: Man of Steel
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Interesting looking grid, yes? Weve seen similar ones before; in fact, it reminds me somewhat of this Frank Longo puzzle from 2004 (Across Lite, Solution). Thats O.K. There are only so many permutations of design possible in a 1515 grid, after all, and its whats on the inside that counts, right?

title: Nurses Plan Walkout at St. Lukes-Roosevelt
description: Nurses at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital will go on strike on Jan. 3 unless last-ditch negotiations succeed in bridging a divide over wages, according to leaders in the New York State Nurses Association, which issued a 10-day strike warning early Thursday on behalf of 1,300 registered nurses at the hospital.

title: Shopping for Presents While Most Are Asleep
description: The tourists had long vacated Times Square, leaving the streets there and to the south nearly empty; even the halal food vendors on 34th Street had packed up their kebabs for the night. Yet there it was: The sound of Christmas carols emanating from outdoor speakers at Herald Square, an aural enticement for the faithful to come to shop, regardless of the hour.

title: Lottery Numbers
For $101,000, the 12 Days of Christmas Are Covered
description: Giving the holiday presents of a French hen, a milking maid, a leaping lord or even a partridge in a pear tree is rather unlikely in this day and age. But the gifts from the favorite holiday carol The 12 Days of Christmas are lighthearted clues to how the economy is faring.

title: The Lure of the Hedge Fund, Despite Poor Performance
A Victory Considerably Aided by the Other Side
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama did not win much substantively with his victory Thursday over House Republicans in their showdown over extending payroll tax cuts and unemployment aid for two months. But he got a lot politically: a big start toward retiring the perception  fair or not, and even among Democrats  that in a pinch with the other party he will inevitably surrender.

title: Wukan Journal
description: After a land-dispute protest which attracted media from around the world, life in Wukan, China, seems to have returned to normal for now.

title: Oil Spill Moves Toward Nigerian Coast
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  An oil slick roughly 350 square miles in size from a Royal Dutch Shell platform is slowly making its way toward the southern Nigerian coast, threatening wildlife and widespread shore pollution, Nigerian officials said Thursday.

title: Financial Aid Changes Game as Ivy Sports Teams Flourish
description: The eight Ivy League colleges, renowned for their academics, were also once among the countrys highest-achieving athletic institutions, with national champions and multiple prominent and ranked sports teams.

title: New Models of Implants Not Better, Study Finds
description: A new study suggests that the recent technology for artificial hips and knees did not perform any better than older, less expensive designs.

title: Canny Villagers Grasp Keys to Loosen Chinas Muzzle
description: WUKAN, China  As journalists and bloggers began trickling into Wukan last week, residents decided to put to use a two-story house, once the home of a family that left for Hong Kong some time ago. They turned it into the de facto press center of this fishing village of 13,000.

title: Silent Night (or Two) for Attack Ads
description: WASHINGTON  Santa Claus is bringing a very special present for Newt Gingrich this weekend: a bit of relief.

title: Rangers Capitalize on Islanders Mistakes
description: Since being referred to as probably the softest team weve played against by San Jose Sharks center Joe Thornton on Oct. 31, the Rangers are 16-5-1  their latest victory a 4-2 nailbiter over the improving Islanders on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Benefits, and a Few Snags, in Recruiting
description: For Ivy League athletics, there have been some additional, indirect benefits  and veiled complications  to the new financial-aid initiatives instituted throughout the league.

title: Thousands of Dollars of Work Offers Shaky Assurance
description: Craig Irving just bought a 1920s bungalow in the Rockridge neighborhood of Oakland last October and the house starts to move, he said. The fact that his new house had been seismically retrofitted  a common procedure to reinforce older buildings in the Bay Area against possible earthquake damage  had been a selling point, he said, but even so his first thought was, Please dont let this be the big one.

title: Pakistani Premier Warns of Plotting by Military
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani lashed out against his countrys powerful military on Thursday, warning of conspiracies against the civilian government. His accusations threw a spotlight on swirling rumors that the military might have plotted a coup after being humiliated by the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

title: Corrections: December 23
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: X Factor Watch: And the Winner Is
description: Melanie Amaro, a 19-year-old from Florida with a power voice and an apparent gift for making almost any hairdo look good, won The X Factor on Thursday night, beating out Josh Krajcik, the man with the most compelling rasp in America, for a $5 million recording contract.

title: Bleeding Green: Jets Fans Have a Home at Last
description: Brian Bassett is the founder of SNYs The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at @Brian_Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

title: Holiday on Monday  Christmas (Observed)
description: NEW YORK

title: Fire at Home in Texas Ends Former Iraq Commanders Run for the Senate
description: SAN ANTONIO  Ricardo S. Sanchez rummaged through a pile of charred rubble in the backyard of his home here one recent morning. He picked up a small book with ripped and stuck-together pages. It was a prayer book one of his children had given his wife. He found what appeared to be a blackened, soggy rag. Unfolding it, he realized he was holding his daughters baptismal dress.

title: Dyed in Blue: Unable to Stand a House Divided
description: Ed Valentine is the editor of Big Blue View, a Giants blog. He and Brian Bassett of The Jets blog will write in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

title: E-Mail Error Heightens Rape Fears in Mission
description: On Dec. 8, the residents of Fair Oaks Street in the Mission woke up to the news that a brutal rape had taken place in the early morning on their normally placid street.

title: Remembering a Founder Who Never Stopped Learning
description: Last May, The Bay Citizen, an online news organization founded in 2010 by the financier and philanthropist Warren Hellman, came upon a story involving a prominent San Franciscan: Warren Hellman.

title: In Treating Disabled, Potent Drugs and Few Rules
description: Something was happening to Katie Strignano.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/23/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/23/2011

title: After Missing Out Last Year, 7 States to Share Almost $200 Million in Education Grants
description: Seven states that narrowly lost out in last years Race to the Top school improvement competition will share nearly $200 million in the latest round of winners announced Thursday by federal education officials.

title: Year in New York Pictures
description: NEW YORK has always been too big an idea to be rendered successfully in a single image: simultaneously cruel and generous, dazzling and demeaning, unbearably vibrant and  as it waits to see what path a tropical storm will take  suspensefully calm. But one thing that almost every New York moment has in common is a surprise of some sort. Some surprises are dreadful. An 8-year-old boy named Leiby Kletzky was supposed to walk the seven blocks back to his home in Borough Park one day in July, but he never made it. Other surprises were joyful. Same-sex couples did not go into the year thinking they would have the right to marry before the summer was out. Felix Ramirez and Peter Vargas of the Bronx had already been together 24 years by the time they were wed at City Hall. (Or at least near it.)

title: Word of the Day | unfettered
description: unfettered \n-fe-trd\ adjective

title: Don Sharp Dies at 89; Director Who Revived Hammer Horror Film Company
description: Don Sharp, a veteran film director who had never watched a horror movie until Hammer Films  the English studio described, usually admiringly, as dripping cinematic blood  enlisted him in the mid-1960s to help revivify its presentation of Gothic terror, died on Sunday. He was 89.

title: Doe Avedon, Fashion Model and Actress, Dies at 86
description: Doe Avedon, a bookish beauty reluctantly transformed into a high-fashion model at the hands of a visionary photographer, Richard Avedon  a story that inspired the 1957 musical Funny Face, about a bookish beauty (Audrey Hepburn) reluctantly transformed into a high-fashion model at the hands of a visionary photographer (Fred Astaire)  died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 86.

title: North Korea Warns South to Show Respect for Kim Jong-il
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea urged South Korea on Friday to show proper respect over the death of its leader, Kim Jong-il, calling the Souths decision to express sympathy for the North Korean people but not to send a government delegation to Mr. Kims funeral next week an unbearable insult and mockery of our dignity.

title: Arab Spring
description: THE BREATH AND HUM of democracy seemed almost a libidinous thing in parts of the Middle East, but, in truth, the body heat had been simmering for years. The protests took hold in Tunisia in late 2010 after the street vendor Mohamed Bouazizi set himself on fire. The kindle caught and the spirit of his self-immolation lit a fuse across the region. A wave of protests struck Algeria, Egypt, Yemen, Jordan. Almost as soon as protesters in Cairo were being herded away from Tahrir Square, they were dancing at the news of Mubaraks resignation. Ruling families began to fall. Power-transfer treaties were brokered. Parliaments were dissolved. Monarchs locked their gates and boarded their windows. In Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was ousted and killed. NATO planes streaked a sky so blue it seemed it to speak of other Septembers. Faces, too, were lit by a new blue light. It was the era of the revolution down through the wires: time was collapsed and geography shrunk by the use of social networking. The whole world was indeed watching, listening, e-mailing. Some in the media lost their lives for the art of the images that emerged  the photographs didnt just capture singular moments, but they looked backward and forward at the same time, at what has happened, and what is yet to come. Thelight from the Arab Spring rose from the ground up; the hopeis now that the darkness doesnt fall.

title: Occupy Wall Street
description: WE ARE THE 99 PERCENT. It was so much beyond a local slogan: the louder it was spoken, the more it began to say. My job, my streets, my economy, my riot, my skin. Cities shook their souls out. The yearning went global. Some protesters poured gasoline into bottles and lighted the sky with fire. Others unfurled hammocks under light poles. The idea was to be seen, to be heard, to be tweeted. The year 2011 was an evanescent spectacle of anger. Every corner was a world, and every world had its corners. The bankers stood back, the corporations hushed a moment, the politicians held their breath, and the cops took out their pepper spray. It might have begun in Wisconsin, had its adolescence in Greece, and shattered the night in London, but it lost and won its innocence in Zuccotti Park. Suddenly, a tent had as much meaning as a tower. Kids from all over the country boiled collard greens in the courtyard of commerce. The citys bureaucrats tried frantically to barricade them in, or out  nobody seemed sure which. The anger rolled all the way down to Wall Street and the markets shivered a moment. When cold weather kicked in, the tents began to disappear and the anger diffused, but the images remained, another sort of fire in flight.

title: The Nation
description: SOMETIMES there is a necessity for anniversaries, even for things that cannot be forgotten. The memorial services for 9/11 were remarkable for their grace and dignity. The falling water, beside the reflecting pools, spoke volumes. While the Republicans fumbled for their own sort of memory  trying somehow to bring back the apparent ease of the Reagan years  the rest of the country drove down a street of foreclosed homes. We were all, in some way, looking for a brand-new roof.

title: The World
description: THOSE WERENT JUST tank lights leaving the desert behind. That was the darkness of a nearly nine-year war made visible. The soldiers moved through the sandstorms, and landed back home in the United States to deal with the continuing legacy of American foreign policies. In 2011, Barack Obamas promises were finally beginning to find their way onto the front pages. A spectacular nighttime raid found Osama bin Laden in Abbottabad, Pakistan. The helicopters landed. The weight of the past was kicked up in the dust. Author of a decade of killing, Bin Laden had endpages that were quick and sharp. He was shot dead, buried at sea, and the White House held its breath: it sounded so much like a sigh of joy, exhausted and necessary. The soldiers continued their journeys: it was a big world they were returning to. The seven billionth baby was born, starting global discussions on issues of environment, health and technology. Europe teetered on the edge of ruin, stunned by even more economic philandering. In the fall, lights were lit for Kim Il-sung and a regime that has hidden its face. In Norway the island of Utoya heard gunshots among the trees. Parts of Africa were dealing, yet again, with an almost impossible hunger and thirst. But stories and images are always new, no matter how old the theme. The surprise of the world is that it can still surprise us.

title: Nature
description: THE WATER ROSE. And rose. Soon there were traffic lights flipping, doors tumbling, tatami mats spinning in the current. Cars began to float alongside washing machines, computers, people. The incredible could occur. And then the tsunami seemed to wash away the last vain dream of the 20th century: the nuclear answer. The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant went into meltdown and watched its poisons filter out to sea, and what remained is what we all must live with: the democratic rage of nature. No matter what we do, we cannot regulate how we are shaped by weather. We look for calm, but there is always an inevitability of storm. The images from Joplin, Mo., were pure with grief. A snowstorm paralyzed Tulsa, Okla. The Souris River shed more than a tear. The streets of Bangkok were almost apocalyptic during floods. There were droughts, earthquakes, wildfires scattering animals like dice. So, the question, then, is ancient: How with such rage shall beauty hold a plea? Rescuers in Turkey put their fingers on part of the pulse when they managed to pull 2-week-old Azra Karaduman from the rubble. Her mother and grandmother also emerged safely. She was tiny and voiceless, yet she said so much.

title: Milestones
description: A PHOTOGRAPH is sometimes a perfect testament to the notion that we cant afford to lose our delight. While the news, and its makers, might dwell on what weve lost, we occasionally still witness the most remarkable music: marriages, journeys, longings, births and returns. Every now and then, the ground just wont show its shadows.

title: In Russia, the Bhagavad Gita Has a Date in Court
The Arab Spring, Seen From Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Last week, a photograph of Dilma Rousseffs terrorism trial in 1970 circulated on the Internet, sending shockwaves across Brazil. She was 22 and an active member of a guerrilla cell fighting the dictatorial regime of the day. In the shot, young Dilma looks pretty and clean-faced, like a freedom-fighter girl taking on a gerontocracy of mighty generals.

title: News Quiz | Dec. 23, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Dec. 23, 1986 | Voyager Aircraft Completes First Nonstop Around-the-World Flight
description: On Dec. 23, 1986, the experimental airplane Voyager, piloted by Dick Rutan and Jeana Yeager, completed the first nonstop, around-the-world flight without refueling. It landed safely at Edwards Air Force Base in California.

title: France Recommends Removal of Suspect Breast Implants
description: PARIS  French health authorities issued an extraordinary guideline on Friday urging 30,000 French women to have defective breast implants removed, deepening concerns in half a dozen countries and adding more unwelcome light to failings in French medical oversight.

title: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 23, 2011
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the review of the television show Homeland, Private Torment Trumps Terrorism.

title: Santa, Santa Everywhere
description: WHO is Bill Cunningham?

title: How Are You Spending the Holiday Break?
description: Traveling? Seeing family and friends? Reading? Cooking? Playing games? Seeing movies? Working? Studying? Thinking? Shopping? Catching up on sleep? Just relaxing? There are many ways to use the holiday break from school  how are you spending the time, and why?

title: Police Fire Tear Gas at Protesters in Chinese City
description: BEIJING  Police officers fired tear gas at hundreds of protesters in Haimen city in southeastern China on Friday as a huge protest against the expansion of a coal-fired power plant persisted for a fourth day.

title: Syria Blames Al Qaeda After Bombs Kill Dozens in Damascus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Two powerful car bombs exploded outside government security offices in Damascus on Friday in what appeared to be the most brazen and deadly attack against President Bashar al-Assads government since the start of the uprising in Syria in March.

title: Undecided, Without One College Choice Ranked Above All Others
description: Where to begin? Should I simply tell you my name? Or maybe where Im from? Perhaps I should just talk, and see where that takes us.

title: Berlin Imports Coffee, and Its Culture
description: The worlds second largest importer of coffee, Germany has embraced more than just beans. Coffee culture has slowly worked its way to the German capital, and the selection of specialty roasts offered in Berlin is more varied than ever, thanks to an influx of expat-run cafes. Following are three coffee entrepreneurs who give the traditional afternoon kaffeeandkuchennew verve.

title: The Early Word: Concession
description: Todays Times:

title: Corvette Chassis No. 5 Heads to Auction in Arizona
description: Crude might be a charitable word to characterize the early Chevrolet Corvette. The first few were actually hand-built in a garage in Flint, Mich., and the fit and finish of those early 1953 models, as one Chevrolet engineer remarked shortly after its construction, was not commercially acceptable. Yet the fiberglass-body cars were pushed onto dealers, who in some cases apologetically offered them at discounted prices.

title: Week 16 Matchups: Its a Wonderful Game
description: Giants (7-7) at Jets (8-6)Saturday, 1 p.m.Line: Jets by 3

title: A Budding Psychology Major Seeks to Help Veterans with Post-Traumatic Stress
description: My name is Clare Tiarsmith, and I am a high school senior from Atlanta. For the past several months, my life has been filled with college visits, college applications and college meetings; in other words, my life along with every other seniors has been filled with college, college, college.

title: The Wyden-Ryan Plan: Dj Vu All Over Again
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Hello World: The Inventor of C
description: Hello, world. Those were the words that appeared on the screen once you had programmed and run the iconic first example in the book The C Programming Language, which Dennis Ritchie, the creator of C, co-wrote with Brian Kernighan. In The Lives They Lived edition of the Times Sunday Magazine, the life of Mr. Ritchie is highlighted. Read the entire item in the Magazine.

title: Turkeys Leader Counters French Law With Accusations of Colonial-Era Genocide
description: ISTANBUL  In a deepening diplomatic rupture, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey accused France on Friday of genocide against Algerians in the period of French colonial rule, one day after France moved ahead with a measure that would make it a crime to deny the Armenian genocide by the Ottoman Turks.

title: On Our Radar: Nigerian Coast Braces for Oils Advance
description: Nigerian coastal communities are on alert as a 350-square-mile oil slick from a Royal Dutch Shell spill moves toward their shores. Officials report that it is the worst offshore spill there since 1998. [The Guardian]

title: For Cee Lo Green, a Busy Year
description: In 2011, the singer became one of the busiest stars in pop, logging thousands of miles while taping television shows and music videos, recording an album and making personal appearances.

title: Why Washington Irving High Must Close
Student Crossword | Hispanic Heritage
description: Play our crossword (PDF) to learn more about Hispanic people and culture in the United States. You can find the answers here.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: In Turkey, Western Companies Find Stability and Growth | Turkeys split personality has often left it caught between two worlds. Some European nations have vocally opposed the countrys attempts to build closer ties with the West. And many of its Middle Eastern neighbors have been wary of the avidly secular state.

title: Opinion Report: The Payroll Tax Cut Deal
description: From the editorial page

title: Indian Flavors: Daniel Bouluds Quail with Garam Masala
description: Daniel Boulud might be famous for his French cooking, but he seems equally taken by Indian flavors. The chef and owner of 13 restaurants including Daniel, his eponymous Michelin three-starred eatery, spent several hours before a recent interview with India Ink creating a green curry using the distinctly Indian black salt and pomegranate powder. His plan is to use the saucy base to enliven rabbit, which is a staple in his native France and can be bland on its own, he said. I am a huge fan of Indian food and incorporate spices from India into my cooking whenever I can, he said.

title: What Do Dragon Tattoo and Iron Lady Have in Common? Ask the Grousers
description: Its time for the holidays and, as ever, its time for eggnog recipes and disgruntlement over holiday movies.

title: Survival of the Wrongest
description: Jeff Madrick has a good post on the 10 worst economic ideas of 2011. What continues to fascinate me  in a bad way  is how economic debate continues to be dominated by ideas that (1) are in conflict with textbook macroeconomics and (2) have led to bad predictions every step of the way.

title: More PolitiFact
description: I was going to write something snarky about the attempt at self-justification, but on second thought Ill just lay it out straight.

title: Mourners in Prague Honor Havel
description: PRAGUE  Mourners filled the historic St. Vitus Cathedral here on Friday and gathered outside by the thousands on a frigid December morning for the funeral Mass of the playwright, dissident and former president Vaclav Havel, an emotional outpouring of affection that largely eluded him in his later life.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 23
description: News Corporation is in talks to hire a Washington lawyer, Gerson Zweifach, to be its next general counsel, as the company handles the legal fallout from the phone-hacking scandal in Britain, Bloomberg News reported Thursday night. He would replace Lawrence Jacobs, who resigned in June to pursue other opportunities.

title: Streep Dons Thatchers Armor
description: WHAT do you do after turning yourself into Julia Child, a bold, occasionally bossy woman who changed the way people think about food? You turn yourself into Margaret Thatcher, of course, an even bolder and bossier one, who changed the way people think about Britain. This is what Meryl Streep does in The Iron Lady, which opens Friday in New York. In yet another of her miraculous impersonations, which has already been nominated for a Golden Globe award, she seems even more Thatcher-like than Mrs. Thatcher, so that after the movie if you go back and look at photographs of Mrs. Thatcher in her prime, you cant help feeling that theyre a little off. She no longer looks like herself.

title: Daily Report: The Boycott Against SOPA Supporters
description: The biggest news Friday is the battle in the tech world between those who are proposing a boycott of everyone who supports the Stop Online Piracy Act and those who think that tactic is an affront to free speech. Congress would give companies some teeth to fight Web sites that publish pirated songs and movies. Opponents of the bill decry it as censorship. Edward Wyatt wrote about the bill in The New York Times several days ago.

title: Great Escape | Snowed In
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Challenging Hip-Hops Masculine Ideal
description: HIP-HOP is primarily a celebration of black masculinity. Sure, there have long been significant black female and white male figures, but the majority of the conversation in hip-hop is and has always been about the actions, thoughts, feelings and ethos of black men. But this hegemony cannot last forever. Eventually the throne will have to be shared. The world of hip-hop has some diversity: Eminem, Mac Miller and Nicki Minaj now; the Beastie Boys, Lauryn Hill and Missy Elliott in the past. We have respected rappers of South Asian descent: M.I.A. and Heems from Das Racist. But what about the American white woman? Could she ever rock the mic for real?

title: Back When Mother, Too, Knew Best
description: TO baby boomers of a certain age Donna Reed was a sunny-bright television fixture for eight seasons, the perfect mom  at least according to the prevailing values of the day  radiantly gliding down the staircase every week to answer the beckoning phone, its ringing augmented by an impossibly perky musical theme fittingly titled Happy Days.

title: A Sweet Voice Ventures Into Tough Terrain
description: Mariah McManus

title: Dec. 25  31
description: Theater

title: Groupons Real Deals Trump Zyngas Virtual Sheep
description: This holiday season, investors seem to prefer real deals to virtual sheep.

title: Friday Reading: Students Say No to Healthier School Fare
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Their Noonday Demons, and Ours
description: By some miracle, you set aside a day to tackle that project you cant seem to finish in the office. You close the door, boot up your laptop, open the right file and . . . five minutes later catch yourself thinking about dinner. By 10 a.m., youre staring at the wall, even squinting at it between your fingertips. Is this day 50 hours long? Soon, you fall into a light, unsatisfying sleep and awake dizzy or with a pounding headache; all your limbs feel weighed down. At which point, most likely around noon, you commit a fatal error: leaving the room. Ill just garden for a bit, you tell yourself, or do a little charity work. Hmmm, I wonder if my friend Gregory is around?

title: Roberto Bolao Plays With History
description: RobertoBolao is one of the most prolific of dead writers: some half a dozen books in Spanish and at least twice that in English since his death (at the age of 50) in 2003. Of course he didnt write these works in the afterlife, even if such a feat is no doubt every authors fantasy; the bulk of the posthumous material is drawn from the beginning and middle of his career, before the Spanish publication of The Savage Detectives in 1998 turned him into an international phenomenon. The amount of unpublished work tells a story. We read these previously missing early texts differently because we have the later ones. It is also possible that the early work will help us with the later work. (This is likely to be true of the still untranslated Sinsabores del Verdadero Polica, published in Spanish this year, which Bolao was working on from the 1980s to his death. Literally, a sinsabor is something that lacks savor, but idiomatically the word means a minor unpleasantness  a fluent literary version of the title might be The Troubles of the True Policeman.)

title: Finding My Religion
description: Books about God tend to fall into two categories: objective inquiries into the nature of belief and personal tales of spiritual awakening. One type explores history, creation myths and religious ritual. In the other, the author typically undergoes a crisis  a terminal illness, the death of a loved one, an onset of existential dread  that causes him to confront his lifes emptiness, coming to realize that there is something out there greater than himself.

title: Why We Lie
description: In 1995 I traveled to the University of California, Santa Barbara, for the annual meeting of the Human Behavior and Evolution Society, which turned out to be a pep rally for psychologists, anthropologists and others who view humanity through the lens of evolutionary theory. Attendees heard Darwinian takes on lust, love, infidelity, status-seeking, mental illness, violence, patriotism, politics, economics and religion, as well as keynote addresses from such luminaries as Richard Dawkins and Steven Pinker.

title: How Insomnia Feels
description: Its hard to ignore the force of the sentences in Blake Butlers new book, Nothing: a Portrait of Insomnia. Best known for his fiction, Butler is obsessed with the possibilities of syntax, and the most obvious feature of Nothing is a lyric and intellectual buffer overflow that results in long, often interestingly ungrammatical sentences, sometimes stretching over six pages. The most ornate of these is adorned with footnotes, a nod to David Foster Wallace, to whose memory the book is dedicated. As such the book draws attention to its own linguistic surfaces in ways that most memoirs never attempt.

title: The Caucus | Romney Campaign Ramps Up
description: Ashley Parker reports from New Hampshire on the week with Mitt Romney as the campaign shows its organizational might.

title: The Enlightenments True Radicals
description: In recent decades, Jonathan I. Israel writes, the Enlightenment has emerged as the single most important topic, internationally, in modern historical studies, and one of crucial significance also in our politics, cultural studies and philosophy. That is a large claim for a movement of 18th-century thought, and many will find it exaggerated, if not self-serving, seeing that its author, a professor of history at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., has devoted the last decade of his life to exploring that very subject.

title: Paul Nelson: Bad Boy Rock Critic
description: Paul Nelson, a propagandist committed to some dubious values, had a gift for imbuing disreputable, even dangerous ideas with discomforting grace. You might almost say he was the Leni Riefenstahl of rock criticism. One of the first writers of the post-Elvis era to take the popular music of his time seriously, he never liked black music and thought the blues were overrated, negligible in comparison with the work of overtly cerebral and conspicuously poetic artists of the 60s and early 70s like Bob Dylan and Jackson Browne. Nelson revered Browne. He subscribed, both in his writing and in his life, to the macho outcast myths of noir movies and pulp fiction, and he seemed blind to the importance of the great female artists nearly absent in his writing, like Joni Mitchell and Aretha Franklin. Nelson loathed the music of Patti Smith.

title: Five Seasons and a Movie: Fans Raise Money for German Office Film
description: While devotees of the struggling sitcom Community gather in Rockefeller Center and don fake beards in hopes of convincing NBC to keep that show on the air, fans of Germanys equivalent of The Office are actually reaching into their pockets to see the series continue: They have raised about $1.3 million in an online campaign to produce a movie based on the German show, which is currently in its fifth and final season, The Hollywood Reporter said.

title: Caucus Video: The Romney Campaign Ramps Up
description: Ashley Parker reports from Mitt Romneys New Hampshire bus tour about the campaign showing its organizational might.

title: Harry Kesslers Fin de Sicle Diaries
description: Count Harry Kessler (1868-1937), whose diaries provide an unusual guided tour of belle poque and early-20th-century artistic and high life in Berlin, Paris and London, was born in Paris to great wealth. A lifetime of extravagant spending and the Depression took their toll. After a long and painful disease, he died impoverished and solitary in Pontanevaux, a village in the Beaujolais region of France.

title: Q&A: Trouble-Shooting Browser Problems with PDF Files
description: Q.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: REIMAGINING EQUALITY  Stories of Gender, Race, and Finding Home.  By Anita Hill.  Beacon, $25.95.

title: Hard Rock in Las Vegas Plans a Three-Day New Years Celebration
description: Celebrating New Years Eve in Las Vegas isnt a novel concept, but the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Las Vegas is offering a fresh way to ring in 2012. The hotel has scheduled three days of events, beginning on Dec. 30, that emphasize its musical roots. The hip-hop star Drake, the alternative singer Corey Taylor, the heavy metal band Guns N Roses and a popular local band, Sin City Sinners, are all scheduled to perform.

title: The Most Dangerous Girl in Mexico Goes to America
description: Luis Alberto Urrea spent nearly 20 years researching his family history for his enchanting 2005 novel The Hummingbirds Daughter. Out of old letters, historical documents and oral histories emerged the fantastical story of the authors great-aunt Teresa, a Mexican saint and revolutionary who was the illegitimate daughter of Toms Urrea, a wealthy landowner, and a Yaqui Indian woman known simply as Cayetana, or the Hummingbird. By the final wrenching pages of that novel, Teresita, as shes called, has by presidential decree been declared the Most Dangerous Girl in Mexico. Banished from the country, she and her father are put on a train headed north to the United States.

title: Paying for the Payroll Tax Cut
description: So House Republicans have decided to go along with a two-month extension of the payroll tax cut.

title: Last Exits in Brooklyn
description: Nobody knows a man better than his ex-wife. So Moe Pragers ex-wife, Carmella, is wise to this veteran private eye, accepting the fact that no matter how many times he marries, his first love will always be Brooklyn. When you die, they should just bury you right here, under the boardwalk, she tells him in HURT MACHINE (Tyrus, $24.95; paper, $15.95), Reed Farrel Colemans latest book in a series heavily saturated with local color. Since Prager has recently been told he has stomach cancer, that day may come sooner than Carmella thinks. But this stubborn old shamus is determined to do two things before his ashes are consigned to the sands of Coney Island: Attend his daughters wedding, and find the person who murdered Carmellas older sister, Alta.

title: The Doors
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Choice

title: Inside the List
description: THE USUAL SUSPECTS: Tom Clancys fans like to describe his macho geek-boy thrillers as prescient, citing among other things his 1994 novel Debt of Honor, in which a deranged pilot crashes a 747 into the Capitol. On Sept. 11, 2001, Clancy himself played up the overlap on CNN, without mentioning that the book is a ludicrous alarmist fantasy about a corporate-controlled Japan making war on America. In other words, it was less prescient than derivative: Rising Sun, Michael Crichtons version of The Japanese are coming! had been a best seller two years before. In a telephone interview on Charlie Rose later on 9/11, Clancy again seemed out of the loop. As Roses panelists talked about Osama bin Laden and the possibility of military retaliation, Clancy jumped in petulantly. Saying Osama bin Laden,  he insisted, is like Claude Rains in Casablanca saying, Round up the usual suspects. Hes simply the usual suspect. But there has been no definitive information linking him to this event. Until there is, talking about him is just a waste of air. Later on the program, as the former National Security Adviser Samuel Berger tried to answer a question, Clancys disembodied voice floated over the set. Why is there a car in our driveway? he asked, apparently forgetting he was wired for sound.

title: Up Front
description: Michael Woods first three books about literature concerned a Frenchman (Stendhal), a Latin American (Garca Mrquez) and a Russian emigrant to America (Nabokov). If this sounds like the start of a bar joke, it also confirms Woods commitment to cultural diversity  as does the fact that between Stendhal and Garca Mrquez, he also found time for a book about film, America in the Movies. In a recent e-mail, Wood recalled that when Wilfrid Sheed reviewed that book in 1976, he said I had a grasshopper mind. It wasnt a compliment but its not untrue, and one can make some sort of virtue even out of bad habits.

title: MF Global Trustee Seeks Money From British Arm
description: The trustee liquidating MF Globals trading operations said on Friday that his office was seeking the return of more than $600 million from the failed firms British arm, potentially setting up a cross-border fight over customer money.

title: Paperback Row
description: GATHERING EVIDENCE: A Memoir, by Thomas Bernhard. Translated by David McLintock (Vintage International, $16.95.) Bernhard, the Austrian playwright and novelist who died in 1989, describes his harrowing childhood in Nazi-dominated schools and the bouts of pneumonia and tuberculosis that shaped his lifelong obsession with death. This volume includes My Prizes, translated by Carol Brown Janeway, a series of acerbic essays that recall Bernhards literary awards and muster moral outrage against the idea of state-sanctioned art.

title: A Recap From the Third (and Final) Night of the Choice Blogs Live Chat on Facebook

title: Farewell, Pumpkins of Kane Street? They Did Not.
description: We bid adieu to the pumpkins of Kane Street, an array of  100 carved by Jane Greengold of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn that have become a local Halloween tradition. The horrific decay of the pumpkins has reached a tipping point on the scales of good taste so rigorously upheld by City Room. This will be our final installment of the series.

As he told investors in 2008, We feel very fortunate to have dodged a significant number of bullets, landmines and other incendiary devices during this dramatic year.

title: For the Colts (and Maybe Andrew Luck), a Rewrite
description: Just when you thought you had the script for this N.F.L. season all figured out, things started going awry. The first taste of this was when the Packers, on a mesmerizing march to a perfect season, tripped over the dreadful Chiefs. And now, at the bottom of the standings, the actors are no longer dutifully playing their parts. Somewhere late in the fourth quarter of Thursday nights game against the Texans, the Colts went full ad-lib on us with a game-winning touchdown drive in the final minute, led by quarterback Dan Orlovsky, who almost no one realized was even a member of the Colts cast.

title: Two Gifts
description: Gift-giving can be tricky for older people and their caregivers. The seniors often dont need more Stuff  they have enough pajamas, dusting powder and flannel shirts to last a literal lifetime. When my dad left his apartment to move to an independent living facility near my sister and me, we found shirts and sweaters wed given him for birthdays and Hanukkah years before, still in gift boxes. Oh well.

description: Of all the sticky quandaries in the parenting world, divorce, especially when it comes with questions of custody, must be the stickiest, and it only gets stickier when a new spouse enters the picture. This weeks quandary comes from one such new spouse and stepparent. Four years (and two children) after her marriage, shes not sure if she and her husband have done the right thing by letting her stepchildren spend every holiday with their mother.

Its packed with more than 200 magazine covers (including some of ours) and commentary from some of the worlds leading art directors and designers. Its a great tool for magazine junkies, students and readers alike. You can order it here.

Lascivious customers leer, toss money and revel in their own unbridled lust. It is a scene that could have been in any of the hood movies that once proliferated or even a Tyler Perry melodrama in which Christian values would be affirmed after this bit of titillation.

title: Weekend Fare

A nosh party will follow, $28 per person, from 7 to 9 p.m., with snacks like Sichuan peppercorn latkes and ginger Sriracha wok-fried bagel strips. Tickets will be on sale until midnight Friday.

title: Business Is in the Bag
description: Carolina Herrera Baez, not to be confused with her mother, the designer Carolina Herrera, has been a quiet influence in her familys atelier for most of her life. But it isnt until now that she could call herself a designer. Two years into her post as a consultant for her mothers CH Carolina Herrera collection, Herrera Baez is introducing her own accessory: the Mini Matryoshka bag  a bucket tote made of Goya leather that comes in seven different Bauhaus-inspired colorblocks, like canary yellow and grass green, or Piet Mondrian-esque red and black. Though theres much in the capsule that can be credited to her mother  She has a small purse philosophy, says Herrera Baez by way of explaining why, for example, the bag is the compact size that it is. You carry only what is essential  the bags graphic look and feel are entirely original. Sometimes, great ideas on paper are just that, says Herrera Baez. The ability to fine tune an aesthetic in tandem with intuition is a good trait for any designer to have. Tuck that one in your tote.

title: Crossing the Delaware, More Accurately
description: There are few images as enduring in American history as the one of General George Washington standing tall, next to the Stars and Stripes, in a rowboat gliding past mini-icebergs as he leads his troops across the Delaware River on Christmas Day 1776 to start a surprise attack on Hessian forces during the Battle of Trenton.

title: Best Apps for Children  End of Year Edition
description: Giving your child an iPad or iPod Touch as a gift this year? Preload it with some quality apps before you wrap it. That way youll increase your chances for a positive first impression. Heres a fresh batch of suggestions, arranged from young to old.

title: In a Hymn, Words of Courage That Ring True Long After a Soldier Son Returns
description: The Christmas cards Im sending this year feature a photograph of two Border collies and several ducks in a snowbank. The dogs and the ducks appear perfectly at ease and content in each others company, and a caption above the picture reads, And on Earth, Peace. I love the picture and the reference to Luke 2:14. But, it has occurred to me that the picture might not actually be compatible with its quoted Scripture. Border collies are not, after all, lions who lie down with lambs. Rather, Border collies are defenders of lambs against lions.

title: Your Best Meal of 2011
description: As we put together our lists of our favorite restaurants of 2011, were curious about the best meal you had this year. It could be something as humble as a taco at a truck in Los Angeles, or as grand as a visit to Per Se, or, of course, it can be something you cooked yourself great meals come in many forms. Tweet us at @nytimesdining using the hashtag #bestmeal2011. Well cull some of the highlights and feature them here next week.

title: Lessons Learned in Congress, or a Sign of Things to Come?

Boehner is this: how to answer the hue and cry of the far-right corner of his conference  especially the most conservative of the 87 freshmen who often seem willing to walk to the point of legislative disaster over a point of principle  and actually get things done.

title: Another Collapse at Pompeii Renews Fears About Its Fate
description: Mount Vesuvius preserved the city of Pompeii in ash nearly 2,000 years ago, but current neglect of this Unesco World Heritage site in southern Italy is taking its toll. A courtyard column of a Roman house collapsed on Thursday, the latest in a series of crumbling artifacts at the site, Reuters reported. Last year there were other collapses, including part of what is known as the House of Gladiators. The damage played a role in a no-confidence vote against Culture Minister Sandro Bondi earlier this year. Although Mr. Bondi survived the vote, he ended up resigning in March.
