description: A series of Christmas Day church bombings rocked Nigeria on Sunday in what appeared to be a coordinated assault by a radical Islamist sect with suspected training links to Al Qaeda, raising the sects violent antigovernment struggle to a new and more dangerous level that the Nigerian authorities seem powerless to contain. At least 25 people were killed.

title: Japanese Leader to Focus on N. Korea During Visit to China
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda of Japan arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a two-day state visit that was originally aimed at improving bilateral ties, but is now expected to focus on the uncertainty over North Koreas intentions after the death of Kim Jong-il.

title: Sudans Government Says Powerful Rebel Leader Is Dead
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Khalil Ibrahim, a powerful Sudanese rebel leader who once mounted a daring and near-successful raid that took his fighters from the sun-blasted deserts of Darfur to the doorstep of the capital, Khartoum, died on Saturday from wounds he received in battle, the Sudanese government said.

title: Lax Security Exposes Voice Mail to Hacking, Study Says
description: BERLIN  It may be tempting to view the illegal interception of telephone voice mails, a practice that has roiled Britain and the News Corp. media empire of Rupert Murdoch, as an arcane tool employed by scofflaw journalists with friends in Scotland Yard.

title: Retreat of Glaciers Makes Some Climbs Tougher
description: Three decades ago, when Mick Fowler climbed the north face of the Eiger in the Swiss Alps, he used crampons and ice axes to haul himself up sheer walls of snow and ice.

title: The Book Beyond the Book
description: That sound you hear is the wrapping being torn off of millions of Kindles and iPads. When those devices are fired up and start downloading texts, it will be the greatest shift in casual reading since the mass market paperback arrived six decades ago. Will this dislocation destroy the traditional book? Will it doom the traditional independent bookstore? Will Amazon and Apple control the distribution of thought and culture in America? All these questions will be played out imminently.

title: Womans Daughters and Parents Killed in Connecticut Fire
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  The three children and the parents of a well-known advertising executive were killed when a predawn fire tore through the familys Victorian house in a neighborhood overlooking Long Island Sound.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: Photographs from Iowa, New Hampshire and Virginia. More Photos

title: Critics Picks: The Thin Red Line
description: A. O. Scott looks at the relationship between humans and the natural world in Terrence Malicks war drama.

title: Bombings in Nigeria
description: Boko Haram, a radical Muslim sect waging an increasingly sophisticated sectarian fight, claimed a series of attacks.

title: Classic Newsstand Gets Ready to Roll
description: Few newsstands merit a cameo role in a major motion picture, but the octagonal structure with a gracefully tapering roof at Columbus Circle is such an echt newsstand that Woody Allen cast it in Bullets Over Broadway.

title: Reads and Reactions
The Year in Arts Portraits
description: Artists, actors, filmmakers and musicians by photographers from The New York Times.

title: For Joplin, a Love Letter in Ruins
description: JOPLIN, Mo.  As this rebuilding city races to finish clearing the rubble from the deadly tornado last spring, one irreparably broken structure has been allowed, for now at least, to remain.

title: A Memorial Still Stands, but Barely
description: Since the tornado that cut through Joplin in May, several monuments have emerged. But as rebuilding continues, the community is wondering what to do with one that is, itself, rubble.

title: Disruptions: Norelco on Takeoff? Fine. Kindle? No.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has its reasons for preventing passengers from reading from their Kindles and iPads during takeoff and landing. But they just dont add up.

title: For One Day, the First, the Knicks Have Just Enough
description: There was joy again at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, a blend of holiday cheer, pent-up expectation and the thrill of the N.B.A.s belated return after a long, strange off-season. The joy gave way to anxiety, then a bit of nastiness.

title: The Netherlands: Court Releases Rwandan Rebel Leader
description: A Rwandan rebel leader was released Friday by the International Criminal Court in the Hague after almost a year in detention and returned to his home base in Paris, the court said. Callixte Mbarushimana, a former United Nations computer technician, had faced charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity but pre-trial judges threw out his case last week in a 2-1 decision, saying that the evidence against him was not sufficient to warrant a trial. Prosecutors appealed in vain this week to stop his release, saying he was the main political leader of the violent Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda. The rebel movement, which operates from a base in the Democratic Republic of Congo, has unleashed a terrorist campaign in the region which thousands of civilians have been raped and killed. He was the first person to be released by the international court.

title: $42 Million Payday For Simon Cowell
description: The X Factor may have had relatively disappointing ratings in its first season, but the show generated a big payday for Simon Cowell, its creator, below. According to corporate filings in Britain Mr. Cowell made about $42 million through a deal with Sony last year that established a joint-venture company for his entertainment businesses, including The X Factor, The Guardian of London reported. For its 50-percent share in the company Sony paid about $49 million and turned over its ownership stakes in two of Mr. Cowells other entertainment properties. Mr. Cowell received $42 million of that money by handing over the shares of another company under his control. On Thursday, when Melanie Amaro, a 19-year-old from Florida, was crowned the first winner of The X Factor, 12.4 million viewers tuned in. That fell short of the 20 million that Mr. Cowell once predicted for the show.

title: Demi Lovato Blasts Disney Over Jokes
description: The actress and singer Demi Lovato, who sought help last year for an eating disorder, criticized the Disney Channel, her former employer, on Friday over televised jokes about that condition. Eating disorders are not something to joke about, she wrote on Twitter in all-capital letters after hearing a character on the show Shake It Up say, I could just eat you up, well, if I ate. Ms. Lovato, right, was the star of the Disney Channels Sonny With a Chance until the spring, when she told People magazine that being in front of a camera would make me nervous. She is now concentrating on a music career. One of her fans told her about a similar comment made on So Random, which succeeded Sonny With a Chance, and Ms. Lovato shared it with 5.3 million followers. A Twitter account operated by Disney Channel replied to Ms. Lovato two hours later, We hear you and are pulling both episodes as quickly as possible and re-evaluating them. The channels account added, Its NEVER our intention to make light of eating disorders!

title: Tempting Targets for Ita in 2012
description: Ita Unibanco in Brazil bills itself as the Global Latin American Bank. Thing is, its not. Or at least, its not yet. That may change in the coming year. Itas solid finances, robust market valuation, searing ambitions and a wealth of opportunities from the misfortunes of global rivals make it the bank to watch in 2012.

title: Crystal Bridges
description: Images from the museum in Arkansas.

title: The Muses of Insert, Delete and Execute
description: The literary history of the typewriter has its well-established milestones, from Mark Twain producing the first typewritten manuscript with Life on the Mississippi to Truman Capote famously dismissing Jack Kerouacs On the Road, pounded out on a 120-foot scroll, with the quip Thats not writing, thats typing.

title: Young Artists, Playing With the Stars
description: Unlike students in most other fields, fledgling musicians never really take vacations from their training. They cant. If they stop practicing for a few weeks simply because school is out, they will only need to work harder to get back in trim. Besides, setting aside their instruments is not, typically, what they want to do. Every winter about 60 musicians between 15 and 22 years old put their winter vacations to good use by coming to Manhattan for the New York String Orchestra Seminar, a 10-day program in which they are coached by a starry roster of soloists and chamber players.

title: Fans Notes, Rapturous and Otherwise
description: Sports are like life, simplified. The rules are enforced instantly and on the spot. Winners are clearly declared. In the stadium theres delightful relief from the real-world trial of sifting enemies from allies: if theyre wearing your teams uniforms, theyre good guys.

title: Under the Bouffant, a Sewer Mouth on Go-Go Wings
description: A once proud and subversive warrior tribe that deified freakdom, drag queens have become awfully mainstream. Tame transvestites are now passing for Kardashians, while biological women all over television are communing with their inner drag divas on shows like Mad Fashion, RuPauls Drag U and The Real Housewives of You Name It.

title: The Less Obvious Defense Brought Victory in Bulgaria
description: The International Bridge Press Association gives annual awards for excellence both at the table and away from it. The winners receive a lot of publicity, but some of the deals that did not gather sufficient votes are worthy of print inches.

title: Christmas Dinner in Baghdad
description: Members of The Timess Baghdad Bureau  Tim Arango, Jack Healy and Michael Schmidt  made Christmas dinner for a group of fellow journalists, tweeting along the way. Heres the holiday as tweeted; scroll down to the bottom of the post to read them from this morning onward.

title: A Dispute Over Who Owns a Twitter Account Goes to Court
description: How much is a tweet worth? And how much does a Twitter follower cost?

title: Holiday Monday (Christmas Observed)
description: NEW YORK

title: Hunting Deer With My Flintlock
description: Bushkill, Pa.

title: The Future of Moral Machines
Conditions in Hungary
description: To the Editor:

title: A Year in the Air
description: The Bolshoi Theater reopened in 2011 after a six-year, $760 million, scandal-plagued renovation. Images from the year in culture.

title: Iron Hand Hurts Police, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Knee Injury Shelves Rookie for 2-4 Weeks
description: Iman Shumpert gave the Knicks a charge Sunday afternoon, and their first setback of the season  a right knee injury that will leave him on the sideline for up to a month.

title: A Tax to Narrow the Rich-Poor Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoke-Free Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Egyptian Blogger Released From Jail
description: Updated | 6:28 p.m. A prominent Egyptian activist and blogger, Alaa Abd El Fattah, was released from detention in Cairo on Sunday and went directly to Tahrir Square to join a protest against the countrys military rulers.

title: Portraits of the Artists
description: What happens when a photographer encounters a subject who makes his or her living in front of the camera? Is the result truth or illusion?

title: Dallas Celebrates Past; Miami Enjoys Present
description: DALLAS  Emotion etched on his face, Dirk Nowitzki appeared alone in his thoughts as he soaked in the moment. Delayed by the N.B.A. lockout, the Dallas Mavericks were unable to commemorate the franchises first title until Sunday, when they again held aloft the Larry OBrien Trophy and raised their championship banner.

title: Monday: Train That Doesnt Skip a Stop
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  O.K., now that weve all finished our holiday meals and gingerbread cookies, its time to start burning some serious puzzle calories. I see you all out there, lazing on the couch. Sharpen those pencils! Take a lap! Get those knees up!

title: A Year of Disappointment at the Movie Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  With five days left in 2011, ticket sales in North America are running about $500 million behind last year  despite higher prices  prompting a round of soul searching by studios trying to determine what went wrong and how best to proceed.

title: In Englands Post-Christmas Spotlight
description: While the rest of Europes big leagues are resting, teams play in Britain to bumper crowds this week because tradition, and demands of TV.

title: On Internet TV, Silicon Valley Displays Its Whimsical Side
description: LOS ANGELES  There she was, one of the business worlds most important and serious executives, being interviewed about  leg warmers?

title: The Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the S.& P./Case-Shiller home price index for October and consumer confidence for December (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims, the Chicago purchasing managers index for December, and pending home sales for November (Thursday).

title: No Auctions Set for This Week
description: In observance of the Christmas holiday, both the stock and bond markets will be closed on Monday. The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: A Village in Revolt Could Be a Harbinger for China
description: BEIJING  Chinas state-run media have had a field day this autumn with Occupy Wall Street, spinning an almost daily morality play about capitalism gone amok and an American government unable or unwilling to aid the victims of a rapacious elite.

title: Appearing Frail, Pope Offers Prayers for Peace on Christmas
description: ROME  Offering his annual Christmas Day message on the state of the world, Pope Benedict XVI on Sunday prayed for peace in the Middle East and Horn of Africa and offered prayers for flood victims in Southeast Asia.

title: Afghanistan Low on News Agenda
description: The 10-year-old war in Afghanistan remained just a blip on the American news medias radar in 2011.

title: Knicks Photo Replay: Dec. 25
description: Carmelo Anthony scored 37 points, including two free throws with 16 seconds left, as the Knicks survived a seesaw season opener against the Celtics.

title: In North Korean Mourning, Succession Clues
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea broadcast television footage on Sunday of the top military brass flanking the countrys young new leader, Kim Jong-un, as they paid respects to Mr. Kims father, who died of a heart attack on Dec. 17, and vowed allegiance to his chosen successor.

title: The Art of the Possible: Christmas Dinner in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Nobody can guarantee you a peaceful Christmas dinner in Iraq. Things explode. Riots break out. Angry politicians quit the government. As a reporter roosting in Baghdad over the holidays, all you can do is plan a menu, start cooking early and be ready to abandon your turkey if mayhem erupts.

title: Monday Night Matchup: Falcons at Saints
description: Falcons (9-5) at Saints (11-3), 8:20 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

title: A Welcome Change: Her Only Worry Is Her Dog
description: Marisol Santiago was worried about the hard, teardrop-shaped spot under her dogs eye. The dog, Princess, is a schnauzer, and tends to get infections. Ms. Santiago, 42, cleans the spot each day with hot water and disinfectant, but cannot afford to take Princess to the veterinarian.

title: In Becks Shadow, Rise of The Five
description: When Fox News and Glenn Beck broke up in June, the networks chairman, Roger Ailes, knew he could not put any single man or woman in that 5 p.m. time slot, lest he or she be compared to Mr. Beck or be pummeled in the press if the ratings tumbled.

title: In N.B.A., Games Begin, but Time Will Determine Who Won
description: The reality of the new N.B.A. season is a testament to a simple but profound truth learned the hard way by 435 players during a contentious lockout: progress depends on risk and sacrifice.

title: Californian With an M.B.A. Follows His Heart to Brazilian Funk
description: NOVA IGUAU, Brazil  The train to this city on Rio de Janeiros edge carries passengers from the urban underclass chasing dreams big and small: teenagers trying out for a soccer club, a maid studying to be a nurse, a knife salesman plying his trade in the aisles.

title: Rio Funk, American Style
description: Los Angeles native Alex Cutler left behind a life of American affluence to follow his dream in the funk music scene of Rios gritty slums.

title: Robert Morvillo, Legal Pioneer, Dies at 73
description: Robert G. Morvillo, a prominent New York trial lawyer who pioneered the practice of white-collar criminal defense and whose client list included colorful celebrities, powerful politicians and billionaire businessmen, died on Saturday at his home in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 73.

title: Seeing City in Need, Southern Baptists Plan Growth
description: As a Southern Baptist, Freddy T. Wyatt knows he is a minority in New York. But, he said, that was exactly what prompted him to move to the city from Clarksville, Tenn.

title: U.S. Firms See Opportunities in Europes Woes
description: As Europe struggles with its debt crisis, American businesses and financial firms are swooping in amid the distress, making loans and snapping up assets owned by banks there  from the mortgage on a luxury hotel in Miami Beach to the tallest office building in Dublin.

title: Robert Ader, Who Linked Stress and Illness, Dies at 79
description: Dr. Robert Ader, an experimental psychologist who was among the first scientists to show how mental processes influence the bodys immune system, a finding that changed modern medicine, died on Tuesday in Pittsford, N.Y. He was 79.

title: With Christmas Morning, the Rare Serenity of Long Ago
description: At 8 in the morning, a scrap of paper blew across an apocalyptic Times Square, and Costantino Gava, a tourist from Italy, stood amid an archipelago of abandoned red cafe tables. He looked about at the vast circus of neon lights winking allure at no one, and snapped another picture of the desolation.

title: Falcons Have Had a Winning Strategy for Fitness
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  When Coy Wire signed with the Atlanta Falcons in 2008, he considered himself in the vanguard regarding fitness techniques.

title: Christmas Morning
description: The stillness of the city on Christmas morning

title: Cee Lo Strikes Gold, Without a Gold Album
description: Ducking through a crowd of tourists at Rockefeller Center, the singer Cee Lo Green took a breather during rehearsals for NBCs annual tree-lighting concert on Nov. 30. But between a shopping detour at Swarovski Crystal and last-minute talks with the shows producer, there wasnt much time to rest.

title: The Anti-Entitlement Strategy
description: Mitt Romney wants to stigmatize most safety net spending  the array of social insurance programs from Medicare to food stamps to unemployment compensation to free school lunches  as a form of welfare that is cultivating government dependence.

title: Collapse by Lakers Gives Win to Bulls
description: LOS ANGELES  Longtime stars of N.B.A. Christmas programming, the Los Angeles Lakers left hearth and home for the 14th season in a row, sent into a colder world that no longer sees them as sprinkled with stardust.

title: A Living Wage, Long Overdue
description: New York City provides hundreds of millions of dollars a year in taxpayer-financed subsidies to private developers. It is only right that the jobs created by those projects pay a decent wage. The Fair Wages for New Yorkers Act, widely known as the living-wage bill, would nudge these employers in the right direction.

title: A Showcase for Stars and Big-Market Rivalries
description: Happy New Year, Knicks fans, even if it still is 2011. Your teams resolution to be resourceful, tough and smart when it matters most was unwrapped in the final minutes of what felt like Game 5 against the Celtics on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Expanding Internet Domains
description: Come January, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers plans to allow businesses, nonprofits and others to apply for their own top-level domain with their own online suffix, like the familiar .com and .org suffixes that now rule the Internet.

title: Manning Loses His Hot Hand, and Doesnt Have Much Time to Find It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Of all the questions lingering over the Giants as they prepare for a winner-take-all game against the Dallas Cowboys  including will Coach Tom Coughlin need crutches on the sideline?  the most critical one is obvious: which Eli Manning will show up Sunday night?

title: Fairness for Home Care Aides
description: Evelyn Coke spent 20 years as a home care aide helping the elderly and the sick, but she did not live to see fair labor laws applied to her work.

title: U.S. Prepares for a Curtailed Relationship With Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  With the United States facing the reality that its broad security partnership with Pakistan is over, American officials are seeking to salvage a more limited counterterrorism alliance that they acknowledge will complicate their ability to launch attacks against extremists and move supplies into Afghanistan.

title: Love on the Spectrum
description: Jack Robison and Kirsten Lindsmith, two college students living in Greenfield, Mass., discuss how autism affects their lives and relationship.

title: Buckle Up on Buses
description: The curbside bus industry has become a booming inter-city phenomenon offering cheap fares in hard times  but also a crash fatality rate seven times that of mainline carriers based in terminals, where maintenance and safety checks are more common.

title: Putins Children
description: IN the waning days of the Soviet Union, I spent a lot of time in a cluster of apartment towers along the Moscow River, contemplating what seemed to me an essential question about the future of our cold-war adversary: Could Russia grow an authentic middle class? Not a privileged class, favored wards of the state, but independent achievers who would be the engine and the evidence of upward mobility.

title: Springtime for Toxics
description: Heres what I wanted for Christmas: something that would make us both healthier and richer. And since I was just making a wish, why not ask that Americans get smarter, too?

title: For Jets, Faint Hope and Ebbing Glory
description: Toward the end of his first year with the Jets, Rex Ryan offered what by now has become a familiar refrain  a bold, but incorrect, prediction. He proclaimed their season over after a crushing loss to Atlanta, but fortune smiled on the Jets, who benefited from an improbable confluence of events to make the playoffs.

title: Hackers Breach the Web Site of Stratfor Global Intelligence
description: While the rest of the world engaged in merriment and good cheer, hackers used the holidays to attack a United States research group that puts out a daily newsletter on security issues.

title: For Start-Ups That Aim at Giants, Sorting the Data Cloud Is the Next Big Thing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The idea of big data goes something like this: In a world of ever-increasing digital connectivity, ever larger mountains of data are produced by our cellphones, computers, digital cameras, RFID readers, smart meters and GPS devices. The huge quantity of data becomes unwieldy and difficult for companies and governments to manage and understand.

title: Baby Formula Is Called Safe
description: Mead Johnson Nutrition said on Sunday that tests it conducted on samples of its Enfamil baby formula tied to a Food and Drug Administration investigation found no presence of bacteria. The company called the product safe.

title: Salt Lake's Superheroes
description: A band of self-proclaimed superheroes takes to Salt Lake City streets at night looking to fight crime, except, of course, when its too cold.

title: Expansion Plans Divide School and Son of Its Former Headmaster
description: Each weekday morning, the headmaster of St. Davids School stands at the front door of the all-boys school on East 89th Street, heartily welcoming his students with a smile and firm handshake.

title: Crusaders Take Page, and Outfits, From Comics
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Red Voltage and two of his masked crime-fighting colleagues were approaching an intersection here in Utahs capital on a recent evening, walking night patrol on foot, when a car suddenly slowed next to them. The night was bitterly cold, laced with a wispy stew of fog that might or might not conceal a thousand dangers. The cars window rolled down.

title: Alliance Formed Secretly to Win Deal for Campus
description: The first secret meeting took place last March, in a place no one would suspect: Beijing. For the second, in July, they holed up in the Cornell Club of New York, rather than a hotel where they might be noticed by outsiders.

title: Joseph Farrell, Who Used Market Research to Shape Films, Dies at 76
description: In the 1987 film Fatal Attraction, a psychopathic woman terrorizes a married man with whom she has had a one-night stand, making more and more threatening gestures toward him and his family until her violent demise becomes inevitable.

title: 2011: The Year in Sports
description: Times editors and reporters share memories from the sporting year.

title: Lottery Numbers
Memories From the Year in Sports
description: Reporters and editors for The Times recalled the people, teams and moments that made the past year memorable. Readers can share their favorite moments of the year below.

title: Near Dallas, 7 Found Shot to Death Amid Their Unwrapped Gifts
description: Police officers responding to a silent call from someone who dialed 911 in a Dallas suburb on Sunday morning found seven people dead in an apartment, all shot shortly after opening their Christmas presents. The gunman, who was wearing a Santa suit, was among the dead, the police said, and the seven appeared to be related.

title: N.B.A. Photo Replay: Dec. 25
description: A look at season-opening games played in Dallas, Los Angeles and Oklahoma City.

title: Hamas Leader Leaves on Tour of Arab Nations to Seek Support
description: JERUSALEM  Ismail Haniya, the Hamas prime minister of Gaza, left the isolated Palestinian enclave on Sunday to seek regional support for his Islamic movement in his first foreign trip since uprisings spread across the Arab world a year ago.

title: Corrections: December 26
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Watchdog for Conservative Ideals
description: PHOENIX  Clint Bolick looks like any other high-powered lawyer, for the most part. But glance down at his index finger, which sports a scorpion tattoo, for first-hand evidence of his unconventional streak.

title: Slimming Down
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paul Disowns Extremists Views but Doesnt Disavow the Support
description: The American Free Press, which markets books like The Invention of the Jewish People and March of the Titans: A History of the White Race, is urging its subscribers to help it send hundreds of copies of Ron Pauls collected speeches to voters in New Hampshire. The book, it promises, will Help Dr. Ron Paul Win the G.O.P. Nomination in 2012!

title: NYT Front Page for 12/26/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/26/2011

title: E-Reader Help From New York Public Library
description: Anticipating a flood of library patrons who received e-readers as holiday gifts, the New York Public Library will offer a free service for instructing users how to download e-books, library officials said. Free e-books are available for members of the New York Public Library and can be downloaded remotely without a visit to the library. Patrons can visit nypl.org/ebookcentral for instructions on downloading e-books and other digital materials, including video and music. The library will also offer in-person assistance from Jan. 4 to Jan. 13 at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building and the Mid-Manhattan Library at 455 Fifth Avenue. Nearly 22,000 e-books are available at the New York Public Library, a number that has been growing rapidly along with the widespread adoption of e-readers.

title: Navigating Love and Autism
description: GREENFIELD, Mass.  The first night they slept entwined on his futon, Jack Robison, 19, who had since childhood thought of himself as not like the other humans, regarded Kirsten Lindsmith with undisguised tenderness.

title: Twofold Goal in Iowa for G.O.P. Hopefuls
description: The political universe in the coming week begins and ends with the borders of Iowa, where the six contenders for the Republican nomination will race toward the Jan. 3 caucuses. Their dual mission: persuasion and organization to lay the groundwork for a strong showing.

title: Modernizing Attack Ads by Using Old Videos
description: It seemed innocuous enough at the time. The Democratic speaker of the House and one of her Republican predecessors cozy up on a love seat arranged for them at the bottom of Capitol Hill. They look into the camera, then at each other, and declare that they are really not all that different when it comes to caring about global warming.

title: From Russia With Lightness
description: MOSCOW  Every night last week, writers, artists, actors, ad men, office managers and assorted others climbed the stairs to the fifth floor of a converted factory building in Moscow to make a statement. Pavel Bardin, a well-known young film director, had set up a camera in a conference room there. Everyone who came in  some by invitation, some having found out about the filming from friends or Facebook  wrote his or her name and vocation on a length of masking tape, and named his or her reason for planning to attend what would be a giant protest on Saturday, the 24th.

title: Pain and Glory From Down Under
description: For an Indian fan, test cricket in Australia is about waking up at 5 a.m. in order to watch the first session of play with the television on mute so as to not wake the rest of the family. It is about watching the Boxing Day test match in Melbourne and soaking in the tradition even if it is from thousands of miles away. It is about wondering how something as ubiquitous as the wind can be called the fremantle doctor during test matches in Perth.

title: In Shillong, Carols and Dohneiiong for Christmas
description: Christmas comes early in the northeastern city of Shillong, where traditional local food mixes with Christian carols and fruitcake for a unique holiday celebration.

title: Complete N.F.L. Playoff Possibilities
description: Green Bay clinched home-field advantage throughout the N.F.C. playoffs with a victory over Chicago on Sunday night. The defeat knocked the Bears out of the playoffs and handed a playoff spot to Atlanta. Here are the up-to-date playoff possibilities after the game, via The Associated Press:

title: U.S.: Roster Rumblings and Ramblings
description: Now that Jurgen Klinsmann has named his roster for the United States soccer teams January training camp and for its two friendly matches against Venezuela and Panama, its time to roll up our sleeves, stare at the list and start reading between the lines.

title: In London, a Taryn Simon Show Nears Its End
description: For four years, Taryn Simon traveled the world photographing 18 family bloodlines and their related stories. The resulting images document victims of genocide in Bosnia, a polygamist family in Kenya, the alleged body double of Saddam Husseins son, Uday, Filipino farmers and miners, children with no known bloodline from a Ukrainian orphanage, and many more.

title: Utopian Capitalism
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Q&A: Finding a Port With Power
description: Q.

title: Five Killed in Latest Baghdad Bombing
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber driving a car packed with explosives attacked a checkpoint in front of the Iraqi Interior Ministry on Monday morning, killing 5, wounding 39 and roiling a country unsettled by a political crisis and a wave of deadly bombings just days ago.

title: New North Korean Leader Meets South Koreans and Assumes Leadership of Party
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Jong-un, the new leader of North Korea, met Monday with a private delegation of prominent South Koreans, his first face-to-face encounter with any visitors from the estranged South since assuming the top spot a week ago when his fathers death was announced.

title: Sony to Cease Its Flat-Screen Partnership With Samsung
description: TOKYO  In a bid to streamline its unprofitable television business, Sony said Monday that it would sell its stake in its flat-panel screen venture with Samsung Electronics, cutting its production capacity at a time when outsourcing has become the norm for manufacturers.

title: Ex-Players Sue Over Concussions; Current Players Hide Them
description: In a series of interviews about head injuries with The Associated Press over the last two weeks, 23 of 44 NFL players  slightly more than half  said they would try to conceal a possible concussion rather than pull themselves out of a game.

title: When Modernity Trumps Tradition
description: JOHANNESBURG  The Southern Africa Report recently ran a story alleging that as part of an annual ceremony called Incwala King Mswati III of Swaziland has sex with a bull beaten into semi-consciousness. I have no way of confirming the report. But it did serve to raise what is a very real issue in this part of the world: the clash between tradition and modernity.

title: What Rex Ryan Said After the Jets-Giants Game
description: Reviewing Rex Ryans comments to reporters after the Jets lost to the Giants on Saturday. The full transcript is below, via Jets.com.

title: Crystal Bridges, the Art Museum Walmart Money Built, Opens
description: BENTONVILLE, Ark.  By just about any measure, the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, which opened last month in this small town in northwest Arkansas, is off to a running start. The dream-come-true of Alice Walton, an heir to the Walmart fortune, it is characterized by people both inside and outside the museum as a work in progress, with plenty of room for improvement. But there it stands, a big, serious, confident, new institution with more than 50,000 square feet of gallery space and a collection worth hundreds of millions of dollars in a region almost devoid of art museums.

title: China Jails Writer for Subversion
description: Chen Xi, a liberal Chinese writer, has been sentenced to 10 years in prison on a charge of inciting subversion of the state, according to reports by news agencies on Monday that cited Mr. Chens wife, Zhang Qunxuan.

title: Japan Panel Cites Failure in Tsunami
description: TOKYO  From inspectors abandoning of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant as it succumbed to disaster to a delay in disclosing radiation leaks, Japans response to the nuclear accident caused by the March tsunami fell tragically short, a government-appointed investigative panel said on Monday.

title: The Best in Culture
Celery Root-Potato Pure
description: Time: About 30 minutes

title: For New Years, a Bit Fancy, but All Relaxed
description: THOUGH it can be great fun to go out for New Years Eve, this year Im staying home. Im not in the mood to fight the crowds, but Ill happily cook for a small group of friends and celebrate around the table for hours.

title: How to Celebrate at Home
description: There are many ways to celebrate New Years Eve, some pious, some raucous, no doubt everything in between. Festivities take place high above the twinkling city, in humble taverns, and in the street. (And there is always a meditative yoga option for those seeking purity and abstinence.)

title: Path Is Cleared for Yemeni Leader to Get Care in U.S.
description: HONOLULU  The Obama administration has decided in principle to allow the embattled president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, to enter the United States for medical treatment, subject to certain assurances, two administration officials said Monday.

title: Debt and Growth in the G7
description: Ive written fairly often about the often-cited Reinhart/Rogoff claim that terrible things happen to economic growth if the ratio of debt to GDP exceeds 90 percent. Its a claim that has been pretty thoroughly debunked  yet it continues to circulate among Very Serious People as a known fact. Anyway, I was looking at some debt data, and thought that it might be useful to look at debt of the major advanced economies since World War II, and see what gets picked out by the 90 percent criterion.

title: A Visual Feast in an Undersea Twilight Zone
description: It was an extraordinary day for me. To understand why, it may be useful to explain a bit about my research. Using advanced closed-circuit mixed-gas rebreather technology, my colleagues and I have spent the past two decades traveling the tropical Pacific Ocean to to document life that occurs below the realm of scuba divers. The environment that I focus on  tropical reef habitats at depths of about 200 to 500 feet  has variously been referred to as deep coral reefs, mesophotic coral ecosystems and the coral-reef Twilight Zone.

title: Syria Observers Urged to Hurry to Homs, Where Death Toll Keeps Rising
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At least 30 people were killed in fighting in the rebellious Syrian city of Homs on Monday, spurring France to join with residents and opposition figures in urging observers from the Arab League to quickly visit the city.

title: Monday Reading: Apps to Entertain Children  While Traveling
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: A Plan for 2012 That Youll Actually Follow
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog. His new book, The Behavior Gap, will be out in January.

title: The Best in Design
Discussion on Caste, Heated as Always
description: Writing about caste in India often generates a heated response, and Indias Boom Creates Openings for Untouchables, a recent article in The New York Times about successful Dalit, or untouchable, entrepreneurs, was no exception. Readers weighed in on social mobility in India today and the role caste continues to play in the country, often in stark and argumentative terms.

title: Numberplay: Uncertain Return
description: Tis the season to be grateful for the remarkable conversations weve had here at Numberplay  and for the creative and generous readers that make it all happen. Some of the most beautiful puzzles are ones that emerge in the middle of the week once things really get rolling. Heres one of my favorites.

title: Contaminated Milk Is Destroyed in China
description: BEIJING  Chinas largest dairy company, the China Mengniu Dairy Company, says it has destroyed a batch of milk contaminated with a substance that can cause liver cancer.

title: Dark Clouds Descend on Broadway (Can You See Any Glints of Silver?)
description: Sorry, Tiny Tim, theres no getting around it: This week represents the beginning of one of the unhappiest seasons on Broadway, when struggling plays and musicals prepare to close once the tourists leave town. One show will finish on a high note  Hugh Jackman will conclude his limited run on Sunday with roughly $14 million in ticket sales in just 10 weeks  while others will end at a loss. The $6 million flop Bonnie & Clyde will close Friday without recouping any of its money and The Addams Family will exit on Saturday without earning back all of its $16.5 million capitalization.

title: Really? The Claim: For Famous Musicians, 27 Is a Dangerous Age
description: THE FACTS

title: An Idyllic Picture of Serenity, but Only if Youre Not Inside
description: Tropical fish hobbyists will tell you their tanks are a source of relaxation, but recent research suggests the fish might disagree.

title: Rare but Grudging Judicial About-Face in Bias Case
description: Its a nice Christmas present, isnt it? said U. W. Clemon, Alabamas first black federal judge.

title: Romney Pushes Economic Agenda in New Ad
description: CHICAGO  Mitt Romney wont arrive back in Iowa until Tuesday evening. But his campaign began the final week before the caucuses with a new television advertisement stressing his conservative economic credentials and promising to get rid of President Obamas health care program.

title: Merry Christmas Roundup (Featuring Jensons Horrible Ad)
description: There is not much new in the world of Formula One racing, as the teams finally take a real break and prepare for the new year and the testing of new cars, which begins in February. This is when the media receives a slew of Christmas greetings from the teams and other F1 related people, like circuits and promoters. Now, then, is also the time for me to wish this blogs readers a merry Christmas, and a thanks for another year of faithful readership.

title: Merry Christmas Roundup (Featuring Jensons Horrible Ad)
description: There is not much new in the world of Formula One racing, as the teams finally take a real break and prepare for the new year and the testing of new cars, which begins in February. This is when the media receives a slew of Christmas greetings from the teams and other F1 related people, like circuits and promoters. Now, then, is also the time for me to wish this blogs readers a merry Christmas, and a thanks for another year of faithful readership.

title: La Churreria to Open in NoLIta
description: You cannot eat just two, or even four or five  skinny, crispy churros still warm from the fryer, that is. Though New York has no shortage of restaurants and street vendors offering these fluted fritters that are popular in Spain and Latin America, a new bakery, La Churreria, will specialize in them.

title: Tiniest of Spiders Are Loaded With Brains
description: Tiny spiders have brains so large that they fill up their body cavities and extend into their legs, a new study reports.

title: Bony Sixth Toe Helps an Elephants Stance
description: Their feet may look like solid, flat-bottomed tree trunks, but elephants actually stand tiptoed, more like dogs or deer.

title: Kings of the Track Share Traits With Speedy Cats
description: The foot and ankle structure of human sprinters resembles that of cheetahs and greyhounds, a new study reports.

title: Shiny Patches in Maines Streambeds Are Bright Sign for Salmon
description: WASHINGTON COUNTY, Me.  Ernie Atkinson waded up Old Stream on a warm fall afternoon, peering through polarized sunglasses to scan the streambed. Before long, he pointed out a place where the bottom looked different.

title: Israel Risks New Turkish Ire with Recognition of Armenian Genocide
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Parliament on Monday held its first public debate on whether to commemorate the Turkish genocide of Armenians nearly a century ago, an emotionally resonant and politically fraught topic for Israel, founded on the ashes of the Holocaust and trying to salvage frayed ties with Turkey.

title: Portraits of the Southwest in the Shadow of Drought
description: The intense, deep blue skies of the American Southwest, skies that have drawn painters and photographers for a century or more, are a product of the regions extremely dry air.

title: A Great Aridness
description: Pages 22-27

title: In Madrids Heart, Park Blooms Where a Freeway Once Blighted
description: MADRID  Even on a chilly Thursday afternoon in December, the old men, engulfed in cigar smoke and reading newspapers, were sitting around chess tables under tall pines. Nearby, a young woman had strung her line between the trunks of two mulberry trees to practice tightrope walking.

title: Madrid Ro
description: Images of the new park in Spain.

title: Daniel Craig to Politicians: I Do Not Want to Be Your Friend
description: What would M say about this?

title: Lucky Foods to Ring in the New Year
description: I love the fact that beans, lentils and greens symbolize prosperity in the New Year in places as disparate as the American South and the South of France. I wonder if its really because lentils and beans are round like coins and swell when they cook, or if its because thats about all anybody can afford to eat after the excesses of the holiday season.

title: Science and Censorship: A Duel Lasting Centuries
description: We have consultations, which of the inventions and experiences which we have discovered shall be published, and which not; and take all an oath of secrecy for the concealing of those which we think fit to keep secret; though some of those we do reveal sometime to the State, and some not.

title: Sodium-Saturated Diet Is a Threat for All
description: Maybe you think you dont have to worry about salt. After all, you dont have high blood pressure, youre not overweight and you exercise regularly.

title: Little Rascals in a Secret Garden
description: Researchers may have neglected middle childhood until recently, but authors and screenwriters have long revisited the grade school years in their work. Below, a sampling, compiled by Gregory Cowles, an editor at The New York Times Book Review.

title: Lives Overlap on the Track in McCarren Park
description: Aristotle believed circular motion to be a distinguishing characteristic of perfection. If you have ever seen a world-class runner cruise around a track, you may well agree that a body curving in motion is a sight of beauty.

title: The Hormone Surge of Middle Childhood
description: VIEWED superficially, the part of youth that the psychologist Jean Piaget called middle childhood looks tame and uneventful, a quiet patch of road on the otherwise hairpin highway to adulthood.

title: Video: How to Shuck an Oyster
description: Bivalve purists would say the best thing to serve with freshly shucked oysters is absolutely nothing. The plump mollusks slide delightfully down the gullet dressed in their own juices, no embellishments needed.

title: Graceful Moves, for a Boy Made of Metal
description: PHILADELPHIA  What makes an automaton tick?

title: Your Favorite Quotes About Childhood
description: In todays Science Times, Natalie Angier explores the science and the mystery of middle childhood, a time between toddlerhood and the teenage years when a young brain learns awareness, friendship and responsibility.

title: Scenes From McCarren Park in Brooklyn
description: The track at McCarren Park, which is dear to the people of Greenpoint and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, caters to the needs of the physically curious, the committed and the compulsive.

title: Risks: Blood Pressure Tests May Not Be Enough
description: A single blood pressure test, or even several readings over a short period of time, may not be enough to gauge the risk of developing cardiovascular disease.

title: Prevention: Beer and Martinis: As Healthy as Wine?
description: Many studies have found an association between the moderate consumption of alcohol and increased longevity, and some have found evidence that wine has a more beneficial effect than other alcoholic drinks.

title: Gingrich Unlikely to Get on Virginia Ballot
description: 6:03 p.m. | Updated  Continuing to smart from its failure to get on the primary ballot in Virginia, Newt Gingrichs campaign said it would explore ways to persuade the Republican Party of Virginia to bend its rules and allow Mr. Gingrich and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who also failed to qualify, to join the only two names now on the ballot: Mitt Romney and Ron Paul.

title: Recalling a Trip to North Korea Before the Death of Kim Jong-il
description: Mun Ho-yong placed the bouquet of flowers at the foot of the towering outdoor portrait of Kim Il-sung, the founder of North Korea. Then he turned to the Chinese businesspeople and tourists, and to the foreign journalists. Now please bow to our leader, he said.

title: A Note On The Ricardian Equivalence Argument Against Stimulus (Slightly Wonkish)
description: There have been a lot of shockingly bad performances among macroeconomists in this crisis; but if I had to pick the one that is most startling, it is the way freshwater economists have demonstrated that they dont understand one of their own doctrines, that of Ricardian equivalence.

title: Patterns: HPV Vaccine Is Not Linked to Promiscuity
description: A survey has found that girls ages 15 to 19 who are vaccinated against human papillomavirus, or HPV, are no more likely to be sexually active or to have more partners than unvaccinated girls.

title: In Blow to Government, Sadr Followers Call for New Elections
description: BAGHDAD  A powerful political group led by the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr called on Monday for Parliament to be dissolved and early elections to be held, the first open challenge to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki from within his Shiite coalition in an escalating political crisis.

title: U.S. Report Faults NATO Delays on Pakistan Strike
description: WASHINGTON  A military investigation has concluded that it took about 45 minutes for a NATO operations officer in Afghanistan to notify a senior allied commander about Pakistans calls that its outposts were under attack, one of several breakdowns in communication that contributed to airstrikes that killed 26 Pakistani soldiers last month.

title: Playoffs? Some Battling for No. 1 Pick
description: Three playoff spots, and numerous seedings, will be determined on the final day of the regular season Sunday. But for a longer-term effect on the N.F.L., look to the otherwise meaningless game between the Jacksonville Jaguars and the Indianapolis Colts.

title: The Toughest Seed
description: Q. How can plant seeds  tomatoes, for example  survive the digestive processes of birds and other animals and thus be spread in their droppings?

title: Eighteenth-Century Play to Get First North American Performance
description: The London Merchant, a tragedy from 1731 that was one of the first British dramas to focus on the middle and working classes  and that has apparently never received a professional production in North America  will be performed Jan. 6-28 at the Theater at the Church of Notre Dame in Morningside Heights in Upper Manhattan. Written by George Lillo, The London Merchant is about the downfall of a young apprentice who is led astray by a prostitute. It was highly popular in the 18th century. The Storm Theater Company and Blackfriars Repertory Theater will jointly produce the work, directed by Peter Dobbins, Storms artistic director. A spokesman for the production, Pete Sanders, said on Monday that the producers had done research on the history of the play and could not find evidence that it had been performed professionally in the United States or Canada.

title: Killing on Oxford Street Mars Boxing Day in London
description: The annual British day of bargain-hunting was cut short in London on Monday, as a young man in London was stabbed to death just after noon.

title: Wonderful Life Lifts NBC in Holiday Ratings
description: Television programming has its own holiday traditions, and they were reflected in the Nielsen ratings over the weekend. An encore telecast on NBC of Its a Wonderful Life, the 65-year-old Christmas stalwart, was the No. 1 program in all ratings categories on Saturday, with 4.6 million total viewers. It was the most-watched film on any of the broadcast networks since April.

title: Malaria: World Health Organization Says Deaths Have Dropped 25 Percent in Last Decade
description: Malaria deaths have fallen by more than 25 percent in the last decade, thanks to a coordinated attack on the disease, but that progress remains fragile, the World Health Organization announced this month.

title: Faceless
description: Dori Frame has a neurological disorder called prosopagnosia. She cannot recognize human faces, and even close friends and relatives can look unfamiliar to her.

title: Have We Met? Tracing Face Blindness to Its Roots
description: Close your eyes. Picture your closest friend. Maybe you see her blue eyes, long nose, brown hair. Perhaps even her smile.

title: Preliminary Returns and Concerns for Contending Teams
description: Any self-proclaimed N.B.A. contender can piece together an effective starting lineup, but several of the teams gunning for the leagues top tier face serious issues with their benches. Now that the season has officially begun, those depth concerns shift out of the hypothetical realm and become the harsh reality for teams on the cusp. Thanks to a helter-skelter schedule, depth is more important than ever, and teams like the Lakers, Clippers, Celtics and Knicks will have to find ways to balance their strong starting lineups with unremarkable reserves.

title: A World Without Faces
description: Imagine being unable to recognize your children or your closest friend. You can see their faces perfectly fine, but if you passed them on the street you wouldnt be able to place their unique eyes, nose and ears.

title: Patient Voices: Multiple Sclerosis
description: What is it like to be told you have a disease that may rob you of your sight and ability to walk? Eight men and women speak about life after a diagnosis of MS.

title: New Drugs Raise Hope for Patients With M.S.
description: Three years ago, Kristie Salerno Kent, a singer-songwriter, was standing in a security line at the airport on her way home from a gig when her legs went numb. From the waist down, it felt as though I was trying to walk through a bowl of oatmeal, said the 38-year-old musician, who has multiple sclerosis.

title: Poisoning Kills More Than Car Crashes
description: In 2008, for the first time in nearly 30 years, more people died of poisoning than in car crashes. Poisoning is now the leading cause of injury death, and 90 percent of poisonings were caused by drugs.

title: Poof to Life as You Knew It
description: Based on the admittedly flimsy evidence of films like The Darkest Hour, the best defense against invading aliens is to be as attractive as possible. Being one-dimensional doesnt hurt, either, even if that particular character flaw can be safely blamed on whoever is responsible for the screenplay  in this case, Jon Spaihts. Given that he is also one of two writers credited on Ridley Scotts much anticipated 2012 film (and possible Alien prequel) Prometheus, it is to be hoped that his lazy ideas were not equally apportioned between the two projects.

title: Scholars Retract Another Study Linking Virus to Fatigue Syndrome
description: For the second time in a week, a key study suggesting a link between a retroviral infection and chronic fatigue syndrome has been retracted.

title: Tough Choices This Hanukkah (Holiday) Season
description: Last Tuesday was the first night of Hanukkah, and my 14-year-old son sang in his all-male high schools holiday concert. When my children were enrolled full-time in a Jewish day school, they would head to the gold-domed State House in Boston and perform an annual Hanukkah concert. Every year the same tin-eared politician would lurch forward with a boxers stance and proclaim, When you shake my hand, wish me a Merry Christmas instead of a happy holiday!

title: Mechanical Memory
description: The Maillardet automatons motions are controlled by dozens of slowly rotating brass disks. These disks contain all the data necessary for its lifelike movement and drawings  in effect, they serve as a mechanical form of read-only memory.

title: A Rappers Regional Appeal and an Actresss Musical Birthright
description: WEBBIE

title: Nigeria Arrests 2 in Blast That Killed 26 in Church
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  As Nigerian officials announced arrests Monday in connection with the deadly bombing of a church on Christmas Day, American officials and analysts said the violence underscored the increasing ability of a shadowy Islamist insurgency to carry out complex strikes against multiple targets, complicating the fight against it.

title: A Look Back, and Ahead, at Pemberley
description: Pemberley, Jane Austen fans will recall, is the large Derbyshire estate owned by Fitzwilliam Darcy, who weds Elizabeth Bennet at the end of Pride and Prejudice, and in Death Comes to Pemberley, P. D. Jamess surprising new sequel to that novel, it becomes the scene of a murder.

title: Israel TV Stations Troubles Reflect a Larger Political Battleground
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli television station reported last spring on numerous trips Benjamin Netanyahu had taken as an elected official to Paris, London and New York before becoming prime minister in 2009. Accompanied by his wife, he flew first class and stayed in baronial hotel suites. Mrs. Netanyahu had her hair styled and her wardrobe dry-cleaned. The bills, displayed on screen, were paid for by wealthy friends.

title: The Name Is Distinctive, But the Role Is Generic
description: LOS ANGELES  How to Rock, a forthcoming series on Nickelodeon, follows a simple rule for childrens television: if its not broken, then copy it.

title: Bard College Names New Theater Director
description: Bard College has announced that Gideon Lester, a former associate artistic director of the American Repertory Theater, will succeed JoAnne Akalaitis as its director of theater programs, a position that will expand under Mr. Lester to include taking productions to its Fisher Center for the Performing Arts and the Bard SummerScape festival there. Ms. Akalaitis, a longtime director of experimental productions and a former artistic director of the Public Theater in New York, is stepping down as head of the theater department after 14 years. Mr. Lester, now co-curator of the Crossing the Line arts festival in New York, teaches at Columbia University.

title: Helping Immigrants Get the Lawyers They Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Poverty and Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Pt. and Fukushima: Alike or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: Free-Spirited Invention With Instruments Centuries Old
description: You can count on Frederick Renz and the musicians of his Early Music New York to offer a Christmas program unlike anything else the citys music world has to offer. Some years it is a theatrical piece, like Mr. Renzs reconstruction of the 12th-century Play of St. Nicholas; in others, like this one, it draws on rarely heard sacred works, carols and instrumental pieces from across Europe, presented in an orderly procession that traces changing approaches to the Christmas story and the evolution of Western harmonic and rhythmic practice.

title: S.&P., on Credit Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Penny-Wise and No Fools in Stores
description: On Monday, the day after Christmas, TLCs cameras were cruising Forever 21, Lane Bryant and GameStop stores in Florida and California for a future episode of recession-era entertainment: Extreme Couponing.

title: Pakistan Prime Minister Says No Plans to Dismiss Military Chiefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on Monday denied news reports that he was planning to dismiss the countrys army and intelligence commanders in the aftermath of tensions that have emerged over a controversial memo that claims the civilian government had sought American help in constraining the powerful Pakistani military.

title: Graphic: Going Negative in Iowa
description: The run-up to the Iowa caucuses has seen deeply negative advertising. Some Republican presidential candidates, particularly Ron Paul and Rick Perry, are spending heavily to criticize their opponents and President Obama. Outside groups, like the super PACs that support certain candidates, and independent groups, like Crossroads GPS, are also doing their part.

title: Turtles Show Way to Prosperity
description: The turtles in a large aquarium in a Midtown window often bring passers-by to a halt, even those used to seeing the unexpected.

title: Dont Go After Military Pensions
description: Washington

title: Santorum Hunts for Birds and an Endorsement, but Leaves Disappointed
description: ADEL, Iowa  Wearing blaze orange, including a cap stamped with the letters N.R.A., Rick Santorum announced on Monday that he had failed to meet expectations during a pheasant hunt with one of Iowas leading conservative legislators.

title: Political Struggle in Congress Delayed, Not Resolved
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress handily passed a bill to set payroll tax rates, jobless benefits and Medicare doctors fees for the next two months, it seemed to end an epic political struggle between President Obama and Republicans on Capitol Hill. In fact, that was just the beginning.

title: In New Ad, Perry Attacks His Rivals for Serving in Congress
description: Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, released a new ad on Monday as the Republican primary campaign began to ramp up again after the holiday.

title: Want a New You? Change Your Name
description: IN June, my band performed at a party at a Lower East Side boutique that specialized in wool ankle cuffs and sheer tunics. A few weeks later, we were playing in Brooklyn when a man approached me and said, I just thought you might like to know that a friend I brought to your last show changed her name to Alina Simone.

title: Rangers Staal, Still Battling Concussion, Is Cleared for Contact
description: Defenseman Marc Staal, who continues to recover from a concussion after a clean, but vicious, hit by his brother Eric on Feb. 22, was cleared for contact and took hits during the Rangers practice Monday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Midlife Crisis Economics
description: The members of the Obama administration have many fine talents, but making adept historical analogies may not be among them.

title: TV Prices Fall, Squeezing Most Makers and Sellers
description: Its a great time to buy a television, and Ram Lall, a television salesman, isnt happy about it. In a basement showroom of J&R, the huge electronics store in Lower Manhattan, Mr. Lall says the days of making big money from televisions are in the past. Pointing to a top-of-the line, 55-inch Sony television, Mr. Lall said it would have sold for $6,000 a few years ago. The current price? $2,599.

title: Keeping Students From the Polls
description: Next fall, thousands of students on college campuses will attempt to register to vote and be turned away. Sorry, they will hear, you have an out-of-state drivers license. Sorry, your college ID is not valid here. Sorry, we found out that you paid out-of-state tuition, so even though you do have a state drivers license, you still cant vote.

title: Markets Rise While Dollar Loses Ground
description: Among the stock markets that were open worldwide on Monday, most climbed, while the dollar maintained losses against higher-yielding peers amid speculation that the United States economy would continue to recover.

title: Law to Find Tax Evaders Denounced
description: Legislation meant to help the United States government locate overseas assets of American tax cheats created little stir when it was quietly slipped into a jobs bill last year.

title: A Push to Tie New Drugs to Testing
description: ChemGenex Pharmaceuticals found out the hard way how important it is to have a trustworthy companion.

title: In China, Power in Nascent Electric Car Industry
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Three years ago, as part of its green-energy policy, the Chinese government set an ambitious goal: by the end of 2011, the nation would be able to produce at least 500,000 hybrid or all-electric cars and buses a year.

title: In Europe, Securities Overseer Spreads Gospel of Streamlined Regulation
description: PARIS  Steven Maijoor, the chairman of Europes new securities regulator, has been piling up the frequent flier miles.

title: Dealing With Chinas Troubles
description: Chinas economy seems to be in trouble, which could be a very big problem for the world unless Chinas leaders and trading partners ensure that economic strains in the worlds largest exporting nation do not lead to trade confrontations around the globe.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Social Media in the 16th Century and Online Piracy
description: Heres what the tech reporters and editors found on the Web over the holiday weekend. The full list is at the right.

title: After 123 Years, Manischewitz Creates Kosher Food for Gentiles
description: IN recent years, Jews who keep kosher rejoiced when popular foods that had been off-limits gained kosher certification, from Oreo cookies in 1997 to the Tootsie Roll in 2009.

title: For Jackson, Leading Warriors, Not Knicks, Was Meant to Be
description: Just before the tip-off of his first game as Golden States coach on Christmas night, Mark Jackson looked behind him and spotted his children. Then he looked across the floor and saw his wife.

title: As Inquiry Widens, Comptroller Is Busy Showing That All Is Calm
description: By most accounts, John C. Liu, once considered a top contender for mayor in 2013, has been badly damaged by the federal investigation into whether illegal donations were funneled into his campaign treasury. But one would never know it watching him go about his days.

title: A Range With Unwelcome Moving Targets
description: The live training exercises that take place on a nearly two-million-acre bombing range prepare military pilots for battle, but can be halted by illegal immigrants trying to cross the nearby border from Mexico.

title: Strafing Mock Targets, but Holding Fire, Too
description: BARRY M. GOLDWATER RANGE, Ariz.  It was like a scene out of Iraq, back when American fighter jets crisscrossed the skies there, or out of Afghanistan, where air-to-ground combat continues. But the F-16 fighter jets that roared across the desert the other day with bombs exploding underneath them were, in fact, over Arizona.

title: As Indonesia Grows, Discontent Sets in Among Workers
description: JAKARTA  As a flare-red sun set, a group of laborers in their 20s and 30s gathered on the bare floor of a battered house wedged beneath power lines in an industrial part of Jakarta. They were members of a confederation of multisector workers, one of the largest trade unions in Indonesia, whose slogan is Young, brave, militant.

title: A Member of the House Who Rents Out Rooms
description: Among her colleagues, Representative Carolyn B. Maloney is known as a fiery liberal from Manhattan, a rebel and a bit of a showman (she once appeared on the House floor in a burqa to draw attention to the mistreatment of women in Afghanistan).

title: Airlines Are Retrenching, and Alternatives Are Slim
description: THE coming year will be a time of reckoning in business travel, as airlines reduce service at many airports and prospects fade for practical alternatives to flying, including the long-term promises of high-speed rail.

title: The Military Minds Take on Civilian Flights
description: I ACTUALLY enjoy business trips. I really like not being in charge or in control. I can get work done, read a book, or just sit and think without being disturbed. Even though Im the chief executive of a software company, I almost never fly first class or business class. Im a coach guy. If I get an upgrade, dont get me wrong, Ill take it. But most of the time Im sitting in the back of the plane.

title: Year That Began Like a Dirge for San Diegos Organist Ends in Joy
description: SAN DIEGO  On the best days, loyal fans say, it is possible to hear the thundering organ three miles away. Weighing nearly 100,000 pounds with more than 4,500 pipes, it is nearly the largest outdoor organ in the world.

title: Citigroup May Yet Benefit Its Investors
N.B.A.s Opening Games Bring High TV Ratings
description: Four of the N.B.A.s five Christmas games generated higher viewership this year over last year, perhaps not a surprise because they opened the lockout-shortened season.

title: Airfares With Less Fine Print
description: Advertisements that make airfares seem enticingly low will soon lose that asterisk pointing to a dense paragraph of additional taxes and fees that make a cheap ticket much more costly.

title: Million-Dollar Visas
description: The federal governments investor visa, created in 1990, gives foreigners a chance at green cards if they invest $1 million to build a business in the United States that creates at least 10 jobs. Investing in an area with high unemployment would cut that price in half.

title: Clearer Bank Account Terms
description: Consumer advocates are rightly pressuring the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to require banks to disclose important terms on checking accounts like the monthly fee in easy-to-understand forms. JPMorgan Chase has voluntarily adopted a new, straightforward disclosure policy. Other banks that have been resisting this policy should follow Chases lead.

title: Teetering Jets Lament Lack of Balance on Offense
description: Get past Rex Ryans bluster, all those proclamations and pronouncements, and what endures is a mantra he has long preached: players and coaches are judged on wins and losses.

title: Ships Espresso-Fueled Mission: Laying Cables Beneath the Hudson
description: For several minutes on Thursday, Al Figueroa was up to his neck in mud nearly 70 feet below the swift-moving surface of the Hudson River.

title: One Game In, Knicks Seek Extra Players
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  One game into the truncated 66-game season, with the Knicks already hampered by injuries, Coach Mike DAntoni was asked Monday about the possibility of Nate Robinsons return to the team to help out at the guard spot.

title: The Old Order Changeth
description: I will not be attending the Modern Language Association meeting in Seattle (Jan. 5-8), but I have read through the program to see whats going on and whats no longer going on in literary studies.

title: Whose Tea Party Is It?
description: Newt Gingrichs brief turn as presidential front-runner was only the latest paroxysm of a tumultuous Republican primary season. Whats going on? Tensions within the Tea Party help explain the volatility of the Republican primary campaign, as candidates seek to appeal to competing elements of the Tea Party with varying success.

title: In Fires Rubble, Signs of Grandfathers Last Heroic Act
description: After a career dedicated to keeping others safe, Lomer Johnson was happy to indulge another passion in retirement: dressing up as a department store Santa, heeding the wishes of children, even if he could not always fulfill them.

title: Andrew Geller, Modernist Architect, Is Dead at 87
description: Andrew Geller, an architect who embodied postwar ingenuity and optimism in a series of inexpensive beach houses in whimsical shapes, many of them in the Hamptons, and who helped bring modernism to the masses with prefabricated cottages sold at Macys, died on Sunday in Syracuse. He was 87 and lived in Spencer, N.Y.

title: Economic Downturn Took a Detour at Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON  When Representative Ed Pastor was first elected to Congress two decades ago, he was comfortably ensconced in the middle class. Mr. Pastor, a Democrat from Arizona, held $100,000 or so in savings accounts in the mid-1990s and had a retirement pension, but like many Americans, he also owed the banks nearly as much in loans.

title: Documents Appear to Contradict Gingrichs Account of First Divorce
description: New court documents that have emerged seem to contradict Newt Gingrichs account of how his first marriage ended. On his campaign Web site, under the heading Answering the Attacks, the Gingrich campaign maintains that it was his first wife, Jackie Battley Gingrich, the mother of the couples two daughters, who sought a divorce in 1980.

title: Glasss Road to Redemption
description: Early next week, a lawyer will file a brief with the California Supreme Court, arguing that his client has the good moral character to be admitted to the California bar. His client is Stephen Glass.

title: A Soldier in the West
description: A force of Creek and Seminole warriors emerged from rugged hills in Indian Territory and fanned out across frozen Texas ground on Christmas Day 1861. They formed a long line and watched, quietly from a distance, as newly arrived Confederate soldiers pitched tents and organized camp in the bitter cold.

title: Lynn Samuels, a Brash Radio Talker, Dies at 69
description: Lynn Samuels, whose brash political opinions and unrestrained New York accent made her an unmistakable voice in the male-dominated world of political talk radio, died on Saturday at her apartment in Woodside, Queens. She was 69.

title: Lottery Numbers
Fiscal Crisis Takes Toll on Health of Greeks
description: PERAMA, Greece  The free clinic here opened about a year ago to serve illegal immigrants. But these days, it is mostly caring for Greeks like Vassiliki Ragamb, who was sitting in the waiting room hoping to get insulin for her young diabetic son.

title: Greeces Deep Cuts
description: As Greece is forced to make steep spending cuts, many families are falling into poverty and face losing healthcare coverage.

title: Toughness of Coughlin Rubs Off on Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After running back D. J. Ware crashed into Tom Coughlins left leg in the Giants victory over the Jets on Saturday, the Giants players reminded Coughlin of a saying he has used to motivate them, No toughness, no championships.

title: An Unusual Straight Talker Is Back in Good Voice and Looking at City Hall
description: Long ago, as a young reporter in the depths of the 1991 recession, I was assigned to cover the release of the mayors management report, that bible of all things municipal.

title: Tuesday: Start of a Cry by Juliet
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  The artist Winslow Homer was a 19th-century American landscape and maritime painter who began his career as a magazine illustrator and lithographer. Eventually, his interests expanded to both oil and watercolor painting, and his success was so great that he was able to give up his illustration career and paint full time. His most famous works captured the lives of the men and women who worked near the seaside, as well as children at play.

title: Currency Agreement for Japan and China
description: BEIJING  China and Japan have agreed to start direct trading of their currencies, officials announced during a visit here on Monday by Japans prime minister, Yoshihiko Noda.

title: Easing Restrictions on Gun Permits
description: States across the country have made it easier for people to obtain permits to carry concealed guns

title: A 9th-Grade Dropout Returns to School
description: Reading her notes on the No. 3 train, Tamara Gonzalez did all she could to push the doubts out, out, out of her mind. Yes, it was only a quiz, but it had been a while since she had taken one. And then there was the matter of her advanced age.

title: Kazakhstan: President Fires Son-in-Law
description: The president of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbayev, who has appointed several relatives to government jobs in the Central Asian nation, fired his son-in-law Monday from one of them: manager of the countrys sovereign wealth fund. Timur Kulibayev, who is married to Mr. Nazarbayevs second daughter, lost his job after at least 16 people died in violence between striking oil workers and the police this month.

title: Afghanistan to Disband Irregular Police Force Set Up Under NATO
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai has taken steps to disband a little-known, irregular police force financed by the American military with members in at least four northern provinces. Some members of the force are former militiamen and thugs known as much for extorting money from ordinary citizens as for intimidating insurgents and upholding the law.

title: Nets Begin Rebuilding Project With a Win
description: WASHINGTON  Symbolic of a transition year, the Nets opened their season on Monday night with an up-and-down performance.

title: Guns in Public, and Out of Sight
description: Alan Simons was enjoying a Sunday morning bicycle ride with his family in Asheville, N.C., two years ago when a man in a sport utility vehicle suddenly pulled alongside him and started berating him for riding on the highway.

title: Rangers Blank Islanders for Fifth Straight Victory
description: The puck skipped across the ice Monday to Rangers defenseman Michael Del Zotto, who looked up and saw only Islanders forward Frans Nielsen standing in front of him. Suddenly, Nielsen was behind Del Zotto, who spun Nielsen around as if he were Dorothy Hamill.

title: A Growing Divide Between Congress and Constituents
description: Members of Congress experienced a 15 percent jump in net worth from 2004 to 2010.

title: Romo Is Feeling Better, So Dallas Is, Too
description: IRVING, Tex.  Swelling remained in quarterback Tony Romos bruised right hand Monday, and the Dallas Cowboys, while optimistic, said they were not sure if he would practice Wednesday.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/27/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/27/2011

title: Debate Persists on Deadly Flu Made Airborne
description: The young scientist, normally calm and measured, seemed edgy when he stopped by his bosss office.

title: G.O.P. Race Still Unsettled in Sprint to Iowa Caucus
description: DES MOINES  Mitt Romney and his allies are making an assertive final push this week to increase his chances of a strong finish in the Iowa caucuses, the outcome of which could help determine the length of the Republican presidential nominating battle.

title: How Can Romney Lose?
description: The conventional wisdom on the Republican nomination race has once again shifted. In the span of just two weeks, Mitt Romney has gone from seeming quite vulnerable to the near-inevitable Republican nominee. The odds attributed to Mr. Romney winning the nomination at the betting market Intrade, which closed at a low of 42 percent on Dec. 13, had shot up to 72 percent as of Monday night.

title: The Whole Family Under One Roof?
Shifting Debate Over Lokpal
description: Today the lower house of Parliament begins what is expected to be a very passionate debate on the Lokpal Bill, which would create an anti-corruption ombudsman.

title: Madrid Ro
description: Images of the new park in Spain.

title: Emerging Freedoms in Myanmar
description: Paula Bronstein has been traveling to Myanmar to take photographs for almost 20 years, so shes accustomed to the feeling that she was being followed everywhere. Mind you, its not paranoia when youre actually being followed .

title: 11 Detained Over Attack at a Store in London
description: LONDON  Eleven people between 16 and 22 years old were in custody on Tuesday after a fatal stabbing 24 hours earlier shut down Londons main shopping street during one of its busiest days of the year, a move that prompted frustrated consumers to surge against police lines and a police officer to fire a stun gun.

title: North Korea Asks South to Restore Deal to Spur Investment
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Tuesday that it wanted to restore scuttled agreements with South Korea that could channel extensive investments from the developed South into the impoverished North.
