The request was conveyed in the first official interaction with visitors from the South since the death of the Norths leader, Kim Jong-il.

title: As Jan. 1 Application Deadline Nears, an Argument for a Yearlong Breather
description: Robert Clagett is a former dean of admissions at Middlebury College and former senior admissions officer at Harvard College.

title: Top 10 N.F.L. Trends on the Field
description: The problem with many Top 10 Stories of the Year articles is that they focus on drama and hype. Reading about Ndamukong Suhs stomping incident or the Jim Schwartz-Jim Harbaugh postgame scuffle or the publics reaction to Tim Tebow is entertaining, but it wont make anyone a smarter football fan. For those who prefer analysis, here are the top 10 trends and developments that took place between the sidelines in the N.F.L. this season.

title: In Berlin, Urban Spas to Combat the Winter Chill
description: Berlins harsh winters can chill its residents to the bone, and the decrease in daylight hours can render the season truly grueling. To fend off the depression that the season can bring, Berliners find a respite in the citys saunas and public bathhouses. The following are distinctive yet each carries Berlins own brand of cool:

title: How Politics Came to Dominate Payroll Tax Debate
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Q&A: Another Way to Restart TiVo
description: Q.

title: Lower House of Indian Parliament Passes Anticorruption Measure
description: NEW DELHI  After a day of high political theater, Indias Parliament moved closer on Tuesday to passing landmark legislation to create an independent anticorruption agency, even as the activist Anna Hazare sought to rally public support for his own anticorruption demands by beginning a three-day hunger strike in Mumbai.

title: Japan Recommends Temporary State Control for Tokyo Electric
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government told the operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant on Tuesday to consider accepting temporary state control in return for a much-needed injection of public funds, in effect proposing an interim nationalization of the struggling utility.

title: This Year in Small Business: The Best Reads
description: Until I started writing this weekly column, I never realized how many things can affect my small business. And I never realized how many smart people there are writing about and interpreting these things to try to help people like me better understand them. Of all of the pieces I reviewed this year, here are the best.

title: Challenges Emerge as Arab League Observers Begin Work in a Syrian City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A team of observers from the Arab League traveled to the embattled Syrian city of Homs on Tuesday in a visit that quieted days of fierce violence but also provided hints of the potential challenges of a group trying to monitor a withdrawal of the governments security forces in towns across the country.

title: Parliament Kicks Off Fight of the Year
description: Indias Parliament kicked off the years capstone political fight on Tuesday with the Parliamentary discussion of the Lokpal Bill, Jim Yardley and Vikas Bajaj write in The New York Times.

title: Philippine Floods Put Popular Leader to Test
description: Shortly after more than 1,200 people were killed in one of the worst disasters in recent Philippine history, the glamorous starlet Valerie Concepcion cooed about President Benigno S. Aquino III, who is affectionately known as P-Noy.

title: The View from Penn State: A Scandal, a Fight, and a Bowl Game to Play
description: 9:09 a.m. | Updated Between an intra-team fight and a $5.17 theft, in addition to the scandal surrounding the university, Penn State has a whole lot of distractions in its way as it prepares to face a high-powered Houston offense.

title: 340-Ton Sculpture Versus Immovable Bureaucracy
description: LOS ANGELES  There was a time when what has become known here simply as the Rock  the 340-ton boulder that the Los Angeles County Museum of Art is installing as a major piece of outdoor art  was supposed to begin its nine-day trip from a quarry in Riverside, Calif., in August. With little fanfare, that date slipped until September. And then October. And now ... .

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Frustration and Hope at Hazares Fast in Mumbai
description: Kushal Malde, a 23-year old who works at an Indian bank in the Bandra Kurla Complex.

title: On Our Radar: Philippine Flood Toll at 1,250
description: The death toll from flash floods in the Philippines is hovering at 1,250, but scores of people are still missing. Tens of thousands are displaced in and around the port cities of Iligan and Cagayan de Oro. [CNN]

title: Sanchez and Eli Manning, a Year 3 Comparison
description: Rex Ryan stood by Mark Sanchez on Monday, saying he has a huge amount of confidence in him.

title: The Core, Not Rotten
description: There have been many news reports the past few days about declining inflation  very different from this time last year, when warnings of higher inflation (and higher interest rates) abounded. As Ive written many times, events amount to another win for the IS-LM model and the concept of a liquidity trap.

title: Three of Five Advocates for Chinese Village Released
description: BEIJING  Three of five village advocates who had been abducted by men in plain clothes and detained by the police during a prominent confrontation between local officials and irate residents of a coastal village in south China have been released, a village spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: Remembering a Dean of the White-Collar Bar
description: Robert G. Morvillo, a prominent New York trial lawyer who pioneered the practice of white-collar criminal defense and whose client list included colorful celebrities, powerful politicians and billionaire businessmen, died on Saturday at his home in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 73.

title: Shallow Be Thy Name
description: Karl Smith says something true:

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 27
description: Lighter posting because of the holiday week.

title: Daily Report: Trouble for TV Makers Is Good for Consumers
description: In The New York Times on Tuesday, Andrew Martin writes about the market for television sets, where prices have continued to fall, to the delight of consumers and the chagrin of manufacturers. There is little money to be made in televisions, in part because companies like Sony and Samsung ramped up production capacity for flat-screen sets just before the economic downturn, causing a glut. Online retailers and low-cost set makers have also put pressure on profit margins.

title: Can a Sports Teams Ill Fortunes Be Foretold in Its Name?
description: Developments in the New York sports world over the holiday weekend lead to a conclusion that has been bubbling for a while, and now seems inescapable: If you root for a team whose name ends in ets, youre swimming in a sea of troubles.

title: Architect of Russias Political System Under Putin Is Reassigned
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlin on Tuesday announced the reassignment of Vladislav Y. Surkov, the architect of the highly centralized political system that has come under waves of protest from middle-class Muscovites over the last month.

title: Van Halen Looks Ready to Jump Into Reunion Tour
description: The reunion they said would never happen, already happened once before but didnt happen in time for a Grammy Awards nomination concert, appears to be happening (again). The classic lineup of Van Halen, including David Lee Roth and the brothers Eddie and Alex Van Halen, and what remains of their colossal 1980s-era hair looked as if they were poised to regroup for a new concert tour after the appearance of videos that were posted on the bands Web site, www.van-halen.com. The black-and-white segments, set to parts of the Van Halen songs Jump, Panama and Hot For Teacher, show the bandmates rehearsing and goofing around while a ticker on the bottom of the screen reads: Van Halen on Tour 2012 and First tickets on sale Jan. 10. No other information was immediately available.

title: What Were Reading
description: National Geographic Traveler: Melina Gerosa Bellows voyages to Mexico to investigate the world (and taste the honey) of a stingless, endangered bee that, in ancient Mayan culture, was viewed as a mystic emissary.  Jeff Gordinier

title: The Best in Books
Gingrich Once Sided With Romney on Health Care
description: Before Newt Gingrich was locked in a bitter rivalry with Mitt Romney for the Republican nomination, he offered high praise for the health care law that Mr. Romney signed in 2006 as Massachusetts governor.

title: Helen Frankenthaler, Abstract Painter Who Shaped a Movement, Dies at 83
description: Helen Frankenthaler, the lyrically abstract painter whose technique of staining pigment into raw canvas helped shape an influential art movement in the mid-20th century and who became one of the most admired artists of her generation, died on Tuesday at her home in Darien, Conn. She was 83.

title: In the Barber's Chair
description: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, joins William C. Rhoden and others in a barbershop in Harlem for a talk about the safety of the pro game and other issues.

title: Iranian Court Begins Trial of U.S. Man
description: An Iranian court began hearings on Tuesday in the trial of a man who appeared on state television this month and confessed to being an American spy sent to infiltrate the intelligence services of Iran.

title: Video: Roger Goodell in the Barbers Chair With William C. Rhoden
description: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, joins William C. Rhoden and others in a barbershop in Harlem for a talk about the safety of the pro game and other issues.

title: No Relief in Report on Housing
description: The latest housing report indicates that further declines are in store for the weak American market, or at best a period of long, slow recovery.

title: Tuesday Reading: How Government Austerity Affects Health Care
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: In Iowa, the Campaign Begins. Really.
description: DES MOINES  If there was a time to start paying attention to the Republican presidential contest, this is it.

title: EDF of France to Increase Stake in Italian Utility
description: MILAN  The French utility EDF, Europes biggest power generator, said Tuesday it would raise its stake in the Italian energy company Edison, as it seeks to secure a bigger foothold in the country.

title: MetLife to Sell Bank Unit to GE Capital
description: MetLife announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell the bulk of its retail bank deposits business to GE Capital, as it seeks to focus on its core insurance business.

title: After 1,500 Years, an Index to the Talmuds Labyrinths, With Roots in the Bronx
description: The Talmud is a formidable body of work: 63 volumes of rabbinical discourse and disputation that form Judaisms central scripture after the Torah. It has been around for 1,500 years and is studied every day by tens of thousands of Jews. But trying to navigate through its coiling labyrinth can be enormously difficult because the one thing this monumental work lacks is a widely accepted and accessible index.

title: The Times Names a New Deputy Managing Editor
description: The New York Times said Tuesday that it was promoting its longtime design director, Tom Bodkin, to deputy managing editor, the latest change to the masthead since Jill Abramson took over as executive editor in September.

title: America Is Not Exceptional
description: Uh-oh  Mitt Romney is going to go after me. Maybe Id better get out of the country and start an apology tour

title: Middle Childhood Is Peak Time for Learning
description: Parents have long loved middle childhood, that period from the end of toddlerhood to the teens. In the past in this country, and even now in many remote or agricultural societies, middle childhood marked the moment when children became useful; for modern, Western parents, it marks the time when children become truly fun (and easier) to have around.

title: Leading Off  Saints Had Eye on Record, and Little Else
description: The Miami Dolphins, past and present, have been taking their knocks. They lost the first seven games of the season, their starting quarterback and eventually their coach, Tony Sparano. The Green Bay Packers fell short of duplicating the 1972 squads perfect season, but now another of the Dolphins lifetime achievements, Dan Marinos single-season passing record, has fallen.

title: The Not-So-Beautiful Game
description: ISTANBUL  Welcome to hell! was how Istanbul fans once greeted foreign soccer teams. But now its Turkeys top team that finds itself in a small hell of its own making. Not only is a recent match-fixing scandal threatening the countrys premier league, but it has also forced the governing Justice and Development (AK) Party into scoring against itself. The party that was elected in 2002 as the new broom to sweep Turkey clean looks like its sweeping dirt under the carpet.

title: Gains in Colon Cancer Show a Racial Gap
description: Advances in screening, diagnosis and treatment of colon cancer mean fewer people are dying of the disease today than they were 20 years ago. But not everyone is benefiting equally.

title: A Countdown of Sam Siftons Top 10 New Restaurants of 2011
description: The Timess restaurant critic for much of 2011 lists his favorite new places of the year  a strong one for smart-casual cooking.

title: Sam Siftons Top 10 New Restaurants of 2011
description: FOLLOWING is a list of my favorite new restaurants among those that I reviewed in 2011, before stepping down as critic in October. It suggests a strong year for smart-casual cooking, the sort of food that takes a lot of work to prepare but is often served by people in untucked shirts and flash sneakers. Of course there were exceptions. Chief among them is a restaurant that narrowly missed inclusion here: the elegant Ai Fiori, which Michael White opened in the Setai Hotel. (Ai Fiori recently lost its chef, Chris Jaeckle.)

title: Lamperts Hit-or-Miss Portfolio
description: After reporting disappointing holiday sales, Sears announced on Tuesday it would shut up to 120 stores nationwide, another blow to the billionaire investor Edward S. Lamperts dream to transform the beleaguered retailer.

title: The Get | Oscar de la Renta Headphones
description: In one of the seasons coolest (or coziest, depending how you look at it) collaborations, these fox fur headphones from Beats by Oscar de la Renta combine the designers love of music with the fluffy earmuffs seen in his most recent holiday collection. Frivolous? Maybe. Fabulous? Beyond.

title: Hand to God to Return for 8 Weeks, Possibly Longer
description: The creators of Hand to God, a well-reviewed, recently shuttered Off-Broadway production that revolves around a demonic sock puppet, are in talks with several producers about a possible commercial run of the play in New York, according to people involved in those discussions. Meanwhile, the head of the nonprofit theater where Hand to God ran this fall disclosed that it would return there for an eight-week encore this winter.

title: Iran Threatens to Block Oil Shipments, as U.S. Prepares Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Iranian official on Tuesday delivered a sharp threat in response to economic sanctions being readied by the United States, saying his country would retaliate against any crackdown by blocking all oil shipments through the Strait of Hormuz, a vital artery for transporting about one-fifth of the worlds oil supply.

title: In New Hampshire, Romney Saves His Attacks for Obama
description: LONDONDERRY, N.H.  As attention turns to Iowas caucuses, Mitt Romney scheduled two stops in New Hampshire on Tuesday morning, reaching out to voters in a state where he is considered the front-runner before heading off to Iowa later in the day.

title: Adult, Autistic and in Love
description: Parents of children on the spectrum spend more time than many parents worrying about what lies in their childrens future. We all worry about jobs, economics, relationships, education  but parents of children with autism worry about those things on a more basic level. For many, its not will my child get a good job but will my child be able to hold any job? Not will my child have a happy relationship but is there any kind of romantic partnership in my childs future?

title: More of Your Best Meals of 2011
description: Readers continue to tweet their best meals of the year, with a few themes emerging: eye-opening meals encountered on vacation in Italy and Spain, pizza places through the continental United States, and several nods to restaurants like Per Se and Eleven Madison Park (our critics agree).

title: Pew Feature Illustrates Banks Transaction Infractions
description: An arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts have been gaining some traction with its campaign to get banks to disclose fees associated with checking accounts in clear, simple language. One bank practice that Pew thinks is especially important for banks to clearly explain is the order in which they process transactions, which can affect the number of fees you pay if you overdraw your account.

title: Street Style: Winter Hats
description: The best of readers street style for the week of Dec. 19.

title: AMCs Hell on Wheels Will Keep Rolling for Second Season
description: Though Hell on Wheels may not match the ratings-increasing power provided by the undead hordes of its AMC sibling The Walking Dead, its own shambolically attired characters will be back for a second season, the cable channel announced on Tuesday.

title: Warming Up Short Days and Long Nights in Iceland
description: It was pitch black at 8:30 a.m. on a frigid Icelandic morning, but at least there was no snow falling. Though cloud cover the night before had scuttled my chance to see the Northern Lights, my plan for a 36-hour road trip from Reykjavik, ending a great four days in Iceland, was in full effect.

title: Leaders of Arctic Methane Project Clarify Climate Concerns
description: Dec. 29, 9:28 a.m. | Updated below |Ive been in touch withNatalia ShakhovaandIgor Semiletov, the intrepid Russian researchers, based at the International Arctic Research Center in Fairbanks, Alaska, who for more than a decade have been leadingan important international projectanalyzing methane plumes rising from the seabed in the shallow Arctic waters spreading north from eastern Siberian shores. (Heresvideo of Shakhovadescribing the methane releases and their work.)

title: TimesCast | December 27, 2011
description: The Timess Baghdad bureau chief, Tim Arango, looks back at the year in Iraq | Steven Erlanger reports from Paris on the challenges for the euro in 2011.

title: Slicing Costs, and Still Serving
description: You see them all across the country, in shopping malls and street corners, suburban towns and city centers: zombie restaurants.

title: House Freshmen Set Voting Record
description: House freshmen, including those elected in special elections in 2011, on average missed the fewest votes of any class of first-year lawmakers since at least 1990, the earliest that the House of Representatives published electronic voting data.

title: Video Shows Observers in Syrian City as Protests Swell
description: Updated | 5:43 p.m. As our colleague Kareem Fahim reports, Syrian forces cleared tanks from areas of Homs, residents said, as Arab League observers arrived on Tuesday to monitor pledges by the government to end the violence that has gripped the restive city.

title: Pro-Gingrich Group Kicks Off Ad Campaign
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa  Newt Gingrich has been aggressively outspent by rivals on television and radio ads that have done serious damage to his standing in polls, especially here in Iowa. But a new independent super PAC supporting Mr. Gingrich plans to spend more than $1 million in the next seven days on TV, radio and digital spots, most in Iowa ahead of the Jan. 3 caucuses.

title: The Party Continues, but Those Who Know Are Already There
description: LOS ANGELES  Getting to this party took commitment. The chosen had to R.S.V.P. early to get on the guest list but were not told where they were going. The address came later, by e-mail: Be at a dimly lighted parking lot just east of the Los Angeles River at 1 a.m. They lined up at a corrugated steel fence, shivering in their furs and leather jackets on the chilly December night.

title: Why Nobody Will Play Nice With Windows Phone 7
description: Microsofts Windows Phone 7 software has a unique, modern design that many say is superior to Androids more rugged, computery look. But a former Microsoft employee says looks alone are not enough to make Windows Phone succeed.

title: Nebraska Senator Wont Run Again
description: 8:24 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

title: New Hope for Multiple Sclerosis Patients
description: After decades of slow progress, the range of treatments for multiple sclerosis may now be on the verge of a turning point. As Laurie Tarkan explains in todays Science Times, patients now have several promising new drug options to help them ease symptoms of the disease:

title: Update: Lok Sabha Passes Lokpal
description: The lower house of Parliament made speedy work of the Lokpal Bill, voting late Tuesday night to approve it, though a second vote to give it constitutional status failed. The votes happened even as three minority parties, the Left Front, the Samajwadi Party and the Bahujan Samaj Party walked out of the discussions.

title: Safety Agency Investigating Rust Problems on G.M. and Ford Vans
description: Owners complaining of what they saw as rust-related safety problems have prompted the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to open separate investigations into vans made by General Motors and Ford.

title: Obama to Nominate Two for Vacancies on Fed Board
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that he would nominate Jeremy C. Stein, a Harvard economist, and Jerome H. Powell, a former private equity executive, to fill the two vacant seats on the Federal Reserves board.

title: Dunderdon Workshop: Winters Reality Check
description: I DONT do winter. Not that I leave town, mind you, but I try to dress in February as I do in October or April, maybe hiding a layer or three. No cold snap can freeze my mind to the point where I feel like bundling up beyond all shape recognition. Bulk bad. Slim good.

title: Fatal House Fire Linked to Embers Discarded From Fireplace
description: The deadly fire that roared through a stately Victorian home in Connecticut near the water early Christmas morning has been tinged with heart-wrenching details.

title: More on the Nursing Home Exodus
description: The intensifying federal effort to move people out of nursing homes and into the community has brought both consternation and applause among readers here.

title: The Worst C.E.O.s of 2011
description: Sydney Finkelstein is a professor of strategy and leadership at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College and the author of the bestselling book Why Smart Executives Fail.

title: Deals Appear to Avert Nurses Strikes at Two Hospital Centers
description: 9:38 p.m. | Updated A nursing strike has been averted at two of Manhattans busiest hospital centers, as union and hospital negotiators reached tentative deals over pay and benefits, officials involved in the talks said Tuesday.

title: Toyota Introduces Compact Hybrid to Japanese Market
description: On Monday, the Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a compact gasoline/electric hybrid vehicle for its home market. The car, which will be sold as the Toyota Aqua in Japan, was introduced at a Tokyo news conference and will eventually be available in other markets, including the United States, as the Prius C.

title: Cuban Free Agent Is Next Hot Commodity
description: Now that the Texas Rangers have won the right to negotiate with the Japanese pitching phenom Yu Darvish, Major League Baseball has turned its attention to Yoennis Cespedes, a captivating Cuban outfielder with a running backs body whom scouts have been following for years.

title: Middle childhood, censoring bad news on avian flu and the science behind a character in the movie Hugo.
description: Middle childhood, censoring bad news on avian flu and the science behind a character in the movie Hugo.

title: Sorghum Speaks With a Sweet Drawl
description: ATLANTA

title: Sam Rivers, Jazz Artist of Loft Scene, Dies at 88
description: Sam Rivers, an inexhaustibly creative saxophonist, flutist, bandleader and composer who cut his own decisive path through the jazz world, spearheading the 1970s loft scene in New York and later establishing a rugged outpost in Florida, died on Monday in Orlando, Fla. He was 88.

title: The Defeatism of Depression
description: A number of people have asked me to weigh in on David Brookss piece today. Sorry, not gonna do a tit-for-tat. Let me instead just make a more general point.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: In Motion
description: Andrea Mohins 1011 Dance photos

title: Univision Finds Ratings Success
description: Against a full slate of repeats on the big four broadcast networks, the Spanish-language network Univision emerged as the highest-rated channel in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic on Monday night, according to Nielsen data. The two-hour finale of the telenovela La Fuerza del Destino (The Strength of Destiny) averaged 5.4 million total viewers and trailed only a repeat of Two and a Half Men on CBS in the 18-to-49 category. Elsewhere, NBCs new quiz show Whos Still Standing? continued to pull in respectable numbers with its highest viewership total, 6.9 million.

title: Santorum Takes Aim at Paul in Iowa
description: MASON CITY, Iowa  Rick Santorum urged voters in Iowa on Tuesday to think for themselves and not jump on the Republican bandwagon that suggests only a certain few of the partys presidential candidates could defeat President Obama.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Well All Scream

title: 2011: Year in Iraq
description: The Timess Baghdad bureau chief, Tim Arango, examines the year in Iraq.

title: Two New Jersey Democrats to Face Each Other
description: Get ready for some Democrat-on-Democrat infighting in New Jersey. Representative Steve Rothman, a Democrat whose 9th District has been upended by redistricting, will face off against a fellow Democrat, Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., who currently represents the states 8th District.

title: Wheelies: Having Cars on the Mind
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: New Yorkers Life Expectancy Reaches 80.6 Years, Higher Than National Rate
description: The life expectancy for babies born in New York City reached 80.6 years in 2009, the highest level recorded and one that surpasses the national life expectancy rate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday.

title: 2011: Year for the Euro
description: Steven Erlanger evaluates the year for the European Unions debt crisis.

title: In Eugene, They Love a Fashion Statement
description: EUGENE, Ore.  The Rose Bowl uniforms for the University of Oregon were revealed Tuesday by Nike.

title: Bachmann and Perry Make Final Appeal to Social Conservatives
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  Michele Bachmann on Tuesday accused her Republican rivals of being confused about abortion and gay marriage as she sought to make a final appeal to social conservatives in Iowa before the Iowa caucuses next week.

title: Mobile App Downloads Set Records on Christmas
description: While some customers couldnt rely on Best Buy to deliver their goods on time for the holidays, mobile app stores didnt disappoint. Christmas day downloads of Apple iOS and Android apps more than doubled compared to years past, shattering records, according to a report.

title: Ten of the Best Inexpensive Restaurants of 2011
description: Here are 10 of the best restaurants of the year from $25 and Under and the Dining Briefs:

title: Ten of the Best Inexpensive Restaurants of 2011
description: Best Pizza in Williamsburg, Agua Fresca in East Harlem and other standout restaurants from $25 and Under and the Dining Briefs.

title: A Drum Mecca Prepares to Close Up Shop
description: For years Drummers World on West 46th Street was a destination for percussionists of all stripes. Numerous jazz drummers made trips there. Roadies for famous touring bands stopped by. People involved with Broadway productions bought instruments. Even members of symphony orchestras traveled to the shop to find equipment.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, India, China and Iowa.

title: Sports Replay: Dec.27
description: Hockey and soccer and other sports from around the world on Tuesday.

title: For Wall Street Deal Makers, Sometimes It Pays to Be Bad
description: Instead of awarding Fs for the worst deals and deal-making of the year, I am going to focus on two of the years biggest buyouts. The first: J.Crews $3 billion buyout by its chief executive, Millard S. Drexler, and the private equity firms TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners. The second: Del Monte Foods $5.3 billion acquisition by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, Vestar Capital Partners and Centerview Capital.

title: Our Top Ten Photo Books of 2011
description: It was not unlike a political caucus. The candidates  in this case, nearly 100 photography books published this year  took over every inch of available counter space in the photo department, where they were carefully scrutinized by a group of opinionated voters, each of whom was given just 10 Post-it notes as ballots. Impassioned speeches were made. Votes were cast: a few books grew polychromatic bouquets of Post-its  each voter had his or her own individual color  while others sprouted single lonely Post-its. Votes were changed: worthy candidates, including the likes of Diana Vreeland and Gerhard Richter, were abandoned. Finally, after weeks, a group of winners emerged. Like all campaigns, it was brutal. Here are the 10 victors, in no particular order.

title: Occupy the Caucus Is Ready to Go in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  As the Republican presidential candidates make their final pleas to voters across Iowa, a local offshoot of the Occupy Wall Street protests here has traded in tents for its own campaign office.

title: Knicks Claim Former Harvard Guard Off Waivers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Jeremy Lin, a Harvard-educated point guard and N.B.A. summer-league sensation, is joining the Knicks. His stay may be short.

title: Could Chicken Be the New Monkey Someday?
description: When the Wildlife Conservation Society set out to study bush meat consumption in Gabon, researchers reluctantly had to rule out some sites. Especially in the rainy season, it became hard to gain access to some rural communities. Washed-out roads grounded trucks in the muck, and precarious mountain passes were in some cases too risky to navigate.

title: Holiday Spirit Doesnt Extend to Serious-Themed Shows on Broadway
description: Ticket sales for serious-minded Broadway shows were akin to a lump of coal last week during the run-up to the Christmas holiday, according to an analysis of weekly show grosses released on Tuesday.

title: With Essays on Democracy, Chinese Blogger Stirs Debate Among Reformers
description: A popular writer, race-car driver and heartthrob stirred intense debate this week in China with three short political essays that drew fire from democracy advocates, including the dissident artist Ai Weiwei, while appearing to hearten the Chinese authorities.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, India, China and Iowa.

title: Ways to Get Guests to Say, Ooooh!
description: Modest luxuries add panache to holiday entertaining. Guests will not miss the caviar if you garnish and season canaps, desserts, ceviche and even drinks with Cocktail Pearls, glistening globules of flavor and color about the size of salmon roe. The pearls are made with fruit pulp treated with xanthan gum and sodium alginate, those essentials of the molecular pantry. So, no surprise, they are from Spain. Versions in strawberry, apple-ginger and lemon-lime add bright sweetness. Shallot-vinegar, lemon-pepper and chile are sharp and tangy.

title: When the Familys Foodies Visit New York
description: IF its Tuesday, this must be Jean Georges, and the end must be nigh.

title: Iraq in 2011: Troop Departures and Power Struggles
description: For Iraqis and Americans, 2011 was marked by the issue of whether the United States military would stay or leave. In Tuesdays TimesCast, The Timess Baghdad bureau chief, Tim Arango, looks back at the process of deciding that question, and at other news from the year in Iraq.

title: Tremont
description: 51 Bank Street (West Fourth Street); (212) 488-1019, tremontnyc.com

title: Whitehall Bar and Kitchen
description: 19 Greenwich Avenue (West 10th Street); (212) 675-7261; whitehall-nyc.com

title: Times Co. Agrees to Sell Regional Newspaper Group
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated The New York Times Company announced on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to sell the companys Regional Media Group to Halifax Media Holdings, of Daytona Beach, Fla., for $143 million in cash.

title: A Year of Acquired Tastes
description: NO doubt about it, Ive had the privilege of drinking some spectacular wines in 2011. Most astounding of all was a summer evening that I spent with the sort of great old Burgundies that I never imagined I would see in the first place and that I never expect to drink again.

title: A Brooklyn Girl Whos Just Not Frilly
description: Dont be put off by the harsh title of Pariah, the stirring coming-out story of a virginal 17-year-old African-American lesbian living in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. The teenager, Alike (pronounced ah-LEE-kay), dresses like a boy when out of her parents sight and endures a fair share of barbed, homophobic remarks, but she is not viciously persecuted.

title: Southern Farmers Vanquish the Clichs
description: ST. MATTHEWS, S.C.

title: Italy to Play U.S. in February, Italian Coach Says
description: The United States national team will face Italy in an exhibition game in February, according to Italy Coach Cesare Prandelli.

title: Shlomi Reuveni
description: Mr. Reuveni, 44, is the senior managing director of Brown Harris Stevens Select, a luxury new development marketing group that he helped establish in 2007. Before joining Brown Harris Stevens, Mr. Reuveni was a broker for the Corcoran Group for about 12 years. He began brokering deals as a teenager.

title: If Cave Men Told Jokes, Would Humans Laugh?
description: You may think you know someone who thinks like a Neanderthal. You may even think you know someone who is a Neanderthal, or at least part one. Chances are youre right about both. Websters definition of Neanderthal is unflattering: suggesting a cave man in appearance or behavior. (The definition of cave man: One who acts in a rough primitive manner, esp. toward women.)

title: Life Expectancy Rises for New Yorkers
description: Want to add years to your life? Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a suggestion: Move to New York City.

title: Shifts in Health Care Delivery Stimulate a String of Property Deals
description: MedRite Urgent Care has a bustling office on Second Avenue and 49th Street, packed with professionals in suits rushing to have their blood drawn between meetings and neighborhood residents who like the convenience. The clinic, which provides checkups, drug testing and other primary and urgent medical care for walk-in patients, opened in February.

title: Reviewing Mas (la grillade)
description: A couple of years ago while traveling in Spain I had two life-changing meals. One was at El Bulli, a restaurant some of you may have heard of, which no longer exists. The other was at Asador Etxebarri, in the little Basque town of Axpe, about as far from El Bulli in spirit as you can journey.

title: The Power of Smoke and Flame
description: WOOD, fire, smoke and flesh. It doesnt get any simpler, more elemental or more prehistoric than this fundamental equation.

title: South Florida Poised for Birth of Casino Gambling
description: MIAMI  When the Florida Legislature returns from its holiday recess, it will consider a bill to allow three Las Vegas-style casino resorts to be built in the southern part of the state. Lobbyists for the gambling industry have swarmed Tallahassee, trying to ensure that the bill passes.

title: Sources of Debris in Artificial Hips
description: Data from orthopedic registries in England and Australia shows that standard all-metal replacement hips are failing at rates two to three times greater than ones made of metal and plastic. Metal wear is the principal culprit. But researchers say such wear can happen in differing ways that can contribute to the early failure of various hip models.

title: Change Remains a Constant in Nutcracker
description: Despite cast changes, Act I of The Nutcracker is more or less the same at every performance. Because of cast changes, Act II is almost never the same. If you attend several Nutcracker shows a season, you go to see the cast changes in Act II. And yet it is Act I that is the more miraculous: Tchaikovskys score, permitting only two or three tiny breaks for applause before intermission, is constantly on the move, answering the scale and subject of the story with a fluency that breaks the mold of 19th-century ballet.

title: Questions About Motives Behind Stratfor Hack
description: When hackers used the Christmas holiday to attack Stratfor, a security group based in Austin, Tex., they initially said they were aiming to steal the credit card numbers of its clients and use them to make $1 million in donations to charity.

title: Gingrich Strikes Economic Themes in Hitting Romney
description: DYERSVILLE, Iowa  Newt Gingrich introduced a new theme to his sharpening contrast to Mitt Romney: that he was a founder of supply-side economics that brought the country prosperity under Ronald Reagan and can do so again  but not if Mr. Romney is the nominee.

title: Bound for Local Glory at Last
description: TULSA, Okla.  Oklahoma has always had a troubled relationship with her native son Woody Guthrie. The communist sympathies of Americas balladeer infuriated local detractors. In 1999 a wealthy donors objections forced the Cowboy Museum in Oklahoma City to cancel a planned exhibition on Guthrie organized by the Smithsonian Institution. It wasnt until 2006, nearly four decades after his death, that the Oklahoma Hall of Fame got around to adding him to its ranks.

title: A Crude, Rude Christmas Tale
description: When it comes to Christmas movies, the French prefer naughty over nice any day. Le Pre Nol Est une Ordure (whose literal translation would make George Bailey blush, so Santa Stinks will have to do), a much-loved 1982 farce finally having its American theatrical premiere at the Museum of Modern Art, is a fine example. Crude, rude and with more foul language than a Gordon Ramsay marathon, this smutty staple could give even the most hardened Francophobe a few guilty giggles.

title: A Thug Talks and Talks, and Scribbles
description: In a nondescript motel room somewhere along the border between Mexico and the United States, a former hit man  a sicario  for the Mexican drug cartels speaks. Unquestioned and uninterrupted, this black-garbed thug regales us with 20 years worth of kidnapping, torture and cold-blooded murder, all the while scribbling compulsively in a large notebook.

title: Mitt Romneys New Hampshire Stump Speech
description: Mitt Romneys full New Hampshire speech.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Touch Screens and Floating Incubators
description: Interesting things that Bits reporters and editors found on the Web. More here.

title: Pro-Romney Group Makes Post-Iowa Ad Buy
description: Even if Newt Gingrich, a former House speaker, pulls out a victory in the Iowa caucuses next week, Restore Our Future will be waiting.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,840 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: In Lawsuit, Perry Challenges His Exclusion From Virginia Ballot
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas filed a federal lawsuit on Tuesday challenging his exclusion from the Republican primary ballot in Virginia, a state known for having some of the most restrictive ballot access rules in the country.

title: Two Artists Who Embraced Freedom
description: It is strange that the sculptor John Chamberlain and the painter Helen Frankenthaler should have died within a week of each other  he on Dec. 21, and she on Tuesday  considering that they occupy such similar positions within the history of American art. Both emerged in the 1950s and provided crucial links between art styles, specifically helping to forge the transition from Abstract Expressionism to what lay beyond.

title: Bettye Danoff, Founding Member of L.P.G.A., Dies at 88
description: Bettye Danoff, one of 13 founding members of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, which began as a hardy, poorly paid band of women who traveled the country for the chance to play the game, died on Thursday in McKinney, Tex. She was 88.

title: Making Themselves Heard in a Changed Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  The day after a lumbering line of whooping, high-fiving American soldiers drove out of Iraq and into history, the 30 million Iraqis they left behind woke to a bright cold day filled with echoes of nearly nine years of war.

title: Karzai Agrees to Let Taliban Set Up Office in Qatar
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After prodding by his American and European backers, President Hamid Karzai dropped his opposition to allowing the Taliban to set up an office in the Persian Gulf state of Qatar, saying on Tuesday that he could abide by such a step if it was what the United States wanted.

title: Battling Anew Over the Place of Religion in Public Schools
description: JEFFERSON, S.C.  It has been nearly 50 years since the Supreme Court ruled that officially sponsored prayer in public schools violated the separation of church and state.

title: Nelson to Quit the Senate, Giving G.O.P. an Advantage
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Ben Nelson, the embattled two-term Democrat from Nebraska, said Tuesday that he would not seek re-election in 2012, giving Republicans a decided advantage in their drive to win his Senate seat and a leg up in their effort to bring the Senate under Republican control.

title: Crowded Sidelines Leave Coaches Nowhere to Run
description: Marv Levy can vividly recall the play some 40 years later: a sweep to the right, Bears linebacker Dick Butkus running full speed toward the sideline, then Levy landing on his back. The feared Butkus had bowled over Levy, then an assistant coach just starting his career in the N.F.L., when his momentum carried him out of bounds. It became one of Levys favorite war stories.

title: State Threatens to Pull Millions for Schools in the City and Elsewhere
description: New York States education commissioner threatened on Tuesday to withhold tens of millions of dollars in federal grants to struggling schools in New York City and nine other districts statewide if they do not prove by Saturday that they will carry out new evaluation systems for teachers and principals.

title: Work Habits, Once Questioned, Are a Key to Newtons Success
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Fake smile. Selfish. The next JaMarcus Russell.

title: Enticing Doctors to Endorse a Weight-Loss Program
description: WHEN Medicare announced in November that it would begin paying for obese patients to undergo physician-supervised treatment for weight loss, it was welcome news to the Center for Medical Weight Loss, a company offering an obesity program adopted by doctors throughout the country.

title: Finding Hospice Care for the Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: Spinoffs Become a Favored Strategy
description: In corporate finance, this will go down as the year of the spinoff. Activity is on pace to hit $230 billion, which is six times last years total and approaching a whopping 8 percent of global deal activity, according to Citigroup. With rocky economic conditions unlikely to give executives much reason to go shopping, 2012 could bring still more splits.

title: Rapes on the Rise in Somalia
description: This year, tens of thousands in Somalia have died from famine, with countless others cut down in relentless combat. Now Somalis face yet another widespread terror: an alarming increase in rapes and sexual abuse of women and girls.

title: Perry Changes Position on Exceptions for Abortion
description: OSCEOLA, Iowa  Gov. Rick Perry said Tuesday that he had undergone a transformation on the issue of abortion and now believed that there should be no exceptions made for rape, incest or the life of the mother.

title: Despite Warning, Dickey Readies for Climb
description: Pitcher R. A. Dickey is leaving next Tuesday for a climb of Mount Kilimanjaro despite the Mets request that he not make the trip, which is designed to benefit a charity that helps poor and desperate people in Mumbai, India.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Time for a Third Party?
description: To the Editor:

title: Madrid Joins Cities Replacing Concrete With Greenery
description: I have to make note of the fascinating article by Michael Kimmelman in The Times describing Madrids ambitious reinvention of what Kimmelman describes as a crippling gash of aging riverside highway lanes as a green swath that one resident calls new lungs. (The video above, produced by the city, provides background on the project.)

title: Beginning Iowa Push, Romney Focuses on Obama
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa  Kicking off a three-day bus tour through Iowa, where he is making an aggressive push before next weeks caucuses, Mitt Romney on Tuesday offered a sharp contrast between himself and President Obama while not even mentioning his rivals for the Republican nomination.

title: Eliminating Deadly Viruses
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety at Indian Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Hit by Injuries, Knicks Add Former Harvard Guard
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  On the third dizzying day of this most unusual season, the Knicks added a player, rushed through a practice and boarded a cross-country flight, to play three games in four nights, in their only visit to the Pacific time zone.

title: Bacteria 1, F.D.A. 0
description: Earlier this month, the Maine-based grocery chain Hannaford issued a ground beef recall after at least 14 people were infected with an antibiotic-resistant strain of salmonella. Chances are this is the first youve heard of it. After all, its not much compared to the 76 illnesses and one death back in August that led Cargill to recall almost 36 million pounds of ground turkey products potentially contaminated with drug-resistant salmonella. The particulars get confusing, but the trend is unmistakable: our meat supply is frequently contaminated with bacteria that cant readily be treated by antibiotics.

title: Helen Frankenthaler Dies at 83
description: Helen Frankenthaler, the lyrically abstract painter who became one of the most admired artists of her generation, died on Tuesday at her home in Darien, Conn. She was 83.

title: Contemplating Official Mercy: No Small Task
description: As Andrew M. Cuomo comes to the end of his first year as governor, its a moment to remember that he has yet to exercise one power that does not require him to argue with Sheldon Silver in the State Assembly, haggle with Dean G. Skelos in the Senate, box with Michael R. Bloomberg in City Hall or fence with the public employee unions.

title: Courtroom Chaos
description: To the Editor:

title: A Friendlier Romney in New Hampshire
description: At coffee shops and veterans halls, on sidewalks and factory tours, the reworked version of Mitt Romney, it turns out, is not all that different from the original.

title: The Retooled, Loose Romney, Guessing Voters Age and Ethnicity
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa  When Mitt Romney introduces himself to voters, he has a peculiar habit of guessing their age or nationality, often incorrectly. (A regular query: Are you French Canadian?)

title: With Gas Drilling Next Door, County in New York Gets an Economic Lift
description: HORSEHEADS, N.Y.  At the Glamour and Glow boutique in the local mall here, crystal necklaces and fake fur vests have been hot-ticket items the last year.

title: Obama to Ask for $1.2 Trillion Increase in Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will ask Congress this week for $1.2 trillion in additional borrowing authority, which would raise the federal debt limit to $16.4 trillion and avoid the need for further increases before the 2012 elections, administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Juggling a Long Commute and 2 Children With Disabilities
description: Late one afternoon, Marlene Minto sat her two children down at the dining table and stood over them as they began their homework. A nurses assistant, she still had on her scrubs, with her ID card hanging from a green clip shaped like a frog. It was early into what she could call her second shift.

title: Lottery Numbers
Republican Rivals Unleash Broadside on Paul in Iowa
description: MASON CITY, Iowa  The Republican presidential candidates sharpened their criticism of Representative Ron Paul on Tuesday in an effort to keep his support from growing among voters who are frustrated with government and may be inclined to send a message to the Washington establishment by supporting him in the Iowa caucuses.

title: For Somali Women, Pain of Being a Spoil of War
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The girls voice dropped to a hush as she remembered the bright, sunny afternoon when she stepped out of her hut and saw her best friend buried in the sand, up to her neck.

title: The High Cost of Failing Artificial Hips
description: The most widespread medical implant failure in decades  involving thousands of all-metal artificial hips that need to be replaced prematurely  has entered the money phase.

title: Ask About Hip Replacement
description: In The High Price of Failing Artificial Hips, New York Times reporter Barry Meier examines the economic cost of the most widespread medical device disaster in decades, the premature failure of all-metal replacement hips:

title: A Snapshot of the Race for the Senate
description: The electoral implications of the impending retirement of Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska are fairly obvious. This is bad news for Democrats, who were already going to have a difficult time holding on to their narrow 53-47 advantage in the upper chamber.

title: Appealing to Evangelicals, Hopefuls Pack Religion Into Ads
description: DES MOINES  There is Rick Perry, a stained-glass window and a large illuminated cross over his right shoulder, looking more preacher than politician. An aerial shot of a soaring church steeple zooms into focus a few seconds later. Then  blink and youll miss it  a picture of Mr. Perry, the Texas governor, with his arm around Mike Huckabee flashes on the screen.

title: Kevin Warns Republicans
description: WASHINGTON

title: Sports Replay: Dec. 26
description: The day in sports, including the world junior mens hockey championships in Canada and soccer action in the English Premier League.

title: S.E.C. Wins Delay in Citigroup Fraud Case
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court granted an emergency ruling late Tuesday that temporarily halted proceedings in the Securities and Exchange Commissions case against Citigroup. The decision will allow the court to consider an appeal of a lower courts decision to throw out a $285 million fraud settlement between the commission and Citigroup.

title: Corrections: December 28
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Miami Beckons, and Brazilians Come Running With Cash
description: In Miami, no group has been as courted and pampered as much as the Brazilians.

title: Miami Has a Hearty Oi (Hello) for Free-Spending Brazilians
description: MIAMI  Even in a city that has embraced so many waves of Latinos that it is jokingly referred to as the only South American capital in North America, no one group has been as courted and pampered as the Brazilians.

title: Silence of the Lambs, Bambi and Forrest Gump Added to National Film Registry
description: Hannibal Lecter is going away for a long time  and so are Bambi, Forrest Gump and the adorable moppet played by Jackie Coogan in a classic Charlie Chaplin feature: the movies featuring these characters are among the 25 works that have been added to the National Film Registry, the Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday.

title: Wednesday: Go Head to Head
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  If youve ever been a victim of identity theft, you know theres nothing funny about it. Peoples credit and entire lives have been ruined by this crime, so I was a little concerned about the potential reaction to the theme of this puzzle. On the other hand, its just a crossword puzzle, and just another deletion theme, so lets talk about it from that perspective.

title: Israeli Girl, 8, at Center of Tension Over Religious Extremism
description: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel  The latest battleground in Israels struggle over religious extremism covers little more than a square mile of this Jewish city situated between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, and it has the unexpected public face of a blond, bespectacled second-grade girl.

title: After Weak Holiday, Sears to Shut 120 Stores
description: Christmas was anything but merry for Sears Holdings.

title: CarMax Accused of Failing to Disclose Aspects of Cars History
description: A Maryland judge is being asked to find CarMax, the automotive retailer, in contempt of court for failing to abide by a 2008 class-action settlement. That settlement required that consumers be given a clear warning when a used vehicle offered for sale was once in a rental fleet.

title: How to Save Iraq From Civil War
description: Baghdad

title: Rick Perry on Abortion
description: Dec. 27, 2011 - Responding to a questioner at a town hall meeting in Iowa, Texas Governor Rick Perry said he has undergone a 'transformation' on the issue of abortion.

title: Online Merchants Home In on Imbibing Consumers
description: After enjoying a few drinks, some people go dancing. Others order food. And for some, its time to shop online.

title: For the Herds Sake, Vaccinate
description: West Hartford, Conn.

title: Honoring All Who Saved Jews
description: IN December 1942, when I was 13 years old, German troops occupied my hometown. Within days, our house was commandeered as an officers mess hall. I soon had a yellow star on my dress, setting me apart from many of my childhood friends. The men of our family were ordered into forced labor. My happy life had vanished.

title: Court in Egypt Says Rights of Women Were Violated
description: CAIRO  An administrative court ruled Tuesday that the Egyptian military had wrongly violated the human rights of female demonstrators by subjecting them to virginity tests intended to humiliate them.

title: Nets and Fans Silenced in Home Opener
description: The Nets have won more than 50 games only once during their tenure in New Jersey. A 106-70 loss in their final home opener before their move to Brooklyn reminded fans why.

title: An Operator of Group Homes Keeps State Aid Despite Faults
description: The state has had plenty of reasons over the years to end its relationship with the Federation of Multicultural Programs of Brooklyn.

title: Disparities in an Oil Boomtown
description: An oil boom has caused money to to flow by the barrelful into Mountrail County in North Dakota, transforming a sleepy community once proudly situated in the middle of nowhere into an unexpected oasis of prosperity.

title: A Great Divide Over Oil Riches
description: STANLEY, N.D.  Just like everybody else around here, Fred Evans spent his life coaxing a good enough living out of the earth. He grew wheat, ran cattle and, during a couple of short-lived bursts of activity, worked on the drill rigs searching for oil across the northern prairie.

title: Where a Qaddafi Son Once Played, Ex-Rebels Wait and Wonder
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Sometimes the young fighters gather under a date palm next to the empty swimming pool to joke and strum the guitar. When it rains, they retreat indoors to play foosball in an improvised game room inside their favorite hangout, a ransacked house where one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis sons once lived and entertained.

title: Mr. Pauls Discredited Campaign
description: Ron Paul long ago disqualified himself for the presidency by peddling claptrap proposals like abolishing the Federal Reserve, returning to the gold standard, cutting a third of the federal budget and all foreign aid and opposing the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: Wall Street Meets Reality
description: Wall Street reported nearly $3 billion in losses in the third quarter of 2011, reducing profits through September to $9.6 billion, which was well below forecasts, according to a recent analysis by the New York State comptroller. The comptroller estimates that Wall Street banks and smaller brokerages may cut some 10,000 jobs in New York City by the end of 2012.

title: Giving Yemen a Chance
description: The Obama administration is reportedly preparing to admit President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen into the United States for medical treatment. It is not an easy call. But admitting Mr. Saleh, under strict conditions, offers the best hope for speeding his exit from power and ending the repression that has cost hundreds of Yemeni lives.

title: Cancer Found in President of Argentina
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina has thyroid cancer and will undergo surgery on Jan. 4 before taking a three-week absence from office, her spokesman said Tuesday in a televised address.

title: The Grand Game of Getting to Work
description: Eight-thirty in the morning and the subway is full. Straphangers  strapless for years now  brace themselves against stainless steel poles and overhead rails and almost half the heads on the train are bent, pewlike, over small electronic devices. You can tell who is reading and who is not by the use they make of their thumbs. (This is a grand era for thumbs.) The ones who are thumbing might be scrolling or texting or even writing an e-mail message. But many of them are gaming their way to work.

title: Joining Trend, College Grows Beyond Name
description: After a century firmly anchored in Boston, Northeastern University is branching out  becoming Southeastern, Northwestern and perhaps Western and Midwestern as well.

title: What Do Iowans Want in a Candidate?
Getting It Right
description: Dissatisfaction and disappointment have pervaded the Republican presidential campaign. Pundits pining for a game-changing candidate have been repeatedly let down, and voters have pinballed from one unsatisfactory option to another, with infatuation giving way to disillusionment every time.

title: An Uneven Oil Boom in North Dakota
description: As some North Dakota residents cash oil royalty checks worth tens of thousands of dollars a month or more, many of their neighbors are resigned to receiving almost nothing.

title: The Year in Fitness
description: If all the Phys Ed columns published this year have a single message, it is that now is a fine time to own a body. The diverse exercise-related experiments published in 2011 and covered in this space each week suggest that its possible to retain your cognitive powers, muscle mass, running speed and waistline, even as you age, and that a little exercise can go a long way in terms of physiological benefit. Recent, important science even tells us that coffee, chocolate and beer enhance exercise performance, which is fortunate, since I have no plans to give up any of those. As most of us prepare our exercise resolutions for 2012, now seems an ideal time to review the past year in fitness science and the lessons it contained, both encouraging and cautionary.

title: A Provider With Problems
description: The Federation of Multicultural Programs was cited for failing to meet federal health and safety standards more than any other provider in New York State.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/28/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/28/2011

title: North Korean Mourners Line Streets for Kim Jong-ils Funeral
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Jong-un, the designated dynastic heir in North Korea, walked alongside the hearse carrying the body of his father, Kim Jong-il, through snow-covered downtown Pyongyang on Wednesday, leading a state funeral that provided early glimpses of who is serving as guardians of the young, untested leader.

title: As It Is Focus of Bhagavad Gita Trial
description: The Bhagavad Gita was first translated into Russian in 1788, but if a court in the Siberian city of Tomsk rules against it this week, one version of the ancient Hindu text will be added to Russias 1,057-item list of banned material deemed extremist.

title: What Will Team Anna Do Now?
description: The Lokpals quick passage on Tuesday through the Lok Sabha, or lower house of Parliament, leaves anti-corruption activist Anna Hazares camp in a dilemma.

title: Syrias Defecting Bloggers
description: Above, The Timess news report on the bombing in Damascus.

title: Will China Outsmart the U.S.?
description: Three months before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Angus Echols, a member of DuPonts executive committee, began shaping the chemical giants plans for the coming decade. The U.S. would soon be at war, he explained in a series of memos and high-level discussions, and the company needed to aid the effort. But it also needed to think far ahead. When the war ended, Echols argued, women would want to buy cheap stockings. And where was DuPont on this crucial matter?

title: Newt Gingrichs Glory Days
description: It was just after dawn in Coralville, Iowa, the week before Christmas, and I asked the young waitress at the hotel restaurant if she would kindly direct Newt Gingrich to my table when he arrived. She looked uncertain.

title: Breathing In Music, Photographing Dance
description: Looking back at the years photos in The New York Timess digital archives, several dance images shot by Andrea Mohin jumped out at us. We asked her to choose some favorites to share  not the year in dance, but the images that moved her.

title: Tip of the Week: The Silver Screen on Your Screen
description: As the year winds down and the rest of the Oscar-contending movies hit theaters, it may take extra effort to keep up with what is playing where (and when). For serious film buffs, the Flixster add-on for Googles Chrome browser pulls in a list of all the latest releases, trailers, show times and theaters near your location, plus new movies arriving soon or on DVD.

title: Italys Borrowing Costs Plummet, Reducing Pressure
description: Italys short-term borrowing costs dropped sharply on Wednesday at an auction of government bills, easing the immediate pressure on the countrys economy.

title: Blueprint for Beating Tebow and Broncos
description: A closer look at some of the games from Week 16, with the benefit of film analysis:

title: The Biggest Cut in Unemployment Benefits
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Ringing in the New Year at Parisian Churches
description: Few holiday classical music concerts draw more devoted audiences than those that take place on New Years Eve at two of the Pariss most splendid and historic churches, LEglise St. Germain des Prs and Ste. Chapelle.

title: Mark Sanchez Speaks About Love for Jets
description: Much has been said about the Jets Mark Sanchez and Rex Ryan (and even Peyton Manning) in the last few days. Here are Sanchez and Ryan in their words:

title: Polling Gridlock in Iowa Could Produce Last-Minute Momentum
description: The most interesting thing about the latest polls in Iowa (which are the basis for our forecasts) is that they essentially show a four-way tie for third place among the Republican presidential contenders, with Newt Gingrich, Michele Bachmann, Rick Santorum and Rick Perry all projected to receive between 11 and 14 percent of the vote.

title: Jets Long-Shot Chance Is Put at 9 Percent
description: Jets fans know it doesnt look good, and were here to put a number on that feeling: According to NFL-Forecast.com, the Jets have a 9.3 percent chance of advancing to the playoffs.

title: The Best of the Boss
description: Here at Youre the Boss, we believe that most small-business owners are really good at a few things, the things that allowed them to get their businesses off the ground. Inevitably, however, most owners are unprepared for the dozens of other tasks that are essential to running a business. We hope to help with those. But we dont try to make it look easy.

title: Indian Activist Calls Off Fast but Vows to Keep Fighting
description: MUMBAI, India  A day after the lower house of the Indian Parliament passed an anticorruption law that the activist Anna Hazare has dismissed as weak, he called an early end on Wednesday to a three-day fast for health reasons.

title: In Drilling Safety Debate, Hydrofrackings Not the Only Target
description: In the heated debate over fracking in New York, it is often forgotten that conventional natural gas drilling has been taking place in the state for decades.

title: Threat of Bhagavad Gita Ban Lifted in Russia
description: RIA Novosti, Russias state-run news agency, said the Tomsk court has ruled against banning The Bhagavad Gita as it is.

title: UPDATE: For Team Anna, the Answer is Rest
description: Anti-corruption campaigner Anna Hazare, whose agitation and hunger fasts sparked a populist uprising this year and the introduction of a bill to curb government misdeeds, said Wednesday afternoon he would end his fast early and appeared to suspend plans for a Jail Bhalo or protest involving people being arrested.

title: Military to Lend $1 Billion to Bolster Egypts Currency
description: CAIRO  Egypts military rulers are lending $1 billion to the central bank to prop up the countrys flagging currency, offering evidence of both the precarious state of the economy and the militarys singular status within it.

title: Rapes on the Rise in Somalia
description: This year, tens of thousands in Somalia have died from famine, with countless others cut down in relentless combat. Now Somalis face yet another widespread terror: an alarming increase in rapes and sexual abuse of women and girls.

title: A Day With the Bridges
description: The exercise routines and diets of Janice and Adam Bridges, who have lost about 165 and 110 pounds and struggle daily to keep the weight off.

title: The Fat Trap
description: For 15 years, Joseph Proietto has been helping people lose weight. When these obese patients arrive at his weight-loss clinic in Australia, they are determined to slim down. And most of the time, he says, they do just that, sticking to the clinics program and dropping excess pounds. But then, almost without exception, the weight begins to creep back. In a matter of months or years, the entire effort has come undone, and the patient is fat again. It has always seemed strange to me, says Proietto, who is a physician at the University of Melbourne. These are people who are very motivated to lose weight, who achieve weight loss most of the time without too much trouble and yet, inevitably, gradually, they regain the weight.

title: Victor Cruz, Pro Bowl and Paterson, N.J.
description: Six points from around the Web, with an extra point from the Fifth Down:

title: What Moves Republican Crowds in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  The Republican candidates for president are doing a lot of talking in the last week before voting begins.

title: Are Polls During the Holidays Less Reliable?
description: The Iowa caucuses are six days away, and the latest polls were more than a week ago  a lifetime when opinions are so volatile. Later this week, fresh surveys of Iowan Republicans may be released, but those occurred during the holiday week, when voters are hard to reach and distracted.

title: A Parade of Sharks, Dazzling Yet Diminished
description: Cocos Island is perhaps best known for an abundance of large marine animals, sharks in particular. Most iconic of these are the vast schools of scalloped hammerhead sharks, which can be found by the hundreds at various sites in the waters around the island.

title: The Problem
description: Richard Koo has another paper on balance sheet recession out (pdf), with good charts for a number of countries. I still have some differences with him over monetary policy  I still dont understand why he doesnt see debt-eroding inflation as something helpful in dealing with debt overhang  but his view of the sources of our Lesser Depression is completely right.

title: Kim Jong-ils Funeral Procession
description: Kim Jong-ils funeral procession took place on Wednesday in Pyongyang, North Korea.

title: The Best in Womens
Unlikely Agitator, an Insider, Speaks Out Against Electoral Fraud in Russia
description: VLADIMIR, Russia  At first glance, Sergei N. Filippov seems an unlikely political provocateur.

title: Holiday Surprise: Hollywood Is at Work
description: LOS ANGELES  Gone are those glory days when everyone who was anyone in Hollywood decamped to Aspen or Kahala for the holidays, leaving a few nobodies (and some underpaid journalists) to keep the home fires burning.

title: Daily Report: Clicking Checkout While Under the Influence
description: In The New York Times on Wednesday, Stephanie Clifford reports about the phenomenon of alcohol-induced online shopping. Reliable data is scarce, but one comparison-shopping site says that nearly half the people it surveyed in Britain had shopped online after drinking. And online retailers suspect that enough shoppers buy online goods in the evening while they are drunk, or even just tipsy, that they are aiming promotions for later hours, hoping to tempt buyers after the bars close.

title: Colosseum May Be a Fixer-Upper but Its Not Collapsing, Italian Officials Say
description: ROME  Italian archaeology officials on Wednesday played down Italian news reports that chunks of masonry had been falling off the Colosseum. Nothing has collapsed at the Colosseum since the 18th century, said a statement issued by a department of the Culture Ministry responsible for Romes archaeological sites. The Colosseum, the first-century A.D. arena, is Italys most popular tourist draw.

title: Wednesday Reading: Life Expectancy for New Yorkers Reaches All-Time High
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Debt Is (Mostly) Money We Owe to Ourselves
description: I want to expand a bit on something Dean Baker said yesterday:

title: Chimpanzee Said to Be Cheetah in Tarzan Films Has Died
description: 5:03 p.m. | Updated

title: What Were Reading
description: Wine Economist: Tracking the holiday sales: Champagne, of course, but Oregon pinot noir and German riesling? Apparently.

title: The 1 Percent? Thats So 2011. Its the 6 Percent You Should Be Worried About.
description: Here at City Room, weve had enough of people picking on the 1 percent. Sure, some might brand them greedy, but even in New York City, where, thanks to the financial-service industry, they are particularly well compensated, they receive only 33.8 percent of the total income, kindly leaving two-thirds for the rest of us.

title: Why Lost Pounds Come Back
description: In this weeks New York Times Magazine, I explore new research that helps explain why most dieters who lose weight end up gaining it all back.

title: Ask a Railroad Station Expert
description: As part of this weeks Q&A, David Naylor, an architectural historian and author of Railroad Stations: The Buildings That Linked the Nation (Norton), took readers questions on railroad stations. He is no longer taking questions.

title: NYSE and Deutsche Borse Extend Merger Deadline
description: Deutsche Brse and NYSE Euronext have extended the deadline to complete their $9 billion proposed merger to March 31, amid resistance from European regulators.

title: Williams Looking for Teammates and Continuity
description: One year ago Deron Williams was in his sixth season for the Utah Jazz, and his career was the picture of continuity.

title: Design Flaws Cited in Deadly Train Crash in China
description: BEIJING  Chinese investigators delivered a long-awaited report on Wednesday on the deadly July 23 high-speed train crash in the eastern coastal city of Wenzhou, citing a string of blunders, including serious design flaws in crucial signaling equipment.

title: Paul Comes to Iowa, Swinging
description: DES MOINES  As he arrives in Iowa today, Ron Paul is continuing to wage his expensive television campaign against Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney with a new advertisement that dubs them part of the Washington machine.

title: A Welcome Role Reversal
description: Generally speaking, children like their parents to be all-knowing and to fear nothing  they want them to be paragons of authority, capability and calm. Nonetheless, it can be hugely satisfying, reassuring even, to see Mom shriek at the sight of a mouse or Dad throw a tantrum over a traffic jam.

title: Chasing Presidents in Blue Frye Boots
description: For more than 15 years, Helene Cooper, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, has followed American presidents and diplomats to places like Beijing, Tripoli, Kandahar and Jerusalem. Here, some packing wisdom from an international road warrior.

title: Insider Travel Tips From Campaign Reporters
description: TRAVEL is one of the great perks of being a journalist  over the years, my job has taken me to places like Los Angeles, Paris and Saudi Arabia. But when I began covering Mitt Romneys presidential bid five months ago as a member of The New York Times political team, I suddenly found myself shuffling through airport security several times a week.

title: How to File an Auto Insurance Claim
description: The Consumer Federation of America estimates that more than 325,000 auto accidents will occur during this years holiday travel period, resulting in more than 200,000 claims filed with the nations insurance companies.

title: The Israeli TV Report on Gender Segregation That Sparked Protest
description: As my colleague Isabel Kershner explains, an Israeli television report on a girl who was harassed by ultra-Orthodox men for not being dressed modestly enough sparked a protest against gender segregation on Tuesday night in the town on Beit Shemesh.

title: Apropos Appropriation
description: ONE recent afternoon in the offices of the Midtown law firm run by David Boies and his powerful litigation partners, a large black clamshell box sat on a conference table. Inside were raucous, sometimes wildly funny collages of photographs and magazine pages handmade by the artist Richard Prince, works of art that have become the ur-texts of one of the most closely watched copyright cases ever to rattle the world of fine art.

title: Big City Book Club: Up Next, Alfred Kazin
description: When the Big City Book Club reconvenes for its next online literary discussion on Jan. 10, we will be talking about Alfred Kazins A Walker in the City, the writers 1951 memoir of growing up in Brownsville, Brooklyn.

title: Dark Days Behind It, Central Park Pulses at Night
description: For as long as most New Yorkers can remember, the rules have been clear: Enjoy Central Park by day. Keep out at night.

title: Morgan Stanley to Cut 580 Jobs in New York
description: Morgan Stanley will slash 580 jobs in New York as part of a broader wave of layoffs underway at the bank, according to a public filing.

title: Perry Hits Obama on Lack of Military Parade
description: URBANDALE, Iowa  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has plenty of criticism for President Obama on the campaign trail: he typically hits Mr. Obama for the decision to delay a major pipeline project, for the ballooning federal debt and for much, much more.

title: Why Books Are Better Than e-Books for Children
description: Do you read to your children from your iPad or other device, or encourage them to use an e-reader to read to you? Many of us do, at least on occasion  even I, who wrote here some weeks ago that I rarely read on my own iPad anymore because I want my children to see me reading books, recommended an app for creating fun picture books for travel last week. If you have a tablet or e-reader, why not add it to your childs reading repertory as well?

title: After the Holiday Rush, Time for Reveries
description: Today, the lake is smoothly white at nearly noon, glowing in the pale winter sunshine, with grey-blue shadows of clouds stretched across its further reaches. Minute diamonds glitter from within the white snow on our sloping front field, crossed with long ski tracks and the wallows marking falls and wrestling sessions (with ones inner ski-demon). Earlier this morning the wind on the lake blew up great billows of loose snow, but the air is still now. I thought I heard a snowmobile, which was a surprise since there really isnt enough snow yet to ride out on one.

title: Bishops Say Rules on Gay Parents Limit Freedom of Religion
description: Roman Catholic bishops in Illinois have shuttered most of the Catholic Charities affiliates in the state rather than comply with a new requirement that says they must consider same-sex couples as potential foster-care and adoptive parents if they want to receive state money. The charities have served for more than 40 years as a major link in the states social service network for poor and neglected children.

title: The Best Jazz of 2011
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen, jazz critics for The Times, discuss the best jazz artists and albums of the year.

title: Ralph Ruccis World, Times Two
description: YOU might expect a book on the designer Ralph Rucci to have a scholarly appreciation by the fashion historian Valerie Steele; swooning testimonials from society clients of Mr. Ruccis like Deeda Blair and Susan Gutfreund; and romantic color plates of his high-wire dresses by a princeling photographer on the order of, say, Patrick Demarchelier.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Romney on Ayatollahs, and Parenthood
