All in all, the flights cost $350. The flight attendants were looking at me as if I was nuts, because for each pair of cities, I flew back and forth with the same crew. Saturday was Houston to Dallas to Houston to Austin to Houston; and Sunday was from Dallas to Houston to Austin to Houston. Ah, the crazy things we do to retain status.

title: Activists Document Raids on Civil Society Groups and a Protest in Cairo
description: Updated | 8:01 p.m. As my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and David Goodman report, Egyptian security forces stormed the offices of 17 nonprofit groups around the country on Thursday, including at least three democracy-promotion groups financed by the United States, as part of what Egypts military-led government has said is an investigation into foreign hands in the recent outbreak of protests.

title: S.&.P. Outlook on Citi Field Bonds Sours
description: The Mets know things are not great at Citi Field. Attendance dropped again last season as they finished with a losing record for the third consecutive season. Revenue fell from virtually every source.

title: Your Best Meals of the Year: From New York, to Tuscaloosa, to a Singapore Cafe
description: Heres one last batch of readers best meals of the year, though if you continue to share them on Twitter with the hashtag #bestmeal2011, well keep on retweeting. Below youll see a shout-out to a barbecue joint in Austin, Tex.; a reader torn between lunch at the French Laundry and lunch at In-N-Out burger the next day; and, at Annisa in Manhattan, an aged ribeye with escargot, earthy funk the likes of Bootsy Collins. Heres to good eating in 2012.

title: Californias Delta Ecosystem Is Healthier, For Now
description: The ecosystem of the delta where the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers meet has been in the legal equivalent of an intensive care unit for four years. But just before Christmas, an upbeat report came in, showing that a year of copious rain and snow had significantly improved.the deltas condition.

title: In Pennsylvania, a Quick Shot of Peace, on a Budget
description: LATE in November I arrived at the Jesuit Center in the reclusive hills of Wernersville, Pa., on a blindingly dark and stormy night to begin a silent five-day retreat. Such a scenario might have compelled someone more compos mentis to turn around. But that was the point. As a 43-year-old mother of three wrung out from three years of panic attacks triggered by the specter of financial ruin, I needed a solid period of quiet to recombobulate. Cheaply.

title: The Burden of Debt, Again Again
description: I admit to having been surprised by the reaction to my two posts on the burden of debt. I thought I was saying something that would be obvious once it was pointed out; instead, many of the comments were baffled, and quite a few were utterly enraged.

title: Hoping to Avoid Turf Troubles, Yanks Call Up Tougher Sod for Pinstripe Bowl
description: Less than seven minutes into a football game between Rutgers and Army at Yankee Stadium on Nov. 12, the grounds crew hustled onto the field and stepped on several large divots of turf that had become dislodged near one end zone. It was at about that moment that Lonn Trost cringed.

title: A Classic American Boat Weds a Contemporary Japanese Engine
description: The classic and highly prized wooden speedboats made by Chris-Craft have long been fitted with potent automobile engines, including small-block Chevy V-8s and Chrysler Hemis. Now, Infiniti has joined with Nashville State Community College and Freeport Boat Outlet of Maine to customize a 1962 Chris-Craft Holiday and equip it with a 400-horsepower 5.6-liter V-8 from an Infiniti QX56 S.U.V. Its the kind of pairing of classic and contemporary that has always been part of the automotive scene, but has perhaps been more rare in the world of boats.

title: A Slump Is A Good Time To Invest In Infrastructure
description: Multiplier issues aside, funding is cheap, and many of the resources you would use would otherwise be unemployed. Theres really a compelling argument that we should be doing a lot of public investment right now.

title: Series: Firepower
description: Articles in this series explore gaps in gun laws and their impact on public safety.

title: Popcast: The Best Jazz of 2011
description: In the last of three year-end wrap-up shows, the music critics Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen listen to and discuss some of the best jazz of 2011.

title: A Public Marriage Proposal? Think Again
description: My girlfriends parents are giving a big brunch party on Jan. 2, the federal holiday. Id like to surprise my girlfriend by asking her to marry me in front of all the guests. Weve been going out for six months, and Im ready to make the commitment. The new year feels like the perfect time. But do I have to get her parents permission to ask during the brunch? In case it matters, they like me. Ben, Florida

title: Man Who Tried to Extort Letterman Is Hired by Newsmagazine
description: Robert Joel Halderman, the 48 Hours producer who pleaded guilty last year to having tried to extort David Letterman, has been hired by a competing crime newsmagazine, On the Case With Paula Zahn, which is shown on the Investigation Discovery channel.

title: New Game Plan: Smelling the Roses
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Back in 1986, when Urban Meyer was a graduate assistant at Ohio State, he shared an office the size of a little furnace room with five of his peers, his primary duty the cutting and splicing of 16-millimeter film.

title: Long Faces at the Palace, a Beloved Diner Set to Close
description: One by one, they all came in, arriving one last time to have a turkey club sandwich and to say goodbye to another Queens diner.

title: Growing Old With Sex on Their Minds
description: Why did Alan Bennett give the title Smut to this admittedly slight but always enjoyable and often hilarious pair of novellas? Maybe its a coy apology for a book that celebrates several varieties of sexual activity, a subject he has said was barely mentionable in lower-middle-class Yorkshire, where he was raised. Maybe its a defiant cry from a writer who has accused his younger self of being bashful, diffident and very, very repressed. Maybe the title is wry, rueful, ironic, nostalgic and mischievous  all of which Smut itself turns out to be.

title: 24/7 Episode 3: A Festive Mood as the Winter Classic Nears
description: Much has been made about the fracas between Jets Coach Rex Ryan and Giants running back Brandon Jacobs after the Giants victory on Christmas Eve. Turns out, Ryans comeback was taken straight out of Flyers Coach Peter Laviolettes playbook.

title: A House Divided by Exasperation
description: A Separation, a tightly structured, emotionally astute new film from Iran, begins with a couple, at odds and in distress, arguing in front of a judge. Simin (Leila Hatami) wants to leave the country with her daughter, Termeh (Sarina Farhadi), and Simins husband, Nader (Peyman Moadi), insists on staying at home in Tehran to care for his frail and elderly father, who suffers from dementia and needs constant attention. Quite possibly there is more at issue than practical domestic arrangements  there are hints of suppressed anger in Naders demeanor, of long-simmering exasperation in Simins  but an Iranian courtroom may not be the best place to discuss intimate marital matters.

title: Vain Glorious | New Hairs Eve
description: When it comes to hair, this holiday time can be frustrating. Spring trends are not yet relevant, and most fall and winter looks have been exhausted. So what to wear to ring in the New Year? An up-do that embodies the best of both seasons.

title: After Frustration and Sorrow, Season of Revival for Gaborik
description: Marian Gaborik, who is second in the N.H.L. in goal-scoring, has been smiling a lot lately. Long just a step away from stardom, he seems finally to have become a marquee player for a Rangers team newly arrived in hockeys spotlight.

title: Coming Soon: The Letter That Sank Mark Hurd
description: Theres another installment coming in one of Silicon Valleys stranger soap operas.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Taqueria Tlaxcalli
description: A Bronx restaurant serves authentic cuisine in a borough that is home to a growing population of Mexicans.

title: Like Home, if Home Is Mexico
description: IT used to be that authentic Mexican restaurants were a kind of urban legend in New York. And transplants from California and Texas, to say nothing of Puebla and Mexico City, still stalk the citys cantinas, often with disappointing results, and trade tips about the best  places like Taqueria Tlaxcalli in Parkchester, a diverse expanse of urban blocks in the Bronx.

title: What We Collect
description: From Beatles memorabilia to Barbie dolls, people collect a range of objects. What drives people to collect objects? And when does collecting become a problem?

title: V.I.P. Perks, Secondhand Stores
description: SEPARATE lines had formed outside a 6,000-square-foot warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, on a Saturday: one for general admission, one V.I.P. A man with a clipboard started checking names. Then the select few were in, and the masses continued to wait their turn. They had another hour to lean, shivering, against the wall.

title: Dear FloFab: My Check Has a Tip Tacked On
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: A New Verizon Fee for Some Bill Payments
description: Our colleagues on the Bits blog have a post of interest to our readers, too. It says that Verizon Wireless plans to begin charging a $2 fee on Jan. 15 when customers use their credit cards to make a one-time payment online or over the phone.

title: Lens: From a Marines Side of the Camera
description: Over on the Lens blog, Sgt. Thomas James Brennan writes about the close bonds that form during battle, even between soldiers and the combat photographers documenting them. When Finbarr OReilly, a Reuters photographer, embedded with Sgt. Brennans squad of Marines in Afghanistan last October, he was a little guarded around the man with the camera. But the war didnt give him time or space to hold onto those feelings. And conversations with Mr. OReilly, coupled with the closeness of battle, forged a bond between the men that continues to today. A bond was cemented with the commonalities the men shared, as Sgt. Brennan notes:

title: Look Out, _____ Is the New Grunge!
description: FEAR not, rockists: all is not lost. Just because the mainstream, as buffeted by major labels, has been resistant to new ideas for several years doesnt mean it cant be infected. Bubbling below the mook-rockers, the 90s revivalists and the toothless oldsters are plenty of microscenes, any one of which could be seized upon by A&R executives looking to reboot their labels approach to rock. Here are a few of the most promising options.

title: Making Fun of Hipsters for a Living
description: Magazine writer Elizabeth Weil on the new season of "Portlandia" and meeting the show's co-star Carrie Brownstein in Portland, of course.

title: An Indoor Park and Mini-Golf in a Bar
description: Normally this time of year finds the Miser making a gigantic list of possible resolutions. (There are always many to choose from.) But with vacation extending into the first week of January, the plan is to ease into the new year with some mildly active fun that wont require facing the cold reality that the holidays are over.

title: They Say the Noen Lights Are Bright on Brodaway
description: Thanks to the Arts for Transit program, there are moments of genuine delight to be found in the New York City subway. There are also delightful surprises that have nothing to do with artistic intent.

title: Leaping Off the Pages in the Himalayas
description: Diversity in the comic book industry  whether in the characters adventures or in the creators who devise them  is a topic that inspires a gnashing of teeth. Why arent there more female creators? Why arent there more series with minority leads? When different cultures are represented, how can it be done without that whiff of tokenism?

title: Factory Jobs Gain, but Wages Retreat
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Manufacturers are hiring again in America, softening a long slide in factory employment. But for a new generation of blue-collar workers, even those protected by unions, the price of employment is likely to be lower wages stretching to retirement.

title: Bill to Create Anticorruption Agency Stalls in India
description: NEW DELHI  Indias coalition government failed on Thursday to push through legislation to create an independent anticorruption agency, after an exhausting day of parliamentary speechmaking, political posturing and backroom negotiations could not produce a deal, possibly stalling the bill for months.

title: Parental Quandary Resolved: After a Divorce, Who Gets the Children for the Holidays?
description: Last week, Nina (all names and identifying details have been changed) asked our parenting crowd source for advice about a question shes been struggling with for some time. When her husband and his first wife divorced, his now ex swore hed never see the children on a holiday, and in the eight years since, shes made good on her promise. During that interval, he met Nina, they married, and had two children together. Hes never objected to his ex-spouses claim to his children for the holidays (or even her constant pulling them back from other arranged visits), but Nina wondered if maybe he  they  should. What if her stepchildren (now 11 and 15) think they werent wanted?

title: Showcasing Composers Versatility
description: The holiday season is usually hectic for the New York Philharmonic, and this year the orchestras December schedule has been particularly diffuse, with Messiah performances, chamber performances and a pair of Contact! concerts built around H. K. Grubers Frankenstein!! The orchestra took last week off, but its New Years Eve concert  a Bernstein and Gershwin program  is still ahead. So for the subscription series that began on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Alan Gilbert led works by Haydn, Schubert and Ravel  a thoroughly settled, mainstream selection, you might think, until you looked more closely.

title: Foreign Aid Worker Is Killed and Colleague Is Wounded in Somali Capital
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A foreign aid worker was shot dead and another was wounded by a former colleague at their office here in the capital on Thursday, according to officials and witnesses, adding to a series of attacks on humanitarian workers and journalists that has underscored the dangers of working in this war-torn country.

title: On Our Radar: Scientists Appeal to G.O.P. Candidates
description: Less than two weeks before the New Hampshire primary, 50 scientists in that state call on Republican presidential candidates to accept the overwhelmin scientific evidence on the human role in climate change and to support action to rein in greenhouse gas emissions. Their statement follows a similar appeal from scientists in Iowa. [E2Wire.]

title: Samoa Sacrifices a Day for Its Future
description: The Pacific island nation of Samoa and its even tinier neighbor Tokelau are skipping Friday this week, jumping westward in time across the international date line and into the shifting economic balance of the 21st century.

title: Russians Rally for Activist in Hopes of Inspiring a Movement
description: MOSCOW  Opposition leaders trying to sustain the momentum of their upstart protest movement gathered about 200 people on Thursday for an unsanctioned rally in central Moscow in support of a jailed activist they are hoping to turn into a cause clbre.

title: For Hollywood, More Year-to-Year Reasons for Concern
description: LOS ANGELES  A little math, albeit fuzzy, may explain why executives at film studios, both big and small, are having a nervous holiday (and actually spending time in the office, as mentioned earlier).

title: The Top 10 Top 10 Lists of 2011
description: 1. Top 10 Films of John Waters (Artforum). A near-perfect list, iconoclastic and personal, but loaded with great, weird, wild, Watersian movies. The No. 9 curveball? Amid the art films, apocalypse comedy and Bieber concert film, a quiet, heartbreaking AIDS documentary.

title: The Most-Commented Posts of 2011
description: As 2011 comes to a close, City Room takes note of the events that proved irresistible to readers, attracting the highest volume of reader comments. The Occupy Wall Street protests, former Representative Anthony D. Weiners lewd social networking habits, and the posts tracking the drama of Violet, Bobby and Pip, the red-tailed hawks and the subjects of the Hawk Cam, dominated our list.

title: 2011: Arab Spring
description: A look back at the year of change in the Middle East with the Beirut bureau chief Anthony Shadid.

title: Truck Drivers for Romney?
description: MASON CITY, Iowa  Mitt Romney came to Mason City to stand before a faux Music Man backdrop of River City, Iowa, and give an answer diplomatically worthy of the musicals con man  or, at least, a typical politician.

title: An Election Year Dawns Without Keith Olbermann
description: 6:05 p.m. | Updated  Keith Olbermann, who came to Current TV this year to remake the channel and compete against his old home, MSNBC, is sitting out the biggest political nights of the season.

title: A Working Vacation
description: The Biggest Loser Resort offers participants a picturesque setting in Ivins, Utah, to tackle losing weight.

title: My Week at the Biggest Loser Fat Camp
description: COME on guys! Three more minutes and Day 2 is over! screamed Sharon, our six-foot trainer, punching the air with her fists and tossing back her slick black hair, which perfectly matched her shiny black tracksuit.

title: Spare Times for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Around Town

title: Movie Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Movies

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Pop

title: Theater Listings: Dec. 30  Jan. 5
description: Theater

title: Jazz Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Jazz

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Classical

title: Technology Headlines 2011
description: A recap of the years major technology headlines and a gear roundup that includes digital-audio amplifiers and a solar-powered keyboard.

title: Londons Beloved Bus Returns, With an Update
description: The streets of London were brightened this holiday season by a very new, very red addition. The first running prototype of the new double-decker bus, a modern version of the classic Routemaster, drove across the city the week before Christmas.

title: Tackling Beethoven and the Firebird
description: What choreography in 2012 whets the appetite in advance? Its dismayingly hard to know. The choreographers Mark Morris, Alexei Ratmansky, Paul Taylor and Christopher Wheeldon will all present premieres in New York. But while Mr. Morris and Mr. Taylor are capable of real greatness, and Mr. Ratmansky and Mr. Wheeldon are the most important choreographers in ballet today, experience has taught us that each can disappoint.

title: Photo Replay: Dec.29
description: A view of the day in sports included ski jumping in Germany and cricket in Australia.

title: Dance Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Dance

title: Pop Will Thrive in Greenwich Village
description: Theres little need to wait for two of 2012s most promising events. Thanks to the intrepid Association of Performing Arts Presenters, which braves January in New York City for its annual convention, a brigade of jazz and world-music performers converges in downtown Manhattan next weekend. On Jan. 6 and 7, the Winter Jazzfest shares five Greenwich Village clubs within a three-block radius, each presenting half a dozen acts nightly. Then, on Jan. 8, Globalfest offers a dozen acts on three stages in Webster Hall in the East Village. First-rate music awaits those willing to endure scrimmages at doorways and chatty audiences.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Art

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Prospect Park Audubon Center

title: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from North Korea, Turkey, Bahrain and Iran.

title: From Cage at His Briefest to Wagner at His Longest
description: John Cage is an anomaly among contemporary composers for a great many reasons, not the least of which is that his name and some of his conceptual notions are more widely known than his music. His most famous score is silent  or at least people think it is. Actually, that work  433  was composed for Maverick Concerts, a summer festival near Woodstock, N.Y., held in an open shed, and Cages hope was that listeners would focus on the natural sounds that filtered into the concert space as the piece was performed. Obviously, the piece works in indoor halls as well, once you understand how to approach it.

title: A Second Chance for TVs Season
description: New TV shows are liable to pop up any time these days, but over the last few years January has solidified its position as the start of televisions second season. There are probably more series making their debuts or having their season premieres next month than there were during the official start of the 2011-12 broadcast network season in September. A quick scan turns up more than 70.

title: The Met to Present Entire Ring Cycle, and More
description: You cannot fairly assess a production of Wagners Ring until you see the entire cycle of four operas. Wagner buffs will finally get that chance this spring when the Metropolitan Opera presents the director Robert Lepages new production of the Ring in three complete cycles in April and May. This ambitious venture is rightly the most anticipated event of the Met season. First, Gtterdmmerung, the last installment, will be introduced on Jan. 27, with Fabio Luisi, the Mets principal conductor, on the podium. The pros and cons of Mr. Lepages work in the first three operas have been heatedly discussed, and the debate will surely continue.

title: Soundtracks for a Years Last Parties
description: Another year down, another drop of the ball, another chance to get it all right.

title: Not Just New Games, but Also New Systems
description: Once upon a time, the winter months were sleepy in game land. Not anymore. Early 2012 will bring the release of not only some closely watched games, but also a major new portable hardware system. And Nintendo has said it intends to introduce its successor to the Wii, the Wii U, some time after May.

title: From Outlaws to Presidents in a Year That Was Filled With Curious Treasures
description: Specialty museums closed by the dozen this year, in fields as rarefied as New Jersey farming and Arizona mining, and their collections were stored away or split up. But broader institutions and their benefactors still had spare cash to make high-profile purchases. Here are six of 2011s most intriguing auction lots that emerged on the market and are now already on view or will be soon.

title: Like Home, if Home Is Mexico
description: It used to be that authentic Mexican restaurants were a kind of urban legend in New York. And transplants from California and Texas, to say nothing of Puebla and Mexico City, still stalk the citys cantinas, often with disappointing results, and trade tips about the best  places like Taqueria Tlaxcalli in Parkchester in the Bronx.

title: A Cold Mountain Village Where Heartbreak Is Everybodys Business
description: The small, hardy community in the Rocky Mountains that gives Angels Crest its name is a rough-hewn working-class town of grain elevators and meat-and-potatoes eateries where everyone knows everyone elses business. Ethan Denton (Thomas Dekker), the films main character, is a 21-year-old father who works in an auto parts shop and is raising his 3-year-old son, Nate, singlehandedly. The childs mother, Cindy (Lynn Collins), a bitter and promiscuous alcoholic much older than Ethan, keeps her distance.

title: AMRs Shares to Be Grounded
description: AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, disclosed Thursday that its shares would be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange before the market opens on Jan. 5.

title: Revivals and Retellings, Some Served With Blood
description: SHAKESPEARE IN BROOKLYN

title: Cathy Horyn Recounts the Year in Fashion
description: The best and worst of 2011, from the Alexander McQueen exhibit to John Gallianos topple.

title: A Judge Who Reshaped the Corporate Landscape
description: Many judges are lucky to handle just one era-defining case during their tenures on the bench. In his 16 years as a federal bankruptcy judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez has handled three.

title: The Santorum Surge in Iowa and Beyond
description: The extent to which Rick Santorum has gained in Iowa polling is not entirely clear. Although two polls have him with 16 percent of the vote, two others that were in the field at the same time have him at 10 and 11 percent, respectively.

title: In Panama City, Colorful Red Devil Buses Yielding to Paler, Safer Kind
description: PANAMA  Here comes the Diablo Rojo, the Red Devil bus blasting its air horn and fishtailing around a fellow demon just in time to claim Irma Betancourt and other morning commuters. Suffice it to say the Red Devils earn their name.

title: Meatball Recipes
description: Recipes for classic Italian meatballs, global alternatives and updated takes on a cherished form.

title: Honda Tells Dealers Not to Sell Used Models Until Air Bag Is Fixed
description: Honda has told its dealers not to sell some used models until they carry out a recall to fix an air bag defect the automaker has linked to 18 injuries and two deaths.

title: Specters and Shades of Black in 2012 Films
description: The most widely anticipated question in cinema for 2012 may well be this: Has The Woman in Black (a ghost story starring Daniel Radcliffe and scheduled for release in February) ever dated any of The Men in Black 3 (coming in May)? Also, what are we to make of the appearance, weeks apart, of Declaration of War (January) and This Means War (February), neither of which, incidentally, is about war?

title: Yankees Hats Are Everywhere, Even North Korea
description: Yankees caps are everywhere these days, perhaps even on planets yet to be discovered.

title: Some Favorite Things Not Hanging on a Wall
description: Last year around this time, three art critics for The New York Times chose a few of their favorite paintings on long-term display in New York museums and wrote about them. The hope was to bring some attention to works that are often overlooked in the citys constant deluge of art-viewing possibilities. This year were doing it again, but with the focus shifted to three-dimensional objects.

title: At Sears, Excessive Confidence Has a Price
description: Becoming very rich can show that you are a genius.

title: Saints Could Be a 13-Win Team Without a Bye
description: After a streak of coin flip futility earlier thisseason,are the Saints headed for another dubious distinction?

title: Republican Candidates Campaign in Iowa
description: Voters have readily acknowledged that their decision will be driven as much by personal chemistry as political positions, as much by biography as policy.

title: Judge Blocks Californias Low-Carbon Fuel Rule
description: A federal judge on Thursday blocked enforcement of a California regulation favoring producers of gasoline, diesel fuel and biofuels whose methods generate fewer greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Mansionlike Luxury, Without the Bother
description: IT is when you go pre-prewar  that is, before World War I  that you get to the richest lode of apartment luxury. That could be anything from the Dakota (1884) to 998 Fifth Avenue (1912), in part because they were designed before experience taught developers how to cut corners.

title: How Low Can Rates Go?
description: IF your New Years resolutions include buying a house or refinancing, the Federal Reserve has you covered. It has committed to keep long-term interest rates low through next year, so a 30-year mortgage will be pegged about where it is now  4.32 percent in New York  at least through spring, said Frank E. Nothaft, the chief economist at Freddie Mac.

title: Perrys Presidential Campaign Gaffes Put Texans on the Defensive Yet Again
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Space Plan From China Broadens Challenge to U.S.
description: BEIJING  Broadening its challenge to the United States, the Chinese government on Thursday announced an ambitious five-year plan for space exploration that would move China closer to becoming a major rival at a time when the American program is in retreat.

title: Q & A
description: Setting a Date for a Board Meeting

title: A Larger Place (Couch Must Fit)
description: FOR most of her eight or so years in New York, Amber Field lived only on the top floors of walk-up buildings.

title: Lingerie on 6; Lobster on 9
description: MAYBE it was that scene between Kris Kringle and Alfred, the people-pleasing porter, in Miracle on 34th Street: lunch at a cafeteria in Macys.

title: Serving With Saddams Ladle
description: IT was Friday before dusk and my husband had corralled our three children  showered, in good clothes and on notice for good behavior  to sing Sabbath prayers. I broke away for a moment and ran upstairs to my computer to check the status of a shiny treasure looted from the devil.

title: Looking Past the Potato
description: ON a trip to Italy last year, Carol Festa and Tom Geppel of Mattituck savored the pecorino and ricotta in Tuscany. Back home on the North Fork, motivated by an increasing involvement with the sustainable farming and local food movement, they leased farmland and bought 13 hardy Icelandic sheep.

title: Too Many Stops, but Leave Mine!
description: Nick Rougley, a student housing coordinator at the Art Institute of San Francisco, commutes every day from the Fillmore to Civic Center. Sometimes he takes the No. 5-Fulton Muni bus for the mile-long trip. Sometimes he walks. The bus is so slow, said Mr. Rougley, Its really almost the same as walking.

title: 2011: The Year of the Turndown
description: EVEN as 2011 was a year of stable prices and steady sales in Manhattan real estate, it may go down in history as a banner year for co-op and condo board vetoes.

title: Standing Still
description: Three critics choose their favorite sculptures and three-dimensional objects in New York City.

title: Whos Parking Where? City Doesnt Know, but It Hopes to Find Out
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Violet the Red-Tailed Hawk Is Dead
description: Violet, the red-tailed hawk whose intimate family life in a nest overlooking Washington Square Park was chronicled on a live-streaming webcam, delighting more than a million viewers with the sacred spectacle of nature, died on Thursday. She was believed to be about 5 years old.

title: Bachmann Strikes Thatcher Comparison in Iowa
description: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa  Representative Michele Bachmann, trying to keep her campaign alive in the waning days of the race in Iowa, highlighted a theme she has been using lately, comparing herself to Margaret Thatcher, the conservative British prime minister during the 1980s who was known for her steely toughness.

title: Haitis Tragic History
description: For the better part of two centuries, outsiders have been offering explanations that range from racist to learned-sounding  the supposed inferiority of blacks, the heritage of slavery, overpopulation  for why Haiti remains the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. None of these work: nearby Barbados has a greater population density, and about 90 percent of its people are descended from slaves, yet it outranks all but two nations in Latin America on the United Nations Human Development Index. Neither Barbados nor any other country, however, had so traumatic and crippling a birth as Haiti.

title: Filenes Basement Closes in Boston, and Shoppers Mourn
description: BOSTON  On the final day of the farewell sale at Filenes Basement on Boylston Street here, Andrew Eisenmann made a funereal trip from the store to his double-parked car, pushing a clothing rack he had just purchased for $40.

title: $68 Million Settlement Proposed for 10 Children Fraudulently Adopted and Abused
description: Lawyers for 10 disabled children who were fraudulently adopted by a Queens woman more than 15 years ago and subjected to years of abuse have proposed a $68 million settlement in a civil rights lawsuit filed on their clients behalf, according to a confidential court filing.

title: Graphic: How the Weather Turns Out in Iowa
description: On Fox News Sunday, Mike Huckabee claimed that if the weather is bad in Iowa this Tuesday, Representative Ron Paul will win the state caucuses over Mitt Romney, whose supporters are not as dedicated. Current forecasts predict the weather will be relatively balmy, with no chance of rain or snow  which, according to Mr. Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, will favor Mr. Romney.

title: Romney, Eye on Paul, Digs In as He Bets on Iowa
description: DES MOINES  With days left before voting begins in Iowa, Mitt Romney has fully embraced the state that spurned him four years ago, betting that heightened expectations for his performance at the Republican caucuses here on Tuesday will not undercut his chances of a strong start to the presidential nominating contests.

title: The Caucus Click: Campaigning Across Iowa
description: By all accounts, the 2012 presidential race is supposed to hinge on the troubled American economy and the overriding anxiety of a restless electorate. However, voters have readily acknowledged that their decision will be driven as much by personal chemistry as political positions, as much by biography as policy. More Photos

title: Failed Adoptions Create More Homeless Youths
description: Lamar West has lost parents twice in his life. The first time was when he was 4; the second was a month before his 18th birthday. The circumstances differed, but the outcomes did not.

title: Spain: Kings Son-in-Law Summoned to Court Over Fraud Allegations
description: A high court in Spain issued a summons Thursday to the son-in-law of King Juan Carlos as a suspect in a spreading fraud scandal that involves millions of dollars in public money given to his private foundation. A judge in Palma, Majorca, called on the son-in-law, Iaki Urdangarin, 43, to face questioning on Feb. 6 about allegations that he used his royal credentials to secure multimillion-dollar contracts for his foundation, the Nos Institute, to organize sports and tourism events. After he was named as a formal suspect on Thursday, the Spanish palace and a number of government institutions issued careful comments offering respect for the decision of judges. The king has taken a number of steps to keep a distance from his son-in-law, whose family did not spend Christmas Eve with the royal family for the first time in years.

title: In G.O.P. Field, Broad View of Presidential Power Prevails
description: WASHINGTON  Even as they advocate for limited government, many of the Republican presidential candidates hold expansive views about the scope of the executive powers they would wield if elected  including the ability to authorize the targeted killing of United States citizens they deem threats and to launch military attacks without Congressional permission.

title: Finding Optimism in a Longer View of Equities
David Axelrod Is at Home Waging What May Be His Last Campaign
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Jildy App Sorts Your Facebook Friends for You
description: Youre in line for coffee. You really want to check your familys Facebook posts to see if theres anything you need to know about, but theyre lost among status updates from friends. You never did spend the time to create a group of just your relatives, so there you are, thumbing through your iPhones entire news feed.

title: Amid 31-Game Losing Skid, Towson Focuses on Future, Not Futility
description: TOWSON, Md.  A large crane swayed above the construction site for Towson Universitys new basketball arena Wednesday, a glimmer of hope for the future.

title: Contract Deadline Nears for 22,000 Office Cleaners in City
description: The owners of 1,500 office towers in New York City, most of them in Manhattan, are preparing for a possible strike at midnight Saturday, lining up thousands of workers to replace union employees who clean the buildings during overnight shifts.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,844 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Deciding Who Is Eligible to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Stop-and-Frisks
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall St. Cant Carry the City
description: To the Editor:

title: Background Checks
description: To the Editor:

title: New Ford Fusion Will Warn Drivers Who Drift
description: The Ford Motor Company offered on Thursday a taste of some advanced technology that will be featured in the all-new Fusion, which is scheduled to be introduced at the Detroit auto show in January. The technical tidbit is a tracking system that can help prevent drowsy or inattentive drivers from wandering out of their lane. While similar technology has previously been offered on some automobiles, Octavio Navarro, a Ford spokesman, said in a telephone interview that the Fusion would be the first affordable nonluxury vehicle to offer this type of system.

title: California: Court Allows Elimination of Redevelopment Agencies
description: The State Supreme Court ruled Thursday that Gov. Jerry Brown and the Legislature had the right to eliminate local redevelopment agencies, redirecting more than $1 billion to help close a huge budget gap. The state began authorizing the agencies in the 1940s to subsidize construction in rundown areas. After the Legislature voted to abolish them this summer, several cities and agencies sued, saying the state had no right to the funds. The court said that abolishing the agencies was a proper exercise of the legislative power vested in the Legislature and that the government could establish or dissolve local agencies and subdivisions as it sees fit. The Legislature also approved a plan allowing cities to reorganize the agencies if they agreed to use the money for state obligations this year, but the court ruled that plan invalid, effectively eliminating the nearly 400 agencies.

title: Vermont: Storm-Hit Roads Reopened
description: State officials on Thursday reopened the last stretch of state highway still closed after flooding from Hurricane Irene in August. About seven miles of Route 107, a busy east-west road connecting Bethel and Stockbridge, was opened. State officials say all 500 miles of state roadways damaged during the storm have now been repaired.

title: Loading Up on Stock Options
description: When the financial crisis depressed stock prices, many companies saw an opportunity to grant a large number of options to their executives  so that if the share prices recovered, the executives would reap windfalls.

title: 12 Arrested at Occupy the Caucus Protest
description: DES MOINES  An air of irritation surrounding the Occupy the Caucus movement crept in Thursday as 12 protesters, including a 14-year-old girl, were arrested for blocking the doors to the Iowa Democratic Party headquarters.

title: For a Corn Chip Maker, the New Spokesman Is the Product Itself
description: AT the Fiesta Bowl on Monday, the games sponsor, Tostitos, will have a new endorser  a spokesbag puppet in the form of a chip bag with arms, a mouth and a generous dollop of swagger  to humorously convey the message that it is the tortilla chip brand that enlivens social gatherings.

title: A Growing San Antonio Shakes Off Sleepy Label
description: SAN ANTONIO  In 2008, after 15 years as the Alamo Citys largest corporate resident, AT& T announced it was moving its headquarters to Dallas  and taking 700 executives along with it. In the past, that San Antonios first Fortune 500 company had outgrown its home might have seemed an insurmountable blow for this city with a pre-existing inferiority complex. But these days, it is not easy to shake the citys confidence.

title: Deep Thoughts for the Giants Against Dallas
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For seemingly as long as the Giants have played football, the running game has been the bedrock of their offensive philosophy. That is, until this season.

title: 4 U.S. Makers of Towers for Wind Turbines File Complaint Over Chinas Steel Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON  Four domestic companies that make most of the steel towers for wind turbines in the United States filed a trade complaint against China and Vietnam on Thursday, seeking tariffs in the range of 60 percent. The action is a significant new skirmish in an emerging green energy trade war.

title: Billing Both Legislature and Campaign? Prove It.
description: In politics, one mans mistake is anothers opportunity. Now that Representative Joe Driver, Republican of Garland, has been sentenced for double dipping billing both his campaign and the State Legislature for the same expenses opposition researchers in this primary season are scrambling for other cases.

title: Disputed Voting Turns Church, a Kremlin Ally, Into Its Critic
description: MOSCOW  Among the thousands of Russian voices raised against the Kremlin this month after parliamentary elections widely dismissed as fraudulent, perhaps the most surprising was that of Patriarch Kirill I, the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, who defended popular protests as a lawful negative reaction to corruption.

title: Pauls Stance on Foreign Policy Divides Many Traditional G.O.P. Voters
description: DES MOINES  This month, a wealthy Republican called up two officers who served as platoon leaders in Iraq and Afghanistan with a proposition: He would lend them his private jet, and they would fly around Iowa to Representative Ron Pauls campaign events in the weeks before the Jan. 3 caucuses, telling reporters at each location that the congressmans foreign policy and military positions were dangerous and nave.

title: An Artist Whose Compulsions Have Their Upsides
description: Ed Loftus, an Oakland artist known for his hyper-realistic graphite drawings, sat in a cafe in downtown San Francisco last week talking about how he had become obsessed with his hair. It sounds nuts, but all I could think about was getting my hair cut, he said. Its like: I should get my hair cut. When am I going to get my hair cut? Why am I thinking about getting my hair cut? I wish I could stop thinking about getting my hair cut.

title: Jamaica Comes Alive With Airport Arrivals
description: A steady stream of travelers dragging wheeled suitcases and speaking a Babel of tongues is helping revive downtown Jamaica, a vibrant hub of Queens that weathered several gloomy decades of decay and crime.

title: 2011 Was a Good Year for Causes of Gays
description: Although the court fight over same-sex marriage in California is unresolved, lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender advocacy groups scored major legislative victories in 2011.

title: Record Low Set in Deaths From Traffic, Mayor Says
description: Those who long for the simpler days of trolley cars and horse-drawn carriages should take pause: traversing New York Citys busy streets is now far safer for pedestrians and drivers alike.

title: Santorum Events Reflect Rising Iowa Numbers
description: CORALVILLE, Iowa  As Rick Santorum pondered something almost unthinkable a couple of weeks ago  a respectable finish in the Iowa caucuses on Tuesday  he urged a gathering of about three dozen potential voters to resist the impulse to play it safe.

title: For Metta World Peace, a New Name and Outlook
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  World Peace is possible. Just check the box score.

title: An Uproar on the Web Over $2 Fee by Verizon
description: The Web lit up with howls of protest on Thursday as word of a planned new Verizon Wireless fee spread wildly  and somewhat inaccurately.

title: Lottery Numbers
As Supply Dwindles, Organic Milk Gets Popular
description: There is a shortage of organic milk across the country, and it has become so bad in areas like the Southeast that Publix stores from Florida to Tennessee have put up signs in dairy cases anticipating the shoppers frustrated refrain: Wheres my organic milk?

title: An Ill Young Woman and the Aunt Always by Her Side
description: Linda Torres says that Carmen Estrada, her aunt, spoils her, even when money is tight. When Ms. Torres was 12, her favorite band was N Sync, so Ms. Estrada scraped together the money to take her to see the group in concert.

title: Corrections: December 30
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lessons in DNA and Mercy
description: In 2006, during a debate in the race for state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo criticized his opponent for having failed to give a DNA test to a man who was in prison for a murder that he turned out to have had nothing to do with. A few years before that, Mr. Cuomo spoke at a party for a book written by a man who had spent 12 years in prison for having handled $500 in a drug sting.

title: Closing In on the Climb of a Lifetime
description: R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, will climb Mount Kilimanjaro in January. Hes doing it in part to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats.

title: Italian Premier Outlines Plan to Stimulate Growth in a Struggling Economy
description: ROME  Prime Minister Mario Monti on Thursday presented in broad terms his governments master plan for Italy, which he called Grow Italy.

title: Bringing Home the Bacon
description: When I was 4 years old, I remember sitting in a diner for lunch with my mom and brother, blissfully eating one of my favorite foods, a B.L.T. A couple of hours later I began to come down with the flu and spent much of the afternoon throwing up.

title: Schottenheimer Weathers Criticism With Smile
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Brian Schottenheimer bounded up to the lectern Thursday afternoon, smiled and even asked the first question: Hows everybody doing?

title: Gov. Chafee Declines
description: Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island took a principled position when he refused an order from a federal court to transfer a prisoner to federal custody for prosecution because that would expose the prisoner to the death penalty. As Mr. Chafee said in a statement, that is a penalty consciously rejected by the State of Rhode Island, even for those guilty of the most heinous crimes.

title: Friday: Holder of Legends
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Have you ever started filling in a long answer based on the crossings, with little awareness of what the complete entry might be, but as you scribble and the answer dawns on you, you can feel the smile spread across your face? Thats what happened to me as I filled in 3 Down. I wound up laughing out loud at UP THE WAZOO, but it was the first time I think I was actually aware that the writing and the smiling were happening at the same time.

title: Why We Collect Stuff
Iran and the Strait
description: Irans threat to shut the Strait of Hormuz  one-fifth of the worlds oil trade passes through there  if the United States and Europe press ahead with new sanctions is unacceptable. The Obama administration is right to signal, in deliberately moderated ways, that Washington will not back off if Tehran ever attempts to carry it out.

title: Darker Nights as Some Cities Turn Off the Lights
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich.  When the sun sets in this small city, its neighborhoods seem to vanish.

title: Abrupt Shift in Leadership at a Hospital in Brooklyn
description: The chief executive of a troubled Brooklyn hospital has been abruptly dismissed, less than a month after a task force set up by the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo outlined a plan to carry out a major reorganization of how hospital care is delivered in Brooklyn.

title: The School Lunch Barometer
description: The economic downturn is driving more and more families into the ranks of the poor and the near poor who barely make it from paycheck to paycheck. This pattern is chillingly clear from the rising numbers of formerly middle-class children now qualifying for free or low-cost meals under the federally financed school lunch program.

title: Judge Says S.E.C. Misled Two Courts in Citi Case
description: WASHINGTON  The federal judge overseeing the Securities and Exchange Commissions fraud case against Citigroup became even more direct in his criticism of the agencys actions on Thursday, accusing the commission of misleading both his court and the federal court of appeals.

title: Charlie Morgans Battle
description: There is nothing theoretical about the ongoing pain inflicted by the Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages. Ask Charlie Morgan, a chief warrant officer in the Army National Guard, based in New Hampshire.

title: Howard Shows Nets Just How Much They Could Use Him
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  If there was any doubt about how much the Nets need a player of Dwight Howards caliber, especially now, a season before their move to Brooklyn, he punctuated that point with a violent blocked shot early in the first quarter of Thursday nights game, airmailing the ball from beneath the basket into the fourth row of the courtside seats.

title: Letter That Led to Downfall of Hewlett Chief Surfaces
description: The June 2010 letter that led to Mark V. Hurds downfall as the head of Hewlett-Packard paints a portrait of an executive who pressed a contract employee for sex, touched her inappropriately and asked her to spend the night with him.

title: Evelyn Handler Dies at 78; Led Two Universities
description: Evelyn Handler, a cell biologist who, as the first woman to serve as president of Brandeis University, set off an acrimonious debate over the universitys Jewish identity when she secularized some campus traditions in hopes of attracting more non-Jewish students, died Dec. 23 in a pedestrian accident in Bedford, N.H. She was 78.

title: Finding the Cleanup Crew After a Messy Hack Attack
description: In the film Pulp Fiction, Harvey Keitel plays the Wolf, a fast-talking and meticulous man who is called in to deal with the aftermath of an accidental shooting.

title: Going Home Again
description: Rod Dreher grew up in St. Francisville, La., a town of about 1,700 people 30 minutes northwest of Baton Rouge. He left for college and then lived in Washington, New York, Miami, Dallas and Philadelphia, working as a writer for various magazines, a newspaper and a foundation.

title: Letter to Mark Hurd Alleging Harassment
description: A copy of a letter sent in June 2010 by Gloria Allred, an attorney, to Mark Hurd, who was then the chief executive of Hewlett Packard, alleging harassment of her client, Jodie Fisher.

title: Voters Examining Candidates, Often to a Fault
description: DES MOINES  Jonathan Gabhart, a 21-year-old college student from Spencer, Iowa, is leaning toward voting for Ron Paul because of the Texas lawmakers unpolished speaking style  a high-pitched, squirrelly voice, as he put it. He seems like a real person because of his eccentricities.

title: The Allred/Fisher Letter vs. Emails sent by Jodie Fisher
description: A timeline of e-mails that Jodie Fisher apparently sent to Mark Hurd, the former chief executive of Hewlett Packard, contrasts the events outlined in a letter that accuses Mr. Hurd of sexual harassment.

title: Keynes Was Right
description: The boom, not the slump, is the right time for austerity at the Treasury. So declared John Maynard Keynes in 1937, even as F.D.R. was about to prove him right by trying to balance the budget too soon, sending the United States economy  which had been steadily recovering up to that point  into a severe recession. Slashing government spending in a depressed economy depresses the economy further; austerity should wait until a strong recovery is well under way.

title: For N.F.L., Concussion Suits May Be Test for Sport Itself
description: The long debate over the National Football Leagues handling of concussions is reaching the courts in a flurry of lawsuits, raising the possibility that dozens of former players will go before juries to outline the leagues medical practices and describe long-term cognitive problems they say were caused by the sport.

title: Should the World of Toys Be Gender-Free?
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, Environmental Advocate, Dies at 81
description: Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, a Georgian aristocrat and a lifelong New Yorker who became an environmental watchdog in posts in and out of government, died on Monday in his home on the Upper East Side. He was 81.

title: Tax Benefits From Options as Windfall for Businesses
description: The stock markets rebound from the financial crisis three years ago has created a potential windfall for hundreds of executives who were granted unusually large packages of stock options shortly after the market collapsed.

title: Answers to the Year in Questions
description: UTTERANCES

title: Holiday on Monday  New Years Day (Observed)
description: NEW YORK

title: How the Candidates Roll
description: While the G.O.P. hopefuls are all making their final tours around early voting states, their modes of travel  and their entourages  vary widely.

title: Todays Cable Guy, Upgraded and Better-Dressed
description: The cable guy is becoming sleeker and more sophisticated, just like the televisions and computers he installs.

title: Bryants Advice for Alex Rodriguez
description: LOS ANGELES  Before Alex Rodriguez flew to Germany to undergo a cutting-edge medical treatment, he consulted someone he knew and trusted to give him sound advice: Kobe Bryant.

title: Judge Blocks a California Fuel Regulation
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge on Thursday blocked enforcement of a California regulation favoring producers of gasoline, diesel fuel and biofuels whose methods generate fewer greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Neophyte Runs Into Realities of Politics
description: Alderman Ameya Pawars recent fund-raiser featured a praise-filled speech from his most prominent constituent, Mayor Rahm Emanuel. The event, on Dec. 13, capped a storybook year for the political neophyte, who upset the Emanuel-backed candidate in the mayors home 47th Ward in the City Council election in February.

title: Chaos at Midnight, Hung Lokpal
description: An exhausting day of parliamentary speechmaking, political posturing and backroom negotiations could not produce a deal, on the anti-corruption Lokpal Bill, Jim Yardley writes in the New York Times.

title: This Blagojevich Listens, but He Acts Up a Lot, Too
description: Blagojevich, who was transferred two years ago from Illinois to Michigan, feasts on three square meals per day with a daily jog around the paddock, his unusually thick mane glinting in the sunlight.

title: TCW Settles Suit With Its Former Star Investor
description: One of the years most contentious white-collar employment disputes came to an end Thursday, as Trust Company of the West, the California-based mutual fund, announced that it had settled a lawsuit with its former star investor, Jeffrey E. Gundlach.

title: NYT Front Page for 12/30/2011
description: NYT Front Page for 12/30/2011

title: Our Smartest and Dumbest Columns of 2011
description: Some of my favorite columnists and bloggers have started something called a prediction audit, which looks back at their year of writing and evaluates which of their articles seem to have been the most and the least prescient.

title: Bryant Masterfully Guides Lakers Past Knicks
description: LOS ANGELES  The faces have changed many times over, the uniforms recycled for one hopeful crew of Knicks after another, all of them fated to witness the same inevitable result: Kobe Bryant, rising above them, wielding the basketball as a weapon and a taunt.

title: Shooting Dharavi, A Photographers View
description: Adam Ferguson, a photojournalist who has spent most of the past three years covering Afghanistan, returned to India, where he first worked in 2007 to photograph Dharavi for The New York Times recent story. He spent a week taking pictures in Dharavi and another 10 days shooting a video that will be on our Web site.

title: Harper Save the Queen
description: MONTREAL  Hanging a portrait of the head of state in embassies and consulates abroad is the sort of thing most countries do as a matter of routine. For Canada, though, the move has proved controversial, not least because the countrys head of state lives thousands of miles away, in London.

title: Kim Jong-un Named Leader of North Korean Army
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea announced on Saturday that its new leader, Kim Jong-un, had officially been named supreme commander of the countrys powerful army, a day after the country warned that it would not soften its stance toward South Korea.

title: Israeli Strike Kills Gaza Militant
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military killed a radical Palestinian militant in Gaza on Friday and seriously wounded another one in what it said was the thwarting of a rocket attack into southern Israel.

title: Lets Start Paying College Athletes
description: Mark Emmert, the president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the almighty overseer of American college sports, likes to think of himself as a reformer. A few months ago, after hed been on the job for a little more than a year, he pushed through a series of improvements, including slightly higher academic standards for college athletes, a full-scale review of the N.C.A.A.s fat rule book and a new provision giving universities the option of offering four-year scholarships. The current one-year deals are, believe it or not, renewable at the discretion of coaches, who can effectively cut injured or underperforming student athletes, as the N.C.A.A. likes to call them.

title: Kim Geun-tae, South Korean Democracy Activist, Dies at 64
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Geun-tae, one of South Koreas best-known pro-democracy activists, whose constant smile belied his mental and physical struggle with the aftermath of torture he suffered from a past military dictators spy agency, died here on Friday. He was 64.

title: Wyden-Ryans Unrealistic Assumptions
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

title: The Peyton Manning Solution for the Jets
description: Six points from around the Web, with an extra point from The Fifth Down:

description: Todays Times:

description: Q.

title: Fresh Start Needed for Schottenheimer and Sanchez
description: The longtime Fifth Down commenter Walt Bennett, a Jets fan from Harrisburg, Pa., weighs in on a Jets offense that is in disarray:

title: When a Fast Fails: Lessons From Gandhi
description: Even Mohandas K. Gandhi, the architect of the Indian obsession with the hunger strike, did not always succeed in his fasts  although success was, admittedly, measured by Mr. Gandhis own standards.

title: Week 17 Matchups: A Playoff Handshake
description: Cowboys (8-7) at Giants (8-7)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Giants by 3

title: Is Lokpal Jinxed, or Was This a Serial Killing?
description: Nine times in the past four decades, a Lokpal bill to create an anti-corruption ombudsman  has been introduced in Indias Parliament, and eight times the bill has died. In its most current incarnation, the bill is in intensive care.

title: Obama and Republicans Seek to Define 2012
description: DES MOINES  The 2012 presidential election, Mitt Romney said on Thursday, could be our last chance to save the United States from Greece-like bankruptcy.

title: Democrats Keep Focus on Romney
description: DES MOINES  If Mitt Romney wins the Iowa caucuses and goes on to eventually snag the Republican nomination, the prize for the best crystal ball may go to none other than the Democratic Party.

title: Medical Aid Group Vows to Stay in Somalia After Fatal Attack
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A day after two of its foreign workers were gunned down by a former colleague, a medical aid group vowed on Friday to continue working in Somalia. The attack was the latest in a series on humanitarian workers and journalists, underscoring the dangers of operating in this war-torn country.

title: Sportcraft Files for Liquidation
description: 10:16 a.m. | Updated

title: Daily Report: The Mark Hurd Saga Continues
description: In Fridays New York Times, Quentin Hardy reported on yet another chapter in the saga of Mark Hurd, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. A Delaware court ruled Wednesday that the letter that led to Mr. Hurds resignation on Aug. 6, 2010, could be made public. The court did not release the letter yet, but the document was obtained by The Times from someone close to the case.

title: Hackers Release More Data From Stratfor
description: 1:41 p.m. | Updated  Adding analysis of the data release.

title: Ukraine Sends Opposition Leader to Remote Prison
description: MOSCOW  The Ukrainian authorities abruptly transferred the jailed opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko to a prison camp about 300 miles east of the capital on Friday, a move that her supporters suspect is intended to cut off her access to the press and the public.

title: For Entrepreneurial Change Agents,  a Green M.B.A.
description: As we noted in a post in August about a new survey, an increasing number of colleges are beginning to offer courses or entire programs devoted to green business practices in response to growing demand.

title: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 30
description: The job of cable TV installer has become an increasingly sophisticated, Amy Chozick writes, as the products offered by cable companies have become more intricate. Many now have backgrounds in engineering and computer science, all the better for installing, and explaining, products like cloud-based cable boxes and iPad apps that let subscribers set recording times remotely.

title: Thousands Rally in Syria to Prove Their Discontent to Arab Monitors
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tens, and possibly hundreds, of thousands of people defied a continuing government crackdown to fill the streets of several Syrian cities on Friday, intent on showing visiting monitors from the Arab League the extent of opposition to President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Former Insider Indicted in Chinese Corruption Scandal
description: BEIJING  A former fugitive accused by the Chinese authorities of being responsible for one of the nations biggest corruption scandals was indicted on Friday after he was said to confess to bribery and smuggling, according to state news organizations.

title: The Best in Travel
For Cunningham Dance Company, Contentment and Finality at Armory
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company is ending its 58-year career this week by looking forward as well as back: time present contains time past and time to come. There were to be six performances of a 50-minute Event at the Park Avenue Armory. I wrote this after the two performances on Thursday; there were two more on Friday, and the last two will be on Saturday.

title: Wall Street Ends Back Where It Started
description: Like a roller coaster returning to the platform, the stock market in the United States ended the last day of trading in 2011 just about where it started the year. But what a wild ride it was in between.

title: Friday Reading: Municipal Cutbacks Leave Residents in the Dark
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: High-Tech Tools, Primeval Wonders
description: Some days ago here, in a rich biodiverse ecosystem off the Costa Rican coast, we had planned to take another step closer to my lifelong dream of fully integrating advanced closed-circuit rebreather technology with a sophisticated submersible to leverage the strengths of each for exploring the coral reef twilight zone  that is, coral-reef habitat at depths of about 200 to 500 feet.

title: What Were Reading
description: Chicago Reader: It seems like the perfect cooking ingredient for the close of a year: ash.  Jeff Gordinier

title: At a Brooklyn Music Store, Resolving to Adapt
description: A cheery holiday card from Tati and Gerry at Ansonia Records rests on the counter of Manny Riveras Brooklyn music store, hidden behind a pile of compact discs, domino sets and assorted tropical knick-knacks. Its a nice, personal touch in a business that has long since lost it.

title: Reports Describe Deadly Clash in Restive China Region
description: BEIJING  Police officers killed seven people they accused of being kidnappers in a remote mountainous area of Xinjiang on Chinas turbulent western frontier, according to state-run news organizations on Friday.

title: 52, and Still Working the Streets
description: LIKE many single mothers, Barbara Terry, 52, scrounged for baby sitters and leaned on her own mother while raising her four children and working the night shift.

title: In Common
description: Lance Cpl. Benjamin Whetstone Schmidt was killed in Afghanistan on Oct. 6. He was a 24-year-old native of San Antonio, a Marine scout sniper and a son of proud parents. Like many others, Corporal Schmidt volunteered for the combat tour that cost him his life because, as he explained to his friends and family, he wanted to go back to protect his fellow Marines.

title: Romney Releases New Ad in New Hampshire
description: Mitt Romney has a new ad in New Hampshire, highlighting a theme that dovetails with the messages of his previous ads by focusing on optimism. The ads counterbalance what has been a negative barrage of advertisements by the Restore Our Future super PAC supporting Mr. Romney. Those ads have been sharply critical of Newt Gingrich and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. Mr. Romney is back in New Hampshire Friday as he tries to maintain a lead in the polls in that state.

title: Australia by Sail, Manning My Own Ship
description: THE Whitsunday Passage was looking rough. The trade winds had picked up around dawn and were whipping 20 knots from the southeast while the ebbing tide carried the water in the opposite direction. The conflict between these two forces of nature had filled the channel with burly 10-foot waves  a sea of bouncers determined to prevent our sailboat from reaching the Whitsunday Islands off the coast of Queensland, Australia.

title: Blue Screen At Dawn
description: OK, not quite at dawn  but I did start my day with the blue screen of death, and a computer that is apparently pining for the fjords.

title: A Classic Cocktail with a Thai Twist
description: Maybe youre not the kind of drinker who leaps to the assumption that a spirit  rye, for instance  can be made even better if the bartender just keeps dumping in more ingredients.

title: A Yen For Yen
description: The FT has an article noting the strength of the yen against the euro, which it attributes to the yens enduring status as a haven against the global financial turmoil. Well, yes  Japan is seen as safe, despite its high level of debt, just like all the other advanced countries that have retained their own currencies.

title: Week 17 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

title: Memorial Service Held for Woman Set Afire in Elevator
description: Deloris Gillespie loved bargains, and when she found a good one  milk at half-price, soap at a discount  she bought in bulk and shared with her friends. She gave gifts to everyone, but would not accept any for herself. And when she shared recipes, ingredients were included.

title: Goodbye to the Gowns, the Glamour and the First Person Plural
description: Does anyone need a gown?

title: 2011: Stories That Changed the Way We Parent Now
description: If theres yet been a year without a full slate of news stories that change the way I think about myself as a parent, it must have predated my time in that role. This year had more to offer in that respect than most of us wanted. Parenting-related topics led Facebooks most-shared list. There were thousands of articles about family published in 2011. You may feel as if you read them all  but how many really changed you?

title: Puddin by Clio Opening in the Village
description: Clio Goodman grew up in a family of serious cooks, so it was only natural that she would try her hand at a culinary career. After graduating from the Culinary Institute of America, she worked at Danny Meyers restaurant group and for Daniel Boulud.

title: Z New York Hotel, Long Island City, N.Y.  Hotel Review
description: UPSHOT

title: When You Root, Root, Root for a Team Thats Not From Home
description: Why do fools fall in love? Great oldie.

title: New Poll Confirms Gingrichs Slide
description: The latest poll of likely participants in the Republican Iowa caucuses confirms Newt Gingrichs slide as Mitt Romney and Representative Ron Paul lead the pack.

title: A Cherubs Classical Vocabulary
description: LONDON

title: Consultants With Their Pants on Fire
description: Culver City, Calif.

title: Working-Class Blues and R&B Royalty
description: Dont change the calendar yet. This Playlist is the last gasp of 2011, a final handful of albums released through the year that almost got away. Almost.

title: 30 Years Later, Revisiting Brideshead
description: REVIEWING Evelyn Waughs Brideshead Revisited in 1946, Edmund Wilson found himself cruelly disappointed. After a promising start, he wrote, Waugh abandoned his usual comic motif for a mere romantic fantasy, shot through with shameless and rampant snobbery and characters both implausible and tiresome.

title: Snapshot
description: METS OR YANKEES?

title: Punch List
description: UNDER CONSTRUCTION

title: Cool Area, Hot Rental, $1,000 Deposit
description: IN one indication of the strength of the New York rental market, a new building in Chelsea abutting the High Line is requiring a $1,000 nonrefundable deposit to reserve an apartment.

title: Dumbo on His Mind
description: WHEN a scruffy young man in a tattered sweater stepped up to the podium at the annual fall lunch of the Brooklyn Real Estate Roundtable, he looked more Silicon Valley entrepreneur than big-city real estate tycoon.

title: This Is How the End Begins
description: THERE are 16 shots in Lars von Triers hauntingly beautiful overture to Melancholia, a movie about love, family and the apocalypse. The movie, among Mr. von Triers greatest, stars Kirsten Dunst as Justine, a young advertising copywriter who, shortly after she gets married endures two separate yet related catastrophes: A wedding party at an oceanside golf resort owned by her brother-in-law ends with her new husband leaving. This in turn brings on the depression that overtakes her and seems to inaugurate the end of the world or her dream of the same. Many of the movies themes are introduced in the first eight minutes, a masterpiece in miniature that is a palimpsest of literary, artistic and cinematic allusions.

title: Liu Xiaobos Plea for the Human Spirit
description: I have no enemies, and no hatred. Liu Xiaobo, the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize winner, spoke those words on Dec. 23, 2009, just before he was sentenced to 11 years in prison for incitement of subversion of state power. It was his fourth jail term since the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989. Liu is the only Chinese citizen to win any Nobel while living in China and, as Perry Link notes in introducing a new collection of Lius writings, one of only five Nobel Peace Prize winners unable to appear in Oslo to receive the gold medal: In 1935, Carl von Ossietzky was held in a Nazi prison; in 1975, Andrei Sakharov was not allowed to leave the Soviet Union; in 1983, Lech Walesa feared he would be barred from re-entering Poland if he went to Oslo; and in 1991, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was under house arrest in Burma.

title: Up Front
description: It might have seemed inevitable that Joyce E. Chaplins interests in science, technology and early American history would lead her to that grand figure of early American science  Benjamin Franklin. But her path to him wasnt inevitable at all. Years ago, when a colleague suggested Franklin as a subject, her reaction, as she describes it in an e-mail message, was: Boring, too obvious. Only after she had written books on agricultural innovation in the 18th and early 19th centuries and on frontier science and technology did she turn to Franklin, who, she is quick to point out, of course isnt boring at all.

title: Read It Again, Sam
description: To the Editor:

title: Buckley
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Upon These Shores
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: THE READER: One of the things Robert K. Massie reveals in his magisterial biography of Catherine the Great, at No. 8 in its sixth week on the hardcover nonfiction list, is that the empress had a voracious appetite for books  especially as an escape from her prosaic husband, Czar Peter III, whose conversation was of a dullness, Massie quotes her saying, that I have never seen equaled. When he left me, the most boring book seemed delightful. Catherine read plenty in Russian, Massie reports, but French was the language she preferred, and she read French books indiscriminately, picking up whatever her ladies-in-waiting happened to be reading. She always kept a book in her room and carried another in her pocket. The empress eventually bought Diderots library for more than 50,000, thus sealing her reputation as a patron of the arts and making the rest of Europe finally take notice of Russia as a cultural center.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE THIRD REICH, by Roberto Bolao. Translated by Natasha Wimmer (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A German vacationing in Spain plays a World War II strategy game with a mysterious burn victim in a novel found among Bolaos papers after his death.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MASTER SWITCH: The Rise and Fall of Information Empires, by Tim Wu (Vintage, $15.95.) This history of modern communications  covering phones, radio, television, movies and, finally, the Internet  is organized around what Wu calls the Cycle: from somebodys hobby to somebodys industry; from jury-rigged contraption to slick production marvel; from a freely accessible channel to one strictly controlled by a single corporation or cartel  from open to closed system.

title: The Dirt About Gossip
description: Most of us scriveners feel obliged to call our books something catchy in the hope of impressing potential readers with how clever we are. Not so Joseph Epstein. Whats your book about? Gossip. Whats it called? Gossip. Epstein has repeatedly opted for titles with the generic ring of labels on the files he must have kept for his research: Ambition, Friendship, Snobbery, Envy. On the part of any other writer, this might be taken as a sign of laziness or exhaustion. But in Epsteins case, it seems a bold grab to own a great big subject, even  or especially  one on which the Almighty has had a tendency to dominate the conversation.

title: Penelope Livelys Anatomy of a Mugging
description: How it begins: The pavement rises up and hits her.

title: Surviving Katrina
description: Job has nothing on 15-year-old Esch. Shes poor and pregnant and plain unlucky. Mamas dead, Daddys a drunk and dinner is Top Ramen every night. Sex is the only thing that has ever come easily to her. When the boys used to take her down in the dirt or in the back seats of stripped cars in her front yard, she could escape briefly, pretend to be Psyche, Eurydice, Daphne, her favorite nymphs and goddesses from the Greek myths. But Manny, the boy who put the baby inside her, wont look at her anymore. Esch cant lie down in the dirt and pretend to be someone else or anywhere else. Shes stuck in shabby Bois Sauvage, a predominantly black Mississippi bayou town in the direct path of a hurricane theyre calling Katrina.

title: Pico Iyers Kinship With Graham Greene
description: Wilson sat on the balcony of the Bedford Hotel with his bald pink knees thrust against the ironwork. Those who love Graham Greene  and their numbers are legion  will recognize this sentence, the first line of his quietly devastating novel The Heart of the Matter, published in 1948.

title: Rosamond Bernier and the Art of Living
description: In the late summer of 1926, when Rosamond Bernier was not quite 10 years old, her father put her on a ship and sent her off to her English boarding school, all by herself. Every evening she changed into a party dress, ate cold smoked tongue and then retired to the smoking room for gambling. I had spectacular luck, Bernier writes in her bonbon of a book, Some of My Lives: A Scrapbook Memoir.

title: The Case of Loving v. Bigotry
description: In 1958, Richard and Mildred Loving were arrested in a nighttime raid in their bedroom. Their crime: being married to each other.

title: The Strange Second Life of a Michigan Factory Town
description: According to the quote from the unelected Mr. Harris about the city finance director he fired: He was smart and articulate, but he just wasnt doing anything that I couldnt do. Is that the new criterion for dissolving democracy? I find this situation very troubling. If a corporation has laudable reasons for establishing a company town, it should do the things that uplift the residents and help them participate in their own stability. It is obvious that what Whirlpool and the current state government were really after was a takeover of the shorefront property for a resort that benefits the wealthy outsiders and edges out the undesirable community who has been gifted the shorefront land. Being poor does not negate protection under the law and does not eliminate any Americans constitutional rights.

title: Pieces of a (Very Young) Man
description: I was not motivated by things that dipped into my mothers finances. I was not on her for this or that; I had what I needed to get by. I managed to hold myself together by hustling. I made deliveries up the hill to old ladies on my bike. In the evening I met the newspaper trucks for the night editions and rolled them back to a corner candy store on Fordham Road and Sedgwick Avenue. Between what I covered with the wagon and peddled up that hill, I kept pocket money that I often doubled by betting on stickball games at the park in the afternoons.

title: The Pakistanis Have a Point
